title: Verboten, a New Dance Club in Williamsburg, Opens
description: Hit any club along Wythe Street in Williamsburg and youre sure to see packs of cigarette-slim Continentals who order water with gas, stay in AirBnb apartments and dance till sunrise. But with Marchs opening of Verboten, a 10,000-square-foot, open-till-6 a.m. dance club with a Teutonic theme and a strong European lean, this newly anointed night life concourse is truly starting to feel like a Little Berlin.

title: F.A.A. Computer Problem Delays Flights in the West
description: A computer failure at an air traffic control center forced the Federal Aviation Administration to hold planes on the ground at Los Angeles International Airport and other airports in the region on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Fans Lose Soccer Team, Then Build Their Own
description: TAMPERE, Finland  When the referees whistle sounded at the end of the first half on Saturday, Juha Kumaras hamstring ached so badly that he took himself out of the game and limped into the stands.

title: New York City Approves 30 Surcharge to Pay for Accessible Taxis
description: The de Blasio administration on Wednesday approved a 30-cent surcharge on all yellow and street-hail livery taxi rides as part of a plan to make half of New Yorks yellow cabs wheelchair accessible by 2020.

title: Senator Urges N.F.L. to Change Name of Redskins
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid of Nevada on Wednesday called on the N.F.L. to change the name of the Washington Redskins, urging the league to respond to charges that the name is offensive by following the example set by the N.B.A. in punishing the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Outrage Across Ideological Spectrum in Europe Over Flawed Lethal Injection in U.S.
description: LONDON  Europeans largely consider the death penalty a particularly brutal American anachronism, but the prolonged death of Clayton D. Lockett in Oklahoma, after a botched execution by lethal injection, produced more than the usual horror on Wednesday.

title: Illinois Republicans Object to Plan to Spend $100 Million to Lure Obama Library
description: CHICAGO  The Democrats, who run this state, regularly fret over Illinoiss financial woes  the unpaid bills, the mortifying credit ratings, the benefits cuts to save one of the nations most underfunded pension systems. But then there is the dream of becoming home to Barack Obamas presidential library, which is, it seems, a whole different matter.

title: Before Ink Dries on Army Rules, Soldiers Rush to Get Tattoos
description: LAKEWOOD, Wash.  An Army soldier walked into Brass Monkey Tattoo last month and told Dan Brewer, the tattoo artist, to go for it.

title: Alibaba Said to Be in Talks to Regain Stake in Alipay
description: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant on the cusp of going public in the United States, is in talks with its Alipay payment affiliate about regaining a stake in the business, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

title: Gerry Adams Questioned Over Murder From 1972
description: LONDON  The president of Sinn Fein, Gerry Adams, was arrested and questioned Wednesday night about the 1972 abduction and murder of a widowed mother of 10, whose body was found on a beach in the Irish Republic in 2003, according to the Sinn Fein website and the police in Northern Ireland.

title: Candidate for President in Egypt Tempers His Expectations
description: CAIRO  Hamdeen Sabahi says he does not really expect a fair race against his opponent for president of Egypt, the former military officer who led the takeover of the elected government.

title: Good-Looking Colt. Nice Story. 5-2 Odds. Whats Not to Like?
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It is hard not to like California Chrome. He has run away with four stakes races by nearly 25 lengths combined. He is a handsome and agile colt with muscles bulging beneath his gleaming chestnut coat and a stride as effortless as a glider skipping on clouds. He has an interesting back story as well.

title: Dylans Handwritten Lyrics to Like a Rolling Stone to Be Auctioned
description: For the giver, who is famously unsentimental about his past, it may have seemed just a sheaf of papers that had outlived their usefulness. For the receiver, a collector of rock memorabilia who met the giver, Bob Dylan, through a non-musical connection, that sheaf was a prized possession for many years. It may soon become his retirement fund.

title: With Security Tight, Iraqis Cast Votes in Unaccustomed Peace
description: BAGHDAD  Millions of Iraqis voted for a new Parliament on Wednesday, defying threats from Islamist extremists, in an election that was carried out, by Iraqs brutal standards, in remarkable peace.

title: State Backs More Cameras to Catch Speeders Near New York Citys Schools
description: State lawmakers agreed on Wednesday to add 120 speed-tracking cameras to New York Citys streets, providing a significant addition to the citys automated enforcement devices as the de Blasio administration seeks to improve traffic safety.

title: A Ghost Town, Going Green
description: NIPTON, Calif.  Gerald Freeman leaned on a walking stick on a dusty hill near the four rows of his solar arrays, talking about it like an apostle on a mission. Down the road are the eucalyptus trees he planted as a potential source of biomass. And not far away, he said, he hopes to install a hydrogen system, another source of renewable fuel.

title: Email Suggests White House Strategy on Benghazi
description: WASHINGTON  A newly released email shows that White House officials sought to shape the way Susan E. Rice, then the ambassador to the United Nations, discussed the Middle East chaos that was the context for the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.

title: Hundreds in Albuquerque Voice Distrust of the Police
description: ALBUQUERQUE  For the third consecutive day Wednesday, Justice Department officials sat in rooms big and small here listening to disgruntled people pour out their frustrations about the Albuquerque Police Department, which was castigated in a Justice Department report in April for systemic and unconstitutional use of excessive force.

title: Job Crushing or Lifesaving?
description: Speaker John Boehner blasts job-crushing regulations. The House majority leader, Eric Cantor, prefers a variant: job-destroying regulations. That mantra has been repeated so much that we might think that all regulations do is crush, destroy, annihilate, maim, gut, crucify and extirpate jobs.

title: State-Sponsored Horror in Oklahoma
description: At 6:36 p.m. on Tuesday in McAlester, Okla., Clayton Lockett started kicking his leg, then twitching, then writhing and moaning in agony, and everyone watching knew something had gone terribly wrong. Mr. Lockett, a convicted murderer, was strapped to a gurney in the death chamber of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary, about to be executed by lethal injection, but the untested combination of a sedative and a paralyzing agent had failed.

title: Famous Faces Cross Over to Online Video
description: THE creators, producers and distributors of online video are cranking up the star power as they seek to woo viewers and advertisers, particularly as they offer digital programming in what is being called the new living room, where people may watch a clip or show on a TV set, a smartphone, a tablet, a desktop or a laptop.

title: The Dark Side of the Sharing Economy
description: Proponents of the sharing economy say websites like Airbnb that make it easy for people to rent a spare bedroom or an apartment on a short-term basis are a boon to cities like New York and San Francisco because they generate income for residents while giving visitors a cheap place to stay. But advocates often ignore or casually dismiss big problems with these short-term rentals, including the fact that they are making housing less affordable in big cities by restricting supply. And in some cases the rentals may be illegal, which is one reason the New York state attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, has begun an investigation.

title: Stronger Action Required on Syria, Aid Chief Warns
description: UNITED NATIONS  When the Security Council passed a legally binding resolution two months ago to provide relief to Syrians trapped behind front lines, Western delegates pledged further steps if the warring parties blocked aid deliveries by United Nations agencies. They specifically warned the Syrian government about its use of barrel bombs, the improvised mix of shrapnel and explosives that aircraft crews have dropped on civilian areas to devastating effect.

title: Director and Deputy of Intelligence Agency Are to Retire by Fall
description: WASHINGTON  The director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn of the Army, and his civilian deputy, David R. Shedd, will retire by early fall, the agency said in an email to its employees on Wednesday.

title: Its Only a Million
description: Its sad what a million dollars has fallen to.

title: For McIlroy, a Sudden Transformation From Prodigy to Role Model
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Two days before his 21st birthday, Rory McIlroy outpaced his elders at Quail Hollow Club to become the youngest winner on the PGA Tour since Tiger Woods. Four years later, McIlroy has gone from big deal to big brother.

title: Man and Woman Killed Her Uncle Then Jumped From Bridge, Police Say
description: SUFFERN, N.Y.  The couple arrived at the George Washington Bridge on Monday morning, traveling in a green Chevrolet Malibu taken from a dead man.

title: Qaeda Affiliates Gain Regional Influence as Central Leadership Fades
description: WASHINGTON  Al Qaedas affiliates in Somalia, Syria, Yemen and West Africa are exerting increasing influence in their regions, posing new challenges for American counterterrorism officials even after a decade of allied attacks that have weakened the groups leadership in Pakistan, according to a State Department report released Wednesday.

title: Jewish Coalition Rejects Lobbying Groups Bid to Join
description: American Jewish leaders on Wednesday voted to deny membership in an influential national coalition to a lobbying group that has at times criticized the Israeli government.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 30, 2014
description: April 30, 2014

title: Not All Health Care Premiums Are Paid Up, House Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON  A House committee said Wednesday that only two-thirds of people signing up for private health insurance in the federal exchange had paid their premiums by April 15. Without payment, consumers will not have coverage.

title: Doctors in the Death Chamber
As New Shipping Rules Are Studied, Another Oil Train Derails
description: In the latest accident involving rail cars carrying crude oil, a CSX train derailed and erupted into black, smoky flames on Wednesday in downtown Lynchburg, Va., forcing scores of people to evacuate and causing a spill in the James River.

title: Mice and Mothers
description: The needle penetrated my latex glove and slipped into the soft skin of my finger. It was quick and painless. I was in the animal lab of Childrens Hospital Los Angeles, buried under Sunset Boulevard. Despite the thousands of mice within, the lab was peaceful. I was alone.

title: Mets and Yankees Have Identical Records, if Not Identical Expectations
description: The Mets and the Yankees arrived at the soggy end of April on Wednesday with identical 15-11 records. Twice in the last decade they have finished the season with the same mark: in 2006, when both made the playoffs, and in 2008, when both missed.

title: Bill Clinton Defends His Economic Legacy
description: Former President Bill Clinton, who has grown increasingly frustrated that his economic policies are viewed as out-of-step with the current focus on income inequality, on Wednesday delivered his most muscular defense of his economic legacy.

title: 2 Law Students Get a Lesson on the First Amendment, Complete With Subpoenas
description: Lets give credit where due: A New York University Law School trustee has devised a terrific First Amendment lesson for students.

title: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
description: WASHINGTON  Is a family with a car in the driveway, a flat-screen television and a computer with an Internet connection poor?

title: Mr. Poe, Over Here! Do Raven
description: I think you folks are in for a real treat, says the guy in the Smokey Bear hat and trim park rangers get-up. With his genial aw-shucks manner, Ranger Steve, played by Jeremy Wilhelm, would seem to make a rather odd narrator for Red-Eye to Havre de Grace, a new musical theater work about the grim last days of Edgar Allan Poe that opened on Wednesday at New York Theater Workshop.

title: Subject of an Eerie Rural Legend
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Ew. Thats not an opinion about Brandon Hensleys debut puzzle; Its an opinion about the legend it highlights.

title: How the Execution Went Wrong
description: What should have happened in the execution of Clayton D. Lockett.

title: From a Playoff Scratch to a Standout for Boston
description: BOSTON  By the time Dougie Hamilton reached high school in St. Catharines, Ontario, he had found his sporting passion. The child of two Canadian Olympians, he tried all sports and excelled in most of them before concentrating on hockey.

title: Few Options for Those Who Missed Health Insurance Deadlines
description: If you dont have health insurance through your employer and havent enrolled through a government insurance exchange, your options for getting coverage this year are dwindling.

title: Protester Says She Doesnt Recall Hitting Officer With Elbow
description: Cecily McMillan, the Occupy Wall Street protester charged with assaulting a New York City police officer, testified on Wednesday that she has no recollection of blackening the officers eye with her elbow. Having watched a video of the episode, though, she does not deny doing it.

title: The Derby Draw
description: Post positions for Saturdays 140th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Scion of Art Family Gets a Year in Prison
description: With a stinging rebuke, a federal judge on Wednesday sentenced Hillel Nahmad, an Upper East Side gallery owner and scion of a powerful art family, to a year in prison on a gambling charge, saying that money could not prevent his incarceration.

title: L.I.R.R. President Is Being Replaced
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that it would remove the longtime president of the Long Island Rail Road, upending the leadership of an agency mired in labor negotiations.

title: Top State Judge Tightens Rules on Debt Collection
description: New York States chief judge announced on Wednesday that he would institute new court rules and protocols that would make it more difficult for debt collection companies to win default judgments and would offer more protection to debtors.

title: Claiming a Copyright on Marx? How Uncomradely
description: The Marxist Internet Archive, a website devoted to radical writers and thinkers, recently received an email: It must take down hundreds of works by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels or face legal consequences.

title: Toronto Mayor Said to Seek Help
description: Citing a problem with alcohol, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto said late Wednesday that he was temporarily stepping aside from his mayoral re-election campaign and seeking professional help. His statement followed the online posting of a still photograph from a video that The Globe and Mail said appeared to show him smoking crack cocaine last weekend. The videos appearance may undermine Mr. Fords hopes of re-election in October.

title: Video Captures Students on Sinking Ferry
description: Cellphone video from one of the passengers aboard the ferry Sewol, Park Su-hyeon, before it capsized. Pictured, the ferry going down on April 16, 2014.

title: Second Man Sentenced for 2011 Murder of High School Basketball Star
description: A second man received a sentence of 25 years to life in state prison for the 2011 murder of a high school basketball star in Harlem, the Manhattan district attorneys office said on Wednesday.

title: The Americans Recap: Eight Things About the Show That Dont Make Sense
description: In Episode 10  three episodes away from the season finale  Philip and Elizabeth face encroaching threats on many fronts. Agent Stan Beeman is getting closer to their operation. He has had an artist rendering of them for some time, but now hes shown it to Jared, the son of their murdered colleagues, Emmett and Leanne. Jared seems to recognize Elizabeth, who recently visited disguised as a social worker.

title: As Pressure Reaches a Peak, So Does Lundqvist
description: Heading into Game 7 against the Philadelphia Flyers on Wednesday, the Rangers had to feel confident with history and Henrik Lundqvist on their side.

title: Nets Exhilarating Rally Ends in Excruciating Fashion
description: TORONTO  Roughly three and half minutes remained in the third quarter here Wednesday when a familiar sound bubbled up in a slow crescendo from the arenas upper tiers. Within seconds, the noise was deafening.

title: Walter R. Walsh Dies at 106; Terrorized Gangsters and Targets
description: Walter R. Walsh, a world-class marksman who shot clothespins off laundry lines as a boy and went on to become an F.B.I. legend in shootouts with gangsters in the 1930s, an Olympic competitor and a trainer of generations of Marine Corps sharpshooters, died on Tuesday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 106.

title: Keenan Takes Home K.H.L. Title
description: Mike Keenan became the first North American coach to win the Kontinental Hockey League championship as Metallurg Magnitogorsk defeated Lev Praha, 7-4, on Wednesday in Game 7 of the finals. With the score tied, 2-2, in the second period, Metallurg scored twice in a minute to pull away from the visiting team from Prague.

title: Corrections: May 1, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Haunting Display of Specimens Large and Small
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Stefanie Zweig, Author Who Fled Nazis to Kenya, Dies at 81
description: Stefanie Zweig, the author of Nowhere in Africa, a best-selling autobiographical novel about the life of a Jewish family in Kenya after their escape from Nazi Germany and the inspiration for an Oscar-winning film, died on Friday in Frankfurt. She was 81.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The 18-Year Rash
description: The Challenge: Can you figure out what can cause a rash that lasts 18 years?

title: Word of the Day | clangor
description: clangor\klaN-r also -gr\ noun

title: India Election Digest: May 1
description: What you need to know on Thursday about Indias elections: A selfie gets the Bharatiya Janata Partys candidate for prime minister into trouble, its tough to pin down the reasons for the high voter turnout, and a village in Uttar Pradesh abstains from the vote out of protest.

title: Times Minute | Minimum Wage Politics
description: Today on the Minute, the minimum wage is at the heart of debate between Democrats and Republicans.

title: Times Minute | Minimum Wage Politics
description: In the Video

title: Envisioning the End of Employer-Provided Health Plans
description: The days of Americans getting health insurance through their employers may be numbered  and the change could be just as profound as the shift of employers forcing employees to manage their own retirement savings.

title: Atlanta Hawks Stress Their System While Leading Their Series
description: ATLANTA  They are the accidental playoff participant, a team whose management has stressed winning its players acceptance of a fresh system more than winning games this season.

title: Al Feldstein, the Soul of Mad Magazine, Dies at 88
description: Al Feldstein, who took over a fledgling humor magazine called Mad in 1956 and made it a popular, profitable and enduring wellspring of American satire, died on Tuesday at his ranch in Paradise Valley, Mont. He was 88.

title: Frank Budd, Once Known as Worlds Fastest Human, Dies at 74
description: Frank Budd, a former Olympic sprinter who for a time was considered the worlds fastest human after he set a record in the 100-yard dash in 1961, died on Tuesday in Marlton, N.J. He was 74.

title: Hunger Striker Ends Fast, but Not Fight, Against Nuclear Power in Taiwan
description: A former head of Taiwans Democratic Progressive Party has announced that he is ending his hunger strike, but not his campaign, against nuclear power on the island.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) IHEARTRADIO MUSIC AWARDS More than 13.2 million votes were cast by iHeartRadio listeners to determine favorite artists and songs in this first-time awards ceremony, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Nominees include Imagine Dragons (above), Justin Timberlake, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, Maroon 5 and Rihanna for artist of the year; Florida Georgia Line, Icona Pop, Imagine Dragons, Lorde, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, and Passenger for best new artist; and, in the most voted-on category, Holy Grail and Suit & Tie, both by Jay Z and Mr. Timberlake; Stay, by Rihanna and Mikky Ekko; The Monster, by Eminem and Rihanna; and Timber, by Pitbull and Kesha, for best collaboration. Blake Shelton, Drake, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell Williams, Pitbull, Shakira, Thirty Seconds to Mars, Luke Bryan, Arcade Fire, Ed Sheeran and Ariana Grande will perform at the auditorium and in locations around Los Angeles, including the Roxy and the Hotel Cafe. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on E!

title: Caught Again on Camera, Rob Ford Leaves for Treatment
description: TORONTO   Rob Ford, Torontos troubled mayor who acquired international notoriety for his drug use and a seeming inability to experience shame, quietly took a break from public life on Thursday.

title: A Former Chief Minister Turns on the Heat in Amritsar
description: This is the second of a two-part series on the crucial parliamentary race in Amritsar, India. You can read the first part, a profile on Arun Jaitley of the Bharatiya Janata Party, here.

title: At Least One Killed as Blasts Hit Indian Train Station
description: NEW DELHI  Two small explosions tore through an express train at Chennais central railway station on Thursday, killing one woman and injuring more than a dozen bystanders, some of them critically.

title: Profit Drops at Lloyds Bank, but Outlook Improves
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that its first-quarter profit declined 24.7 percent, but that its outlook continued to improve as it cut costs and avoided additional charges for legacy problems.

title: Putin Demands That Ukraine Pull Its Troops From Southeast
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday that Ukraine must remove its military from the southeastern region of the country to resolve the showdown there with pro-Russian militants who have seized several official buildings, the Kremlin said.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 1, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: After Obama Visit, Planned Naval Drills With Russia Reported
description: China and Russia will soon hold joint naval exercises near islands disputed by Beijing and Tokyo in the East China Sea, the Jinghua Times newspaper reported on Thursday, quoting Chinas Ministry of National Defense.

title: Online, a Censored Reaction to Urumqi Bombing
description: With May 1 a national holiday in China, and censorship heavy, reaction to the deadly bomb and knife attack late Wednesday at a train station in Urumqi, in the western region of Xinjiang, appeared slow to take off.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Suddenly Everyone, It Seems, Wants to Buy the Clippers
description: In Suddenly Everyone, It Seems, Wants to Buy the Clippers, Billy Witz and Mary Pilon write about how the Los Angeles Clippers franchise suddenly finds itself the toast of Los Angeles and a coveted commodity in professional sports.

title: On the Brink in Brownsville
description: In a typical game of skelly, two children flick homemade plastic pucks into numbered squares drawn on the asphalt. Its a quaint and simple contest  a mix between shooting marbles and playing shuffleboard  that New Yorkers have played for generations. On warm days in Brownsville, Brooklyn, when there is no school, teenage boys pour out of the housing projects to play. Its a curious thing to see, boys their age, with the freedom to roam, so captivated by this elementary pastime. But there they sit, with new tattoos on their arms and new hair on their faces, channeling their energy into their fingers and thumbs.

title: No Choice but to Protest and Take Pictures
description: Although he made a career photographing protests in the 1960s, Benedict J. Fernandez was a young man without a cause growing up in East Harlem in the 1950s.

title: Turkish Protesters Defy Governments May Day Ban
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Istanbul on Thursday in May Day rallies, confronting riot police officers to protest a government mired in a corruption scandal and accused of imposing a creeping authoritarianism in Turkey.

title: What Movies Do You Watch, or Reference, Over and Over?
description: Mean Girls turns 10 this week, but, according to a recent Times article, its still a go-to source of shorthand for female  and human  dynamics because young women everywhere continue to quote the lines and create memes around it.

title: Its PC Sales Tailing Off, Sony Now Expects Loss
description: Sony slashed its profit outlook for the third time in a year on Thursday, putting increased pressure on its chief executive, Kazuo Hirai, to show he can still engineer a turnaround.

title: New York Today: Waterlogged
description: Good morning on this sodden Thursday.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Photos: Theres Always the Kentucky Derby, in Good Times and Bad
description: Horse racings fortunes have taken turns soaring and ebbing in the 140 years that the Kentucky Derby has been its crown jewel, and with the current state of the sport ranging somewhere from lagging to collapsing, depending on your point of view, it is tempting to look backward longingly.

title: A West Virginia Democrat Battles Extinction
description: It was a vote intended to split along party lines; instead, it revealed just how worried some House Democrats are about re-election.

title: BG Aims to Speed Up Deals to Bring Its Riches to Market
description: LONDON  The British oil and gas company BG Group said on Thursday that it would most likely accelerate the pace of deal-making to raise money and help develop its rich holdings in countries like Brazil and Australia.

title: Chinas Leader Warns of Long-Term Terror Fight After Blast
description: HONG KONG  President Xi Jinping of China said the government must prepare itself for a long-term fight against what he called separatist forces in the countrys restive Xinjiang region after assailants with knives and a bomb killed one person and injured at least 79 on Wednesday evening at a railway station in Urumqi, the regional capital.

title: How Not to Be Misled by the Jobs Report
description: We obsess far too much on the Labor Departments monthly jobs report.

title: Daily Report: Facebook to Enhance Privacy Controls
description: Trying to become even bigger  and make more money  Facebook will allow users to reveal a little less, Vindu Goel reports.

title: Covering the Greatest Two Minutes in Sports
description: Joe Drape learned about horse racing from his father, who taught him to read the Daily Racing Form as a child.

title: Sex Abuse and China's Children
description: BEIJING  When I was 13, living in the outskirts of Nanjing, China, in the 70s, my math teacher molested all the girls in our class, including me. Under the pretense of checking my work, he would lean over me, his face so close that I could smell his garlic breath, and hed move his hand up my shirt, touching my chest.

title: Britain Bars Former UBS Senior Trader From Financial Industry
description: LONDON  Britains Financial Conduct Authority on Thursday barred John Christopher Hughes, a former senior trader at UBS, from working in the financial industry, but did not fine him for failing to report a slush fund of money used to help manage his desks daily profit and losses.

title: Snapchat Goes After Mobile Messaging With a New Design
description: The last few years have been a roller coaster for Snapchat, the ephemeral photo-messaging service. Since it started in 2011, the company has made headlines for turning down billions from potential buyers and luring heavyweight talent from Facebook, Google and Amazon, facing criticism over gaping security vulnerabilities, and finding itself in a legal battle over ownership of the companys original concept.

title: The Dresses of Charles James
description: A forthcoming show at the Mets new Anna Wintour Costume Center analyzes Jamess sculptural designs.

title: No Choice but to Protest and Take Pictures
description: A retrospective of Ben Fernandezs images of the 1960s reveals a man who not only documented protests, but also educated a generation to follow his lead.

title: A Stroll Through Kips Bay
description: Finally, the Kips Bay show house gets the showplace it deserves.

title: In Korea, Grieving Over Hundreds of Young Lives
description: Ansan has been suffocating in grief since a ferry disaster left 250 students dead.

title: Derby Day
description: For the 140th straight year, Churchill Downs in Louisville will stage the Kentucky Derby, where the first Saturday in May retains a timeless feel.

title: In Our Pages: May 2
description: 1914: British Resorts Advocated

title: Lazards Earnings More Than Double on Jump in M.&A. Activity
description: The strong burst of deal-making this year has been good to Lazard.

title: Hey, Evildoers, Heres Webbing in Your Eye
description: The last time Spider-Man swung into sight, it was to fight a lizard man in a lab coat and cozy up to a living doll. The lizard landed in the clink, but the doll, Gwen Stacy, is back for the good of Spider-Man (Andrew Garfield) and the franchise. As played by Emma Stone, who has the zing of a screwball heroine and the depthless eyes of an anime character, Gwen brightens The Amazing Spider-Man 2, a sequel that, until a late, lamentably foolish turn, balances blockbuster bombast with human-scale drama, child-friendly comedy and gushers of tears.

title: A Dinner Among Survivors of the Financial Crisis
description: Call it the financial crisis survivors club.

title: Awaiting Alibabas I.P.O.
description: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant that is about to go public in the United States, is said to be in talks with its Alipay payment affiliate about regaining a stake in the business, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The two sides have been in talks for nearly a year and a half, and no agreement is imminent. In any case, the possibility that Alibaba could be formally reunited with its payment division would be of great interest to the companys future shareholders.

title: A Royal Rejection
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pentagon Study Finds 50% Increase in Reports of Military Sexual Assaults
description: WASHINGTON  A Pentagon study released Thursday showed a sharp increase last year in reports of rapes and sexual assault  they were up by 50 percent  but the study immediately came under fire for what critics said were significant limitations.

title: In Golf Digests Bid for Younger Readers, Its Less Faldo, More Fallon
description: Golf Digest was founded in 1950 and soon became an authoritative voice of the game, swept along by Americans migration to suburbia and the popularity of transformative golf figures from Arnold Palmer to Tiger Woods. The magazine flourished, as golf did, on the backs of a devoted cluster of baby boomers.

title: Listen Up | Winsome Rock Hits Wisconsin
description: In the sleepy college town of Eau Claire, Wis., a folk hero has emerged in Justin Vernon (above center)  the bearded, pleasantly helium-voiced singer-songwriter who, in 2007, retreated to a cabin in the woods to record songs under the name Bon Iver. The resulting album, For Emma, Forever Ago, earned Vernon widespread acclaim, but instead of taking his newfound fame elsewhere, he set up April Base Studios, which has served as an incubator for the states emerging indie music scene. That includes Bon Ivers drummer, S. Carey (above left), whose gorgeous sophomore album, Range of Light, was released last month; the Milwaukee-based folk outfit Field Report, led by the singer-songwriter Chris Porterfield (above right); and Phox, a six-piece indie pop group from Baraboo, Wis., whose self-titled debut is out next month. Despite a growing profile and their home states reputation as a harbinger of hipster culture (see: Pabst Blue Ribbon, artisanal cheese, taxidermy), the musicians insist that what makes them distinctly Wisconsin is their obliviousness to being cool. A lot of us were in the marching band, Phox frontwoman Monica Martin says. Its sort of a rite of passage.

title: Explosion at Florida Jail Kills 2 Inmates
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.,  One day after nearly two feet of rain swamped Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle, causing severe flooding, a gas explosion ripped through a local jail late Wednesday night, killing two inmates and injuring about 150 inmates and corrections officers.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Short-Changing Canadas Veterans
description: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

title: A Complete U-Turn
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  One of the first questions asked of Alan R. Mulally when he joined Ford Motor as its new chief executive in 2006 was what kind of car he drove.

title: Washington, D.C., the Most-est Place in the Country
description: The nations capital: Its the richest, gayest, most educated, most expensive and most economically optimistic place in America.

title: How to Make New York Cheaper for Travelers
description: Search for a room in New York City on Hotels.com and most of the top results will be for rooms that cost more than $300 a night. Go over to Airbnb.com, and you will find many options under $200 a night and some in Queens and Brooklyn for less than $100.

title: Diane Keaton: By the Book
description: The actress and author of Lets Just Say It Wasnt Pretty describes listening to Patti Smiths audiobook of Just Kids as a revelation  What is it about her voice? The way she uses her words and makes them sing?

title: Loved the Book. Felt the Character.
description: LAS VEGAS  Back in 1999, Shailene Woodley and her mother, Lori, could be found in a tiny dressing room trailer on the set of Replacing Dad, the television movie in which Ms. Woodley had her first speaking role. If the pair were hoping to pass themselves off as anything but novices, they failed miserably, especially when it came to availing themselves of the lunch provided by the production.

title: One Womans Wish List Against Street Harassment
description: Sometimes Valerie Granzo ignores the comments about her appearance that strangers yell to her on the streets of New York City. Sometimes she yells back.

title: Eight Tips for Parents Who Have Saved Nothing for College
description: A couple of days ago, a post here by a mother in Maine lamenting her lack of savings for her sons college education inspired an outpouring of comments. A number of people questioned her and her husbands decision to raise six children. Others thought she might have been better off putting money aside years ago instead of paying for music lessons and sports.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Links to Slides
description: Wrapped up the class yesterday. Here, in one place, are links to the lecture slides (all pdfs). If youre wondering about lecture 3, it was snowed out, and the material folded into other classes.

title: Florida Advances Tuition Aid for Children Brought to U.S. Illegally
description: MIAMI  After weeks of hand-wringing in the State Legislature and last-minute attempts by Senate leaders to scuttle the effort, the Florida Senate on Thursday voted to make students who were brought to the United States illegally as children eligible for in-state college tuition, an issue dominated by political calculations at least as much as policy ones.

title: Mark Josephson of Bitly, on Leading With a Compass
description: This interview with Mark Josephson, chief executive of Bitly, the web link shortening service, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Coffee Tied to Lower Diabetes Risk
description: Drinking more coffee may decrease your risk of Type 2 diabetes, while cutting down may increase your risk, a new study has found.

title: Television Revenue Helps Profit at Viacom to Rise 4%
description: Viacom, the media powerhouse that includes the movie studio Paramount and cable television channels like MTV, Comedy Central and Nickelodeon, generated $502 million in profit for its latest fiscal quarter, driven by increased advertising and higher affiliate fees for its television outlets, the company reported on Thursday.

title: Art Matters | A Decommissioned Catholic Church in Berlin is Reborn as a Hub of Creativity
description: To the 32-year-old German gallerist Johann Knig, art is religion.His father, Kasper, is one of the most respected curators in Europe; his mother, Ilke, and uncle, Walter, are leaders in art-book publishing and his older half-brother, Leo, is a noted Manhattan art dealer.And so, when several years ago, the architect Arno Brandlhuber approached Knig with the idea of leasing a decommissioned Catholic church called St. Agnes  a striking example of Brutalist architecture in the Berlin neighborhood of Kreuzberg  Knig signed a nearly century-long lease, despite the fact that the building (which included a nursery school, offices and a courtyard along with the church itself) was too big for his gallery alone.

title: Poetry Pairing | Sweeping the States
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Sweeping the States by Jacob Saenz and the article Drought Takes Its Toll on a Texas Business and a Town by Manny Fernandez.

title: Whos Frequenting the Tattoo Parlor
description: The United States Army has changed its rules and now restricts tattoos above the neckline and below the elbows and knees. Luckily for many members of the military, tattoos in these visible places are grandfathered in. Current and former members of the military are among the most tattooed members of American society, with 36 percent having at least one, according to a recent Fox News poll. That tattoo rate exceeds the rate for liberals (26 percent), conservatives (18 percent) and nonveterans (18 percent).

title: S&P Capital IQ Report
description: A report from S&P Capital IQ projects that by 2020, about 90 percent of American workers who now receive health insurance through their employers will be shifted to government exchanges.

title: Excerpt: Hill Street Blues
description: James B. Sikking in a scene from the influential police drama.

title: Excerpt: Hill Street Blues
description: Charles Haid and Michael Warren in a scene from the influential police drama.

title: Excerpt: Hill Street Blues
description: Bruce Weitz in a scene from the influential police drama.

title: Spring Has Sprung
description: TIMES INSIDER  Welcome to the May 2014 Times Premier Puzzle Pack. This month, were celebrating the arrival of spring.

title: Can You Afford Your Medicine? Doctors Dont Ask
description: From the doorway, my patient looked pregnant  but his protuberant belly was actually a sign of serious liver disease that had quickly worsened. Given the fluid pressing on his abdomen, he was no doubt in pain. Yet his spirits were high, and raucous laughter often accompanied his nearly toothless smile.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Belle
description: The director Amma Asante narrates a sequence from her film.

title: 17-Minute Delay Found in Reporting Missing Plane
description: HONG KONG  Seventeen minutes passed after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared from civilian radar screens before air traffic controllers in Vietnam and Malaysia raised any concerns about it, according to a Malaysian government report released on Thursday that described confusion and miscommunication in the hours that followed.

title: Times Minute | Brutal Weather Hits U.S.
description: Scenes from a storm system that has killed at least 38 and spanned from Florida to Connecticut.

title: Times Minute | Brutal Weather Hits U.S.
description: In the Video

title: Letters: Plato at the Googleplex
description: Plato at the Googleplex

title: South Sudan May Receive Peacekeepers From Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  With violence escalating in South Sudan, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that African troops could soon be sent to the strife-ridden country to augment the United Nations peacekeeping effort.

title: Lonely Writers in the Movies
description: In this weeks Bookends, Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss why its so difficult to capture a writers life on film. If the movies have a hard time with the act of writing, they do better with the stark isolation the craft can demand.

title: Cadillac Recalls 51,000 SRX Crossovers for Acceleration Problem
description: General Motors is recalling almost 51,000 Cadillac SRX crossovers from the 2013 model year because the powertrain might balk when the driver wants to accelerate, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted Thursday on the agencys website.

title: Connecticut Allows Medical Marijuana, but Sellers Encounter Hurdles
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  This states law approving the sale of marijuana for medical purposes has been on the books for two years, but the drug is still not available.

title: Chvrches and Titus Andronicus Among Highlights of Northside Festival
description: The Northside Festival, a Brooklyn showcase devoted mostly to indie bands  but with films and panels on innovation and a trade show as well  has quickly become a northeastern version of South by Southwest. Northsides founders, Scott and Daniel Stedman, have described its mission simply as to showcase whats next, and this year, the festivals sixth, that will include performances by 400 bands, along with 50 films and 100 speakers in its Northside Innovation series. The festival runs from June 12 to 19.

title: May Day Protests in Turkey
description: In Istanbul, the police fired tear gas and used water cannons to disperse May Day protesters, some of whom fired back their own tear gas canisters.

title: Dennis Kamakahi, 61, Hawaiian Guitarist and Composer, Dies
description: Dennis Kamakahi, a prolific Hawaiian songwriter, an influential slack-key guitarist and a central figure in the 1970s cultural movement known as the Hawaiian renaissance, died on April 28 in Honolulu. He was 61.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Belle
description: In this video, the director Amma Asante narrates a sequence from her period film Belle, featuring Gugu Mbatha-Raw. The movie explores the life of Dido Elizabeth Belle, an 18th-century black woman raised in an aristocratic family who may have helped influence the British debate over ending slavery.

title: Disney Keeps Focus on Star Wars With a New Line of Apps
description: LOS ANGELES  Disneys steady trickle of Star Wars announcements continued on Thursday as the company and its Lucasfilm unit unveiled a line of at least six apps aimed at helping younger moviegoers catch up with the story line ahead of the 2015 release of Star Wars: Episode VII.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 42
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Teacher Accord Gives City a Map for Other Deals
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, confronting the unsettled labor agreements that have loomed over his first months in office, announced a deal on Thursday with New York Citys largest teachers union that would raise wages by 18 percent over nine years in exchange for a $1.3 billion reduction in health care costs.

title: California Fines Ford $3 Million Over Defective Pollution Control Equipment
description: Ford is being fined $2.96 million because the pollution control system on 2011-12 Fiestas sold in California are not working properly, the states Air Resources Board said late Wednesday.

title: On Beauty | Talking Blues
description: Favored by 4-year-olds, misfits and drag queens, wearing cobalt eye shadow means forsaking good taste for a welcome jolt of indiscretion.

title: Today in Small Business: $100 Billion in Lending
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: 55 Colleges Named in Federal Inquiry Into Handling of Sexual Assault Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday released the names of 55 colleges and universities under investigation for their handling of sexual assault complaints, an unusual step meant to increase pressure on the institutions to crack down on the problem on their campuses.

title: Acting Like an Ape
description: Actors from Dawn of the Planet of the Apes receive ape-like movement training near the film set in New Orleans.

title: Exxon Mobil Profit Falls for a Fourth Straight Quarter
description: HOUSTON  For the fourth quarter in a row, Exxon Mobil on Thursday reported lower year-over-year profit because of falling production volumes and disappointing earnings from its international refining and chemicals businesses.

title: A New Way to Stir Up Benghazi Anger
description: A member of Congress plans to introduce a measure that would at long last amend the Authorization for the Use of Military Force, passed after the 9/11 attacks and warped over time to excuse all manner of executive overreach, including electronic surveillance without a warrant.

title: K.K.R. Seeks to Attract Investments as Small as $10,000
description: Updated, 8:00 p.m. | Only the wealthiest and most sophisticated investors are allowed to put money into the leveraged buyouts done by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. But that may be changing.

title: Auditing Ape School
description: We started with the breathing: low, deep, yogalike. Our eyes closed, our bellies unflexed.

title: The Posture, the Gestures, the Thoughts
description: NEW ORLEANS  The actress Judy Greer was trying to find her animal self. She stood in an awkward crouch, pelvis pitched forward, arms aloft. No desire to be tall at all, Terry Notary, a stocky former gymnast, instructed her. Your power comes from rooting yourself down.

title: Image of the Day: May 1
A Mother on Her Deathbed, Tape On
description: When Monique Sindler was dying in her bed in Paris in 2006, Sophie Calle, her daughter and the renowned French conceptual artist, set up a video camera and began taping. The artist, 60, has explained that her reason for the camera was that she didnt want to be out of the room when the moment of death came. She wanted to hear her mothers last word and see her last breath, but she had heard that the dying often wait until nobody is around to let go.

title: Being Careful Out There? Hardly
description: Cop shows had never looked like this.

title: Lawrence Lessig Starts a Super PAC
description: Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard law school professor who has long opposed big money in politics, wants to start a super PAC to end all super PACs.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Scrutinizes Branch Over Honor for Clippers Owner
description: When the racist words of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling spilled out in a recording last week, the incident not only caused the N.B.A. to ban Mr. Sterling for life, it also drew attention to the N.A.A.C.P.s small Los Angeles branch, which had been planning to honor him with a lifetime achievement award this month.

title: Kids Need More Structured Playtime, Not Less
description: The cover story of last months Atlantic magazine struck a nerve with many parents. Written by Hanna Rosin, an Atlantic national correspondent, and titled, The Overprotected Kid, it describes a generation of children who have experienced hardly an unsupervised or unstructured moment in their lives. Looking for an alternative to Americas risk-averse culture of child rearing, the author takes her 5-year-old son, Gabriel, on a trip to North Wales, where an adventure playground called the Land opened two years ago.

title: The Artistry of Plants and Pots
description: Mutant cacti in pots with unconventional, often imperfect, glazes. Sounds strange? Strangely beautiful is more like it. A Tale of Plant & Pot  an exhibition on view at the Venice, Calif., design shop Chariots on Fire  pairs the plant artistry of Kohei Oda with the ceramics of Adam Silverman. The 36-year-old Oda owns Qusamura, an award-winning plant shop in Hiroshima, Japan, and hes like a rock star in the horticulture world. His specialty is the grafted cactus, the art and science of connecting two pieces of living plant tissue together to grow as one composite plant. He is drawn to, as he says, plants with personality, and using grafting techniques to salvage damaged plants and to create new, and often unexpected, forms.

title: Audio From Malaysian Flight 370
description: Audio recording of the conversations between the cockpit of Flight 370 and Kuala Lumpur air traffic control.

title: U.S. Will Host Expanded Copa Amrica in 2016
description: The Copa Amrica, South Americas soccer championship, will play its centennial tournament in the United States in 2016 and include six teams from North America, Central America and the Caribbean, officials from those two regional confederations announced Thursday.

title: Suicide Attack Kills 12 in Afghanistans Panjshir Valley
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide car bombing killed at least 12 people, including at least five security force members, in Panjshir Province on Thursday, in an attack that struck at the symbolic heart of resistance to the Talibans rule and the Soviet occupation.

title: Searching for Yield, at Almost Any Price
description: When buyers demand something, the supply will be created.

title: Sinn Fein Braces for Fallout After Arrest
description: DUBLIN  When Gerry Adams became president of Sinn Fein more than three decades ago, the party was regarded as an irrelevant apologist for Irish Republican Army atrocities. Now, it shares power in Northern Irelands Parliament, and in the Republic of Ireland it is riding high in the polls ahead of local and European elections this month.

title: Nasty Rivalries Spice Playoffs Second Round
description: As in the first round, the conference semifinals of the N.H.L. playoffs feature intense rivalries, some with long postseason histories and some starting fresh.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an e-mail. Sign up

title: Theories on Why Housing Is Stalled
description: Last week, we explored the fact that housing remains one of the major weak spots in the economy, with building activity far below its longer-term averages. Economic commentators around the Web had a range of reactions; here are some of the more interesting ones and a few thoughts on the critiques of our article.

title: A Late Rush to Sign Up for Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The number of people signing up for health insurance through the federal marketplace soared in March, exceeding the number who signed up in the previous five months, the Obama administration said Thursday in its final report on enrollment under the new health care law.

title: In Paris, Showcasing Films About Dance
description: Cinephiles passing through Paris often have the Cinmathque Franaise on their list of musts.

title: Thriving on a Dash of Audacity
description: On a warm night, the door to Dotory is propped open under the J, M and Z tracks, and cold glasses of barley tea, tasting like toasted water, are handed round. There is soju, too, steeped with dill and cucumber, cleaner than vodka and deadly, poured into cups so small that the mildest of gestures sends them flying. Jazz piano rustles from the speakers, and then the train crashes by and we all quake awhile.

title: Tributes and Mourning on Social Media as an Egyptian Voice Goes Silent
description: Last Updated, 6:51 p.m. | In the time he spent chronicling events in Egypt since the 2011 uprising, Bassem Sabry gained a reputation as a prescient and astute commentator on the transformation and turmoil of his countrys political scene.

title: California Analysis Pours Cold Water on Expanded TV and Film Subsidies
description: LOS ANGELES  The California legislative analysts office on Wednesday offered what it called preliminary observations on the push for expanded film and television subsidies in the state  and its that initial advice was to proceed with a great deal of caution.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: walkings benefits, nail salon risks and a new vaccine. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Art Matters | A Powerhouse L.A. Gallery Heads East
description: While it seems like a foregone conclusion that many of New Yorks most successful contemporary art galleries will join the ranks of those that maintain outposts in Los Angeles  like Gagosian (whose empire began in L.A. in 1979) and Matthew Marks (whose West Hollywood space opened in 2012)  perhaps it comes as a surprise that a bit of reverse migration is now also taking place, with some of best of the west heading east. Today Blum & Poe, one of L.A.s top art galleries  it anchors the strip that snakes along La Cienega Boulevard through Culver City  opens its new exhibition space in a renovated townhouse at 19 East 66th Street, off Fifth Avenue.

title: Do Statins Change Our Eating Habits?
description: Are statins giving people license to eat? A 12-year study has found that people who use statins gradually increase their consumption of fat and calories.

title: Our Fifth Annual New York Times Summer Reading Contest
description: Update | Sept. 2: This contest has ended, but you can find all of this summers winners here

title: The Gun Report: May 1, 2014
description: Is trespassing a capital offense? No, the German government says, and it wants justice for one of its citizens, who was shot and killed in Montana on Sunday.

title: Baseball Shakes Up Its Investigative Unit
description: In the wake of the Alex Rodriguez doping case, which drew accusations of unethical behavior by Major League Baseballs top investigators, the league has fired some members of its investigative team and moved to restructure the unit.

title: A Timely Call for Bike Trails
description: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Udall Urges More Bicycle Paths appeared on page 29 on May 2 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Queens New Music Festival to Offer Eclectic Works
description: Move over Brooklyn, Queens is staking its claim for new-music street cred. Random Access Music, a composers collective founded in 2006, is presenting eight concerts of new and recent works in three days this month, under the banner of the Queens New Music Festival at the Secret Theater in Long Island City.

title: Pfizer Looks for a Quick Strike on AstraZeneca
description: Time often benefits bidders rather than targets thats why Kraft left its British rival Cadbury flailing for months after making a takeover approach. But the dynamics of Pfizers interest in AstraZeneca are unusual. Pfizer has good reason to seek a quick negotiated deal.

title: Nan Rosenthal, Curator Who Championed Modern Art, Dies at 76
description: Nan Rosenthal, a curator who helped bring the 20th century to the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: 36 Hours in Zanzibar, Tanzania
description: The name Zanzibar conjures up visions of sultans palaces, paradisiacal beaches and winding alleyways leading to spice-filled bazaars. Indeed, this coral archipelago in the Indian Ocean, 23 miles off the eastern coast of Tanzania, still has many of the features that it did when it was an important trading center and its historic Stone Town served as the capital of an Omani sultanate. Zanzibars largest island, Unguja, is home to most of the cultural attractions, many of them found in beguiling Stone Town, which was awarded Unesco World Heritage status in 2000. In recent years, theres been a concerted effort to restore and give new life to the citys distinctive structures. Palaces have been turned into museums and cultural centers, and grand Swahili mansions have been reborn as restaurants and boutique hotels. Yet the coast still offers the delicious view that the explorer Sir Richard Burton recorded, of a cocoa-fringed shore of purest white, and the sea blue as a slab of lapis lazuli. (Note: Prices in Zanzibar are routinely quoted in dollars  alongside, or occasionally instead of, the islands official currency, the Tanzanian shilling.)

title: Walking Tours in the Spirit of Jane Jacobs
description: Jane Jacobss 1961 book, The Death and Life of Great American Cities, a sweeping critique of the modern metropolis, was both a best seller and quite contentious. What set Jacobs apart from many of her critics, including her archnemesis Robert Moses, was that as lofty as her ideas and prose could be, they sprang from, and remained rooted in, the street. So its easy to imagine her feeling honored to have inspired Janes Walk, an annual series of free guided walking tours across all five boroughs, organized by the Municipal Art Society of New York.

title: Hangups of the Heterodox (Vaguely Wonkish)
description: Thomas Palley and Simon Wren-Lewis have been having a back and forth over heterodox economics versus garden-variety saltwater economics, and their role in making sense of the economic crisis. Palley accuses Wren-Lewis and me of flimflam; Wren-Lewis wonders what hes talking about.

title: Yankees Attendance and Ratings Rebound, but the Mets Are Mixed
description: The Yankees, built on winning and the star system, are benefiting from the return of Derek Jeter and the addition of Masahiro Tanaka and Jacoby Ellsbury.

title: Eurocentric Beauty Ideals in the Military
description: People of African descent have been tyrannized for centuries by a Eurocentric aesthetic that deems light skin and straight hair beautiful and that casts dark skin, African features and kinky hair as undesirable, if not ugly. This bias is less potent than it was, say, 50 years ago. (Movies, advertisements and prime-time television clearly show that.) But it still weighs heavily in judgments about what is beautiful and what is not; it also limits the opportunities of people whose appearances place them far from the Eurocentric ideal.

title: Wheelies: The Police Truck Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Revisiting Familial Territory
description: The past seems to haunt the writer-director Diane Kurys  and to tempt her to reimagine events, testing out versions of her parents and stretching their emotional contours by placing them in different dramatic situations.

title: Unto the Next Generation, Cinematically
description: By most counts, Gia Coppola  whose first film, Palo Alto, opens May 9  is the fourth generation in her famous Hollywood family to enter the world of film.

title: The Mysterious Adventure of the Good Nights Sleep
description: The protagonist of Altered States of Plaine suffers from an affliction that causes him to teleport to unexpected places. The condition also apparently affects the movie, which has somehow appeared in a commercial theater, despite betraying few signs of visual, aural or narrative control.

title: From Childhood to a Soccer Career, Much Has Stayed the Same
description: I often write about change  the constant fluctuations in my thought process and reinvention of myself as a person and a soccer player. My environment and situation are constantly in flux. This year in the National Womens Soccer League is no different.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, Cuba and Italy.

title: Donald Sterling and the Inequality Debate
description: Turning from the controversies of Roman Catholicism back to the ongoing inequality conversation, I highly recommend this post from Reihan Salamon Donald Sterling, the disgraced owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, and the interesting ways that Sterlings career as a Southern Californian slumlord is entangled both with the phenomenon of petits rentiers (Thomas Pikettys term for the capital-accumulating mass upper class) and with Americas ongoing debates (which Pikettys Capital seems to havegotten a bit wrong) over whether and how high to raise the minimum wage.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, Cuba and Italy.

title: The Best Way to Organize Bookshelves?
description: In the magazines most recent Riff,Mireille Silcoff notes that although e-books are outselling their physical counterparts on Amazon, the latter still remain objects of desire for the average consumer  just not for the reasons you might think.

title: F. Scott Fitzgerald, Uncut, in a New Edition of Short Stories
description: When Taps at Reveille was published in 1935, it marked the end of F. Scott Fitzgeralds career as a short-story writer. It was his fourth collection and his last. Now, it turns out, a lot of the words were missing, excised by editors at The Saturday Evening Post, where all 18 stories in the collection first appeared.

title: A Life Story of Glitter and Tragedy
description: If Jobriath, a would-be star of glam-rock during the genres 1970s heyday, is recalled at all, its because of his monster billboard, which loomed over Times Square despite a debut album that failed to sell.

title: Call for Limits on Web Data of Customers
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, hoping to move the national debate over privacy beyond the National Security Agencys surveillance activities to the practices of companies like Google and Facebook, released a long-anticipated report on Thursday that recommends developing government limits on how private companies make use of the torrent of information they gather from their customers online.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Power Outage
description: Is there a company on earth that has been more thoroughly examined at ponderous length than Apple? There are books about its early years, books about Steve Jobss ouster from the company in 1985, and books about his triumphant return in 1997. Recently there was a book dissecting Apples internal culture; another profiling its design wiz, Jonathan Ive; and a third charting Apples tempestuous relationship with Google. All these volumes now orbit around Walter Isaacsons Steve Jobs, the definitive chronicle, considering the imperious co-founder himself opened the door to his secretive empire as he battled pancreatic cancer.

title: American Architect
description: Lynne Cheney, a historian and the wife of former Vice President Dick Cheney, believes it is time to clear away misconceptions about the founder and fourth president, James Madison; to brush off cobwebs that have accumulated around his achievements and recover his fine reputation, which somehow has gotten lost over the past two centuries. He is popularly regarded today  when remembered at all  less as a bold thinker and superb politician than as a shy and sickly scholar, someone hardly suited for the demands of daily life, much less the rough-and-tumble world of politicking.

title: Historys Stranglehold
description: On June 5, 1978, the Congolese dictator Joseph-Dsir Mobutu stood on a hot grassy bluff in the south of his vast country  then named Zaire  and watched as the engines on a space rocket ignited. Slowly, the rocket rose from the launching pad. A hundred kilometers into the atmosphere, thats where it was headed, a new step forward in African space travel. After a few moments, though, the rocket listed, cut a neat arc to the left and landed a few hundred meters away, in the valley of the Luvua, where it exploded. For David Van Reybrouck the rocket represents Mobutus regime: A parabola of soot. . . . After the steep rise of the first years, his Zaire toppled inexorably and plunged straight into the abyss.

title: Donors Weigh Jilting Christie for Jeb Bush
description: Jeb Bushs increasingly serious and public examination of a run for president has shaken the ranks of establishment Republican donors and fund-raisers who had planned to back Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in 2016, forcing many of them to rethink their allegiance to the embattled governor.

title: Whitney Edits a Tale of a Nation
description: A year away from opening, the new home of the Whitney Museum of American Art is still a construction site, but it is already a vivid presence in Manhattans meatpacking district, and curators have mapped out months worth of exhibitions there.

title: Seth MacFarlane and Charlize Theron on A Million Ways to Die in the West
description: Q. Were you surprised, Charlize, at how easily you fit into the world of this film that Seth directed, co-wrote and co-starred in?

title: The Investigation of the Horrific Oklahoma Execution Will Not Be Independent
description: Did anyone really believe that Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma would allow a truly independent review of the execution  death by torture is more like it  that shocked the conscience of the nation and the world on Tuesday night?

description: To the Editor:
