title: Maritime Treasures Surface at Museums
description: Antiques from New Yorks vanished coastal workplaces are coming to light in museum and gallery displays in the next few months. Pier A at Battery Park City, the 1880s Lower Manhattan building that once housed the citys harbor police, is being turned into bars, restaurant spaces and a visitors center, with period steamship gauges and other nautical memorabilia incorporated into the dcor.

title: Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne on Neighbors
description: Q. When did you two first meet?

title: EBay Settles No-Poaching Antitrust Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The auction site eBay has settled a federal antitrust case that accused it of having a secret deal with Intuit not to try to hire each others employees.

title: Former Auteur in Love With Outrage
description: In 1998 the German artist Christoph Schlingensief organized the Last Chance Party, a deliberately absurdist mix of art and politics that encouraged ordinary people to nominate themselves as candidates for the coming parliamentary elections.

title: Melissa McCarthy and Ben Falcone on Tammy
description: Q. Did meeting each other in a professional setting forever determine your relationship?

title: Old Paint and Built-In Sticker Shock
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Secret Power of Synonyms
description: Words have been the subjects and primary constituents of the enigmatic yet acerbically provocative paintings Mel Bochner has been creating over the past 12 years. Mel Bochner: Strong Language, an elegantly produced exhibition at the Jewish Museum, gives them their due and traces their roots back to text-based works that Mr. Bochner created in the 60s and early 70s, when he was one of New Yorks pre-eminent Conceptual artists.

title: Split Day in Court, as Defendant and Counsel
description: As often occurs in busy courthouses, lawyers appear repeatedly on the same day, before different judges, in different courtrooms.

title: Yin and Yang, Now Breathing as One
description: The singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens thought he disliked ballet until the New York City Ballet dancer Justin Peck asked him for permission to choreograph a piece to his electronic song cycle, Enjoy Your Rabbit. The ballet, Year of the Rabbit, was a raging success in 2012, and Mr. Stevens  famous for his folk-inspired melodies, haunting narratives and eccentric large-scale projects  became a convert.

title: Cameron Diaz and Jason Segel on Sex Tape
description: Q. This is the second comedy youve made together, after Bad Teacher. Are you more comfortable working with each other now?

title: Meagan Good and Romany Malco on Think Like a Man Too
description: Q. Before playing Zeke and Mya in the Think Like a Man movies, you were paired up in The Love Guru. What were those earliest encounters like?

title: A Shoulder for Buildings to Lean On
description: Hudson Yards, the 26-acre urban hub rising from obscurity on the Far West Side, some of it on a customized platform deftly suspended above an unlovely rail yard, is the genesis of a vibrant neighborhood and skyline where now there is none. As is usual in her line of work, the input of the structural engineer Aine M. Brazil wont be visible once the finished product is. Shes the quintessential behind-the-scenes player.

title: Ford Names New Chief Executive Officer
description: Ford Motor Company announced that Alan R. Mulally, the president and chief executive officer, will retire July 1 and be replaced by the chief operating officer, Mark Fields.

title: This Weekend: Deadly and Funny Musical
description: A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder, which just received 10 Tony nominations, is still on Broadway; a rooftop exhibition at the Met is now open; and celebrities are still cheating on one another.

title: Jaimie Warren: Thats What Friends Are For
description: The Hole

title: Rainer Ganahl: El Mundo
description: Kai Matsumiya

title: Etel Adnan
description: Callicoon Fine Arts

title: Robert Longo: Gang of Cosmos
description: Petzel

title: Low-Down-Payment Loans
description: Loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration offer first-time home buyers the advantage of a down payment as low as 3.5 percent. But rising premiums for the required mortgage insurance have made the loans prohibitively expensive.

title: Theater Listings for May 2-8
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Archie Isnt Dead. Hes Free. (For One Day.)
description: COMIC book characters are now a staple of prime-time television and blockbuster films. But Free Comic Book Day, an annual effort to promote the comic-book industry that began in 2002, shifts the focus back to the printed page and the stores that sell them.

title: Comedy Listings for May 2-8
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for May 2-8
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 2-8
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: An Innocent Awakened
description: Though it takes place in Poland in 1962  a weary, disenchanted country grinding along under gray, post-Stalinist skies  Pawel Pawlikowskis Ida has some of the structure and feeling of an ancient folk tale. It concerns an orphan who must make her way through a haunted, threatening landscape, protected only by her own good sense and a powerful, not entirely trustworthy companion.

title: Jazz Listings for May 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: This Weekend: A Delightful and Deadly Musical
description: In the Video

title: Where the Password Is Deco
description: NIGHT and day, New York reveals itself as the Art Deco capital of the world. I dont mean just the obvious treasures  the Chrysler Building, Radio City Music Hall, Rockefeller Center  but the Deco surprises that decorate just about every other block.

title: If These Walls Could Speak, Theyd Say Her Name
description: HOW many worshipers, at the 1920s Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, or St. Bartholomews Church, the Episcopal bastion nearby, realize  if they notice them at all  that the intricate mosaic ornamentations in these contrasting houses of faith were produced by a singular vision? The same sensibility distinguishes an altar in St. Patricks Cathedral, and the glistening red mosaic walls at One Wall Street, which turn to orange the higher they go. If audiences dashing to Radio City Music Hall tilted their heads back, they would suddenly be struck by brightly colored figurative roundels on the 50th Street facade. From one coast to the other are many more instances of the same artists remarkable decorative work, forgotten in plain sight.

title: When Ghosts Have Hobbies
description: The premise of Howard Normans new novel is eerie enough to make the skin crawl. Next Life Might Be Kinder is narrated by a blocked, troubled writer named Sam Lattimore, who delivers an opening sentence worthy of the Noir Hall of Fame.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for May 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: To the Manner Born?
description: No bodices seem to have been harmed, much less ripped, during the making of Belle, a period film at once sweeping and intimate, about an 18th-century Englishwoman who transcends her historical moment. Even so, peekaboo bosoms tremble throughout the movie amid the rustle of luxurious gowns and the gasps of polite company as conventions are crushed underfoot. Melodramatic and grounded in history, Belle is enough of an old-fashioned entertainment that it could have been made in classic Hollywood. Well, except for one little thing that would have probably given old studio suits apoplexy: The movies prettily flouncing title character is biracial.

title: Netanyahu Plans to Promote Legislation on Jewish State Designation
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday that he intended to promote legislation bolstering the status of Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people, anchoring the principle as one of the basic laws that serve as the countrys Constitution.

title: The Lord of Gondor, Taking Manhattan
description: For decades, John Noble told no one, not even his wife, of the career he dreamed of having when he was 20-something and unknown, living in his native South Australia.

title: Attackers Use Microsoft Security Hole Against Energy, Defense, Finance Targets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  By the time Microsoft warned customers of a nasty security hole in its web browser Saturday, a sophisticated group of attackers were already using the vulnerability against defense and energy companies, according to FireEye, the security company.

title: Dance Listings for May 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Group Show in TriBeCa Explores Black Identity Today
description: The curator Nicola Vassell has a blue-chip art-world pedigree as a former director at both Deitch Projects and Pace. And perhaps because her gallery work positioned her in contexts where glitz and glamour are currencies of their own, media coverage of Vassell has often focused on her taste and style  her former modeling career, her wardrobe, the social goings-on at her SoHo loft. But Vassell has lately gone independent  she left Pace in 2012 to found Concept NV, which she describes as an art ideation lab  and its clear shes got more pressing social concerns on her mind. Activism is important to me, she says. I find that sometimes the art world is too busy with its art-world view to consider that. Her latest show, Black Eye, underscores the continuing need for increased diversity in a still narrow art world. The wide-ranging exhibition, which opens tomorrow night in TriBeCa, features paintings, photographs and collage by 26 emerging and established black artists, including Wangechi Mutu, Jacolby Satterwhite, Steve McQueen and Kerry James Marshall.

title: Art Listings for May 2-8
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Out of Japan, Rising
description: Ranking the great Japanese filmmakers of the mid-20th century is an easy parlor game, made convenient by the long, prolific and amazingly consistent careers of the major contenders. The big three of the Japanese golden age are traditionally acknowledged to be Akira Kurosawa, Kenji Mizoguchi and Yasujiro Ozu, born within 12 years of one another around the turn of the 20th century.

title: Bursting the Democrats Midterm-Turnout Bubble
description: The Democratic midterm turnout problem is no secret. Young and nonwhite voters tend to stay home in off-year elections, leaving the electorate older, whiter and more Republican than in a presidential election.

title: The Future Is So Dark, Pack a Lamp
description: Geography is destiny. Even in the land of opportunity, the place you are born and brought up has a lot to do with determining your future. And if that place is Van Buren, Me., a dingy, fading agricultural town on the Canadian border, there is not much of a future to look forward to.

title: This Weeks Movies: May 2, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Ida, Belle and The Amazing Spider-Man 2.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 2-8
description: FLUFF: A STORY OF LOST TOYS

title: On the Trail of a Gene That Kills
description: Decoding Annie Parker, Steven Bernsteins useful, high-minded docudrama about breast cancer, is a gawky mixture of medical tutorial and personal history. Ms. Parker, played by Samantha Morton with an air of crumpled dolefulness that masks a core of ferocious determination, is a Canadian living in Toronto whose mother and sister succumb to breast cancer, which she eventually develops herself. It was the first of her three bouts with cancer, all of which she survived.

title: Timeline Describes Frantic Scene at Oklahoma Execution
description: McALESTER, Okla.  Early on the morning of Clayton D. Locketts scheduled execution, he defied prison officers seeking to shackle him for the required walk to get X-rays. So they shocked him with a Taser, Oklahomas chief of corrections stated in an account released Thursday of Mr. Locketts final day, before his execution went awry.

title: Spare Times for May 2-8
description: Wall to Wall Cabaret (Saturday) One of the largest assemblages of New York nightclub talent in recent memory will gather at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, for this free eight-hour musical marathon. (Select premium seats are available for the afternoon and evening sessions for $100 each.)

title: Game Legend Carmack at Center of Oculus Dispute
description: John Carmack is one of the most celebrated technical wizards in the video game business, known for pushing the boundaries of the medium with Quake, Doom and other pioneering games. Most recently, he took up virtual reality as a cause, seeing in it a way to make games more immersive than those played on computer and television screens.

title: Curse of the Abominable Snow Mutants
description: For anyone who still associates Austrian cinema with Michael Hanekes dour, stringent visions, Blood Glacier, from the Vienna-born filmmaker Marvin Kren, presents a rousing alternative, complete with giant flying insects. In Mr. Krens enjoyably committed and splattery creature feature, scientists and visitors at an Alpine weather station fend off mutant beasts that materialize after the discovery of a sprawling, rust-colored hunk of ice.

title: Possible Flight Paths
description: The Malaysian government released a map Thursday showing several possible flight paths for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight.

title: Merck Said to Be Near Closing Deal With Bayer
description: Updated, 8:01 p.m. | Merck, the big health care company, is close to a deal to sell its consumer unit to Bayer for about $14 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Finding a Survivor, or Perhaps a Fraud
description: The flashier of the two stories in Unclaimed, Michael Jorgensens intensely moving documentary, is about a man claiming to be a long-missing Vietnam War veteran. Quietly shadowing this central identity quest, however, is a less attention-grabbing but perhaps even more compelling tale of how one man from a broken home finds peace and purpose in reconstructing the home of another.

title: Capturing an Elusive Troubadour
description: According to the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan, performing in front of an audience is the realest me that there is. Taking him at his word, the director Hanly Banks makes his live shows the meat of Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film, allowing her introspective subject to reveal as much, or as little, as he pleases.

title: Sports, the Most Progressive Force in America
description: In the capital of the old Confederacy, Richmond, Va., on a boulevard of elegantly aged homes and muscle-limbed trees, stands a string of large statues honoring a nation that enshrined human bondage in its founding document. Generals and politicians, these heroes of the Civil War South are well known.

title: Insert an Emoticon Here
description: Movies have struggled to make social media cinematic, but judging from Friended to Death, the revolution can wait. The feature debut of the director Sarah Smick, this bubble gum comedy gambles on a noxious protagonist  and fails to find much humor in him.

title: Ares Management Set to Go Public, Joining Rivals
description: The biggest private equity firms were widely known to investors by the time they first sold their shares to the public.

title: A Man and His Elephant, and Flying Fists
description: Again with the elephant?

title: Love? These Couples Lust for Laughs
description: Whether its a volley of verbal repartee or a flurry of custard pies, the best comedy bits seem to require two people to pull them off: one person to give, and the other to give back just as good.

title: Q & A: Jeffrey Wasserstrom on History, Dissent and the Power of May 4 in China
description: The political tumult that erupted in China in 1989 was a struggle over rival views of the countrys future, often fought through rival views of the past, and no date mattered more than May 4, an anniversary claimed by both the student protesters and the Communist Party.

title: Bridges of Madison County to Close on May 18
description: The new Broadway musical The Bridges of Madison County will close on May 18 after months of modest ticket sales and little help at the box office from the four Tony Award nominations for the show on Tuesday.

title: Kevin Spacey and Company Hit the Road
description: The first image that appears in NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage is the Spacey Presents logo. Thats Kevin Spacey, the benefactor and, more or less, the focus of this entertaining documentary  entertaining for a select audience, which pretty much means fans of theater or Mr. Spacey, or both. Im both. Your results may differ.

title: A Penis With a Mind of Its Own
description: A mans worst nightmare isnt that an ex posts an Internet rant about him or that beer is found to cause impotence. Its that his penis takes human form. Oh, the stories it could tell.

title: A Vision of the Future From Those Likely to Invent It
description: In a series of interviews, seven people who are driving this transformation provided a glimpse into the not-too-distant future

title: Broderick and Lane Heading Back to Broadway Together
description: Matthew Broderick and Nathan Lane, who made comic gold out of showbiz shenanigans in The Producers, will team up again in another stage-world comedy  an updated version of Terrence McNallys Its Only a Play, with Jack OBrien directing.

title: New York Through a Lens Instead of a Windshield
description: As we learn in More Than the Rainbow, Matt Weber has retired from driving a cab to devote himself to snapping pictures of New Yorks streets. But this scattered, earthy documentary from Dan Wechsler, featuring Mr. Weber, along with a colorful gallery of fellow photographers and associates, has the ramble and scramble of a crosstown conversation with an opinionated driver.

title: Looking for a Welcome in the American Melting Pot
description: After years of working as a reporter in the United States, Jose Antonio Vargas performed the journalistic equivalent of a scientific experiment on himself. He publicly revealed his status as an illegal immigrant through an article in The New York Times Magazine in 2011. In the film Documented, which is part get-out-the-message tour, part personal reckoning, Mr. Vargas argues on behalf of liberalizing immigration policy and confronts others  and himself  about his predicament.

title: A Life in a String Quartet, and Beyond
description: Allan Miller wisely keeps the hagiography to a minimum in Speak the Music, his documentary about Robert Mann, the longtime violinist for the Juilliard String Quartet. Though colleagues and former students chime in, Mr. Miller lets Mr. Mann and his violin do most of the talking, drawing on assorted interviews and vintage performance clips that convey both the skill and the enthusiasm underpinning his subjects long career.

title: Healing Sought (Bring Your Own Magic)
description: At 42 I had never loved someone who loved me back. Recovering (still) from childhood sexual abuse by a neighbor, I couldnt transcend romantic failure.

title: A Melting Pot in the Sun
description: Is there any spot on earth with higher densities of flesh, noise, salt, fat and naked, hormonal humanity than Coney Island? Only in New York would people choose this as a place to unwind.

title: Something Borrowed
description: I am an academic yuppie and am getting married soon. Typically, women like me keep their maiden names. But the catch for me is that I share a surname with several high-profile terrorists. I am not related to any of them, but my name often brings worried frowns during introductions and extremely thorough airport searches. I think taking a husbands name in 2014 is regressive, but my fiancs surname is discrimination-proof and it sounds classy with my first name, too. Any advice?

title: A Piano Great Is Back, Singing a Gusty Blues
description: ON a recent Sunday night at Smalls, the Greenwich Village basement club, Johnny ONeal sat at the piano drawing lush clumps of harmony from the keys as he shouted a blues standard. She puts whiskey in her coffee, whiskey in her tea, he sang, his voice craggy and windblown. Whiskey in her whiskey, too much whiskey for me.

title: A Troupe in Lock Step With the Wit of a Master
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  People have flown here from all around the world to see a four-day festival of works by the British master-choreographer Frederick Ashton. The 2013-14 season commemorates the 25th anniversary of Ashtons death; this festival brings it to a climax.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: In Mayweathers Corner, and in the Corner Office
description: Bad blood flowed between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya during the news media tour to promote their fight in 2007, but the promoter Richard Schaefer feared that tensions could reach new heights.

title: Steering for Laughs, in a Roar or a Whimper
description: Lewis Black, a screamer, and David Spade, more of a sniveler, are worlds apart in comedic style but both are likely to incur the wrath of driver-safety groups with their endorsements of texting while driving in their latest stand-up specials.

title: Faulted in Medicaid Fraud, Company Keeps Contract
description: For nearly five years, a state contractor allowed workers with limited expertise to approve dental claims for Texas Medicaid program, the joint state-federal insurer. State spending on orthodontic services spiraled out of control; by 2012, federal and state auditors found that the contractors actions had opened the door for a massive Medicaid fraud scheme that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: In Some Places, a Lot of Voters Arent Enough
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: State Politicians Find Fertile Turf in Federal Land Dispute
description: State Representative James Frank has been hearing from constituents since February about goings-on along the Red River: The United States Bureau of Land Management, citing a series of court rulings dating to the 1920s, had decided that a 116-mile stretch of land belonged to the federal government.

title: Events in New Jersey for May 4-10, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Howard Smith, Trend-Spotting Columnist, Dies at 77
description: Howard Smith, a journalist whose long-running Scenes column in The Village Voice was the message board of the hippie counterculture in the 1960s, and who later produced and directed Marjoe, an Oscar-winning 1972 documentary about another subculture, Christian evangelism, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 77. The cause was cancer, his son Cass said.

title: Why Economics Failed
description: On Wednesday, I wrapped up the class Ive been teaching all semester: The Great Recession: Causes and Consequences. (Slides for the lectures are available via my blog.) And while teaching the course was fun, I found myself turning at the end to an agonizing question: Why, at the moment it was most needed and could have done the most good, did economics fail?

title: Seattle Mayor Details Plan for $15 Minimum Wage
description: SEATTLE  Mayor Ed Murray presented on Thursday what he described as an imperfect but workable plan to increase the citys minimum wage to $15 an hour, more than twice the federal minimum wage and one of the highest anywhere in the nation, through a series of complex and phased-in stages. Just as crucially, he said, the plan has broad political support, with a coalition of labor and business groups ready to push hard for it at the City Council, starting with the first hearings next week.

title: Spending and Pay Gains Suggest Better Economy
description: WASHINGTON  After a winter that seemed endless, has the long-awaited spring economic thaw arrived?

title: When Its Good to Talk to a Stranger
Open-Source Software Specialist Selected as Executive Director of Wikipedia
description: The foundation that runs Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia, has named a new executive director, Lila Tretikov, a software engineer in Silicon Valley.

title: Hoping to Fend Off Suits, G.M. Is to Return to Bankruptcy Court
description: An unusual meeting took place this week at a law office high in a Times Square skyscraper. Lawyers from about 100 law firms participated, either in person or by phone. The agenda: solidifying a strategy for taking on General Motors in bankruptcy court.

title: Love Story
description: Eight months ago, I came across a passage in a book that has haunted me since. It was in Michael Ignatieffs biography of Isaiah Berlin, and it concerns a night Berlin spent in Leningrad in 1945. Berlin was hanging out when a friend asked if hed like to go visit Anna Akhmatova. Not knowing much about her, Berlin said yes.

title: HOW THE INDUSTRY FARED IN APRIL
description: Overall vehicle sales in the United States rose 8 percent last month.

title: Patients Fear Mt. Sinai Will Drop Low-Cost Insurance Plans
description: For four months, Yitzchok Shuster felt secure in the knowledge that he had signed up for a health insurance plan on New Yorks Affordable Care Act exchange, and that he was still able to see his longtime doctor, who was employed by the Mount Sinai Health System.

title: G.M. Sales Increased 7% in April, Apparently Unaffected by Recalls
description: Despite a steady drumbeat of negative news surrounding the recall of 2.6 million small cars with a deadly defect, General Motors continues to be unaffected in its showrooms.

title: Fair-Housing Collision in Westchester
description: Politicians bitterly defying the federal government over racial desegregation is an old American story, but not a dead one. You can find it in 50-year-old black-and-white newsreel clips. Or you can go to YouTube and see an angry campaign video posted this week by the Westchester County executive, Rob Astorino.

title: U.S. and Germany Fail to Reach a Deal on Spying
description: WASHINGTON  The effort to remake the intelligence relationship between the United States and Germany after it was disclosed last year that the National Security Agency was tapping Chancellor Angela Merkels cellphone has collapsed, according to German officials, who say there will be no broad intelligence sharing or no-spy agreement between the two countries when Ms. Merkel visits the White House on Friday.

title: A Surge Forward on Marriage Equality
description: In a landmark 5-to-4 ruling in June, the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Acts denial of federal benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples  but, in another case from California, declined to say whether the Constitution requires states to allow such marriages to begin with. Now, just 11 months later, the battle for marriage equality has turned an important corner, with a new round of cases beginning to reach federal appellate courts for review. This creates the potential for a speedier-than-expected return to the Supreme Court, perhaps as early as next term.

title: U.S. Looks Into Wagers, Pro and Con, on Herbalife
description: Three federal agencies and one billionaire hedge fund manager have placed Herbalife under the microscope, scrutinizing whether the diet-supplements company is a pyramid scheme.

title: At Least 3 Die in Collapse of Gold Mine
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  At least three people were killed in the collapse of an illegal gold mine in western Colombia, and rescuers were searching for other miners believed to be missing, officials said on Thursday.

title: Little Recourse for Sterling
description: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver handed down a lifetime ban to the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling this week for racist comments he made during a recorded conversation. Silver also vowed he would force Sterling to sell the team and fined him $2.5 million. No one knows quite where it will lead. As Alan Rothenberg, a longtime sports lawyer who has known Sterling for decades said, Donald is hugely litigious. He added, Hell fight as hard as can legally.

title: The Right Lessons From Chernobyl
description: Twenty-eight years after Unit 4 at the Chernobyl power plant in what was then Soviet Ukraine erupted into a volcano of radioactivity, its name has become synonymous with the nightmarish side of nuclear power. It is also the site today of an extraordinary international project, the construction of a vast steel shield to cover the leaky concrete sarcophagus in which the highly radioactive remains of the reactor are to be entombed for at least 100 years.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 1, 2014
Events in Connecticut for May 4-10, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Professional Pompom Problems
Three-Drug Protocol Persists for Lethal Injections, Despite Ease of Using One
description: Terminally ill people who want to die can take drugs to end their lives peacefully. Ailing pets are put down humanely every day. Clearly, the technology exists to bring about a quick and painless death.

title: Scratched From the Kentucky Derby
description: Mike Smith, the jockey for Hoppertunity, talks about the horses injury.

title: Israeli Military Officials Caught Off Guard by a Digital Rebellion
description: JERUSALEM  Thousands of photographs poured onto Facebook: uniformed Israeli soldiers in elite units, office workers on lunch break, a beachgoer in a bikini, a right-wing politician, toddlers and even puppies, all holding signs in Hebrew: We are with David the Nahlawi.

title: Helmets Do Little to Help Moderate Infant Skull Flattening, Study Finds
description: Pediatricians have long urged parents to put newborns to sleep on their backs to help prevent sudden infant death syndrome. While the practice undoubtedly has saved lives, it also has increased the numbers of babies with flattened skulls.

title: Derby Dreams Meet an Early End
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The saying goes that there is no cheering in the press box, and presumably that sort of restraint applies to crying, too. Yet Thursday morning, as word spread around the Churchill Downs backside, crying is exactly what I wanted to do.

title: Reaction to the Dockery Arraignment
description: Marcell Dockerys lawyer and the president of the Patrolmens Benevolent Association spoke after Mr. Dockery was arraigned on charges of setting a fire that killed a police officer.

title: Lawyer Says Confession in Fatal Fire Was Coerced
description: The defense lawyer for the Coney Island teenager charged with murder for starting a fire that led to a police officers death signaled on Thursday that he would argue his client gave a false confession.

title: 4.1% Are Said to Face Death on Convictions That Are False
description: Some 4.1 percent of death row defendants are falsely convicted, according to a widely cited study published this week. The figure concerned but did not surprise opponents of the death penalty.

title: As Netflix Resists, Most Firms Just Try to Befriend Comcast
description: In the middle of an otherwise routine earnings report last week, Netflix took an unexpected detour into the realm of antitrust enforcement: It opposed Comcasts proposed purchase of Time Warner Cable, it said, because the deal would create a powerful giant with anticompetitive leverage.

title: Ferdinand and Imelda, Back on the Disco Floor
description: Here Lies Love, which opened in April 2013 for a limited run, returned last night for an open run at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village; 212-967-7555, publictheater.org. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantleys review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 24 last year; the full text is here.

title: Silver Screen Name
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I will go out on a limb and speculate that, while there might have been a few marquee entries that inspired Brendan Emmett Quigleys puzzle today, Nate Silvers FIVE THIRTY EIGHT was probably the seed entry just so Mr. Quigley could clue it as Silver screen name? Thats brilliant.

title: After Avalanche, New Yorks Sherpas Recall Perils of a Job They Left Behind
description: BREWSTER, N.Y.  They may have stunning expanses of rolling hills, but Westchester and Putnam Counties are hardly the Himalayas.

title: With Online Video Offerings, the Establishment Plays the Upstart
description: WHAT would Henry Luce, legendary titan of journalism, have said about the video series to be introduced this year by his company, Time Inc.  offerings like I  My Closet, featuring celebrities giving peeks at their possessions, and Eyesore, a makeover show hosted by the comedian Rachel Dratch and her childhood friend, an interior decorator and organizational expert?

title: The Man Behind the Commissioners Ruling
description: When N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver announced a lifetime ban of the disgraced Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling and said he would urge the leagues Board of Governors to vote for a forced sale of the team, Silver was widely hailed for his decisive leadership in defusing a burgeoning crisis.

title: $298 Million Mistake Gives New York City Retirees Brief Windfall
description: Across New York City, retired police officers and firefighters awoke on Thursday to a surprise: A $12,000 pension payment had appeared in their bank accounts.

title: Events on Long Island for May 4-10, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Dozens Are Killed in Airstrike at a Bustling Market in Syria
description: A bustling outdoor market area in Syrias battleground city of Aleppo was turned into a mass of bloody rubble and body parts on Thursday by missiles and improvised barrel bombs that killed at least 33 people and wounded many others. Antigovernment activists described it as another deliberate attack on civilians by President Bashar al-Assads military aircraft.

title: V.A. Hospital Officials in Phoenix Are Placed on Leave
description: Two top administrators at the Department of Veterans Affairs health care system in Phoenix have been placed on leave at the request of the departments inspector general, who is investigating allegations that the hospital created a secret waiting list for patients intended to hide long wait times for appointments. Congressional officials have said as many as 40 veterans may have died while awaiting care, though none of the deaths have explicitly been tied to longer wait times.

title: How the Industry Fared in April
description: Overall vehicle sales in the United States rose 8 percent last month.

title: Neighbors Win Fight to Have a Towering Eyesore Demolished
description: The application seemed innocent enough: The owner of a house in Homecrest, Brooklyn, requested permission from the city to make a horizontal and vertical enlargement to an existing two-story, one-family residence.

title: Fast Company Wins Magazine of the Year
description: Fast Company, the magazine about business, technology and design, won the coveted title of Magazine of the Year on Thursday for its print and digital coverage.

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard
description: The horses for the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs. (Note: Pablo Del Monte, an alternate entry who will wear saddle No. 21, was added to the field and will start in the outside post after the scratch of Hoppertunity, who was to start from the No. 11 post. The horses in between will keep their program numbers but each move up a gate.)

title: Events in Westchester for May 4-10, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Developers Killing Said to Be Unplanned
description: In the four months since the body of a Brooklyn real-estate developer was found smoldering in a trash container outside a Long Island gas station, rumors of devious and occasionally outlandish plots have swirled around his death in the community and the media.

title: Kidd Urges Nets to Enter Attack Mode as They Face Elimination
description: For the Nets, months of bravado and high ambition have been reduced to this: a desperate Game 6 at Barclays Center on Friday night, when they will face elimination from the first round of the playoffs for the second consecutive season.

title: Looming Energy Crisis Again Confronts Egypts Leaders
description: CAIRO  A growing energy shortage that helped inflame the protests against President Mohamed Morsi before his ouster last year is returning to vex Egypts new military-led government.

title: Under a New Agreement: More Bonuses and New Work Rules
description: High-performing teachers would be offered up to $20,000 per year to mentor their peers. Schools would set aside 40 minutes each week for meetings with parents. Teachers with histories of poor performance could be more easily fired.

title: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Girlfriend
description: A former co-owner of a West Village guitar shop was arrested Thursday evening after the police said he fatally stabbed his girlfriend inside his apartment.

title: For the Rangers, an Unfavorable History Against the Penguins
description: The Rangers have faced the Pittsburgh Penguins four times in the postseason, and each series ended badly. Mario Lemieux and Company swept the Rangers in 1989, knocked them out in six games in 1992 and ousted them in five in 1996. In 2008, Sidney Crosby was at the controls as the Rangers fell in five.

title: N.Y.U. Law School Trustee Whose Company Subpoenaed Students Is Stepping Down
description: A New York University Law School trustee whose company subpoenaed the personal emails, texts and diaries of two N.Y.U. law students is stepping down.

title: With Yankees Seeking More From Staff, Kuroda Offers More of the Same
description: What the Yankees needed Thursday was a little reassurance. A pick-me-up. Some shred of evidence that the future of their starting rotation was not as bleak as previously forecast.

title: The Education of a Public Man
description: Fed up with dysfunctional public officials? With politics altogether? Even given up on voting? Then do yourself a favor and read Richard Ravitchs inspiring So Much to Do: A Full Life of Business, Politics and Confronting Fiscal Crises (PublicAffairs).

title: Top-Seeded Pacers Avoid Elimination
description: ATLANTA  The familiar idiom one and done, which has taken on new meaning in recent N.B.A. playoffs, cannot be applied to the Indiana Pacers.

title: 4-Year-Olds Death Focuses Attention on Two New York City Agencies
description: It was a sunny Sunday morning, so Juan Sanchezs mother took him and his four brothers out to a park. It would be his last play date.

title: A Heinous Crime, Secret Histories and a Sinn Fein Leaders Arrest
description: BOSTON  For years, the researchers painstakingly recorded and transcribed oral histories from many of the leaders of the factions caught up in the Troubles in Northern Ireland. They pledged absolute secrecy to their subjects until after their deaths.

title: Pitchers Handling Hitters From Start to Finish
description: There were plenty of skeptics when the Chicago White Sox signed the Cuban slugger Jose Abreu for $68 million over six years. But it turns out that Abreu, with no major league experience, was one of the few batters no one needed to worry about.

title: 2 Brothers Sentenced to Maximum for Killing a Manhattan Man
description: The murder victim was found kneeling with his head resting on his bed in Hamilton Heights, his feet bound with a dog leash and a belt, his wrists tied behind the back with a scarf, his mouth and nose covered with packing tape. He had been pummeled in the head more than 32 times and stabbed repeatedly with a fork. One ear had been cut in half.

title: The Mona Lisa of Stamps to Be Auctioned at Sothebys
description: WASHINGTON  Heres our patient, as they called it in London, David N. Redden told the specialist, a world-class expert who had agreed to do a thorough examination using special equipment unavailable in England.

title: Life in the Balance
description: The artist Taryn Simon finds a metaphor for Robert Pinskys meditation on agriculture and avarice in Jenga, a childrens game in which one wrong move spurs collapse.

title: Women of the House
Classic Met Gala-Worthy Looks
description: Next week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art reopens the doors to its Costume Institute, now dubbed the Anna Wintour Costume Center, with a show dedicated to the works of the Anglo-American couturier Charles James. The inaugural exhibition, Charles James: Beyond Fashion, will of course inform the dress code for the fashion flock attending the opening gala on Monday evening  the designers classic style (think: society balls and Hollywood starlets) marking a complete departure from last years garbage-bag gowns and safety-pin-fastened concert tees for the Punk: Chaos to Couture event. In anticipation of one of fashions biggest nights of the year, weve curated some modern black-tie-appropriate designs that nod to the midcentury glamour that James helped define. In case your golden ticket got lost in the mail, nows as good a time as any to make Monday evening plans worthy of floral-printed opera gloves and statement diamond earrings.

title: Ask Well: Triglycerides and Heart Disease
description: Question:

title: U.S. to Store Gasoline for Crises in the Northeast
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government will build its first gasoline storage reserves in the New York Harbor area and in New England in response to the shortages suffered after Hurricane Sandy, the secretary of energy, Ernest J. Moniz, is to announce on Friday.

title: Word of the Day | incarnation
description: incarnation\in-()kr-na-shn\ noun

title: Berkshires Energy Arm to Buy AltaLink, a Power Transmission Company
description: OMAHA  Berkshire Hathaways energy division agreed on Thursday to buy AltaLink, Candas main energy transmission companies, for about $2.9 billion.

title: India Election Digest: May 2
description: What you need to know on Friday about Indias elections: A public broadcaster defends itself from criticism of its interview with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party, voter turnout has risen among women and young people, and the Election Commission goes to great lengths to make sure every Indian can vote.

title: Mets Are Doomed by a Pitcher at the Plate
description: DENVER  The Mets have become accustomed to struggling on offense, relying instead on strong starting pitching to establish themselves as one of the surprise teams of the young season. But on Thursday night at Coors Field, their starting pitcher did not last through the fifth inning and their offense did not wake up until the ninth, resulting in a 7-4 defeat to the Colorado Rockies.

title: Interest Grows in Animal Testing Alternatives
description: With China planning to relax its requirement that cosmetics and other personal care products be tested on animals before they can go to market, a government training program in alternative testing methods is suddenly so popular it has had to turn away applicants.

title: North Korea: Activity at a Missile Site
description: New commercial satellite imagery shows that North Korea is expanding its main rocket-launching site and testing engines of what is believed to be its first road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, a website specializing in the North said Thursday. The reported activities at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongchang-ri near North Koreas western border with China come amid fears that the North may be preparing for another nuclear test. In recent days, more activity has been reported at an underground nuclear test site in Punggye-ri in northeastern North Korea. The website, 38 North, which is run by the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said its analysis of satellite images of Tongchang-ri showed that North Korea conducted one and maybe more engine tests of what is probably the first stage of a KN-08 road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile in late March to early April. With this latest activity, three KN-08 rocket engine test series have been identified for the first and possibly second stages dating back to mid-2013, the website said. As this effort progresses, the next technically logical step in the missiles development would be a flight test of the entire system.

title: Pagliacci, by Appointment Only
description: The Italian heritage of Brooklyns Homecrest is evinced by the Virgin Mary statuettes on the block that is home to the Enrico Caruso Museum of America. A tidy house at 1942 East 19th Street, owned by Aldo Mancusi since 1956, doubles as a shrine to the opera icon. A hobby gone crazy, Mr. Mancusi said, his silver mustache as neatly pruned as the yards hedges.

title: Times Minute | Why G.M.s Case Matters
description: General Motors is in court facing a rising tide of claims for faulty ignition switches. What its continuing legal battle could mean for American business.

title: Times Minute | Why G.M.s Case Matters
description: In the Video

title: U.S. Sanctions Strategy, Explained
description: Some background on the impact of sanctions on Russia and what could happen if the Western leaders decide to go further.

title: Trump Courses to Host Two Events
description: The P.G.A. of America provided the developer Donald Trump with a double gift, announcing that it had awarded the 2017 Senior P.G.A. Championship to Trump National Golf Club in Washington, and the 2022 P.G.A. Championship to Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J. This week, Trump agreed to acquire the Turnberry Resort in Scotland, which is part of the rotation of courses that host the British Open.

title: So Far, U.S. Sanctions Over Ukraine May Be Inflicting Only Limited Pain on Russia
description: WASHINGTON  As it tries to punish Moscow for its intervention in Ukraine, the White House asserts that the sanctions it has imposed have had a significant impact on Russias economy, but their real effect so far, according to economic specialists, appears to be more psychological than tangible.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) SHARK TANK: SWIMMING WITH SHARKS Lara Spencer anchors this special, which ventures behind the scenes of the reality show to reveal what happens after the deals are made. The series sharks (above from left, Kevin OLeary, Barbara Corcoran, Ms. Spencer, Daymond John, Mark Cuban and Lori Greiner; not pictured, Robert Herjavec) discuss their strategies for landing deals and making the most money, lament their regrets and divulge what they think of one another. This show will also follow up with the entrepreneurs Mark and Hanna Lim of Lollacup, a sippy cup; Rick and Melissa Hinnant of Grace & Lace, a sock company; Al Baker of Bubbas Q Boneless Ribs; Lani Lazzaro of Simple Sugars, a sugar scrub; and Johnny Georges of Tree-T-Pee, an irrigation device, and reveal its most successful business in the shows five seasons.

title: Warriors Hold Off Clippers to Force Game 7
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In a playoff series destined to be remembered for the off-court drama of the N.B.A.s decision to force the expulsion of the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, the on-court fight between the Clippers and Golden State Warriors will end with a Game 7.

title: AstraZeneca Rejects a Higher Bid From Pfizer
description: The British drug maker AstraZeneca rejected an improved offer by its American rival Pfizer on Friday as political debate in Britain intensified over whether a foreign takeover of one of the countrys largest pharmaceutical firms should be encouraged.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: China Criticizes U.S. Terrorism Report
description: Days after a deadly attack in the western region of Xinjiang, China has criticized the United States State Departments annual terrorism report, saying it wrongly plays down Chinas counterterrorism efforts and accusing the United States of holding double standards on terrorist assaults in China.

title: Ukrainians Strike Rebel-Held City as Fighting Spreads
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Two days after Ukraines interim government declared itself all but helpless to control events in the eastern part of the country, Ukrainian military and police forces on Friday resumed their effort to retake this rebel-controlled city, forcing armed separatists from the citys outskirts with armored vehicles, helicopters and ground troops  and seemingly pushing ever closer to a confrontation with Moscow.

title: South Sudan Will Talk With Rebels, Kerry Says
description: JUBA, South Sudan  Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday that he had secured a commitment from Salva Kiir, South Sudans president, to open talks with his rebel opponent as early as next week.

description: Use the following question to test your ability to identify signal words.

description: In Behind Focus on College Assaults, a Steady Drumbeat by Students, Jennifer Steinhauer reports on the student activism that helped draw attention to the problem of sexual assault on college campuses.

title: R.B.S. Profit Triples on Lower Loan Charges and One-Time Gains
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said Friday that its first-quarter profit tripled as the lender benefited from a reduction in loan impairments in its Irish business and several one-time gains.

title: An Unlikely Indian Political Stars Latest Crusade
description: VARANASI, India  Narendra Modi, the man widely expected to be Indias next prime minister, came to this tattered holy city last month like a messiah, greeted by vast crowds that showered him with adulation and rose petals in a triumphal procession.

description: Jason Houge never intended to live with 30 feral cats.

title: Do Girls Get Better Grades Than Boys in Your School?
description: By the time they enter kindergarten, girls are already performing better according to many social and behavioral measures than boys. By eighth grade, they are getting better grades. By college, they are graduating in higher numbers. Do you see any evidence of this national trend around you?

title: Train Accident Leaves Scores Injured in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A train pulling into a Seoul subway station on Friday smashed into the back of another train that had stopped for a mechanical problem, injuring 170 passengers, city officials and local news reports said.

description: Good morning to you on this strangely rainless Friday.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Early Saturday night, the horses for the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby will saunter onto the racetrack as a capacity crowd at Churchill Downs serenades them with a full-throated My Old Kentucky Home. It promises to be a stirring tableau of Americas oldest sport showcasing its history and grandeur and the beautiful athletes at its center.

title: European Jobs Market Still Stagnant, March Data Show
description: PARIS  The European labor market remains stagnant in spite of recent signs that growth might be ticking up, an official report showed Friday.

title: Shanghai Laments Loss of TV Show in Local Dialect
description: Because DocuTV will soon start broadcasting on satellite, programs in local dialect cant go on and Shanghai Dialect Talk will close. Thank you everyone for your support! Im grateful!

description: Every day, hundreds of thousands of readers make their way through The New York Times, in print or online. Hundreds of them  outraged, amused or touched in some way  like to write back and give us a piece of their mind.

title: Deadly Attacks Heighten Tension in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Four separate bombings in Egypt killed at least five people on Friday in a sharp escalation of militant violence just weeks before the country is scheduled to hold a presidential election.

title: Chinas Censored World
description: In February, while I finished work on a book about China, a publishing company in Shanghai asked for an early copy, in order to begin a translation. The book follows people Ive come to know, some prominent, others not, as they try to change their lives in a country throbbing with possibility  individuals like Gong Haiyan, a farmers daughter and businesswoman who envisions herself in a race against the clock, to seize the initiative before its lost.

description: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

title: Teenagers in The Times | April 2014
description: It is not easy to wade through the negative press about teenagers that often dominates the news to find stories showcasing young people making positive change in the world. Thats why we are trying a new take on Teenagers in The Times this month.

title: Morning Agenda: Scrutiny for Traders of Herbalife
description: U.S. LOOKS INTO WAGERS ON HERBALIFE | Three federal agencies and one billionaire hedge fund manager have placed Herbalife under the microscope, scrutinizing whether the diet supplements company is a pyramid scheme, Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. But Herbalife is not the only one under investigation. Some federal authorities are pursuing other inquiries that might expand the regulatory gaze from Herbalife to the traders who traffic in the companys stock.

title: Where Mean Girls Rule
description: There isnt a woman in Washington who doesnt traffic in at least five of the seven deadly sins. Greed, lust, envy, wrath and pride are the currencies of power in the nations capital, and some of its most dangerous brokers are women on television.

description: As you may have noticed, our Friday Skills lessons have been evolving a bit this year.

title: Jump in Payrolls Is Seen as a Sign of New Optimism
description: After a frustrating series of false starts since the economic recovery began five years ago, American businesses appear to be increasingly confident about hiring new workers.

title: Super Rugby Has Its Eye on Asia
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  Super Rugbys bosses have not ruled out their competition eventually going global, but for now their priority is deciding who gets to join the revamped tournament beginning in 2016.

title: The Eye Has to Travel
description: An avid Instagrammer, the fashion designer Julia Leach chronicles unexpected treasures hiding in plain sight, from sky-blue vistas in Athens to smooth stones in the sand in Riviera Nayarit, Mexico. When I travel, pure moments that have graphic sensibility and emotional simplicity always catch my eye, the former creative director of Kate Spade says. These discoveries serve as inspiration for Chance, Leachs nascent line of breezy basics, including striped boat-neck T-shirts, cotton caftans and woven hats  the kind of clothing that makes one want to head off and seek the sun.

title: Q & A: Nicholas Bequelin on Why Tensions Are Rising in Xinjiang and Beyond
description: Wednesday evening, at least two assailants armed with knives attacked a crowd of people outside a train station in Urumqi, the capital of the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang. At least 79 people were wounded and three died, two of them believed to have been the attackers, who also set off an explosive device. The one suspect the police identified, a 39-year-old man, has a name that suggests he belonged to the Uighur ethnic group, once the dominant people in Xinjiang, who after decades of migration by ethnic Han Chinese are now a minority.

title: The Jobs Report Isnt as Good as It Looks
description: Rarely does a monthly report on the United States job market look so terrific on the surface while being so disappointing underneath.

title: Its a Mistake to Pretend This Jobs Report Tells a Consistent Story
description: A brief piece of advice for fellow journalists: Dont try to pretend that the headline numbers from the two surveys that the Labor Department released this morning can tell a consistent story. They cant.

title: April Jobs Report | The Upshot Countdown
description: The Upshots David Leonhardt breaks down the April Jobs report in less than 30 seconds.

title: Steve Jobs Defied Convention, and Perhaps the Law
description: If Steve Jobs were alive today, should he be in jail?

title: Despite Racial Divides, Poll Finds Wide Support for Sterlings Penalties
description: As the fallout continues from the disclosure of racist remarks made by Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, a national New York Times/CBS News poll showed that while there is wide support for the actions taken by the N.B.A., there are deep racial divisions among basketball fans.

title: Daily Report: White House Calls for More Privacy Protections
description: The White House, hoping to move the national debate over privacy beyond the National Security Agencys surveillance activities to the practices of companies like Google and Facebook, released a long-anticipated report on Thursday that recommends developing government limits on how private companies make use of the torrent of information they gather from their customers online, David E. Sanger and Steve Lohr report.

title: Should You Believe the New Jobs Numbers? Depends on What You Mean by Believe
description: On Thursday, we wrote  that you shouldnt be snookered by the monthly jobs report, showing that routine sampling error can create a distorted picture of how the nations economy is evolving.

title: That Body Part Returns, in Spanish
description: In a memorable early passage in The Vagina Monologues, Eve Ensler quotes various women on the nicknames they had created for the body part that gives the play its title. New York audiences giggled, squirmed and nodded their heads knowingly to the likes of mushmellow, ghoulie and Gladys Siegelman during the shows original three-year run, which ended in 2003.

title: The Jobs Number Is Actually Four Numbers
description: What was the change in employment in April?

description: When News Corporation announcedon Fridaythat it was buying the romance-novel publisher Harlequin Enterprises, cheap jokes inevitably started to fly.

title: Pit Bull vs. Pistorius
description: Between Oscar Pistoriuss emotional testimony and the tactics of the prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, the courtroom interaction during the trial over the death of Reeva Steenkamp has kept many riveted.

title: In Our Pages: May 3
description: 1939: 5,000 Refugees Put to Work

title: Video Reviews of The Amazing Spider-Man 2, Ida and Belle
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Ida, Belle and The Amazing Spider-Man 2. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: 43 Questions to Ask Before Picking a New Town
description: When it comes time to move to the suburbs, pick a town or settle in a new neighborhood, the checklist generally begins like this: Best school test scores. Most house for the money. Shortest commute.

title: Debut Novels
description: THE BOOK OF JONAH  By Joshua Max Feldman  Henry Holt, $28.

title: Paperback Row
description: ROBERT OPPENHEIMER: A Life Inside the Center, by Ray Monk. (Anchor, $20.) Monk emphasizes Oppenheimers psychological complexity and his contributions to physics as he brings the father of the atomic bomb vividly to life  from his tenure as the director of the Los Alamos laboratory to his exile under McCarthyite anti-Communism. THE GIRLS OF ATOMIC CITY: The Untold Story of the Women Who Helped Win World War II, by Denise Kiernan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) In 1945, the town of Oak Ridge, Tenn., had 75,000 residents and used more electricity than New York City. As Kiernan explains in this engaging history, Oak Ridge was home to the Manhattan Projects top-secret uranium enrichment facilities, staffed by young women who learned the true nature of their work only after the first bomb fell on Hiroshima.

title: Editors Choice
description: FORCING THE SPRING: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality,  by Jo Becker. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) A fly-on-the-wall account of the 2013 Supreme Court case that led to the overturn of Californias ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Facts & Figures: Environmental Racism
description: Three environmental organizations released a study Thursday on the demographics of the 134 million U.S. residents living with the danger or vulnerability zones of 3,433 chemical facilities, and the 3.8 million living with the fenceline zones closest to potential harm, with the least time to react in the event of a catastrophe.

title: Adventures of a Somebody
description: All she did was dab a little rouge on her cheeks to disguise her wan complexion and provide a rosy contrast to the black gown she would wear. But her husband strongly disapproved. Grabbing a towel, he pulled her onto his knee and wiped her face clean. It did not matter to John Quincy Adams that Queen Louise of Prussia had given his wife the cosmetic and expected it to be used.

title: Blight and Flight
description: What does the essayist David Giffels have in common with LeBron James, Chrissie Hynde, the Professional Bowlers Association and Devo? They all originated in the Rubber Capital of the World. Born at the end of the baby boom in a city cloaked in smoke, Giffels came of age just as Goodrich, Firestone and General Tire were high-tailing it out of Akron, Ohio, chasing nonunion labor and sunnier climes. Almost a third of the citys population fled after the closures, along with the pop stars, the bowling association and, most crushingly, LeBron. But Giffels stuck around to document every empty Main Street storefront and every piece of the regions postindustrial detritus, down to a dirty diaper frozen atop a Lake Erie swell.

title: Are You My Father?
description: The lost or unknown parent tantalizes from behind the drape. The child cast off or left behind spins absence into myth. Most of us are given little to imagine about our mothers and fathers; they stand squarely before us on their fallen arches. We know from whom we got our own flat feet. The forsaken child, though, can hope for better, also that a bit of the mystery has been passed on to him, a secret compartment holding an untapped talent, an innate courage, a sensitive nature. And, against the evidence, love may also wait.

title: Spy Anxiety
description: Mai Jia is the pen name of Jiang Benhu, perhaps the most widely read writer youve never heard of. Jiang enrolled in a military college in China in 1981 and stayed in the Chinese Army after graduation, writing and editing. Since returning to civilian life in 1997, he has produced a number of novels with military intelligence themes that have sold millions of copies. Some have been made into popular television productions and films. Today Jiang is president of the state-sponsored writers association in Zhejiang Province.

title: Gomorrah by the Bay
description: Emma Donoghues novel Room, published in 2010, was rightly celebrated for its terse depiction of love in a dark place. Narrated by a small boy, its a claustrophobic and sparsely furnished exercise in horror and redemption. A mother and her young son, held captive for years in a locked room, do not go mad and destroy each other. Instead they make a sort of world, a private civilization of tenderness and warmth, population two. The novel is a triumph of the obsessed imagination thriving on a real paucity of resources.

title: Train of Jewels
description: In 2005, the settlement of a notorious case of postwar liability took place in a federal court in Florida. Sixty years previously, the so-called Hungarian Gold Train had arrived near Salzburg, Austria, bearing property requisitioned by the Nazis from Hungarys estimated 800,000 Jewish citizens. Making its way to Germany as the Allies closed in, the train was intercepted by the Americans. Some of its cargo  jewelry, glassware, carpets, bed linen, cutlery, furs, furniture, gold coins, watches and much else from households whose occupants had vanished into the concentration camps  was subsequently commandeered by the generals working on the Marshall Plan, who needed to furnish their headquarters. Numerous items were irretrievably lost, never to be seen again by their rightful owners or by their owners heirs. It would take more than half a century for Hungarian survivors of the Holocaust to settle a lawsuit that eventually granted $21 million as compensation to a number of Jewish social service agencies.

title: In for Nasty Weather
description: Life on the planet Earth. . . . Wars and strife and surprises and love and children and art. . . . This is our parade and Im marching in it. She squeezed my hand and we went back to writing on our postcards and eating croissants and being here, glad to be alive in the only world there is, alive and eating and still breathing and not afraid really of anything that might happen next. We were Americans, for Gods sake, we werent in the habit of being afraid.

title: Inside the List
description: Je Ne Sais Quoi: Everybodys Got Something, a new memoir by the Good Morning America anchor Robin Roberts, makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. Robertss book is like one of those packets of heavily sweetened instant oatmeal  you can pretend its healthy even as you search out the sugar bombs of drama (her medical crises, her mothers death, her ratings war with the Today show) and celebrity gossip (her 10-year relationship with the girlfriend she met on a blind date: I liked the fact that she had no idea who I was). Roberts delivers all of this in the soothing, upbeat voice that has made her so formidable a presence on morning TV. Im no Pollyanna, she says in the current issue of Good Housekeeping, but I believe optimism is a choice  a muscle that gets stronger with use. Right foot, left foot . . . just keep moving. This spirit of levelheaded resolve is widely credited with helping Roberts topple Today from its perch in 2012. But she almost didnt get the chance. She was a woman of great personal dignity, stately beauty and, whats most important in her mysterious genre, a certain je ne sais quoi that you cant just order up by the ounce from human resources, the media reporter Brian Stelter wrote of Roberts in Top of the Morning, his 2013 best seller about the competition for breakfast-hour viewers. Naturally, because morning TV still comes down to a group of elite men trying to guess the needs of a mass audience of mostly women, many of the powers that were at ABC wanted to fire her as soon as feasible.

title: Today in Small Business: 288,000 Jobs
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Tony Awards 2014: Nominees Plan Bs
description: Tony nominees talk about what they would be doing for a living if they didnt work in the theater.

title: More Senior Departures Expected From Barclays in Upheaval at British Firm
description: Updated, 8:03 p.m. |

title: Artistic Director of Pennsylvania Ballet to Step Down
description: Perhaps 35 years feels like enough. Roy Kaiser, who joined the corps de ballet of the Pennsylvania Ballet in 1979 and rose through its ranks to principal before eventually becoming artistic director of the company in 1995, has announced that he is stepping down.

title: Legal Fight Over Nursery School Admissions Keeps Delhi Kids at Home
description: NEW DELHI  It has been over a month since the new semester began at nursery schools in Indias capital. Yet at Springdales School the corridors are silent, the swings and see-saws are motionless and the classrooms are empty.

title: Tony Awards Video: If I Werent in Show Business
description: On Wednesday several of this years Tony Award nominees gathered at the Paramount Hotel for the annual meet-and-greet, where they chatted with the press, schmoozed with one other and sized up the competition.

title: Wall Street Embraces a Rule It Hates
description: Wall Street banks have a special loathing for a new and arcane rule, and they have gone to extraordinary lengths  like helping write a bill that is currently in Congress  to neuter it.

title: Militants Kill 11 in Northeastern India, Police Say
description: NEW DELHI  Eleven people were killed in two separate attacks on western villages in the northeastern Indian state of Assam on Thursday night, where long-simmering tensions have pitted members of the Bodo tribal group, who are demanding a separate state, against non-Bodo residents.

title: My, What Lovely Flowers. Who Lobbied for Them?
description: WASHINGTON  There was something different about the iris and quince blossoms in the flower arrangements at the state dinner for France at the White House this year: They were grown in the United States, not overseas.

title: New-Music Concerts for Mothers Day, Kids Welcome
description: The violist and composer Lev Zhurbin, who performs under the name Ljova, is experimenting with a new approach to presenting concerts that, if it works out, will expand audiences and, at the same time, save parents a small fortune in babysitting fees. On Mothers Day, May 11, Mr. Zhurbin is presenting two double-bill programs at the National Opera Center, which has two adjacent halls, both of which figure into Mr. Zhurbins plans.

title: Ares Management Slumps in Trading Debut
description: The stock market is greeting the initial public offering of Ares Management, a private equity and debt investing firm, with a shrug.

title: Going It Alone
description: I have always disliked brokers. When my husband and I first set out to buy an apartment in 2004, we felt harassed by the pushy hoverers who chased us with sign-in sheets and referred to closets as baby nooks. It seemed their only goal was to create an unwarranted frenzy over each unit as a way of getting some idiot to pay far too much.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Love and Treasure
description: This week, Ayelet Waldman talks about her new novel, Love and Treasure; John Williams on the weeks literary news; Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss movies about writers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: In Champions League Final, a Battle for the Hearts of Madrid
description: After another season of big occasions and very big spending, the most important club soccer competition in the world has boiled down not to an international duel between economic equals but to an intercity derbi between neighbors of disparate means.

title: A Voice of Dissent in Egypt Is Muffled, but Not Silent
description: CAIRO  CRITICS here called his films vulgar and damaging to the publics taste. When the Muslim Brotherhood came to power last year, one Islamist preacher called him Satans prayer caller. But after two decades of mocking the powerful as a popular columnist and screenwriter, only now has Belal Fadl been blacklisted.

title: A Reading of Cunning and Greed by Robert Pinsky
description: The American poet reads his meditation on agricultural greed.

title: My Civil War
description: As a teenager growing up in the piney woods of Winn Parish, La., I frequently looked out our front window to see an old man in well-worn overalls gingerly climb over the fence and walk up the hill toward the house.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Love and Treasure
description: This week, Ayelet Waldman, Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens.

title: Movie Review: The Amazing Spider-Man 2
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Amazing Spider-Man 2.

title: Movie Review: Belle
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Belle.

title: Late-Morning Jolt: Subway Derailment in Queens Injures 19
description: The F train slithered across Woodside, Queens, without incident at first, its passengers bound for jobs and late-morning appointments in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: A Principled Warrior
description: On Feb. 22, 1848, Representative John Quincy Adams of Massachusetts collapsed over his desk on the House floor and slumped toward the carpet. He was carried to a nearby sofa and eventually transported upon it to the speakers office, where he died the next day. His only words upon that sofa were: This is the end of earth. I am composed. It was a fitting death scene for someone who had served 17 years in the House and emerged as one of his eras most magnetic men of conviction.

title: Word Wide Web
description: Earlier this year, one of those BuzzFeed quizzes that tempt the idle with spurious but irresistible personality tests asked web surfers to click a box to identify their worst fear, choosing among nine popular forms of dread. Many of the choices in the Fear category were unsurprising  Failure, Cancer, Dying Alone  but one stood apart: Suddenly Becoming Stupid. Who would have thought, in this age of gung-ho, market-driven anti-intellectualism, that anxiety about fading brainpower was sufficiently potent and widespread to go viral? Who knew it was even, as millennials say, a thing?

title: Residents Sue to Halt Closing of Brooklyn Assisted-Living Home
description: A group of residents of the Prospect Park Residence, an assisted-living center for older people in Brooklyn that is scheduled to shut down in June, filed a lawsuit on Friday against it and the State Health Department, seeking to halt the closing.

title: Tea Party Candidate in Kentucky Hits Snags
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  For Matt Bevin, the main challenger in the Republican primary to topple Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the campaign could be boiled down to this, his one chance to try to confront his opponent in person, in the crowded ballroom of a Marriott hotel.

title: Introducing The Data Boss: Making Smarter Decisions
description: I helped startRJMetricsin 2009 with a simple mission: to inspire and empower data-driven people. Today, our software helps hundreds of online businesses use their data to make smarter decisions and grow faster.

title: Movie Review: Ida
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Ida.

title: Honda Recalls 25,000 Odyssey Minivans for Air Bag Defect
description: Honda is recalling almost 25,000 Odyssey minivans from the 2014 model year in the United States for an air bag problem, according to a report the automaker posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Italian Confidence Undimmed by Statistics
description: THE Italian economy has been a laggard for years. In the final quarter of 2013, it registered scant growth of just 0.3 percent at an annual rate, and that was a great improvement. Before that, it had shrunk for nine consecutive quarters. The economy remains smaller than it was 14 years ago. Unemployment has climbed to nearly 13 percent, twice its level in early 2008.

title: Upper East Side Rowhouse Growth Spurt
description: When does a coherent row of brownstones become a miscellany of masonry? That point is nearing or even past for the rowhouses on the south side of East 69th Street, from Second to First Avenues. Thirty years ago they were a nearly uniform group of charming dwellings. Now the string has broken, and these little pearls are skittering across the floor.

title: Next Week on Retro Report
description: After the 1998 N.F.L. draft produced one of the greatest busts in history, what have we learned about the science of evaluating human talent? Visit NYTimes.com on Monday for the full story.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Making Men Marriageable
description: Continuing my recent series of posts offering what I hope is constructive criticism for anti-inequality liberals, let me addressthis recent piece from Naomi Cahn and June Carbone, two sociologists Ive both learned from and differed with in the past, in which they make a case for the wisdom of working-class single motherhood in an age of downscale male underemployment. Using the pseudonymous case of Lily, a single mom for whom the father of her baby, Carl, is more a burden than a helper, they argue that its often much more sensible for women who want children to get pregnant and raise them on their own than to hold out for a decent, productive, reliable man who may never actually materialize:

title: In Latest Government Shuffle, North Korean Leader Removes No. 2 Official From Top Posts
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has removed an official who was widely considered No. 2 in his government from top military and party posts, according to reports in the countrys state-run news media over the weekend.

title: Moogfest: Avant-Pop and Analog Geekery
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss why analog synthesizers and techno-futurism makes for an agreeable festival.

title: Exposing the Hypocrisies of the New York Liberal
description: This month is the 100th anniversary of the death of Jacob Riis, the Danish immigrant and celebrated chronicler of social malady whose outrage over turn-of-the-century inequities left him with plenty of psychic space to accommodate a full catalog of bigotries. Riiss compassion for the underclasses was of the kind never distant from disdain. In How the Other Half Lives, his classic exploration of slum life in New York City, he evinces equal horror at the conditions in which new immigrants are forced to live and the cultural characteristics he believes contribute to their depredations. Chinamen are lost in their opium haze; Southern Italians are complacent idiots.

title: Nissan Tests Self-Cleaning Car
description: Washing cars is enough of a chore that many people simply dont bother. But what if the car didnt have to be washed, but would still look clean?

title: Shelter From the Storm
