description: The seaside neighborhood of Rockaway, Queens, still piecing itself together a year and a half after Hurricane Sandy, has found its patron saint in Klaus Biesenbach, the most hospitable grill master in the art world.

title: Tips for Choosing Care for an Aging or Ailing Family Member
description: UNLIKE other areas of health care, the cost of hiring someone to help tend to an aging family member at home has been relatively stable.

title: Moogfest: Avant-Pop and Analog Geekery
description: This week on the Popcast, we check in on Moogfest, the annual festival in Asheville, N.C., that is named after the Moog (rhymes with vogue) brand of analog synthesizer. The companys founder, Bob Moog, lived in Asheville from 1978 until his death in 2005. (The instruments are still manufactured at the Moog factory there.)

title: Advice for Parents Touring Colleges: Dont Talk
description: Ask my son, who is a junior in high school, if he remembers the Great College Schlep of 2011 with his big sister and he will still fume that it was no kind of summer vacation. Maybe not, but on that virgin tour through 1,200 miles of Anywhere, U.S.A., my husband and I learned a lot about our daughter, the college applicant. She dreaded going away from home more than we realized. She worried about the transition from high school to college, panicking over whether she would she make friends there. She was also consumed with worry in equal parts over whether her roommate would be a psycho, and how she might handle Starbucks withdrawal.

title: Drink Your Greens
description: Ive never been one to eat or drink a particular food just because its good for you. So for years Ive been rolling my eyes whenever anyone starts talking about green smoothies or green drinks. I love greens, but not in my morning smoothie.

title: The Monster of Kings Island
description: The monsters of Southern Ohio had long wait lines and strict height requirements. But one behemoth in particular  a roller coaster called the Beast  served as a rite of passage for us kids of Cincinnati. Even before I saw the roller coaster, its infamy was scored in my mind by way of the Beasts ubiquitous logo: two manacled claws straddling a railroad track that disappeared into a fiery hellhole.

title: Who Made That Food Truck?
description: In 1872, a vendor named Walter Scott cut windows into a small covered wagon and parked it in front of a local newspaper office in Providence, R.I. Sitting on a box inside, he sold sandwiches with pies and coffee to journalists and pressmen working late.

title: Brother, Can You Spare Some Emphysema?
description: I dont smoke, but once or twice a year I have a cigarette with old friends. I bought a pack for one such evening, and only a few were consumed. On my way to work the next morning, I was about to throw it away, but then I saw a group of homeless people on the sidewalk. I gave the pack to the only woman in the bunch, and she accepted it with gratitude. Should I have thrown them away? MARK LESSARD, BROOKLYN

title: Reply All: The 4.20.14 Issue
description: HOW OBAMA GOT TO I DO ON SAME-SEX MARRIAGE

title: Dunkin Corn Pone
description: Talking birds and bees; King Solomons hot dog.

title: Where Brazilians Go to Splurge
description: Flush with time and money to spend, the well-to-do beneficiaries of Brazils recent boom times are eagerly traveling abroad. In 2013, an estimated 895,000 Brazilians visited New York, shopping for clothing, appliances, baby goods and electronics, while staying in high-end hotels and taking in Broadway shows. Fred Dixon, the chief executive of NYC & Company, the citys marketing and tourism organization, says Brazilians average about a week per visit; a few who were in town last month can be seen on the following pages. Because of sky-high taxes on imported goods in Brazil, many there find that shopping sprees in New York can pay for themselves. Theyre creating a love affair with New York, Dixon says, adding that the high-fashion, celebrity-oriented culture in the city fits right in with their lifestyle. They feel at home here. Julie Bosman

title: Ruth Reichl Ditches the Wigs for a New Disguise: Fiction
description: I see on your Twitter that you ate lobster for breakfast. I did. They were claws left over from dinner the other night.

title: Pfizer Has Yet to Make a Compelling Bid to AstraZenecas Shareholders
description: Pfizers courtship of AstraZeneca looks like a hate-hate relationship. In January, the British pharmaceutical firm AstraZeneca viewed its larger rivals takeover proposal of 46.61 pounds a share as too low on cash, too risky, and too cheap to even talk about. Pfizers latest proposal, an effort to get AstraZeneca to begin friendly talks, hasnt moved the needle much.

title: New Princess Diaries Books Coming, for Older and Younger Readers
description: When Meg Cabot published Forever Princess, the 10th volume (a few of them published in multiple parts) of her Princess Diaries series, in 2009, she announced that she would give her young princess, Mia Thermopolis, an indefinite break, and would take one herself. It made sense: the series had become a young adult megahit, with sales reportedly around five million copies, and had a couple of films in its wake; and now Mia was 18 years old, with her romantic life sorted out, and cracking the books at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Keeping It on the Road
description: Writing used to be a lonely business, but not anymore because of my friend Siri. What I especially like is how she is so nonjudgmental.

title: Image of the Day: May 2
Times Minute | Behind Sterlings Ouster
description: The role of Kevin Johnson in ousting the Clippers owner Donald Sterling. Also on the minute, a highly positive jobs report and the origins of the food truck.

title: Simplicity in the Midst of Complexity
description: Lets take a moment to consider the 10 artists in New York City Ballets exciting Festival of 21st-Century Choreographers at the David H. Koch Theater: Mauro Bigonzetti, William Forsythe, Benjamin Millepied, Justin Peck, Angelin Preljocaj, Alexei Ratmansky, Liam Scarlett, Richard Tanner, Christopher Wheeldon and the companys ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. (Does the French street artist J R, the mind behind the flashy new Les Bosquets, make 11?)

title: The Tale of Two Schools
description: Fieldston and University Heights are in the same borough but are worlds apart. How much understanding between their students can a well-told story bring?

title: Times Minute | Behind Sterlings Ouster
description: In the Video

title: A Botched Execution, 155 Years Ago
description: This week, the execution of a man in Oklahoma went wrong. On May 11, 1859, The Times reported the death of Michael McNamee, another botched execution.

title: Video Purports to Show Downed Helicopter
description: A leader of Pro-Russian separatists attempted to rally the citizens of Slovyansk against the government, as reports circulated of a downed Ukrainian helicopter.

title: One $10,000 Martini, Please
description: What 22 items can tell us about inequality in New York.

title: Hagel Urges European Allies to Increase Military Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a forceful case on Friday for European members of NATO to increase their military spending, calling Russias intervention in Ukraine a clarifying moment for the alliance.

title: A Preview of the Kentucky Derby
description: California Chrome is the early favorite to win the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Edgar Awards Handed Out for Top Mystery Works
description: William Kent Krueger walked off with the award for best novel for his Ordinary Grace (Simon & Schuster/Ataria) on Thursday night as the Mystery Writers of America presented the 2014 Edgar Awards at their annual banquet in New York. The awards honor the best mystery writing in several categories, including fiction, nonfiction and television. Mr. Kruegers book is about a mans look back at the summer of 1961 in Minnesota, when he was 13, and death assumed many forms.

title: All the Rage | Graffiti Made of Plants, Not Paint
description: In recent years, city walls have become fertile artistic ground  quite literally  for a new wave of graffiti art that uses live plants instead of paint. Many such artists borrow their secretive practices from tagger tradition, jealously guarding their walls and rarely revealing their locations. But as in the spray-can graffiti world, many also accept commissions from public or private organizations to spruce up the streetscape.

title: Exclusive Clip of The Double
description: Richard Ayoades new film is an adaptation of Dostoevskys The Double, starring Jesse Eisenberg as a man whose exact double and opposite shows up to work alongside him.

title: West Village Farmhouse
description: A historic five-story Federal-style brick townhouse at 21 West 10th Street, one of the most picturesque residential blocks in the West Village, is poised to enter the market at $23.9 million.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 41
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama tried to mend fences with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday, calling her one of my closest friends on the world stage. But Ms. Merkel replied tartly that Germany still had significant differences with the United States over surveillance practices and that it was too soon to return to business as usual.

title: On Court or Off, He Savors Assists
description: In Gang Related, Ramon Rodriguez portrays Ryan Lopez, the adopted son of a crime lord who infiltrates the Los Angeles Police Department to help his family keep ahead of the law. But while Mr. Rodriguezs real life doesnt have the heart-stopping close calls, underworld gore or angsty divided loyalties that riddle this new Fox series, starting May 22, his childhood was a textbook example of how a father figure  or three  can help put a troubled boy on the right path.

title: Spring Vegetable Stew With Artichokes and Fennel
description: This is inspired by a lush Sicilian springtime stew called fritteda that also includes peas and fava beans (and much more olive oil). This one is simpler, but equally sweet and heady because of all the fennel and the spring onions. I like to serve it with bow-tie pasta and a little Parmesan as a main dish, or with grains as part of a meal in a bowl. It also makes a delicious side dish with just about anything.

title: Inequality Has Been Going On Forever ... but That Doesnt Mean Its Inevitable
description: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long  in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones  that it has come to seem inevitable. It is no longer news that the affluent did better than everyone else during the booms of the 1980s and 90s and through the mediocre growth of this centurys first years. Or that the rich have recovered from the financial crisis far better than the rest of country.

title: Baked Frittata With Yogurt, Chard and Green Garlic
description: Inspired by the signature Provenal chard omelet called truccha, this beautiful baked frittata incorporates thick Greek yogurt and lots of green garlic. It will puff up in the oven, but then it settles back down. Use a generous bunch of chard for this  green, red or rainbow  and save the stalks to use in the chard stalk and chickpea pure that Im also posting this week. I like to serve the frittata at room temperature, or I grab a cold slice for lunch. Its a wonderfully portable dish.

title: Timeless Papua New Guinea
description: When the newsmagazine Vice made its debut on HBO last year with fast-paced segments on child suicide bombers in Afghanistan and Dennis Rodman in North Korea, some critics cried sensationalism.

title: Quinoa Bowl With Roasted Artichokes, Spring Onions, Peas and Garlic Yogurt
description: Theres a lot going on in this springtime meal in a bowl  the onions and peas are sweet, but the onions also have that lovely bitter-edged char, as do the artichokes, from roasting. I first roasted artichokes for a bulgur salad not too long ago, and now Im roasting them all the time. Roasting intensifies their flavor. Bulgur is also a great grain choice for this bowl.

title: A Mystery Endures in Beijings Old Legation Quarter
description: On a freezing January morning in 1937, the mutilated body of a beautiful 19-year-old British woman was found lying at the base of Fox Tower along old Pekings Ming dynasty protective wall. Her heart had been ripped out, her face slashed with a knife. Her head lay to the west, her feet to the east. Strangely, there was little blood.

title: Squid: Make It Tender, Make It Quick
description: If you are a calamari fan and you also care about choosing sustainable seafood, look no further. Get thee to a fishmonger and buy some squid. It wont set you back much; a pound of squid costs only a few dollars. By rights, something that tastes so good should cost a lot more.

title: Solo in Paris
description: Some go to La Coupole, the 87-year-old Art Deco brasserie in Montparnasse, to commune with friends; others, to dine with ghosts  Picasso, Piaf, Sartre, all former patrons. I went alone, to live in the present.

title: Stir-Fried Baby Turnips With Spring Onions, Green Garlic and Tofu
description: The fresh ginger Im finding at springtime farmers markets is new and juicy, like the spring garlic and onions. Im sure this is going to be just one of many springtime stir-fries, but right now its a favorite. Its inspired by an irresistible bunch of baby turnips I bought at a Sunday farmers market. The turnips were no bigger than a small round radish, but their greens were lush  I had about 6 cups of leaves after Id stripped them from the stems. Sweet spring onions and green garlic contrast beautifully with the bitter flavor of the turnip greens.

title: Chard Stalk, Chickpea, Tahini and Yogurt Dip
description: When youve bought a bunch of Swiss chard and used the leaves for another dish, like an oven-baked frittata with yogurt, Swiss chard and green garlic, save the stems. Then you can make this dip, which is a cross between hummus and classic Middle Eastern dip called silq bil tahina, made with chard stalks and tahini. Ive added lots of yogurt to the mix. I love to use some red chard stalks because they give the dip a beautiful pale pink hue.

title: Billions Not Required for Angel Investing
description: JUST about every major tech success  from Facebook to LinkedIn to Instagram  started with angel investors taking a chance. These risk takers ended up being richly rewarded for their early investments, and no doubt they have inspired would-be angels to search for the next big thing.

title: See It, Feel It, Touch It, Be Healed
description: Though she was one of Brazils most celebrated artists of the post-World War II era, Lygia Clark (1920-88) is not well known in the United States, a circumstance that should be corrected by Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988, beginning Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Clark started out as a maker of geometric abstractions under the influences of Klee, Mondrian and Lger. In the 1960s she was associated with Neo-Concretism, the Brazilian movement that insisted on the sensual and material  as opposed to intellectual  properties of paintings and sculpture, sometimes encouraging viewer interaction with objects and installations. After 1966, Clark claimed to have abandoned art. She shifted her approach away from creating conventional forms and toward a kind of art therapy that involved the application of materials and devices directly to the peoples bodies. Art was treated as a form of psychological healing. Her late works should be of particular interest to fans of socially engaged and otherwise participatory types of art making. (Through Aug. 24, 11 West 53rd Street, 212-708-9400, moma.org.)

title: Two Generations of New-Music Stars
description: A new-music great and a rising star both have tantalizing concerts on Saturday. The pianist Peter Serkin, 66, fresh off a recent Bartok triumph with the New York Philharmonic, arrives at the 92nd Street Y with a characteristically varied program. Stretching from the early Baroque composer Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck to three recent works by Charles Wuorinen, the evening also includes Carl Nielsen and Beethoven. (8 p.m., Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.)

title: In the Footsteps of the Founder
description: Since its founding in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa has been a home to, and champion of, brash and venturesome artists. This month, that East Village theater presents its annual La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, now in its ninth year, featuring more than 50 local and international artists (through May 25). In the first week, the festival hosts a benefit concert, Dancing for Japan 2014 (Wednesday), to support victims of the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami. Next, Miki Orihara, a longtime dancer for the Martha Graham Dance Company, will perform Resonance, a series of solos by modern-dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers (Thursday through May 11).

title: Onstage in Harlem, a Week of Jazz
description: The Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival, in its fourth year, rallies around a sense of place and the past, from a vantage that feels convincingly like the present. Running from Sunday through Saturday at more than half a dozen locations, it finds common ground for concert premieres, tributes and academic talks. On Monday at Mintons, for example, a 7:30 p.m. conversation about the bebop progenitor Charlie Parker, with the critic and biographer Stanley Crouch and the scholar Farah Jasmine Griffin, will be followed by a 10 p.m. jam session led by the alto saxophonist Antonio Hart, one of Parkers many heirs.

title: In Estate Planning, Family Isnt Always First
description: WHETHER its treasured pearl earrings or a vintage camera, a house or whats left of your life savings, deciding who should inherit your worldly goods means making sometimes wrenching choices. For older people without children, stepchildren or grandchildren, the decision can be even more complex.

title: Dirty Dancing Encouraged Here
description: Who needs two tickets to paradise when a spicy shimmy will do? Mario Lopez, the Season 3 runner-up on Dancing With the Stars, and his wife, Courtney, a Broadway hoofer, are proof. Their chemistry ignited while performing in a revival of A Chorus Line. Now the Lopezes are testing their theory in Love & Salsa, a new dating competition produced by him and hosted by her and having its debut Tuesday night at 10 on NUVOtv.

title: Kaboom!
description: Are all explosions the same? The Decorative Destruction Index.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: An African Safari for Families
description: Most safari camps in Africa either dont allow young children or they dont cater to their interests, but the New York- and Hong Kong-based outfitter Asia to Africa Safaris is offering a new family-friendly animal viewing trip.

title: Obama Orders Policy Review on Executions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared this weeks botched execution in Oklahoma deeply disturbing and directed the attorney general on Friday to review how the death penalty is applied in the United States at a time when it has become increasingly debated.

title: Teaching and Titillating, No Matter the Instrument
description: Sonny Rollins

title: Springtime at Carnegie Hall
description: Spring for Music, the annual weeklong festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, begins and ends with requiem settings: the New York premiere of Christopher Rouses Requiem, performed by Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic on Monday, and a little drama built around Mozarts Requiem, performed by Manfred Honeck and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra on May 10. Whether that framing came about by happenstance (unlikely, given the jesting proclivities of the festivals chief executive and artistic director, Thomas W. Morris) or by design, it is, alas, all too appropriate. Spring for Music, in only its fourth season, is evidently a goner.

title: A Choreographic Cross-Pollination
description: Sophie Claudel was living in Paris and working at the Pompidou Center when France Moves took over New York City. I heard a lot about it, she said over coffee, referring to the 2001 dance festival of French choreography. Her eyes widened with curiosity. I always thought, why shouldnt we try to do something?

title: Rivka Galchen on Comic Strips, Lucille Ball and What Shes Reading Now
description: Rivkas Galchens 2009 debut novel Atmospheric Disturbances was filled with pleasurably twisty sentences and casually engaging intellectualism, earning her effusive praise and comparisons to Jonathen Lethem, Thomas Pynchon and Jorge Luis Borges. Her new book, American Innovations (out May 6 from Farrar, Straus and Giroux) gathers 10 short stories  each written from a female perspective in response to a canonical work like Gogols The Nose and Borgess The Aleph  that are sharp and rich, astutely observed and wildly imaginative.

title: A Great War Reading List at PEN World Voices Festival
description: July is the centenary of the outbreak of World War I, but publishers got a major jump on the anniversary last year. Christopher Clarks The Sleepwalkers, Margaret Macmillans The War That Ended Peace, Max Hastingss Catastrophe 1914 and Sean McMeekins July 1914 were just four of the hundreds of books to mark the moment a year early. The deluge continues in 2014, with, well, The Deluge by Adam Tooze (coming in November), David Reynoldss The Long Shadow and many more.

title: A Love for the Classics Thats More Than Skin Deep
description: An old Ford and a young woman who appreciates tradition prove an ideal match.

title: New Inquiry Sought on Benghazi Attack
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday escalated their battle with the White House over the continuing investigations into the 2012 attack that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, ensuring that the issue will not recede in the midst of a fierce partisan fight for control of Congress.

title: Car Bombs in Central Syria Kill at Least 19
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the latest strike in a rapid-fire series of bloody attacks on children and other civilians in Syria, two car bombs exploded in the central province of Hama on Friday, killing at least 19 people, including 11 children, Syrian state news media reported, blaming insurgents.

title: Readers Get to Weigh In on Apologies
description: When Andrew Ross Sorkin and I came together to start Apology Watch, our goal was to elevate the conversation about authentic apologies. In that vein, we are introducing an Apology Metric survey to give readers an opportunity to share their insight. Through these surveys, we hope to change the shortsighted lens through which apologies are typically viewed. People review them as theatrical performances for a few days and quickly forget about them. Instead, as Ive argued before, we ought to track the apologizers behavior over time to see whether he or she has genuinely committed to a new course of action, which is why we are offering these surveys.

title: G.M. Talks to Families With Claims Over Defects
description: The lawyer hired by General Motors to explore compensating victims of cars with a defective ignition switch met on Friday with a representative of hundreds of people and their families who say they were affected by accidents involving the vehicles.

title: Life Sentence Is Imposed in 08 Killing of Therapist
description: Slouching over the defense table in the stained, gray sweat clothes he wore throughout his trial, David Tarloff finally got a chance to speak on Friday in the Manhattan courtroom where his sanity had been debated for weeks.

title: Audi Sticks With a Winning Formula
description: Audis A3 sedan, new for 2015, is a car that buyers think they already know, one that instantly elicits warm and cuddly expectations.

title: Yet More of the Wait and See Strategy on Ukraine
description: As the situation deteriorated further in Ukraine on Friday, the American president and Europes most powerful leader met at the White House.

title: On Kentucky Derby Weekend, a Tea Party Julep for Mitch McConnell
description: If Senator Mitch McConnell has to hear one more ad saying he has betrayed Kentuckys conservative values, hell probably want a drink. Fortunately, in addition to being a symbol of conservative activism, tea is also an infusion that pairs well with bourbon. At least, thats what we heard from Sachin Hasan of Manhattans Pierre Hotel, who discussed tea-bourbon drinks with T Magazine back in January.

title: Penguins Discuss Line Strategy and Tiring Out the Rangers
description: PITTSBURGH  For an N.H.L. coach, the Pittsburgh Penguins Dan Bylsma is refreshingly open about tactics.

title: Listen Up | A Ghostly Hymn From Your New Swedish Obsession
description: Alice Boman wrote and recorded her new song, Over, alone in her apartment in Malmo, Sweden. I didnt know it was going to be released, she says of the hauntingly spare recording, which will appear on her new release, EP II, out June 3 via the Control Group. This intimate, lo-fi approach is characteristic of the soft-spoken singer-songwriters work. Her first EP, last years Skisser (Swedish for sketches), earned raves for its minimal arrangements and simple, heartbreaking lyrics. She tried to capture the same magic with EP II, cutting more tracks at home and, at one point, holing up in a cabin in the Swedish woods to record her ethereal sounds. The rustic setting  Boman says she had to trek to a neighbors to fetch water each day  proved a fitting backdrop for the 26-year-olds elegiac, if oddly uplifting, tunes. It was beautiful, she says.

title: Book Review Podcast: Ayelet Waldmans Love and Treasure
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Catherine Taylor reviews Ayelet Waldmans new novel, Love and Treasure. The book features the so-called Hungarian Gold Train, which held property requisitioned by the Nazis from Hungarys Jewish citizens. Ms. Taylor writes:

title: For This Wedding, the Roundtable Reconvenes
description: When Shaun Cherewich, a retired high school teacher and coach, says hes old-fashioned, hes not talking raccoon coats and jitterbugging. Hes talking about going way back  all the way to Europes medieval period.

title: Taking a Spin: Everything Comes Up Republican
description: My inaugural weekly spin of the wheels on The Upshots Senate model, named Leo, gave Democrats a dream outcome: 54 Senate seats. In perhaps the surest indication of the uncertainty that remains at this early stage, my spin this week yields the exact opposite result: 54 seats for Republicans.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Black Tie? How About Black Mouse Ears?
description: When LeslieAnn Dunn was married in Central Park last July, she asked her guests to wear summer black and white with a splash of yellow so her wedding photos would have a cohesive look. Most guests followed her color scheme, and yellow popped up in nail polish, bow ties and flowers.

title: New Faces Bringing the Heat in Summer Movies
description: Ellar Coltrane, Boyhood

title: A Love Letter to Fiamma Ferragamo
description: The women of the Ferragamo family pay tribute to Fiamma, the iconic designer, beloved daughter, sister and aunt who died in 1998.

title: With Hindsight in the Rearview Mirror
description: In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the story of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

title: The Gun Report: May 2, 2014
description: This week, a firearms investigation unit of the N.Y.P.D.and a unit from the Brooklyn district attorneys office shut down a weapons pipeline from Georgia to New York. Among the hundreds of guns seized were an AR-15, a MAC-11, two TEC-9 semi-automatic handguns and a Taurus .380-caliber semi-automatic pistol.

title: Hip-Hops New New York
description: When I ventured into the underground rap world of New York City, I discovered a tight community, a new wave of artists, the New New York. Many of them performed on the Beast Coastal tour. They grew up together or met through hip-hop and have now created something of a family. Their sense of brotherhood inspired me to start photographing rap shows.

title: Hundreds of Afghans Are Killed in Landslides
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Huge landslides caused by heavy rainfall buried hundreds of houses in a remote area of northeastern Afghanistan on Friday. As many as 2,500 people were said to be missing in the disaster, one of the worst to hit the war-torn country in at least a decade.

title: Memos to Hollywood
description: Summer is sequel season, when the movie studios celebrate their lack of imagination by disguising it as populism. Why should movie critics be any different? Five years ago, we published the first installment of our Memos to Hollywood, in which we presumed to give advice to everyone involved in the making, distributing and watching of movies. And now were back with another spectacular, game-changing, blockbuster episode. This time, theyll pay attention.

title: A Long and Questionable Record in Sales
description: The sign on the door of the building on Eighth Avenue hard by Pennsylvania Station reads Vigilant Hotel. It is handwritten on cardboard. The Vigilant is a mens-only, single-room-occupancy dwelling, the sort that lined the Bowery and its skid row a generation ago. Rooms go for $150 a week.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: How Not to Pick Judges
description: ROCHESTER  RESEARCH has long shown that female judges vote differently from men on issues of sex discrimination, harassment and sentencing, while black judges vote differently from whites on issues involving civil rights and affirmative action.

title: Singing an Ode to the Naked City
description: In 2006, while the Irish writer-director John Carney was promoting his indie musical film Once, he fell hard for New York City. Literally. Cycling around, going the wrong way down one-way streets, I got the feel of living here, Mr. Carney said, adding that when he crashed that bike, he admired the efficiency with which New Yorkers stopped for the minimal amount of time to make sure I wasnt dead.

title: Naismiths Choices on Race, From Basketballs Beginnings
description: At the end of a week in which the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling became, for a moment, the most talked-about man in basketball, lets rewind the historical videotape and remember the Canadian-born farmer-chaplain-physician who invented the game. Here is James Naismith in 1928, holding a peach basket for his wife, Maude, to make a shot. Naismith seems now like an anachronistic figure, yet even nearly a century ago he too had to make serious choices about issues like race and money in basketball.

title: Big Ticket | For $26.6 Million, a Penthouse in SoHo With a Lawn on the Terrace
description: A SoHo artists studio that underwent a radical transformation from an airy but spartan loft to a sybaritic 7,200-square-foot luxury penthouse sold for $26,580,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Weekend Reading: Targeting Big Banks. No, Not Those Big Banks.
description: The news this week that federal prosecutors were nearing criminal charges against a French bank and a Swiss bank received a mixed reaction from a public weary over the mantra that Wall Street is too big to jail.

title: The Peripatetic Physician
description: Dr. Bernt Nesje, 67, says he has two guidelines for taking on patients: They must live in or around Greenwich Village, and they have to be older than me.

title: Think Like a Doctor: 18-Year Rash Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 40-year-old woman had a rash on her hands for nearly two decades. I thought this was a really tough case. Apparently, so did my readers. Nearly 300 of you wrote in with some very thoughtful suggestions, but only five were able to make the diagnosis.

title: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
description: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long  in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones  that it has come to seem inevitable. But inequality is not inevitable. Many societies, including the United States, have found ways to reduce inequality and lift living standards for the middle class and the poor.

title: Small and City-Smart, Microvans Proliferate
description: If Americans found the arrival of the Ford Transit Connect in North America in 2009 a bit unsettling, by now they have become accustomed to its upright and somewhat ungainly shape. In just a few years, small cargo vans have become a familiar sight in American cities  and Fords competitors are taking notice.

title: If Your Bucket List Includes a Taco Truck
description: TESTED 2014 Ram ProMaster

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Sudan, Ukraine and Washington.

title: A Fraud Case Offers a Cautionary Tale of Finance
description: TWO decades. Twenty-six million dollars. Almost 2,000 victims. Seven guilty defendants.

title: Wheelies: The Car Show Season Opener Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Review: 2014 Ford Fiesta ST
description: For those who love to drive, the ST truly is a Fiesta. Party on!

title: In the Moment, Connecting and Questioning
description: Jess Dugans portraits engage her subjects in a visual conversation and ask viewers to rethink their notions of identity and community.

title: Consider It a Sequel to a Hit From the 90s
description: Reruns are comforting. Gilligan always screws up the rescue, Lucy gets smashed on Vitameatavegamin every single time, and no characters on Seinfeld remain masters of their domain. At some point its not about laughing at all the jokes, its the satisfaction of knowing all the jokes.

title: Jil Sanders New Creative Director, Diane Keatons Kooky Sale and Stella McCartneys Designs for Kids
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: More Pickup Buyers Opt for V6s
description: Its much too soon for a retirement party, but the V8 engine seems to be losing its clout with buyers of full-size pickup trucks. For the first time in about 50 years, many big-truck customers no longer consider a 6-cylinder engine to be a downgrade.

title: Her True Colors, in Plain View
description: EAST MEADOW, N.Y.  Over a lunch of grilled cheese sandwiches at Panera Bread on Hempstead Turnpike here, Kim Schreier told the stories behind the tattoos that, she said, covered some 60 percent of her body.

title: The New Firefox Is Fantastic. So Is Every Other Web Browser.
description: Mozilla has just released the latest upgrade to Firefox, its popular open-source browser. Were at version 29 now, which as software goes is pretty long in the tooth.

title: Obama and Merkel on Ukraine
description: The president and the visiting Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany delivered remarks on finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis in Ukraine.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Week in Pictures for May 2
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: A Teachers Contract for New York
description: There was no snarling at City Hall when Mayor Bill de Blasio and the teachers union announced a very significant labor agreement on Thursday. Dispensing with the unproductive tension that tarnished the Bloomberg administration, the two sides showed that real progress can be made  on both the fiscal and the educational sides of the contract  when there is good will instead of disdain. On the whole, the agreement represents a good deal for the city and its students, though there were several missed opportunities and unanswered questions.

title: Friday Night Music: Alison Krauss
description: Too busy to post much. But on Wednesday there was a lovely memorial event for Jerry (George W) Goodman, aka Adam Smith, that among other things highlighted his love of music, and included performances of some of his favorites  including this piece.

title: Now Screening | A Comedy Director Gets Serious
description: In Richard Ayoades film, The Double, the quiet, self-conscious office clerk Simon James (played by Jesse Eisenberg) is struggling through a work day when he is suddenly confronted with his doppelgnger: exact in physique, but opposite in temperament. Arrogant, suave and irresistible to women, James Simon (also played by Eisenberg) glides into Simons life, throwing light on his weaknesses and self-loathing, and preying on his love interest Hannah (played by Mia Wasikowska). Nothing ever seems to go right for Simon, while everything is perfect for James. Based on Fyodor Dostoyevskys novella, the story delves into questions of identity, psychosis and self-preservation with absurd and sometimes agonizing humor. A seasoned comedian, the British director can draw a link between Dostoyevskys piercing insight and Larry Davids brazen style: Hes really willing to go to un-noble places in people.

title: Outdoor Trips With a Fitness Focus
description: Travelers who cant sit still have a new outings option. Two high-profile brands in the active lifestyle and fitness worlds are teaming up to offer Reebok Fitness Vacations by Austin Adventures.

title: A New Benefit for Heart Failure Patients
description: The number of older heart failure patients who qualify to enter a cardiac rehabilitation program paid for by Medicare has just been vastly expanded. About two million people are newly eligible, Medicare officials estimate.

title: Suspenseful Last Note for a Tribute to Britten
description: Last fall Carnegie Hall commemorated the centennial of Benjamin Brittens birth with a substantive festival highlighted by an inspired concert performance of the opera Peter Grimes. That event, featuring an outstanding cast of singers and David Robertson conducting the St. Louis Symphony, took place on Nov. 22, 2013, the 100th anniversary of the composers birth.

title: Troubles for Icarus and His Father
description: Were No. 1! Were No. 1!

title: Sass of a Blues Mama, the Skill of a Stage Star
description: As her big eyes widen, and her lusty voice peels away protective layers of pop decorum, Lillias White expresses the drive and critical intelligence of a 62-year-old dynamo who needs extra space to reveal her full, complicated self.

title: What Is the Role of Nurse Practitioners?
Why Religious Literacy Is Important in Our Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheering a Revival of Interest in James Baldwin
Video: The Ford Fiesta ST Is a Party on Wheels
description: A 197-horsepower car is not the kind of machine that gets acceleration addicts excited. A basic V6 Mustang delivers 305. The V8 GT has 402. But 197?

title: Support for Casinos
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | Seasoned
description: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature.

title: Revenge, My Lovely
description: OSLO  I WAS lying in bed thinking about how I tortured the man who had raped my partner, how I made sure he didnt die at once but still experienced some of the fear and physical suffering he had inflicted upon this innocent woman beside me, who had escaped by the skin of her teeth. Half-asleep, I smiled, warmed by the duvet and the glow of revenge and slept like a baby. The latter, I hope, because there had in fact been no rape, no rapist, no torture.

title: Now That Sugar Man Is Found, Lawsuit Focuses on Missing Royalties
description: The documentary Searching for Sugar Man tells the story of Rodriguez, an obscure singer-songwriter from Detroit whose albums were commercial flops when released in the early 1970s, but  unknown to Rodriguez and everyone around him  later became gigantic hits in South Africa.

title: Selling a Fake Painting Takes More Than a Good Artist
description: The recent arrest in Spain of two brothers accused of passing off forged paintings as the work of Americas greatest Modernist masters has refocused attention on the people behind an art fraud that has lasted 15 years, garnered $80 million and helped bring down New Yorks oldest gallery, Knoedler & Company.

title: Bill Cunningham | Seasoned
description: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature. The spring coat has disappeared, replaced with the short jacket. Most popular is the biker style, worn with fluid trousers or distressed jeans. No fashion trend dominates, but the haberdashers look, with a masculine hair style, left, is strong. Black remains popular with city women, but light pastels have their own fashion force. The parks are spectacular with flowers, and trees with leaves as fresh as new grass.

title: Evening Hours | Dodging the Raindrops
description: A wet spring couldnt slow down the whirl of parties.

title: Summer Movie Release Schedule
description: Yes, Scarlett Johansson wakes up with superpowers and takes no prisoners, but the season isnt totally about would-be action blockbusters. Philip Seymour Hoffman gifts us with two posthumous performances, as a blue-collar American loser and as a powerful German spy. Documentaries explore a dizzying range of topics, including legal marijuana, the war in Afghanistan, breast-feeding and the Koch brothers. And climate change rears its plot-driving head, ready to replace midcentury nuclear testing as the villain in sci-fi and futurist fantasies.

title: Under Cover: Body Language Tells the Story
description: This weeks cover features two students from schools that are located in the Bronx but exist worlds apart.

title: Taking Fares, and Writing in Between
description: CHICAGO  In the Arab world, the Syrian writer Osama Alomar has a growing reputation as the author of short, clever parables that comment obliquely on political and social issues. But here, where he has lived in exile since 2008, he spends most of his time as the driver of Car 45 at the Horizon Taxi Cab company.

title: Cruelty, Class and Corruption
description: Ugly is as ugly does, and ugliness is everywhere in Anurag Kashyaps new film, which opens the 14th-annual New York Indian Film Festival on Monday. With Ugly, part of last years Directors Fortnight at Cannes, Mr. Kashyap, an interesting if uneven director, delivers a damning, noirish tale about the corruption that comes after a 10-year-old girls kidnapping.

title: Torch Solo, Then Jammy Time
description: A few months ago, a little girl with a big voice grew too tall to be Matilda on Broadway anymore.

title: A Concert for Characters
description: A rat who dreams of cooking haute cuisine. A more or less silent robot in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. A grumpy old widower nursing a demented notion. These are just a few of the improbable heroes that Pixar, the animation studio, has brought to astonishing, and astonishingly profitable, life since its first full-length picture, Toy Story, in 1995.

title: Hey, Jack, Youre Back! Anything New?
description: There is a Persian custom that could probably improve television.

title: First U.S. Case of MERS Virus Is Found in Indiana Man Who Visited Mideast
description: A virus that has killed more than 100 people in the Middle East has been found in the United States for the first time, in an Indiana health care worker who recently returned from Saudi Arabia, federal health officials said on Friday.

title: Art Bound by Its Time
description: One of the most pervasive issues in modern dance is relevance. How does a company formed in 1946 find meaning in todays world? The Limn Dance Company, created by Jos Limn and Doris Humphrey, is an integral part of American dance history, yet the troupe, performing at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, is trapped in another age.

title: Done In by Dcolletage and Defeatism
description: A beautiful woman leaves a bar and goes home with James Marsden. And that is just about the only thing that makes sense in Walk of Shame.

title: Vying for Bragging Rights, Prancing Pros and Amateurs
description: As the famed house music D.J. Todd Terry was playing Thursday night, it was difficult to know what direction to look in. On one part of the floor of the Brooklyn Night Bazaar, a circle of people watched dancers working quick, smooth routines before ceding the floor. Nearby, another circle oohed and aahed over a man who made a lighted cigarette disappear and reappear in his mouth.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 534 said they were interested in following professional basketball.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States.

title: Sinn Fein Leaders Time in Jail Is Extended, as Party Sees Political Motives by Police
description: LONDON  The Northern Ireland police were granted permission on Friday to keep Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, in custody for another 48 hours for questioning about a gruesome 1972 murder. His party claimed that the police were playing politics before the local and European parliamentary elections this month.

title: Defining an Online Phenomenon: Virtuoso or a Wedding Band Star?
description: One of the most unlikely music phenomena of recent years has been Lindsey Stirling, whose classical-meets-dance music has catapulted her to huge online popularity, with her videos having been viewed hundreds of millions of times. This week Ms. Stirling released her second album, Shatter Me (Lindseystomp). In an email exchange, two critics for The New York Times  Jon Caramanica, whose specialty is pop, and Zachary Woolfe, whose area is classical  discussed Ms. Stirling, her gifts and where she fits into the music world. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

title: Oakland: Brooklyn by the Bay
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  On a recent Tuesday afternoon, a group of well-dressed and soon-to-be well-groomed men sat patiently in the sun outside Temescal Alley Barbershop waiting for $25 haircuts and $30 straight-razor shaves. Some idly pecked at their phones, while others wandered into Standard & Strange, a mens clothing store that stocks rugged-looking American-made apparel and accessories as well as some carefully selected items from overseas like Tender jeans, which are handmade and dyed by one guy in Britain and sell for $350. (A leather belt thick enough to harness a thoroughbred, also from Tender, will set you back $240.)

title: Norman Kay Platinum Pairs
description: DALLAS  The International Bridge Press Association hands out annual awards for excellence in bidding and play. The diagramed deal is a front-runner for the defense of the year. It occurred on the last day of the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs during the Spring North American Championships and was described by the victim, Sartaj Hans from Australia (South).

title: Lizzy Plapinger of MS MR: The Melody Maker
description: AGE 25

title: In the Spin Zone, Words Around
description: D.J. Cassidy, who might call himself the first D.J. of the United States (he played at both inaugurations for President Obama, as well as the 50th birthday parties for both of the Obamas) began his night like any music impresario: in the back of an S.U.V.

title: With Bravado and Bravos
description: In the kitchen of a 1940s-era diner in Jersey City, the rapper known as Le1f swayed beneath ancient photos of Sylvester Stallone and Mike Tyson.

title: Life Is Streaming Past You
description: When Beyonc released, without warning, 17 videos around midnight on Dec. 13, millions of fans rejoiced. As a more casual listener of Ms. Knowles, I balked at the onslaught of new material and watched a few videos before throwing in the towel.

title: The Piano, More Than a Partner in These Dances
description: Ballet companies usually like to tuck contemporary work safely between some tutus, carefully sheltering their audiences delicate sensibilities. Not New York City Ballet. (Hooray.) Program 3 of the Festival of 21st-Century Choreographers on Thursday was fairly austere, notable for its impressive musical range, with several scores commissioned by City Ballet.

title: Does Sperm Donor Mean Dad?
description: LOS ANGELES  He is a movie star who shot to fame on a motorcycle in The Lost Boys. She is a California massage therapist from a prominent East Coast family. Four years ago, with his sperm, her eggs and the wonder of in vitro fertilization, they produced a child.

title: They Feel Blessed
description: Here are a few of the ways that God has touched my social network over the past few months:

title: Subversive, but Colorfully So
description: The phantasmagorical works created by the Brazilian-born installation artist Eli Sudbrack, who goes by the acronym AVAF (for Assume Vivid Astro Focus), are dense with connections: sexual, geographic, macroeconomic, social and political.

title: Rule 1: No I Do via Twitter
description: After accepting her boyfriends marriage proposal, Sarah Nolting of Columbus, Ind., did what most modern brides do: She announced her engagement to her Facebook friends.

title: Vatican Dialogue: Man is a Technical Giant and an Ethical Child
description: VATICAN CITY  Birth control.

title: A Divided Country
description: As the separatist movement in eastern Ukraine grows, the divisions within Ukrainian society become deeper as both sides prepare for a potential confrontation.

title: Our Lonely Home in Nature
description: THE tornadoes that have been devastating parts of the South and Midwest, just weeks after a deadly mudslide in Washington, demonstrate once again the unimaginable power of nature.

title: At Princeton, Privilege Is: (a) Commonplace, (b) Misunderstood or (c) Frowned Upon
description: It is a familiar phrase on college campuses, often meant to serve as conversational kryptonite, the final word in an argument to which there is no response.

title: Michigan: Retirees Agree to Cuts
description: Leaders of a group of retired Detroit workers have agreed to accept pension cuts, the latest in a series of tentative settlements secured by the city as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy this fall, officials said Friday. Directors of the Detroit Retired City Employees Association, representing nearly 8,000 municipal retirees, have agreed to cuts of 4.5 percent to retirees pension benefits, a likely end to cost-of-living increases and changes to health care coverage. The cuts were smaller than the city had initially proposed.

title: Can Technology Save the World? Experts Disagree
description: In Silicon Valley, there is a sense that tech companies are doing Gods work. Software can solve the worlds biggest problems, many tech entrepreneurs believe, if only it is put to the right use.

title: Dont Ignore Northern Irelands Ghosts
description: BELFAST

title: A Lost Boy, Trying to Find His Way
description: If you have a very good eye, you might recognize Harry Melling as the fine young actor who made such a tender Fool to Frank Langellas King Lear at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this year. More likely, Mr. Melling looks familiar  grown-up and slimmed down though he is  for having played Dudley Dursley, Harry Potters beastly Muggle cousin, in the film series adapted from J. K. Rowlings books.

title: Accident Leads to Scrutiny of Oil Sand Production
description: CALGARY, Alberta  In the annals of oil well blowouts and pipeline disasters, the 7,400 barrels of oily slush that oozed out of the mossy bogs of the boreal forest in northeast Alberta last summer may seem like a trivial matter.

title: Democrats Struggle to Turn Economic Gains Into Political Ones
description: WASHINGTON  Aprils sharp and unexpected drop in the nations unemployment rate is a springtime gift to President Obama, whose sagging political fortunes could brighten if the burst of job creation holds by the midterm elections this fall.

title: Plying Social Media, Chinese Workers Grow Bolder in Exerting Clout
description: DONGGUAN, China  The call to action, carried by social media to thousands of smartphones across this bleak factory town, roused the workers from their jobs making Nike and Adidas sneakers.

title: A Plays View of a Bigoted Past Holds a Mirror to a Violent Present
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.  Kate Haugan was standing backstage early that afternoon about three weeks ago, waiting to be fitted with a wireless microphone. In less than an hour, she and the rest of the cast members would take the stage at the Jewish Community Center here for the final performance of To Kill a Mockingbird.

title: Juan Formell, 71, Cuban Dance-Band Leader, Dies
description: Juan Formell, the Cuban composer, arranger and bass player who founded the group Los Van Van and made it into one of the worlds greatest dance bands, died on Thursday. He was 71 and lived in Havana.

title: End Corporate Taxation
description: AFTER years of post-recession somnolence, corporate takeovers and mergers have ballooned to their highest level since 2007, fueled in part by American companies fleeing the United States to save tax dollars.

title: Fans Weigh In on the Donald Sterling Controversy
description: This New York Times/CBS News poll is based on nationwide interviews with 534 basketball fans conducted on landlines and cellphones from April 30 through May 1.

title: Mixed Verdict in Apple-Samsung Patent Fight
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  A federal jury said on Friday that Apple and Samsung had infringed on each others patents in some mobile devices but awarded most of the damages to Apple, in the latest court fight between the two technology giants.

title: Teachers Question Pay-for-Performance Element in Proposed Contract
description: It is a concept sprung from the marketplace, and was long a gleam in Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs eye: offering extra pay for the citys best public school teachers.

title: Washington Weighs in on Campus Assaults
description: It keeps happening. One student sexually assaults another on campus. College administrators discourage the victim from opening a case against her assailant or take their time launching an investigation; meanwhile, the two keep living together in the same dorm. Eventually the victim speaks out or files a Title IX complaint and attracts national media attention. The administration pledges to improve its handling of these situations.

title: Let Mr. Erdogan Fight His Own Battles
description: Not long ago, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish preacher in Pennsylvania, were the best of allies. Mr. Erdogan heads an Islamist government, and Mr. Gulen promotes a moderate, pro-Western brand of Sunni Islam that appeals to many well-educated and professional Turks. The two men had a common purpose in confronting and weakening the countrys once-dominant secular military and political leadership.

title: Long Journey to a Rivalrys Signature Series
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  A 30-mile stretch of Interstate 5 separates the home arenas of the Anaheim Ducks and the Los Angeles Kings, but it has taken 20 years for the teams to meet in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Democratic Group to Return Donations
description: MIAMI  The Democratic National Committee, faced with the possibility that it had accepted illegal campaign contributions from straw donors, decided Thursday to return sizable donations made last fall in the names of the children of a Florida cardiologist whose lucrative medical practice has caught the attention of Medicare regulators.

title: Marcel Van Ooyen: Helping Flowers, Herbs and Sons Grow
description: Marcel Van Ooyen is the executive director of GrowNYC, a nonprofit group that operates more than 50 greenmarkets and builds community and school gardens around the city. Previously legislative director for the City Council under former Speaker Gifford Miller, Mr. Van Ooyen, 49, lives in a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with his wife, Cheryl, 48, an executive creative director at an advertising agency, McGarryBowen, and their two sons, Jack, 11, and Jude, 7. They have a rescue dog, Bubba. They think he is an Italian mastiff.

title: Teenager Pleads Not Guilty in Killing on Bus
description: The 14-year-old accused of murder for firing a gun aboard a New York City bus asked investigators whom he had shot, according to court documents released on Friday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 2, 2014
Government Nurtures Innovation
description: Jim Manzi is the founder and chairman of Applied Predictive Technologies, and one of the originators of cloud computing. He is also a well-known libertarian/conservative thinker, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, and a contributing editor to the National Review. Between his tech background and his politics, hes about the last person youd expect to praise the historic role government has played in the critical business of innovation  or to call for that role to be stepped up in the here and now.

title: In Surveillance Debate, White House Turns Its Focus to Silicon Valley
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly a year after the first disclosures about the National Security Agencys surveillance practices at home and abroad, the agency is emerging with mandates to make only modest changes: some new limits on what kind of data about Americans it can hold, and White House oversight of which foreign leaders cellphones it can tap and when it can conduct cyberoperations against adversaries.

title: Where Pedestrians and Bicyclists Are Injured, and Why
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios goal of eliminating pedestrians deaths on New York streets will have to overcome a volatile mix of harried drivers, fast-moving bikers and distracted walkers.

title: Struck on the Street: Four Survivors
description: Dance with me, baby, the night nurse crooned to me. Despite the morphine-induced fog clouding my brain that first week after the accident, I understood that she meant I was to collapse into her arms. Then, holding me like a limp rag doll, she lifted me upright and held my full weight. The new perspective was dizzying, since Id been on my back, looking up, since the cops and the medics got to me.

title: Bidders Lining Up Lobbyists in Fight for New York Casinos
description: ALBANY  The 22 entities vying to build casinos in New York State include operators of some of the flashiest gambling palaces, from Las Vegas to Singapore. Others are mysterious paper-only creatures with no websites, no offices and not so much as a slot machine to call their own.

title: Celebrating Sainthood and Witnessing Barbarity
description: The Catholic Churchs canonization of two of its recent popes and the grotesquely botched execution of a murderer in Oklahoma last week stood at opposite ends of the moral scale. Yet there was something about the two events  the public affirmation of a religious order in the one and the medieval barbarity of the other  that seemed to challenge the popular image of a linear march of human progress.

title: Spit It All Out, Tour Golfers: Few Speak of Tobacco Habit
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  What crosses the lips of PGA Tour players, but makes them hold their tongues?

title: For Game of Thrones, Rising Unease Over Rapes Recurring Role
description: From its very beginnings, Game of Thrones has been riddled with sexual brutality. The franchise, which started as a series of fantasy novels by George R. R. Martin about a bleak, feudal world, has at various times included a warrior king who claims his child bride on their wedding night, and the gang rape of a young woman by half a hundred shouting men behind a tanners shop.

title: Death Stalks Muslims as Myanmar Cuts Off Aid
description: SITTWE, Myanmar  By the time the baby girl was brought to the makeshift pharmacy, her chest was heaving, her temperature soaring. The supply of oxygen that might have helped was now off limits, in a Doctors Without Borders clinic shut down by the government in February.

title: George R.R. Martin on Game of Thrones and Sexual Violence
description: The fantasy series Game of Thrones has set off a wide-ranging debate about rape, and whether this popular franchise  which includes best-selling novels, a hit HBO television adaptation, a line of comic books and more  trivializes sexual violence with its frequent and often graphic depictions.

title: Anthony Drexel Duke, 95, Dies; Scion of Wealth Aided Underprivileged
description: Anthony Drexel Duke, a scion of three of Americas wealthiest families who nearly 80 years ago was prompted by a chance encounter to found what became Boys & Girls Harbor, an educational and social service agency that has helped tens of thousands of New Yorks disadvantaged children, died on Wednesday in Gainesville, Fla. He was 95.

title: Derby Dawns for Two Sons Seeking Win Fathers Missed
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  To anyone who follows horse racing, Allen Jerkens is known as the Giant Killer. He is the Hall of Fame trainer whose horses beat the Triple Crown champion Secretariat twice and the great Kelso three times. He is a legend who is rightfully on the short list in the discussion of historys greatest horsemen.

title: Kid Getting Into Treble
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This one was a tough one to get into, but sublime once gotten. Thank goodness for the comforting familiarity of Beatles lyrics. SHE cracked the puzzle open for me.

title: How The Industry Fared In April
description: Overall vehicle sales in the United States rose 8 percent last month.

title: Aboard Untapable, Jockey Napravnik Wins a Second Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  After a blunder at the starting gate unnerved the fillies and unseated a few jockeys Friday, Rosie Napravnik displayed the kind of steady nerves that allowed her to make history two years ago in the Kentucky Oaks.

title: Assi Dayan, a Celebrated Actor and Filmmaker in Israel, Dies at 68
description: JERUSALEM  Assi Dayan, an actor, director and screenwriter who was celebrated for his contributions to Israeli film and culture and infamous for his turbulent personal life  much of it, he complained, spent in the shadow of his father, the general and statesman Moshe Dayan  died on Thursday at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 68.

title: The Race to Beat Best Before
description: At 7:45 one recent Wednesday morning, in front of Entenmanns Bakery Outlet on the corner of 34th Avenue and 41st Street in Astoria, Queens, five people stood in a sloppy but unmistakable line, waiting for the store to open.

title: As Game 7 Nears, Rivers Takes Time for Workers
description: PLAYA VISTA, Calif.  As the Los Angeles Clippers players tried to forget, for a few hours, the events of the last week and focus on Game 7 of their first-round series against Golden State, Coach Doc Rivers was tending to 50 to 75 other members of the team.

title: Marsha Mehran, Writer of Iranians Irish Experience, Dies at 36
description: DUBLIN  Marsha Mehran, an Iranian-born author who wrote a hugely successful debut novel centered on Iranian expatriates in Ireland, was found dead on Wednesday at her home in the village of Lecanvey in County Mayo, on Irelands northwest coast. She was 36.

title: Sothebys Poison Pill Is Upheld by Delaware Court
description: A Delaware state court judge on Friday blocked efforts by the hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb to overturn a crucial corporate defense at Sothebys, the auction house.

title: Mets Young Game Manager Continues to Build a Rapport With His Pitchers
description: DENVER  Every moment Travis dArnaud slides on his catchers mask and squats behind home plate, he is entering a nine-inning battle and partnership with the Mets pitching staff.

title: Ex-Official of Port Agency to Rebuff State Inquiry
description: The former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will cease cooperating with the legislative investigation into the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge, his lawyers said on Friday, dealing the inquiry another setback after a judge ruled that two aides did not have to comply with its subpoenas.

title: Hobbled With Ankle Injury, Williams Carries Nets to Game 7
description: Deron Williams let out a groan late Friday while stepping onto a raised platform to conduct a postgame interview. The pain in his left ankle, which he had so effectively ignored on the court at Barclays Center, was throbbing through the joint again.

title: Shredded, Sliced and Covered Up
description: Ordinarily, as she will tell you, Janet Goleas, the curator of the exhibition Redacted at the Islip Art Museum, is not much of a political animal.

title: A Nets Reserve Recovers His Game
description: Andray Blatche is not the type to ruminate on bad games, although Game 5 was a big one. The ball had been in his hands in those final, achingly dramatic seconds, with the Nets trailing. And Blatche threw it away.

title: An Apocalyptic Vision Unfurled
description: An urban nightmare that grows increasingly bleaker for its young heroine, Marisol is a dark fantasia that reflects a number of the social and spiritual troubles of the early 1990s. Jos Rivera wrote this grimly imaginative drama in 1992, and it is sobering to observe how some of his fiery themes still smolder with relevance in the smart production currently being presented by Luna Stage in West Orange.

title: Virginia Senator Pledges Support for Clinton in 2016
description: Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia and an early supporter of Barack Obama in the 2008 primaries, is expected to announce on Saturday that he is joining Ready for Hillary, a super PAC that is trying to build grass-roots support for a potential presidential run by Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2016.

title: Nicholas Martin, 75, Stage Director in New York and New England, Dies
description: Nicholas Martin, a prominent director in New England regional theater who was nominated for the 2013 Tony Award for best director for his production of Christopher Durangs farce Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: With Touch of Zaniness, Rangers Defeat the Penguins in Overtime
description: PITTSBURGH  Fresh off their exhilarating elimination of the Flyers in Game 7 on Wednesday, the Rangers stunned the Penguins on Friday in overtime, 3-2, on Derick Brassards goal at 3 minutes 6 seconds in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: The Brady Quadroons
description: Oh, look, its Masha, Olga and Irinia. The first time the three sisters in Marcus Gardleys The House That Will Not Stand retire together to their upstairs Louisiana bedroom, those Russian sisters may come to mind. But Mr. Gardley has not written a Chekhov drama. Those who know The House of Bernarda Alba may think of Angustias, Martirio and Adela. And Mr. Gardley was indeed inspired by that Spanish drama, written by Federico Garca Lorca in 1936. But as the new work, having its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, unfolds, the young women may seem more like Marcia, Jan and Cindy.

title: Mets Streak of Quality Starts Is Disappearing Into Thin Air at Coors Field
description: DENVER  The Mets and their starting pitchers began the season with a franchise-record 26 consecutive starts of five or more innings. However, for the second consecutive game, the Mets failed to receive a quality start as the Colorado Rockies erupted for six runs in the first two innings and went on to a 10-3 victory on Friday night.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) WERE THE MILLERS (2013) A drug dealer (Jason Sudeikis) in trouble with his boss (Ed Helms) recruits a stripper (Jennifer Aniston) and a couple of street urchins (Will Poulter and Emma Roberts, above, with Mr. Sudeikis and Ms. Aniston) to impersonate an all-American family known as the Millers. Their mission: to transport a few tons of marijuana from Mexico to Denver in their camper. And in no time at all, theyre caring about one another more than they want to admit. Were the Millers, a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; its the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative. Nick Offerman and Kathryn Hahn play the Fitzgeralds, R.V. enthusiasts with a teenage daughter who are beyond square, which is to say that they are stranger, kinkier and more interestingly individual than the Millers  and funnier as actors, too  Mr. Scott added. A movie about the Fitzgeralds would have been more rewarding than Were the Millers, and also much riskier.

title: Seasonal Dishes, and Romance, in a Castle
description: Born too late, our country is short on castles. Nineteenth-century wealth on the East Coast built instead many Victorian Gothic mansions, some of them on the breezy, wooded land of the Hudson Valley. In Westchester a few still stand, like Lyndhurst and Glenview.

title: A Milestone for Girardi in a Game With a Bit of Everything
description: Entering Friday, only five managers in the 114 seasons of the Yankees franchise had accumulated at least 1,000 games on the bench. Despite all their success, the Yankees have also employed managers who were either not good enough to last very long, or simply had fallen in the way of a cantankerous and impatient owner like George Steinbrenner, who would fire someone at the slightest hint of failure.

title: Corrections: May 3, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Efrem Zimbalist Jr., Star of 77 Sunset Strip and The F.B.I., Dies at 95
description: Efrem Zimbalist Jr., an actor whose mellifluous voice and air of European sophistication left a distinctive stamp on two popular television crime series, died on Friday at his ranch in Solvang, Calif. He was 95.

title: 20 Are Held and Curfew Is Imposed After Attacks on Muslims in India
description: NEW DELHI  The police said Saturday that they had arrested 20 people suspected of being associated with attacks that left at least 29 Muslims dead in western villages in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, where tensions between members of the Bodo tribal group and non-Bodo residents, including Muslims, have been simmering for years.

title: No Hope for Those Buried by Mudslide, Afghanistan Official Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A day after landslides buried much of a village in northeastern Afghanistan, local officials said they feared that more than 2,000 people were dead, entombed in a blanket of earth nearly 30 feet deep.

title: Analytics: Is Doomsday Coming?
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 4 issue of the magazine.

title: Ukraine Presses Pro-Russia Militants After Fighting Spreads to a Port City
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraines security forces pressed their assault to try to reclaim the pro-Russian stronghold of Slovyansk on Saturday, even as the rebels freed seven European military observers and the Kremlin cited the deaths of dozens of people in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.

title: Valuable Humans in Our Digital Future
description: In the spirit of college commencements, here is some advice to the class of 2014: Be human. It pays.

title: Celebrity Rich, Cash Poor
description: Teri Polo, a B-list star, filed for bankruptcy last month. In doing so, she became the latest in a long list of celebrities who went from fame to financial ruin. Here are six in the celebrity bankruptcy hall of fame.

title: Berkshire Hathaways 2014 Shareholder Meeting
description: OMAHA  Thousands of shareholders flocked to listen to Warren E. Buffett at Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting at the CenturyLink Center in Omaha, and DealBook had live reports throughout the day.

title: Media Slant: A Question of Cause and Effect
description: Consumers of the news, both from television and print, sometimes feel that they are getting not just the facts but also a sizable dose of ideological spin. Yet have you ever wondered about the root cause of the varying political slants of different media outlets?

title: Video Notebook: Nets Win Game 6
description: Kevin Garnett talks about Deron Williamss play against the Raptors and what the victory meant for the Nets.

title: Video Notebook: Andray Blatche on Game 6
description: Andray Blatche discusses the Nets strong start in the first half Friday night against the Raptors.

title: Teacher and Student Meet Again on the Ice, as Foes
description: PITTSBURGH  Brad Richards helped teach Sidney Crosby to play hockey. That may seem hard to believe as they line up across from each other in the Stanley Cup playoffs, but they said it was true.

title: Variety: A Tactile Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Todays quote is from a fascinating look into the world of synesthesia, a neurological condition that involves a blending of sensations that are normally experienced separately. Some synesthetes, for example, report that they experience numbers as colors, shapes or motions, as the author of Born on a Blue Day confirms.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: May 1, 2014
description: New York-based pharmaceutical giant Pfizer revealed a multi-billion dollar offer to acquire British rival AstraZeneca, and if the acquisition is successful, Pfizer plans to reincorporate in the United Kingdom. Doing so would lower the companys tax rate by 7 percent and allow it to avoid paying U.S. taxes on profits made overseas. This week on Money Talking, Rana Foroohar and Joe Nocera discuss whether Pfizer could inspire other U.S.-based, international companies to pursue a similar path.

title: Condoleezza Rice Backs Out of Rutgers Speech After Student Protests
description: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who had been invited to give the commencement address at Rutgers University in New Jersey this month, said on Saturday that she would no longer give the speech. Her announcement came after weeks of protests by some students and faculty members over the universitys decision to invite her.

title: The Flavor of a Family Business
description: Eric Bassett , 20, works for  Bassetts Ice Cream, at the Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia. Bassettsalso distributes its productsin the Philadelphia area and other markets.

title: Pondering Whether to Make Amends
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Guantnamo Prosecutor Fights Handing Secrets Over to Defense
description: WASHINGTON  The chief prosecutor at the Guantnamo Bay war-crimes court has asked a judge to set aside an order that requires the government to give defense lawyers sweeping amounts of classified details related to the Central Intelligence Agencys treatment of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, a Saudi detainee accused of orchestrating the 2000 bombing of the destroyer Cole.

title: A Path to Retirement, for Those Far From It
description: There is a big retirement problem in America, maybe even a crisis. Many working people wont have enough money to leave their jobs and live in comfort and security. How many are in jeopardy is debatable, but the problems existence is not.

title: Paying a Premium to Cross the Pond
description: Why does it cost so much more to fly from New York to London than from New York to Los Angeles? Sure, the distance across the Atlantic Ocean is about 3,500 air miles, about 40 percent farther than going to the West Coast. But it costs three to four times as much.

title: Learning to Love Bikers
description: THIRTY-TWO THOUSAND bicyclists are expected to ride in the annual Five Boro Bike Tour in New York City this morning. About half the registrants are from out of state and wont be familiar with riding in the city. Theyll be getting their dose of it on its best day, when cyclists seize thoroughfares like Avenue of the Americas and the Belt Parkway from quotidian traffic terrors like the garbage truck and the wide-turning bus.

title: A Whole New Chapter for a Writing Pitcher
description: The Houston Astros practice victory celebrations every spring training. It may seem like a futile exercise for a struggling team, but Bo Porter, the manager, wants to establish a winning mind-set.

title: Where a Desk Just Gets in the Way
description: Urban rescue

title: Nets Fate May Rest With Backcourt
description: Heading into a Game 7 in Toronto on Sunday, the Nets should feel about as good as any team can before a winner-take-all matchup on the road. The Nets and the Raptors may have won the same number of games, but the Nets have controlled most of their first-round N.B.A. playoff series.

title: Six Seconds of Loopy Creativity, and Millions of Fans
description: When Twitter last year introduced Vine, a slick app that lets people shoot and share short videos, I did what I always do when a buzzy, high-profile service makes its debut: I immediately downloaded it and started playing.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 40
description: After he sustained a knee injury last November, the German news media all but ruled out Sami Khedira from being fit for next months World Cup in Brazil. Thing is someone apparently forgot to inform Sami Khedira.

title: With Many Gaps to Fill, Giants Pose a First-Round Draft Mystery
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Since last years N.F.L. draft, the Giants suffered through a humiliating 0-6 start to the 2013 season, missed the playoffs, lost their starting running back to a serious neck injury and watched as a big-name receiver and two of the teams most productive defensive linemen left via free agency.

title: The Great Unwatched
description: Some of the biggest names in Internet media have been gathering in New York City at the third annual Digital Content NewFronts, a pitch-a-thon where companies like Yahoo, AOL and Crackle  and, yes, The New York Times  trumpet their digital platforms to brands eager to reach consumers via online video ads.

title: Loans That Avoid Banks? Maybe Not
description: It was that rare thing, scarcely seen in the financial world since the debut of the A.T.M. or microfinancing: an innovation to help regular people. When peer-to-peer, or P2P, lending began in the middle of the last decade, it offered an easy way for people to lend money to each other over the Internet.

title: Calm in the N.B.A. After the Sterling Storm
description: By the weekend, the elation surrounding the lifetime ban issued Tuesday to the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, had given way to pragmatism.

title: At Bank of America, a $4 Billion Wet Blanket on the Party
