title: Editorial Contest Winner | Inferior Substitute Teaching
description: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

title: Deadly Clashes Erupt in Ukraine as Troops Push Toward a Rebel-Held City
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Ukrainian security forces and antigovernment rebels clashed on the edges of this rebel-controlled city on Monday as the acting president, Oleksandr V. Turchynov, said roadblocks were being set up around Ukraines capital, Kiev, because of fears of disturbances or violence during an emotionally charged holiday later in the week.

title: Indias Divisions Writ Small in a Frontier State
description: UKHRUL, India  This February, Narendra Modi, the Bharatiya Janata Partys candidate for prime minister, gave his first speech in the state of Manipur, straining to reconcile his partys Hindu nationalism with the very different attitudes of a remote, substantially tribal, partly Christian state, where the population has spent decades trying to secede.

title: Share Your Thoughts on Times Insider
description: As a New York Times reader, you might wonder how things work in the newsroom. You might have questions about how decisions are made. You might want to know more about the background of Times reporters and editors.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | May 5, 2014
description: Update: May 6

title: Why Germans Love Russia
description: BERLIN  Like most foreign-policy experts, I was shocked by Russias annexation of Crimea and its continuing soft invasion of eastern Ukraine. Can such a naked land grab really be happening now, in 21st-century Europe?

title: Daily Report: Independence but Little Revenue Growth for Tumblr After Acquisition by Yahoo
description: When Yahoo bought Tumblr for $1.1 billion a year ago, it sent a ripple of excitement  and anxiety  through the tech industry, Jenna Wortham reports. Would Yahoo and its recently arrived chief executive, Marissa Mayer, breathe new life into Tumblr? Or would Yahoo smother the start-up, as it did after acquiring popular young services like GeoCities and Flickr?

title: Saturday With Buffett in Omaha
description: Tens of thousands of investors flocked to Omaha, Neb., this weekend, but it was not for the steak. Instead, as they do every spring, these investors were attending Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting with the hopes of asking a question of its chief executive, Warren E. Buffett, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes.

title: Citigroup Wins Business of Norways Giant Wealth Fund
description: Norways sovereign wealth fund, one of the largest single investors in the world, has selected Citigroup to provide custodial and securities lending services for its $850 billion investment portfolio.

title: Polios Return After Near Eradication Prompts a Global Health Warning
description: Alarmed by the spread of polio to several fragile countries, the World Health Organization declared a global health emergency on Monday for only the second time since regulations permitting it to do so were adopted in 2007.

title: Zendesk Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: Zendesk, a cloud-based customer support start-up, said in a filing on Monday that the price range of its proposed initial offering would be $8 to $10 a share.

title: A Q.&A. With the Author of a Buffett-Praised Book on 3G Capital
description: Warren E. Buffett speaks about virtually anything at the annual Berkshire Hathaway meeting in Omaha, and this past weekend proved no different. But surprisingly, he took a fair amount of time to praise some of his newest business partners.

title: Verdict in Apple-Samsung Patent Trial
description: The jury found that some Samsung smartphones and tablets had violated Apple patents covering things like the slide-to-unlock feature, which opens the phones features to users. The bulk of the damages  $99 million  were for a patent that covered a method for so-called quick links.

title: Faltering Target Parts Ways With Chief
description: The chief executive of Target, Gregg Steinhafel, resigned from the company on Monday, signaling the depths of the damage done by last years extensive breach of customer information.

title: A Composers Ambitious Take on Sophocles Makes a Big Impression in London
description: LONDON  When a composer who has been around for a while and who has already earned an international reputation finally feels confident enough to write an opera, the stakes are high. Especially if the composers score is as magisterially ambitious as Julian Andersons Thebans, a commission by the English National Opera, which packed the London Coliseum at its premiere on Saturday.

title: Profit Off, Pfizer Again Aims to Lure AstraZeneca
description: As the drug maker Pfizer announced a 15 percent drop in first-quarter earnings on Monday, its chief executive renewed his call for its British rival AstraZeneca to accept Pfizers offer to buy it.

title: Sothebys Yields to Hedge Fund Mogul and Allies
description: Updated, 11:48 p.m. | For months, Sothebys fought tooth and nail as the hedge fund mogul and longtime client Daniel S. Loeb waged a boardroom war against the auction house in an effort to win board seats and a change in strategy.

title: South Sudan Fighting Rages as Kerry Appeals to Rebel Leader
description: BENTIU, South Sudan  The sound of bullets cracked, whistled and popped on Monday over a United Nations base where 25,000 people huddled for safety. A middle-aged woman was hit by a stray bullet and carried to a clinic in a wheelbarrow. Nyapes Lach, a 4-year-old girl, was struck in the head as she sat with her family, rushed to the clinic in a blood-soaked bandage, and pronounced dead.

title: U.N. Panel on Torture Presses Vatican Envoy on Abuse
description: GENEVA  The Vatican faced sharp questioning by a United Nations panel on Monday about whether it failed to abide by an international treaty against torture in its response to the sexual abuse of children by priests.

title: Everyone Wants to Be a Homeowner. Why Not a Foodowner?
description: Imagine if we bought food the way we buy housing.

title: Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide
description: WASHINGTON  In a major decision on the role of religion in government, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that the Constitution allows town boards to start their sessions with sectarian prayers. The ruling, by a 5-to-4 vote, divided the courts more conservative members from its liberal ones, and their combative opinions reflected very different views of the role of faith in public life, in contemporary society and in the founding of the Republic.

title: For Justices, Free Speech Often Means Speech I Agree With
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Antonin Scalia is known as a consistent and principled defender of free speech rights.

title: Seven Tips for Stock Traders Determined to Defy the Odds
description: Last week, I wrote about the documented evidence that trading activity results in lower returns to investors. This is equally true for those people we think of as professional investors and for people day trading in their parents basements.

title: Justices Turn Away Case About Carrying Guns in Public
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday turned away a case about whether the Second Amendment guarantees a right to carry guns in public for self-defense. As is their custom, the justices gave no reasons.

title: Podcast: Chernobyls Radioactive Forest, Advanced Placement Boot Camp, Flat-Headed Babies
description: Stroll through irradiated woods near the worlds worst civilian nuclear disaster; in Pittsburgh, a school tries to raise the number of its students who get college credit on A.P. science tests by 80 percent; some babies develop misshapen heads, but an expensive corrective helmet might not be effective in restoring roundness.

title: Barclays Confirms Its Head of Mergers Is Leaving
description: Barclays confirmed on Monday that its global head of mergers, Paul G. Parker, was leaving  the latest prominent departure from the British bank.

title: Food Curated | Northern Spy Food Co.
description: The chef Hadley Schmitt shows how to make the Egg Begley Jr., a kale and egg sandwich initially created for the GoogaMooga Festival in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: White House Tech Advisers: Online Privacy Is a Market Failure
description: The White House published two lengthy reports on big data and privacy last Thursday. The one that got all the attention, understandably, was the review led by John D. Podesta, a senior adviser to the White House. It was the more general report  and concluded with a handful of policy recommendations, including developing government limits on how companies use the vast amounts of information they collect about people.

title: Mad Men Recap: This Symbolism Does Not Compute
description: Season 7, Episode 4

title: Video: Northern Spy Food Co.s Egg Begley Jr.
description: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

title: Witness Describes Pistoriuss Anguish
description: Oscar Pistoriuss trial resumed on Monday after a two-week recess, with the defense team calling its fourth witness, Johan Stander, whom Mr. Pistorius said he phoned after he shot Reeva Steenkamp.

title: In the Canadian Rockies, a Sky-High View of Glaciers
description: A new attraction in Jasper National Park in the Canadian Rockies is offering travelers a different world view this springone that will take them quite literally over the edge of a cliff.

title: Podcast: Head Flattening and Helmets
description: Catherine Saint Louis talks more about a new study that assessed the efficacy of corrective helmets.

title: Nigerian Islamist Leader Threatens to Sell Kidnapped Girls
description: DAKAR, Senegal  In a video message apparently made by the leader of the Nigerian Islamist group Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls nearly three weeks ago, called them slaves and threatened to sell them in the market, by Allah.

title: Nigerians on Boko Haram Abductions
description: President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria vowed to find the girls kidnapped from their school in northeastern Nigeria last month, but relatives of the missing accused the government of not doing enough.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Association of Music Producers, New York, is naming two brands, Budweiser and Nike, into the A.M.P. Hall of Fame for what the organization calls outstanding achievement in the use of music to define a brand.

title: The New Yorker Calls on a Trio of Its Artists for Annual Festival Promotion
description: The New Yorker is turning to three of its best-known artists, whose covers, cartoons and drawings have become emblematic of the magazines graphic style, to help promote the 2014 edition of the annual New Yorker Festival.

title: Hispanic Growth Is Strength but Also Challenge for U.S. Catholic Church
description: The Roman Catholic Church has known for years that its future in the United States depends heavily on Hispanics. The church, which is the largest religious denomination in the country, is already about 40 percent Hispanic, and the demographic change is inexorable: Within the next few decades, Hispanics are expected to make up a majority of American Catholics.

title: Daniel Finkels Perfect Hopscotch Loops
description: This weeks challenge was suggested by Daniel Finkel of the Seattle-based Math for Love, which is committed to sharing the beauty and joy of math through seminars, festivals and camps. Lets try a few rounds of

title: China Further Restricts Foreign Dairy Brands
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government has imposed new limits on foreign brands of milk powder and infant formula sold in China, according to reports on Monday by the state-run news media.

title: I.S.S. Supports Dissident Slate for GrafTech Board
description: Nathan Milikowsky, a former board member of the steel company GrafTech, has won support from Institutional Shareholder Services, a leading proxy advisory firm, in his effort to regain influence on the board.

title: Now Screening | Catching Up With the Original Punk Rock Girl of Film
description: Starting May 7 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a series called Punk Rock Girls will showcase the women of the movement in all their pierced, ripped, hairsprayed glory. The theme is so resonant, says the programmer Nellie Killian, who conceived the monthlong event as a valentine to the era. Especially for female viewers, its so important to have these types of girl characters, and we wanted to put in the lineage of movies of girls carving out a space for themselves within alternative culture. Highlights will include a rubber-braceleted, Danceteria-era Madonna brazenly appropriating the Port Authority hand dryers (Desperately Seeking Susan); Diane Lane and friends, in slashes of scarlet eye shadow and skunk-striped hair, stepping up to the mike (Ladies and Gentlemen, the Fabulous Stains); and Robin Johnson and Trini Alvarado hurling TV sets off Manhattan rooftops (Times Square).

title: How Gary Becker Transformed the Social Sciences
description: Gary Becker was the most important social scientist in the past 50 years and possibly longer, in my view. He was my intellectual hero, and I want to explain why.

title: An Offbeat Gallery Show With Its Own Soundtrack
description: The painter Mark Ryden made his name creating distinctive, cartoonish record sleeve art, most notably for Michael Jacksons Dangerous album, Aerosmiths Love in an Elevator single, and records by the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Tyler the Creator. Now he is, in a limited way, becoming a record producer as well. While assembling The Gay 90s West, a thematic show of his paintings based on 19th-century themes, Mr. Ryden told The Hollywood Reporter, he decided to invite some of his friends in the pop music world to contribute to an accompanying album.

title: No Comment Necessary: Fed to the Lions
description: Responding to Tuesdaysbotched executionof an Oklahoma inmate, a local lawmaker said it didnt matter how the state put citizens to death.

title: Today in Small Business: Better Light Bulbs
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Image of the Day: May 5
Sounds, And Ideas, That Never Stay Still
description: The rangy terrain traversed by the Nels Cline Singers on Thursday night, in a riveting, sold-out show at Le Poisson Rouge, could be understood a few different ways: as a rejection of fixedness, or an endorsement of flux, or a way of moving the conversation forward. What it all amounted to was a distillation of the musical ideals long embodied by Nels Cline, a guitarist with a knack for wrangling restlessness into coherence.

title: Investors Gather for Sohn Conference
description: The Ira Sohn Investment Conference brings together prominent hedge fund managers to share their investment ideas in a venue that helps raise funds for a charity that focuses on the treatment of pediatric cancers.

title: Picasso Museum Reopening Delayed Until September, For Now
description: PARIS  The Muse Picasso, which has been closed for more than four years while undergoing a renovation and expansion, will not reopen to the public until at least mid-September, an official from the Culture Ministry said here on Monday.

title: Aid Arrives for Afghan Landslide Victims
description: Residents of the Afghan village of Abi Barak searched for survivors of a landslide that killed hundreds of people as aid groups and the government rushed to provide food and shelter.

title: Books to Share on Mothers Day
description: First of all, go, right now, to the store. Buy a card for your mother, mother-in-law and anyone else you want to receive one this Sunday. Have your children make cards and greetings tonight, and put it all in the mail tomorrow. Dont spend another year apologizing or justifying your use of priority overnight Saturday delivery whatnot. (Please dont tell me Im the only one to do both regularly!)

title: Vatican Faces Questioning by U.N. Panel
description: In a grilling at the United Nations, the Vatican undercut arguments that it had violated an international treaty against torture in its response to the sexual abuse of children by priests.

title: De Blasio Sets a 10-Year Plan for Housing, Putting the Focus on Affordability
description: New York City will commit $8.2 billion in public funds to a 10-year housing plan that could transform the cityscape from Cypress Hills in Brooklyn to the shores of the Harlem River, while providing affordable homes to thousands of low- to middle-income residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday.

title: Old Nightmares Revisited in Weird Fantasy
description: Part of an occasional series on vintage comics.

title: Seeking Guilty Pleas From Corporations While Limiting the Fallout
description: When it comes to bringing criminal charges against corporations, prosecutors have been gun-shy, fearing the dreaded Arthur Andersen effect.

title: Times Minute | Largest Tech I.P.O. Ever?
description: Alibaba is getting ready to file what could be the largest technology I.P.O. in history. Also on the Minute, the state of affairs in Ukraine and a preview of this summer blockbuster season.

title: Reasons to Brush Up Your Serve
description: For tennis players and fans, several resorts are offering new incentives to travel.

title: Times Minute | Largest Tech I.P.O. Ever?
description: In the Video

title: Document | About a Boy
description: For nearly two years, the Brooklyn-based photographer Dean Kaufman has relished the simple pleasure of watching his son lose himself in a work of art. He began this series when Leo was 4 and started toting a small notebook on family trips to New York art museums. Leo would plunk down near whatever caught his eye and begin to sketch, while his father stealthily captured the moment. Kaufman says the activity  whether sprawling out in front of a Jasper Johns painting at the Whitney Museum of American Art (middle left), or carefully copying Chris Burdens tower of concrete bags at the New Museum (bottom center)  has nurtured Leos love for drawing. Still, he hesitates to interpret the 5-year-olds curiosity as a sign of future art stardom. Hes got a limited attention span, Kaufman says. He does the drawing and then he says, Lets go have lunch.'

title: Stolen Guitar to Be Returned to Zakk Wylde
description: Zakk Wylde, the guitarist in Black Label Society whose striped and bulls-eye-emblazoned guitars are as distinctive as his shredding style, is about to be reunited with a custom-built Pelham blue Gibson Les Paul that was stolen from his tour bus in March. The guitar, which bears Mr. Wyldes distinctive bulls-eye design, and which Mr. Wylde valued at $10,000 at the time of the theft, was recovered on Friday after a pawn shop owner began to suspect that the instrument was probably worth more than the $50 he paid for it.

title: France Says It Opposes G.E.s Bid for Alstom Unit
description: Updated, 4:22 p.m. | PARIS  The French government said on Monday that it would oppose General Electrics friendly $13.5 billion offer for a large portion of Alstom, the countrys largest industrial conglomerate, saying the deal should be reconfigured on a more equitable footing.

title: Most Americans Likely to Approve of Ruling on Prayer
description: Mondays Supreme Court decision to allow prayer at municipal gatherings will probably be met with approval by a majority of Americans.

title: Weekly News Quiz | April 29-May 5, 2014
description: A horse race, a Supreme Court decision and a long-awaited movie sequel: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

title: Safety Agency Pressures Graco to Recall More Child Seats
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is increasing pressure on Graco Childrens Products to recall about 1.8 million car safety seats the agency deems dangerous, and has ordered a series of tests. The goal, the agency said, is to see how long a malfunctioning buckle would delay freeing an infant during an emergency.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 38
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Devils Food Cake
description: Melissa Clark makes the most devilish of devils food cakes by using two types of frosting: black pepper buttercream and chocolate fudge.

title: Cosmic Connections in the Deep Sea
description: TUFFY CANYONS, Belize  I have never felt closer to the sky than when I was 170 feet under the ocean here.

title: Two Frostings Are Better Than One
description: Its said you can judge cooks by the way they roast a chicken. So how do you judge bakers? I say, by their devils food cake.

title: Some Kind Words for Airport Body Scanners
description: IF I may take a somewhat long way around the barn to make a point, a horse fell on me last year.

title: Hollywood Charities Boycott Hotel to Protest Bruneis Adoption of Shariah
description: LOS ANGELES  The response here to the planned imposition of Islamic law in Brunei, with extreme penalties for adultery and gay sex, has become more pointed in recent days as two Hollywood-related charities moved events from the Beverly Hills Hotel, which is owned by the Brunei Investment Agency.

title: Learning to Laugh Through the Pain
description: IVE been traveling for business for about 15 years. Ive always been involved in sports training. I have degrees in physical therapy and exercise science, and have worked with many professional athletes, like football players or mixed martial artists. I was even a member of the United States bobsled team. When I developed my strength and conditioning program, called Training for Warriors, my travel schedule became insane. Ive been to 25 countries so far doing motivational speaking, training or some combination of both.

title: Michelle Obama Joins in a Salute to Anna Wintour
description: On Monday morning, from the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Vogue editor Anna Wintour proved yet again that she can get the entire fashion world to show up.

title: Ralph Ruccis Continuing Homage to Charles James
description: Charles James was one of American fashions first couturiers, as well as one of its most influential designers and most notorious perfectionists. His contemporaries, such as Christian Dior and Mainbocher, venerated him; Balenciaga famously called him the worlds best and only dressmaker, and both Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel wore his designs. Tonight, The Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Art will pay tribute to the late masters 30-year career with the gala for Charles James: Beyond Fashion, which opens to the public May 8. Nearly 75 of the 200 designs ever completed by James will be on display at the newly christened Anna Wintour Costume Center and first-floor Special Exhibition Galleries. And to accompany this retrospective, an eponymous book has been written by its curators Harold Koda and Jan Glier Reeder, cataloguing the work on view.

title: Financial Data Company Markit Files for I.P.O.
description: Markit, a financial data company, has been a behind-the-scenes player on Wall Street since its founding roughly a decade ago. Now, it is preparing to make its public market debut.

title: Weekend Gun Report: May 2-4, 2014
description: Last Monday, 14-year-old Endia Martin was shot and killed in the Back of the Yards neighborhood of Chicago. She and a former friend, a 14-year-old honor-roll student, were in a dispute over a boy, and what started as a Facebook fight erupted into a brawl. The confrontation drew 20 people, some of whom were armed with pipes and bottles.

title: Ackman Urges Allergan Board to Begin Deal Talks With Valeant
description: Two weeks after unveiling an audacious partnership with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to take over Allergan, the maker of Botox, the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman is getting to work.

title: Red in the Face
description: Q. After I have had a glass of wine, my face heats up and turns bright red. This also happens to my siblings. What is going on?

title: Crocodile Tears Hit the Spot for Butterfly and Bee
description: A butterfly and a bee were seen, above, sipping the tears of a spectacled caiman (Caiman crocodilus) along the Ro Puerto Viejo in northeastern Costa Rica. The insects were probably seeking protein and salt. Tear drinking in the wild may be common but not often seen, said Carlos de la Rosa, an aquatic ecologist at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica who witnessed the event.

title: Helping Small Companies Go Big in China
description: When I encounter other American companies that do business in China, I am often surprised by the relatively small size of their operations in the United States. Many had less than $500,000 in annual sales when they decided to open operations in China.

title: A 9,000-Year-Old Hunting Cabin, Underwater
description: A 9,000-year-old stone structure used to capture caribou has been discovered 120 feet beneath the surface of Lake Huron. Researchers say it is the most complex structure of its kind in the Great Lakes region.

title: Dialogue: Nate Lowman and Devon Welsh
description: The artist Nate Lowman discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh of Majical Cloudz in Lowmans TriBeCa studio.

title: Woman Found Guilty of Assaulting Officer at an Occupy Wall Street Protest
description: A trial that had become a rallying point for many Occupy Wall Street activists ended on Monday with a jury finding a protester guilty of assaulting a police officer at Zuccotti Park in Manhattan in 2012.

title: Less Air in Latest Internet Bubble
description: The latest Internet bubble is a mere shadow of the excesses that came crashing to an end in 2000. Sure, even though the run-up may have paused, the feverish signs are unmistakable. Dozens of companies are in line to go public, hubris is rampant, oddball valuation metrics abound, and revenue-free start-ups are still worth fortunes. Even nerd culture has somehow become hip. The latest boom is as absurd as the last, but its far smaller.

title: Film Festival Moves to New York With Think Like a Man Sequel and Spike Lee Film
description: The 18th edition of the American Black Film Festival will make its New York debut next month with films directed by Tim Story and Spike Lee bookending the June 19-22 event, organizers announced Monday.

title: After a Heart Attack, Eat Your Fiber
description: It is never too late to increase your consumption of dietary fiber, a new study suggests.

title: Nate Lowman and Majical Cloudzs Devon Welsh Talk Creativity and Music
description: To commemorate its launch tomorrow, the new high-end headphone brand Master & Dynamic commissioned a series of videos that pair two artists from different disciplines together to discuss the influence of sound on their work. The first, making its debut here, offers a firsthand look inside the artist Nate Lowmans TriBeCa studio, where he discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh, frontman of the indie duo Majical Cloudz.

title: A New Womens Issue: Statins
description: Should so many women be taking statins?

title: Deutsche Bank Hires Consumer M.&A. Adviser
description: Deutsche Bank announced Monday that it had hired Jeff Rose as a managing director of its global consumer and retail mergers and acquisitions group, and the new head of its consumer and retail investment banking coverage in the Americas.

title: Taking Aim at 12-Step Programs
description: Did you know that the most widely accepted treatments for alcohol and drug addiction  Alcoholics Anonymous and similar 12-step programs  rest on the flimsiest of scientific evidence? I didnt.

title: One Million
description: Champagne and other sparkling wines owe much of their appeal to their bubbles. They dont just set the mouth tingling; bursting bubbles at the surface also help propel the aromas toward the nose.

title: More Blight for the Palisades?
description: LG Electronics USA has been facing a growing outcry about the companys plan to build a 143-foot tall headquarters along the Palisades Park in New Jersey. That tower, which will stretch far above the tree line, will permanently deface the view along a once-protected stretch of the Hudson River. Politicians, environmentalists, architectural critics, outraged citizensand even potentialLG customers have appealed to the company to lower this tower to the traditional limit of 35 feet.

title: Boko Haram Leader Releases Video
description: The leader of Nigerias terrorist group Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau, said his group was fighting to reinstate a medieval Islamic caliphate in northern Nigeria.

title: Box Office Bump for Top Tony Nominees
description: Last week was one of the best yet for the Broadway musical A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder, with sharp increases in both weekly box office grosses and advance ticket sales following its 10 Tony Awards nominations, the most of any Broadway show.

title: A Central Banker of a Different Color
description: On Saturday afternoon in Louisville, Ky., a central banker was under scrutiny. Investors with deep pockets were watching his every move, weighing odds on how he would perform under pressure.

title: Running Food, Taking Photos
description: When his photo career stalled, Robert Larson took a nightclub job  where he discovered new faces and scenes in the blur of action between the kitchen and the club.

title: Listening to Sancerre Tell Its Story
description: Updated | June 2, 2014

title: Apple-Samsung Jury Sticks With Original Total for Damages
description: The federal jury in the latest patent trial involving Apple and Samsung returned to court on Monday to recalculate some of the damages Samsung owed to Apple. After making the changes, the jury came to the same overall figure: $119.6 million.

title: Outside Spending Enters Arena of Judicial Races
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The ad first appeared on television the Friday before last, a black-and-white spot charging that Justice Robin Hudson coddled child molesters and sided with the predators in a North Carolina Supreme Court dissent. It has run constantly since.

title: In Store | Bonpoint Arrives in SoHo With a Capsule and a Collaboration
description: Bonpoint, the Paris-based purveyor of chic childrens wear, will debut a new flagship store in New Yorks SoHo tomorrow. In celebration of the opening, the brands creative director Christine Innamorato has designed a special SoHo 2014 capsule collection, which includes Liberty-print dresses  the designs for 12 of which were sourced from the Bonpoint archive  and bags, brooches, swimsuits, as well as soaps and candles that come packaged inside Liberty-print bags. And as an added incentive for the parents of chic tykes, Innamorato teamed up with the jewelry designer Aurlie Bidermann to create a limited-edition 18-karat gold and lacquer bracelet, featuring Bonpoints signature cherry logo, that adjusts to fit both children and adults. A portion of the profits from sales of the bracelet and capsule items will be donated to New Yorkers for Children.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, South Africa, Ukraine and Romania.

title: A Goal to Combat Malaria With the Help of a Robot
description: In its effort to develop a unique malaria vaccine, the American company Sanaria wants to build a robot that will do what now requires a line of trained humans with microscopes: dissecting half-frozen mosquitoes with tiny needles to extract their salivary glands.

title: King Cotton and His Bloody Surrogates
description: At first glance, this exhibition might seem a bit quaint, its subject  textiles and the Civil War  evoking Americana more than American history. But this show, Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts and Context in the Civil War, which opened last month at the New-York Historical Society after originating at the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., does much more: It turns Americana back into history.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: In Performance | Vanessa Williams
description: Vanessa Williams, with Adam Birnbaum on piano, sings I Cant Give You Anything but Love from the musical revue After Midnight, on Broadway at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: A Debt to the Future, Face of Pain, Science Meets Fiction
description: Climate Change

title: Pan-Latin Rhythms, Percussive to Sultry
description: Throughout its 45-year recording career, Santana  led by the great Mexican-American guitarist Carlos Santana  has been synonymous with Latin rock. Yet Corazn is the first Santana album with nearly all of its lyrics in Spanish. Gathering much of the albums material from outside the United States, Mr. Santana now embraces the Pan-American rock and pop that he heralded.

title: Denny Hamlin Wins at Talladega; Marc Marquez Takes Fourth Race in a Row
description: Denny Hamlin passed Kevin Harvick for the lead on the penultimate lap and then received the checkered flag when a multicar wreck on the final lap froze the finishing order in the Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama.

title: Lonely-Hearts and Action Tales
description: Swing & Beowulf, paired one-acts at the Irish Arts Center, both come from the Dublin Fringe Festival, but thats all they have in common. Swing, a portrait of lovelorn Dubliners in a dance class, is rooted in Irelands recessionary present. Beowulf: The Blockbuster, a phantasmagorical conversation between a father and son, jumps through space and time. O.K., the plays share one more thing: They are both very worth the trip.

title: Met Opera Contract Talks Stumble to a Start
description: After an unusually stormy overture, the curtain went up Monday on the first round of contract talks between the Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing its chorus, dancers, singers and stage managers.

title: Mississippi Chefs to Protest State Law on the Eve of Annual Picnic
description: Every June for 35 years, hundreds of New Yorkers and displaced Mississippians have gathered in Central Park to eat catfish, listen to the blues and praise the virtues of that Southern state.

title: When Playwrights Fancies Turn
description: Attention struggling playwrights: Should you need inspiration, avoid Shakespeare, Molire and the like. Their skills could frustrate you. Instead, see The Spring Fling: First Love, six short plays so tedious that they may actually serve a purpose: Youll find yourself thinking, If that can get staged, my work must have a chance.

title: Still Counting Gulf Spills Dead Birds
description: After the Deepwater Horizon oil rig blew out in the Gulf of Mexico some 50 miles from the nearest land, responders were left to cope with a search area of nearly 40,000 square miles, as well as wind and currents that kept evidence of damage away from the more easily searchable coastline.

title: An Artists New York Moment
description: Most choreographers have had a long, thankless slog on the way to professional status. (Never mind success.) First come many years of training to be a dancer, then more years performing for others, trying to find time and money to create work, and get it onstage.

title: Confronting the Inevitable, Graphically
description: Roz Chast feels  and draws  our pain. Our neurotic worries and genuine fears, our mundane and existential anxieties, our daydreams, nightmares, insecurities and guilty regrets. Or, rather, she does such a funny, fluent job in her New Yorker cartoons of conveying the things that keep her up at night that many readers are convinced that she is somehow mapping their own inner lives.

title: The Animals of Chernobyl
description: Biologist Timothy Mousseau has been studying the lasting effects of radiation on the flora and fauna of Chernobyl, Ukraine.

title: At Chernobyl, Hints of Natures Adaptation
description: NOVOSHEPELYCHI, Ukraine  The clicking sound from Timothy Mousseaus radiation detector slowly increased as he walked through the forest here, a few miles west of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.

title: New Election Model Machinery: A Look Under the Hood
description: John Sides, Ben Highton and Eric McGhee of The Monkey Cage have started Election Lab, a Senate forecasting model at The Washington Post. Their model gives Republicans more than an 80 percent chance of retaking the Senate; thats much more than the 54 percent chance that Leo, The Upshots Senate model, gives the G.O.P.

title: A Composer Attuned to the Earths Swirling Motion
description: John Luther Adams has never been inside the main auditorium of Carnegie Hall. Its not a fact that distinguishes him greatly in his hometown, Fairbanks, Alaska, where he has lived for four decades. There Mr. Adams, now 61, was first known as an environmental activist who helped secure passage of the Alaska Lands Act in 1980, before dedicating himself full time to music and building a small but fervent following as a composer of hypnotically immersive musical landscapes. But when Mr. Adams attends his first concert in Carnegie Halls Stern Auditorium on Tuesday, he will be in the unusual position of doing so as a newly minted Pulitzer Prize laureate hearing his winning work, Become Ocean, played there for the first time.

title: In Search of a Lost Wonder, Off the Rivers of Babylon
description: This is the time of year when weekend gardeners peer into the neighbors yards for confirmation of their own superiority or inadequacy. But practically every gardener will feel unworthy upon viewing Tuesdays episode of the PBS series Secrets of the Dead.

title: Punched Out in Hard Times
description: In James McManuss overwrought Cherry Smoke, Fish (Vayu ODonnell) is an amateur boxer with what his brother, Duffy (Patrick Carroll), describes as a serious lunatic streak. On a set  sandbags, red stucco, ruined tires  resembling an apocalyptic desert but meant to suggest western Pennsylvania, Fish cycles from back-alley bouts to prison stints to riverside encounters with his guileless girlfriend Cherry (Molly Carden). An exploited child-woman, she is prone to statements like, There useta be a bluebird in my heart, but it flew away. She also describes a form of birth control so violent it provokes laughter.

title: To Honor a Master, One Day Wont Do
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  The Sarasota Ballets four-day festival honoring the superlative choreographer Frederick Ashton that ended on Saturday was a triumph of courage, enterprise, enthusiasm, artistic importance, stylish dancing, but, above all, choreographic felicity. Visiting Ashton dancers from the 1950s to the 70s spoke with awe of how well this young Gulf Coast company reminded them of what they had loved years ago and had thought lost.

title: Were Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Condoleezza Rice Silenced?
description: In 2009 a Catholic advocacy group said it was an outrage for Notre Dame to select President Barack Obama as its commencement speaker and give him an honorary degree, arguing that it was wrong for a Catholic university to honor a politician whose views on abortion contradicted those of the church.

title: Franco & ODowd: I Met Dr. Ruth
description: Part 5: The actors discuss Chriss performance in Bridesmaids, and talk about the role of improvisation in theater.

title: Franco & ODowd: These Two Guys
description: Part 2: The actors discuss how this production of Of Mice and Men came together, and explain how they knew they would make a good team.

title: Franco & ODowd: Gumball 3000
description: Part 3: The actors reflect on the daunting challenge of acting on Broadway, and describe the mental pitfalls of preparing for a Broadway show.

title: Franco & ODowd: Spring Breakers
description: Part 4: The actors explore Jamess performance in the film Spring Breakers, and explain how the text of a play is not like a screenplay.

title: TimesTalks | Franco & ODowd: Preview
description: The actors James Franco and Chris ODowd discuss making their Broadway debuts in Of Mice and Men.

title: Franco & ODowd: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors James Franco and Chris ODowd.

title: Franco & ODowd: Talented Women
description: Part 7: The actors recall the women who have been major influences on their careers.

title: Franco & ODowd: Judd Apatow
description: Part 6: The actors reflect on how Pineapple Express changed Jamess career, and explain what theyve learned from working with the Apatow crew of comic actors.

title: Critics Circle Names Fun Home Best Musical
description: The critically acclaimed Fun Home picked up another award for best musical of the New York theater season on Monday, this time from the New York Drama Critics Circle, an association of theater reviewers. Fun Home, the story of a lesbian cartoonist and her memories of childhood and her father, who committed suicide, also won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding Off Broadway musical on Sunday night. The show finished its run at the Public Theater this winter; a Broadway transfer is now in the works for next season.

title: Franco & ODowd: All I Need
description: Part 12: The actors explain the fundamental difference between theater acting and film acting.

title: Franco & ODowd: Professor Franco
description: Part 9: The actors discuss Jamess work as a teacher and what hes gained from both sides of the academic experience.

title: Franco & ODowd: Timeless, Not Timely
description: Part 8: The actors explore what makes Of Mice and Men different and more personal than Steinbecks other depression-era work.

title: Franco & ODowd: This Is the End
description: Part 10: The actors talk about Jamess role as himself in the film This Is the End, and reflect on how comedy can illuminate truths in ways drama cant.

title: Franco & ODowd: Celebrity
description: Part 13: Chris ODowd talks about his writing process, and James Franco shares his thoughts on his public persona.

title: Franco & ODowd: Calvary
description: Part 11: The actors discuss Chriss upcoming film Calvary and talk about switching between comedy and drama.

title: Franco & ODowd: Riff Raff
description: Part 14: The actors recall their earliest experiences with Steinbeck, and explore the varied audience reactions to Spring Breakers.

title: Franco & ODowd: Daniel Desario
description: Part 16: The actors talk about Jamess character on Freaks and Geeks, and discuss his upcoming film, Child of God.

title: Franco & ODowd: Filming Is So Boring
description: Part 15: The actors discuss Leighton Meesters performance as Curleys Wife in Of Mice and Men, and explain the process of casting the show.

title: Franco & ODowd: Creative Pitfalls
description: Part 17: The actors reflect on the importance of structure in living a creative life.

title: Met Gala Red Carpet Arrivals
description: Part of the red carpets allure is the way that guests interpret (or protest) the theme.

title: The Mulleavy Sisters Tap an Artist to Reinvent Their Books Cover
description: When Nevena Borissova, the owner of Curve  a boutique with locations in Miami, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York  set out to host an event celebrating Rodartes fall collection, she approached Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the sisters behind the label, to help her think outside the rack. The trio came up with the idea of putting a new twist on the 2011 book they created with the fine-art photographers Catherine Opie and Alec Soth. The Mulleavys then called on their friend, the artist and ceramist Rebekah Miles, to create 27 new individually hand-painted covers, which were unveiled yesterday at an intimate book signing at Curves NoHo location. Its something that she does really beautifully, says Laura Mulleavy of Miless book-jacket paintings.

title: Mortality Drop Seen to Follow 06 Health Law
description: BOSTON  The death rate in Massachusetts dropped significantly after it adopted mandatory health care coverage in 2006, a study released Monday found, offering evidence that the countrys first experiment with universal coverage  and the model for crucial parts of President Obamas health care law  has saved lives, health economists say.

title: A Spotlight on Sex Assaults on Campus
The Fervor for Great Books and Big Ideas Isnt Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: A Truce at Sothebys After a Costly and Avoidable Battle
description: Really, Sothebys?

title: Bill de Blasio Shows Liberals Can Be Pro-Development
description: Last year, I predicted that Bill de Blasio would be New Yorks most pro-development mayor in decades. The affordable housing plan Mr. de Blasio released Monday is a step in that direction.

title: Cellphone Searches
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Policy Toward Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Study of Helmet Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: After Buffett, Should Berkshire Hathaway Be Broken Up?
description: There is an uncomfortable question hanging over one of the worlds biggest corporations: Should Berkshire Hathaway be broken up when Warren Buffett retires or dies? The answer might be found in the very underpinnings of how American industry is organized and governed.

title: A Red-Hot Rumor About Apple Falls Apart
description: Dont believe everything you read online. Especially if youre reading it on the anonymous social app Secret.

title: 3 Are Exonerated of Murder in Cases Tied to a Discredited Detective
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office will ask a judge to vacate the murder convictions of three half-brothers whose trials relied on questionable evidence produced by a now discredited homicide detective, several lawyers close to the cases said.

title: The Streamlined Life
description: Every year researchers at U.C.L.A. do a survey of incoming college freshmen. These surveys, conducted over four decades now, show how the life cycle has changed over the past couple generations.

title: Hotel Boycott Grows Over Brunei Penal Code
description: LOS ANGELES  The response here to the planned imposition of Islamic law in Brunei, with extreme penalties for adultery and gay sex, has become more pointed in recent days as two Hollywood-related charities moved events from the Beverly Hills Hotel, which is owned by the Brunei Investment Agency.

title: New York City Gives Families of 9/11 Victims One-Week Notice That Remains Will Be Moved
description: New York City has notified families of Sept. 11 victims that the unidentified remains of those killed at the World Trade Center will be moved on Saturday to a specially built repository at ground zero. But like much else in this yearslong process, the news was met with a mixture of anger, confusion and acceptance, reflecting the divisions of opinion, and continued heightened passions, of the relatives.

title: Soccer Practice, Or Else!
The Perfect Essay
description: Looking back on too many years of education, I can identify one truly impossible teacher. She cared about me, and my intellectual life, even when I didnt. Her expectations were high  impossibly so. She was an English teacher. She was also my mother.

title: Pride of Italy Takes a Dive as Soccer Ultras Gain Control
description: ROME  It was a humiliating moment for Italian soccer, and for Italy: With the final of the prestigious Italian Cup delayed after a fan from Naples was shot outside Olympic Stadium, authorities flirted with canceling the Saturday night match between Napoli and Fiorentina of Florence. Rumors rippled through the stands, and many Napoli supporters seemed on the verge of boiling over.

title: Big East and Big Ten Announce an Annual Series Beginning in 2015
description: The Big East and Big Ten Conferences announced Monday that they will hold a series of mens basketball games beginning in November 2015.

title: Balky Wi-Fi Above the Clouds
description: ATLANTA  When he was involved in marketing, it never occurred to Jack Salerno to fire up his computer during a flight, link to the Internet and dig into work. I liked the quiet time to think, he said.

title: Against the Odds, a South Bronx Swim Team Finds Success
description: The pool is old and small, and scarred by chipped stone and peeling paint.

title: A Famous Tennis Dad Writes, but Not About Tennis
description: Richard Williams stood outside his Midtown Manhattan hotel Monday afternoon, fighting a losing battle with a gusting wind as he attempted to keep a half-smoked cigarette lit.

title: She Had to Tell What She Knew
description: Mary Willingham remembers the exact moment when she realized she had to go public. It was at the memorial service in the fall of 2012 for Bill Friday, the former president of the University of North Carolina. During his long career, Friday had championed the amateur ideal  the notion that college athletes needed also to be students, and that academics mattered as much as wins.

title: Captain Barnes and the Wilderness
description: As night settled on the Wilderness on May 5, 1864, the moans of wounded men still on the battlefield haunted the halting sleep of the men lucky enough to survive the first day of fighting unscathed. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant had chosen the thickly wooded region west of Fredericksburg as his avenue of attack into Confederate-held Virginia.

title: Another General Motors Official to Leave
description: DETROIT  Another top General Motors official is leaving the company after the automakers long-delayed recall of 2.6 million small cars with defective ignitions.

title: Massachusetts Starts Over on Health Website After Troubles
description: WASHINGTON  Massachusetts will stop trying to fix its deeply flawed health insurance website and instead buy new software to help its residents enroll in coverage, officials there said Monday. But the state will also prepare to join the federal insurance marketplace by the next enrollment period, which starts in November, in case the new system is not working in time.

title: The Declining Coffee Harvest
description: A fungus called coffee rust has caused declining harvests of Guatemalan coffee in the last two years. Luis Antonio, a coffee bean farmer, says the spread of the fungus is threatening his livelihood.

title: Judge Paves Way for Voting on Detroits Recovery Plan as Two Police Unions Settle
description: DETROIT  A federal judge on Monday signed off on a document that cleared the way for tens of thousands of Detroits retirees, employees and bondholders to begin receiving ballots on the citys plan for rebuilding and shrinking its debt.

title: Banks Sued on Claims of Fixing Price of Gold
description: Frustrated traders and offbeat activists have complained for years in whispers and in online screeds that the price of gold has been subject to collusion. On Monday, these accusations of manipulation found a more august arena for expression: the federal courts.

title: In Missouri, Republicans Prevail on Tax Bill
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  In a showdown over tax policy, the Republican-controlled State Senate on Monday overrode Democratic Gov. Jay Nixons veto of a major tax-cut bill, setting the stage for sharp reductions in state personal income taxes.

title: Republicans Have a Grimm Problem
description: Representative Michael Grimm, the only Republican in New York Citys congressional delegation, was indicted last week on charges of tax fraud. He insists he is innocent, but these charges come at a particularly bad time for his fellow Republicans. A former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, Mr. Grimm was already in trouble with many voters after he was shown on television threatening to throw a NY1 reporter off a balcony. Now he is accused of operating a restaurant illegally.

title: Complaints of Abuse by Border Agents Often Ignored, Records Show
description: On Feb. 16, 2010, a Mexican teenager caught trying to cross into the United States near Douglas, Ariz., filed a formal complaint accusing a Border Patrol agent of punching him in the face during his arrest.

title: Bailout Is Over for Portugal, but Side Effects Will Linger
description: LISBON  Europes climb out of its debt crisis has been narrated by a long debate on whether the austerity imposed on countries that needed international bailouts would bring more pain than relief.

title: A Defeat for Religious Neutrality
description: The American values of pluralism and inclusion are central to the First Amendment, which forbids government from favoring or aligning itself with any particular religion or believers over nonbelievers.

title: Berkshires Radical Strategy: Trust
description: OMAHA By the standards of the rest of the world, we overtrust. So far it has worked very well for us. Some would see it as weakness.

title: Chasing Death Camp Guards With New Tools
description: STUTTGART, Germany  After years of relative inaction, German prosecutors have opened dozens of fresh investigations of men and women suspected of having served as Nazi death camp guards, racing against the clock to bring the aging suspects to justice. Not since the end of World War II have so many cases been initiated at once.

title: Beard Award Winners Announced
description: California restaurants and female chefs fared well in this years James Beard Awards, which were announced Monday night at a ceremony at Lincoln Center attended by more than 1,700 food professionals and others.

title: Mr. de Blasios Moon Shot
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios housing plan is so big that it took not one but two media events, in Brooklyn and the Bronx, to unveil it on Monday, in which the mayor and local pols exulted over the plans breadth and ambition. Yet if Mr. de Blasio really is going to keep his campaign promise and end New Yorks crisis of inequality and housing unaffordability, he is going to have to go big.

title: Protectionism Will Only Hurt France
description: In a bid to encourage more foreign investment in France, President Franois Hollande in February told executives from foreign companies that the country was open for business. Unfortunately, officials in his government appear to be shutting the door in one case.

title: Ex-State Senate Leader on Trial Again for Fraud
description: ALBANY  The accusations are familiar: no-show jobs, fraud and big money for a horse of questionable value.

title: N.F.L. Prospect From Princeton Hits Right Notes
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The window shades were pulled low in the office of Steve Verbit, the longtime Princeton associate football coach. Caraun Reid was about to watch film. The N.F.L. draft was less than a month away, and Reid, a decorated Ivy League defensive tackle, cued the footage: Jets versus Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Sept. 8, 2013.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 5, 2014
Coca-Cola to Remove an Ingredient Questioned by Consumers
description: Coca-Cola is moving to eliminate an ingredient used in many of its citrus-flavored products after consumers expressed concerns.

title: Judicial Nominees Memos on Drones Stirring Bipartisan Concern in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas choice for a powerful appeals court appointment is in peril from both the left and the right, highlighting how the fraught politics of an election year are threatening the presidents agenda even among his allies on Capitol Hill.

title: Marquee Matchup of Playoffs Second Round Has Star Power to Spare
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Before the celebration had stopped in the Los Angeles Clippers locker room Saturday night, as the joy of vanquishing the Golden State Warriors in a seven-game series still coursed among the players, a scouting report of the Oklahoma City Thunder sat in each players cubicle.

title: Quashed Case Against Christie Ally Was Foretaste of Scandal
description: Before the bridge scandal, there was Bennett Barlyn.

title: Lack of Orderly Means to Distribute Aid Is Latest Setback for Afghan Village
description: ABI BARAK, Afghanistan  An outpouring of aid has come to the remote village of Abi Barak, where a devastating landslide is likely to have claimed 2,100 lives and instantly left thousands homeless. Tents, water, food and blankets have streamed in from all quarters, including community donations and international contributions.

title: A Coffee Crop Withers
description: SAN LUCAS TOLIMN, Guatemala  When coffee rust attacked the farms clinging to the volcanic slopes above this Mayan town, the disease was unsparing, reducing mountainside rows of coffee trees to lattices of gray twigs.

title: A House, and Family, Divided
description: Hester Ferris, the social lioness played by the marvelous Jan Maxwell in the terrific new play The City of Conversation, by Anthony Giardina, knows a fellow feline when she sees one. When the pert young woman who has arrived in Hesters plush Georgetown living room asks innocuously if she can observe as Hester prepares for the power-player dinner party she is hosting that evening, Hester turns on her a glare both amused and assessing.

title: So the Story Goes
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  One of the crueler tricks in the Mean Older Sibling Handbook that you might have committed when you were young was a little something dubbed PICK UP STICKS. In my house, at least, this was a bonus round to the game KerPlunk, a strategy game where you had to carefully withdraw wooden (later, plastic) skewers from a cylinder without letting any of the marbles balanced on top fall to the bottom of the cylinder.

title: U.S. Signs New Lease to Keep Strategic Military Installation in the Horn of Africa
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Monday that it had signed a 20-year lease on its military base in Djibouti in the Horn of Africa, the only American installation on the continent and a staging ground for counterterrorism operations in Yemen and Somalia.

title: Obama Meets With Djibouti President
description: President Obama discussed the situation in Somalia at a meeting with President Ismail Omar Guelleh of Djibouti.

title: High-Tech Push Has Board Games Rolling Again
description: MERCER ISLAND, Wash.  Dan Shapiro sold a company to Google and worked at Microsoft. His name is on nearly a dozen technology-related patents.

title: PBS Seeks Web Sponsors, but Big Bird Still Wont Sing Jingles
description: FOR the first time, PBS is signaling Madison Avenue how interested it is to sell sponsorships and other types of advertising for the online video clips and series that are published through its PBS Digital Studios division.

title: If Nets and Heat Are Not Yet Rivals, Their Players Are
description: MIAMI  Paul Pierce insisted on Sunday that there was not a rivalry between the Nets and the Miami Heat, the teams that will meet Tuesday to begin a much-anticipated Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series.

title: Now Comes Chapter 5 in Players Rivalry
description: LeBron James has tangled with Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce in the postseason on four previous occasions, all of the battles occurring when Garnett and Pierce played for the Boston Celtics.

title: Renovator of Victorian Beauties Profits From Preservation
description: In the enclaves of Victorian Flatbush  Prospect Park South, Ditmas Park, Midwood  no two houses look exactly alike, though many share the same grand flourishes, with turrets, wraparound porches and columns inside and out.

title: Rhode Island: Circus Accident Linked to Metal Fastener
description: Fire officials in Providence said an accident that injured nine performers with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus on Sunday apparently occurred when a metal fastener snapped, causing an apparatus to plummet 30 feet to the ground. Eight of the performers remained at Rhode Island Hospital on Monday, with two listed in critical condition and the rest in serious or good condition. The circus canceled two performances on Monday but said performances planned for Hartford later this week would proceed as scheduled.

title: In South Africa, A.N.C. Is Counting on the Past
description: ALEXANDRA, South Africa  In this poor black township on the outskirts of Johannesburg, the campaign posters exhorting voters to return the African National Congress to power in Wednesdays election reached deep into the partys glorious past.

title: New Mexico: New Protests Against Albuquerque Police
description: Protesters in Albuquerque threw fake arrest warrants at the police chief on Monday, prompting the City Council to end debate on a charter amendment that would transfer authority for picking the police chief from the mayor to voters. The protest came two days after an officer fatally shot Armand Martin, the 25th person killed by the police here since January 2010. The Justice Department recently released a report rebuking the Police Department for systematically using excessive force.

title: Jeters Swing, for Now, Is Missing His Final Tour, Raising Questions of Resilience
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Over the course of his 20 seasons in the major leagues, Derek Jeter has played in 79 games at Angel Stadium and done well, despite some painful losses in the postseason.

title: At Met Gala, Fashionistas Dress Up in Tribute
description: On Monday night, at the Metropolitan Museum of Arts annual Costume Institute gala, there were ball gowns, leg slits, white ties and trains. Lots of trains.

title: Mets Bullpen Squanders Lead as Marlins Stage a Late Rally
description: MIAMI  Mets Manager Terry Collins shrugged his shoulders, pursed his lips and averted his eyes. His bullpen had blown another game, wasting a strong start from Jon Niese.

title: Obama Aides Tell Executives to Skip Forum
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has pressured the chief executives of some of Americas largest energy, financial and industrial corporations into canceling plans to attend an international economic forum in Russia to be hosted by President Vladimir V. Putin this month, the latest effort to isolate Moscow in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine.

title: Once Again, Weary Rangers Come Up Empty
description: Their coach challenged Rick Nash, Martin St. Louis and other Rangers stars to put on their big boy pants against Pittsburgh on Monday. But the weary Rangers responded in miserable fashion, fumbling and bumbling their way to a 2-0 loss, and falling behind the Penguins in their second-round playoff series by two games to one.

title: Intersection | Berlin Fashion Boldness
description: In the Kreuzberg neighborhood, Ron Dietze, a musician, loves that you can wear colorful clothing, like his vintage red leather jacket, without getting strange looks.

title: Syrian Opposition Delegation Is Given Diplomatic Status
description: WASHINGTON  As a delegation of Syrian opposition leaders arrived in Washington to plead for more American support, the Obama administration on Monday granted the group diplomatic status and pledged an additional $27 million in nonlethal assistance.

title: Breakthrough for Crosby Sets the Tone
description: For Sidney Crosby, it was simply a matter of time.

title: Rent Board Backs Raises Much Smaller Than Usual
description: New York Citys Rent Guidelines Board voted on Monday night to recommend an unusually low range of possible rent increases for the coming year, even raising the possibility of a rent freeze for one-year leases.

title: With Death, 84 Shooting Brings New Charge
description: Carlos Carromero served nearly a decade in prison after pleading guilty to attempted murder in the 1984 shooting of John Pugh, in the Bronx.

title: Ex-General Vows to End Brotherhood if Elected
description: CAIRO  Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover here last summer and is expected to become president next month, vowed Monday to eliminate the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that dominated the previous elections.

title: India Election Digest: May 6
description: What you need to know on Tuesday about Indias elections: Overseas investors arent convinced that the Bharatiya Janata Party will win the balloting, intellectuals are united in their opposition to Narendra Modi of the B.J.P. but divided on the alternatives, and campaigning ends for the next-to-last phase of voting.

title: With Conspiracy-Minded Intrigue, Life Imitates Fiction in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Istanbul as an urban tableau of intrigue is well-worn literary and cultural terrain, traveled by Graham Greene and Ian Fleming and by more contemporary spy novelists such as Joseph Kanon and Alex Berenson.

title: Beijing Steps Up Campaign Against Pollution
description: BEIJING  The Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau announced Monday that it had imposed fines of more than $1.7 million against companies and business ventures that violated air pollution standards in the first four months of 2014.

title: The Narrative of Home
description: As with her novels, the decoration of the Milan apartment belonging to Italian writer Benedetta Cibrario reveals an obsession with moments gone by and objects that mark the passage of time.

title: From the Design Curator Murray Moss, a Book of Unexpected Juxtapositions
description: For the veteran design entrepreneur Murray Moss, 2012 was a year of turning points. It saw the closing of his fabled SoHo boutique Moss, and it was also the year he was diagnosed with Parkinsons. He soon discovered that his medication had a number of side effects. They keep me up late at night, he says, and they increase my already compulsive nature. He sought to turn these new traits to his advantage by combing through hundreds of vintage press photos in the wee hours, and combining them to create surprising, often funny visual conversations. This is what I used to do, literally daily, for 18 years, with the objects I displayed at the store, Moss says. Now I exercise this obsession with juxtapositions I make with press photographs instead of objects. Its like making a movie and filming multiple endings. His efforts are showcased in his new book, Tertium Quid ($75), due out later this month in a limited print run.

title: Inside Elena Arzaks Kitchen
description: Last week we introduced readers to Elena Arzak, one of only two women chefs named to the 2014 Worlds 50 Best Restaurants list for her familys restaurant, Arzak, which she runs with her father Juan Mari Arzak. Here, Elena invites T into her restaurant, perfectly located, she says in the above video, in the seaside town of San Sebastin. Step into her beautifully orchestrated kitchen as she discusses Basque cuisine, the creative and modern influence El Bulli had on her regional cooking and the importance of family  from her secret to working seamlessly with her chef father to the value of a balanced and lip-smacking staff meal. The staff meal or family meal is really important, she says. It has to be very well made, very well cooked, no different from what goes out to the restaurant.

title: Getty to Jump-Start Latin American Art Research in California
description: LOS ANGELES  The ambitious regionwide arts collaboration known as Pacific Standard Time, which three years ago focused on Southern California art from 1945 to 1980, will have for its sequel a broader but still relatively underexamined field: Latin American art.

title: South Korea: Ferry Diver Dies
description: One of the civilian divers searching for victims of the South Korean ferry disaster died on Tuesdayafter losing consciousness underwater, officials said. The diver, identified as Lee Gwang-ok, 53, was employed by a salvage company that worked with Navy divers in the now three-week-old effort to recover bodies from the 6,825-ton ferry Sewol, which capsized and sank off southwestern South Korea on April 16. The divers have struggled against strong currents and poor visibility to reach the ship and then make their way through a dark maze of corridors and cabins clogged with debris. As ofTuesday, 39 people remained missing, with 263 confirmed dead.

title: George H. Heilmeier, an Inventor of LCDs, Dies at 77
description: George H. Heilmeier, an electrical engineer who in the 1960s helped invent a kind of screen display that used liquid crystals to project images  technology that is now ubiquitous in telephones, digital watches, computer monitors and flat-screen televisions  died April 21 in Plano, Tex. He was 77.

title: Word of the Day | typhoon
description: typhoon\ti-fn\ noun

title: For Female Filmmakers, Indies Provide More Work Than Studios, Study Finds
description: In case there was any doubt, women fare better when they go independent.

title: Time to Worry About Stock Market Bubbles
description: With relatively little fanfare, the stock market has become expensive again.

title: Times Minute | Three Primaries to Watch
description: Jonathan Martin, national political correspondent for The Times, on contests to watch in North Carolina, Georgia and Kentucky for early clues about the 2014 midterm elections.

title: Times Minute | Three Primaries to Watch
description: In the Video

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (Starz Cinema) ANIMAL KINGDOM (2010) A bleached-blond mama lion (Jacki Weaver, above, with Sullivan Stapleton) with piercing blue eyes and a glinting smile and her brood of armed robbers and drug dealers (Luke Ford, Mr. Stapleton and Ben Mendelsohn) take on rogue cops in Melbourne in this directorial and screenwriting debut from David Michd. But then a police sergeant (Guy Pearce) on the right side of the law interrogates her grandson (James Frecheville), who has been thrown into the fray after his mother dies of a heroin overdose, and plants the seeds of distrust that force him to fight to save himself. The films depiction of the raw fear lurking below the brothers braggadocio is the most pronounced emotion in a movie whose focus on the personalities of its criminals suggests an Australian answer to Goodfellas, minus the wiseguy humor, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The relative absence of gun battles and car chases helps Animal Kingdom build and sustain a mood of deepening dread. It goes out of its way to deglamorize the criminal life and portray its family of crooks as warped psychopathic thugs in a losing enterprise.

title: U.S. Air Force Aids Rescue of Chinese Fishermen in Pacific
description: United States Air Force rescue personnel parachuted into the Pacific Ocean 1,100 nautical miles off the Mexican coast to assist in the rescue of Chinese fishermen injured in a fire.

title: Jack Ageros, a Champion of El Barrio, Dies at 79
description: Jack Ageros was an activist. The term is concise, like his many sonnets, but it hardly captures the expanse of his life, which saw him go from a childhood in East Harlem to defending its Puerto Rican people as an antipoverty official, celebrating its culture by expanding and moving El Museo del Barrio, and memorializing its greatest poet by translating the complete works of Julia de Burgos.

title: Corrections: May 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Another Violent Attack at Railway Station in China
description: A man with a knife slashed at least six people during a brazen late morning assault outside a railroad station in Guangzhou, China, on Tuesday, officials said. It was the third such attack by assailants at a railroad station since March.

title: Yankees Angrily Fall to Angels in First Game of Trip
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Shawn Kelley had just been removed from the game after issuing a walk to Howie Kendrick in the eighth inning, and as he walked off the mound, he yelled something at the home-plate umpire, Laz Diaz, who had already been involved in a nasty argument with Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.

title: U.S. Said to Seek Records From Anticorruption Panels Members
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have issued a grand jury subpoena seeking emails, text messages and other records from all the members of the anticorruption commission that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo abruptly shut down in March, three people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

title: Hedge Fund Moguls Pay Has the 1% Looking Up
description: Hedge fund managers heavily populate the so-called 1 percent in the United States. And they are getting richer.

title: The Device that Runs the Worlds Biggest Election
description: NEW DELHI  Thanks to a device that is the size and shape of a mini piano keyboard, India can boast that the countrys voters, all 814.5 million of them in 543 constituencies, can cast their ballot electronically, even in areas that have just one person.

title: Earnings Slide at Barclays on Trading Slowdown
description: LONDON  The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that its first-quarter profit fell 5 percent from the period a year earlier as revenue from trading bonds, currencies and commodities declined.

title: UBS Profit Rises 7% Amid Restructuring
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS said on Tuesday that first-quarter profit rose 7 percent as it reshaped its business to reduce risk and better navigate future financial upheavals.

title: Beijing Kebab Vendors Among List of Polluters Hit With Fines
description: China has engaged in a war against pollution, as Prime Minister Li Keqiang has said. And in the trenches on the enemy side are legions of roadside kebab vendors, if one takes Beijing officials at their word.

title: Test Yourself | History, May 6
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits
description: In X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits, William J. Broad reports on a discovered shipwreck, decades of legal battles, an arrest warrant and finally a new recovery effort.

title: Universal Mammograms Show We Dont Understand Risk
description: In an effort to reduce childhood injuries, the American Academy of Pediatrics issued a policy statement in 2001 recommending that all kids younger than 2 sit in safety seats in airplanes as they do in cars.

title: Radio Killed the Political Star
description: Mike Rogers keeps telling me how fed up he is with all of the brand identity politicians he is serving alongside in the United States Congress. And by this, the Republican from Michigan means those colleagues who would rather raise their profiles and get into the media and do that celebrity thing than, say, pass bills or help constituents or win the respect of peers. They are all about their brand, Rogers laments, drawing out the word with an extra disdainful beat: BRAAH-und. This, of course, is one reason that Rogers has decided to cede his chairmanship of the House Intelligence Committee, and all the loudmouths in the Peoples Chamber that come with it, for his very own talk-radio show. In March, he announced his decision to leave behind the whole celebrity political class in Washington, D.C. for what is expected to be a nationally syndicated gig with Cumulus Media.

title: Q. and A. About Birds in New York City
description: Updated, May 8 | Thank you to everyone who participated in our Q. and A. with Gabriel Willow. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature, but his responses about birds are available in the comments section.

title: Running Food, Taking Photos
description: So, whats a food runner?

title: Does Suffering Make Us Stronger and Lead to Success?
description: The writer Alfie Kohn challenges the drumbeat of critics who contend that kids these days get too many rewards, from stickers to trophies, without truly earning them. He disputes the commonly held notion that suffering and conditionally granting awards (e.g., trophies only for the winners) prepare children for real life and teach them resilience.

title: As Ukrainian Election Looms, Western Powers and Russia Campaign for Influence
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Russia and the West maneuvered on Tuesday ahead of a seemingly inevitable clash over Ukraines plan to hold a presidential election on May 25 that Western powers view as crucial to restoring stability and that the Kremlin says will be illegitimate, particularly if the government in Kiev cannot first stabilize the country.

title: G.O.P. Establishment Sees Its Candidate Win North Carolina Senate Primary
description: WASHINGTON  Thom Tilliss victory Tuesday in the North Carolina Republican Senate primary sets up a campaign against Senator Kay Hagan, a first-term Democrat, in what will be one of the nations most contentious and expensive races in the battle to win control of Congress.

title: In Our Pages: May 7
A Festive Curtain Raiser, Yes, But One With Somber Hues
description: Spring for Music opened on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall with a powerful New York premiere: Christopher Rouses Requiem by the New York Philharmonic and the Westminster Symphonic Choir, conducted by Alan Gilbert. In many ways it was a perverse choice for the occasion. This weeklong festival, in its fourth and  because of a shortage of financing  final year, is a joyous celebration of orchestral excellence and adventurous programming. Orchestras from across North America converge for a good-natured contest of skill and spirits, cheered on by supporters who fill the auditorium with the colors of their hometown band.

title: Rights Lawyer Detained Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
description: A prominent civil rights lawyer has been detained by the Beijing police one month before the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement, friends and human rights groups said on Tuesday.

title: New York Today: Sports Turnaround
description: Good morning on this fair Tuesday.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: 4 Employed by Operator of Doomed South Korean Ferry Are Arrested
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Four officials with the operator of the doomed South Korean ferry have been arrested on charges of overloading the ship with cargo, a senior prosecutor said on Tuesday, as President Park Geun-hye attributed one of her countrys worst peacetime disasters to corporate greed.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | The Wonders of Wandering
description: A video by Lucas Schroeder made to accompany his winning essay.

title: Bayer Deal to Expand Consumer Business With Merck Deal
description: Updated, 12:06 p.m. | LONDON  The German drug maker Bayer said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Mercks consumer care business for $14.2 billion, a deal that will make Bayer one of the largest providers of over-the-counter products.

title: How to Move the Windows Address Book to a New Computer
description: Q. Is there a way to move the information in the Windows XP address book program to a Windows 7 computer so I dont have to retype it?

title: Too Hot to Be Safe
description: Unwary smokers of electronic cigarettes may have a new danger to worry about. Those who heat the liquid nicotine and its solvents to very high temperatures to get an especially big nicotine jolt are apt to get a big dose of formaldehyde or other carcinogens as well.

title: Profiling the City He Knew, and Learned to Know
