description: For two years, Michael Powell has written the Gotham column about New York politics and government. In July he will become a Sports of The Times columnist. Before he immerses himself in the world of sports, we asked him to reflect on his time writing about New York and New Yorkers.

title: Using Mac Notifications and Multi-Touch Gestures
description: Q. I have a new Mac laptop and have noticed that I keep accidentally doing something that opens a list of calendar appointments and new email messages on the right side of the screen that stays there until I click around. What is this?

title: The First Meeting Was Fabulous. Why Isnt My Phone Ringing?
description: I believe Im a good salesperson. Im good at getting meetings with the right people and getting them excited, but I suffer from recurring attacks of what I call First Meeting Syndrome. My first meeting is red hot, but I struggle to get a follow-up; time passes and the deal goes cold. Im a great door-opener, but Im not so good at closing the deal.

title: Daily Report: Computer Technology Is Reviving the Board Game
description: Technology, by all rights, should have killed old-fashioned games, which can never equal the eye-popping graphics, visceral action and immense online communities of todays video games. Yet the opposite has occurred. Largely because of new technologies, there has been a creative outpouring of games by independent designers, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: U.S. International Relations
description: Obama finds himself outnumbered on the international court.

title: A Big Haul for Hedge Fund Moguls
description: Hedge fund managers, who heavily populate the so-called 1 percent in the United States, are getting richer. The 25 highest-earning hedge fund managers in the United States took home a total of $21.15 billion in compensation in 2013, according to an annual ranking published on Tuesday by Institutional Investors Alpha magazine, DealBooks Alexandra Stevenson writes. The payday, earned in a year when most hedge fund managers fell short of market performance, is the highest since 2010 and 50 percent more than in 2012. No women placed among the top 50.

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: A colleague noted six uses of the description deep-pocketed in our copy in a single week not long ago. There were four more appearances during another recent week: deep-pocketed investors, deep-pocketed donors and deep-pocketed tobacco companies (twice).

title: In Performance: Vanessa Williams of After Midnight
description: This weeks video features the actress Vanessa Williams singing the number I Cant Give You Anything but Love, written by Dorothy Fields and Jimmy McHugh, from the Broadway musical revue After Midnight. Ms. Williams is performing in the show at the Brooks Atkinson Theater through May 11.

title: VSCO, a Digital Photography Company, Raises $40 Million From Accel Partners
description: Chances are, if you have used Instagram, you have come across the hashtag #VSCO or #VSCOCam.

title: AstraZeneca Makes Its Case Against Pfizers Takeover Bid
description: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | AstraZeneca, the British drug maker, on Tuesday made an impassioned defense for itself as a stand-alone company, just a day after the American pharmaceutical giant Pfizer again pressed its case for a $106 billion takeover offer.

title: Pistorius Is Accused of Sinister Aside During Break at Trial
description: The trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee South African track star, took a bizarre turn on Tuesday when a lawyer claimed that during an adjournment, the athlete had asked a close friend of the woman he is accused of murdering, How can you sleep at night?

title: Jimmy Kimmel Gets a Two-Year Contract Extension
description: ABC has affirmed its commitment to its late-night star Jimmy Kimmel, extending the hosts contract for two more years.

title: Alphonso Mangoes Flood Indian Market After E.U. Ban
description: MUMBAI, India  The Indian mango, and in particular the Alphonso, is a much-coveted and much-fetishized fruit by Indians, loved as much for its flavor as for its scarcity. Because of its rarity the fruit has achievednear-mythical importancein India, where access to mangoes early in the season is a sign of prestige.

title: U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods
description: The effects of human-induced climate change are being felt in every corner of the United States, scientists reported Tuesday, with water growing scarcer in dry regions, torrential rains increasing in wet regions, heat waves becoming more common and more severe, wildfires growing worse, and forests dying under assault from heat-loving insects.

title: Paying for Snacks: An Outrage
description: Dear Diary:

title: Float, Memory
description: Amid an ocean of style disasters, one man explores the sartorial and psychological conundrums of the swim trunk.

title: Barclays Technology Banker to Join Evercore
description: The exodus of former Lehman Brothers bankers from Barclays continues as its top technology banker departs the bank.

title: Fund Founded by Alistair Lumsden Opens to Outside Money
description: LONDON  East Lodge Capital Partners, a London hedge fund founded by Alistair Lumsden, has opened to outside money, according to a letter sent to investors on Tuesday.

title: Do Critics Make Good Novelists?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Leslie Jamison discuss whether literary critics can also be good novelists.

title: A List of Those Whove Left Barclays This Year
description: Tuesday brought the announcement of another senior banker from Barclays  J. Stuart Francis, chairman of the banks global technology group  who is decamping to Evercore Partners.

title: Join the Debate: Should We Let Kids Quit Activities?
description: Its me versus  my colleague Bruce Feiler on Room for Debate. (Bruce writes This Life for Sunday Styles.) Bruce is a staunch advocate of kid-commitment:

title: Cornelius Gurlitt, Scrutinized Son of Nazi-Era Art Dealer, Dies at 81
description: BERLIN  Cornelius Gurlitt, the German recluse who captured the art worlds attention last fall after it was revealed that he had kept hidden for decades a collection of 19th- and 20th-century European masterworks amassed by his father under the Nazis in his Munich apartment, died on Tuesday at his home in Munich. He was 81.

title: Jonny Greenwood to Join Performance of His Film Score
description: Jonny Greenwood, the lead guitarist for Radiohead who has been devoting himself in recent years to experimental orchestral music  an interest he developed as a teenage violist  will join the Wordless Music Orchestra in September for a concert performance of his There Will Be Blood film score. The performances, on Sept. 19 and 20 at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, will include a full screening of the 2007 Paul Thomas Anderson film, with the orchestra playing the score live. (Besides the sections composed by Mr. Greenwood, the score includes music by Arvo Prt and Brahms.)

title: How an Experiment With Dolls Helped Lead to School Integration
description: This 1947 photograph (by Gordon Parks, for Ebony Magazine) may look simply like a child being observed at play, but, in fact, it reveals an experiment that helped lead 60 years ago this month to the Supreme Courts monumental decision in Brown v. Board of Education, demanding the racial integration of American public schools.

title: Even With Maturity, Pauls Inner Defiance Flourishes
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Do not let the clever commercials with his alter ego fool you. And those bright, expressive eyes? They are not the windows to this soul.

title: Capus, Once Head of NBC News, Moves to CBS Evening News
description: CBS News announced on Tuesday that Steve Capus, the former president of NBC News, would become the executive producer of its evening newscast, anchored by Scott Pelley.

title: Plans for Barenboim-Said Academy in Berlin Unveiled
description: BERLIN  The Barenboim-Said Academy unveiled the architectural model for its new headquarters at a news conference on Tuesday here and announced an official opening date of October 2016.

title: A Merging of Movement Cultures and Subcultures
description: There is no chief curator, no unifying aesthetic and no central headquarters for Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas. This citywide undertaking, led by the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, is willfully, delightfully heterogeneous.

title: Two Ensembles Step Into the Others Shoes
description: Its not unusual for ensembles to have a composer or two in their midst, although its certainly more uncommon for all members to be performers and composers. And its surely a first for a group to feature a trombone, trumpet, clarinet and baritone, the combination that makes up the ensemble Loadbang.

title: Today in Small Business: Credit Cards for Small Businesses
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Scent Messaging Wafts In
description: Tuesday begins the slow rollout of oNotes, a so-called scent messaging platform from which all sorts of olfactory miracles are supposed to unfurl, including a device, out in early 2015, that will deliver scent messages (via text, tweet or email) and play olfactory tunes. Dont scoff: the oPhone is no overpriced Febreze dispenser. One of its inventors is David Edwards, a bio-engineer at Harvard and the founder of Le Laboratoire, a celebrated collaboration hub in Paris, who has been exploring the far edges of food and technology with products like edible packaging and inhalers that deliver shots of taste and aromas. Hes a bit of rock star, or to mix imagery, Willy Wonka with lots of venture capital.

title: Sotomayor Finds Her Voice Among Justices
description: WASHINGTON  I am a lawyers judge, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said last year. I write very technically.

title: Why Are We Moving Again?
description: I added up the expenses for our move: the trans-Atlantic move itself, health insurance, house rental and car. I considered the amount, went to the kitchen and opened a bag of chips. My husband, Matt, came in. We usually work at night after we put our two children to bed and then meet in the kitchen for snacks.

title: The American Scholar Crowdsources a Sonnet
description: Statisticians and late-night dorm-room bull session partisans have long debated whether a monkey banging away at a typewriter for an infinite amount of time would inevitably tap out the complete works of Shakespeare. But can a swarm of people on the Internet write a plausible sonnet in 14 weeks?

title: Jessye Norman Talks About Stand Up Straight and Sing!
description: Stand Up Straight and Sing!, the memoir by the soprano Jessye Norman that came out on Tuesday, takes readers from her close-knit girlhood community in Augusta, Ga., to Carnegie Hall and beyond. Ms. Norman talks about her childhood in a supportive but segregated world, singing for Rosa Parks, befriending Marian Anderson and growing up as an artist. Ms. Norman spoke about her book and her life during a recent interview at Carnegie Hall. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Morgan Stanley Fined $5 Million Over I.P.O. Work
description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has fined Morgan Stanley $5 million, saying that the firm did not follow proper procedures in the initial public offerings for 83 companies including Facebook and Yelp.

title: G.M. Recalls 56,000 Saturn Auras for Gearshift Cable Defect
description: After resisting federal regulators for about three years, General Motors is recalling about 56,000 Saturn Aura sedans from the 2007-8 model years because a transmission shifter cable could break, which would keep the driver from being able to shift the transmission into park.

title: Image of the Day: May 6
New Kidnapping Reported in Nigeria as U.S. Offers Help
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  A second kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigerias northeast by Islamist militants put new pressure on the countrys troubled government, which had been hoping to showcase its emergence as Africas largest economy this week but instead has been forced to confront its failure to contain a growing insurgency in its north.

title: A Conversation With Roz Chast
description: How did you pull this off, Roz Chast? How did you document the last eight years of your parents lives, in your distinctively doodle-ish drawings and candid prose, and make the story highly specific to their escape-from-the-Cossacks pasts in Brooklyn and, simultaneously, so universal? And how did you make this memoir  tellingly titled Cant We Talk About Something More Pleasant?  both heartbreaking and snortingly funny?

title: SAP and VMware Head for the Future Together
description: The big incumbents in enterprise computing are doing a lot of keeping up with the times this month.

title: A Lost Mendelssohn Song Surfaces
description: The manuscript of a lost song by Felix Mendelssohn that was known to scholars only by its title  Des Menschen Herz ist ein Schacht (A Mans Heart Is Like a Mine)  has turned up in a private American collection. Its whereabouts had been uncertain since the late 19th century, when it was listed in Leipzig auction catalogs in 1862 and 1872. It is about to be auctioned again, on May 24 at Christies in London. The houses online catalog gives its expected sale price as 15,000 to 25,000 (about $25,000 to $42,000).

title: Strolling Through Paris, Solo
description: It was easy in Paris to surrender to the moment, Stephanie Rosenbloom wrote in the Travel section this weekend. But why? What alchemy transmuted ordinary activities, be it a walk across a bridge or the unwrapping of butter, into a pleasure?

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 37
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Missouri Republicans Hand Defeat to Governor Once Called Purplish
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  Last September, Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, pulled off a political long shot: He lobbied so successfully against a tax-cut bill championed by the Republican-controlled Legislature that the lawmakers were unable to override his veto.

title: Times Minute | Climate Change Report
description: Climate change has moved firmly into the present, scientists reporting to the White House said. Also on the Minute, South Africas national elections and advance bids for top art at spring auctions.

title: Times Minute | Climate Change Report
description: In the Video

title: 60th Anniversary of the Four-Minute Mile
description: Roger Bannister broke the four-minute mile 60 years ago today. His time was 3 minutes 59.4 seconds.

title: The Most Daring Red-Carpet Ensembles From Last Nights Met Gala
description: Last night, the Anna Wintour Costume Center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art held its annual gala tocommemorate the work of the midcentury couturier Charles James. While thered carpet boasted no shortage of on-theme voluminous ball gowns and opera gloves  as worn bySarah Jessica Parker in Oscar de La Renta, KarenElson in Zac Posen and Suki Waterhouse in a stunning Burberry  the most interesting looks of the evening deviated from that formula. From StarWars prints and exposed midriffs to brocade cigarette pants andaustere minimalism, T salutes the women who politely declined the dress codeand instead demonstrated what a fashion red carpet is really all about.

title: Ask Well: Polio Vaccine
description: Do you have a question about the polio vaccine? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.

title: Major Research Groups Are Given Low Marks on Disclosing Donors
description: WASHINGTON  The conservative-leaning Hoover Institution, based in California, and the liberal Center for American Progress, based in Washington, are polar opposites in terms of political leanings. But according to a first-of-its-kind survey of the worlds most prominent research organizations, the institutions share an important trait: a relatively poor record of disclosing the sources of their financing.

title: A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
description: ROME  A true if unlikely tale: Young woman enrolls at a drama school sponsored by nuns, where the artistic director is a former Italian erotic film actress who redirected her career after a religious awakening. The students are selected to perform before the pope at St. Peters Square, but during rehearsals the young woman fractures an ankle.

title: Witnesses on China Train Station Attack
description: Witnesses recalled moments of chaos after a knife attack at a railway station in Chinas southern city of Guangzhou wounded six people.

title: Europe Seeks Tougher Rules on Aircraft Recorders
description: PARIS  Nearly two months after a Malaysian jetliner disappeared, Europes aviation safety agency on Tuesday formally proposed a series of new measures aimed at improving the chances of finding the flight recorders of aircraft that crash at sea.

title: The Party and the Hangover
description: Here are a couple of ideas that didnt make it intomy Sunday columnon Paying For the Party: How College Maintains Inequality, a rich and depressing new book about the relationship between libertine social life and socioeconomic stratification at a prominent Midwestern state university:

title: What Tim Geithner Got Right
description: Jennifer Taub is an associate professor at Vermont Law School. Her book Other Peoples Houses will be published on May 27 by Yale University Press.

title: Ex-Christie Aide, Testifying in Bridge Inquiry, Portrays a Highly Political Office
description: TRENTON  Providing a vivid, firsthand account of how the George Washington Bridge lane closings exploded into scandal in Gov. Chris Christies office, a former aide to the New Jersey governor testified that the woman he cast as the central villain in the scandal was not a decision maker, and that she did not believe that woman had planned the closings.

title: A Mysterious Republican Committee in the Virgin Islands
description: There are a few things you should know about the Virgin Islands Republican Party: It has no full-time staff, has not had regular meetings for nearly two years, and only about 4 percent of the $200,000 it has raised since last fall has gone to party coffers.

title: Rainbow Room Will Reopen in October
description: Headliner

title: 101 Places to Find Great Coffee in New York
description: The number of serious coffee shops in New York has exploded. Enter your address to find the shops closest to you.

title: Wheelies: The i3 Invasion Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Tribute to Cannon Ball Bakers Century-Old Motorcycle Record Hits the Road
description: SAN DIEGO   A tribute to the  record-setting cross-country motorcycle journey by  Erwin G. Baker, known universally as Cannon Ball, 100 years ago is underway, with a group of enthusiasts retracing Bakers 11-day ride, May 3-14, from San Diego to New York City.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Raymond Pettibon and Iris Apfel
description: Raymond Pettibon, American artist and counterculture prophet whose drawings for the band Black Flag helped define punk culture, takes on Iris Apfel, style icon, interior designer and self-proclaimed geriatric starlet who will return in June to HSN, where she sells her Rara Avis line of chic and affordable accessories. (A new book of Pettibons work, Raymond Pettibon: To Wit, was just released.) See the chart.

title: Scene City: Inside (and After) the Met Ball
description: The annual star-filled gala at Mets newly named Anna Wintour Costume Center, followed by downtown party.

title: Rap Genius Website Agrees to License With Music Publishers
description: Rap Genius, a popular website that compiles annotations of song lyrics, has reached a licensing agreement with music publishers after being accused of using the lyrics of thousands of songs without permission.

title: Americans Are Outliers in Views on Climate Change
description: As President Obama sets out to convince the public that climate change requires immediate attention, he has his work cut out for him.

title: New Venture Envisions Films Based on Gritty Journalism
description: LOS ANGELES  An Oscar-winning screenwriter, a billionaire film financier and a well-known magazine editor have come together to form a movie and television company built on a journalism foundation.

title: French Set Conditions for G.E. Takeover of Alstom
description: PARIS  The French government, caught between concern about jobs at home and the nations reputation abroad for meddling in the economy, is plunging more deeply into the takeover offer for Alstom, one of Frances premier companies.

title: Netflix Redesigns Logo  Sort Of
description: When Netflix created its first logo  which is black and white and red all over  the company was going for a LOOK AT ME design.

title: Canny Taste Buds and a Nose for Sleuthing
description: Theres only one recipe in Delicious!, Ruth Reichls first novel, but its a keeper. You have to flip to the back to find it. Its for a gingerbread cake enlivened by orange zest and fresh ginger and black pepper and cloves and cardamom. Its for grown-up taste buds.

title: Missouri Keeps Tumbling Rightward
description: The Missouri legislature had no trouble passing a big tax cut today over the veto of Gov. Jay Nixon. As a Missouri native, Im probably more irritated by this than most Times readers are, but my state is only one of many that have been sharply pulled to the right in the last few years. Whats happening in Jefferson City is already familiar to residents of Wisconsin, Michigan, Kansas, North Carolina, and many others.

title: Travel Companies Boycott Brunei-Owned Hotel Group
description: Travel companies are boycotting the Dorchester Collection of hotels this week after Hassanal Bolkiah, the sultan of Brunei, the small, oil-rich country on the island of Borneo that owns the hotel group, began implementing a new criminal code that will allow for homosexuals and adulterers to be stoned to death.

title: The New Wave of Oyster Bars
description: LOS ANGELES  On the surface, Connie & Teds is the sort of hot new restaurant youd expect in West Hollywood. Its chef and co-owner, Michael Cimarusti, is an established culinary star. Its imposing building looks like a ski chalet outfitted with repurposed NASA parts. The busy valet-parking attendants see few economy cars.

title: The Garden, Both Muse and Oracle at LArpge
description: PARIS  Dinner started with a plate of leafy radishes followed by a small cabbage turnover, and ended with a garlic crme brle whose burned-sugar shell had been liberally spritzed with lemon confit. In between came a dozen courses made from turnips, carrots, peas, beets, cauliflower and potatoes. Two see-through bands of lardo on grilled white asparagus and, down at the bottom of vegetable minestrone, some bits of chorizo that would have fit into a gum wrapper were the only visible signs of animal flesh.

title: You Won 50 Games, Coach? Your Job Securitys Still Zero
description: Last year, it was George Karl, Lionel Hollins and Vinny Del Negro. This year, so far, it is Mark Jackson.

title: Watching North Carolina for Clues to the Senate
description: Over the last two cycles, the Republican nominating process cost the party critical Senate seats in states like Missouri, Delaware, Indiana, and probably in Colorado and Nevada as well. Similar mistakes in 2014 could easily cost Republicans the chance to take control of the Senate.

title: How Bayers Buy Makes Sense
description: Bayers $14.2 billion acquisition of Mercks consumer care business is less pricey than it looks.

title: In a Wheelchair, Honing a Defiant Stand-Up Act
description: Can a calamity plus a couple of months at Bellevue Hospital Center equal comedy?

title: Judge Voids Murder Convictions for 3 Half Brothers Linked to Brooklyn Detective
description: The decades-old murder convictions of three half brothers whose arrests were facilitated by a now discredited homicide detective were vacated in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday, as prosecutors acknowledged that the men had been deprived of fair trials because of a questionable witness.

title: Twitter Plunges as More Shares Hit Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Shares of Twitter went into free fall on Tuesday as early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market for the first time. The companys shares dropped 17.8 percent, to close at $31.85, their lowest level since the companys initial public offering of stock in November.

title: An Artist Who Let His Ideas (and Others) Do the Work
description: The central action in Sol LeWitt, Chris Teerinks eye-catching and informative new documentary about that great American conceptual artist, is the execution of one of his pieces  Wall Drawing 801: Spiral  on the interior wall of a vast, bell-shaped room at a Dutch museum.

title: Tiny Mouths to Feed, a Path Often Fraught
description: Whether spraying or leaking, massaged by hand or pumped by machine, the breasts of the young mothers in Breastmilk are arguably more active than the infants they nourish. Cheerfully exposed or decorously veiled, the functioning of these workhorses may be life-sustaining, but, as Dana Ben-Aris admirably agenda-free documentary reveals, it can also be shockingly stressful.

title: Reports on Alibabas I.P.O.
description: Investors are salivating over the initial stock offering of Alibaba Group, the giant Chinese e-commerce company.

title: A Portrait of the Outsider Artist, Older and Still Unfiltered
description: In more ways than one, Tamar Halpern and Chris Quiltys documentary Llyn Foulkes One Man Band is about not knowing when to stop. The filmmakers are blessed and cursed with a subject who seems to lack the usual filters. We in turn witness Mr. Foulkes in action, at length  revamping his works, railing against the art world and speaking his neurotic mind.

title: Sterlings Right-Hand Man Is Placed on a Leave of Absence
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The N.B.A. took another step in trying to clean up from the Donald Sterling scandal, announcing Tuesday that Andy Roeser, the Los Angeles Clippers president and Sterlings longtime lieutenant, had been put on an indefinite leave of absence.

title: G.E.'s Bid for Alstom Units Puts Siemens in a Bind
description: FRANKFURT  If the American industrial giant General Electric has a corporate doppelgnger in Europe, it is the German company Siemens. Both are global conglomerates that make trains, medical scanners and  most notably at the moment  the turbines and other equipment that generate and transport much of the worlds electricity.

title: Scene City: Inside (and After) the Met Ball
description: The annual star-filled gala at Mets newly named Anna Wintour Costume Center, followed by downtown party.

title: Lewinsky Breaks Silence About Clinton Affair, Saying She Was Made a Scapegoat
description: WASHINGTON  Monica Lewinsky says she became reclusive during Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign for president in 2008 for fear that she would be used for political purposes and that she feels gun-shy even now as Mrs. Clinton considers another run in 2016.

title: New Ice Cream Flavors Debut This Season, Houston Pralines and More
description: To Scoop: New Ice Cream Flavors Include Beer and Olive Oil

title: Chamber of Commerce Makes Ad Buy Supporting Pro-Business Republicans
description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday is releasing new 30-second television ads for 10 House Republican candidates, in a more than $3 million buy that will last for two weeks and is intended to support candidates who the group believes can win in November.

title: Knee-Jerk Revivals and Other Punch Lines
description: At the end of a long, bleary season on Broadway, a burnt-out case ducks into a hole in the wall off Times Square, looking for a little sympathetic companionship. Soon enough, he finds it in a woman perched on top of a piano, wearing a little beret and an air of infinite jadedness.

title: The Stock Market, in Six Charts
description: Recently on The Upshot, we explained why the stock market looks expensive. No doubt some stock traders and analysts will disagree and offer highly technical arguments to the contrary. Ive often found the debate around stock market valuations can be confusing. So below is a step-by-step guide, with some charts, to help to make sense of the current stock market outlook.

title: Chinese Giant Alibaba Will Go Public, Listing in U.S.
description: Updated, 9:04 p.m. | The Chinese e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for Chinas booming Internet industry.

title: Text to Text | President Johnsons Great Society Speech and 50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back
description: President Johnson announced 50 years ago this month his vision for a Great Society during two speeches  first at Ohio University and then at the University of Michigan. In those speeches he detailed his grand vision for America, which included not just ending poverty and racial injustice, but also a plan to build the Great Society in our cities, in our countryside and in our classrooms. A centerpiece of President Johnsons Great Society was to free all Americans of the crushing weight of poverty. In this Text to Text, we pair President Johnsons Great Society speech with an article by Trip Gabriel describing the new face of poverty in rural West Virginia.

title: Fanwood, N.J.: A Future Coupled With Transit
description: Every morning, Arbi Zadorian, a software programmer, walks a few blocks into town where he joins scores of other commuters at the Fanwood station to catch trains to Newark or New York. Built in 1874, the Victorian station is the oldest in Union County. It is also what has come to define this boroughs past, present and future.

title: Where to Find Serious Coffee in New York? Everywhere
description: If you want to see just how much has changed in New Yorks coffee scene in the last few years, stop by Gregorys Coffee.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: The Gun Report: May 6, 2014
description: Yesterday, the Supreme Court declined to consider a challenge to a New Jersey law that prohibits residents from carrying guns in public. It would have been the most significant gun control case since the District of Columbia v. Heller decision in 2008, which upheld the right to keep handguns at home for self-defense.

title: The Curious Case of Milwaukees Suburban Voters
description: The most polarized part of a polarized state in a polarized nation  thats how Craig Gilbert of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel describes the Milwaukee metropolitan area in the masterful first article of a four-part series on the regions politics. The region is just as polarized as Mr. Gilbert suggests.

title: Commute for Subway Art Is Three Years, Door to Door
description: Ralph Fasanellas painting Subway Riders has not budged since 1995, when it became the first oil painting to be installed in a New York City subway station. Now it is heading out on the road.

title: Frozen Helps Lift Profit for an Energized Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  The stunning success of Frozen, surging theme park spending, strong merchandise sales and higher fees for ESPN combined to deliver quarterly results for the Walt Disney Company that were nothing short of spectacular.

title: What Is Alibaba?
description: The e-commerce company has seized investor and public interest to an extent that is unusual for a company that does much of its business in China.

title: An Uncoupling, but the Band Plays On
description: Last month, word of the impending dissolution of the marriage of Chris Martin, frontman of Coldplay, and Gwyneth Paltrow arrived with an emphatic thud on her website, Goop.com. It is with hearts full of sadness that we have decided to separate, the brief statement began. The post was credited to Gwyneth & Chris, but it did not have the feel of a shared reveal. It ended with a plea: We have always conducted our relationship privately, and we hope that as we consciously uncouple and coparent, we will be able to continue in the same manner.

title: Another Idiot With a Gun
description: One of the many problems with the growing normalization of gun ownership is that a growing number of idiots will want to buy and keep guns for no particularly good reason, and a subset of those idiots will go on to kill people.

title: European Financial Trading Tax Moves Forward, Despite New Pockets of Resistance
description: BRUSSELS  An effort by some European countries to tax financial transactions met new resistance on Tuesday, as Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands voiced reservations.

title: After Huge Alibaba Payday, a Test for Yahoo Executives
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For Yahoo, the initial public offering of stock in the Alibaba Group will unlock the door to a giant trove of cash. Depending on the price of the deal, Yahoo most likely will receive $10 billion to $15 billion for the 9 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce company that it is required to sell in the offering.

title: Christies to Return Cambodian Statue
description: Yet another ancient statue looted in the 1970s from a single remote temple in the jungles of Cambodia has turned up in the United States, this time at Christies, which is voluntarily paying to return it to its homeland.

title: Beauty on the Met Gala Red Carpet
description: From moody pouts to birds nest hair, there were several beauty moments that could not go unaddressed.

title: Chef Elena Arzak on Basque Cuisine
description: Elena Arzak, joint head chef at Arzak restaurant in San Sebastin, Spain, discusses her training at El Bulli, working with her father and the importance of the staff meal.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Gustave H.
description: Part 2: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel discuss Ralph Fienness character in the film.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Almost Japanese
description: Part 3: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel talk about how the film deals with real history via a story set in a fake country.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Academy Ratio
description: Part 5: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel, explains why the majority of the film was shot in the old square Academy ratio format.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Inventing a Hotel
description: Part 4: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel recalls what inspired the look of the films titular hotel.

title: TimesTalks | Anderson & Fiennes: Preview
description: The director Wes Anderson and the actor Ralph Fiennes discuss their film The Grand Budapest Hotel.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the filmmaker Wes Anderson and the actor Ralph Fiennes.

title: Egyptian TV Cites Simpsons Episode as Proof Arab Spring Was Foreign Plot
description: During a recent broadcast on the Egyptian television channel Al Tahrir, the anchor Rania Badawy alerted viewers to what she called video evidence which suggests that what is happening in Syria today was premeditated. She then presented an 80-second clip from an episode of The Simpsons first broadcast in early 2001 and later dubbed into French and posted on YouTube.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Still Rolling!
description: Part 6: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel describe what it was like working together for the first time.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Wes and His Actors
description: Part 7: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel talk about the films impressive cast, and discuss Wes Andersons ability to attract star actors, even for bit parts.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Papers and Passports
description: Part 10: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel, discusses the filmmakers who influenced him the most on this film, and talks about why there are so many train scenes in the movie.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Young Owen Wilson
description: Part 12: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel explain why they dont think its good to rehearse too much when making a film.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Tony Revolori
description: Part 8: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel reveal the best thing about working on a Wes Anderson film, and talk about working with the newcomer actor Tony Revolori.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: A Smashed World
description: Part 9: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel explore the influence of Stefan Zweigs The World of Yesterday on the film, and the surreal pre-war feeling they tried to capture.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Wes Andersons 007
description: Part 11: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel, reveals his idea for a James Bond movie.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: The Newcomer
description: Part 13: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel, describes why he cast Ralph Fiennes as the films lead without ever having worked with him before.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Make the Thing
description: Part 15: The director and star of The Grand Budapest Hotel share their advice for young filmmakers.

title: Anderson & Fiennes: Treasured Objects
description: Part 14: Wes Anderson, director of The Grand Budapest Hotel, talks about what happens to the lovingly created props in his movies after a shoot is over.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, India, Philippines and China.

title: Jets Sued by Cheerleaders
description: The Jets on Tuesday became the fourth N.F.L. team to be sued by their cheerleaders for back wages.

title: Allowing Prayers at Town Meetings
description: To the Editor:

title: #BringBackOurGirls: Kidnapping Horror in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracking Nazi Guards
Silence on Honor Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Bishops Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizers Tax-Driven Plan
Philip Roth in Class
description: To the Editor:

title: White House on Climate Change Report
description: In a video released by the White House, President Obamas science adviser, John P. Holdren, discussed a new study on climate change.

title: Only Minorities Need Apply
description: SAN DIEGO  THIS year is the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, which among other things prohibits the use of race in deciding whom to hire, fire, promote or place in the best and worst jobs.

title: What Can I Do to #BringBackOurGirls?
description: Why is this not mentioned on Motherlode?

title: Leave Organic Out of It
description: The ever-increasing number of people working to improve the growing, processing, transporting, marketing, distributing and eating of food must think through our messages more thoroughly and get them across more clearly. I dont pretend to have all the answers, but I can say that a couple of buzzwords represent issues that are far more nuanced than we often make them appear. These are organic and G.M.O.'s (genetically modified organisms).

title: The Risks of Investing in Alibabas I.P.O.
description: The planned initial public offering of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, has Wall Street buzzing. But investing in the tech behemoth carries a number of risks.

title: Laid-Back English Country Retreats
description: English countryside hotels have sometimes had a reputation for being overly formal and stuffy, but that may change with several new properties that can be described as laid-back. The trend started in 2009 with the opening ofLime Wood(rates from 255 a night, about $428), a 29-room 18th-century hunting lodge turned upscale getaway in Hampshire, about 90 minutes southwest of London. Instead of the antique dcor typical of country retreats, the furnishings are contemporary and eclectic with touches like free-standing bathtubs in the middle of guest rooms. The hotel welcomes travelers in jeans and has a 20,000-square-foot spa and an Italian restaurant with its own smokehouse.

title: Whispers From Fed Could Lead to Wild Swings, Internal Critic Says
description: Jeremy Stein is in the final weeks of his role as the Federal Reserves most important internal critic, and Tuesday night in New York he renewed his warnings that the Feds retreat from its stimulus campaign may yet roil financial markets.

title: Kara Walker on Aerobics, DAngelo and Her Favorite Hair Haunt
description: This week, the artist Kara Walker will unveil a major new public artwork at at the decommissioned Domino Sugar factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, presented by Creative Time, the elaborately titled A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby, an Homage to the unpaid and overworked Artisans who have refined our Sweet tastes from the cane fields to the Kitchens of the New World on the occasion of the demolition of the Domino Sugar Refining Plant.

title: Driver Detained After Following Obama Daughters Motorcade
description: WASHINGTON  A driver followed a motorcade carrying the Obama daughters through a security checkpoint near the White House on Tuesday afternoon, leading the complex to be locked down as the car was stopped and searched in a restricted section of Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Alibaba, by the Numbers
description: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, is big. And from its user numbers to its valuation, everything about the company is growing.

title: The G.O.P. Cant Ignore Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  TO waste, to destroy our natural resources, to skin and exhaust the land instead of using it so as to increase its usefulness, will result in undermining in the days of our children the very prosperity which we ought by right to hand down to them amplified and developed.

title: A Name Pronounceable in Nearly Every Language
description: In a world of two-syllable Internet company names, Alibaba stands out.

title: U.S. Chamber of Commerce Begins Ad Blitz for G.O.P.
description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce released 30-second television advertisements on Wednesday for 10 Republican candidates for House seats in a broadcast campaign that will cost more than $3 million to run and will last two weeks. The ads will run in the districts of six incumbents  Andy Barr of Kentucky, Dan Benishek of Michigan, Mike Coffman of Colorado, Chris Gibson of New York, Joe Heck of Nevada and David Valadao of California  and in support of the candidates Bob Dold in Illinois, Stewart Mills in Minnesota, Doug Ose in California and Richard Tisei in Massachusetts. The chamber is changing its strategy to focus on the general election.

title: Paying Homage to Bin Laden, Mosque Re-emerges as Bastion of Militancy
description: LONDON  Rising from the heart of Islamabad, the Red Mosque has long been a barometer of militant Islam in Pakistan. In the 1980s it funneled fighters into the anti-Soviet jihad in Afghanistan. In the 90s its leaders made an awe-struck pilgrimage to visit their hero, Osama bin Laden, at his farm outside Kandahar.

title: Second Top Runner Is Signed by Skechers
description: Two weeks after Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon in Skechers, the brand added another distance star, Kara Goucher, to its sponsorship roster. The deal gives the shoe line, more commonly known for its fashion footwear, two of Americas most established and popular distance runners.

title: Can a Pope Help Sustain Humanity and Ecology?
description: VATICAN CITY  For four long days, several dozen physical, environmental and social scientists hunkered here with theologians, philosophers, economists and a poverty campaigner to explore ways to balance human ambitions with the planets limits. The rare joint meeting of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences  Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Nature, Our Responsibility  helped demarcate where science leaves off and the rest of society, including organized religion, plays a role in shaping the quality of human life and environmental conditions in this century.

title: Vatican Tells of 848 Priests Ousted in Decade
description: GENEVA  The Vatican has dismissed more than 800 priests for sexual abuse of children in the past decade and paid billions of dollars in compensation, senior Vatican officials told a United Nations panel on Tuesday, presenting the Roman Catholic Church as a model of reform but drawing the ire of victims groups that said it still seeks to dodge responsibility for the harm that priests continue to inflict.

title: Alibaba Investors Will Buy a Risky Corporate Structure
description: Shareholders have been willing to take a lot of risk in their lust for Internet initial public offerings, but Alibabas I.P.O. may take that risk to a whole new level. The reason: Investors in the offering wont have title to most of Alibabas Chinese assets because of Chinese prohibitions on foreign ownership.

title: Georgia College Seeks Return to Calm After Shootings Taint End of Academic Year
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  After two days of gunfire at Paine College, Tuesday brought a grim and uneasy silence here.

title: Nigerias Stolen Girls
description: Three weeks after their horrifying abduction in Nigeria, 276 of the more than 300 girls who were taken from a school by armed militants are still missing, possibly sold into slavery or married off. Nigerian security forces apparently do not know where the girls are and the countrys president, Goodluck Jonathan, has been shockingly slow and inept at addressing this monstrous crime.

title: Stanford to Purge $18 Billion Endowment of Coal Stock
description: Stanford University announced Tuesday that it would divest its $18.7 billion endowment of stock in coal-mining companies, becoming the first major university to lend support to a nationwide campaign to purge endowments and pension funds of fossil fuel investments.

title: Graying of America Is Speeding, Report Says
description: The number of Americans 65 and older is expected to nearly double by the middle of the century when they will make up more than a fifth of the nations population, according to a Census Bureau report released Tuesday.

title: Mocked on Internet, Diet Coke Alters Ads
description: A CAMPAIGN for Diet Coke carrying the theme Youre on, which the Coca-Cola Company introduced in North America only three months ago, is being turned off after being mocked in social media.

title: Jimmy Ellis, a Boxer Long in Alis Shadow, Dies at 74
description: Jimmy Ellis, the onetime sparring partner for Muhammad Ali who captured the heavyweight boxing championship after it had been stripped from Ali for his refusing induction into the armed forces, died on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky. He was 74.

title: Go Big, Get Crazy
description: Up to now, Russias president, Vladimir Putin, has been playing a weak hand in Ukraine very well. I mean, how strong are you when your allies insist on wearing masks? But Putin thinks he knows his adversaries better than they know themselves. He thinks the Americans will never be serious about energy, that the Europeans will never be serious about sanctions, that the Ukrainian reformers will never be serious about governance, and that he can control the separatist forces hes unleashed in eastern Ukraine and dial them up or down as he pleases.

title: In Speech and Essay, Chiara de Blasio Details Her Depression and Addiction
description: Taking on an unusual role for the child of a sitting mayor, Chiara de Blasio, 19, the first daughter of New York City, traveled to Maryland with her parents on Tuesday to accept an award from the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, and published an emotionally raw essay online about her struggle with depression and addiction.

title: Titles, Not M.V.P.s, Define the Greats
description: MIAMI  Welcome, Kevin Durant, to LeBron Jamess world. Enjoy yourself, while being mindful of every competitive stumble. Someone is liable to knock you over, kick you when youre down.

title: U.S. Sought Delay of Morsis Ouster, Egyptian Leader Says
description: CAIRO  Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who is poised to be elected Egypts president in next months elections, said in an interview broadcast Tuesday night that the American ambassador had asked him to hold off for a day or two before ousting the freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, last July.

title: The Six Banks Leading Alibabas Giant I.P.O.
description: The Alibaba Groups long-awaited prospectus was chock-full of information about the Chinese Internet titans business.

title: With Caution, a Poor Corner of Brooklyn Welcomes an Affordable Housing Plan
description: With its rows of two-family homes and its corridors of auto repair shops and storefront churches, East New York sits far away from the heated debates over density and building height that have roiled other, more sought-after Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Park Slope.

title: U.S. Imposes First Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
description: WASHINGTON  In its first use of economic sanctions against combatants in the bloody fighting in South Sudan, the Obama administration on Tuesday ordered asset freezes and travel bans on two individuals, one on each side of the conflict.

title: 3 Oregon Basketball Players Face Rape Allegations
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The University of Oregon has come under intense scrutiny this week after three mens basketball players  including one who transferred from Providence after being accused of sexual assault there  were investigated by the Eugene police in connection with rape allegations by an Oregon student.

title: 2 Apollo Global Partners Are Said to Be Leaving
description: Apollo Global Management has climbed to the pinnacle of the private equity world, reaping billions of dollars in profit and raising a huge new buyout fund.

title: Boston College Says It Will Return Interviews About Northern Ireland
description: BOSTON  Boston College officials said Tuesday that they would relinquish their secret interviews with former Irish paramilitaries if the interviewees, who spoke years ago under a guarantee of confidentiality, wanted them back.

title: The Global Polio Threat, Back Again
description: Just when it looked as if polio was headed toward eradication around the world, the disease is once again on the march.

title: A Conversation About Tests That Educators Want to Have, but Cant
description: Lets talk about testing.

title: They Bought Into a Scrappy Chinese Start-Up, and Now Stand to Reap a Windfall
description: Alibabas filing on Tuesday to sell stock to the public for the first time disclosed a handful of winners who are poised to reap big paydays for taking a chance on the company, the once-scrappy Chinese start-up founded by Jack Ma that has become an e-commerce giant.

title: Independent of the Independence Party
description: New Yorks Independence Party survives on confusion. Many who sign up with the party think they are registering as independent voters, unaffiliated with any party. Instead they are unwittingly contributing their names to a bizarre and fractious political group that endorses candidates from the two major parties. The Independence Party should lose its prime place on the state ballot, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo could make that happen by rejecting its endorsement this year.

title: Rising Temperatures
description: Average temperature in 1991-2012 compared with the 1901-60 average.

title: Brash Ukrainian Mogul Prepares to Fight U.S. Bribery Charges
description: VIENNA  Arrested on bribery charges at the request of the F.B.I., and freed on more than $170 million bail that a Russian friend paid in cash, Dmitry V. Firtash, one of Ukraines richest, most powerful and most secretive businessmen, sat at a conference table here in his office at Centragas Holding, one of the many companies owned by his international conglomerate, Group DF.

title: Burning the Beret
description: WASHINGTON  Monica Lewinsky says she would meet me for a drink.

title: Alan Steel
description: Mr. Steel, 64, is the president and chief executive of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, which, along with the Hudson Yards redevelopment and a spurt of new hotels, is helping to redefine the underused Far West Side of Manhattan.

title: How to Regulate Disruption?
Kershaw Pushes the Reset Button for the Dodgers
description: WASHINGTON  The best pitcher in baseball waited more than six weeks for Tuesday, and he was not shy about showing his frustration. Clayton Kershaw, the two-time National League Cy Young Award winner, would bounce a baseball against the outer wall of his managers office, every thump a reminder of how much he hated his first trip to the disabled list.

title: Here Comes Trouble
description: Before anything happens in Alain Buffards Baron Samedi, the set alone tells us a lot: a sloping, sleek white floor, like a barren hillside, curled up at two corners and slightly warped around the edges. Theres great potential soon to be tapped in that simple design (the work of Nadia Lauro), for highs and lows, for climbing up and sliding down, for stumbling off balance, for falling off the edge. Its unstable terrain.

title: Local Policies Help an Indian Candidate Trying to Go National
description: AHMEDABAD, India  To anyone familiar with the quagmire that typically engulfs large building projects in India, the reconstruction of the Sabarmati riverfront  championed for the last decade by Narendra Modi, the leader here in the state of Gujarat  is a startling sight.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Busy Arenas Keep Rangers on the Move
description: The Rangers had just played their sixth game in nine days, including two sets of back-to-back games, on Monday night when Coach Alain Vigneault called the teams schedule stupid.

title: Rival House Bills Aim to Rein In N.S.A. Phone Data Program
description: WASHINGTON  Senior members of the House Judiciary and Intelligence committees have agreed on similar but rival bills that would restrict the National Security Agencys ability to collect Americans phone call data in bulk.

title: From Netscape to Alibaba
description: A look back at the Internet revolutions notable I.P.O.s, and how valuations have fared over the years.

title: Fiat Chrysler, Unfazed by Quarterly Loss, Pins Hopes on Jeep
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  The new Fiat Chrysler Automobiles laid out an ambitious business plan on Tuesday that takes on a distinctly American flavor, relying heavily on growing sales of its Jeep sport utility vehicles.

title: Murder Charge for Driver in Drug-Related Crash at a Manhattan Deli
description: A driver who crashed a car into a corner grocery in the East Village last year was charged with murder on Tuesday, becoming the second defendant in Manhattan to face that charge in recent months after causing a fatal accident while drunk or under the influence of drugs.

title: Big Profits at Alibaba, but Filing Has Gaps
description: The Alibaba Group opened its books on Tuesday, revealing a company raking in extraordinary profits from its vast online marketplaces in China.

title: Russia Quietly Tightens Reins on Web With Bloggers Law
description: MOSCOW  Russia has taken another major step toward restricting its once freewheeling Internet, as President Vladimir V. Putin quietly signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government, a measure that lawyers, Internet pioneers and political activists said Tuesday would give the government a much wider ability to track who said what online.

title: Reaching Out to Tech and Creative Tenants, Starting With Lunch
description: A factory district does not typically spring to mind as a prudent location for retailing, but some of Manhattans successful food vendors have chosen the Falchi Building in a spartan part of Long Island City, Queens, for their next retail ventures.

title: Witness in Terrorism Case Recalls Being Taken Hostage in Yemen
description: The group of tourists was traveling in December 1998 when their convoy in Yemen was ambushed by armed militants who then took them hostage. The next day, with the sound of gunfire around them, one kidnapper turned to the group and said, Its goodbye to you all, one former hostage testified in federal court in Manhattan on Tuesday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 6, 2014
Examples of How Clippers Could Benefit From League Takeover
description: When Tom Schieffer became Major League Baseballs on-site monitor of the Los Angeles Dodgers three years ago, he did not expect huzzahs at Chavez Ravine, least of all from the combative Dodgers owner Frank McCourt. Commissioner Bud Seligs concerns over McCourts financial dealings and personal life had led Selig to take control of the Dodgers. McCourt was enraged.

title: Scientists See Quake Risk Increasing in Oklahoma
description: A sharp rise in the number of earthquakes in Oklahoma, apparently related to underground disposal of wastewater from oil and gas production, has significantly increased the chances that a damaging quake will occur there, federal and state scientists say.

title: Pakistan: Province Bars Entry to Those Not Vaccinated for Polio
description: In the wake of World Health Organization travel restrictions imposed on Pakistan to stop it from spreading polio abroad, one Pakistani province said Tuesday that citizens from anywhere else in the country would not be able to enter it without proof that they had been vaccinated. According to the news service Dawn, the health adviser to the chief minister of Punjab Province said vaccination booths would be set up at airports and all roads leading into the province, which includes the countrys second-largest city, Lahore. While many countries impose vaccine requirements on foreign visitors, vaccine requirements within a countrys borders are almost unheard-of. Almost all of Pakistans polio cases occur in the northwest frontier areas, where resistance to vaccine is high. Travel restrictions were also imposed Monday on Cameroon and Syria; they must ensure that anyone leaving their borders is vaccinated against polio.

title: Giant Development in Cambodia Hinges on Chinese Buyers
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  There is an island in Cambodia that, unlike others in Southeast Asia, is not the object of an ownership dispute. But it is equally clear whom its current owners would like to land there: Chinese property buyers.

title: After a Stroke, a Penguins Defenseman Makes an Impact
description: Watching Kris Letang dart up and down the ice, his long black hair waving behind, you would never know that 14 weeks ago, he was lying flat on his bathroom floor after having a stroke.

title: Focusing on Lesser-Known Open Spaces in New York
description: For the past year, the notion of park equity  that all of New York Citys parks should be equally well kept  has emerged as a hot topic in public policy discussions. It was the subject of a City Council hearing last month, and there is even a #ParkEquity hashtag on Twitter.

title: Words to Live By
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This one tickles my pop culture nerve endings, although I predict the theme wont be for everyone. There will be solvers who wonder what the point is of a theme that basically just lists the lines that made four male television stars famous, but for me, this theme by Kurt Mueller reminded me of my family.

title: At the U.N., a Free-for-All on Setting Global Goals
description: What should the worlds priorities be? Is the most urgent task to guarantee everybody a minimum standard of subsistence? To reduce inequality? To combat global warming, perhaps at the expense of economic growth?

title: U.S. Plan Aims to Draw Immigrants With Technology Skills
description: The Obama administration, looking to make adjustments to the nations immigration system while broader legislation is stalled in Congress, announced plans on Tuesday to allow the spouses of some highly skilled temporary immigrants to work in the United States.

title: Animated Debate in New York State Capital? Its About Yogurt
description: The New York State Senate sometimes considers weighty matters like taxes and budgets.

title: Associates of Kansas Governor Are Investigated Over Fund-Raising and Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. is investigating fund-raising and lobbying activities of associates of Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, an inquiry that follows his efforts to consolidate control of the states Republican Party during his first three and a half years in office.

title: Using Weathercasters to Deliver a Climate Change Message
description: WASHINGTON  Jim Gandy is the chief meteorologist on WLTX in Columbia, S.C., and makes a point of incorporating links between bad weather and climate change into his daily broadcasts.

title: Roy Thompson Jr., War Hero Who Played Himself in Movie, Dies at 85
description: Roy Thompson, a decorated officer during the Korean War who, while still on duty, starred as himself in a Hollywood movie that was shot entirely on location, died on April 22 in Panama City, Fla. He was 85.

title: Colon Has One Bad Inning, and Thats Bad Enough
description: MIAMI  Long before he was a Met, Bartolo Colon was considered an enigma. He looked overweight, he served a 50-game suspension after testing positive for synthetic testosterone and, as he approached 40, he was pitching perhaps as well as he ever had.

title: Alan J. Friedman, Who Revived Hall of Science in Queens, Dies at 71
description: Alan J. Friedman, a physicist who specialized in communicating the tenets of science to nonscientists and as the director of the New York Hall of Science in Queens oversaw its growth from a moribund museum to one of the citys formidable educational institutions, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Highlights of The Timess Alibaba Coverage
description: With the Chinese tech giant Alibaba announcing on Tuesday that it is going public, The Timess technology and business reporters examine the multifaceted impact of the initial public offering:

title: Federal Officials Reject Design of California Drivers Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
description: LOS ANGELES  Californias plan to offer drivers licenses to immigrants in the country illegally has hit a major snag, with the Obama administration informing state officials that the licenses they had designed violated federal law, California officials said Tuesday.

title: Yankees May Use Ryan to Replace Jeter Late in Games
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Brendan Ryan joined the Yankees for the first time this season on Tuesday after recovering from a back problem that shut him down early in spring training. And with him came questions about Derek Jeters playing time.

title: Supreme Injustice
description: The Supreme Courts ruling earlier this spring in McCutcheon v F.E.C., which increased the amount of money donors can contribute to political campaigns for federal office, has added new fuel to an 80-year-old debate between those who contend that the Supreme Court decides cases on the basis of abstract principles of law and those who argue that judicial rulings are based primarily on political and economic considerations.

title: Heat Snuff Nets Hopes of Early Edge
description: MIAMI  Before the Eastern Conference semifinals tipped off Tuesday night, there was a fairly rational debate about whether the Nets might be uniquely suited to destabilize the Miami Heat, the two-time defending champions and a popular favorite to win the title this year.

title: Fargo Recap: A Prayer for the Prey
description: Let us prosper in the smallest of ways. Ill be your humble servant the rest of my days.

title: India Election Digest: May 7
description: What you need to know about Indias elections on Wednesday: In the next-to-last phase of voting, seven states will go to the polls, with 897 candidates vying for 64 seats in the lower house of Parliament. The states participating in the eighth phase are: Andhra Pradesh (25 seats), Bihar (7), Himanchal Pradesh (4), Jammu and Kashmir (2), Uttar Pradesh (15), Uttarakhand (5) and West Bengal (6).

title: Insurers Say Most Who Signed Up Under Health Law Have Paid Up
description: WASHINGTON  Most of the people choosing health plans under the Affordable Care Act  about 80 percent  are paying their initial premiums as required for coverage to take effect, several large insurers said Tuesday on the eve of a House hearing about the law.

title: Christies First Spring Sale Drops Prices Back to Earth
description: After all the predictions that prices were only going one way  up  the spring auction season got off to a tepid start at Christies on Tuesday night, where some examples of Impressionist and modern art by Picasso, Kandinsky and Dal brought far less than expected; others barely skimmed by, and two classic works by Degas were left unsold, victims of estimates that were simply too high.

title: Times Minute | Obamas California Trip
description: Expect questions Obama the N.S.A. when he stops in Silicon valley. Also on the Minute, new media censorship from Vladimi Putin and a singing nun in Italy become a viral sensation.

title: The Luxury of Humility
description: Axel Vervoordt designed a penthouse hotel suite based on wabi-sabi, a philosophy that embraces quietude and modesty, in Manhattan, a place known for neither.

title: Art and Fashion Are at It Again
description: Last October, in Paris, Karl Lagerfeld transformed the Grand Palais into a white-walled art gallery filled with Chanel-themed paintings and sculptures for his spring/summer 2014 runway  a motif which seemed to officially set up this years warm-weather fashion landscape as one intertwined and imbued with art. And now that the season has arrived, the connection is undeniable. As fashion editors gear up for art and design shows opening both here and there  New Yorks Collective 2 design fair on Thursday and Frieze Art Fair on Friday, and Pariss Monumenta art exhibition at the Grand Palais on Saturday  obvious outfit choices abound, from artists-sketch-covered separates to sculptural bangles fit for a ceramists studio.

title: The Collective 2 Fair Kicks Off a Month of New York Design Happenings
description: This weekend sees the return of two hugely successful contemporary art fairs to New York, Frieze New York and NADA, which are set to fill the streets with collectors and fashionable folk from across the globe. But it also marks the kick-off for a month-long marathon of design events, openings, fairs, conferences and parties. The first is Collective 2, the second annual collectible design fair, which was started last year by the architect Steven Learner. It opens tomorrow at Moynihan Station.

title: Times Minute | Obamas California Trip
description: In the Video

title: Panel Urges One-Drug Lethal Injections
description: Days after President Obama said a bungled execution in Oklahoma was deeply disturbing and called for a review of how fairly the death penalty was used, a bipartisan panel of legal experts has urged sweeping changes in what it calls the deeply flawed administration of capital punishment.

title: Early Fitness Can Improve the Middle-Age Brain
description: The more physically active you are at age 25, the better your thinking tends to be when you reach middle age, according to a large-scale new study. Encouragingly, the findings also suggest that if you negligently neglected to exercise when young, you can start now and still improve the health of your brain.

title: HP Makes $1 Billion Bet on Open Cloud
description: Hewlett-Packard is making its big bet on cloud computing, with a significant change of its own products and business, and the biggest endorsement yet of an open source alternative to the systems of Amazon and Google.

title: Judge Halts Investigation of Political Spending in Wisconsin
description: A federal judge lateTuesdayordered that officials stop an investigation into political spending by conservative groups in recall elections that took place in Wisconsin in 2012, including that of Gov. Scott Walker.

title: Word of the Day | illimitable
description: illimitable\()i(l)-li-m-t-bl\ adjective

title: Jet Magazine to Shift to Digital Publishing Next Month
description: Jet, the pioneering African-American weekly magazine that rose to prominence covering the civil rights movement, is expected to announce Wednesday morning that it will no longer publish a regular print edition, the latest in a growing list of periodicals avoiding print in favor of digital publications.

title: Masala Dosa to Die For
description: Saravana Bhavan doesnt look like a house of secrets. Its dining room at the corner of Lexington Avenue and 26th Street is clean and bright and often attracts a line out front. It doesnt advertise because it doesnt need to; the fact that its one of the worlds largest chains of vegetarian restaurants  33 in India, another 47 in a dozen other countries  is considered too obvious to its core clientele of Indian expatriates and tourists to be worth trumpeting. In a city overwhelmed with underwhelming north Indian food, Saravana Bhavan is the standard-bearer of the delicacies of the south, but it makes no effort to educate the uninitiated. If you dont know what a dosa is or how to eat it, youre on your own.

title: Corrections: May 7, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 2:50 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FAREWELL, MY QUEEN (2012) Sidonie Laborde (La Seydoux, above left, with Julie-Marie Parmentier), the reader to Marie Antoinette (Diane Kruger) at Versailles, watches as the French monarchy falls in this drama directed by Benot Jacquot from a novel by Chantal Thomas. Nomie Lvovsky portrays the queens lady-in-waiting; Virginie Ledoyen is the woman rumored to be the queens lover. If the rules and the players of this continuing, increasingly dangerous court intrigue remain obscure, its because Farewell, My Queen is told through Sidonies eyes, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Tapping her palace sources, notably an archivist (Michel Robin) and a dressmaker (Anne Benot), Sidonie learns of news known only to the nobility and their trusted stewards: that the Bastille has been seized. Mr. Jacquot, she added, has always been a sensitive director of actresses, his sympathies evident in his caressing, sometimes ogling camerawork and the time and space he gives women and their stories. That sympathy is evident here too, though crucially, while he doesnt demonize Marie Antoinette, he doesnt turn her into a spurious feminist martyr. In French, with English subtitles.

title: Strong Start by Kuroda and Late Homer by Roberts Lift Yankees
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  When Brian Roberts came to the plate with two outs in the ninth inning, the game tied and the Yankees in fairly urgent need of a win, he did not require any fancy scouting reports on the opposing pitcher, the fastball artist Ernesto Frieri.

title: South Africans Vote as Zuma Seeks Second Term as President
description: MARIKANA, South Africa  Voters cast ballots across South Africa on Wednesday after a long campaign season that betrayed the governing African National Congress partys internal cracks, highlighted President Jacob Zumas deepening unpopularity and hinted at a realignment of the nations politics in the years ahead.

title: Thai Prime Minister Ordered Removed From Office
description: BANGKOK  A Thai court on Wednesday ordered Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra removed from office, a highly divisive move and a victory for a powerful opposition movement that for six months has sought to overthrow the government.

title: Chinese Train Maker Seeks Up to $1.5 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: HONG KONG  China CNR Corporation, one of the nations and the worlds biggest manufacturers of trains, is planning to raise up to $1.5 billion in a Hong Kong stock offering this month, a person familiar with the deal said on Wednesday.

title: Socit Gnrales Profit Suffers From Russian Exposure
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale, the second-largest French bank, said on Wednesday that its first-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, as it wrote down the value of its Russian assets amid the international crisis over Ukraine.

title: Vietnam Squares Off With China in Disputed Seas
description: HONG KONG  Tensions in the South China Sea intensified Wednesday as Vietnamese vessels confronted Chinese ships that were working to place an oil rig off Vietnams coast, and Vietnamese officials claimed that their ships had been rammed by the Chinese vessels three days earlier.

title: Playing Down Any Alstom Move, Siemens Reorganizes and Makes Other Deals
description: FRANKFURT  The head of the German electronics and engineering giant Siemens said on Wednesday that the company would not be strong-armed into acquiring the power units of its French rival Alstom, displaying notably less ardor for a deal than was shown by its rival General Electric.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 7, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: Three Charts on Secular Stagnation
description: Apologies for blog silence  stuff happened. Right now Im in Oxford, preparing for a talk tonight on secular stagnation and all that; and I thought Id share three charts I find helpful in thinking about where we are.

description: Updated, 10:28 a.m. |

title: 6 Qs About the News | Spreading the A.P. Gospel to Nurture Scientists and Engineers
description: In Spreading the A.P. Gospel to Nurture Scientists and Engineers, Kenneth Chang writes about a nonprofit organization working with schools to expand the success of Advanced Placement classes.

title: Indian-Born Tibetans Allowed to Vote, but Few Take Up Offer
description: DHARAMSALA, India  This year marks the first election in which Indian-born Tibetan refugees have the right to vote, but as the state of Himachal Pradesh, including the residents of this shady hill station, went to the polls on Wednesday, there were few Tibetans among them.

title: Italys Independence in Postwar Photography
description: The Italian photographer Ugo Zovetti was known for his sense of realism. In a 1958 photograph, he captured a group of four street musicians, all wearing signs around their necks that declare, BLIND. Its reminiscent of Paul Strands Blind Woman, a 1916 photo that shows the subjects affected eye and evokes sympathy. The blind men in Zovettis image, in contrast, are simply playing on the street.

title: Chinese Police to Help With Tourist Influx in Paris
description: France has invited the Chinese police to Paris this summer to help with the pressures of huge numbers of Chinese tourists visiting the French capital, Agence France-Presse reported, citing a French Interior Ministry official. The move comes as Chinese travelers in France have experienced a rising number of robberies and assaults, the French news agency said.

title: What Messages About Food and Eating Have You Learned From Your Family?
description: How would you characterize your familys attitudes toward food and eating? What rules or restrictions, if any, do they impose on what or how you eat? How do you think these attitudes have affected you?

title: Telefnica Offers to Buy Majority Stake in Spains Digital Plus
description: LONDON  The Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica has offered to pay about $1 billion for a majority stake in the pay-television provider known as Digital Plus.

title: New York Today: Allergy Season, Light
description: Good wheezy Wednesday morning to you.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: The Unlikely Ascent of Jack Ma, Alibabas Founder
description: HONG KONG  The first time Jack Ma used the Internet, in 1995, he searched for beer and China but found no results. Intrigued, he created a basic web page for a Chinese translation service with a friend. Within hours, he received a handful of emails from around the world requesting information.

title: Mary Landrieus Very Difficult Re-election
description: A survivor. Thats how some Republicans think of Senator Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat who seemed to defy political gravity by winning two tough re-election campaigns, even while Louisiana, like the rest of the Deep South, became unshakably Republican.

title: Vocal Few in Congress Keep Benghazi Issue Alive
description: The 2012 Benghazi attack has become a rallying point for many conservative figures in the news media, but only a handful of Republicans in Congress have continued to call public attention to it. Just six members of the House and Senate mention it regularly in official statements.

title: The Struggle for Access in War-Torn Syria
description: Anne Barnard, Beirut bureau chief for The Times since January 2013, is covering the civil war in Syria. Before coming to The Times in 2007, she worked as the Baghdad bureau chief and Middle East bureau chief for The Boston Globe.

title: An Owner Grows Her Business  and Her Family
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, Jennifer Blumin, who owns Skylight Group, talked about the challenges of opening a San Francisco office while awaiting the arrival of her second child, due this month.

title: Hurt by Asia, HSBCs Quarterly Earnings Decline 18%
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC reported on Wednesday that first-quarter profit fell 18 percent amid a slump in its Asian operations, which account for more than half its earnings.

title: Syrian Rebels Depart Homs District Under Deal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias third-largest city, Homs, was one of the first to hold large demonstrations against President Bashar al-Assad. Protesters there were among the first to take up arms against the state, and Homs neighborhoods were the first to suffer indiscriminate bombardment by government forces.

title: Daily Report: Alibaba Files for Public Stock Offering in the U.S.
description: The e-commerce behemoth Alibaba filed in the United States on Tuesday to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for the booming Chinese Internet industry, Vindu Goel, Michael J. de la Merced and Neil Gough report.

title: Grab a Dream and Sing Out
description: Youre not going to get us to pull each others hair, Kelli OHara said as she and her four fellow Tony Award nominees for best actress in a musical  one of this years most competitive races  met recently to discuss life in the theater. But as warm as they were to one another, their words carried some bite about the business.

title: Indie Music to Return to South Street Seaport
description: The Seaport Music Festival, which has been spicing up New York summers with indie bands since 2002, will return to the South Street Seaport, at Fulton Street between Water and Front Street, for eight Friday evening shows in July and August.
