title: What the Alibaba I.P.O. Means
description: After months of anticipation, it finally happened: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to go public, Vindu Goel, Michael J. de la Merced and Neil Gough write in DealBook. The move, they write, is an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for Chinas booming Internet industry.

title: Councilman Is Accused of Stealing Public Funds
description: The charges brought on Wednesday against a New York City councilman accused of stealing thousands of dollars in taxpayer money had a familiar ring to them: a shell company, pilfered campaign funds, a department-store shopping spree with the spoils.

title: Mondelez and Dutch Firm Aim to Create a Coffee Powerhouse
description: Mondelez International, the owner of Cadbury chocolate and Chips Ahoy cookies, is carving out its coffee business to combine it in a joint venture with a Dutch company to form a global coffee seller with more than $7 billion in annual revenue.

title: With Swagger, and Some Gifts, a Candidate Builds a Constituency
description: HYDERABAD, India Just weeks before elections in Hyderabad, the capital of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, a would-be candidate sat at a wooden desk in his modest campaign headquarters, unsure which party would give him a ticket to run for a seat in the state assembly.

title: Daily Show Takes on Financial Crisis Cases
description: The vampires finally got their blood, Jon Stewart of The Daily Show said, mocking those who wanted to see Wall Street punished for the financial crisis. The victim: Kareem Serageldin.

title: Son of Nazi-Era Art Dealer Left Works to Swiss Museum
description: Updated, 12:30 p.m. | BERLIN Cornelius Gurlitt left his collection of hundreds of European art works  amassed by his father under the Nazis  to the Kunstmuseum Bern, the museum announced on Wednesday. In a statement, the museum said that the news came like a bolt from the blue.

title: AOL Profit Slides 64%, Sending Its Shares Down 20%
description: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, the giant media and advertising technology company, has said that it was poised for significant long-term growth. On Wednesday investors displayed their skepticism  resoundingly.

title: On Climate, Republicans and Democrats Are From Different Continents
description: Americans are less worried about climate change than the residents of any other high-income country, as my colleague Megan Thee-Brennan wrote Tuesday. When you look at the details of these polls, you see that American exceptionalism on the climate stems almost entirely from Republicans. Democrats and independents dont look so different from people in Japan, Australia, Canada and across Europe.

title: Even as U.S. Hispanics Lift Catholicism, Many Are Leaving the Church Behind
description: By all accounts, Hispanics are the future of Catholicism in America. Already, most young Roman Catholics in the United States are Hispanic, and soon that will be true of the overall Catholic population. But the Hispanicization of American Catholicism faces a big challenge: Hispanics are leaving Catholicism at a striking rate.

title: City Ballets 2014-15 Season to Feature Ballets by Peck, Scarlett and Ratmansky
description: New York City Ballets 2014-15 season will feature new ballets by Justin Peck, Liam Scarlett and Alexei Ratmansky; a festival of George Balanchines cherished Black and White ballets; the principal dancer Wendy Whelans farewell performance; and the company premiere of La Sylphide by its ballet master in chief, Peter Martins.

title: A Continuing Murder Mystery Keeps Its Grip on Filmmakers
description: In one form or another, Damien Echols has now been a star of at least five films, but this is not a distinction that fills him with pride.

title: Yellen Wont Be Pinned Down on Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Wednesday that the economy was growing at a decent rate and that the Fed intended to continue the stimulus campaign that it considered at least partly responsible.

title: There Are No Mainstream Republicans Left in North Carolina
description: The national Republican Party is exulting that the establishment won in North Carolinas Senate primary yesterday. Thats only because they have redefined the term Republican establishment to include adamant adherents of a far-right ideology.

title: Turner Prize Nominees Announced
description: LONDON  Dances, screen prints, YouTube clips and slideshows are all elements used in the work of this years Turner Prize nominees, who were announced on Wednesday by Tate Britain, where an exhibition of the four artists work will take place from Sept. 30 to Jan. 4.

title: Putin Announces Pullback From Ukraine Border
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin, faced with rising violence in southeastern Ukraine that threatened to draw in the Russian Army at great cost and prompt severe new Western economic sanctions, pressed pause on Wednesday in what had started to look like an inevitable march toward war.

title: Feeling For | Decadent Cashmere Blankets With a Planet-Friendly Pedigree
description: Just how much good karma can be packed into a single home accessory? Quite a bit, as evidenced by a new series of limited-edition cashmere blankets made by Jane Palmer of Noon Design Studio  the fashion industrys eminent natural dye house, which is also known for its popular indigo kits and decorative housewares  and the artist Christy Matson. Carpet-thick yet feather-light, the blankets are hand-loomed by Matson in Los Angeles on the same jacquard machine she uses in her fine-art practice. The lofty cashmere yarn is not only hand-twisted by members of a womens cooperative in Afghanistan, but also  two degrees of virtuousness  sourced directly from fashion houses that would otherwise have discarded it. The rich, variegated colors are hand-dyed by Palmer using flowers, leaves and minerals; the jet-black hue comes from a dye recipe of roots, bark and indigo that dates back to medieval times. Each is one of a kind; custom designs are also available by special order. Palmer and Matson have set aside a small number of the blankets for T readers, and can ship overnight  just in time for a (very decadent) last-minute Mothers Day gift.

title: Mother Love
description: New picture books to help celebrate Mothers Day include A Mom for Umande, about a zoo-born baby gorilla.

description: San Francisco General is largely a hospital for the poor. Its the citys safety net hospital, known for providing free care for all who cant afford it, and for its display  while you wait and wait  of the parade of humanity in all its glory.

title: 50 Years Later, Questions Over Who Designed a Worlds Fair Dome
description: Imagine an elegant, inverted, 175-foot-wide sieve covering a half-acre of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. Within it, long-necked cattle egrets glide overhead. A scarlet macaw scolds loudly from a branch, while northern bobwhite quails rustle the underbrush. Flashes of sapphire blue  the bills of Argentine ruddy ducks  glint against the dark waters of a small pond.

title: South African Leaders on Election Day
description: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, Archbishop Desmond Tutu and former president F.W. De Klerk said they were optimistic about the countrys future as millions voted in the national election.

title: A Scientists Defense of Keeping AstraZeneca Independent
description: Updated, 1:13 p.m. | LONDON  It is probably no surprise that Briggs Morrison, head of global drug development at AstraZeneca, has sided with his bosses in opposing the idea of the American giant Pfizer taking over the British company.

title: The Consumer Revolution of Enterprise Computing
description: Workday, a business software company, released its first product in 2007 and recently came out with the 22nd version of its software. It has a 23rd in the works, but you should wonder why it bothers. After all, what version of Facebook are we on?

title: A Small Brand Tries to Escape the Confusing Shadow of a Big Brand
description: Hobby Lobby International makes and sells radio-controlled toys, tools and accessories. What started in 1964 as a shop in a building lobby in Brentwood, Tenn., grew into a thriving mail-order business and, later, an online retailer with $9 million in annual sales. The company was owned by the same family until 2003, when it was sold to a private equity firm. In 2009, Mark A. Cleveland bought the company with the goal of opening more stores and expanding its lines of radio-controlled products.

title: Gehry Honored by Spanish Foundation
description: Frank Gehry, the architect known for the fanciful designs, fluid lines and metallic exteriors of his buildings  which include the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museums in Bilbao and Abu Dhabi  has won the 2014 Prince of Asturias Award for the Arts. The prize includes a 50,000 euro ($69,625) cash award and a sculpture by Joan Mir.

description: Art lovers are undoubtedly familiar with Eugne Delacroixs Liberty Leading the People, a work that has a place of pride at the Louvre Museum.

title: What Off-Season? Drafts Growth Means N.F.L. Has No Downtime
description: Imagine a sporting event that includes no bats, balls or fields, yet compels thousands of fans to wait hours for seats and attracts a larger television audience than many games do. Throw in months of buildup, a red carpet entrance and big corporate sponsors, and you have the N.F.L. draft.

title: Your Questions, Answered
description: I invited you to ask me anything this week, and you did. Here are my answers to some of your most interesting questions  I only wish I had time to respond to every single one of you!

title: Obamas Top Economist Has Some Problems With Pikettys Book
description: The French economist Thomas Pikettys book on the future of inequality is the buzz of the economics world this season. Now President Obamas chief economist has weighed in on its thesis, the first time a senior administration official has discussed it in detail. And he is skeptical of some key assumptions upon which Capital in the Twenty-First Century, Mr. Pikettys sweeping book, is based.

title: Motion Picture Academy Extends Executives Contract
description: LOS ANGELES  The governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences agreed Tuesday night to renew an employment contract with the groups chief executive, Dawn Hudson.

title: You Are Now Here. Find How to Go There.
description: ONE of my favorite parts of a vacation is flying, but organizing the flights can be overcomplicated and frustrating. It doesnt have to be this way, as there are many mobile apps that can help you book flights with ease.

title: Michael Jackson, the Remix
description: Xscape, the new album credited to Michael Jackson, revolves around the familiar voice of a ghost mourned worldwide. That voice is airborne and supple, tenderly concerned, playful and percussive; then it grows increasingly tense, distraught, desolate, embittered. Jacksons voice is a precious digital keepsake; its also, on many of the tracks, the only part of his latest songs that Jackson ever heard.

title: App Smart | Plan Your Next Trip
description: Kit Eaton explores three mobile apps that can help you book flights and plan your travels with ease.

description: The staggering beauty and abundant resources of Colombias Choc region have been preserved through poverty and neglect. With its natural wonders now being discovered, it stands at a crossroads.

title: Indictment of Ruben W. Wills and Jelani R. Mills
description: Mr. Wills, a New York City Councilman, was arrested Wednesday on charges of misusing public funds. Mr. Mills, an associate, was charged with conspiring with the councilman.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 36
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Rebels to Ask for Antiaircraft Missiles
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the Syrian opposition says that he will ask the Obama administration to provide antiaircraft missiles and will try to convince American officials that the weapons would not fall into the wrong hands.

description: Wish you were on vacation right now? Dont. Taking a vacation wont necessarily make you happier. But anticipating it will.

description: Rates

title: Huawei Unveils New Phone to Compete With Apple and Samsung
description: Updated, with additional background.

title: An Incubator for Creativity in Savannah, Ga.
description: The Savannah that most visitors encounter is confined to the historic district between the Savannah River and the trees of Forsyth Park draped in Spanish moss. But several blocks south of the park, beyond the sun-dappled squares and canopied streets, is the increasingly vibrant Starland district. The neighborhood, whose name comes from the defunct Starland Dairy factory it surrounds, has in recent years emerged as an incubator for creativity that overflows from the nearby Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD). Now a clutch of new shops, galleries and cafes has taken root here, providing a refreshingly rough-around-the-edges respite from Savannahs polished, Old South charm.

title: Restaurant Report: Florera Atlntico in Buenos Aires
description: The air at Florera Atlntico, in the Retiro neighborhood of Buenos Aires, is decadent with the scent of fresh flowers. Some pedestrians may wander in looking for a bouquet for an aggrieved girlfriend or wine for a dinner party, but those in the know are aware of what lies beneath the unassuming flower and wine shop. Inside, a hulking refrigerator door swings back to reveal the entrance to a subterranean chamber. This in-vogue restaurant and lounge is underground in every sense of the word.

title: Street Style in Berlin
description: The central Kreuzberg neighborhood has evolved from one of the poorest in Berlin to one of the trendiest. It is where Ron Dietze (with his wife and two daughters) was walking along the graffiti-lined streets on the way to dinner. Dressed in a fitted black suit, a black turtleneck and a cherry-red leather trench coat, Mr. Dietze said he usually wore more color, higher heels and even the occasional skirt. On this day, however, he said he wanted to dress a bit classier for his daughters birthday celebration. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: What Policies Deter Absentee Apartment Buyers?
description: When you try to figure out how to solve the housing affordability problem in the worlds superstar cities, as I did in a recent magazine column, it quickly becomes clear that the market today has been heavily affected by absentee buyers: the global rich who, looking for a safe place to park their cash, are snapping up apartments, in many cases sight unseen.

title: Growth and Governance in Focus at Alibaba
Send a Handwritten Card by Mail, Via an iPad
description: Two days ago, in my books-for-Mothers Day post, I urged everyone to go, right now, to the store. Buy a card for your mother, mother-in-law and anyone else you want to receive one this Sunday. Have your children make cards and greetings tonight, and put it all in the mail tomorrow.

description: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y.

title: Its a Smorgasbord at the Stage Deli
description: It is safe to say that we are rarely, in a single week, introduced to not one but two Off Broadway productions with sandwich makers as central characters. Three people struggle to keep their franchise shop afloat under a corporate structure, which is at turns controlling or indifferent, in American Hero, a dark comedy by Bess Wohl in Second Stage Theaters annual Uptown Series, devoted to emerging playwrights. Leigh Silverman (a Tony nominee for Violet) directs. (Previews begin Monday, McGinn/Cazale Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street; 212-246-4422, 2st.com.)

title: How Could Hobby Lobby International Avoid Confusion With Hobby Lobby Stores?
description: We just publisheda case study about Hobby Lobby International, a 50-year-old company based in Brentwood, Tenn., that makes and sells radio-controlled products and accessories. In 2009, Mark Cleveland bought the company from a private equity firm and made plans to expand.

title: Yellen Speaks on U.S. Economic Future
description: Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testified before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that she expects the economy to expand at a faster pace than it did last year.

title: Why Republicans Have a 55 Percent Chance of Retaking the Senate
description: Weve updated the Upshots Senate model, which we call Leo, with the results of Tuesdays elections in North Carolina. Thom Tillis, the State House speaker, won the Republican Senate primary there.

title: William Forsythe to Join U.S.C. Dance School
description: The choreographer William Forsythe will join the University of Southern Californias Glorya Kaufman School of Dance as a professor in fall 2015, the university announced on Wednesday. The American-born Mr. Forsythe, who has lived in Germany for most of his career and currently heads his own troupe, the Forsythe Company, is widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, with an influence that spans the worlds of ballet and contemporary dance.

title: Does the Establishment Clause Apply to the States?
description: Mondays 5-4 Supreme Court ruling giving a green light to routine, explicitly Christian prayers at town meetings was extreme  but not as extreme as the concurring opinion from the Courts resident reactionary, Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Down in the Subway, Swipe Again
description: The subway is the citys great equalizer, a place where all of New York can jostle peaceably. But in Dutchman, the incendiary 1964 play by LeRoi Jones, proximity breeds anger, then danger, then death.

title: Scientists Add Letters to DNAs Alphabet, Raising Hope and Fear
description: Scientists reported Wednesday that they had taken a significant step toward altering the fundamental alphabet of life  creating an organism with an expanded artificial genetic code in its DNA.

title: Whatd You Bring Me, Mom? Trouble
description: Moms home  first time in eight years  and the long absence has done nothing to dull the sting of her venom.

title: In Youths Death, Some See a Montana Law Gone Wrong
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  Teenagers call it garage hopping. The goal was to sneak into an open garage, steal some beer or other items and slip away into the night. It was dumb and clearly illegal. It was not supposed to be deadly.

title: A Finger Wag in Good Hands
description: Tony Shalhoub remembers watching an interview with a young Jason Robards decades ago. He said, If I see an actor put his hands in his pockets, I know he doesnt know what to do with his hands, Mr. Shalhoub recalled.

title: Public Library Is Abandoning Disputed Plan for Landmark
description: In a striking about-face, the New York Public Library has abandoned its much-disputed renovation plan to turn part of its research flagship on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street into a circulating library and instead will refurbish the nearby Mid-Manhattan Library, several library trustees said.

title: NBC Extends Olympic Deal Into Unknown
description: NBC Universal agreed on Wednesday to pay $7.75 billion for the exclusive broadcast rights to the six Olympic Games from 2022 to 2032, highlighting with that staggering sum the supreme value that media companies are placing on live event programming in a market disrupted by modern viewing habits.

title: Image of the Day: May 7
Times Minute | How to Watch the Draft
description: Melissa Hoppert, the Times N.F.L. editor, on what to look for as teams make their picks this week.

title: A Crane Is Born
description: There is a new bird at the Central Park Zoo  new to the zoo, and new to the world.

title: Times Minute | How to Watch the Draft
description: In the Video

title: Struggling to Score, Rangers May Get Kreider Back
description: Chris Kreider may or may not be back in uniform for the offense-challenged Rangers in Game 4 against the Penguins on Wednesday night, but neither he nor his coach is saying either way.

title: Store Openings and Fashion Events Starting the Week of May 8
description: Celebrating Charles James

title: Inside the Met Ball: Sculptures in Silk
description: Id never really heard of him, Florence Welch of Florence and the Machine said Monday, referring to the irascible, petulant, brilliant and beguiling Anglo-American designer Charles James. Its nice to see a bit of the history.

title: U.S. Trips to Russia Fall Amid Conflict
description: As spring blooms across Eastern Europe, the specter of a widening conflict between the Kremlin and Ukraine is causing some Western travelers to cancel their trips to Russia and spoiling high expectations among hotels and tour operators for the summer travel season.

title: With Stealth, Congressional Spending on Pet Projects Persists, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Congress may have banned earmarks to pay for pet projects in the districts of powerful lawmakers, but pork continues to find its way into spending legislation, though in smaller amounts and with more stealth, a fiscal watchdog group said on Wednesday.

title: Student Crossword | Space Exploration
description: Test your knowledge of space exploration by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Patton Boggs Settles Dispute With Chevron Over Pollution Case
description: The powerful Washington law firm Patton Boggs dropped out of an effort to force Chevron to pay a $9.5 billion Ecuadorean pollution judgment on Wednesday, expressing regrets for its involvement in the case and agreeing to pay the oil company $15 million in settlement payments.

title: Wanted: A Brooklyn Apartment With More Space
description: Eyal and Karen Hen started off as roommates.

title: What Health Insurance Might Do
description: Alert (or at least health-care-obsessed) readers have no doubt been following the coverage ofa new study on mortality in Massachusettsin the years following Romneycares coverage expansion, the gist of which  the authors found a striking, Massachusetts-specific decline in death rates for the non-elderly tends to confirm liberal assumptions about the benefits of health insurance, and undercut the conservative and libertarian argument that insurance doesnt have the impact on health and mortality that most people expect. The studys findings are an almost-diametrical reversal of the results from Oregons Medicaid experiment, which were much discussed around this time last year (heres my contribution), and which seemed to strengthen the conservative critique of Obamacares pursuit of comprehensive coverage. So now its liberalisms turn to claim vindication, and to press Obamacares critics to give ground in the debate.

title: A Note of Caution in Greek Banks Seeming Recovery
description: Greek banks, once seen as the most dangerous investment in the euro zone, have been on a tear of late.

title: With Update, Snapchats Get a Little Less Private
description: Snapchat just released a major update thats been getting a lot of attention. But one less publicized aspect of this update is that Snapchat is a whole lot less ephemeral than it used to be.

title: Photos Trusted but Verified
description: A leading expert on digital forensic analysis has launched a free online service that lets people confirm  or debunk  the authority of online images.

title: Staying Fit Between Flights With No Time to Spare
description: I cleared Canadian customs after the flight from New York, stashed my passport in my backpack and strode down the wide, brightly lighted corridor of Toronto Pearson International Airports Terminal 1.

title: The 11th Most Fascinating Person Ever
description: On May 16, when Barbara Walters signs off from The View for the final time, one of the more remarkable careers in television will come to an (apparent) end.

title: Hong Kong Publishers Prison Sentence Is Called a Political Vendetta
description: HONG KONG  Rejecting defense arguments for leniency, a court in southern China sentenced a Hong Kong publisher to 10 years in prison on Wednesday for smuggling industrial chemicals. The family and supporters of the publisher, Yiu Mantin, has said the charges were a political vendetta brought on by his plans to publish a book condemning the Chinese Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping.

title: Can You Tweet Like Ruth Reichl?
description: In the magazines most recent Talk column, Ruth Reichl, the food writer and former Gourmet editor, discusses her newfound love of Twitter. I discovered that I really loved the discipline of 140 characters, she says. It was a complete surprise to me that you could really paint a portrait of a moment.

title: Feeling For | Beauty Products to Whisk Mom Off to the Beaches of Sicily
description: Sue Townsend, one of the original founders of Britains Crabtree & Evelyn,lives in a15th-century palazzo in Florenceand creates handsome-smelling products under her luxury beauty label Ortigia. Unlike Townsend, everything about the line is truly Sicilian, from the indigenous, natural ingredients to the scents, which evoke the Mediterranean landscape. Some embody local flora the slightly stringent yet delicate Zagara, infused with orange blossoms, or the Sicilian Jasmine, distilled from local white flowers  while others transport, like the musky but honeysuckle-sweet Ambra Nera, infused with patchouli and vetiver and evocative of a warm, amorous night on the island. The calming Fico DIndia scent is inspired by the cactus of the same name that grows wild along the beaches of Sicily.

title: Sam and League Share Uncomfortable Scrutiny
description: The N.F.L. draft, an auction of athletic aptitude with primeval roots and prime-time appeal, will begin Thursday night with an unprecedented subplot. An openly gay player with impressive credentials is in the pool of candidates, casting the usually myopic, football-centric draft in a societywide spotlight with resonant cultural significance.

title: The Evolution of the Draft
description: Once a modest affair with chalkboards and no scouts, the N.F.L. draft has become a major televised spectacle.

title: House Vote on Former I.R.S. Official Signals Element of G.O.P. Election Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to hold Lois Lerner, a former Internal Revenue Service official accused by Republicans of abusing power, in contempt, laying bare the bitter divide over which much of the midterm elections will be fought.

title: Photos Trusted but Verified
description: Fueled by Twitter and Facebook, the enormous growth in citizen journalism  especially photojournalism  has generated intense debate and often skepticism over the authenticity of photographs that purport to document the truth. It has become so easy to digitally manipulate images and post them online that sometimes viewers cannot believe what they are seeing, possibly with good reason.

title: Putin Withdraws Troops From Border
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said troops close to the Ukraine border have pulled back. He also asked separatists in eastern Ukraine to postpone a referendum on independence.

title: For Older Travelers, a Site from AARP
description: While much of the travel industry is scrambling to satisfy the digital desires of millenials, a new travel website from AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, aims to build baby boomers a bridge across the digital divide.

title: Embracing His Inner Thug
description: In the new musical Bullets Over Broadway, Nick Cordero plays Cheech, a pitiless mafia enforcer. Cheechs hobbies include offing rival gangsters and dumping their bodies in the Gowanus Canal. He also enjoys modern drama.

title: Postpartum Repression
description: Playing With Grown Ups, an ominous comedy-drama at 59E59 Theaters Brits Off Broadway festival, is the site of one more skirmish in the mommy wars. There are multiple casualties.

title: The Move Toward Computing That Reads Your Mind
description: Like many people in this modern world, I struggle with the tension between the conveniences offered by the latest technology and the loss of privacy that comes with them.

title: Apps That Predict What You Want
description: Molly Wood tests out contextual apps that can predict what you may want from your phone depending on the time of day or the activity youre doing.

title: Those Keeping a Diet Find Better Signposts to Dining on the Road
description: Melanie Melia, owner of a brokerage company in Glen Cove, N.Y., that represents natural food manufacturers, is a vegan who has found many ways to stick to her diet while traveling for business.

title: Childlike, but Hardly Childs Play
description: LOS ANGELES  It started out as a lark. After long days in the studio making his labor-intensive Butterfly paintings about a decade ago, Mark Grotjahn would unwind by taking empty supply boxes or beer cartons and gluing on toilet-paper tubes as noses. Then he would paint crude eyes and mouths.

title: NBC Looks to ESPN for New Executive at Today
description: The arms race in morning television continued on Wednesday as NBC News turned to ESPN, a sister network of its morning rival, ABC, for the production executive Jamie Horowitz, who will become the senior vice president and general manager of the Today show.

title: The Greening of Business Travel Gains Momentum
description: On a single afternoon recently, Rob Bernard had a meeting in Kenya, one in Ireland and one in Finland  three countries and two continents in less than 24 hours.

title: Connecticut Students Show Gains in National Tests
description: High school seniors in Connecticut performed better last year on federal math and reading tests than their counterparts did four years earlier, but New Jersey and most of the nation remained flat in both areas, according to exam results released on Wednesday.

title: Mets Pitchers Remain Hitless; Their Hitters Effort Is Not Much Better
description: MIAMI  Before his team played the Marlins on Wednesday, Mets Manager Terry Collins sat in his office and discussed how his pitchers had not yet recorded a base hit this season. He did not seem particularly perturbed. If he were to start worrying about his pitchers getting hits  that is, if his offense were so inept that he sorely needed his pitchers to produce  then, he said, we got a real problem.

title: Your Digital Trail Follows You to the Border
description: Information, money and jobs flow easily around the world, yet its getting tougher for travelers to cross some borders.

title: A New Single Hits No. 1; Top Album Is Frozen
description: Yet again, Disneys Frozen soundtrack is the No. 1 album. But there is at least some news on the music charts this week: after a 10-week run, Pharrell Williamss ubiquitous Happy has finally been dethroned as the top song.

title: Hotels Near the Terminal, Some Even Attached
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Before the year is over, China will eclipse the United States as the country with the largest number of residents traveling internationally, according to a new study by Oxford Economics commissioned by the travel technology company Amadeus. Similarly, Asia, the Middle East and South America are experiencing increases in the number of people flying long distances, according to the International Air Transport Association. Such robust growth is prompting a construction boom in hotels incorporated into new airports or airport expansions.

title: Glen Stassen, Theologian, Dies at 78; Championed Nuclear Disarmament
description: Glen H. Stassen, a Southern Baptist theologian who helped define the social-justice wing of the evangelical movement in the 1980s and played a role in advancing nuclear disarmament talks toward the end of the Cold War, died on April 25 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 78.

title: Beware When the Annual Meeting Is in Moosejaw
description: A handful of annual company meetings draw attention because they are unusually celebratory, like Berkshire Hathaways huge gathering in Omaha each May, or because shareholders are able to mount public efforts to curb executive pay or objectionable practices. But most such gatherings are carefully scripted so there are no hiccups.

title: Financial Regulators See Progress and Threats
description: WASHINGTON  Some of the same weaknesses that contributed to the disastrous 2008 financial crisis persist today, the Financial Stability Oversight Council said in its 2014 annual report to Congress.

title: Short Stories That Riff Playfully on Some Enduring Forebears
description: The stories in American Innovations, the new collection by Rivka Galchen, the author of the 2008 novel Atmospheric Disturbances, dont behave like typical short stories. Sure, they bear strong physical resemblances to selections you would find in an anthology with the words Best American in its title. Though Ms. Galchen favors misdirection and indirection, her writing is skillful, imaginative, often funny.

title: Forget 1960, the Golden Age Is Now
description: If you fly a lot, you have heard the nostalgia about a long-gone Golden Age of air travel. During this fabled time, which is said to have occurred as commercial aviation expanded through the 1950s into the jet age of the 1960s, passengers dressed up to fly on airplanes where glamorous stewardesses wearing white gloves served beef bourguignon on fine china.

title: Sothebys to Reimburse Loeb $10 Million
description: Sothebys campaign to fend off attacks by the billionaire activist Daniel S. Loeb has proved costly. But playing nice with Mr. Loeb may be even costlier.

title: Alibabas Acquisition Strategy: Focused Largely on China and Mobile
description: When Alibaba Groups prospectus finally hit Wall Street on Tuesday, analysts and prospective investors eagerly tore into their fullest look yet at the company.

title: For Wearable Computing, Software Must Be King
description: Over the last few years, we have heard that there will be wearable devices for almost every part of the body, from face to feet. But people have paid little attention to the software that accompanies these gadgets.

title: The Gun Report: May 7, 2014
description: Last Saturday, 26-year-old Stephen Guillermo had just returned from a night of drinking when he tried to enter the fifth-floor apartment he shared with his mother and two younger siblings in the South of Market neighborhood of San Francisco. But he mistakenly got off on the third floor, and the apartment he thought was his belonged to Amisi Sudi Kachepa, a 68-year-old retired security guard, who shot Guillermo to death.

title: A Familiar Refrain: Cut Calories
description: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. A Cut in Calories Urged for Nation appeared on May 7 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Footage of Teenage Stowaway
description: Hawaii transportation officials released video of a California teenager hopping from a jets wheel well on April 20 after stowing away for a flight to Hawaii from San Jose, Calif.

title: By Design | Neuehouse Brings Its Artisanal Aesthetic to Frieze New York
description: One of the chief appeals of Frieze New York is its buzzy restaurant partners, which for this weekends edition include Robertas, Mission Cantina and Frankies Spuntino. This year, the fair adds a different kind of lifestyle partner in the clublike co-working space Neuehouse, which has become a hot location for start-ups and cultural programming since opening its David Rockwell-designed office on 25th Street last year. For Frieze, Neuehouse created the V.I.P. tent,an oasis in the middle of the fairs whirl of activity on Randalls Island. Part of the exploration here is that the place that one works, the place that one creates should be stimulating visually and emotionally, and art is a very important part of that, says the Neuehouse co-founder Joshua Abram of the decision to partner with Frieze.

title: Piling On the Luxury
description: For most travelers, flying in style may be a thing of the past, but airlines are determined to bring back some glamour to air travel, at least for those sitting in the front of the plane.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Africa, India, Washington and Spain.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Confections of History, Lovingly Decorated
description: The ballets of George Balanchine are fascinating layer cakes of history. The four that returned to New York City Ballet on Tuesday night were choreographed between 1947 and 1975, and they still capture the moments in which they were made.

title: From Mystical Bells to a Hungarian Folk Duo, the Joys of the Unfamiliar
description: As a rule I do not expect to leave a concert of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center thinking about Donald Rumsfeld. But after Tuesday evenings brilliant Music From Three Centuries at Alice Tully Hall, I was put in mind of the former defense secretarys most famous dictum about those known knowns, known unknowns and, crucially, unknown unknowns in life: the ones we do not know we dont know.

title: Feeling For | A Fashion Magazine Without the Gloss
description: Looking at countless blogs and Tumblrs, the images that we were sharing were much more raw and personal than what I typically see in fashion print, says the creative director Claudia Bruno, a co-founder of the new fashion and culture magazine Bare. Seeking to strip away the artifice of traditional fashion media, Bruno teamed up with her longtime friends, the writers Emily Lundin and Courtney Saunders, to found a fashion magazine for what Bruno calls women like us  smarter, intellectual people who arent slaves to fashion, but creators of it.

title: Nursing a Half-Empty Tankard, the Nebbish Returns
description: What does it say about me that I almost always like shows in the micro-genre of comedians playing themselves  Seinfeld, Curb Your Enthusiasm, The Sarah Silverman Program, Louie, Legit? That I have a taste for low-stakes misanthropy? That I enjoy other peoples misery and embarrassment?

title: Out of the Northwest, Through Sea and Desert
description: Among its many impressive aspects, the concert by the Seattle Symphony on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, part of the Spring for Music festival, was a publicists fantasy.

title: Fight Over Guggenheims Legacy Roils Her Palazzo
description: VENICE  The battle now raging over the Peggy Guggenheim Collection started with just a few words written in brass letters above the sculpted lions that guard the 18th-century palazzo turned art museum here.

title: Garance Dor: A Half, but Whole
description: Garance Dor is a mistress of the slow reveal. Alongside the fetching fashion sketches and street snaps that she posts on her popular namesake style blog, she spins just enough of her charmingly addictive personal musings to keep her followers engaged and clicking on for more.

title: A Team in Need Gets a Fourth
description: In the final of the Bermuda Bowl world team championship last year, Italy defeated Monaco by 210 international match points to 126 over 96 boards.

title: June Festival Adds to New Yorks Lively Early Music Scene
description: The latest addition to New Yorks flourishing early music scene is a festival meant to hold up a mirror to the field: Early Music Festival: NYC, a new festival that will run from June 13 to 19, will focus on early music performers who live and work in New York City. Most of the performances will be free.

title: A Sweet Celebration of Kara Walkers Giant Sugar Sculpture
description: WhoKara Walker was the guest of honor at last nights Creative Time benefit to celebrate the artists 75-foot-high white sphinx sculpture made of sugar in the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. More than 700 guests, most from the worlds of art and fashion, including Chuck Close, Jenna Lyons, Theaster Gates, Solange Knowles, Chlo Svigny, Andr Leon Talley and Walkers 16-year-old daughter Octavia, dined in its shadow.

title: Bank of America Shareholders Press Officials After $4 Billion Error
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  This years annual meeting was supposed to be a victory lap for Bank of America, with many of its mortgage problems receding and its deposits and credit card business growing.

title: Infidelity Runs Amok, but the Party Never Stops
description: As the title character of Ed Bullinss The Fabulous Miss Marie, Tonya Pinkins wears a series of dresses cut low and slit high. One gown has leopard spots, another tiger stripes. (Perhaps her ocelot frock is at the dry cleaners?) Ms. Pinkins slinks around the Castillo Theater stage, yowling and purring as she sips Ambassador Scotch. When she sees a handsome young man, she toys with him for a while. Then she pounces.

title: Motorcyclist Deaths May Have Decreased in 2013
description: Based on preliminary data provided by the highway departments of all 50 states and the District of Columbia, motorcyclist deaths in the United States appear to have decreased 7 percent in 2013, according to an analysis released Tuesday by the Governors Highway Safety Association, a nonprofit organization. But motorcyclist safety has not improved over all in the last 15 years, the group said.

title: Its Here: Climate Change in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Restraint in Foreign Crises
Guys, Please Take It Outside
description: One highlight of the Bottega Veneta fall 2014 runway show was its dip-dyed knitwear: luxurious sweaters with cuffs or hems stained in a contrasting color, as if by happy accident (shown here). Bottega Venetas colors are autumnal  rust orange, burgundy, forest green  but its easy to get a jump on the fall look with any of springs array of dip-dyed goods, these in seasonally appropriate nautical colors.

title: Justices Political Biases
description: To the Editor:

title: Beauty Unmasked for All to See
description: One is accustomed to seeing celebrity profiles beginning with avowals that the subject is wearing no makeup, and rolling ones eyes. Yet, for a few seasons, either on the catwalk, sidewalk or information superhighway, a no-makeup look seems to be emerging as the gold (or beige?) standard.

title: Debate Over a Papyrus Scrap
description: To the Editor:

title: Facts & Figures: What Aliens Have to Do With MH370
description: Now we know what percentage of people believe, or at least what percentage are willing to tell a pollster they believe, that space aliens had something to do with the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: 3 Singers Return, Reflecting About Life
description: Pushin on, pushin on, isnt that what Im supposed to do? Natalie Merchant sings on her self-titled new album, a set of dark, brave, thoughtful and serenely startling songs that is her first album in 13 years with her own lyrics. Ms. Merchant, 50, had million-selling albums in the 1980s with 10,000 Maniacs and in the 1990s on her own before turning away from a routine pop career after her somber 2001 album, Motherland.

title: A Romp in Gossamer, 8 Tons Worth
description: The ceiling has been reinforced. The guards have been retrained. Touching is allowed. Swinging like Tarzan is not.

title: Crime in Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Gas to Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ukraine Crisis: Behind the Coverage
description: Kyle Crichton is a regional editor for Russia and Iran on the International Desk. He has coordinated The Timess coverage of the Ukraine crisis. We asked him about the planning behind the coverage and the impact of President Vladimir V. Putins statement Wednesday that Russian troops were pulling back from the Ukrainian border.

title: Club Echoes, in Sounds and Moves
description: When the doors opened at the Kitchen on Saturday night, the party had already started. Off to one side of the stage, the London D.J.s Elijah and Skilliam were in the midst of spinning what would turn out to be a fabulous, fierce set of Grime music  intriguingly unstable beats with enough bass to make your seat shake whether you wanted it to or not.

title: Tear Down Deadbeat Dams
description: VENTURA, Calif.  OF the more than 80,000 dams listed by the federal government, more than 26,000 pose high or significant safety hazards. Many no longer serve any real purpose. All have limited life spans. Only about 1,750 produce hydropower, according to the National Hydropower Association.

title: After-Parties: The Gala Was Just the Start
description: Some 90 minutes after the Met Gala let out on Monday night, a stream of celebrities with enough wattage to rival an Oscars after-party converged on the Top of the Standard in the meatpacking district.

title: More Hugs Please, Were Chinese
description: Of all the changes to sweep China since the death of Mao Zedong in 1976  stock markets, private cars, fashion  one thing seemed not to have changed: No hugging. Chinese were physically reserved.

title: Art Matters | At Frieze New York, Mixing Pleasure with Business
description: The third iteration of Frieze New York, which opens to V.I.P.s on Thursday and to the general public on Friday with more than 190 contemporary art galleries from 28 countries, is one of the worlds epicenters of pleasure for profit. So perhaps its fitting that this year the fairs organizers embraced the pursuit of leisure via the complementary programming installed in and around the tent. We wanted to interrupt the rhythms of the fair, going from booth to booth, says Cecilia Alemani, the curator of Frieze Projects, the annual array of artworks commissioned for the fair, and Frieze Sounds, a series of audio works looped in the fairs V.I.P. shuttles. It is a marketplace, and we wanted to create a platform where what could be exchanged was also ideas.

title: Islamist Militants Kill Hundreds of Civilians in Northeastern Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Islamist insurgents have killed hundreds in a town in Nigerias northeast this week, the areas senator, a resident and the Nigerian news media reported on Wednesday, as more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by the militants, known as Boko Haram, remained missing.

title: The Tracker
description: AGE 27

title: The Met Gala: By the Labels
description: On a night when the Metropolitan Museum of Art was honoring Charles James, a designer known for his dramatic, structurally inventive ball gowns, it was not surprising that many of the guests, including two of the evenings hosts, Sarah Jessica Parker and Aerin Lauder, chose to wear Oscar de la Renta, a designer whose work seems all but ready for a museum retrospective of its own. Or that Marchesa and Zac Posen, both operating in the less-is-never-more school of fashion design, would be well represented. But who would have guessed that Stella McCartney would come close to stealing the night with a posse of young stars, Rihanna and Reese Witherspoon among them, who turned the red carpet into their own personal party, or that the British retailer Topshop would have as many red-carpet credits as Prada? A selective look at who wore what on Monday night.

title: Can Hashtag Activism Save Kidnapped Nigerian Girls?
description: As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports from Nigeria, President Goodluck Jonathans government is under intense pressure to respond to the mass kidnappings of hundreds of schoolgirls by Islamist militants over the past month. Public outrage over the abductions, and the apparent inaction of the authorities, first expressed in small street protests, has been greatly amplified on social networks, where more than a million messages have been tagged with the simple demand: #BringBackOurGirls.

title: Its the Viral Season
description: Alas, poor J.D. Winteregg. We knew him ... um, actually not very well at all.

title: Mothers Day Beauty Gifts for Edgy Moms
description: Flowery and feminine are the standard Mothers Day beauty gift go-tos, but chic moms may appreciate it if you went for a punk-rock edge.

title: Like Mall Browsing, With a Click
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A couple of years ago, Deena Varshavskaya, the founder of a social shopping site, went through what she called a Steve Jobs phase, wearing a single T-shirt: a lightweight, cotton J. Crew V-neck in different colors.

title: Norways Leaders Snub Dalai Lama in Deference to China
description: The Dalai Lama, Tibets spiritual leader in exile, began a visit to Norway on Wednesday to commemorate the Nobel Peace Prize he received there 25 years ago, but the trip was overshadowed by an uproar over the governments refusal to meet with him in deference to an increasingly assertive China, which considers the Dalai Lama an unrepentant separatist.

title: In College, Nurturing Matters
description: I was a college freshman at Grambling State University in Louisiana. It was the middle of the night, the day before a personal essay was due for a writing seminar. I had put it off for days. I had nothing  nothing but writers block.

title: Pictures on the Street? Its Complicated
description: Mark Cohen has found that his love of taking up-close of pictures of strangers isnt always requited.

title: What Can I Do About Our Buildings Ugly Corridors?
description: Q. Our apartment building has ugly corridors. Is there anything we can do to make a better first impression on buyers?

title: All Angles and Curves
description: Starting next week, furniture by Oscar Niemeyer and Jorge Zalszupin, two of Brazils most-celebrated architects,will be available in the United States, through Espasso, a design gallery in TriBeCa.The re-editions include items that Mr. Niemeyer, who died in 2012 at the age of 104, designed in the 1970s with his daughter Anna Maria Niemeyer, including the Rio rocking chaise ($38,400), and Alta armchair and ottoman ($28,450 for both). Espasso will also offer 20 pieces designedin the 1960sby the now-91-year-old Mr. Zalszupin, including his Circa bench ($17,800) and delicately curving Brasiliana armchair ($10,250). The pieces will be displayed at Espasso from May 14 to June 3, and will be for sale, then and after, along with a new monograph, Jorge Zalszupin: Design Moderno ($80), by Maria Cecilia Loschiavo dos Santos. Espasso is at 38 North Moore Street (Hudson Street). Information: 212-219-0017 or espasso.com.

title: Damien Hirst Plants a Flag in SoHo
description: Damien Hirst has brought his ebullient gestures to New York, with the Tuesday opening of Other Criteria, the retail arm of the British arts-based publishing company of the same name. The two-level 3,500-square-foot SoHo boutique was designed by Michel Schranz and is the first Other Criteria shop to break out of Britain (there are two in London, and one in Devon). Jason Beard, the creative director, said SoHo was chosen over other neighborhoods because: It feels like London. It feels like home. The shop features versions of Mr. Hirsts spin art applied to rugs ($66,700), skulls and guitars. It also sells works by 35 other artists, including Gary Hume, Sarah Lucas, Peregrine Honig and Thomas Scheibitz. Offerings extend from tourist bait like key chains to prints, jewelry and artist-designed wallpaper and vases. A dollar will buy you an I spot DH pin. 458 Broome Street (Mercer Street). Information: 646-762-0123 or othercriteria.com.

title: A Classic (Again) Ripe for an Update
description: Lizzy Ratner is a contributor to the Nation, reporting on serious subjects like politics, education and the economy. Jen Nessel is also a journalist, a former political organizer and the communications coordinator at the Center for Constitutional Rights. They are the mothers of Elias, 4, and Oscar, 8, and the authors of Goodnight Nanny-Cam, a new parody of the much-parodied childrens book (remember Goodnight Keith Moon?) that was first born as an essay in The New Yorker two years ago to skewer the affectations and anxieties of modern parenting.

title: New Fairs Add to Design Mix
description: Happily for New York designers, the entity once known as New York Design Week now stretches over a goodly part of May. Helping to fill the time are two new design fairs. From May 10 to 20, Wanted Design, an annual furniture show in Chelsea organized by Odile Hainaut and Claire Pijoulat, will open a separate exhibition in the 30,000-square-foot Industry City complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The show, called Industry City/Design, will have three sections: one about objects, like Italian TobeUs cars made from wood salvaged from Hurricane Sandy; one about processes, like the creation of Alpi Groups decorative woods, and one devoted to local design organizations.

title: Discounts at Area, Nemati Collection and Jonathan Adler
description: Bed linens are up to 75 percent off at Area, through May 15 (a full/queen Parallel blue cotton duvet cover, originally $225, is $90); 58 East 11th Street (University Place), 212-924-7084, areahome.com.

title: Your Hand in Marriage
description: When Lisa Bayne married the first time, her friends baked a wedding cake topped with bride-and-groom cookies. This being 1976, in Berkeley, Calif., the cookie couple was nude, though the same could not be said of Ms. Bayne and her then-husband, who wore his-and-hers tunics that the bride had sewed by hand from vintage fabrics.

title: Redefining a Beach Share
description: A few years ago, Chad Oppenheim, an architect in Miami, received a run-of-the-mill phone call from a potential client. Debby Lawn, a retired elementary school counselor from San Francisco, had recently bought waterfront property in the Bahamas with her husband, Richard, a semiretired molecular biologist, and the couple, who are in their 60s, wanted Mr. Oppenheim to design a house there.

title: Old, Good Things Seen Anew
description: A rarity among authors who focus on the relentlessly forward-looking profession of architecture, Witold Rybczynski is generally considered something of a conservative. Born in Scotland, educated in England and Canada and residing in Philadelphia, Mr. Rybczynski wrote in the introduction to his most recent book, How Architecture Works: A Humanists Toolkit (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), I consider history a gift, rather than an imposition. While a few of his 18 books are set firmly in the past, most, like the 1986 best-seller, Home: A Short History of an Idea, use a broad historical perspective to better frame the present. His writing has a patient, deliberate quality that is rare at a moment when the dominant medium of architectural discourse is Twitter. Perhaps this is why Mr. Rybczynski, despite himself, is suddenly all the rage. On May 1 he was named a Design Mind by the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in its annual National Design Awards, an honor generally bestowed on visionary thinkers. On the same day he attended the National Magazine Awards as a nominee for three columns he wrote for Architect magazine in which he revisited significant buildings and neighborhoods that were completed many years ago to see how theyve stood the test of time. (This interview, which was conducted by phone and email, has been edited and condensed.)

title: Grandma Never Had It So Good
description: In most cities, adding a second house to a single-family lot would be illegal or would set off an epic battle with the neighbors that could drag on for years. But not in Portland, Ore.

title: Literary Lions in a New Age
description: The annual PEN American Center Literary Gala, at the American Museum of Natural History, was the social event of the season for the citys belletrists.

title: A Celebration of Letters and a Few Characters
description: Anna Wintour and Beyonc lured the eyes of the fashion world to the shimmering Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but they did not hold exclusive rights to the society spectacle that unfolded Monday night along the perimeter of Manhattans common backyard.

title: Furnishings With Geometric Patterns
description: Rafael de Crdenas is a big fan of geometric patterns because theyre a good and relatively easy way to immerse a viewer in a space, he said.

title: French Soccer Club Hires Woman to Coach Its Men
description: Helena Costa, whose father did not like soccer and who often had to go to neighbors homes to watch games, will become the first woman to coach a mens professional soccer team in France.

title: Lawmakers on Benghazi Investigation
description: Representatives from both parties discussed the latest inquiry into the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Hamas Executes 2 Men Accused of Aiding Israel
description: GAZA  The Hamas government on Wednesday executed two men convicted of collaborating with Israel, highlighting a stark difference between its rule in the Gaza Strip and the Palestinian Authoritys in the West Bank and demonstrating the complications that can emerge as the two prepare to join forces in a new government.

title: A Big Win for the Prayer Lobby
description: IF you listened to Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court and his fellow conservatives on the bench this week, you might think the courts 5-4 decision in the case of Town of Greece v. Galloway was no big deal. So what if a town in upstate New York typically opens its council meetings with prayers that acknowledge the saving sacrifice of Jesus Christ on the cross?

title: U.S. Issues Safety Alert for Oil Trains
description: Calling the movement of crude oil by rail an imminent hazard to the public, the federal Department of Transportation said on Wednesday that railroads would be required to notify local emergency responders whenever oil shipments traveled through their states.

title: Pakistani Activist Shot Dead; Aided Blasphemy Suspects
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Rashid Rehman, a veteran Pakistani human rights activist who had received threats for defending people charged under the countrys blasphemy laws, was shot dead on Wednesday night in his office in the southern city of Multan.

title: American Embassy in Yemen Is Closed
description: The United States has closed its embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, to the public because of security concerns, the State Department said on Wednesday, citing recent attacks against Western interests in Yemen as the reason for temporarily suspending operations. Embassy personnel are not being evacuated, but the closing will stop the processing of visas and other services. The department did not say how long the embassy would be closed to the public but stated that the potential threat to the embassy would be evaluated daily.

title: A Soldier Fights Off the Cold
description: WASHINGTON  On Aug. 4, 2004, while in my Stryker combat vehicle battling insurgents for control of a street in Mosul, Iraq, I was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. The core of the rocket, a solid piece of metal only a few inches long, sliced open my stomach from right to left, filled my legs and face with shrapnel, tore my intestines, lacerated my liver, destroyed my spleen, punctured my diaphragm, flattened my lungs, shattered my ribs and ruptured discs in my back. As I struggled to remove my smoldering body armor, I watched my stomach tear open and my intestines begin to push their way out.

title: China: Pollution Fines Multiply
description: By the end of April, the Beijing government had collected 88 million renminbi, or $14 million, in fines levied during the first three months of this year against companies caught violating pollution standards, according to a news release from Beijing officials and a report on Wednesday in Beijing News, a daily newspaper. The amount is 10 times the total levied in the same period in 2013. More than 7,000 companies were fined in the first three months of this year by Beijing environmental protection officials, compared with 2,000 in the same period last year.

title: Wheelies: The Lane-Minder Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Pakistan: F.B.I. Agent Is Questioned
description: The police questioned a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent under the countrys antiterrorism laws on Wednesday, two days after he was arrested on charges of possessing ammunition and knives as he tried to board a domestic flight. Several news outlets, citing American law enforcement officials, identified the man, who arrived in Pakistan on May 1, as Joel Cox. The Associated Press said that Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman in Washington, confirmed that Mr. Cox was an F.B.I. employee on temporary assignment to provide routine assistance to the legal attach at the U.S. Mission in Pakistan. The local news media broadcast images of a handcuffed man wearing a blue and white striped shirt as he was taken to court on Tuesday. The images were reminiscent of the arrest of Raymond A. Davis, a covert security officer for the Central Intelligence Agency, in Lahore in January 2011 after he shot two Pakistani men at a busy intersection. The killings and arrest of Mr. Davis caused a diplomatic furor, with the United States and Pakistan wrangling over American assertions that he had diplomatic immunity.

title: Love and Stuff
description: After her mother passes away, the filmmaker Judith Helfand struggles to pack up her things  figuring out what to keep and how to let go.

title: Love and Stuff
description: When I was a kid I loved Mothers Day. I got to make breakfast in bed for my mom. As I got older I started to resent it. I would tell her: this is between us  not you, me and Hallmark. Every day is Mothers Day. More than gifts, what she always wanted was time. Time with me, with my brothers, with her grandchildren, with my father (may he rest in peace), the guy who made her a mother to begin with. The gift of time always trumped stuff.

title: How Vanity Fair Landed the Monica Lewinsky Story
description: On Tuesday night, the wife of former Vice President Dick Cheney offered her take on Monica Lewinskys essay  Shame and Survival  in the June issue of Vanity Fair magazine. It was part of a Clinton conspiracy, she said, an effort to get that story out of the way before the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Venezuela: Arrests in Shooting of Antigovernment Protester
description: The authorities on Wednesday said they had charged two sergeants in the countrys National Guard in the death of a 23-year-old woman who was shot during antigovernment protests. The shooting of the woman, Geraldn Moreno, in February in Valencia, the countrys third-largest city, provoked outrage and fueled allegations that the protests sweeping Venezuela in recent months had been violently repressed. Witnesses said that Ms. Moreno was on the ground when a soldier shot her in the face at close range. President Nicols Maduro has said repeatedly that his government defends human rights and that it is vigorously investigating allegations of wrongdoing by security forces. A human rights lawyer, Gonzalo Himiob, pointed to an apparent lack of progress in other investigations and questioned the governments commitment to holding violators accountable.

title: For Online Video Publishers, a New Tack on Luring Ad Dollars
description: AS a well-received annual presentation of new digital offerings to Madison Avenue ends, publishers are seeking to keep the momentum going by making it easier for marketers and agencies to spend advertising dollars on online video  whether or not that money is being shifted from television ad budgets.

title: Amid Tensions, a Gesture From Putin
description: If President Vladimir Putin of Russia means what he said on Wednesday, the dangerous standoff over Ukraine could be moving toward a resolution. After meeting with the Swiss president, Didier Burkhalter, who is the current chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mr. Putin said Russian troops have been pulled back from the Ukrainian border, and he urged pro-Russian rebels in southeastern Ukraine to call off a referendum on secession that they had scheduled for Sunday.

title: Muve Music Service Is Said to Be Up for Sale by AT&T
description: One of the most successful music subscription services in the United States may be up for grabs.

title: Young Ukrainians Brush Aside the Crisis and Voice Optimism About the Future
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The din of dire news from Ukraines restive east and south tends to obscure people like Nataliya Gumenyuk, a spiky-haired bundle of energy who co-founded an online television channel that broadcast the countrys revolution. In spite of the daily chaos, conflict and crisis, she and other 20- and 30-somethings here insist that Ukraine has a brighter future in store, and they say they can build it.

title: F.C.C. Commissioner Asks for Delay on New Net Neutrality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A Democratic member of the Federal Communications Commission called Wednesday on the agencys chairman to delay a proposal for new net neutrality rules, throwing into doubt whether the chairman will be able to muster enough votes at an F.C.C. meeting next week to issue proposed rules.

title: Philadelphias Success in Helping the Homeless Gets a Philanthropic Boost
description: PHILADELPHIA  Theres a straight line that goes from David Drap to David Brown, but you cannot find it in most other cities.

title: Six Players, Six Countries, One Team
description: On a recent afternoon on a New York golf course, an Italian discussed strategy with a Canadian while a New Zealander laughed alongside a Briton. Nearby, a Spaniard and a Mexican huddled with an American.

title: For Cleopatras Needle, a Cleaning to Last 500 Years
description: In the course of history, whats a few years?

title: U.N. May Refer Syria Conflict to War Crimes Court
description: UNITED NATIONS  France has drafted a Security Council resolution that seeks to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court in The Hague, tailoring it specifically to address American sensitivities, according to several people who have seen the text.

title: U.S. Awards 3 Wind Power Grants
description: The long-promised potential of offshore wind development along American coastlines took a step toward fruition on Wednesday as the Department of Energy pledged up to $47 million each to three projects it previously supported.

title: After Tornado, Obama Visit Puts Politics on Pause in Arkansas
description: VILONIA, Ark.  President Obamas visit here on Wednesday was in many respects just like the many others he has made to disaster-ravaged communities across the country, but this one came with a bit of political intrigue.

title: Still No. 1? Golf Rankings Reflect a Longer View
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  In sports, you either win or you dont  a rigid bottom line underlying the what have you done for us lately attitude exemplified by the criticism aimed at the N.B.A. star Kevin Durant days before the formal announcement this week of his Most Valuable Player award.

title: When Freedom Is the Right to Stay Under Wraps
description: TEHRAN  Cars honked frantically, their drivers in despair as separate columns of Iranian men and women in black chadors fist-pumped their way through the capitals afternoon rush on Wednesday, shouting for the government to arrest all women who are improperly veiled.

title: Alibaba Bets on a Growing Chinese Economy and New Consumers
description: When American tech upstarts float their companies on the stock market, they often sell investors on a familiar dream  disrupting an existing industry. It doesnt matter if the industry is advertising, software, commerce or some other sector. The start-up will usually claim that its business is a great technological leap forward that will greatly lower costs and improve service for customers and leave rivals unable to respond. Therefore, buy some stock.

title: Growing Pains for a Goldman Sachs Fund
description: One of Goldman Sachss most notable investment vehicles, Petershill, has been less than extraordinary, effectively saved by one good bet among a number of duds, and the bank even came close to selling it to Credit Suisse in 2012. So when Goldman started a second version of Petershill, which buys stakes in big-name hedge funds, it came as something of a surprise to people in the industry.

title: Some Investors Bet on Return to Reverse Mortgages
description: Some private investors are betting that reverse mortgages, an investment product aimed at older people in need of cash, will make a resurgence as more homeowners reach retirement age in the coming years.

title: Americans Views on Climate Change
description: Forty-four percent of Americans said they believed that there is solid evidence the temperature on earth is getting warmer mostly because of human activity.

title: Hostage Testifies About Post-Rescue Meeting With Imam Charged in Kidnapping
description: They each took the witness stand, one after the other on Wednesday in a courtroom in Lower Manhattan: the former hostage and the British imam accused of helping to orchestrate her kidnapping.

title: Convicted Murderer Who Inspired Film Bernie Is Released to Directors Garage
description: LOS ANGELES  More thrilling than a Golden Globe nomination, and it had one of those last year, Richard Linklaters darkly comic film Bernie helped achieve something truly novel this week: Freedom for a convicted murderer, Bernie Tiede, who was the subject of the movie and, in a bizarre twist, will now live in Mr. Linklaters garage apartment.

title: Populist Party Gaining Muscle to Push Britain to the Right
description: GATESHEAD, England  Before winning power, Prime Minister David Cameron once called them fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists, and a cabinet minister, Kenneth Clarke, dismissed them last year as clowns. But the U.K. Independence Party is showing that it cannot be laughed off.

title: Prison Time That Ex-Legislator Must Serve Is Reduced
description: There may have been more corrupt politicians in New York than former State Assemblyman Brian M. McLaughlin, even though he admitted stealing from his campaign, the state government, labor unions, even a Little League program in Queens.

title: Honoring the Missing Schoolgirls
description: When Boko Haram fanatics attacked a girls boarding school in northeastern Nigeria, kidnapping several hundred girls whose only offense was to dream of becoming doctors, teachers or lawyers, the Nigerian authorities initial response was to lie.

title: Called by Republicans, Health Insurers Deliver Unexpected Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans summoned a half-dozen health insurance executives to a hearing Wednesday envisioned as another forum for criticism of the Affordable Care Act. But insurers refused to go along with the plan, and surprised Republican critics of the law by undercutting some of their arguments against it.

title: Christie, Visiting Maine, Aids a Colleagues Re-election Bid
description: PORTLAND, Me.  The S.U.V. had barely come to a full stop before Gov. Chris Christie hopped out and walked briskly under the dusted-white sign on the front of Beckys Diner. His quick entrance on Wednesday, trotting behind Gov. Paul LePage of Maine, set the tone as Mr. Christie, chairman of the Republican Governors Association, campaigned in public with a candidate for the first time since the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal broke.

title: Smartphones, Smartwatches and, Now, Smart Toothbrushes
description: IN the last few years, sensors have become small and inexpensive enough to make the monitoring of practically everything possible.

title: The Lawyer Behind the Drone Policy
description: When the White House nominated David Barron to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, based in Boston, it expected the usual Republican opposition. Mr. Barron, a Harvard law professor, is known as a liberal who was pointedly critical of President George W. Bushs national security policy. What it didnt expect  but should have  was that Democrats would have some problems with the nominee, too.

title: U.N. to Consider Ways to Track Planes Over Seas
description: Frustrated and alarmed by the failure to find any trace of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 after the 250-ton jet disappeared nine weeks ago, the United Nations civil aviation arm will convene a meeting in Montreal on Monday to discuss ways to keep track of planes flying over the open sea.

title: Cable Fees and Football Help Profits Climb at Fox
description: LOS ANGELES  The Super Bowl, new digital streaming TV deals and higher fees for its cable networks resulted in a stronger-than-expected gain in quarterly profit at 21st Century Fox.

title: Miami Finds Itself Ankle-Deep in Climate Change Debate
description: MIAMI BEACH  The sunny-day flooding was happening again. During high tide one recent afternoon, Eliseo Toussaint looked out the window of his Alton Road laundromat and watched bottle-green saltwater seep from the gutters, fill the street and block the entrance to his front door.

title: Sunny Region Yields a Shining Young Player
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  While most hockey players have childhood tales of skating on icy ponds and frozen toes, Anaheim Ducks forward Emerson Etem reminisces about surfing along sandy beaches and wolfing down In-N-Out burgers.

title: Climate Disruptions, Close to Home
description: Apart from the disinformation sowed by politicians content with the status quo, the main reason neither Congress nor much of the American public cares about global warming is that, as problems go, it seems remote. Anyone who reads the latest National Climate Assessment, released on Tuesday, cannot possibly think that way any longer. The report is exhaustive and totally alarming.

title: Abduction of Girls an Act Not Even Al Qaeda Can Condone
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  As word spread like wildfire on Twitter and Facebook that Nigerian militants were preparing to auction off more than 200 kidnapped schoolgirls in the name of Islam, a very different Internet network started quietly buzzing too.

title: Another Push to Pay With Smartphones at Vending Machines
description: SEATTLE  If anything should be able to get people to use their smartphones as mobile wallets, its vending machines.

title: Conflicting Rulings Cloud Wisconsin Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: An investigation into possible campaign finance violations involving conservative groups in Wisconsin and Gov. Scott Walkers campaign committee has become entangled in back-to-back federal court rulings on whether it should continue.

title: Real Threat in a Known Market for Children
description: When the leader of the Boko Haram extremist group threatened to sell hundreds of kidnapped Nigerian girls in the market in a rambling online video posted this week, he was not necessarily making an irrational boast.

title: Taxpayers Bill in Bridge Inquiry Soars
description: The cost to New Jersey taxpayers for Gov. Chris Christies internal inquiry into lane closings at the George Washington Bridge is likely to reach several million dollars, outpacing early estimates and touching off urgent attempts to reduce the cost, according to newly available documents and interviews.

title: China and Vietnam on Oil Rig Dispute
description: Officials from Vietnam and China discussed an incident between the two countries in the South China Sea.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 7, 2014
A Nets Big Man Casts a Long Shadow With His Absence
description: MIAMI  Hello, Brook.

title: American Legion, Citing Problems, Calls for Veterans Secretary to Resign
description: When the commander of the American Legion, Daniel Dellinger, asked the secretary of veterans affairs, Eric Shinseki, last month about why no one in his department had been fired despite an array of serious problems over the years, he was taken aback at the answer.

title: Allen Elevates His Game and Heats
description: MIAMI  Erik Spoelstra practically rolled his eyes Wednesday afternoon when a reporter began to ask about the video his Heat players were watching inside their locker room on Tuesday night.

title: Hush Lifted Over Awards for Nations Libraries and Museums
description: WASHINGTON  When she was 16, Ashley Gagnay did not know that beets and carrots grew underground or that lemons ripened on trees. She had to learn those lessons at a program sponsored by the Childrens Garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Now 21, she teaches those basics to 4-year-olds enrolled in a similar program at the garden.

title: Complaints About Pigeons, Mapped
description: Since 2010, more than 2,700 unsanitary pigeon condition complaints have been made to New York Citys 311 hot line.

title: The Most Republican Company? The Makers of Wonder Bread
description: The most Republican-leaning company in the country, based on political donations, isnt Koch Industries. Its the company that makes Wonder Bread.

title: Making a Statement
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I thought this was a simple yet clever theme that highlights the Liars PARADOX, but Ill be honest right up front with you: This theme has run before, albeit with a slightly different reveal.

title: Nationals Put Trust in Strasburg, Even When He Falters
description: WASHINGTON  When the question came to him, with the cameras on, Stephen Strasburg chose calculated sarcasm. How often does he have all his pitches working the way he did Wednesday?

title: House Approves Panel to Study Building Womens Museum
description: The House on Wednesday approved a commission to study building a womens history museum in Washington, advancing an effort that has been stalled in Congress for more than a decade. Drafted by Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York, and Marsha Blackburn, Republican of Tennessee, the bill would create an eight-member panel to examine potential locations, including on or near the National Mall, and construction and maintenance details. The bill must be approved by the Senate, and the museum itself would require congressional approval. Some critics do not want to use taxpayer money on the project, and several conservatives groups have pressured lawmakers to oppose it because they believe it will reflect a liberal bias.

title: North Carolina: Judge Attacked in Ad Campaign Survives Primary
description: Justice Robin Hudson, who is seeking re-election to the North Carolina Supreme Court, will face Superior Court Judge Eric Levinson in the November ballot after the two received the most votes in Tuesdays three-candidate primary. The primary received national attention because the Republican State Leadership Committee in Washington, using donations from corporations and individuals, provided more than $600,000 for an ad attacking Justice Hudson, a Democrat. On a day of low turnout, Justice Hudson received 43 percent of the votes while Judge Levinson, a conservative, received 37 percent and a second conservative, Jeanette Doran, received 21 percent.

title: The Enquirer Is Returning to Where It All Started
