description: Michael Douglas Marked for Death!! Angelina Walks In on Brad & Jen. Space Platform Circling Mars  Living Creatures May Be Aboard. Japs Attack U.S.  Hawaii, Philippines Bombed by Airmen!

title: Once Shaky in Postseason, Fleury Continues Steady Play in Goal
description: Marc-Andre Fleury came into this second-round series against the Rangers as a bit of a worrisome commodity for the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Kenneth Tomlinson, Conservative Voice in Broadcast Oversight, Dies at 69
description: Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, a conservative journalist who used his leadership role in federal communications agencies to counter what he regarded as liberal bias, died on May 1 at a hospital in Winchester, Va. He was 69.

title: Mondelez and Dutch Firm Aim to Create a Coffee Powerhouse
description: Mondelez International, the maker of Cadbury chocolate and Chips Ahoy cookies, is carving out its coffee business to combine it in a joint venture with a Dutch company to form a global coffee seller with more than $7 billion in annual revenue. The joint venture will join Mondelez Internationals coffee portfolio with D.E Master Blenders 1753 of Amsterdam, giving the combined company control of coffee brands including Gevalia, Tassimo, Senso and, outside the United States, Maxwell House. The new company will be called Jacobs Douwe Egberts and will be based in the Netherlands. After the combination, Mondelez International, which was spun out of Kraft Foods in 2012, will receive about $5 billion in cash and a 49 percent equity stake in the joint venture.

title: Sikorsky and Lockheed to Build New Presidential Helicopter
description: Sikorsky Aircraft and Lockheed Martin won a $1.24 billion contract on Wednesday to begin building a new presidential helicopter. The companies were the only bidders in the latest phase of a decadelong effort to begin replacing the aging, white-topped helicopters that alight from the White House lawn. An earlier program run by Lockheed Martin and AgustaWestland of Italy collapsed in 2009 because of technical difficulties and billions of dollars in cost overruns, with President Obama complaining that it was an example of the procurement process gone amok. Industry officials said that AgustaWestland, Boeing and Bell Helicopter did not bid this time because they believed that the specifications favored a version of Sikorskys S-92 helicopter, which is smaller than most of its rivals. The new contract will cover the development of six aircraft. The Navy, which runs the program, is likely to eventually buy 21 helicopters. Sikorsky, which built the current presidential helicopters, is a unit of United Technologies. It will assemble the new aircraft in Stratford, Conn. Lockheed will install the mission systems in Owego, N.Y.

title: Night of Lows Has Rangers Down and Almost Out
description: When Henrik Lundqvist broke his stick over the crossbar in disgust after allowing a short-handed goal, he may have provided the defining moment of the Rangers ghastly 4-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Farley Mowat, Author, Dies at 92; a Champion of the Far North
description: OTTAWA  Farley Mowat, one of Canadas most popular and prolific writers, who became a champion of wildlife and native Canadian rights and a sharp critic of environmental abuse, died on Tuesday in Port Hope, Ontario, where he had lived for several years.He was 92.

title: Tatiana Samoilova, a Movie Star Behind the Iron Curtain, Dies at 80
description: MOSCOW  Tatiana Samoilova, a movie star who was known in the Soviet Union for her beauty and strong-willed performances but who remained virtually unknown in the West because the Soviet authorities would not let her work there, died here on Sunday, her 80th birthday.

title: Bill H. Dana, Pilot Who Outflew Bullets and Touched Space for NASA, Dies at 83
description: Bill H. Dana, a NASA research pilot who flew the X-15 rocket plane at record supersonic speeds and tested many of the most innovative and dangerous aircraft ever developed, died on Tuesday in Phoenix. He was 83.

title: Yankees Roberts Stops Trying to Hit Like Cano and Starts to Thrive
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  When the Seattle Mariners were in New York last week, Robinson Cano had a chance to catch up with many of his former Yankees teammates. He spoke with Derek Jeter, C. C. Sabathia and Ichiro Suzuki, among others. He also talked several times with a Yankee he had never played with: the man who took his place.

title: India Election Digest: May 8
description: What you need to know on Thursday about Indias elections: Rahul Gandhi made a surprise appearance in his home constituency to appeal to voters, an analysis of voter turnout indicates an anti-incumbency mood, and the Aam Aadmi Partys absence of caste politics is helping it in Varanasi.

title: Dissident Journalist Held Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
description: An outspoken Chinese journalist who was jailed after the armed crackdown of 1989 has been detained in Beijing on charges of obtaining and leaking a confidential Communist Party document, a state-run news agency reportedon Thursday. The report said the journalist, Gao Yu, had admitted to the crime and was willing to accept legal punishment.

title: Mediocre Night at Sothebys, as One-Third of the Art Does Not Sell
description: It was another bumpy night at the spring auctions, the second of the weeks evening sales of Impressionist and modern art. On Wednesday, many in the art world converged upon Sothebys, where nearly a third of the art went unsold. Paintings and sculptures by masters like Degas, Renoir and Picasso were either overpriced or were just not good enough to tempt buyers.

title: Quaffable Cocktails That Get Their Flavor From Surprising (and Surprisingly Obtainable) Ingredients
description: As the wave of cocktail innovation continues to crest, intrepid bartenders are turning to unexpected ingredients in their quest to make the most delicious drinks imaginable, including imported amaros, eaux de vie and fortified wines. With the latest edition of the Manhattan Cocktail Classic festival descending on the New York Public Library this Friday, we offer six recipes from some of the countrys most renowned bartenders that derive their character from unexpected, but easily obtainable ingredients. Belly up to their bars for a taste, or mix them up yourself at home.

title: A Passage to India
description: Having cut a stylish swath from Brussels to Bombay, the free-spirited designer and hotelier Loulou Van Damme has returned to her birthplace in the Palani Hills for her latest adventure.

title: Lost in Paradise
description: The laid-back surf town of Todos Santos, Mexico, serves as a vibrant backdrop for summertime knits that provide cover  and a touch of hippie chic  to any vacation ensemble.

title: A Photographer Looks to New Horizons
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: The Americans Recap: Invisible vs. Invincible
description: Episode 11 of The Americans begins in the Soviet Union. It is a depressing, gray morning and the camera pans over a woman, naked, sleeping facedown on a bed. Next to her, the forcibly repatriated scientist Anton Vaklonov wakes and rises. He is still miserable back in his former country. He is, however, working on the Soviet version of a stealth plane  what choice does he have, really?  the radar-evading technology that was an important issue during the Cold War.

title: Stories as a Window Into Schizophrenia
description: CINCINNATI The psychologist Lynda Crane found that of the many injuries inflicted by schizophrenia, the greatest could be the pain of being forgotten. Just naming the illness somehow erased the person, something she learned when her 18-year-old sons doctors said he had schizophrenia. Six years later, he committed suicide.

title: Word of the Day | incompatible
description: incompatible\in-km-pa-t-bl\ adjective

title: Corrections: May 8, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Ukrainians Favor Unity, Not Russia, Polls Find
description: Ukrainians, including most Russian speakers, want to keep their country united with its current borders intact, but there are concerns about the government. While few Ukrainians have confidence in President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, his reputation has grown considerably at home, with more than 80 percent of Russians trusting his handling of world affairs.

title: Times Minute | New Yorks Iconic Library
description: Culture reporter Robin Pogrebin on the abrupt change in plans for New York Citys landmark central library.

title: Times Minute | New Yorks Iconic Library
description: In the Video

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) AMERICAN COMEDY AWARDS Chris Rock, above, will present Bill Cosby with the Johnny Carson Award for Comedic Excellence at this ceremony honoring funny people in film, television, stand-up and viral video. Nominees  voted on by fans and entertainment industry professionals  include Alexander Paynes movie Nebraska and its star, Bruce Dern; Julia Louis-Dreyfus, for Nicole Holofceners film Enough Said and the HBO series Veep; The Colbert Report; Jason Bateman, for Netflixs Arrested Development; Louis C.K.: Oh My God; and Bound 3, starring James Franco and Seth Rogen. Bill Hader, Johnny Knoxville, Leslie Mann, Stephen Merchant, Aubrey Plaza and J. B. Smoove are among the presenters. The house band is Craig Robinson & the Nasty Delicious.

title: A.N.C. Leads South Africa Vote, but Others Gain
description: JOHANNESBURG  South Africas long-ruling African National Congress was headed to another big victory in national elections on Thursday, though it appeared to fall short of President Jacob G. Zumas goal of a two-thirds majority, incomplete results showed.

title: At Election Seasons End, Sri Lankan Tamil Refugees Forgotten Again
description: PUZHAL, India  As Tamil civilians were increasingly caught in the crossfire between the Indian Peace Keeping Force and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in the 1980s, Sasitharan and his parents followed the exodus from the Tamil-majority northern and eastern regions of Sri Lanka.

title: Jeter Homers to Lift Yankees Over Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Baseball has long been rife with superstitions, whether wearing a rally cap, eating a special pregame meals or avoiding stepping on the foul line. At Angel Stadium this week, the Yankees have discovered a new one: the lucky dugout bathroom.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 8, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: With Words and Actions, Durant Leads Thunder Past Clippers
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  When Kevin Durant expressed through tears on Tuesday how important his family, his teammates and his fans were to him, he was not just offering thanks for helping him win the N.B.A.s Most Valuable Player award.

title: 6 Qs About the News | U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods
description: In U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods, Justin Gillis reports on a major study that found that water shortages, torrential rains, heat waves and wildfires were worsening.

title: After Years of Ambitious Growth, Barclays Seeks to Be Leaner
description: Updated, 7:52 a.m. | LONDON  After decades of building a global investment bank, Barclays is sounding a retreat.

title: Deutsche Telekom Profit Falls Amid Aggressive Spending in U.S.
description: LONDON  Deutsche Telekoms first-quarter earnings suffered as it continued to spend heavily to expand its operations in the United States, the company said on Thursday.

title: Pictures on the Street? Its Complicated
description: After 40 wonderful years, Mark Cohen has abruptly ended his relationship with his muse. It might seem like cold betrayal, but its really more complicated than that.

title: How Well Do You Take Criticism?
description: Do you instinctively get defensive when someone criticizes your work  an essay you wrote, a performance you gave or a layup you missed? Or, are you able to see critique as an opportunity to do even better and push yourself harder?

title: China Hesitates to Label Guangzhou Attack Terrorism
description: The Chinese state-run news media and government officials have not described the attack on train passengers in Guangzhou on Tuesday, which left six people wounded, as an act of terrorism. Instead, they have described the incident as a knife attack, suggesting the possibility that it was the work of a lone assailant with no connection to militants from the northwestern region of Xinjiang.

title: Blast Hits Pakistani Army Convoy, Killing 9 Soldiers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful explosion hit a Pakistani Army convoy early Thursday in the North Waziristan tribal region, killing at least nine soldiers while leaving several others critically injured, according to a Pakistani security official based in the area.

title: An Explosion and a Blockade, and a Syrian Pact Is in Limbo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A deal to evacuate insurgents from the Old City of Homs in central Syria hit a snag on Thursday when rebels in Aleppo Province refused to allow all of a humanitarian convoy to enter two villages they had blockaded, as called for under a pact between the government and the rebels, opposition activists and a pro-government television channel reported.

title: New York Today: An Island of Art
description: Good morning on this drippy Thursday.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: The Silence of Doctors Around Alzheimers
description: A fate worse than death, my colleague muttered to me as we examined an elderly man admitted to the hospital with severe dementia.

title: Why Do You Watch Birds?
description: Most people go to the top of the Empire State Building to look down. But I go to look up.

title: Ousted Thai Premier Faces Impeachment Amid Rising Tension
description: BANGKOK  The Election Commission of Thailand on Thursday cast doubt on elections tentatively set for July as proceedings to impeach the ousted prime minister took another step forward, sharpening a political crisis that has already left the country with a hamstrung government.

title: Prisa of Spain Agrees to Sell Digital Plus Stake to Telefnica for $1 Billion
description: LONDON  The Spanish media company Prisa has agreed to sell its majority stake in the local pay-television provider known as Digital Plus to Telefnica for around $1 billion.

title: Glencore Names Former BP Chief as Chairman
description: The commodities colossus Glencore Xstrata has named Tony Hayward, a former chief executive of BP who was widely criticized for his handling of the companys huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, as its chairman.

title: Why Do-Not-Call Lists Dont Work Against Pollsters
description: To stop annoying phone calls, you listed your telephone number on the national Do Not Call registry, and interruptions from telemarketers diminished. So why are you still getting uninvited calls from people in my profession, polling?

title: Separatists Defy Kiev and Putin on Referendum
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Pro-Russian militants in eastern Ukraine vowed on Thursday to press ahead with a referendum seeking autonomy, a risky move that seemed to defy their political patron, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, whose motives in urging a delay in the vote came under furious attack by officials in Kiev.

title: Gail Collins: Staying Busy in the Political Off-Season
description: What does a Times columnist do in a slow political season? Plenty. Our Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins discusses how curiosity, humor and the occasional obsession keep the gears of topical commentary turning. She was interviewed by Peter Catapano, an editor in Opinion.

title: The Value of Peer-to-Peer Business Groups
description: Im a big fan of peer-to-peer business groups.They take many forms, and Ive been involved in more than my share over the last 35 years.

title: YouTube Founders to Sell Delicious, a Social Bookmarking Site
description: The social bookmarking service Delicious has changed hands twice over the last decade, while failing to attract a mainstream audience.

title: Police in Deadly Confrontation in Restive Chinese Region
description: HONG KONG  The police in Xinjiang, the far-western Chinese region beset by ethnic tensions, fatally shot one person and captured another on Thursday in the latest of a string of deadly confrontations there, state-run media reported on Thursday.

title: The Big Reason Republicans Should Hope Jeb Bush Runs
description: Florida has been an afterthought in electoral politics over the last few cycles, but it is positioned to return to the forefront. No state looms larger as the Republican Party mulls its future.

title: Daily Report: In I.P.O., Alibaba Wagers on a Growing Market: China
description: When American tech upstarts float their companies on the stock market, they often sell investors on a familiar dream  disrupting an existing industry, Farhad Manjoo reports. It doesnt matter if the industry is advertising, software, commerce or some other sector. The start-up will usually claim that its business is a great technological leap forward that will greatly lower costs and improve service for customers and leave rivals unable to respond. Therefore, buy some stock.

title: Pick to Replace Sebelius Draws Senators Praise at Confirmation Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obamas nominee to replace Kathleen Sebelius as secretary of health and human services, charmed senators at a surprisingly cordial confirmation hearing on Thursday.

title: An Overhaul at Barclays
description: In a sharp retreat from Wall Street, Barclays plans to shrink its investment banking business by cutting more than a quarter of the operations work force, Chad Bray and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. Antony P. Jenkins, the banks chief executive, is aiming to reshape the bank and revive its image after a series of scandals.

title: European Central Bank Says Stimulus Is Likely, but Not Before June
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Thursday held interest rates steady, but signaled that it was likely to take action next month to stimulate the euro zone economy, amid growing concern about economic fallout from the crisis in Ukraine.

title: Just Try Borrowing a Cup of Sugar
description: At an especially stressful moment in their domestic life  they are in the midst of an escalating battle with the fraternity next door, about which more shortly  Mac and Kelly, a married couple with a cute (and notably quiet) baby daughter, have a fight. At issue is who has the right to be irresponsible. Although they have a kid, a mortgage and other trappings of grown-up life, neither is entirely willing to give up the wild, impulsive behavior associated with youth. Mac (Seth Rogen) thinks his gender (and perhaps also his body type) entitles him to be the self-indulgent one. We cant both be Kevin James, he says. And of course, he points out, Kelly (Rose Byrne) is a wife and mother, a bit of biological typecasting she furiously resents, and one that Neighbors rejects.

title: Moving Your Show to Broadway? Not So Fast
description: Its the most critically acclaimed musical of the New York theater season. It has endearing characters  a hungry protagonist and a colorful family  as well as clever storytelling and tuneful songs. Its creators spent years developing the show, dreaming of Broadway, but tempering their expectations, only too well aware they didnt have the big-name stars or tourist-friendly material that can keep a multimillion-dollar musical in business.

title: Apollo Global Reports Sharply Lower Profit
description: The private equity giant Apollo Global Management reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings on Thursday, as it reaped less profit from its investments.

title: Former BP Chief Is Named Chairman of Glencore Xstrata
description: LONDON  Glencore Xstrata, the big commodities trading and mining company, said on Thursday that it had named Tony Hayward, the former chief executive of BP, to be its permanent chairman. Mr. Hayward has been serving in the role in an interim capacity for the past year.

title: Reaping Benefits of Expansion, Emirates Profit Rises 43%
description: PARIS  Emirates, the fast-growing Persian Gulf airline, reported on Thursday a 43 percent jump in annual profit as its international expansion and the steady introduction of new wide-body jets to its fleet drew millions of new customers through its Dubai hub.

title: In Our Pages: May 9
description: 1939: Alleged Nazi Leader Freed

title: Requesting a Handout, in 2 Acts
description: Dear Diary:

title: JPMorgan Backs an Online Broker, Motif Investing
description: Motif Investing, an upstart online broker, has attracted the nations biggest bank as a backer.

title: After Postponing Its I.P.O., Box Gets a Break
description: Box, an online content storage company that last week had to postpone a much-expected initial public offering, got a little good news on Thursday.

title: Where Elegance Meets Eros
description: So much for the debate about whether fashion can be art. Charles James: Beyond Fashion, a landmark exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Costume Institute, proposes that this perennial question, which sprang up in the 1970s, was asked and answered in the late 1940s and 50s. Thats when the Anglo-American couturier Charles James was at the height of his powers, making coats, suits, cocktail dresses and especially ball gowns, creating a sartorial sublime similar to the vaunted abstract sublime of the Abstract Expressionist painters working at the same time.

title: Big Hands, Small Colleges and the N.F.L. Draft
description: Some say you can take the measure of a man by the firmness of his handshake.

title: Charlie Chaplins Home in Switzerland to Become a Museum
description: Charlie Chaplin spent the last 25 years of his life in Corsier-sur-Vevey, above the shores of Lake Geneva in Switzerland. In an 18th-century mansion on a 35-acre estate he gardened, made films, composed music, wrote books and spent time with his wife, Oona Chaplin, and their eight children. Now three of those children  Michael, Eugene and Victoria Chaplin  have announced their partnership in a new museum, called Chaplins World in their former family home, The Associated Press reported.

title: Vaccine Opponents Can Be Immune to Education
description: Vaccines will prevent the deaths of tens of thousands of children born this year over their lifetimes. So why are potentially dangerous numbers of parents in some states opting out of one of the great achievements of modern medicine?

title: Pinocchio Rex, Chinas New Dinosaur
description: Scientists have discovered a new species of dinosaur, a relative of the ferocious Tyrannosaurus rex, according to a report in Nature Communications. The story of the discovery of the 30-foot-long Qianzhousaurus sinensis, which began more than three years ago in a construction site in southeastern China, is one of drama and luck, as well as science.

title: Lopsided Approach to Wall Street Fraud Undermines the Law
description: Mr. Kaufman, a former United States senator from Delaware, is a visiting professor of the practice at the Duke University School of Law.

title: House Republicans Say Comcast Merger Risks Undue Sway on Channels
description: WASHINGTON  Several House Republicans expressed concern on Thursday that a merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would give the new company undue influence over the potential success of cable channels whose programming might compete with Comcasts.

title: A Chef in the Field | Microgreens
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: In Assam, a Familiar Pattern of Violence
description: BAKSA, India  The Assamese villages of N.K. Khagrabari and Narayanguri border a thickly forested national wildlife sanctuary on one side and the Beki River on another, in the western part of the state.

title: Cities in India Among the Most Polluted, W.H.O. Says
description: NEW DELHI  New Delhis air is the most polluted in the world, according to an international report that quantifies pollution levels, confirming findings by experts confounded by the lack of attention to the citys problem.

title: Classical Playlist: Pavarotti, Berio, Shostakovich and More
description: BELLINI: I PuritaniJoan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Piero Cappuccilli, Nicolai Ghiaurov; Richard Bonynge, conductor; London Symphony Orchestra, Chorus of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden(Decca; three CDs)There has been almost a mini-festival of bel canto opera taking place at the Metropolitan Opera of late, with the return of Rossinis La Cenerentola and revivals of two Bellini works: La Sonnambula and I Puritani. In anticipation of I Puritani, I took out the 1973 recording featuring Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti, with Richard Bonynge conducting the London Symphony Orchestra. I can hardly stop listening to it. No matter ones taste in the art of bel canto, no matter ones passion for Maria Callas (which we all share), Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti are thrilling exemplars of the tradition. This recording captures them in their glory. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Today in Small Business: Buying American
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Harry Trumans Formidable Mother-in-Law
description: Here a conspicuously uneasy Harry S. Truman is in the breakfast room upstairs at the White House with his mother-in-law, Madge Gates Wallace. The scene is in the vicinity of Mothers Day 1946. It appears as if Mrs. Wallace cannot stand to look at him. (Trumans sister-in-law, Natalie Ott Wallace, sits between the two, in a kind of demilitarized zone.)

title: Poetry Pairing | To My Mother
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features To My Mother by Edgar Allan Poe and the Op-Ed column Muddling Through Mothers Day by Frank Bruni.

title: Americas First Queer Jazz Festival to Be Held in Philadelphia
description: OutBeat, a four-day event that organizers are describing as the first jazz festival with a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender focus (its subtitle is Americas First Queer Jazz Festival), will be staged in Philadelphia from Sept. 18 to 21. The festival, which was announced by its sponsor, the William Way LGBT Community Center, at a news conference in Philadelphia on Wednesday, will include panel discussions and receptions as well as performances at several clubs and halls around the city.

title: China Offers Its Side of Story in Sea Dispute With Vietnam
description: China acknowledged on Thursday it had used a water cannon against Vietnamese vessels in a dispute in the South China Sea, but denied that Chinese Navy ships were present.

title: Your Vintage Wedding Rings
description: Last month, we asked readers to submit Instagram photos of their heirloom wedding rings or those inspired by the styles of yesteryear. Here, a selection.

title: Where to Turn When the School Wants to Have Your Child Tested
description: Dear Mrs. Lahey,

title: Deflation Threatens Europe. Policy Makers Wait.
description: Europe is staring into the face of the kind of deflationary cycle that has paralyzed the Japanese economy for the better part of two decades. Prices are rising far more slowly than its central bank wants, against a backdrop of astronomical unemployment on much of the Continent.

title: What Ive Been Reading
description: Expanding on the bold (terrifying?) experiment in columnist transparency that inspired our recent spate of ask me anything featureshere at Op-Ed, Im going to begin posting regularly on my current reading (and I believe some of my colleagues may soon be doing the same).My model, in form and at least initially in style, will be Tyler Cowens recurring reading lists, except that Im not quite such a polymath and dont manage to read quite as many books, so Ill be listing magazine essays, interviews, and other pieces as well.

title: The Stars Align ... With the Ensemble
description: It may be that Denzel Washington and Daniel Radcliffe have been doing their jobs too well. As the leading men of the hit Broadway revivals of Lorraine Hansberrys A Raisin in the Sun (Mr. Washington) and Martin McDonaghs The Cripple of Inishmaan (Mr. Radcliffe), they are both offering affecting and astute interpretations  in the case of Mr. Radcliffe, what is surely his best stage work to date.

title: The Unconventional Earn Their Applause
description: Although it often seems that nothing much changes on Broadway these days  here comes another pileup of celebrities; watch out for the latest movie coming to a stage near you  every season springs a surprise or two. The one just past, while unremarkable in many respects, had more than its share of oddities, as sprigs of unconventionality struggled to take root in the artistically arid ground.

title: And the Nominees Should Be ...
description: Charles Isherwood makes his Tony Award choices. For the Should have been nominated category, the Timess critics were allowed to expand the potential nominees to Off Broadway productions that were ineligible for the Broadway-only Tonys. (Ben Brantleys picks are here.) The ceremony for the 68th annual Tony Awards will be broadcast on June 8 on CBS.

title: And the Nominees Should Be ...
description: Ben Brantley makes his Tony Award choices. For the Should have been nominated category, the Timess critics were allowed to expand the potential nominees to Off Broadway productions that were ineligible for the Broadway-only Tonys. (Charles Isherwoods picks are here.) The ceremony for the 68th annual Tony Awards will be broadcast on June 8 on CBS.

title: Wheelies: The Secret Service Security Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Antibiotic-Resistant Germs, Lying in Wait Everywhere
description: The Lechuguilla Cave in New Mexico is a network of chambers stretching 1,600 feet underground. The bacteria that grow on the walls of its most remote recesses have been living in complete isolation for more than four million years.

title: For U.S. Cities, a 2024 Olympic Competition
description: When NBC Universal agreed to spend $7.75 billion on six Olympic Games through 2032, perhaps it was counting on the added value of having one of those Olympics staged in the United States.

title: Dan Colen, Art World Bomb Thrower, Gets Respectable. Sort Of.
description: Thirty four is hardly old, but Dan Colen has done a lot of growing up since bursting on the art scene a decade ago, after earning a degree in painting at the Rhode Island School of Design. Colen came to prominence as a member of the Irak crew, a posse of graffiti writers, artists, pranksters and drug users that also included Ryan McGinley and the late Dash Snow. Those formative years are central to Help, Colens new retrospective at the Brant Foundation in Greenwich, Conn., which opens this Monday. Theres been an arc in my work and an arc in my life, says Colen, who still maintains a punkish air, but is now a monied property owner (of a fully operational farm in Pine Plains, N.Y.) with close relationships to art-world power players like Peter Brant, Charles Saatchi, Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. The exhibition, he says, is an opportunity to look at the old work and the new work, and really for the first time to consider what ties it all together.

title: Chuck Berry and Peter Sellars Win Polar Music Prize
description: The Polar Music Prize for 2014 has been awarded to the rock n roll patriarch Chuck Berry, and to Peter Sellars, the iconoclastic director of operas and staged concerts. The prize, announced on Thursday by the foundation that administers it, is essentially a lifetime achievement prize and carries a cash award of one million Swedish krona ($153,725) and a touch of royalty: though it not a government prize, it is given to the winners by King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a banquet in Stockholm. This years ceremony is on Aug. 26.

title: Red-Hot Web in China Richly Rewards Foreign Investors
description: SHENZHEN, China  It is one of the best investments of the digital age.

title: A Different View on Risk and Reward
description: This interview with Wayne Jackson, chief executive of Sonatype, a software security firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Gillian Flynn: By the Book
description: The author of Gone Girl says its hard to get over something first read at age 12: I will probably be clutching Flowers in the Attic in my gnarled hands on my deathbed.

title: Tough Task for Yahoo: Spending Its Alibaba Windfall Wisely
description: More than ever, Marissa Mayer needs to find the exclamation point in Yahoos business. After the company sells around half of its 22.6 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, Ms. Mayer, the Yahoo chief executive, could have $12 billion on hand. Spending it wisely will be tough.

title: Highlights and Analysis of the 2014 N.F.L. Draft, Round 1
description: There was a lot of hype surrounding the first round of the 2014 N.F.L draft, and it didnt disappoint. From the slide of Johnny Manziel to the unexpected names called in the second half of the round, the first 32 picks in 2014 came with a lot of excitement.

title: Studio Tours Resume in North Carolina
description: After a three-year absence, EUE/Screen Gems Studios in Wilmington, N.C., has resumed tours at its production complex.

title: Image of the Day: May 8
Climate Debate Isn't So Heated in the U.S.
What Timothy Geithner Really Thinks
description: This is kind of like a hearing, Timothy Geithner said, swaying uncomfortably, face scrunched and hair perfectly tousled. Do you guys always do it this way?

title: Off the Record in a Chat App? Dont Be Sure
description: What happens on the Internet stays on the Internet.

title: 5 Takeaways From Magazine Article on Geithner and the Financial Crisis
description: Timothy F. Geithner is finally going public. Since Mr. Geithner stepped down as Treasury secretary last year, he has remained largely out of the public eye. Now, with the publication of his book, Stress Test: Reflections on Financial Crises, to be published next week, Mr. Geithner is breaking his silence. I caught up with him last month as he was putting the finishing touches on the book. We discussed  and debated  his tenure in government and his prescriptions for solving financial crises. During a series of interviews, he was surprisingly frank. The result of those interviews  and an early look at his book  appear as the cover story in the coming issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Medicaid, Romneycare and Mortality
description: My post yesterday on the new study of post-Romneycare mortality rates in Massachusetts set up a contrast between two policy scenarios: One in which health insurance expansions have a substantial effect on health (as the Massachusetts mortality data suggests), and another in which insurances connection to public health is much more limited (as the data from the Oregon Medicaid experiment had indicated).

title: Snapchat Settlement With F.T.C.
description: The mobile messaging service Snapchat settled with the Federal Trade Commission over charges that the service inaccurately claimed that, once sent, messages disappeared.

title: 36 Hours in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
description: Buzz, buzz, buzz. Whether its the roar of motorbikes, the near constant opening of bars and restaurants, the chatty nature of its inhabitants, or the abundance of great coffee, theres just something invigorating about Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnams largest metropolis. Its no surprise that Saigon, as most locals call it, exudes a youthful, inventive energy  after all, over half of its eight million dwellers are younger than 35. This dynamic spirit shines through in quirky cafes, innovative cuisine and boutiques selling homegrown fashion. And when you need a breather from all thats new and fabulous, its easy to steal quiet moments in crumbling colonial buildings and contemplative art spaces.

title: Nate Berkus on Decorating With Souvenirs
description: Ask the interior designer Nate Berkus about a piece of dcor in his New York home, and youll very likely discover its a souvenir from one of his travels abroad.

title: Predictions and Prejudice
description: The 2008 crisis and its aftermath have been a testing time for economists  and the tests have been moral as well as intellectual. After all, economists made very different predictions about the effects of the various policy responses to the crisis; inevitably, some of those predictions would prove deeply wrong. So how would those who were wrong react?

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 35
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Along the Aegean, a Turkish Town Sees a Revival
description: A Turkish town populated mostly by retirees and known for its prime windsurfing conditions was, without employment opportunities for its young, headed for desertion and disrepair five years ago. But this spot on the Aegean has recently seen a revival as children from Turkeys big cities who vacationed there in the 1980s grew up and returned to stay.

title: Times Minute | Ukraines Two Votes
description: The Timess David Herszenhorn reporting from Ukraine on what two votes  one local and one national  could mean for the country.

title: Times Minute | Ukraines Two Votes
description: In the Video

title: In Odessa, Home-Grown Combatants Keep Pro-Russia Forces in Check
description: ODESSA, Ukraine  In a basement headquarters behind a home electronics store, Ruslan Forostyak pored over a map of the citys defenses against pro-Russian militants: roadblocks, zones of responsibility, strategic sites to defend.

title: With Elections Nearing, Republican Senators Take On Yellen on Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Thursday sharply questioned Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, about the persistence of unemployment and the slow pace of the economic recovery during a hearing that highlighted the growing prominence of election-year considerations on Capitol Hill.

title: Economies of Scales
description: Brad Plumer tells an important, little-known tale. It begins with things going badly:

title: Footage of Hotel Bombing in Aleppo
description: Video from Shaam News Network, an anti-Assad group in Syria, showed a rebel-claimed bombing in Aleppo that leveled a hotel that government troops used as a military base, near the citys ancient citadel.

title: De Blasios Budget Raises Spending Without Big Cuts
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday announced a $73.9 billion budget plan for New York City that included significant new spending on education, social services and municipal payrolls  but virtually no service cuts or new channels of revenue.

title: Next Week on Retro Report
description: The use of the herbicide Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese. Visit NYTimes.com on Monday for the full story.

title: The Push to Keep the Internet Open
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission dropped the regulatory equivalent of a bombshell last month when he proposed new rules that would allow broadband companies to charge fees to content providers for the delivery of video, and other data to consumers, on a preferential basis.

title: Banksy Emerges From Shadows to Weigh In on Dispute Over Work
description: Banksy, the mercurial street artist, typically keeps clear of the disputes that break out when his graffiti artworks are removed from the walls and doorways where he painted them  and sometimes later sold for enormous prices. But the case of the piece now known as Mobile Lovers  a door-size painting of an embracing couple checking their cellphones behind each others backs, painted on plywood and screwed to a wall  has brought the secretive artist out of hiding for long enough to leave a typed, signed note for one of the pieces potential beneficiaries, the BBC reported.

title: U.N. Report Documents Atrocities by Both Sides in South Sudan War
description: BENTIU, South Sudan  Two weeks after a massacre here, the stench of dead bodies clung to the walls of the Kali-Ballee mosque. Bloodstains marked the ground; shirts, pants and sandals were still scattered about; and torn pages from the Quran were strewn all over the place.

title: Patients Cells Deployed to Attack Aggressive Cancer
description: Doctors have taken an important step toward a long-sought goal: harnessing a persons own immune system to fight cancer.

title: Hal Brooks Will Oversee Pearl Theater Company
description: The Pearl Theater Company, an Off Broadway theater devoted to classic works, announced on Thursday that the director Hal Brooks has become its new artistic director and that he will stage two of the companys productions next season, Chekhovs Uncle Vanya in September and Molires Don Juan in May 2015.

title: Egyptian Tourisms Message to World: Come Anyway
description: CAIRO  Weve missed you, Egypts ministry of tourism says in its new advertising campaign, a plaintive plea for summer visitors from wealthy countries in the Persian Gulf.

title: This Ship Has Sailed
description: Dior invited roughly 900 people to the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Wednesday evening for its cruise collection runway show.

title: Unveiling Diors Cruise Collection
description: The first time I flew on Air France, knuckles paling well in advance per usual, a friend tried to calm me by invoking the comparative chic of the flight attendants. They all have these ... scarves, she said, waving her hands at her throat to indicate the mysterious dexterity of these foreigners.

title: In California, Spigots Start Draining Pockets
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.  The municipal water utility in this city, home to wide beaches, sun-kissed weekend getaways and evocative alternative scholarship, just got tough. Last week it started rationing water  for nonfarmers, the most draconian response to date to Californias debilitating drought.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Double
description: Richard Ayoade narrates a sequence from his film The Double, featuring Jesse Eisenberg.

title: The Case of the Missing Birds at the National Arts Club
description: Not long ago, the National Arts Club was home to dozens of birds, including lovebirds, finches, a Quaker parrot and a raven. They had been acquired by the clubs eccentric president, O. Aldon James Jr., who also collected other animals in the more than century-old club on Gramercy Park, including a chinchilla and a snail discovered by a cook in some corn silk.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: boosting memory, vaccine robots and statin use by women. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Oklahoma, Investigating Failure, Extends Delay of Execution to November
description: Oklahoma on Thursday delayed the execution of Charles F. Warner by six months, to allow time for a review of lethal injection procedures that was started after a bungled execution last week left a prisoner writhing in pain before he died of heart failure.

title: Yankees Will Retire Torres No. 6
description: MILWAUKEE  The Yankees announced Thursday that they would retire the No. 6 worn by the former manager Joe Torre, something they had informally said they would do. They also said that they would put plaques in Monument Park for Goose Gossage, Tino Martinez and Paul ONeill, and that Bernie Williams would be honored in 2015.

title: Richard Ayoade Narrates a Scene From The Double
description: In this video, the director Richard Ayoade narrates a sequence from his film The Double, featuring Jesse Eisenberg as an office worker who encounters his doppelgnger.

title: Enter the Strange City of the Artists Kabakov
description: Each year, on the occasion of the annual art exhibition called Monumenta, the sprawling nave in the Grand Palais in Paris becomes a blank canvas for an internationally-renowned artist. In years past, large-scale installations like Anish Kapoors enormous balloon sculpture and Christian Boltanskis mountain of clothing have filled the room. And this Saturday, the Russian-born, Long Island, N.Y.-based artist couple Ilya and Emilia Kabakov will unveil The Strange City there for the shows sixth iteration, which will be on view through June 22.

title: Hearing Held for Health Services Nominee
description: A Senate committee held a confirmation hearing for Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee to become the next secretary of health and human Services, succeeding Kathleen Sebelius.

title: Last Minutes on Everest
description: Footage captured minutes before Aprils deadly Everest avalanche highlights the Sherpas pride and resilience, which support not only Western expeditions but also the Sherpas families far below.

title: An Afternoon at the Improv
description: There is no falafel on the falafel plate at El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette. This is not an error. What appears instead could be described on the menu (but thankfully isnt) as evanescence of falafel, and may be the most low-key  and satisfying  example of culinary deconstruction in the city.

title: The Making Of | A Camera Bag Designed to Keep Photojournalists Safe
description: The designer Miguel Hurtados a-ha moment took place one afternoon five years ago during a visit to Bahia, in northern Brazil. He was snapping pictures at Carnival when a young boy ran up to him and grabbed his camera. The kid wasnt a thief; he was trying to telegraph a warning to Hurtado that there were some bad guys in the area and that he should put the camera away because he was about to be robbed. Immediately, Hurtado stashed his gear in his potato-shaped canvas Domke, a camera bag that advertises to the world, I am currently in possession of a very expensive camera. Right there I started to wonder, why does a camera bag have to scream luxury? Hurtado recalls. Why does it have to make you a mark?

title: Kellogg Agrees to Alter Labeling on Kashi Line
description: The Kellogg Company, maker of some of the countrys most familiar breakfast cereals, said on Thursday that it had agreed to drop the terms all natural and nothing artificial from some products in its Kashi line as part of a settlement agreement ending a class-action lawsuit.

title: A Case for Rejecting Pfizers Bid for AstraZeneca
description: Bill George is professor of management practice at Harvard Business School, former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic and author of True North, a book about authentic leadership. He serves on the boards of ExxonMobil, Goldman Sachs and the Mayo Clinic. In the past two years, he has taught custom leadership programs at Harvard for AstraZeneca executives and consulted with the company in 2012-13.

title: Why Are American Nuns Under Vatican Scrutiny?
description: The 57,000 American women who are working among the needy as Catholic nuns received some words of encouragement this week from a German cardinal, dubbed the popes theologian because of his close friendship with Pope Francis. I am also considered suspect! Cardinal Walter Kasper, an outspoken liberal church writer, said at Fordham University on Monday. He was alluding to a Vatican investigation into the quality of the life at womens religious institutes  code for Rome-appointed busybodies probing nuns for feminist influences and traces of heresy.

title: A Mothers Instinct, a Daughters Need
description: A little over a decade ago, I made the mistake of taking my mother out to dinner on Mothers Day. The restaurants high ceilings contributed to its poor acoustics, and the servers ran around with a frenetic energy typical of the other days of the year I avoid restaurants, like Valentines Day and New Years Eve. The clanging of dishes interrupted us midsentence, and occasionally, a baby wailed from the other side of the room. It was the type of environment my mother and I avoid with precision, and yet, there we were, regaling in Mothers Day splendor with all the other people who mistakenly felt obligated to eat out.

title: Clip: Rosemarys Baby
description: A scene from Rosemarys Baby, with Zoe Saldana and Patrick J. Adams.

title: Tis Pity Shes a ... Busy Young Professional
description: Perhaps a small Pernod would help. Or maybe a large draft of absinthe?

title: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
description: A photographer is aghast at how her photographs taken in Guinea-Bissau were used  without permission  to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.

title: Man in the Kitchen Is Hungry for Love
description: Food, glorious food! Whatever else it does or doesnt do, Chef, Jon Favreaus good-natured culinary comedy, works as an appetite stimulant. And where theres delicious food  plenty is shown being prepared, served and devoured  theres life.

title: Kurt Masurs Son Named Assistant Conductor in Boston
description: Besides getting a new music director when Andris Nelsons takes up his duties at the start of the 2014-15 season, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will have a new assistant conductor as well. The orchestra announced on Thursday that it had appointed Ken-David Masur to the position. In that capacity Mr. Masur will make his subscription debut during the 2015-16 season, the second year of the two-year position, but he has already led the orchestra in a non-subscription program, at Tanglewood in 2012. On that occasion, he split the conducting tasks with his father, Kurt Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic.

title: The Gun Report: May 8, 2014
description: The attack on prospective smart-gun purveyors continues.

title: Warren Buffett, Joe Nocera and Fessing Up to Readers
description: Mistakes are inevitable. So, too, are newspaper corrections, since newspapers are full of those pesky things known as facts and are produced by human beings, who have a tendency to get things wrong sometimes.

title: Wine Time in Nantucket
description: The warmer weather may still be holding out, but pourers at the Nantucket Wine Festival wont be.

title: A Poker-Faced Nihilist, Stoically Slumming
description: Colson Whiteheads poker memoir, The Noble Hustle, is a throwaway, a bluff, a large bet on a small hand. You can sense that hes half embarrassed to be writing it. His language is so loose and sarcastic that reading it is like watching a guy try to toss playing cards into a hat.

title: House Panel Advances Bill on N.S.A. Collection of Phone Data
description: WASHINGTON  The House Intelligence Committee unanimously passed a bill on Thursday to replace the National Security Agencys program that is systematically collecting bulk records about Americans phone calls.

title: Grand Hotel Reopens, but Only for 4 Nights
description: OVER the last two decades, artworks conceived as participatory events  people eating, sleeping, walking and talking, staring across a table, and doing other real-life things  have become so commonplace in contemporary museums and galleries that a bit of a backlash has set in.

title: Territorial Disputes in the Waters Near China
description: China has recently increased its pursuit of territorial claims in nearby seas, leading to tense exchanges with neighboring countries. A map of some of the most notable disputes.

title: Shamus, Thats the Stuff That Wedgies Are Made Of
description: Noir will become much more than a French vocabulary quiz word for adolescents who see Samantha Spade, Ace Detective: The Case of the Maltball Falcon, at Tada! Youth Theater. This wry new family musical, starring the talented, mostly teenage members of the Tada! ensemble, successfully tackles a challenge that would furrow even Bogies brow: creating a colorful adventure about a black-and-white world that its audience may never have heard of.

title: A Sherpas Final Moments
description: NEW DELHI  The Sherpas setting off up the Khumbu Icefall on the morning of April 18 were young, strong, healthy men. They were also, it is clear from the video that one of them shot that morning, a little nervous.

title: Holding Auditors Accountable on Reports
description: Rolls-Royce  the jet engine maker, not the car company  used estimates and assumptions in its financial results that resulted in mildly cautious profit recognition in an important part of its business. On the other hand, the company was mildly optimistic in other assumptions, resulting in a somewhat lower liability being recorded than might otherwise have been the case.

title: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Labor Market
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a Senate Budget Committee hearing that the long-term labor participation rate had declined substantially.

title: Apollo Seeks a Bigger Role in Europes Banking Sector
description: Barclays pain could be private equitys gain.

title: New Jersey, Once a Rogue State, Is No Longer
description: When it comes to pariah states, some places spring to mind. North Korea. Iran. Syria.

title: Election Commission Votes to Allow Bitcoin Donations
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Election Commission on Thursday voted to allow political committees to accept Bitcoin donations and outlined the ways that the virtual currency can be used by federally regulated campaigns.

title: 12 Ways to Learn Vocabulary With The New York Times
description: One of the winners of our 2017 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest.

title: V.A. Officials Subpoenaed for Inquiry Into Wait List
description: A House committee voted Thursday to subpoena the head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, and other top department officials, stepping up scrutiny of the agency amid allegations that secret waiting lists were used to cover up long delays for doctors appointments.

title: Rauschenberg, Before Fame Struck
description: Scratch an art dealer, and youll often find a curator. Thats the case with Craig Starr, who seems to operate in the secondary art market mainly to support his persistent curatorial itch. For nearly a decade, he has been mounting sharp-focus shows of historical works by prominent American postwar artists in his jewel-box gallery on the Upper East Side.

title: This Time, Tappan Zee Bridge Project Proceeds With Neighbors in Mind
description: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y.  This village on the west bank of the Hudson River has never forgotten the original sin: the destruction six decades ago of more than 100 homes and the communitys entire commercial hub to make way for the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Ingredients of Nerve Agent Still in Syria, Official Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  The last of the chemicals to be shipped out of Syria contain the ingredients needed to make sarin, the lethal nerve agent used in the attack on a Damascus suburb last August, the United Nations official who is coordinating the arsenals destruction saidon Thursday.

title: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
description: A Twitter campaign using the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls has focused global attention on the plight of some 276 Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by the Islamic militant group Boko Haram. Three photos of girls have been posted and reposted thousands of times, including by the BBC and by the singer Chris Brown (who himself has had issues with anger management and violence against women).One problem: The photos are of girls from Guinea-Bissau, more than 1,000 miles from Nigeria, who have no relationship to the kidnappings.

title: Living With Cancer: Careless Care
description: When I consider what happened to an esteemed friend and colleague, I fume at the mayhem that ovarian cancer wreaks and at the deficient care she received at a university hospital in another town. Do instances of medical negligence sometimes go unnoticed because patients are so debilitated that they cannot testify  especially if they are still in treatment?

title: Sothebys Sales Feature a Mondrian and a Bacon
description: Now that the first week of the big spring auctions is over, Sothebys is wasting no time touting its sales in London next month, hanging highlights in its York Avenue galleries for collectors to peruse during the contemporary-art previews this weekend.

title: Ukrainian Separatists to Hold Referendum
description: Pro-Russian separatists in the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Luhansk and Slovyansk said they would hold an independence referendum despite Russian president Vladimir V. Putins request to postpone it.

title: China Presents Its Side in Vietnam Clash
description: Chinese officials offered their side of the story in the dispute with Vietnam over an oil rig operation in the South China Sea.

title: Darkness Visible
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: Cradle of Civil Disobedience
description: At the end of the 19th century, Mohandas Gandhi was a young lawyer living in Durban, South Africa. He left his house in Beach Grove every morning for an office on Mercury Lane, where he spent much of the day helping his fellow Indian immigrants navigate the onerous colonial bureaucracy. He kept meticulous records, including a logbook of correspondence  from an English missionary and local planters, and a series of letters exchanged with the Protector of Indian Immigrants about the treatment of indentured laborers. In January of 1897, and again a few months later, he heard from another lawyer who was, like him, a Gujarati who had studied in England and then struggled to establish a practice in Bombay. The contents of these letters are unknown. In a remarkable new biography, Gandhi Before India, Ramachandra Guha gingerly speculates about what they might have been. Expressions of support for Gandhis nascent activism? Or perhaps explorations of interest in a possible career in South Africa? Guha wisely stops there. What is not in doubt is the name in Gandhis logbook  M. A. Jinnah, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, who would become the founder of Pakistan. All we now know is that, a full 50 years before partition and the independence of India and Pakistan, the respective Fathers of those nations were in correspondence.

title: Recovering From a Short Sale
description: Borrowers who owe more than their homes are worth can sometimes get out from under by negotiating a short sale with their lender. But short-sellers are branded as higher-risk borrowers, so new loans wont come quickly or easily.

title: Pledges of Allegiance
description: Ten days after 9/11, self-professed Texas loud, Texas proud Mark Stroman walked into a Dallas mini-mart, pulled out a gun and asked the brown man working behind the counter where he was from. The hesitation in the clerks reply was enough to unleash Stromans hatred for Muslims, whom he referred to as people with shawls on their face. Stroman pulled the trigger, but his victim, Raisuddin Bhuiyan, an enterprising immigrant from Bangladesh  and a Muslim, indeed  would survive. The other two victims from the fortnights vigilante shooting spree, immigrants from India and Pakistan, would not. So begins Anand Giridharadass The True American, a richly detailed, affecting account of two men bound, as it turned out, by more than just an act of violence.

title: A Surreal Dream, Dark and Deeply Melancholy
description: Christian Rizzo last presented his choreography in New York in 2010, and the afterimage of that ravishing experience, at least for me, remains firmly etched. In b.c, janvier 1545, fontainebleau, Mr. Rizzo created a stark black-and-white landscape in which a series of repetitive angled positions grew into a hypnotic movement meditation for the sleek, high-heeled dancer Julie Guibert. Mr. Rizzo, as an interloper or part of the set, wore a rabbit mask.

title: Sugar, Come Out With Your Hands Up
description: If you are interested in learning the latest on fighting whats called the obesity epidemic, you may want to avoid the Centers for Disease Control and Preventions website. There, in a section about balancing calories (Healthy Weight  its not a diet, its a lifestyle!), amid tips on reducing and exercising, you can read that a calorie is a calorie regardless of its source. The page also features a graphic of a scale with the words calories in and calories out, as if all calories were equal. The American Beverage Association, as it happens, pretty much says the same thing on its website: Quite simply, overweight and obesity are a result of an imbalance between calories consumed and calories burned.

title: With a Change of Heart, California Senate Approves Smartphone Kill Switch Law
description: The California Senate on Thursday voted to approve a state measure requiring smarter antitheft security on smartphones, reversing its decision last month to reject the bill.

title: An Ohio Troupe Returns, With a Boy-Needs-Girl Story and a Rock Stars Songs
description: Are you a fan of Peter Frampton, the British rocker behind such late-20th-century hits as Baby I Love Your Way (1975)? If so, you might fare reasonably well during Hummingbird in a Box, one of three New York premieres that Cincinnati Ballet is presenting at the Joyce Theater. If not, there is unfortunately little to recommend this bafflingly vapid work, choreographed last year by Adam Hougland, the companys resident artist, to a commissioned score by Mr. Frampton. Fandom is key to keeping the viewer afloat.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: On View | Seven More Temporary Art Destinations During Frieze Week in New York
description: The third installation of Frieze New York is the citys main cultural attraction this weekend, but there are also plenty of satellite fairs in Manhattan (and one in Brooklyn) to sate your appetite for art. Below, the top destinations to check out.

title: Glare of a Gilded Age
description: The financial heart of India has long been Mumbai, but it is Delhi, increasingly, that seems to be driven by money, galvanized by it, besotted with it. Delhi is Indias capital. It is where the nations networks of crony capitalism converge, where money seeks license to earn more money. Delhi talks to itself about money  about what money can buy, about the cabinet minister pocketing kickbacks, about the suburban swatch of land that a lawyers untaxed, all-cash fee has purchased and, in near-reverential tones, about the ingenious and illegal ways more money can be made. This last subject, in particular, exercises the citys soul enormously. Delhi is flatulent with greed.

title: Competing Against a Doppelgnger Who Spells Trouble
description: In The Double, Richard Ayoades energetically stylized adaptation of a Dostoyevsky novella, Jesse Eisenberg plays Simon James, a man so unassuming that he barely exists. The security guard at his workplace demands his ID every morning, and a co-worker cheerfully describes poor Simon as a bit of a nonperson, really. His boss (Wallace Shawn) has a vague idea of who he is, as does Hannah (Mia Wasikowska), a fellow employee as well as a neighbor. Simon is hopelessly in love with her, in a creepy way that is also kind of sweet.

title: Wanting a Child in the Worst Way
description: People moving into new apartments in New York City dread brash, nosy neighbors. In Paris, the nightmare next door is more likely to be an elegant, worldly couple with irreproachable manners.

title: Bedeviled Anew by a Pregnancy
description: PARIS  Rosemarys Baby, Roman Polanskis 1968 horror film about a woman impregnated by the devil, may seem somewhat campy in retrospect, but it has influenced scores of filmmakers and spawned innumerable imitators. Now, it has given birth to a remake  set in contemporary Paris, made for television and directed by the esteemed Polish-born director Agnieszka Holland.

title: The Unkindest Cut
description: Some historical events have such utterly catastrophic consequences that no amount of what if counterfactuals can yield a more awful result. World War I, for example, resulted in an enormous number of fatalities, largely entrenched the imperialism that initiated it and paved the way for both Nazism and Stalinism. How could a different path have been worse?

title: Time Warner Sets Date for Time Inc. Spinoff
description: Time Warner has officially approved the spinoff of Time Inc. into a separate company and set a date of June 6 for the transaction to become effective, according to a filing dated Thursday that was made with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Pearls of Regret
description: Saadat Hasan Manto has a good claim to be considered the greatest South Asian writer of the 20th century. In his work, written in Urdu, he incarnated the exuberance, the madness, the alcoholic delirium of his time, when the country he loved cleaved into two and set upon each other, brothers of all religions murdering their infant nephews and raping their sisters-in-law.

title: Communing With an Arctic People
description: This winter was especially rough on a Southern expat like the Miser, whose moods seem perilously pegged to the thermometer. So he can only marvel at the example of the Sami, who have thrived in the Arctic region for centuries, fishing, farming and forging a vibrant culture in spite of the climate.

title: Uneasy Inhabitants
description: One night two summers ago, I was in a car speeding across the border into the eastern Indian state of Bihar. The unlit, pitch-black freeway didnt deter traffic from barreling forward at breakneck speeds. In the inevitable accident, a young man was shredded by a truck. A politician showed up, but instead of taking charge, he distracted the police with laughter and gossip.

title: Heeeeeeres a Tribute From a Tonight Veteran
description: Its no small feat when a performer, without even trying, makes time stand still. But thats what the 86-year-old vocal powerhouse Marilyn Maye did on Tuesday evening at 54 Below, despite abundant evidence that the years are speeding by at the usual breakneck pace.

title: A Glimpse of Lger, a Good Look at Lalique
description: JUST BEFORE LGER

title: Upper West Side Facade Snatchers
description: It goes without saying that Broadway on the Upper West Side is a commercial street, a cacophonic corridor of delis, shoe stores, locksmiths and coffee shops. But what is now a retail strip began with quite different aspirations, as a boulevard of residential refinement, which in the early 1900s certainly meant no stores. Big chain stores and huge garish signage overtook this once domestic idyll after World War I, but in the last two decades the Age of Preservation has brought commerce to heel.

title: Apple Publishes Expanded Report on How It Handles Government Data Requests
description: Apple published a set of guidelines late Wednesday clarifying how, when and why it handles requests from law enforcement or government agencies seeking information about an Apple customer.

title: China Flexes Its Muscles in Dispute With Vietnam
description: BEIJING  Chinas escalating dispute with Vietnam over contested waters in the South China Sea sent new shudders through Asia on Thursday as China demanded the withdrawal of Vietnamese ships near a giant Chinese drilling rig and for the first time acknowledged its vessels had blasted the Vietnamese flotilla with water cannons in recent days.

title: Dior Cruise 2015 Collection
description: Scenes from the Dior cruise 2015 collection photo diary of Olivia Locher.

title: Immigrants Working While They Wait
description: The Department of Homeland Security announced proposed rule changes this week to allow the spouses of some highly skilled temporary workers to hold jobs in the United States, and to remove some of the obstacles that make it difficult for some groups of highly skilled workers to remain here.

title: Putting a Face on Pinot Blanc
description: If it were possible to probe the collective consciousness of wine drinkers for their impressions of pinot blanc, you would be left with little of consequence. Few love it, few hate it, few give it much thought. Its not the dominant grape in any particular region. An even closer examination reveals pinot blanc to be a phantom grape and wine, a cipher that offers few answers but raises many questions.

title: Model-Morphosis | Harleth Kuusik at Dior Cruise 2015 Collection
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captured a transformation of the Dior Cruise 2015 collection in New York. Here, the model Harleth Kuusik before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Phillips and hair by Guido Palau.

title: Letters: Forcing the Spring
description: Forcing the Spring

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Venezuela, Pakistan and Brazil.

title: What Comes of Reading Far Too Many Novels
description: We will not anticipate the past! Our retrospection will be all to the future!

title: A Teenage Tone Poem, Balancing Fear With Rash Impulses
description: The kids in Gia Coppolas Palo Alto move as through a dream. Its a drifty, appealing story, set in the Northern California city that gives the movie its title, about that twilight period between childhoods end and the start of young adulthood. Here, under wavering palm trees, teenagers slip through homes and streets with the vagueness that comes with certain visions of adolescence. These arent the tireless achievers cramming for tests, and preparing for college and the conformity to come. They are instead the anxious children who have  since the likes of Holden Caulfield and James Deans rebel  defined American adolescence as a state of poetic confusion.

title: Districts Told Not to Deny Students Over Immigration
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and Education Secretary Arne Duncan issued a strong warning on Thursday to public school districts nationwide not to deny enrollment to immigrant students in the country illegally.

title: Winklevoss Twins to List Bitcoin Fund on Nasdaq
description: Despite cautions and hesitations among regulators about investing in virtual currency, the Winklevoss twins are inching closer to creating the first publicly traded Bitcoin fund.

title: Theater Listings for May 9-15
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Frieze, and Other Fairs That Tag Along
description: Frieze New York is the axis of the art world through Monday. But the city is teeming with satellite fairs this weekend that cater to the seasoned collector and curious novice alike. Most run Friday through Sunday, with times subject to change, so check websites. There are often discounts for seniors and students.

title: Gathering of Far-Flung Friends, and Trends
description: Within the commercial realms of art, the New Art Dealers Alliance, known as NADA, has earned its good reputation. Founded as a nonprofit in 2002 with the conviction that the adversarial approach to exhibiting and selling art has run its course, it even has a cool name. (What are you doing this weekend? NADA.)

title: This Weekend: Million-Dollar Art on Sale
description: View million-dollar art for sale at one of New Yorks auction houses, visit a minimalist retrospective upstate or listen to the new albums of some 90s music stars.

title: Unorthodox, Maybe, but Scarcely on the Fringe
description: The Outsider Art Fair has officially outgrown its name. Once held in a Midtown office building during the doldrums of January, it relocated last year to the far more visible Center 548 in Chelsea, the former home of Dia Art Foundation, and also started a Paris edition. And this year, the show occupies a plum spot on the calendar, participating in the glut of early-May events known as Frieze Week  a high holiday for the New York art world, as Andrew Edlin, the art dealer and organizer of Outsider Art, writes in his introduction to the catalog.

title: Songs Assembled From Bravado
description: The costumes were almost as loud as the music when Tune-Yards performed at Rough Trade Records on Wednesday night. Merrill Garbus, the Oakland, Calif.-based songwriter who records as Tune-Yards, was in a dress that was part red vinyl, part patterned turquoise fabric and part gold lam, along with high sequined boots. Her band members were in a mlange of brightly colored, clashing patterns, not to mention the fluorescent face paint. Ms. Garbus also had a streak of glitter under one eye.

title: This Weekend: Million-Dollar Art for Sale
description: In the Video

title: Spare Times for Children for May 9-15
description: MEET THE MUSIC! INSPECTOR PULSES MOTHER

title: Promises That Can Bend Without Breaking
description: In December my wife and I moved out of our house into an independent-living apartment. Walking through the building, you might take it for a well-kept hotel, until you notice the handrails lining the hallways, the nursing assistants in the common areas and the people pushing walkers in front of them rather than pulling luggage carts behind them. The average resident is close to 80 years old.

title: The Ghost of a City
description: As rebels in Syria abandon the Old City of Homs this week, little but rubble is left behind.

title: Spare Times for May 9-15
description: New York Bicycle Jumble (Saturday) On the heels  or wheels  of last weekends TD Five Boro Bike Tour, this stationary event in Park Slope, Brooklyn, will set cyclists hearts racing in a different way. For the sixth year, buyers can browse new and used bicycles and accessories, as well as clothing, collectibles and other items offered by vendors from across the country. Guests can talk shop with representatives from the Bicycle Messenger Foundation; the environmental organization Times Up!; and We Bike NYC, a biking group for women. They can even take a potential purchase out for a spin. (This is the first of three such planned events in Brooklyn; the others will be in Red Hook on June 1 and Park Slope in the fall.) From 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Old Stone House at Washington Park, Third Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues; nybikejumble.com; free. Squeaky wheels are welcome. (Anne Mancuso)

title: Concertos as Sounds of Spring
description: Young Concert Artists, which has been fostering the careers of gifted musicians since 1961, mostly presents the winners of its auditions in recitals, including a popular series in New York. But it has become a spring tradition for this essential organization to present a gala concert featuring select winners from recent years in concerto performances. Hearing young musicians in concertos reveals further dimensions of their artistry.

title: Close, if Not Really Antiques and Not a Road Show
description: ROBERT JAFFE will be one of probably more than 2,000 people lined up on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History with a mysterious object in hand.

title: Open House Etiquette
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: India Explains Itself
description: This week we review several new books on the Indian subcontinent. The last decade has seen a bounty of vital writing both from and about the region. Suketu Mehtas Maximum City, a dense, fast-paced account of life in Mumbai, published in 2004, was arguably the advance scout of this movement. In an email interview, Mehta said the boom in the country explaining itself to itself is due to a few significant factors: Publishers can make money off it (my own book continues to sell well in India, a decade after it came out), the rise of English speakers (20 percent of the population) and the huge crowds at literary festivals like the one in Jaipur.

title: The Venting Process
description: I was in a store today, and two people were served before me  out of turn. It happened so quickly, I didnt say anything; they were already in the middle of their orders. When I got back to my car, I told my husband how annoyed I was. He said, Maybe you should speak up for yourself. This made me doubly annoyed, and I lost my temper with him. Ive asked him many times not to give me advice unless I ask for it. Now Im asking for yours.

title: Apple Said to Be in Talks to Buy Rising Music Brand for $3.2 Billion
description: Apple is in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, according to people briefed on the talks, in what would be the biggest acquisition in Apples history.

title: A Chance to Embrace Your Inner Katniss
description: IT is oddly satisfying to discover that, without question, you would be the first person to die in the Hunger Games.

title: A Cultural History of Civil Rights
description: A recent book chronicles the artistic and cultural efforts that were an essential  if overlooked  part of the civil rights movement.

title: Comedy Listings for May 9-15
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hurricane Stress Linked to Stillbirths
description: Hurricanes Katrina and Rita significantly increased the number of stillbirths in the Louisiana parishes most affected by the storms, new research suggests.

title: Cracking a Safe of Painful Memories
description: Paging Dr. Freud? Alex (Jesse Johnson), the haunted, aerosol-huffing antihero of Chapman, works as a locksmith. Every lock has a bypass, a cheat, he explains to an angry landlord before showing him a foolproof method: kicking in the door.

title: Peter Brook: The Tightrope
description: Part 3: The director talks about his use of the tightrope concept in guiding actors through the crucial elements of performance.

title: Peter Brook: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the theater and film director Peter Brook.

title: Peter Brook: A Wretched Word
description: Part 5: The director explains why he thinks the word directing is a poor description for what a director really does.

title: TimesTalks | Peter Brook: Preview
description: The legendary theater and film director talks about his distinguished career, the documentary Peter Brook: The Tightrope, and his upcoming projects.

title: Peter Brook: The Beginners Mind
description: Part 4: The director reflects on the link between a performers body and imagination.

title: Peter Brook: The Funniest Man in London
description: Part 2: The director explains what he wanted to accomplish with the film Peter Brook: The Tightrope.

title: Peter Brook: A Play Must Be Alive
description: Part 6: The director speaks about why he thinks play revivals do not need to recreate the conditions in which the play was originally performed.

title: Peter Brook: Freedom in the Cinema
description: Part 10: The director reflects on why and how he became disillusioned by filmmaking.
