title: Peter Brook: Valley of Astonishment
description: Part 9: The director discusses the research and process behind his upcoming play, The Valley of Astonishment.

title: Peter Brook: Through Fire and Water
description: Part 8: The director explores the complex mental and physical work he does with actors.

title: Peter Brook: The Suit
description: Part 7: The director discusses his production of the play The Suit, and what drew him to direct a theatrical adaptation of the South African short story.

title: Peter Brook: Can Opener
description: Part 11: The director discusses whether he thinks its acceptable for actors to use their own memories and experiences in a performance.

title: Peter Brook: The Bowl Exercise
description: Part 12: The director describes a test that demonstrates the difference between actors and non-actors.

title: Peter Brook: Marat/Sade
description: Part 13: The director reminisces about the circumstances that led to his iconic theater and film productions of Marat/Sade.

title: Peter Brook: The Kali Yuga
description: Part 14: The director reflects on what he thinks a world in crisis demands of artists.

title: Movie Listings for May 9-15
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Not Your Typical Playboy Project
description: The May issue of Playboy features a special section that you find by flipping the magazine upside down and reading from the back. These pages, called the Playboy A-Z special edition, have a different look from the rest of the magazine and feature photographs by such art-world luminaries as Marilyn Minter, Ryan McGinley, Ralph Gibson, Jeff Burton and many others, several of whom have shot for The New York Times Magazine. But in one important way, they look like the usual Playboy issue: The women are naked.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 9-15
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for May 9-15
description: Jazz

title: A Plea to Let Those Waters Flow
description: A stirring argument against dams can be made by the outdoors itself: the rivers, trees, wildlife and vibrant contours of an organically forged landscape. DamNation begins with such images of nature, often artfully framed, and returns to them as well as to some beautifully fine-grained archival photography. But this documentary (which was funded by the outdoor apparel company Patagonia) also lumps together its grievances and interviews in a way that feels scattered and geared toward those inclined to agree.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 9-15
description: Art

title: Dance Listings for May 9-15
Debating the Merits of Nuclear Power
A.B.A.s Vetting of Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle Against Polio
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bottomless Cup of Coffee. Really.
description: It is safe to say that many New Yorkers who drink coffee drink it in bulk. Cups, an Israeli app that has just been introduced in the city, aims to capitalize on that.

title: When Cost Deters Care
description: To the Editor:

title: College Students Today
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lesson in Forgiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for May 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Three Boys Entangled in Mass Hysteria
description: The question is why. Why would the gifted Canadian filmmaker Atom Egoyan choose to make Devils Knot, a feature film about a notorious unsolved 1993 murder case that has been exhaustively investigated in several well-regarded documentaries?

title: At Odds, Omnicom and Publicis End Merger
description: The ad giants Omnicom Group and Publicis Groupe called off their $35 billion merger on Thursday, bringing a premature end to a deal that would have created the largest advertising company in the world.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 9, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on Neighbors, Palo Alto and Chef.

title: Barcelona in Brooklyn
description: In the Barcelona neighborhood of El Born, home to creative types and the people who love them, is there a stylish American bistro called Greenpoint?

title: What Housing Recovery?
description: LOS ANGELES  RECENTLY theres been a lot of happy talk about the nations housing recovery. Frequent reports about rising prices suggest that the tens of millions of people whose homes lost value just have to wait until the recovery reaches their neighborhood to lift them out of crisis. But this supposed housing recovery is bypassing many of our cities and towns.

title: Young Hands Steering the Family Tractor
description: Bad behavior is pretty rare in our industry, one of the six young farmers profiled in Farmland tells us. Though he doesnt elaborate, his comments lack of detail and depth is typical of a film that plays more like a feature-length advertisement than like a documentary. You keep expecting the camera to zoom in on a packet of bacon or a box of cereal.

title: Can the Kochs Hold Back History?
description: For a time, the press lord William Randolph Hearst did everything in his vast powers to keep the film Citizen Kane from finding an audience. He intimidated theater owners, refused to let ads run in his newspapers, and even pressured studio sycophants to destroy the negative.

title: Another Tech Company Finds the F.T.C. Looking Over Its Shoulder
description: Updated, 8:42 p.m. |

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: RadioShack Pulls Back on Size of Store Closings
description: RadioShack said on Thursday that it could not come to an agreement with its lenders that would allow it to close 1,100 of its stores, although it said it would still shutter a number of outlets as part of its plan to turn around the struggling company.

title: Forget Benghazi. Clintons Real Problem Is Obama Fatigue.
description: The latest investigation into the Benghazi attack reminds us that the issue isnt going away any time soon. Pundits are already speculating about potential damage to Hillary Clintons presidential prospects, but dont believe the hype: Scandals rarely matter much in presidential election campaigns.

title: First a Killing, Then a Code of Silence
description: The occasional narrator of Gods Pocket is a Philadelphia newspaper columnist and Jimmy Breslin type who is the beloved voice of the citys blue collar class. Describing the residents of the rough, seedy South Philadelphia neighborhood that gives the movie its name, this local celebrity, Richard (Richard Jenkins), muses out loud with barbed affection: Everyone here has stolen something from someone else, or when they were kids, they set someones house on fire. They know who cheats at cards and who slaps their kids around. The one thing they cant forgive is not being from Gods Pocket.

title: In Mexico, a Rail Line Splits a City and Views
description: EL PASO  When Csar Duarte, the governor of the Mexican state of Chihuahua, announced last week that the government wanted to move the railroad tracks that pass through Ciudad Jurez out of the heart of the city, Cristina Jimnez knew that the battle had only begun.

title: Agreeing to Disagree on States Future Water Needs
description: How much more water will Texas really need by 2060?

title: Now Thats Rich
description: Institutional Investors latest rich list in its Alpha magazine, its survey of the 25 highest-paid hedge fund managers, is out  and it turns out that these guys make a lot of money. Surprise!

title: Wicked Witch Is Dead, but Here Comes a Jester
description: The maps included with many Oz books promised bookish completists that there was always another little corner of this flip-side world to explore. That sense of imagination is largely absent from Legends of Oz: Dorothys Return, a second-rate animated adaptation of a spinoff by Roger Stanton Baum, L. Frank Baums great-grandson. Still, the films set-piece journey through China Country, ruled over by a tiny, haughty, porcelain princess (a delightful Megan Hilty), is a highlight, the picture of a self-absorbed royal hamlet with its own rules and wigs.

title: In Dealings on Syria, Security Council Exposes Its Failings
description: UNITED NATIONS  Since the beginning of the year, the Security Council has discussed Syria no fewer than 18 times and devoted 13 more sessions to Ukraine.

title: Intelligence Policy Bans Citation of Leaked Material
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is clamping down on a technique that government officials have long used to join in public discussions of well-known but technically still-secret information: citing news reports based on unauthorized disclosures.

title: Dads Watching Us? Call Social Services
description: Seldom has wackiness been as tedious as it is in Moms Night Out, a Christian-themed film that is desperate to make adherents seem wild and crazy but mostly makes them seem incapable of raising children.

title: Lost in Crowd, Manziel Slips to 22nd
description: The record-setting quarterback out of Texas A&M, the one with the household nickname, the Heisman Trophy, the golden arm, the hyper-quick legs, the ability to attract attention and controversy like flypaper, was trying to hide the fact that his face was flushed.

title: 17 Human Rights Groups Urge Palestinians to Join World Court
description: A group of 17 human rights organizations including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International on Thursday urged President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to promptly join the International Criminal Court, a move strongly opposed by Israel and the United States. Palestinian leaders have said the court would be the last of the 63 international organizations, treaties and conventions it might join as part of a new strategy to leverage the observer-state status they won at the United Nations in 2012. Many Palestinians and their supporters say the court could prosecute Israel for building Jewish settlements in the West Bank and demolishing Palestinian homes there; legal experts have warned that joining the court could also expose Palestinians themselves to prosecution for war crimes.

title: Obama to Give Push on Climate
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will announce on Friday a handful of executive actions and private and nonprofit groups investments in energy efficiency and renewable energy.

title: Events in New Jersey for May 11-17, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Dow Jones Acting Chief Is Given Job Permanently
description: William Lewis, who has served as acting chief executive of News Corporations Dow Jones division since January, has been named its permanent chief, the company announced on Thursday.

title: A Coup by Another Name in Thailand
description: A decision by Thailands highest court to remove Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra from office is almost sure to send the country deeper into crisis. Pro- and antigovernment groups are already massing for more protests that will further divide the polarized country and further disrupt an already weak economy.

title: Clip: Stage Fright
description: A musical scene from Stage Fright, directed by Jerome Sable.

title: Pfizers Plan to Go to London Spurs Other Companies to Consider Moving Abroad
description: Pfizers attempt to escape the United States corporate tax rate by acquiring a British drug maker has set off a flurry of activity in other big companies across the country, at investment banks on Wall Street and in offices on Capitol Hill.

title: How to Fix the Mortgage Market
description: In the credit bubble of the last decade, the housing market essentially became a tool of the financial system. To sate the banks demand for mortgage-related securities, many loans were made not on the basis of sound lending standards but on the unsound premise that house prices would rise forever  a practice that led to the bust and to the bailouts of Wall Street and of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the federally backed mortgage companies.

title: Recalled Used Cars Roam the Roads as Federal Legislation Stalls
description: David Clayton was driving 70 miles an hour in his Ram 1500 pickup truck last October when he learned the hard way that it had a serious safety problem. The rear axle locked up, causing him to nearly lose control before wrestling the truck to the side of the highway.

title: More Tales of the Righteous
description: Trying to shed light on the darkness of human suffering, Michael Kings The Rescuers travels across Europe to chronicle the actions of those who saved Jews during World War II. While the documentary marshals an impressive array of survivors and visits several international locations, it grindingly adheres to an unwieldy tour-style presentation, with more than a few rough spots and, at times, an unpolished look.

title: Bernie Goes Home With Director
description: CARTHAGE, Tex.  Richard Linklater could not have imagined a more bizarre final scene for Bernie, the dark comedy film he directed, than the one that unfolded Tuesday in East Texas. After nearly two decades behind bars, the convicted killer on whom the movie was based was driven away from the jail (by Mr. Linklater no less) to a home in Central Texas owned by  you guessed it  Mr. Linklater.

title: Center Ring at the Republican Circus
description: The hottest competition in Washington this week is among House Republicans vying for a seat on the Benghazi kangaroo court, also known as the Select House Committee to Inflate a Tragedy Into a Scandal. Half the House has asked to serve on the committee, which is understandable since its the perfect opportunity to avoid any real work while waving frantically to right-wing voters stomping their feet in the grandstand.

title: Simmons Spends Big on Star Power
description: THE Simmons Bedding Company will introduce two new celebrity-driven advertising campaigns this month, in which Dr. Andrew Weil, an alternative-medicine expert, will endorse the ComforPedic iQ mattress, and the actor and auto racer Patrick Dempsey will promote the Beautyrest Black.

title: Despite Orders, Federal Tank-Car Safety Measures Are Slow in Coming
description: The derailment of a freight train carrying crude oil in Lynchburg, Va., last week was a reminder that basic safety features of the oil-by-rails business remain vastly inadequate, despite a flurry of emergency orders by federal regulators.

title: After Barclays, a Former Chief Strives to Revive His Reputation in Africa
description: When Barclays announced on Thursday that it planned to slash the size and scope of its investment bank, the British effectively halted a long campaign to become a true Wall Street powerhouse, one to rival Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase.

title: Some High Notes Are Just Screams
description: The Canadian musical comedy Stage Fright unveils its lone showstopping number early on, as a bus full of kids pulls into theater camp: the one place they arent outcasts. As a sad sack sings of being beaten up a dozen times for singing Stephen Sondheims rhymes, the film offers a glimpse of exactly the sort of demented, toe-tapping sensibility youd expect from a tuneful summer camp farce  in which a serial killer is on the loose.

title: Ugly Words From North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After President Obama and South Koreas president, Park Geun-hye, warned North Korea of harsher sanctions if it continued pursuing nuclear weapons, the North has responded with harsh invective against both leaders.

title: Massachusetts Pushes Fix for State Health Exchange
description: BOSTON  The board of the broken Massachusetts health insurance exchange voted on Thursday to support a state plan to buy new software to help people enroll in coverage, while also preparing to join the federal marketplace if the system is not ready by fall.

title: Marijuana Trade Offered Credit Relief in Colorado
description: DENVER  Seeking to move its growing marijuana industry away from the risk of using only cash, Colorado finalized plans this week to create the nations first financial cooperatives for the marijuana trade. But few expect the effort to gain the necessary approval of Federal Reserve officials leery of offering banking services to companies that grow and sell a federally controlled substance.

title: Venezuela Arrests 243 in Raids on Antigovernment Protest Camps
description: Security forces arrested 243 people in Caracas on Thursday as they dismantled four protest camps set up in the Venezuelan capital by demonstrators opposed to the government of President Nicols Maduro, and a policeman was fatally shot in clashes that followed, officials said.

title: The Theater of Tough Beginnings
description: For everyone who played pretend as a youth, who concocted elaborate stories of homemaking, piracy or other adventure without needing the rules of basketball or Capture the Flag, something about the Cambodian documentary Still I Strive may touch you.

title: Instant Jerseys for N.F.L. Draft Picks
description: Since 2012 the N.F.L. has added a special touch to draft day: It personalizes the jersey given to each first-round selection.

title: Politics Seen in Cuban Accusations of Military Plot by Miami Men
description: MIAMI  There was a time not all that long ago that Santiago Alvarez, a Miami developer, fantasized about swinging an automatic weapon over his shoulder and heading back to Cuba to incite an uprising.

title: Personalizing Jerseys of Top N.F.L. Picks Is a Race Against the Clock
description: The first-round picks that attend draft day at Radio City Music Hall have plenty of reasons to smile: instant renown, multimillion-dollar contracts, the dream job.

title: The Real Africa
description: In 2005, Binyavanga Wainaina published a brilliantly sarcastic essay in Granta called How to Write About Africa, advising people on how to sound spiritual and compassionate while writing a book about the continent.

title: Obama Addresses the Limits of Using Power in Syria and Nigeria
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  As President Obama hopscotched the California coast this week on a fund-raising trip for Democratic candidates and other causes, he used one of the glittering events to offer a candid meditation on the powers of the presidency and its limits.

title: Regulator Suggests End to Banks Self-Grading
description: Self-grading has obvious limitations in education. Now, a senior regulator at the Federal Reserve wants to banish it from bank regulation.

title: All the Way to 2032, Come What May
description: Eighteen years ago, there was no certainty that we would be watching sports and movies on little mobile screens or that outfits like Netflix would engage us by streaming series a season at a time.

title: Compromise on Gays Pleases No One, Scouts Are Learning
description: SEATTLE  Pascal Tessier is a 17-year-old Eagle Scout in suburban Maryland who says scouting made him who he is today, with its lessons about morality, leadership and responsibility. And those very strengths, this openly gay high school senior said, are what compel and equip him to fight back now against Scout policies on gays that he believes are wrong.

title: Oscar Murillo: A Mercantile Novel
description: David Zwirner Gallery

title: Sherrie Levine: Red Yellow Blue
description: Paula Cooper

title: Dona Nelson: Phigor
description: Thomas Erben Gallery

title: Jackie Saccoccio
description: Eleven Rivington

title: Sterlings Wife Asserts Her Ownership Share
description: The Los Angeles Clippers co-owner Rochelle Sterling vowed to retain her 50 percent share of the franchise as the N.B.A. continued its push to oust her husband, Donald, who was barred from the league for life last month for making racist comments on a recording.

title: Robert Kinmont: trying to return home educated
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: Rather Than Buzz, the Nets Garner a Ho-Hum
description: MIAMI  Whatever drama may have been building between the Nets and the Miami Heat abruptly faded in the fourth quarter on Thursday night, and perhaps even died in the deep left corner at American Airlines Arena.

title: California: Agreement on Rainy Day Fund
description: Gov. Jerry Brown and state legislative leaders reached a deal Thursday to place a revised plan for a rainy-day fund on the ballot this fall; it would create a cushion against future economic downturns and allow the state to use extra cash to pay down long-term debt. Mr. Brown, who is running for his fourth term this fall, has been pushing for the measure, which he says is the only way to bolster the states finances for the long term. Under the plan, spikes in money collected from capital gains taxes would be diverted to the fund, with some money set aside for debt payments on pensions. The Legislature would also be required to set aside 1.5 percent of general revenue for the fund each year, and money could be withdrawn from the fund only if overall revenue did not meet historic spending levels. The Legislature is expected to approve the proposal next week so that the measure can be placed on the November ballot.

title: Digs in the Snow
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well, lookee here; a Friday puzzle that almost looks like it might have a theme. Its a 68-worder, but take a gander at those long, horizontal entries. I looked at the blank grid before solving and thought, Huh. A rule breaker.

title: Rangers Recent Struggles Start With the Top Skaters
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Less than a week ago, the Rangers were reveling in a 3-2 overtime victory in Game 1 against the Penguins in Pittsburgh. Penguins goaltender Marc-Andre Fleury was turning into his erratic postseason self, and the Rangers top scorers appeared close to a breakthrough.

title: At His Trial, Imam Tells of Losing His Forearms
description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, the imam on trial on terrorism-related charges, had long been known for the metal hooks he wore as prostheses on his arms after losing his forearms and an eye in an explosion. But how that explosion occurred has been the subject of dispute and even myth.

title: A Vote Against Violence for Indian Women
description: After a brutal gang rape in New Delhi, something changed in India. But maybe not a lot for the countrys politicians. For Nasreen Jahan, the fight for justice in this election season is personal.

title: Wild Have a Carousel in Goal, but Not a Turnstile
description: ST. PAUL  The oddest day in the Minnesota Wilds season of goaltending oddities may have been March 31.

title: Hachette Says Amazon Is Delaying Delivery of Some Books
description: Amazon has begun discouraging customers from buying books by Malcolm Gladwell, Stephen Colbert, J. D. Salinger and other popular writers, a flexing of its muscle as a battle with a publisher spills into the open.

title: Big City Book Club
description: Brooklyn today is a destination for celebrities and wealthy creative types, but not so long ago it was the default settlement for young immigrants without money. When the Big City Book Club convenes next, well be reading Colm Toibins acclaimed 2009 novel, Brooklyn, the story of a young Irishwoman who leaves a fragile mother behind to find herself in Dodgerland in the early 1950s. Brooklyn College and the Fulton Mall both make appearances in a book that explores the conflict between familial obligation and ones own youthful heart and promise. The online discussion will take place on Monday, May 19, starting at 6:30 p.m.

title: Times Minute | Car Recall Controversy
description: Also on the Minute, rising tensions in the South China Sea and the longevity of Snapchats.

title: Times Minute | Car Recall Controversy
description: In the Video

title: Deadly Illness in Nicaragua Baffles Experts
description: CHICHIGALPA, Nicaragua  During the harvest season, when exhausted workers spend seven days a week cutting sugar cane, the signs of illness were hard to spot at first.

title: For Yankees Tanaka, Batters Box Is Anything but Home
description: MILWAUKEE  Masahiro Tanakas split-finger fastball, slider and two-seamer, as well as his tenacity, have combined to make him a rookie sensation for the Yankees. But Tanaka struggles in one aspect of baseball.

title: Garca Clears His Mind, Then the Water, at the Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The 17th hole at TPC Sawgrass was as tranquil as a yoga studio Thursday morning when Sergio Garcas group reached the tee box. The wind was negligible and relatively few fans were on hand to pan or praise shots. The only stress on the players was self-induced.

title: Schoolgirl Abductions Put Scrutiny on U.S. Terrorism Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The abduction of more than 200 schoolgirls in Nigeria has led to new scrutiny of the United States counterterrorism strategy toward Boko Haram during Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure as secretary of state.

title: Coming Off Rout, Nets Adjust but Are Left Adrift
description: MIAMI  As the racket inside the arena rose to an earsplitting volume late Thursday night, Kevin Garnett hit his palms softly together and stared down at the floor. He burrowed his chin into his chest, bending his neck at what looked like a 90-degree angle.

title: Documents on Long-Term Care
description: The goal was cost savings, but the states sweeping changes in Medicaid spending on long-term services set off a stampede in recent years by managed care companies for low-risk, high-profit enrollees.

title: Medicaid Shift Fuels Rush for Profitable Clients
description: When Hurricane Sandy flooded two adult homes in Queens, hundreds of disabled, elderly or mentally ill residents were caught in the surge. After weeks in public shelters, they were bused, over their objections, to a dilapidated four-story building called Kings Hotel, in a crime-ridden section of Brooklyn.

title: Alleging Bias, Employees Sue School Official in Westchester
description: If the claims in a federal lawsuit brought by a principal, four teachers and three other school employees are accurate, the superintendent of the Greenburgh Central School District in Westchester County repeatedly disparaged his staff with bigoted terms, whether they were black or white, Jewish or Muslim, male or female, gay or heterosexual.

title: Newark Mayoral Race Seen as Referendum on Booker
description: NEWARK  One is a municipal councilman and high school principal, son of a celebrated and controversial black poet, who negotiated a truce among this citys gangs and urged them to fight a white conspiracy and seize power, block by block, city by city, place by place.

title: Giants Add a Weapon for Manning
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants fans saw Eli Manning flailing and failing throughout most of the 2013 season. The Giants brain trust apparently saw the same thing.

title: Jets Select a Safety From Louisville
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Divining the Jets draft objectives under General Manager John Idzik has become an annual guessing game, as much because of his guarded approach as the state of their roster. It is more likely that a magician would reveal the secret to his tricks than Idzik would divulge a hint about his intentions for a team that, despite a strong finish to last season, very much remains in transition.

title: Cuomo and Panel He Shut Differ on Its Independence
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has long cast himself as the man who would clean up Albany,offered a blunt defense last month to suggestions that his office had interfered with an anticorruption panel the governor formed last year, then shut down abruptly in March in exchange for enhancements to state ethics laws.

title: Q & A: M. Taylor Fravel on Chinas Dispute With Vietnam
description: The long-simmering territorial dispute between China and Vietnam in the South China Sea had one of its periodic eruptions this week, as Vietnamese vessels confronted Chinese ships that are trying to place an oil rig near the disputed Paracel Islands and off Vietnams coast. The rig is run by China National Offshore Oil Corporation, or Cnooc, and lies just 120 nautical miles off the main coastline of Vietnam. Chinese ships have fired water cannons at the Vietnamese vessels, and both sides have said their ships have been rammed by opposing forces. The Chinese military fought with units from South Vietnam over the southern Paracels in 1974, which led to China taking over the islands, though they remain uninhabited.

title: Key Figure in Fire Department After 9/11 Is to Return as Commissioner
description: Daniel A. Nigro, a former New York City fire official who was thrust into the command of rescue operations on Sept. 11, 2001, when the chief of department was killed by falling debris, will be named the Fire Departments new commissioner, two city officials said.

title: Two Cases of Violence, and a Question About the Severity of the Charges
description: Just before midnight last Tuesday, Robert Borrelli stopped for a light on a corner in the village of Pelham, just north of the Bronx. With him was Joseph Felice, a teammate on an adult hockey team in New Rochelle that had just won a semifinal match. They had reached that quiet corner of Westchester County at that precise instant because their game started after 10 p.m., and its length was determined by a combination of whistles and penalties and icing calls.

title: Suspect Sought in Brooklyn and Queens Hammer Attacks
description: The police are searching for a man who they believe has attacked three commuters with a hammer during robberies in Brooklyn and Queens over the past two months.

title: Council Committee Approves Expansion by Rockefeller University
description: Rockefeller University, a biomedical research institute and graduate school on the East Side of Manhattan, received approval on Thursday from a City Council committee for an expansion that would include building a platform over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: India Election Digest: May 9
description: What you need to know on Friday about Indias elections: You cant escape talk of politics in Varanasi, the Bharatiya Janata Party leaders are accusing the Election Commission of bias, and the leaders of the two main national parties mention alliance possibilities.

title: The River With Hugh Jackman, Is Set for October Opening
description: Hugh Jackmans next Broadway play, Jez Butterworths The River, will begin performances on Oct. 31 at Circle in the Square Theater, the producers announced on Thursday night.

title: Twitter Insiders Sell After Lockup Expires
description: Twitters stock took a beating on Tuesday, the first day that employees and early investors in the company could freely sell their shares after Twitters initial public offering in November.

title: The Art of Eating
description: The congenial lunchtime ritual of breaking bread with others is becoming a rarity, replaced by snacking on the go or in front of a computer. For a few artists, the midday meal is a chance to bring everyone to the table for pleasure and conversation.

title: Tribal Beauty
description: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing the arts.

title: Word of the Day | mnemonic
description: mnemonic\ni-m-nik\ adjective and noun

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 8, 2014
Woman Hit and Killed by School Bus Carrying Children
description: A school bus carrying young children struck and killed a woman Thursday afternoon at a busy, construction-narrowed intersection on the Upper East Side, the authorities said.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) THE SILK ROAD ENSEMBLE WITH YO-YO MA: LIVE FROM TANGLEWOOD This documentary follows Mr. Ma, the cellist, above, and his group  musicians, composers and performing artists from more than 20 countries  onstage and behind the scenes as they celebrate their 15th anniversary with a concert, taped last summer, at the music festival in western Massachusetts. The interaction between the musicians, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times when the ensemble played at Carnegie Hall in October, turns any performance into a visual spectacle.

title: Billy Frank Jr., 83, Defiant Fighter for Native Fishing Rights
description: The crime was fishing. The year was 1945. The boy was 14. It was his first offense, but it would not be his last.

title: William Ash, Danger-Loving Escape Artist, Dies at 96
description: After his Spitfire was shot down over France in the spring of 1942, William Ash made his way to Nazi-occupied Paris with the help of the Resistance. His plan was to go to Spain, then on to England to resume flying. While waiting, he sauntered through Parisian streets as a tourist, visiting the Louvre and the zoo, dining out and swimming daily.

title: Communist Party Newspaper Denounces Detained Lawyer
description: A commentary in a Communist Party-run newspaper has criticized the prominent civil rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang, who was detained in Beijing this week ahead of the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests. The article in the newspaper, Global Times, said that Mr. Pu had clearly crossed the red line of law by attending a meeting to commemorate the 1989 protest movement.

title: Maria Lassnig, Painter of Self From the Inside Out, Dies at 94
description: Maria Lassnig, an Austrian painter whose fierce devotion to self-portraiture  in lacerating, darkly funny, often grotesque ways  led her through decades of obscurity to a celebrated late-flowering career, died on Tuesday in Vienna. She was 94.

title: Corrections: May 9, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: South Koreas Leader and Media Face Scrutiny Over Ferry Disaster
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Parents of high school students killed in the South Korean ferry disaster marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in central Seoul on Friday, as prosecutors tightened their investigative noose around an enigmatic family that controls the operator of the doomed ferry.

title: The Coming Home of Zhang Yimou and Gong Li
description: Coming Home, a new film by Zhang Yimou about the ravages wrought on a family by decades of political violence in China and how they (kind of) overcome them, stars Gong Li, his legendary muse. It made Steven Spielberg cry, the Chinese news media reported. Ang Lee, the Academy Award-winning director of Life of Pi, was very moved by it too, he said on Chinese television.

title: Swedish Payments Processor Raises $55 Million
description: LONDON  The electronic payments start-up Square may be facing problems in the United States, but a European rival is trying to prove that theres still a future for the mobile payments industry.

title: Denials Follow Latest Report on New Delhis Pollution
description: In the World Health Organizations recent report on air pollution, New Delhi ranks as the most polluted city in the world, writes Gardiner Harris of The New York Times, with air pollution far worse than that of Beijing, whose smoggy skies have grabbed much of the international attention.

title: African National Congress Draws 62 Percent of the Vote in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  As the final ballots of South Africas fifth post-apartheid election were tallied on Friday, the results handed the governing African National Congress a victory with 62 percent of the vote  nearly the same share it won in 1994, the year it assumed power under Nelson Mandela in the nations f irst truly democratic election.

title: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
description: MOSCOW  Putting his personal seal on the annexation of Crimea, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traveled on Friday to the naval port of Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany to assert that Moscow had the right to take over the Black Sea peninsula.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 9, 2014
description: Use the following question to test your ability to punctuate a quotation.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
description: In A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World, Jim Yardley reports on Italys new singing sensation.

title: Recovering Steel Industry Lifts ArcelorMittal
description: LONDON  ArcelorMittal, the steel and mining giant, said on Friday that it had a loss of $200 million in its first quarter, less than the $345 million loss it posted for the period a year earlier. The report was taken as a sign that conditions were improving in the steel industry, considered a proxy for overall economic activity.

title: Fire Temporarily Knocks Out Broadcast Service in Kiev
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A fire near a main broadcasting tower briefly disrupted some television service in the Ukrainian capital on Friday morning, as the authorities were on a heightened state of alert because of the countrys political crisis and a major national holiday celebrating victory in World War II.

title: A Cultural History of Civil Rights
description: Two men sit inside a rural Mississippi community center. One of them, a black civil rights activist, has a shotgun at the ready. Their vigil  in a town where the Ku Klux Klan could strike at any moment  is in a makeshift library whose walls are covered with books.

title: If You Had Your Own Talk Show, Whom Would You Want to Interview?
description: After more than 50 years on television, Barbara Walters is retiring  but not after interviewing seemingly every famous person. Last week she made waves again by scoring the first interview with V. Stiviano, the now-famous alleged mistress of L.A. Clippers owner, Donald Sterling. If you had the chance to host your own talk show, whom would you want to interview?

title: Co-operative Banks Chairman to Step Down as It Seeks to Raise 400 Million
description: LONDON The Co-operative Bank said on Friday that its chairman would step down as the embattled lender prepared to raise another 400 million pounds, or roughly $676 million, to bolster its capital.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: Mothers Day Delays
description: Good morning to you on this damp Friday.

title: Thunders 7-Foot Pest Makes an Impression on the Other Team
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  During one trip down the floor, Steven Adams jostled, pushed and tangled arms with Blake Griffin, fighting over a piece of the court as if it were the last crumb at the dinner table.

title: In Our Pages: May 10
description: 1914: Terrible Earthquake in Sicily

title: Daily Report: Snapchat, Settling F.T.C. Case, Agrees to Increased Privacy Controls
description: What happens on the Internet stays on the Internet.

title: Votes for Crooks and Cricket Stars
description: WASHINGTON  In America, the period between a candidates announcement of his intention to run for office and the partys primary election is known as the money primary. Its during this time that aspiring candidates must prove to party bosses and the public that they can rake in enough money to win.

title: Why You Should Pay Frontiers Carry-On Bag Fee
description: Airlines have found another way to make money: Frontier Airlines is now charging for the privilege of carrying a bag on board. A small personal item is still free, but if you need to use the overhead bin, youll generally be paying $20 to $50.

title: Coming Up in the Book Review
description: One of the biggest decisions we make every week at the Book Review is: What will be on the cover? Most weeks, there is a standout novel or work of nonfiction or an extremely commanding review by a prominent author or critic that demands attention. Stephen King on Donna Tartts Goldfinch, for example. Barbara Kingsolver on Elizabeth Gilberts Signature of All Things. Or we group a few books together, as we did last week with three biographies about James Madison, John Quincy Adams and Louisa Catherine Adams.Occasionally, we run a theme issue, like one we did in April on money or one last year that looked at writing about sex. This week, we did something slightly different. While we didnt create an entire issue around a theme, we decided to highlight six new books on the cover that took on the subcontinent as their subject matter. These spring releases really stood out: Rana Dasguptas Capital, John Keays Midnights Descendants, Ramachandra Guhas Gandhi Before India, Saadat Hasan Mantos Bombay Stories, Anand Giridharadass True American and Amitava Kumars Matter of Rats.

title: Mom Genes
description: Why we love wearing our mothers clothes.

title: Boko Haram Kidnapping Tactics, Explained
description: In Nigeria, more than 200 schoolgirls have been held captive since last April. Some background information on the Islamist group that has been trying to topple the countrys government for years.

title: Apples New Tune
description: APPLE IN TALKS TO BUY BEATS | Apple is said to be in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, Ben Sisario, Brian X. Chen and David Gelles write in DealBook. The deal, which would also include the new Beats Music streaming service, would be the biggest acquisition in Apples history and could suggest an effort to shake up its approach to digital music.

title: Chinese Artist Detained Before Tiananmen Anniversary
description: With little more than three weeks remaining until the 25th anniversary of the Chinese Armys bloody crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests, the authorities are policing any attempt to commemorate the event  even those held in private. On Wednesday night, public security agents detained Chen Guang, 43, a former soldier turned artist whose experiences during those tumultuous days have become a haunting inspiration for his work.

title: Schoolgirls Abducted in Nigeria
description: The militant group Boko Haram has kidnapped more than 200 schoolgirls.

title: Just Cant Get Enough of Each Other
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The director and screenwriter James Gray and his frequent star Joaquin Phoenix both say that they first met shortly after Mr. Phoenix picked up a copy of Mr. Grays script The Yards at the apartment of Liv Tyler, then the actors girlfriend. A meeting was set up at Piadina, an Italian restaurant on West 10th Street in Manhattan. It was January 1997. Since then, they have made four movies together, all set in New York: The Yards, We Own the Night, Two Lovers and now The Immigrant.

title: Earnings at Telefnica and Alcatel-Lucent Reflect Industry Difficulties
description: LONDON  Many of Europes largest telecommunications companies are still struggling to profit from consumers seemingly insatiable appetite for Internet access.

title: Fed Up Asks, Are All Calories Equal?
description: Americans have long been told that the cure for obesity is simple: Eat fewer calories and exercise more.

title: As Modi Makes a Last Charge in Varanasi, Tempers and Emotions Rise
description: VARANASI, India  Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, arrived on Thursday in Rohaniya, an hours drive from Varanasis city center. This was to be Mr. Modis last campaign rally in Varanasi, where he is locked in a fierce contest with Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party in a parliamentary race that has gripped India.

title: A Friend Named Joe
description: Dear Diary:

title: Cost-Cutting Helps Danish Maker of Wind Turbines Return to Profitability
description: LONDON  Vestas Wind Systems, the Danish maker of wind turbines, reported on Friday a net profit for its first quarter of 2 million euros compared with a loss of about 150 million a year earlier as the companys efforts to reduce costs began to pay off.

title: Insurance and Freedom
description: These are tough times for opponents of health care reform. They bet everything on a debacle, but Obamacare has failed to fail  and their efforts to deny the increasingly obvious success of the law are beginning to look ridiculous.

title: Artists on Artists | Michelle Grabner on Christopher Williamss Vivid, Exacting Photographs
description: Earlier this year, Michelle Grabner became the first artist to co-curate the Whitney Biennial since Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, the museums founder. The floor she organized was the popular favorite, lauded for its emphasis on mature female painters, like Amy Sillman and Louise Fishman, and lushly handmade objects, including several works by the textile artist Sheila Hicks. Grabner also runs two galleries with her husband, the artist Brad Killam: The Suburban, housed in two sheds in their Oak Park, Ill., backyard, and thePoor Farm, a larger space in rural Wisconsin.

title: U.S. Sells More Shares in Ally Financial
description: The Treasury Department has taken another step to reduce its stake in Ally Financial after the initial public offering of the once-embattled lender.

title: Eurozone Fiscal Myths
description: Matthew Yglesias has a generally very good piece on the euro story so far; a combination of whatever-it-takes financial intervention and political commitment has stabilized the financial situation, but the real economy and the unemployed have suffered terribly.

title: Post Office Says It Lost $1.9 Billion in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON  The financially troubled Postal Service on Friday reported a net loss of $1.9 billion in the second quarter, the same amount it lost over the same period in 2013, postal officials said.

title: U.N. Refugee Agency Says Thousands Fleeing Nigeria Region
description: GENEVA  As international support builds for the search for more than 200 abducted Nigerian schoolgirls, the United Nations refugee agency expressed alarm Friday at the swelling tide of people fleeing their homes in northeast Nigeria to escape attacks by Boko Haram insurgents that it said were unprecedented in their brutality and frequency.

title: An Apple Deal for Beats? The Reaction on the Web
description: Since Apple introduced iTunes and the iPod more than 10 years ago, it has been the king of music.

title: One Word to Describe Your Mother
description: Whats one word you would use to describe your mother? Katie Hafner, the author of Mother Daughter Me, sent me this:

title: The Mothers Day Industrial Complex
description: Behind that perfect bouquet for Mom lies a global network of growers, wholesalers and shopkeepers who are all fighting against time to keep those blooms blooming.

title: In Beats Deal, a New Direction for Apple
description: Apple has never been one for megadeals. Facebook and Google have spent billions on companies like WhatsApp and Motorola, but Apple has stayed well below the billion-dollar mark.

title: United Spirits to Sell Whyte & Mackay Whiskey
description: LONDON  United Spirits of India said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its Whyte & Mackay whiskey business to the brandy maker Emperador in a deal that values the business at 430 million pounds, or $726.5 million.

title: Three Walls in Search of a Ball
description: A century ago, handball was one of the most beloved sports in Ireland, its typical three-walled alley, or court, a fixture in villages and at crossroads. But these were more than just places where people came to play handball, says the photographer Kenneth O Halloran, who visited nearly a hundred abandoned courts in Ireland and Northern Ireland last year. People came to socialize, to dance. After the game moved indoors around the 1950s, many courts that were not demolished became places for parking or storage. There is little nostalgia among the Irish for handball alleys, O Halloran says. I dont think people would value them the way they value a traditional cottage, old crosses or ancient ruins, he says. A lot of people see them as eyesores. Julie Bosman

title: The Horoscope Diet
description: What not to read before shopping; Cliven Bundy vs. Al Bundy.

title: Reply All: The 4.27.14 Issue
description: SHOULD A CHIMP BE ABLE TO SUE ITS OWNER?

title: You Should Seriously Read Stoner Right Now
description: Fifteen years ago, a friend of mine pulled me aside at the tail end of some sodden grad-school party and pressed a copy of the novel Stoner into my hands. I was at the time in the thrall of various junkie authors and thus assumed Stoner would be a tale of psychoactive depravity. The book was a different sort of trip altogether.

title: The Old Switch-a-Brew
description: Sixty years ago, my father worked in a brewery, which produced a premium beer and a regular beer with a different name and a cheaper price. In actuality, the beers were identical, only with different bottles and labels. The premium buyers were getting what they were paying for  a premium beer. The regular beer drinkers were paying less for the same thing. While it doesnt seem that anyone was hurt by the deception, does the fact that there was deceit involved make it unethical? NAME WITHHELD

title: Addict. Informant. Mother.
description: One day last summer, Ann and her husband, Tom, walked two and a half hours to reach Hazleton, a onetime mining town in eastern Pennsylvania. They had lived there until July, when they were evicted and moved in with Anns mother in Sugarloaf, a more affluent township nearby. There was not much to miss about Hazleton, with its decaying downtown and its fading homes spotted with satellite dishes, but to Ann and Tom the town held a shimmering appeal: It had heroin, a lot of it. They had called the usual friends for a ride, with no luck, and their own car had been repossessed. So at midday, the two left Anns mothers condominium by foot and followed the asphalt out of the valley all the way to Hazleton. Eventually they turned onto Alter Street, where, especially in summer, heroin dealers greeted customers outside a packed barbershop and a busy pawnshop, clustering around them, competing for business. Sometimes Ann and Tom joined other users they knew behind a building, where someone had left a tattered couch. Sometimes they got high in an abandoned garage on a side street. Though the walk that day to Alter Street was long, it was worth it to them both: Tom, especially, loved heroin, and Ann loved Tom, and the march to Hazleton was as much about need as it was about love.

title: Philippe Petit Strikes a Delicate Balance
description: Your new book is called Creativity: The Perfect Crime. The first lines are Make no mistake. I frown upon books about creativity. How is yours different? Most books on creativity are written by an author who references all the great creators of humanity  very often Einstein, the Beatles. Theyre not drawing from themselves, and these books are usually in the self-help department. And very often, at the end of a chapter, they have an exercise for you to do. I dont frown upon them; lets be frank, I hate them.

title: A Nannys Love
description: One Mothers Day many years ago, my younger brother handed Tina a card he made in his kindergarten class. When my mom saw it, she said, Thats mine. Tina laughed and handed the card to her boss.

title: Who Made That Stun Gun?
description: In the summer of 1965, just before riots broke out in Watts, President Lyndon Johnson ordered a study on crime in a free society. Among its recommendations was developing a technology for handling unruly citizens. A patrolman ought to have a nonlethal way to incapacitate a criminal, one that worked quickly and with little risk of lasting injury. For example, the studys authors wrote, darts have been used for injecting tranquilizing drugs into animals.

title: Goldman Under Investigation for High-Speed Trading
description: Updated, 3:48 p.m. |

title: Unfrozen
description: Meteorology is not superfluous to the story, W. G. Sebald advised the students in one of his final fiction-writing classes. Its an observation that has never seemed lost on Michael Cunningham. Consider how he introduces Virginia Woolfs last afternoon on earth in the opening sentence of his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Hours: She hurries from the house, wearing a coat too heavy for the weather. And his 2010 novel By Nightfall ended with some rather Joycean evening snow tapping at the bedroom window of an affluent, troubled Manhattan husband, a man about to have a reckoning with his own self-centeredness. (Another excellent tip from Sebald: I can only encourage you to steal as much as you can.)

title: Captive Rites
description: Contemporary tellings tend to mask the real horrors of the original Brothers Grimm stories and their ilk. We remember the princess and the happy ending. Wed rather forget that a passing stranger raped Sleeping Beauty as she lay unconscious, or that Snow Whites jealous stepmother not only called for her death but wanted to eat her liver and lungs. Roxane Gays striking debut novel, An Untamed State, is a fairy tale in this vein, its complex and fragile moral arrived at through great pain and high cost.

title: Skills and Strategies | Engaging in Causes Via Hashtag Activism
description: Update | May 14, 2014: We have added a contribution from 230 girls and their teachers at a school in Panama City, Panama. Scroll to the bottom of this post to see it.

title: Rebel Prince Shines a Harsh Light on Morocco
description: PARIS  HE sat in the car, frozen with fear, as gunmen pointed rifles at his pregnant mother in the drivers seat beside him. They were rushing to the kings birthday party because they had heard there was a commotion. It was the summer of 1971, and the Moroccan Army killed over 100 party guests in its attempt to overthrow the monarchy. The gunmen spared the pregnant woman and her 7-year-old son. Later that day, the coup failed.

title: Today in Small Business: Birth of a Food Fad
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Guilty as Sin
description: Bernie Gunther, the sardonic German detective in Philip Kerrs historical crime novels, survived World War II with life, limb and integrity intact. But Bernie was only up against the entire Nazi high command. In PRAYER (Putnam, $26.95), Kerr introduces us to Gil Martins, an F.B.I. agent with the domestic terrorism unit in Houston who seems to be doing battle with Almighty God himself  or whoever is murdering prominent atheists in his name. As an ex-Catholic and wavering evangelical Christian, Martins is an avid consumer of what he calls atheist porn by writers like Richard Dawkins. And when his friend, the worldly Bishop Eamon Coogan, asks him to look into the curious deaths of some prominent atheists, hes drawn into a mystery that defies both faith and logic.

title: Patients and Fortitude
description: For the deadliest medical conditions, cure is a word even the most optimistic doctors try to resist. Oncologists have seen too often how a few metastatic cancer cells can endure every poison medicine throws at them, chemical or radioactive, only to lurk silently for years before staging a triumphant return. No wonder pharmaceutical companies prefer to describe their state-of-the-art cancer drugs in terms of five-year survival rates, with no promises about what happens in Year 6.

title: Ford Recalls 1.4 Million Crossovers; G.M. Recalls 9,000 Sedans
description: In two actions, Ford is recalling nearly 1.4 million vehicles from the 2013-14 model years for an air bag malfunction and door handles that may not latch properly, the automaker said Friday. The air bag issue covers about 692,500 Escape and C-Max models, including 591,000 in the United States, about 78,000 in Canada and almost 19,700 in Mexico.

title: When the Boss Calls After Hours
description: We shouldnt laugh too hard about the agreement announced last month in France that sought to protect employees from after-hours texts and emails but confused a lot of people.

title: Students and Money, in Their Own Words
description: The college-application essays that four students submitted this year on emerging stronger from economic challenges.

title: Thrift Store Shame, Then Pride
description: Clare Connaughton, a high school student from Mineola, N.Y., reads from her college application essay about how shopping at thrift stores with her mother has gone from necessity to cherished pastime.

title: Four Stand-Out College Essays About Money
description: Talking about money is hard. Writing well about yourself may be harder still. So trying to do both at once, as a teenager, while addressing complete strangers who control your future, would seem to be foolhardy.

title: Beats Deal May Turn Heads in Private Equity
description: With Beats Electronics on Apples shopping list, private equity titans are in line to cash in.

title: The Hamptons-in-Waiting
description: The great Hamptons divide in Hampton Bays is a scenic waterway that offers boats of all persuasions, from blue-collar Boston Whalers to yachts helmed by plutocrats, a fluid north-south link between the Atlantic Ocean and Great Peconic Bay.

title: Luis Surez Reaps the Benefits of Good Behavior
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Luis Surez has made bad choices over the years in much the same way that an overaggressive taxi driver does: consistently and spectacularly.

title: Memoirs
description: THE LAST PIRATE  A Father, His Son, and the Golden Age of Marijuana  By Tony Dokoupil  Doubleday, $26.95.

title: A Mother in Absentia
description: In her wrenching new book, a memoir camouflaged as a novel, the prominent French writer Delphine de Vigan sets out to write my mother, tracing the life of the woman she calls Lucile Poirier from her early childhood just after World War II to her suicide in 2008 at the age of 61. Woven into this dark tale is the equally absorbing story of a daughters quest to research and imagine an elusive woman in order to get close to her, even though her very essence embodied distance: For all of us, Lucile  her gentleness and her aggression  remains a mystery. The difficulty de Vigan has in describing her mother, she confesses, is not so far removed from the distress we felt as children and teenagers when she disappeared. Which she did, dramatically, in a series of manic episodes, beginning in her early 30s.

title: Inside the List
description: Lifes Too Short: Greg Iless thriller Natchez Burning, about racism and murder in the Jim Crow South, is his first new novel in five years. Thats a long time between books for a writer whose previous best sellers arrived as regularly as the Olympics, every two years or so. But Iles has a good excuse. In 2011, when he was putting the finishing touches on an earlier version of Natchez Burning, he was in a car crash that tore his aorta, left him in a coma for eight days and resulted in the loss of his right leg below the knee. The accident, along with the death of his father a year earlier, inspired him to have another go at his novel. I realized that life was too short to pull any punches, Iles told The Greenville News in South Carolina earlier this month. I decided there was no room in this book for formula and fluff. The story had to be handled with appropriate gravitas. I had to deal with it not only the way it deserved but in a way that would make my father proud. The reworked Natchez Burning  which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2  clocks in at almost 800 pages, and is the first of a planned trilogy. Among other things, it explores the role of social elites in allowing racism to thrive. The white lower middle class and lower class did not commit those acts of violence in a vacuum, Iles told The Greenville News. They had been given tacit approval by the upper levels of white society. Nor, he said, is such racism restricted to the past. Look at the scandal over the comments by the Clippers owner, he said, referring to Donald Sterling. The legacy of slavery is the greatest psychic wound in the American character. We still havent fully dealt with it, and I think itll take another lifetime to deal with it.

title: All Year Round
description: The seasons of the year tell a tale that resonates deep inside us. No matter where you start in the calendar, the passing of the seasons presents a beginning, middle and end that is hard-wired to our emotional metabolism. This applies equally to adults and children. A year is a drama in four acts. With a plot like that, you dont even need a story.

title: Grand Experiment
description: When youre in middle school, youre a mess. Its a world of boys with wispy mustaches and bro-tanks revealing an absence of armpit hair. They make comments like Damn, that girl is sexy in cracked voices stuck in the transition between too high and too deep. Its even worse for girls. The moment they get to middle school they start putting on makeup, and they put it on wrong. Growth spurts make them tall and goofy; acne arrives along with a period they are not sure how to manage. At that exact moment, they develop a dream  more of an obsession, really: to be popular. This is when the pain begins.

title: Fantasy Island
description: A patrician New England clan decamps to their private island off Marthas Vineyard for the summer. Of the dozen or so Sinclair family members in residence, No one is a criminal. No one is an addict. No one is a failure. Three lies, the first of many, provide an irresistible premise for this ticking bomb of a novel by E. Lockhart.

title: An Update on 4 Students After a College Year
description: In response to a request from Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, asking high school seniors to share their college application essays that covered the subjects of money, class, working or the economy, 66 students last year submitted their work. We picked four to run online. Heres an update on the students we featured in the column last May.

title: Out-of-Body Experience
description: As far as I can recall  and its been a while  being a teenager is confusing. You have to wrestle with all sorts of issues related to your identity, and the biggest struggle is simply feeling comfortable in your skin. Thats why the premise of John Corey Whaleys young adult novel Noggin  outlandish as it is  has such wonderful resonance. It takes the idea of being alienated from your own body and makes it literal.

title: Heart of a Champion
description: Josh and JB are twins, double trouble on the basketball court, almost 13 years old. When we first encounter them in Kwame Alexanders beautifully measured novel of life and lines, The Crossover, they are deep into a year when everything changes. The story is written in verse, but have no fear: Here, poetry is in service to the interior and exterior worlds of Josh, who plays forward to JBs shooting guard. Besides being an inch taller and the one with dreadlocks to his neck, Josh is also the brother with the larger vocabulary  by the novels end, he will define 12 important words and terms.

title: Slumber Party
description: I dont know about yours, but my bedtime reading does not generally  ever, actually  include books about falling asleep. This should seem strange only to young children, for whom the provision of books about sleeping and not sleeping has captured a large slice of the picture book market. Dr. Robert Needlman, who revised and updated Dr. Benjamin Spocks Baby and Child Care, once told me that the purpose of bedtime stories is to give the imagination a kind of way station between wakefulness and sleep that facilitates an easier slip into unconsciousness. (We were talking about young children, but I think this goes for all of us.) So books for bedtime, sure. But why about? Four new books, swaddled in practically identical shades of sleepy-time blue, attempt to make a case for the genre. Some do a better job than others.

title: Little Sister, Big Plans
description: In literature, as in life, sisters are always compared with one another. Theres the smart one and the pretty one. The shy one and the one who gets invited everywhere. Older sisters are supposed to know better, while younger ones are usually up to something. Little sisters tend to feel left out. Who can forget Amy March tossing Jos manuscript into the fire because she wasnt invited to the play? Or Ramona Quimby baking her doll into Beezus birthday cake?

title: Seeing Reds
description: The year might be 1953, but in Megan Frazer Blakemores The Spy Catchers of Maple Hill, Hazel Kaplansky has to put up with the same baloney that many a contemporary fifth grader faces. Shes sick of dealing with mean-girl bullies and getting stuck playing the triangle in music class. The brainy and impulsive girl thinks that if she exposes the new town gravedigger as a Communist, everyone from her inattentive parents to Senator McCarthy himself will recognize her as the heroine shes meant to be.

title: Collapse of Ad Giants Merger Deals Blow to Moelis
description: When Moelis & Company began wooing prospective investors for its initial public offering earlier this year, one of its main talking points was its presence on big deals.

title: While the Battle Rages On
description: The experiences of children evacuated from London to rural England during the Blitz are familiar to fiction readers, thanks in large part to C. S. Lewiss Narnia chronicles and, more recently, Michelle Magorians Good Night, Mr. Tom. Less well known is the story of the thousands of children who were sent across the ocean to live with American families. L. M. Elliott brings these reluctant immigrants to our attention in Across a War-Tossed Sea, an engaging but uneven tale of two English brothers, Charles and Wesley, who find themselves dispatched to a Virginia farm in 1943.

title: Where Theres Smoke
description: Listen! Long have we known of the dangers of carbon emissions. But even those of us who believe human activity is forever damaging the climate find it difficult to change our everyday behavior, because the real cost of a short drive to the grocery store just doesnt register.

title: One Morning in June
description: On the morning of May 5, 1944, 146 Allied generals, admirals, officers and staff members filed past military policemen into the chilly auditorium of St. Pauls School in London. German bombs had blown out 700 of the schools windows; its students had been evacuated to the countryside. The military men sat on hard benches with overcoats buttoned, blankets on laps. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, standing before a 30-foot-wide plaster relief map of the coast of Normandy, announced that if anyone saw a problem with the plan the group was about to hear, he should speak up. I have no sympathy with anyone, he said, whatever his station, who will not brook criticism. Then the wiry, elfin British Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery began, in his reedy voice, each word as sharply creased as his trousers, to describe the invasion intended to mortally wound Hitlers Third Reich.

title: What It Means When Google Verifies an App
description: Q. When Google verifies apps during installation on an Android device, what is it doing?

title: Russia Celebrates Victory Day
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traveled from Moscow to Sevastopol on Friday to commemorate Victory Day, in the process showcasing his nations military might.

title: The College Admissions Essay: My Story
description: Ron Lieber writes the Your Money column for The Times. The Opposite of Spoiled, his book about parents, children and money, will be published in February.

title: Movie Review: Palo Alto
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Palo Alto.

title: Rhetoric About Womens Issues Outpaces Political Progress
description: At the close of 2012, it seemed that the womens movement in India would never be the same.

title: Michael Jackson Returns
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss Xscape, the new album of previously unreleased demos by Michael Jackson.

title: FedExs Price Rise Is a Blessing in Disguise for Amazon
description: No. 1 on the list of chores the Internet has done away with: dragging yourself to the store to stock up on unwieldy items and carting them home. Many e-commerce companies  led by Amazon.com and the sites it owns, like Diapers.com and Soap.com  have made it easy to order even items like toilet paper and diapers without paying a cent for shipping.

title: A Proposed Merger Brings Out the Thoughtful Side of Congress
description: Lawmakers on the hill, usually eager to score points and yell about imaginary scandals, have been surprisingly thoughtful about Comcasts $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable, a pressing antitrust issue.

title: At Evangelical Colleges, Leadership Is Often the Family Business
description: During the past school year, several leading American universities, including Yale, Princeton, Dartmouth and Carnegie-Mellon, welcomed new presidents. These men were leading scholars, and they were experienced administrators; in some cases, they held degrees from the universities they now lead. And none of them  not one  inherited the job from his father or mother.

title: Grief Lessons
description: When a friend in high school told me The Catcher in the Rye was the funniest book hed ever read, I picked up a copy  and sobbed my way through it. To my friend, Holden Caulfield was a hilarious smart aleck; to me, he was a bereft sibling, falling apart after his younger brothers death.

title: That Amherst Belle
description: In the daily lives of most American children today, poetry has gone missing. Almost entirely absent from elementary school curriculums, rarely chosen as bedtime reading by parents, poetry  formerly a joyful accouterment of youth, an inexhaustible gift  seems forgotten. Yet poetry and children belong together. And who, among the great American poets, could be more appropriate for childhood than Emily Dickinson?

title: Times Minute | Costa Concordias End
description: The next chapter in the Costa Concordia tragedy. Also on the Minute, Putins flamboyant Victory Day parade and a new comedy, Neighbors, opens this weekend.

title: Rangers St. Louis Decides to Play Game 5
description: PITTSBURGH  Rangers forward Martin St. Louis will play Game 5 against the Pittsburgh Penguins on Friday night, a day after his mother died suddenly of a heart attack.

title: Nothing You Say Will Make Me Pay $375 for a Sandal. But Keep Talking.
description: I fell hard for a French shoe this week: suede sandals, two-tone black and tan. They would have served me well because theyd go with everything. There was no price tag on them, which generally translates to: What do you care? Youre not some loser who has to work for a living.

title: Times Minute | Costa Concordias End
description: In the Video

title: Your Building on an Index Card
description: Every new condo or co-op built in New York  from a modest two-family semidetached house upstate to a shiny Manhattan tower with $90-million penthouses  begins its gestation in the same unlikely place: a shabby office near Wall Street where a handful of beleaguered state employees toil under a deluge of paper, date stamp machines and other vestiges of outdated technology.

title: Movie Review: Chef
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Chef.

title: Paperback Row
description: ODDS AGAINST TOMORROW,  by Nathaniel Rich. (Picador, $16.) In Richs apocalyptic second novel, an earthquake has leveled Seattle and a brilliant, neurotic mathematician named Mitchell Zukor spends his days calculating worst-case scenarios for a shadowy consulting firm that indemnifies corporations against potential disasters. Mitchell suffers from visions of nuclear fallout and modern black plagues, but his prognostications acquire near-mythic status after a storm engulfs New York City.

title: A Plan Built on Assumptions
description: This past week, on a day when fast-food workers gathered in front of a McDonalds in downtown Manhattan to announce that they would strike again on May 15 to demand higher wages, clergy members from various denominations around New York joined hundreds of laborers for a service and pray-in at Riverside Church, calling on state legislators to allow cities to set their own minimum wage. The economic realities of life in New York City so often seem to require holy intervention. According to the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group, more than 1.25 million residents, 37 percent of all workers living in the city, make less than $15 an hour. More than half of workers who live in the Bronx subsist in this category; in Brooklyn, which has one of the most competitive housing markets in the country, the figure is 41 percent.

title: When the Clowns Came In, the Rangers Moved Out
description: Rangers fans, it could be worse.

title: Editors Choice
description: JAMES MADISON: A Life Reconsidered,  by Lynne Cheney. (Viking, $36.) Cheneys lucidly written biography clearly, and at times dramatically, brings to life the character and personality of Americas fourth president.

title: A Synthetic Biology Conference Lures an Intriguing Audience
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  When does a scientific conference warrant the attention of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Department of Homeland Security? When the topic is synthetic biology.

title: Movie Review: Neighbors
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Neighbors.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Gandhi Before India
description: This week, Jyoti Thottam discusses Ramachandra Guhas Gandhi Before India; Anand Giridharadas talks about The True American; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Sarah Harrison Smith discusses this weeks Childrens Books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Michael Jackson Returns, at Least on Record
description: This week on Popcast: Michael Jackson is still alive  on Xscape, the latest posthumous episode in a deal between the Jackson estate and Sony Records reportedly worth $250 million.

title: Gender in de Blasios Cabinet
description: Like no mayor before him, Bill de Blasio has tapped women to serve in key roles in his administration. Here is a breakdown of the mayors appointments to top positions so far, compared with the administrations of his three predecessors in the first year of their terms.

title: The Women of New Yorks City Hall
description: With Manhattan still cloaked in early-morning darkness, New York Citys new sanitation commissioner stepped into a semicircle of 40 men holding brooms and dustpans as they finished roll call and prepared to clean the streets of the Village.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: A Catholic Dilemma
description: Before I address myself toCardinal Walter Kaspers latest remarkson how he thinks Roman Catholicism might change its approach to second marriages and the sacraments, I want to engage with Philip Lawlersthoughtfulresponsesto some of the issues raised inmy columnandpostson the possibility of an alteration to Catholic teaching on this front.

title: Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture this weekend.

title: NPR Picks a New Leader With Lots of Commercial Experience
description: NPR has turned to an unlikely figure from the private sector, Jarl Mohn, who earlier in his career founded the E! cable channel, to become its new chief executive, the organization announced on Friday.

title: The Kimchi Mans Pickled Persistence
description: As soon as Yeong Park walked into the cellphone store in Flushing, the woman at the counter waved him off.

title: Video Reviews of Neighbors, Chef and Palo Alto
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Neighbors, Palo Alto and Chef. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Memories of the Paradise Garage, From Those Who Danced There
description: The Paradise Garage crashed onto New Yorks nightlife scene like a tidal wave. When it opened in 1977, the dance club, housed in a former parking garage on 84 Varick Street, offered a counterpoint to its glitzier uptown cousin, Studio 54, where the rich and fabulous went to be seen. The Garage, which did not sell alcohol and wasnt open to the general public, was strictly about the music. For a decade, until the clubs closing in 1987, it was a utopia for New Yorks increasingly liberated black and Latino L.G.B.T. communities, who went there to dance until sunrise (and often beyond) to the cutting-edge sounds of disco, soul, funk, R&B, new wave and an emerging genre that would eventually be known as house music.

title: Hamster Wheels, Sequins and, Yes, a Lot of Singing
description: COPENHAGEN  The crowd of roughly 10,000 fans cheered, and the lights glowed electric blue as a woman in a bright white gown introduced the next act in the giant auditorium here. Please give it up now for Albania! she shouted.

title: Ruling Could Escalate Floridas Status as Haven for Debtors
description: A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR dispute between a politically connected Florida billionaire and the brother-in-law of the king of Jordan over a debt involving oil shipped during the Iraq war might seem irrelevant to the lives of ordinary citizens.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Gandhi Before India
description: This week, Jyoti Thottam, Anand Giridharadas and Sarah Harrison Smith.

title: BMW to Expand U.S. Plant in Push for Lighter, More Fuel-Efficient Cars
description: FRANKFURT  BMW said on Friday that it would invest $200 million and double its work force at a factory in Washington State that makes carbon fibers as the company moves to use more of the lightweight material in cars and meet demand for a new electric vehicle.

title: The Human Factor in Merger Collapse
description: The combination of Publicis and Omnicom looked great on paper, but its idea was sorely misjudged.

title: Ukrainian Forces Attack Militant-Held Police Station
description: MARIUPOL, Ukraine  Ukrainian security forces in armored vehicles attacked a police station here on Friday, reducing the building to smoldering rubble and killing at least seven people, according to residents who say they witnessed the assault.

title: Update on the Baby Red-Tailed Hawks at N.Y.U.
description: In a nest overlooking Washington Square Park, two juvenile red-tailed hawks are beginning to poke their heads above the messy tangle of brown branches.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: A Regiment Redeemed
description: At midday on Sunday, May 8, 1864, two brigades of the Second Division of the 20th Corps  part of Maj. Gen. William T. Shermans Union army group  formed a line of battle in a clearing in north Georgia. It was the fourth day of a campaign that would culminate four months later with the capture of Atlanta. The division commander, Brig. Gen. John W. Geary, rode to the front of the line and addressed the soldiers. He ordered them to take the mountain looming ahead of them, which was reportedly held by a couple of regiments of Confederate cavalry. If you take the hill, Geary closed, it will be a feather in your cap.
