title: In Rwanda, Finding Echoes of Germany
description: I MOVED to Nairobi last year for a challenge and to try something new. I thought that reporting from all over East Africa would be nothing like my previous assignment covering Central Europe from Berlin and I was excited to leave behind the stolid German Finance Ministry and embark on bumpy jeep rides through lush jungles and desert dunes.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 34
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Upper West Side Brownstone With Modern Twists
description: A cleverly conceived hybrid townhouse  the pale front is a historically correct brownstone and the back a bold architectural grid of glass and steel  on a classic Upper West Side block near the American Museum of Natural History is poised to enter the market at $12 million. The annual taxes on the 19-foot-wide, circa-1900 property at 121 West 81st Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, are $63,679.

title: The National Pastime, Amid a National Crisis
description: This is one of the earliest photographs ever taken of a baseball game, and it happened by accident. The photographer, Henry P. Moore, of Concord, N.H., was focusing on the well-uniformed Union soldiers of the 48th New York State Volunteer Infantry, but he also captured their baseball-playing comrades in the background.

title: Bookshelf: Garden Friends and Foes
description: New picture books include Superworm by Julia Donaldson.

title: Does College Pay?
description: Over time, a large and growing majority of incoming freshmen have ranked making more money as a very important reason for going to college, as the Times columnist David Brooks mentioned in a recent column.

title: Clip: Godzilla
description: A scene from the 2014 film.

title: Bookshelf: Oh, Behave!
description: New picture books include Here Comes Destructosaurus by Aaron Reynolds.

title: 7 Republicans Named to Panel Investigating Attack in Benghazi
description: WASHINGTON  House Speaker John A. Boehner on Friday appointed seven Republicans to the 12-person committee tasked with continuing investigations into the 2012 attack that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya. The move forced Democratic lawmakers to struggle to overcome internal disagreements over how to handle the latest inquiry and whether or not to appoint any of their own members to the new committee.

title: Face-Lift? Well, You Still Look Like Hell
description: After 60 years of crushing, fighting and roaring, Godzilla shows no signs of stopping. The oversize lizard that has attracted generations of fans returns Friday in a film that harks back to the creatures roots. The filmmakers behind the latest iteration mainly used the 1954 original, from Toho Studios, as a template for fleshing out the monsters looks and the movies narrative.

title: Apples Midlife Crisis
description: Apple is showing another symptom of a midlife crisis.

title: In Silicon Valley, Morgan Stanley Reigns
description: The Wall Street analyst-turned-blogger Henry Blodget called it a disaster. The Wall Street Journal labeled it a botched offering. And after Facebooks much-criticized initial public offering in May 2012, Morgan Stanleys vaunted technology investment banking team, the lead underwriter on the deal, looked as if it were down for the count.

title: Dishes for Digestive Health
description: Ive long been aware of the term probiotics (is there anybody who watches television who hasnt seen Jamie Lee Curtis touting them in those old ads for Activia yogurt?), the beneficial microbes in our guts, and also in fermented foods like miso and kimchi, that some experts believe play a significant role in gut health and in keeping our immune system robust. But Id never heard the word prebiotics until I attended a talk by the Stanford nutritionist Jo Ann Hattner, who has written (with Susan Anderes) an interesting guide called Gut Insight: Probiotics and Prebiotics for Digestive Health and Well-Being.

title: With Gridlock Comes Piecemeal Tax Legislation
description: Substantive tax legislation is nowhere to be seen. The campaign to overhaul the tax code is on hold, despite a couple of years of concerted effort by Representative Dave Camp, the outgoing chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Max Baucus, who left his post as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee to become the United States Ambassador to China.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Be Gentle in Wedding Party Conundrum

title: The Insider | Amanda Sharp on This Years Frieze Must-Sees
description: As the third annual Frieze New York art fair makes landfall on Randalls Island this weekend, Amanda Sharp will be stationed in the eye of the storm. As the co-founder, with Matthew Slotover, of both Frieze New York and the original Frieze London, Sharp has the inside scoop on what the more than 190 leading galleries have brought to town and what other sights, sounds and tastes await. Here, her tips:

title: Wheelies: The Philanthropic Pony Car Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Book Review Podcast: Gandhi Before India
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jyoti Thottam reviews Ramachandra Guhas Gandhi Before India. Ms. Thottam writes:

title: Struck on the Street: Reader Reactions
description: The note began simply. Thank you for the article you wrote. The boy you mentioned is my son, Cooper Stock.

title: Nets Need More Than Good Game Plan to Beat the Heat
description: After the Miami Heat blew them out of Game 1, the Brooklyn Nets rebounded with a focused, but ill-fated, performance in Game 2 on Thursday night. As has been the case many times, even the right game plan, executed well, was not enough to beat a team as good as the Heat, the two-time defending N.B.A. champions.

title: The Paradox of Art as Work
description: There are few modern relationships as fraught as the one between art and money. Are they mortal enemies, secret lovers or perfect soul mates? Is the bond between them a source of pride or shame, a marriage of convenience or something tawdrier?

title: The Big Wigs of Broadway
description: Getting to the roots of a hair-raising theater season.

title: After Narcs and Satan, Bad Times
description: For a brief moment, between the ascension of Francis Ford Coppola and that of Steven Spielberg, Hollywoods hottest young director was William Friedkin. The one-two punch of The French Connection (1971) and The Exorcist (1973) made the man nicknamed Hurricane Billy a gale-force talent. The successive failures of Sorcerer (1977), The Brinks Job (1978) and Cruising (1980) sent Hurricane Billy out to sea.

title: Green Garlic Stirs a Pot of Chicken Soup
description: To me and many cooks I know, the appearance of green garlic shoots at the market is the real spring harbinger on the East Coast. Along with asparagus, fava beans and peas, wild fiddlehead ferns and ramps, green garlics arrival means the earth has finally consented to give us something hopeful and verdant while we await summers bounty.

title: How to | Shop an Antiques Market
description: Ts European editor, Rita Konig, brings us to Spitalfields, one of her favorite spots to shop for cookware, linens and friendly shopkeepers.

title: Film Stars, but With an Asterisk
description: TORONTO  Camels loitered by the curb, but the sheikh arrived by sedan.

title: Last Stop, Last Drop: Metro-North Bar Cars Chug Into History
description: There are those who sip discreetly on subway trains, reaching for the paper bags in their coat pockets, or pull flasks from their knapsacks in the darkened back corners of a city bus.

title: Pikettys Arguments Still Hold Up, After Taxes
description: One critique of Thomas Pikettys influential new book on wealth accumulation through the ages is that his analysis is solely of market incomes and wealth. He largely ignores systems of taxes and transfers and the extent to which they offset inequality.

title: Season for a Do Thats Special
description: Gender bending, whether playful or politically pointed, or both, is the theme of the IFC Centers Summer of Drag series, which leads off Monday with Richard Benners 1977 cult favorite, Outrageous! Its protagonist, Robin, played by the Canadian drag star Craig Russell, who died in 1990, is persuaded by his schizophrenic roommate to parlay his passion for impersonating legendary female stars into a career as an entertainer.

title: Supersize Motor Homes Can Be a Good Way to Go, or Stay
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Suzi and Edmund Kuehn parked their 41-foot motor home in Flint, Mich., on a Saturday night four years ago. The next morning, Ms. Kuehns ex-husband called from Dallas and told her their 31-year-old son, Leslie, who had been fighting plasma cell leukemia, had died.

title: Shooting in the Bronx Leaves 2 Men Dead, Police Say
description: Two men were shot and killed in the Bronx early Friday morning, according to the police. Both victims, who have yet to be identified, were found in a parked car on Rombouts Avenue.

title: Threes a Trend | Theyve Got Legs, They Know How to Use Them
description: An art fair is first and foremost a playground for the senses, but for any visitor pacing Frieze New Yorks 1500-foot-long SO-IL-designed tent erected on Randalls Island today  or any gallerist standing by to explain their inscrutable wares  these long days are as much about lower-body stamina as they are about the eyes or mind. A trio of works found around the fair render legs  the pivots on which all this weekends deals depend  as art. At Galerie Jocelyn Wolff, Guillaume Leblons pair of ceramic appendages truncated at the knee are poised for action, existentially tensed upon a gnarled, painted clay blanket. Adam McEwens anatomical gypsum sculptures peeking out of the wall at the Modern Institutelook more like hunting trophies; the feet are tucked into bright plastic buckets. And the showstopping, kinetic piece by Jonathan Monk at Galleri Nicolai Wallnertakes a page from the Rockettes with candy-colored, mechanized gams that kick for the pleasure of those who choose to cool their heels there.

title: A Working Vacation on an Umbrian Farm
description: Pride makes fools of us all. Three days into my stint as a farmer at Monestevole, a 98-acre farm nestled atop a hill in Umbria, I was flooded with feelings of smug accomplishment. I was watering the patch of artichoke and tomato seedlings that Id painstakingly planted the day before, when a farmhand named Brad walked by with a cow. I wanted to get Brad to acknowledge my efforts, but my Italian is limited to ordering and waxing enthusiastic about eggplant Parmesan.

title: Echoes of History at a Tuscan Estate
description: Iris Origo was a 22-year-old newlywed Anglo-American heiress  as rich, brilliant and innocent as a Henry James heroine  when she and her husband, an Italian nobleman, decided to buy La Foce. Treeless and shrubless but for some tufts of broom, Origo wrote in October 1923 of her first view of the rundown 3,500-acre estate southeast of Siena; it was a lunar landscape, pale and inhuman.

title: Camping in the Caribbean: A Mother-Daughter Adventure
description: On our second date, the man who later became my husband asked me to promise that I would never make him get on a boat. At some point in his 30s, his inner ear ceased to be his friend, and now he was prone to seasickness so bad that he once became nauseated in a rowboat floating on a lake in Switzerland.

title: Deep Into the Dream World of Kyrgyzstan
description: This was the scene at Pobeda Square in Bishkek, the capital city of Kyrgyzstan. Ahead: a desert of concrete, empty but for a patient queue of newlyweds waiting to have their photo taken next to a guttering eternal flame. Women trilled for joy as doves flapped skyward from wicker cages. In a corner, some wag did handbrake doughnuts in a rust-bucket Mercedes.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz at Mass Moca
description: I visited the art space for the first time a few weeks ago, and it made me think of this atmospheric performance:

title: Obama, Aggravated by Gridlock, Stresses Results in Midterms
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  On a fund-raising trip where President Obama acknowledged at one stop that the country was not going to go where we need to go despite his many executive actions, he was back in sales mode on Friday before returning to still-gridlocked Washington.

title: In Stronghold, a Gandhi Finds the Reception Is More Skeptical than Worshipful
description: AMETHI, India  Naimesh Prasad Pandey, a 60-year-old farmer, can testify to the generations of love that people here have reserved for the Gandhi family.

title: U.K. Finds Way Out of Impasse on Ties to E.U.
description: LONDON  If he wins re-election next year, Prime Minister David Cameron has said he plans to renegotiate British ties to the European Union, then hold a referendum in 2017 on whether to stay in the bloc. But those plans hit a roadblock when Mr. Cameron called for a rewrite of the Unions governing treaty  a tricky political process many other European nations want to avoid.

title: Big Ticket | A Sky-High Retreat for $31.67 Million
description: Another of the popular three-bedroom aeries at One57, this one on the 62nd floor of the Extell Development Companys 90-story Midtown tower, sold for $31,671,075 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Objects From the Lively Past
description: As an antiques dealer, David Duncan is usually focused on the past. But 10 years ago, he looked into the future and concluded the only way to guarantee his survival as a Manhattan shopkeeper was to own his own building.

title: A Drink as Complicated as Motherhood
description: On Sunday, mothers will be celebrated with flowers, or with breakfast in bed. On Monday, most will return to jobs where they are likely to be paid less than their male colleagues  precisely because they are mothers. Studies have repeatedly shown that women lose career opportunities and earnings after they have babies (even though fatherhood increases mens earnings.)

title: Bill Nunn, Scout Who Shaped Steelers Super Bowl Teams, Dies at 89
description: Bill Nunn, a scout for the Pittsburgh Steelers whose deep knowledge of football programs at historically black colleges helped many overlooked players find their way to the Steelers and to stardom as part of the teams dynasty in the 1970s, died on Tuesday in Pittsburgh. He was 89.

title: Taking a Spin: A Senate Survivor in Alaska
description: It is Friday again, which means its time to spin Leos Senate wheels: our weekly demonstration of the considerable uncertainty that remains six months away from the election.

title: Professors Are Prejudiced, Too
description: IN the world of higher education, we professors like to believe that we are free from the racial and gender biases that afflict so many other people in society. But is this self-conception accurate?

title: When Jet Mattered
description: As a grade school student in the late 1950s, I whiled away many Saturday mornings waiting to have my hair cut at Joseahs Barbershop in Chester, Pa., the once-muscular factory town south of Philadelphia where I grew up. It is unremarkable today to see African-Americans and whites sitting side-by-side in hair salons. But in the age of American apartheid  even in the North  beauty and hair-care services were segregated by race.

title: Weekend Reading: 5 Questions for Alibabas I.P.O.
description: DealBook is attempting to fill in the gaps of Alibabas eagerly anticipated filing for a stock listing in the United States.

title: Theyre Stompin on Avenue B
description: Squashed into a sliver of an Alphabet City bar, patrons clapped into each others chests and tapped their toes long after midnight. Movement in any direction was futile.

title: Clintons to Meet With Foundations Big Donors Next Month
description: The most generous donors to the Bill, Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation will convene on June 6 at the Goldman Sachs headquarters in Lower Manhattan for a daylong event to discuss the familys philanthropy with the Clintons themselves.

title: Ex-Leader of Citigroup and Time Warner Is Appointed to Steer Clippers
description: As the N.B.A. pushes forward with its effort to strip Donald Sterling of his ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers, Commissioner Adam Silver on Friday installed Richard D. Parsons, the former chairman of Citigroup and the former chief executive of Time Warner, as the interim chief executive of the Clippers.

title: A Video Lesson in Antiques Market Shopping
description: Ts European editor Rita Konig visits Spitalfields Antiques Market in London, her go-to shopping destination for vintage kitchenalia and home goods that happen to be affordable. You find these old things, and I think that really adds to your home rather than everything being brand new, she says. While there, she finds items like linen pillowcases and a wool blanket, chats with the shopkeepers she has gotten to know on a first-name basis and shares her tips for shopping antiques markets.

title: Every Social Season Has Its Vortex
description: Bob Colacello has a saying, whenever he is asked about his sexuality: I believe in going out, not coming out. And that is just what the Vanity Fair special correspondent and one of the citys most photographed party animals did Wednesday night.

title: The Gun Report: May 9, 2014
description: Following last weeks open-carry demonstration at a Jack in the Box restaurant in Fort Worth, Tex., the chain has indicated that it will enforce its policy prohibiting firearms in any of its corporate-owned stores, which includes theFort Worthlocation.The presence of guns inside a restaurant could create an uncomfortable situation for our guests and employees and lead to unintended consequences, Brian Luscomb, the companys vice president of corporate communications, said in a statement.

title: Raising a Style Icon
description: It was as if Twitter had slipped into a 1968 time warp, and Sharon Tate, the star-crossed ingnue of the flower-child era, was suddenly the hot new thing in Hollywood.

title: Ask Well: Should I Get a Polio Booster?
description: The World Health Organization has declared polio a global health emergency. The Timess Donald G. McNeil Jr. answers readers questions about the vaccine.

title: A New Home for New York Theater Ballet
description: The New York Theater Ballet, a small but inventive and often feisty company that was told last September it would soon have to leave its headquarters for the last 34 years because the building was going to be razed, said on Friday it had found a new home. Starting in September, the company will move its offices and its training arm, the Ballet School NY, to St. Marks Church in-the-Bowery, on East 10th Street. The companys current office and studio space is at the parish house of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, on East 31st Street, and though it was originally told that it had to leave by Sept. 30 last year, the company was given a reprieve while it sought a new space.

title: Scallops With Sorrel Butter
description: Melissa Clark pan-sears sweet sea scallops and nestles them in a bright, grassy sauce of fresh sorrel and garlic.

title: Ask Well: New Questions About Polio Shots
description: Question:

title: Taking Advantage of Sorrels Brief Life
description: Im not much of a gardener, but when tiny green sorrel shoots start inching up from the pots on my deck every spring, I feel an undue sense of accomplishment. That this perennial herb is weedlike and nearly impossible to kill doesnt matter. I take pride in its vigor. And then I gleefully eat it up.

title: The Morning Muse of Television
description: This is the current state of play in the high-stakes world of morning TV.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Students, Please Welcome  Jeff Bezos?
description: Some children get visits at their schools from firefighters and police officers. Some get time with zookeepers bearing marsupials and iguanas.

title: Hairy Days Onstage
description: If ever there were a season to begin handing out Tony Awards for best wig, its this one. Theres big hair, like the Tina Turner meets My Little Pony explosion in Hedwig and the Angry Inch (with its showstopping Wig in a Box number). But there are also scores of modest but evocative hairstyles, like the frumpy comb-over worn by a loan shark in Rocky.

title: A Battery Warranty With a Warning
description: If youre considering the purchase of an electrified vehicle, youre likely to wonder about the warranty coverage for its battery pack, which can cost thousands of dollars to replace.

title: The Future Will See You Now
description: MALIBU, CALIF.  Good luck, America, with your efforts to pigeonhole the BMW i8.

title: Review | 2014 Cadillac ELR
description: Cadillac makes good on the promise of Art & Science.

title: Before the Final Last Call
description: On Friday night, the bar cars on Metro-Norths New Haven line will take their last ride.

title: Silence Is Golden, and Priced Accordingly
description: LOS ANGELES  In explaining the new ELR plug-in hybrid, a Cadillac spokesman offered this rationale: Mercedes-Benz doesnt have anything like this.

title: The Time of the Tummy
description: Seven Nation Army by the White Stripes was pulsating through the dimly lit Ab Attack class at Crunch gym near Union Square on a recent morning. Jewlie Williams, 25, a fashion stylist who lives in the East Village, was in front of the packed room, wearing a tank top and leggings and following the instructor in a 30-minute nonstop sequence of standing crunches with high knees, planks and toe touches with legs raised: all exercises focused on developing the muscles of the midsection.

title: Globetrotting Ambitions, With a Raw Bar
description: In an era of market-tested menus and copycat cuisines, theres usually a warm welcome awaiting any restaurant thats willing to branch out.

title: For the Love of Being Liked
description: Walking through an airport newsstand this year, I noticed a novelty. The covers of Inc., Fast Company and Time all had female executives on the covers: Sara Blakely, Angela Ahrendts and Janet L. Yellen. I quickly snapped a photo and sent out a tweet to my modest list of followers: Women on the cover. Not just for girlie magazines anymore.

title: New Twists in Turning Hot Air Into Horsepower
description: In the half-century since it first appeared under the hood of production cars, the turbocharger has gone from a silver-bullet amplifier of horsepower to a device so widely used it seems on its way to becoming a fixture of every new model.

title: How Powerful? Go Figure
description: How much power drives the Cadillac ELR? It depends on what you mean by power. And by drives.

title: For Diors Cruise Collection, a River View
description: First came the glass condo towers, then came Whole Foods, and now heres Christian Dior.

title: A Shiny New Toy From Cadillac, Battery Included
description: The Cadillac ELR is an intriguing engineering effort and a striking piece of modern automotive art. Whether it inspires buyers remains to be seen.

title: File Under Uncategorized
description: DOME, ARIZ.  Youre not going to take that bike down that road, are you?

title: Owners Who Are Happy When the Engine Doesnt Start
description: It started at the 2014 Portland Auto Show in Oregon with Dave Barthmuss of General Motors West Coast communications office mentioning offhandedly, yet with definite pride, that he had bought a Chevy Volt early last summer  and nine months later, he was still on the first tank of gas.

title: League Races in European Soccer
description: European soccer brings out its best silverware every May, but this year  because of the World Cup and a few impressive performances  the table has been set early. Several top leagues have crowned their champions, and the rest will do so in the next week before they send their best players home to pack for Brazil. Heres a look at the status of the title races in Europes big-five leagues:

title: The House of D.I.Y.
description: The drag balls of Upper Manhattan are known for their celebrations of elegance, realness and high-end designers. In Brooklyn they do things a little differently, as Stephanie Keith found out when she shot the second annual Mr(s) Williamsburg competition, a nine-week extravaganza where anything goes. Brooklyn is very D.I.Y., Ms. Keith said. You dont have to look like a girl to compete. These are people with a graduate degree from SUNY Purchase who are already performance artists. Theyre taking drag to a new place its never been before.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Still Feeding the Herd
description: The long, hard winter at last recedes, the heart springs up, and the mouth hungers for the foods of summer. Burger, anyone?

title: Week in Pictures for May 9
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the unveiling of the mayors housing plan, the exoneration of three men convicted of murder, and the aviary at the Queens Zoo.

title: Nicolas Ghesquires Designs in Monte Carlo, Charles Jamess Return and the Brooklynization of Dior
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Ike? They Liked
description: Imagine a time when White House photographers not only had access to the president, but also honored his skills with a camera.

title: On South Shore, the Lure of the Outdoors
description: In many places, waterfront dining conjures images of beachfront spots and vast expanses of water. On Long Island it often means a deck on a canal, as it does at Reel in East Rockaway.

title: Water, Flour, Yeast and Salt: A Love Story
description: If there is such a thing as a genius of dough making  and why shouldnt there be?  David DiBari would certainly seem to qualify.

title: In the Air | Tribal Beauty
description: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing design, art and fashion.

title: Cellist With a Feel for the Contemporary
description: The cellist Jay Campbell is part of a generation of young musicians with a fresh center of gravity in its repertory. At this point in Mr. Campbells career  he is a masters student at the Juilliard School  he should, by all traditional rights, be focusing on Beethoven, Brahms and the like, with perhaps a polite nod here and there to modern and contemporary music.

title: Orchestra Welcomes a Longtime Collaborator
description: Few doubt the skill and experience of the eminent maestro Bernard Haitink, celebrating the 60th anniversary of his conducting debut this season. But there is evidently some question about his consistency.

title: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Russia, Central African Republic, Syria and South Africa.

title: Obama Delivers Energy Speech at Walmart
description: President Obama wrapped up a week promoting energy policy at a Walmart in Mountain View, Calif. The speech focused on energy efficiency and renewable energy initiatives.

title: Seems Like a Nice Guy. So What if Hes Dead?
description: You probably shouldnt draw conclusions about a countrys national character from how it approaches zombie stories. But its interesting to note that while the American hit The Walking Dead is about sheer survival, the British show In the Flesh is about acceptance and reconciliation, themes it shares with the French series Les Revenants. In America, zombies just want to chow down on you; in Europe, they want to get reacquainted with you and work through all your unresolved issues.

title: Paul Diverges From His Party Over Voter ID
description: MEMPHIS  Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky broke Friday with fellow Republicans who have pushed for stricter voting laws as a way to crack down on fraud at the polls, saying that the focus on such measures alienates and insults African-Americans and hurts the party.

title: Colorado Lawmaker to Accept Donations in Bitcoin
description: Jared Polis may be the first politician to accept campaign donations in Bitcoin.

title: Meteorite Falls on Car, Car Becomes Artwork
description: In 1992 in Peekskill, N.Y., a 4.4-billion-year-old, 26-pound asteroid chunk fell on a 1980 Chevy Malibu. The car soon became famous in meteorite-collecting circles (yes, they exist) and has since traveled all around the world. It will go on view tomorrow for the first time in a fine-art context, at Mark Hagens self-curated show at Marlborough Chelsea, Guest Star, a title that slyly evokes both the rock that did the damage and to Hagens own status in New York (the Los Angeles-based artist is unrepresented in the city). I love the fact that its a man-made object thats been sculpted by alien hands, Hagen says of the car. I believe in alien life.

title: Philip Roth Says He Has Given His Last Public Reading
description: Philip Roth made headlines a year and a half ago with the announcement that he had stopped writing fiction.

title: Fairy Tale Romances, Real and Staged
description: Kiko Zeng and Eric Chengs courtship plays out like something out of a storybook. It is love at first sight. Their first touch is a shy, slow-motion handshake, with neither wanting to let go, until friends pull them apart.

title: In a Mosh Pit, or Maybe a Revolution
description: One by one, they arrived: nine people armed with sticks and facing off as if for a rumble. Rather than striking one another, though, they struck the cymbals on the four drum kits arrayed on the stage and kept striking them. Maud Le Pladecs Democracy started not with one bang but with many.

title: For Better Credit Score, Max Out Payments, Not the Card
description: CREDIT reports, which track your management of credit cards and loans, increasingly include more details about when and how you pay your debts over time. Whether that extra information will eventually have a broad impact on your credit scores  the three-digit numbers that summarize your credit report and are used by lenders to size you up  remains to be seen.

title: Letting an Ensemble Complete Him
description: Christian aTunde Adjuah has a firm, cold flash of a trumpet sound, like the glint off a brandished switchblade. For what seems like the entirety of his playing career, since his anointed adolescence in New Orleans, he has deployed that sound with an effortful assurance: rallying support with it, building bands around it, making it the base currency of his brisk economy of style.

title: Pass the Bong, and Tune Up the Berlioz
description: When the Colorado Symphony announced recently that it would hold a series of bring-your-own-marijuana fund-raisers, called Classically Cannabis: The High Note Series, sponsored by the states newly legal cannabis industry, the orchestra got laughs on late-night talk shows and was featured in publications that rarely cover classical music, including High Times.

title: Big Operas Den Mother Moves On
description: At the end of a long week of work one recent Friday, Sarah Billinghurst worked some more.

title: His Psyche Lurks Inside His Scripts
description: Three books sit on a side table at John Logans hotel suite on Central Park South: Mark Harriss Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood, a history of the best picture nominees at the 1968 Oscars; a collection of English Romantic poetry; and a novelization from the 1984-96 TV series Murder, She Wrote. Together, they represent the breadth of this dramatists interests.

title: Swamp Pop and Old Faves in the Countryside
description: The British singer Lily Allen was at her home in the English countryside, baking a carrot cake, complete with marzipan carrots. This is like my third one with these particular carrots, and Ive kind of got it down, she said by telephone. Im quite pleased. She posted a photo of the perfectly turned-out cake, frosted and dusted with powdered sugar, on her Instagram account, with the hashtag Sheezus, the name of her new album. For Ms. Allen, 29, domestic bliss can align with pop stardom.

title: Top of the Line
description: At American Ballet Theater, where international stars zip on and off the stage like point shoes on a conveyor belt, there is gratification in knowing your corps de ballet. Along with the soloists, these dancers constitute the heart of the company, which opens its spring season Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Today, in the Role of Flower Girl: Grandma
description: Like many good ideas, it started in jest.

title: The Spring Foursomes in Stratford-upon-Avon
description: Top tennis players travel the world to compete in tournaments. Now the best bridge players do, too.

title: The Changing of Ethiopia, in Photos
description: From rural villages and urban centers, Michael Tsegaye has been showing how his homeland has been changing, even if outsiders perceptions have not.

title: Concerts of Mystery and Imagination
description: Spring for Music, the annual festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, was created in large part to encourage adventurous programming and has in its four years produced odd juxtapositions within concerts, typically with some thematic goal in view. But when it comes to juxtaposing whole programs, anything goes, and the results can be mind-bending.

title: The Older Cling to Jobs, Crowding Out the Younger
description: THE proportion of Americans with jobs fell sharply during the Great Recession, and has barely begun to recover, according to overall figures.

title: Events in Connecticut for May 11-17, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: A Storied Rivalry Touching Familiar Bases
description: Theres a clever new offering at the Goodspeed Opera Houses concession counter these days  boxes of Cracker Jack. They help put audiences in a suitable frame of mind for Damn Yankees, the wonderful 1955 musical that won a slew of Tonys and taught the world that you gotta have heart.

title: Literary Help Sending a Shiver Down Your Spine
description: Television is clogged with lurid supernatural fare these days  Salem, The Walking Dead, American Horror Story, The Originals  so staking out a distinctive place within the genre isnt easy. Penny Dreadful tries to do so with a combination of literary allusion, fine acting, patience and fearlessness, which, at least for the first two episodes, clicks deliciously. Oh dear; another show to add to our ever-growing guilty-pleasure lists.

title: A Hotel With Spirit From 1971
description: A hotel is an imitation of home, a home once removed. So what would it feel like to spend the night in an imitation of a hotel? And what if that imitation hotel was really a kind of artwork based on an older imitation of a hotel that was itself partly based on a hotel that existed only in a movie?

title: Simple Pleasures
description: This issue might seem to have little to do with style: walking in nature, swimming in the ocean, eating supper under the stars or setting out to a distant locale.

title: Who Is That Lady in the Painting?
description: Making its first trip to the United States more than four centuries after its creation, Parmigianinos renowned, beguiling portrait of a turbaned woman  known since the early 18th century as Schiava Turca, or the Turkish slave, from 1531-34  will go on view Tuesday at the Frick Collection, bringing along the question that has long trailed it: Who was she? Almost certainly neither Turkish nor a slave, an identification that came about in error because of her exotic costume. Some have wondered whether the woman was real at all or maybe just a feminine ideal dreamed up by the painter. But Aimee Ng, a research associate at the Frick and the shows curator, has a new theory based on subtle clues in the portrait: that she might have been Veronica Gambara, an accomplished poet in Parmigianinos circle.

title: Still Elusive: Brahms, in Concert
description: Brahms is naturally grouped with composers from the Romantic era, but many historians speak of Brahms the Classicist, who strove to reconcile the forms and genres of Viennese classicism with the experiments of the mid-19th century. Then again, Schoenberg titled an influential essay Brahms the Progressive, analyzing the Brahms who explored daring harmonic paths and, in his late works, even anticipated the breakdown of tonality.

title: Joyce Theater Goes to the Dog
description: Dance at the Joyce Theater tends to stay at a safe distance, the fourth wall intact. But through a new initiative, Joyce Unleashed, the theater is expanding its reach, presenting work that doesnt square so neatly with the trappings of a traditional stage. So long, Chelsea. The Joyce is heading to Brooklyn.

title: Two Singular Sensations
description: Creativity brings disorientation  or vice versa?  in the music of two songwriters and sonic experimenters in town this week: Son Lux and Chad VanGaalen. Ryan Lott, who records as Son Lux, has collaborated widely with musicians like Sufjan Stevens and Lorde. In songs that lean toward the reflective  What will we do now?/Weve lost it to trying, one goes  his music encompasses pinpoint orchestral arrangements as well as electronics that can be glitchy, glossy and dizzying. Son Lux appears Tuesday, sharing a bill with the guitarist Rafiq Bhatia as part of the Undead Music series. (8 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

title: In a Blaze of Confusion
description: Documentaries dont come more sparse or more disturbing than Let the Fire Burn, Jason Osders examination of the disastrous confrontation between the police and the radical group MOVE in Philadelphia in May 1985.

title: Grids and Steel Spanning Great Divides
description: The grid was one of the reigning motifs of 20th-century American art, but few artists have treated it with as much versatility as Jennifer Bartlett. Ms. Bartlett came of age in the 70s, following minimalist artists for whom the grid was a kind of talisman, a model of mathematical consistency that cut through the existential drips and heroic angst of the Abstract Expressionists. Ms. Bartlett added some things that made the grid pleasingly weird, however, several of which are apparent in the 26 works in the grandly titled Jennifer Bartlett: History of the Universe  Works 1970-2011 at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill. (History of the Universe is also the title of Ms. Bartletts autobiographical novel, published in 1985.)

title: Hot Ice: The Tortuous Tale of the Pear-Shaped Diamond
description: The thought struck Steven Zaretsky during a party two years ago, when he looked over at his wife and the 7.35-carat, pear-shaped diamond hanging on a thin chain around her neck. It had been a gift from her father to her mother, and later, to her. What was it insured for? When was the last time it had been certified and appraised?

title: A Second Union, to a Commune and Each Other
description: GUILFORD, Vt.  For Verandah Porche, there was never any question about where the wedding would take place. This is home, she said, waving an arm to encompass the rambling house, the rickety outbuildings, the steep fields and the gnarled orchard that make up Packer Corners, the storied commune that Ms. Porche helped found in 1968. It was also the site of her first marriage to the groom, Richard H. Coutant, in 1979.

title: D.J. Whoo Kid: A Social Media Butterfly
description: D.J. Whoo Kid got his start making mixtapes, so long ago that he actually made them on tapes. He has D.J.d for 50 Cent and G-Unit, and is currently the spicy-tongued host of the Sirius XM satellite radio program The Whoolywood Shuffle, where he interviews rap stars and entertainers as far afield as Willie Nelson (he asked the octogenarian Mr. Nelson whether he still got groupies). Born Yves Mondesir 42 years ago in Queens, he lives in Battery Park City and regularly spends time in New Jersey with his estranged wife and two teenage sons. I havent been called by my real name in 20 years, he said.

title: Celebrating Old Times With New: A Premiere
description: New York City Ballets spring gala on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was, for many reasons, exciting. Above all, it celebrated the companys 50 years at Lincoln Center. And the evening reached its climax with a sensational world premiere: Justin Pecks 42-minute new ballet, Everywhere We Go, a work both diffuse and brilliant whose rich supply of configurations, phrases and rhythms often (if not always) suggests that young Mr. Peck can do anything he wants with choreography: a virtuoso of the form.

title: Summer Travel Issue
description: Whether its the design of a hotel suite, the search for a perfect pair of swim trunks or the everyday act of getting around on foot, Ts summer travel issue highlights the power of simplicity. We start in Todos Santos, Mexico, a laid-back surf town whose hippie vibes and reliable waves make it easy to pack light  a bathing suit and a few summertime knits should do. We visit India, where the bohemian designer Loulou Van Damme has channeled her effortless style into a guesthouse in the scenic Palani Hills. And in New York City, we step inside the Greenwich Hotel, where the renowned Belgian antiques dealer Axel Vervoordt has introduced modest luxury by way of a three-story penthouse created in his own wabi-sabi aesthetic. Elsewhere, the ladies of the Ferragamo dynasty line up for a special multigenerational portrait; the MoMA PS1 director Klaus Biesenbach parties with friends in Rockaway, Queens, where hes become the communitys loudest champion; our critic at large Andrew OHagan writes about the transformative power of swimming while searching for the holy grail of trunks; and a trio of artists make time to break bread with their staffs. See all stories from the issue >>

title: A Patent Surfaces Detailing a Facebook Smartphone
description: Over the last several years, there have been dozens of reports about Facebook building a smartphone.

title: More Opposition to the LG Headquarters Beside the Palisades
description: Opposition keeps growing to a proposed new American headquarters for LG Electronics USA, the tech giant, beside Palisades Park in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The National Trust for Historic Preservation will announce Monday that it has designated the Palisades as a National Treasure.

title: Ben Hoberman, 91, Pioneer of All-Talk Radio, Is Dead
description: Ben Hoberman, a radio executive who in 1960 helped start an influential and enduring trend when he transformed the middle-of-the-road music station he was managing, KABC in Los Angeles, into what is generally considered the first 24-hour all-talk station in the country, died on May 3 in Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: A Successor to Colbert Is Named
description: What comes after The Colbert Report?

title: Step Forward Into Past for British Gay Couples: Coats of Arms
description: LONDON  First, same-sex couples in Britain won the right to civil partnerships, then to full marriage. Now, they can have their own coats of arms.

title: Strolling an Island of Creativity
description: The amazing spectacle that is Frieze New York is up and running on Randalls Island. With more than 190 contemporary art dealers from around the world inhabiting a temporary, quarter-mile-long white tent, its a dumbfounding display of human creative industry. Reasoning that in the time allowed, no one reviewer could hope to achieve a comprehensive overview of all there is to see, we both went to look and report. What follows is a sampler of things that caught our attention.

title: Football, Minus the Draft
The Fiery Return of the Political Son
description: Despite some rough edges, A View of the Mountains is an easy enough play to like. Over its 75 minutes this political satire, at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, raises a couple of questions, launches a few zingers and features a plot twist or two. Not everything here succeeds. But taken together, enough works to make it all worthwhile.

title: South Korea: Victims Parents Assail President Over Governments Response to Ferry Accident
description: Parents of high school students killed in the capsizing of a South Korean ferry marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in Seoul on Friday as prosecutors continued to try to determine who was responsible for the accident that killed hundreds of people. The parents, holding photos of their children, said they had come to ask for a meeting with Ms. Park to demand an inquiry into accusations that a slow and ineffective response by her government drastically increased the number of deaths. Two senior presidential aides met family representatives while hundreds of parents and their supporters staged a sit-in for 12 hours near the presidential palace. Meanwhile, prosecutors said Friday that they were seeking to arrest Kim Han-sik, the head of the Chonghaejin Marine Company, which operated the ferry, on charges of ignoring the overloading of the vessel. They were also looking into a family that owns a company that controls Chonghaejin Marine.

title: Italy: Berlusconi Begins His Community Service
description: Dodging a scrum of reporters, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy on Friday began serving his sentence for tax fraud at a nursing home outside Milan. Mr. Berlusconi, 77, was ordered to serve a year of community service, and he will spend four hours a week assisting Alzheimers patients. He did not stop to speak with reporters, slipping in and out of the nursing home, which is in Cesano Boscone. On Thursday, he told a radio station that he was certain that he would be able to help those in need and that the experience would enrich him. He also said that he had been studying the latest treatments for Alzheimers.

title: Republicans Tighten Grip on Debates in 2016 Race
description: MEMPHIS  The Republican National Committee moved Friday to seize control of the presidential primary debates in 2016, another step in a coordinated effort by the party establishment to reshape the nominating process.

title: Afghanistan: British Military to Investigate Photo of Soldier Cavorting Next to Dead Insurgent
description: Britains Defense Ministry said Friday that it had begun an investigation after graphic photos surfaced appearing to show at least one British service member posing next to the corpse of a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2012. In one of the photos, a member of the military is kneeling next to a body and giving a thumbs-up sign, recalling some previous images of Western personnel in Afghanistan and Iraq that caused widespread offense in those countries. This type of behavior is unacceptable and will not be tolerated, said a statement from the Royal Air Force. A defense official confirmed news media reports in Britain that the incident took place after an attack by insurgents on Camp Bastion, the main British military base in Afghanistans Helmand Province. The photographs surfaced first on a website called Live Leak and were reproduced on many British newsweb sites with peoples faces concealed.

title: Funny, You Look Familiar
description: They could have called it Comas and Clones. But Hudson Stage, presenting its last production in Briarcliff Manor before moving to Armonk this fall, has chosen a more dignified route and labeled its evening of two British one-acts  one by Harold Pinter and one by Caryl Churchill  Family Reunion.

title: Librarys Change of Plan: Long Overdue, or a Mistake?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Suspended in Oregon Sexual Assault Case
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Three University of Oregon basketball players accused of sexually assaulting a fellow student two months ago have been suspended and will not return to the team, the university president Michael R. Gottfredson said at a news conference Friday.

title: U.S. and the Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pulverized Prize Changes Hands, Peacefully, in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The last busloads of insurgents left the battered Old City of Homs in central Syria on Friday, under a deal handing over the longtime bastion of rebellion to the government after nearly two years of blockade and bombardment.

title: Events in Westchester for May 11-17, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: The Environmental and Health Hazards of Gas Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: Evening Hours | Petals and Medals
description: Toasting Isabella Stewart Gardner, Charles James and several worthy causes.

title: Dogs in Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | The Met Ball
description: The designer Charles James (1906-78) is the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Bill Cunningham | Remembering Charles James
description: The designer Charles James (1906 to 1978), the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, rose to prominence after World War II during what could be deemed the twilight of splendor, with the height of his career roughly from 1948 to 1957. There was never a question that he was a master couturier. A lone eagle in a world of commercial dressmaking, he was an architect and a sculptor whose medium happened to be cloth. He may have been known for his majestic evening dresses, but his real genius was in coats; he even came up with the first puffer coat.

title: Death Toll Rising, 2 Sides Sign Pact to End South Sudan War
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  President Salva Kiir of South Sudan and the leader of the rebellion against his government, Riek Machar, signed an agreement on Friday to resolve the war that has torn their young country apart.

title: Review of Marijuana Law Exposes List of Conflicts Between Jurisdictions
description: WASHINGTON  If Congress allows a District of Columbia law to take effect that would decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, and someone with one foot on the National Mall and another foot on city property is caught carrying the drug, would that person be charged with a crime under federal law?

title: Events on Long Island for May 11-17, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Agency Urges Quake Study for Indian Point
description: The Indian Point power plant is one of 10 sites considered most in need for a re-evaluation of earthquake vulnerability, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced on Friday.

title: Where the Girls Are
description: This election season is going to be all about women.

title: Apples Pursuit of Beats May Foretell a Shift
description: Has streaming musics moment in the mainstream finally come? Or is it here already, and has Apple  once the great innovator of music technology  finally caught on?

title: Why Divestment Fails
description: LOS ANGELES  TONIGHT, the 20,000 students at Stanford will sleep more soundly. Earlier this week, a group called Fossil Free Stanford persuaded the universitys endowment to divest its stock holdings from coal-mining companies. The world will be a better place.

title: Brunei Ownership Casts a Shadow on a Beverly Hills Hotel
description: LOS ANGELES  For longer than most here care to remember, Arthur Cohn, a producer of The Garden of the Finzi-Continis, which won an Oscar in 1972, has staged an intimate pre-Academy Awards dinner for friends, movie stars and others at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

title: Ford Recalls Vehicles for Air Bag Flaw
description: The three Detroit automakers announced vehicle recalls on Friday, though they said none of the defects had resulted in accidents or injuries.

title: How to End State Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON  GOV. RICK PERRY of Texas scored a big victory last week in his effort to lure companies from other states to his own, successfully offering $40 million to Toyota to relocate its American sales headquarters (and 4,000 jobs) from California. Texas is also one of five states  along with California, Arizona, New Mexico and Nevada  that are bidding against one another for a new Tesla Motors factory that will employ up to 6,500 people.

title: Joe Wilder, Horn Player, Dies at 92; Elegance Was His Theme Song
description: Joe Wilder, a lyrical trumpeter who played with some of the biggest big bands in jazz and helped integrate Broadway, radio and television orchestras, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Reducing Obesity: A Progress Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Exit of the Midwests Winter Buries Gardens in a Deep Freeze
description: MUKWONAGO, Wis.  The freakishly cold Midwestern winter of 2014 has given way to the frustrated Midwestern gardener.

title: In Ukrainian City Under Blockade, Citizens Go to Ground, and Below
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Tatyana Vsevolodovna stood in the cool basement beneath her kitchen, displaying a households preparations for war.

title: Experts Seek Smarter Black Boxes for Automobiles
description: A design flaw in the Chevrolet Cobalt and other small cars has led to deaths and injuries for at least a decade, but the analysts at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration never opened an investigation. All through that period, a few blocks away at a sister agency within the Transportation Department, safety experts were using a program that made extensive use of vehicle data to spot defects and dangerous trends.

title: Memo Revisits Policy on Citing Leaked Material, to Some Confusion
description: WASHINGTON  The Office of the Director of National Intelligence sent an internal memo to its work force on Friday saying that its new policy on pre-publication review of speeches, books, articles, term papers and other writings permits current and former employees to refer to news articles as long as the officials do not confirm any classified information.

title: Rare View Into Inner Workings of N.B.A.
description: It is a 78-page document full of mind-numbing legalese, including a four-page glossary and countless references to entities, guarantors and provisions.

title: Ad Agencies Dust Off and Focus on Future After Collapse of Merger Deal
description: PARIS  The worlds biggest advertising merger had just slipped through his hands.

title: One Big, Happy Budget
description: The first executive budget of a new mayor sets the tone for an administration. In Bill de Blasios case, its the now-familiar one of happy optimism, where all the values are progressive, the conversations civil, spending rises freely, and whatever pain is so spread out and mixed in with the good news that you hardly know its there.

title: In High Seas, China Moves Unilaterally
description: BEIJING  It is the pride of Chinas state-run oil industry and the nations first deepwater drilling rig, a vessel as big as a football field and as tall as a 40-story building, with a $1 billion price tag. Last week, it crawled through the South China Sea, pulled by heavy-duty tugs, and parked in one of the most sensitive spots possible, about 17 miles off a speck of an island claimed by both China and Vietnam.

title: U.S. Officers Kill Armed Civilians in Yemen Capital
description: WASHINGTON  A United States Special Operations commando and a Central Intelligence Agency officer in Yemen shot and killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them while the Americans were in a barbershop in the countrys capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.

title: Squeezed by Povertys Grip in California
description: Californias Inland Empire, east of Los Angeles, has attracted people expecting to live out the American dream. But with jobs and services scarce, the region has a high poverty rate.

title: Citys New Fire Commissioner Vows a Push for More Minorities in the Department
description: The new commissioner of the New York Fire Department vowed on Friday to put an end to an era of lawsuits and court orders over the departments persistent lack of diversity and to lead an effort to attract more minorities.

title: Trouble in the South China Sea
description: China has dangerously increased tensions in the South China Sea by deploying an oil  rig for the first time in a disputed area claimed by Vietnam. The move is certain to make countries in the region feel even more threatened by Chinas expansionist territorial claims. The rig, belonging to a state-owned oil company, was parked in waters off the Paracel Islands on May 2. After Vietnam objected, China dispatched 80 ships to the area; Hanoi responded by sending 35 ships to obstruct the rigs operations.

title: Writers Feel an Amazon-Hachette Spat
description: The worlds biggest bookstore is a bit smaller these days.

title: Hardship Makes a New Home in the Suburbs
description: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  The freeway exits around here are dotted with people asking for money, holding cardboard signs to tell their stories. The details vary only slightly and almost invariably include: Laid off. Need food. Young children.

title: Ex-Deputy in Arizona Kept Cache of Evidence
description: PHOENIX  Evidence bags containing drugs, hundreds of drivers licenses and other items were retrieved last week from the home of a former Maricopa County sheriffs deputy who was found dead there apparently of suicide on Thursday when officers showed up to arrest him.

title: Blooms Return to Washington Square Park After Years of Renovation
description: The park had changed drastically from the days in the 1950s when Bobby Fischer used to come to play, Lamont Holloway said as he sat in gold-framed sunglasses at a chessboard and waited for a tourist or fellow hustler in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village.

title: Like-Minded Russians Visit Occupy Wall Street Inmate at Rikers Island
description: Most people disappear from the headlines into the gray anonymity of Rikers Island after they are found guilty in state court in Manhattan.

title: Dalai Lama Urges Outside Inquiry Into Spate of Self-Immolations Among Tibetans
description: The Dalai Lama, Tibets spiritual leader in exile, on Friday called for an outside inquiry into the self-immolations of more than 130 Tibetans in anti-China demonstrations over the past five years, and he suggested that in some cases, such acts of protest were understandable and not entirely wrong.

title: Dumbledore in the NICU
description: My daughter is lying in Bed No. 3, a clear plastic box in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. She is attached to the wall by a jangle of colored wires, each tracking the strength of her uncertain grasp on this world. She is 6 days old.

title: Germanys Pursuit of Death Camp Guards
description: With time running out, a new generation of criminal prosecutors in Germany has opened dozens of fresh investigations into long-dormant cases of death-camp guards suspected of culpable roles in the Nazi genocide machine. Men and women left to live in freedom for decades after World War II are finally being scrutinized for their work in the camps, with modern technology like 3-D visualizations of the camps being used to contradict their claims that they never were able to witness the ghastly routines of the Holocaust.

title: Teams Build on Defense in 2nd Round of Draft
description: Quarterbacks typically dominate the headlines in the first round of the N.F.L. draft, and this years edition was no different.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 9, 2014
Slovyansk: An Unlikely Flashpoint in Ukraine Crisis
description: Once a quiet industrial city, Slovyansk is now strained by the conflicting pulls of disbelief, pride, anger, and anticipation.

title: Hidden From the Operas Crowd Is a Human Safety Net
description: Chances are that even devoted regulars at the Metropolitan Opera are not familiar with Donna Racik.

title: Its Big in the Suburbs
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I appreciated the Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy advice at 18 Across: DONT PANIC, indeed. I must confess that I used to be intimidated by Mr. Silks byline; Now that Im a Big Girl Solver, I find his puzzles to hit the sweet spot between challenging, but solvable and sparkling with entries that are both cleverly clued and fun to write in the grid.

title: A Performer Whose Love of Baseball Is No Act
description: When Adam Wainwright struck out Carlos Beltran to clinch the 2006 National League pennant for the St. Louis Cardinals, hearts broke all over Shea Stadium. But one fan in the third-base stands rejoiced.

title: The Power of the Street
description: The tangled events leading up to World War I are much written about this centennial year, and one striking element is the power of the street to push history in unexpected and sometimes tragic directions when popular passions are either deliberately fired by demagogues or aroused by tribal loyalties, ethnic myths, xenophobia or legitimate frustration.

title: Body of Fashion Designer, Missing Since March, Is Identified
description: A body pulled from the water in Brooklyn has been identified as that of an emerging fashion designer missing since March.

title: Kings-Ducks Series Grips Southern California
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  On Thursday night, the competition for sports fans viewership was crowded and would seemingly be dominated by the first round of the N.F.L. draft.

title: With Top Ranking in Play, Two Outsiders Take Charge
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The world No. 1 ranking was the trending topic early in the week at TPC Sawgrass, with pros turning into amateur statisticians to figure out where Adam Scott, Henrik Stenson, Bubba Watson and Matt Kuchar needed to finish to supplant the injured Tiger Woods from the top spot.

title: Jets Top Pick, Once a Point Guard, Now Revels in His Physical Play
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When football season ended, basketball came right afterward, and the transition was jarring to Calvin Pryor. His fouls left bruises. He bowled over opposing players. Instead of drawing contact, he inflicted it.

title: A Hundred Visions and Revisions
description: How did Hitchcock make cinematic gold out of the demons of his private dreams? David Rudkins The Lovesong of Alfred J. Hitchcock pries the lid off Hitchcocks psyche, the better to peer in and consider the ghosts and ordeals that Mr. Rudkin sees as the fuel of his art.

title: Giants Add a Center, the First Taken in the Draft
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants went for a flashy pick in the first round of the N.F.L. draft Thursday when they took the swift, dynamic and multifaceted wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. But the tradition-bound Giants did not live on the edge for long.

title: Grieving Star Inspires a Rout by the Rangers
description: PITTSBURGH  Facing playoff elimination on the road and inspired by the presence of Martin St. Louis, who was playing a night after his mother died, the Rangers put forth their best effort of the postseason on Friday, thrashing the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-1, in Game 5.

title: Grand Prix Blazes New Trail at Indianapolis Speedway
description: In the 105 years since racing began at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, there has never been an IndyCar event quite like Saturdays Grand Prix.

title: A Tough Stretch for Tom Wheeler on Net Neutrality
description: Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has had a tough month.

title: Its Gadgets vs. Eyeballs as Two Species of Bird-Watchers Clash
description: Pete Dunne and Benjamin Van Doren are devout birders who share a passion for identifying rare species, recording their sightings and competing in birding events known as Big Days.

title: Two Boys Abducted After Mother Is Fatally Stabbed
description: The authorities in New Jersey issued an Amber Alert on Friday night for two boys who the police say were abducted by their father at school after their mother was stabbed to death.

title: Tight End Fills Jets Needs
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The biggest boon for the development of a young quarterback is a superior tight end, and the Jets believe they found one with their second-round pick.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 10, 2014
description: The two words you dont want to hear on the bar car. Last call.

title: Tanakas Bat Is Quiet, but He Makes Sure the Brewers Match Him
description: MILWAUKEE  It was Saturday morning in Japan, and a big day for baseball fans there. NHK, the national television network, was broadcasting the Yankees game against the Milwaukee Brewers at Miller Park on Friday night. The Japanese sensation Masahiro Tanaka was starting for the Yankees and looking to extend his remarkable unbeaten streak.

title: A Soggy Start to the Weekend
description: More showers are expected Saturday, though Sunday is expected to be mostly sunny, just in time for Mothers Day.

title: Remembering a Young Grandfather Lost
Shortstop Provides Lift, but the Mets Fall
description: The Mets, starved for runs, appeared to trade offense for defense when they recalled shortstop Wilmer Flores from the minor leagues on Friday. Flores, considered a good hitter, is something of a positional conundrum.

title: Signatures on Petitions for Conyers Fall Short
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John Conyers Jr., who has represented the Detroit area in the House for almost 50 years, is in danger of not making the ballot for an August primary because his petitions may be disqualified for not containing enough signatures.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) PRISONERS (2013) Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), a grief-stricken father in a small Pennsylvania town, contemplates the torture and murder of the man (Paul Dano, above right, with Mr. Jackman) he believes has kidnapped his daughter and her friend in this thriller, directed by Denis Villeneuve. Maria Bello plays Dovers wife, submerged in despair; Viola Davis and Terrence Howard are the other girls parents, whose doubts about Dovers means of extracting information strike him as weak and irrational; Melissa Leo is the suspects aunt, intent on shielding her mentally disabled nephew; and Jake Gyllenhaal is the tormented cop determined to solve the case. Prisoners is the kind of movie that can quiet a room full of casual thrill-seekers, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It absorbs and controls your attention with such assurance that you hold your breath for fear of distracting the people on screen, exhaling in relief or amazement at each new revelation. By the end you may be a little worn out, and perhaps also slightly let down by the fussily clever revelations that wrap up the story, but in the meantime you are a willing captive, unable to tell the difference between dread and delight.

title: A Second Conversation With: Times Now Editor Arnab Goswami
description: Arnab Goswami, editor in chief of the Times Now television channel, is the only journalist to have interviewed the two main contenders in the Indian national elections: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Indian National Congress party, and Narendra Modi, prime ministerial candidate of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

title: Corrections: May 10, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Philippines Jails Chinese Sailors in Fish Dispute
description: HONG KONG  Raising the stakes in its confrontation with China, the Philippines said Saturday that it had imprisoned 11 Chinese fishermen who were caught with endangered sea turtles in a part of the South China Sea that is claimed by both nations.

title: Ike? They Liked
description: There are award-winning presidential photographs  though not lately  and sometimes there are award-winning photographs taken by presidents.

title: Analytics: The Jungle of the Law
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 11 issue of the magazine.

title: Under Cover: Martin Schoeller on Photographing Timothy Geithner
description: Martin Schoeller, a New York-based photographer who has taken pictures of the powerful and famous for more than 20 years, often bathes his subjects in fluorescent light and shows them in extreme close-ups. The results can be unnerving for viewers, who suddenly come face to face with the likes of President Obama, Clint Eastwood and Angelina Jolie.

title: Possible Path to Closing Pay Gap
description: Its 2014, and women are still paid less than men. Does this suggest that a gender pay gap is an unfortunately permanent fixture? Will it still be with us in 50 years? I would predict yes. But by that point, it will be men who will be earning less than women.

title: The Role of Education and Health Care in Fostering Sustainable Motherhood
description: Sustainable motherhood?

title: 1914: Lillian Nordica Succumbs to Pneumonia
description: BATAVIA, Java  Mme. Nordica was on board the steamship Tasman when that vessel ran ashore in the Torres Straits of the Gulf of Papua on December 27 of last year. The liner got off and proceeded to Thursday Island, which was reached on December 31. All were well on board, with the exception of the prima donna, who was then suffering from nervous prostration. Finally, on reaching Java, it became evident she could go no further for some time to come. After remaining at Batavia for several weeks, she has succumbed in consequence of her determination.

title: First Lady Condemns Abduction of Nigerian Schoolgirls
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare venture into foreign policy, Michelle Obama on Saturday condemned the abduction of more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls by terrorists and said that she and President Obama had been personally touched by what she called an unconscionable act.

title: In Ceremonial Transfer, Remains of 9/11 Victims Are Moved to Memorial
description: On the granite plaza of the World Trade Center memorial, families of Sept. 11 victims gathered on Saturday morning beneath mist-shrouded skyscrapers to watch as the unidentified remains of people killed there more than 12 years ago were moved to what may be their final resting place.

title: An Alluring Summer Song, Echoed Through Eight World Cups
description: The World Cup could never get better than this, but I had no way of knowing it in 1982, my first time.

title: A Simple Theory, and a Proposal, on H.I.V. in Africa
description: OTIMATI, South Africa  While around the world a vast majority of AIDS victims are men, Africa has long been the glaring exception: Nearly 60 percent are women. And while there are many theories, no one has been able to prove one.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 33
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: A Potent Power Play Does Not Ensure a Path to the Stanley Cup
description: The Rangers went 2 for 3 on the power play in Friday nights 5-1 victory against the Pittsburgh Penguins after having failed on 36 consecutive chances, the longest postseason power-play drought since 2007. Asked if the Rangers had done anything differently, Coach Alain Vigneault said no.

title: Carl Galioto, on Sweeping Away the Negative Energy
description: This interview with  Carl Galioto, managing principal of the New York office of HOK, an architecture and engineering firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Variety: The Diagramless Puzzle That Wouldnt Leave
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I had a little bit of trouble getting started with Fred Piscops diagramless puzzle, but once I got my toehold, it seemed like the grid just went on forever. Thats not an opinion on the solve. Its actually the theme.

title: A Basketball Life of Harsh Reality, Starkly Revisited
description: As he sat in the darkness watching a new documentary about his life, Allen Iverson conceded that he was initially jolted by the film. Its one thing to have been an N.B.A. star who lived in the moment, quite another to watch those moments parade, unfiltered, across a movie screen.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, May 10
description: Investors are longing for growth  and heres a company that really has it.

title: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, and Lately, Coding
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.  Seven-year-old Jordan Lisle, a second grader, joined his family at a packed after-hours school event last month aimed at inspiring a new interest: computer programming.

title: An Upscale Burger Chain From New Zealand Aims at U.S.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Inside the headquarters of BurgerFuel Worldwide is a spray-painted mural of a skull wearing a combat helmet emblazoned with the slogan Born to Grill.

title: Suspended Animation, on a Hollywood Set
description: The director yelled Action! I could feel the wheels of the gurney moving but had no idea where I was headed: I had been instructed to keep my eyes closed. (Was I dead? In a coma? Asleep? Catatonic? No back story was proffered.) There was a quick turn to the left, then a straightaway for 10 feet or so, then another turn, this one to the right.

title: 2 Yemenis Shot by Americans Are Linked to Qaeda Cell
description: SANA, Yemen  The kidnappers pulled up in a pickup truck outside the Taj barbershop in an upscale neighborhood here in the Yemeni capital. One held an AK-47 assault rifle and the other carried a stun gun. As the men went inside, nearby shopkeepers heard shots.

title: Craft Brewers, Finding a Better Seat at the Bar
description: Theres a great moment in Steve Hindys shaggy little history of the craft beer industry, The Craft Beer Revolution, in which Jim Koch, the sharp-elbowed maker of Samuel Adams, loses his temper at the author, himself a brewer of note. It comes after a 1993 industry meeting in which Mr. Hindy and others circulated a petition that questioned Mr. Kochs marketing claims. As Mr. Hindy describes it, Mr. Koch accuses him of trying to subvert his business, shouting at him over and over and using far more colorful language than I am allowed to relate here.

title: Two Found Dead After Balloon Catches Fire
description: The authorities searched a wooded area in Virginia on Saturday for a rider believed to have been killed when a hot-air balloon carrying three people caught fire on Friday night and crashed at a festival.

title: His Passport Took a Two-Year Vacation (Without Him)
description: Its been a little over two years since the Hagglers passport vanished. Longtime readers may recall the particulars: While visiting Stanford University, the Haggler had his passport shipped from Manhattan overnight via United Parcel Service, for a quick and unscheduled trip to Canada. Days passed, and no passport arrived. Calls were made. Facilities were searched. More calls were made. More facilities were searched.

title: Abusing Relativity
description: Jonathan Chait has an extended discussion and takedown of the Fox News All-Star Panel reaction to the National Climate Assessment, which I wont try to summarize. But I do want to delve a bit more into one point. Chait quotes Charles Krauthammer dismissing the scientific consensus because

title: Cant Find It at the Mall? Make It Yourself
description: As a junior in high school, Megan Grassell was disturbed by the choices of bras available for girls and young teenagers.The market, she believed, was dominated by push-up styles with padding and underwires.So last year, Ms. Grassell founded her own company, Yellowberry, and began making colorful, age-appropriate bras herself.

title: Amid Much Uncertainty, Separatists Prepare for Voting in Eastern Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  A day before snap elections to try to legitimize two self-declared new countries in eastern Ukraine, the preparations seemed as ad hoc as the votes themselves.

title: Man Is Arrested in Killing of His Wife; Sons Are Found Safe
description: LODI, N.J.  A New Jersey man, who the authorities say took his two young sons from their school after killing their mother, was arrested early Saturday after a manhunt through several states, officials said.

title: Already in the Lowflation Trap
description: Dean Baker, reacting to Neil Irwin, feels that he needs to make the perennial point that zero inflation is not some kind of economic Rubicon. Below-target inflation is already a problem, and a very serious problem if you dont have an easy way to provide economic stimulus.

title: Clippers for Sale, and the Owner Who Was Desperate
description: It was San Diego in the spring of 1981, a time of fern bars and yacht rock, big hair and short shorts. The man who owned the Clippers, Irv Levin, told his son that they were going to a lunch meeting at Lubachs, on Harbor Drive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Yemen, a Counterterrorism Challenge
description: WASHINGTON  After years of a tortuous relationship with Ali Abdullah Saleh, the strongman who was president of Yemen for more than two decades, Obama administration officials hoped to bolster the credibility at home of Mr. Salehs successor, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, seen as critical to the American fight against Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Pennsylvania Governor Faces an Uphill Battle for a Second Term
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Since Pennsylvania changed the law in 1968 to allow its governor to serve two consecutive terms, no incumbent has been denied re-election. But Tom Corbett, a Republican, is in danger of becoming the first.

title: Defending the Open Internet
description: The future of the Internet  which means the future of communications, culture, free speech and innovation  is up for grabs.

title: Making Ends Meet at Walmart
description: This has not been a good year for Walmart shareholders. Amid a torrid market over the last 12 months, this giant retailers stock has flatlined, reflecting a slowdown in sales growth.

title: The Peril of Knowledge Everywhere
description: Thanks to advances in technology, we may soon revisit a question raised four centuries ago: Are there things we should try not to know?

title: Picturesque but Pretty Daunting
description: A look at the six holes in one there during the Players Championship and the members of this years field with the most career holes in one.

title: Ceremonial Transfer
description: The unidentified remains of Sept. 11 victims were moved to a specially built medical examiners repository at the World Trade Center memorial site on Saturday.

title: Saving Sergeant Savage
description: In an effort to curb addiction, specialists are looking beyond opiates to treat chronic pain. Shane Savage, an injured military veteran, stopped taking pain medicine and is seeking other ways to cope.

title: A Hard Sell to Tame a Name in Spain
