description: CASTRILLO MATAJUDOS, Spain  To outsiders, it might seem obvious that the time has come, or long passed, to change the name of a village that evokes one of the darkest chapters of Spains history.

title: A Soldiers War on Pain
description: Four years and a lifetime ago, a new war began for Sgt. Shane Savage.

title: A Roaring Success and an Agent for Change
description: Richard Sherman is the most recognizable cornerback in the N.F.L. And the most outspoken. And, now, the highest paid. His emotional outburst on live television after the N.F.C. Championship game obscured his proficiency as a defensive dynamo, skills that last week earned him a four-year, $57.4 million contract extension ($40 million guaranteed) from the Super Bowl champion Seattle Seahawks.

title: Tour Players Are in a Hole-in-One Slump. Just Unlucky, They Guess.
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  At a 2010 PGA Tour event in Las Vegas, Jonathan Byrd beat long odds with the golf equivalent of a game-ending home run. Using his 6-iron, Byrd holed his tee shot on the 204-yard par-3 17th at TPC Summerlin to defeat Cameron Percy and Martin Laird in a playoff.

title: Pfizer Continues to Defend Takeover Bid for AstraZeneca
description: Pfizer on Saturday continued to press its case for a $106 billion takeover of AstraZeneca, the British drug maker, in the face of mounting resistance on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Bid for No-Hitter in Texas Is Sullied Before Its Spoiled
description: In the first game of the World Series at Fenway Park last year, Stephen Drew of the Boston Red Sox hit a high pop fly in the infield. Because of a miscommunication, the ball landed safely on the grass between two St. Louis Cardinals. It never touched a fielder and was ruled a single.

title: Brothers Battle Climate Change on Two Fronts
description: WASHINGTON  In the New Mexico of the 1950s, the two brothers grew up steeped in the beauty of the landscape, the economics of energy and the power of science. They skied, fly-fished, explored on the familys 50,000-acre sheep ranch, watched oil towns go boom and bust, and talked of the nuclear weapons up the road at Los Alamos.

title: A Mini Poll of the Smallest State
description: Only 18 percent of Rhode Islanders said their state was the best or one of the best places to live. A poll found that of all 50 states, Rhode Island was the least appreciated by its own residents.

title: Caron Butler Finds Rejuvenation in Return to L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES  When the N.B.A. lockout ended late in 2011, the Los Angeles Clippers had grand designs. They were flush with assets: loads of salary-cap space, plenty of draft picks and some promising young players who could be used as trade chips for a franchise player to complement Blake Griffin.

title: Filling Pages Not Difficult With a Life Lived Large
description: Graphic novels often depict men in colorful garb performing great feats of strength. But the heroes of those stories are usually fictional. That is not the case with Andre the Giant: Life and Legend, an illustrated biography published this month by First Second. The cartoonist Box Brown has woven his love of comics and wrestling to tell the life story of Andre Rene Roussimoff, better known as Andre the Giant.

title: Young Minds in Critical Condition
description: It happens every semester. A student triumphantly points out that Jean-Jacques Rousseau is undermining himself when he claims the man who reflects is a depraved animal, or that Ralph Waldo Emersons call for self-reliance is in effect a call for reliance on Emerson himself. Trying not to sound too weary, I ask the student to imagine that the authors had already considered these issues.

title: More Chopsticks, Please
description: HANOI, Vietnam  BY an accident of scheduling, Ive visited Kiev and Hanoi in the last couple weeks, and its been accidentally extremely revealing. Ukraine is a middle power living next to a giant bear, and Vietnam is a middle power living next to a giant tiger. Ukraine is struggling with how to deal with a declining Russia that is looking for dignity in all the wrong places  like in Crimea  and Vietnam is struggling with how to deal with a rising China that is looking for oil in all the wrong places  like in Vietnams territorial waters. Russias attitude toward Ukraine has been: Marry me, or Ill kill you. And Chinas toward Vietnam has been a variation of that line from There Will Be Blood: I have a long straw, so I think Ill drink my milkshake and yours.

title: Real Goal of Abortion Limits: Bans
description: Anti-abortion groups that saw a chance to get state legislatures to restrict womens reproductive rights piously declared that all they wanted to do was to make women safer. This argument had little credibility then, and it has even less now. What has actually happened is that in state after state, with the enthusiastic support of Republican lawmakers, it has become increasingly difficult, if not impossible, for women to get safe and legal abortion care.

title: With Malice Toward Nuns
description: WASHINGTON  SO much for all the cozy hugs and soothing cold calls and fun selfies and humble gestures and talk of mercy, love, inclusion, equality and justice.

title: The Toxic Brew in Our Yards
description: IN much of the country, its time to go outside, clean up the ravages of winter and start planting. Many of us will be using chemicals like glyphosate, carbaryl, malathion and 2,4-D. But they can end up in drinking water, and in some cases these compounds or their breakdown products are linked to an increased risk for cancer and hormonal disruption.

title: A Health Care Showdown in Virginia
description: In Virginia, there are 400,000 low-income people who cant afford health coverage but dont qualify for federal insurance subsidies. If they lived across the state line in Maryland, West Virginia or Kentucky, which have expanded their Medicaid programs, they could get the coverage they need. Terry McAuliffe, the Virginia governor, campaigned on bringing an expanded Medicaid program to Virginia, too.

title: Of Humans and Nature
description: A metaphysical discussion of our place in the universe and the future of humankind.

title: Lost Booksellers of New York
description: IN the fall of 1965, I arrived in New York City, flush with somebody elses oil money, to purchase books for a bookshop I was managing in Houston. The shop was called the Bookman and had several eccentric features: Our safe was the boll of a Louisiana gum tree; there was a room full of rare tobaccos, though smoking was forbidden; and there was even a young Asian man to serve sherry to such bewildered hicks as straggled in from time to time.

title: Rape and the College Brand
description: IN last weeks column, I wrote about the connection between college social life and socioeconomic stratification, and the way the party scene at many universities, oriented toward heavy drinking and hooking up, creates distinctive challenges for working-class students, whether theyre attracted to its thrills or alienated by its excesses.

title: Whats So Scary About Smart Girls?
description: WHEN terrorists in Nigeria organized a secret attack last month, they didnt target an army barracks, a police department or a drone base. No, Boko Haram militants attacked what is even scarier to a fanatic: a girls school.

title: The Marriage Plot
description: BOY meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. Boy and girl marry, etc., etc., etc. Or. Boy (Girl) meets 25 girls (boys). Boy and girl perform falling in love in front of video cameras, producers and millions of television viewers. It is spring, the feverish time when people fall in love, when people who have fallen in love promise their lives to one another  blushing brides, nervous grooms, extravagant weddings, compressed versions of the overproduced rituals of television shows like The Bachelor and The Bachelorette.

title: Daniel Jurafsky
description: Daniel Jurafsky is a professor of linguistics and computer science at Stanford. He teaches a popular freshman seminar course called The Language of Food, which is also the title of his forthcoming book.

title: Lessons in Catholic Judgment
description: WOULD Pope Francis Sign the New Catholic Teacher Contract? Thats the question spelled out on a dozen billboards that have gone up around Cincinnati over the last week or so.

title: The Benefits of Mixing Rich and Poor
description: Whenever President Obama proposes a major federal investment in early education, as he did in his two most recent State of the Union addresses, critics have a two-word riposte: Head Start. Researchers have long cast doubt on that programs effectiveness. The most damning evidence comes from a 2012 federal evaluation that used gold-standard methodology and concluded that children who participated in Head Start were not more successful in elementary school than others. That finding was catnip to the detractors. Head Starts impact is no better than random, The Wall Street Journal editorialized. Why throw good money after bad?

title: Rhode Island, a State Sized Just Right to Contain Its Pride
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  A lot of people here say that Rhode Island suffers from being the smallest state in the country. Jimmy Saccoccio, manager of the Olneyville New York System, a popular diner, agrees.

title: Saving Striped Bass
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  AS summer approaches, the view from Long Islands easternmost point transforms at dawn as anglers casting for striped bass begin taking their places along the surf. By June, the fish will be racing through these waters on the way to coastal New England as part of their northern migration, a biological spectacle akin to the movement of salmon on the West Coast.

title: Battles for the Crease Exact a Toll in the Playoffs
description: Boston Bruins forward Jarome Iginla knows the playoffs can be a painful experience. In every game, he is poked, slashed, crosschecked, shoved, punched, tripped, sworn at repeatedly and thrown to the ice.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 11
description: Speaker John A. Boehner appointed seven Republicans to a 12-person committee charged with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans. Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina, was tapped to lead the investigation and will appear on Fox News Sunday, along with Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, to debate the new committee and whether Democrats should participate.

title: Advice for a Troubled Teen
description: THE eighth-grade boy I mentor had been suspended for calling his substitute teacher a bitch, loudly enough that a teachers aide heard. Until this incident, he had been making real progress with his behavior problems in school. He had vastly improved since sixth grade, when suspensions were a regular part of his life. He disrupted class, taunted boys and hit girls. In seventh grade, his behavior, if not his schoolwork, had slowly improved.

title: When Music Was Strange
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  IN 1975 it was my friend Daryl  one of the very few African-American students in my mostly white prep school  who was the champion of the new. Boylan, he said one day after school. You have to check this out. Then he put Miles Daviss Bitches Brew on the turntable.

title: Why the Kidnapped Schoolgirls Matter
description: My Sunday column looks at the kidnapping of the NIgerian schoolgirls by Boko Haram, and the similar attacks on girls education by the Taliban and other militants, and asks why extremists are so afraid of a girl with a book. The basic answer is that nothing can be more transformative for a society than educating girls and then moving those educated women into the formal labor force. And just as Boko Haram and the Taliban are right to fear girls education, those of us appalled by extremism should be investing in girls education. Thats the way to stick it to Boko Haram.

title: The Rise of Antibiotic Resistance
description: The World Health Organization has surveyed the growth of antibiotic-resistant germs around the world  the first such survey it has ever conducted  and come up with disturbing findings. In a report issued late last month, the organization found that antimicrobial resistance in bacteria (the main focus of the report), fungi, viruses and parasites is an increasingly serious threat in every part of the world. A problem so serious that it threatens the achievements of modern medicine, the organization said. A post-antibiotic era, in which common infections and minor injuries can kill, far from being an apocalyptic fantasy, is instead a very real possibility for the 21st century.

title: Russia Ratchets Up Ukraines Gas Bills in Shift to an Economic Battlefield
description: LONDON  Gazprom, the natural gas giant 50.01 percent owned by the Russian government, keeps ratcheting up the bill for Ukraine, increasing the economic pressure on Kiev in tandem with military pressure along Ukraines eastern border.

title: Stowaways Are Stranded in Mexico by Train Ban
description: MEXICO CITY  Hundreds of Central American migrants trying to make their way to the United States have been stranded in Mexico in recent weeks after the freight-train line they ride  labeled the Beast  began enforcing a ban on stowaways, migrant advocates say.

title: Disease of Pakistans Poor Now Worries the Affluent
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Until recently, polio was considered a poor mans problem in Pakistan  a crippling virus that festered in the mountainous tribal belt, traversed the country on interprovincial buses, and spread via infected children who played in the open sewers of sprawling slums.

title: In Indian Candidate, Hindu Right Sees a Reawakening
description: VARANASI, India  Shortly after dawn in the village square here each day, two dozen boys and men dress up in crisply laundered khaki shorts and fall into military-style formation behind a saffron-colored flag, brandishing bamboo sticks as if they were rifles.

title: Against Penguins, One Line Clicks for Rangers
description: The Rangers 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh on Friday was very much about Martin St. Louis and the way his teammates rallied around him after the death of his mother. But among the Rangers who touched helmets with St. Louis as they came off the ice were the three forwards who were perhaps most responsible for prolonging the Eastern Conference semifinal series: Derick Brassard, Mats Zuccarello and Benoit Pouliot.

title: Going Home With Kenny G
description: In China, Kenny Gs instrumental Going Home has been used for years as a way to tell people to leave.

title: Methodology on Supreme Court Analysis
description: Accompanying Adam Liptaks article on the Supreme Courts partisanship is a chart showing every court since 1953. The justices are shaded based on the party of the president who appointed them. Theyre arrayed left to right based on their ideology.

title: Merkel and Hollande Send Russia a Warning
description: STRALSUND, Germany  Chancellor Angela Merkel invites only the most select of visitors to this pretty Baltic Sea port, the center of her parliamentary constituency and a rich symbol of Germanys centuries of trade with Russia and the countrys revival after the fall of the Berlin Wall almost 25 years ago.

title: When Politics Approach the Bench
description: The Supreme Court has long included justices whose voting was often at odds with the views of the presidents who appointed them. That mix, including conservative Democratic appointees and liberal Republican ones, ended in 2010.

title: China Says Goodbye in the Key of G: Kenny G
description: BEIJING  There are many things about modern China that defy easy explanation: parents posing their children next to live tigers, the sight of grown women wearing furry cat-ear headbands while shopping, the performance-art-like spectacle of strangers napping together in Ikea display beds.

title: The Polarized Court
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court issued its latest campaign finance decision last month, the justices lined up in a familiar way. The five appointed by Republican presidents voted for the Republican National Committee, which was a plaintiff. The four appointed by Democrats dissented.

title: A Contest Shifts From Ideology to Rsums
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: A Degree Goal: To Close a Gender Gap That Favors Women
description: When Victor Senz, an education professor at the University of Texas at Austin, began to focus his research nearly a decade ago on the plight of men in education, he experienced some pushback, even from fellow academics.

title: For Mother
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  First and foremost, if youve ever been important in the life of a child or a companion animal who depends on you, Happy Mothers Day.

title: A Big Spender Aims to Push State Politics Further Right
description: Shortly before the primaries in March, voters in Amarillo, Midland and Odessa received a two-and-a-half page letter in the mail from Tim Dunn, a wealthy local oil and gas developer.

title: Antiques and Ink Master Play Roles in Renaissance of Fading Fraternal Order
description: WAXAHACHIE  Standing in a doorway of their 123-year-old brick lodge, four members of the Waxahachie Odd Fellows welcomed their brothers to a Monday night meeting. In their 30s, the four men were bearded and tattooed and wore black T-shirts that contrasted with the button-down dress of past members whose pictures adorned the lodges portrait wall.

title: In Historic Pick, Rams Take Michael Sam in Final Round of Draft
description: Over seven rounds of the National Football League draft, teams chose more than 200 players, from surefire stars to kickers and all-but-anonymous players from tiny Division II programs.

title: At 11, New Master Breaks Record Older Than She Is
description: An 11-year-old Californian in March became the youngest American girl to ever become a master, breaking a record that had stood for 18 years.

title: New York Police Recruit Muslims to Be Informers
description: One man was a food cart vendor from Afghanistan, arrested during an argument with a parking enforcement officer over a ticket. Another was an Egyptian-born limousine driver, picked up in a prostitution sting. Still another was an accounting student from Pakistan, in custody for driving without a valid license.

title: Houston Is Next for a Nomadic Quarterback
description: Several notable quarterbacks came off the board during Day 3 of the N.F.L. draft Saturday, including Tom Savage of Pittsburgh, who went in the fourth round to the Houston Texans (135th over all). A few years ago, it would have been tough to imagine Savages being drafted, as he was in the middle of a meandering five-year career in which he played for three programs.

title: Spieth Avoids Bogeys to Claim Share of Players Lead
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  For Jordan Spieth, golf-course etiquette extends to how he refers to his elders, which includes everyone in this weeks Players Championship field. Grouped in the final twosome Saturday with the 29-year-old Martin Kaymer  or, as Spieth was tempted to call him, Mr. Kaymer  Spieth, 20, was as patient as a hunter in a deer blind.

title: With Clean Picks, Giants Look Beyond Talent
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Five of the Giants seven 2014 draft picks were team captains in college. Two were National Honor Society members. One is an academic all-American who spent an off-season building homes in Haitis poorest neighborhoods. Another graduated from college early and is writing a book.

title: In City Where He Dominated, Sabathia Shows Hes Still Adjusting
description: MILWAUKEE  The fans at Miller Park cheered C. C. Sabathia when he walked to the mound for the first time Saturday. They also gave him a standing ovation when he came to the plate in his first at-bat. The appreciative cheers were in recognition of the fine work Sabathia did for the Brewers in 2008, even if it was almost six years ago and only for three months.

title: Orphan Black Recap: Sarah Meets Helena
description: At this point, it is probably poor critical form to praise Tatiana Maslanys work on BBC Americas Orphan Black. It has been done so many times before, one has to question if anything new can really be said. But lets give it a shot anyway.

title: Lem Johns, Who Guarded Johnson in Dallas, Dies at 88
description: Lem Johns, a Secret Service agent who guarded Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas and who became a high-ranking Secret Service official during Johnsons administration, died on Saturday at his home in Hoover, Ala. He was 88.

description: The Nets have spent a huge sum of money to assemble a roster intended to challenge the Miami Heat, the N.B.A.s two-time defending champions and the standard-bearers of the league. On Saturday night, the Nets received contributions from every corner of that roster to deliver a vital counterpunch in this Eastern Conference semifinal series.

When a curtain dropped, there she was on a pillar in a giant feathered headdress and a silver-and-sheer dress that flaunted her flanks. Im strong, Im strong enough to rise above, she sang in her 2013 single, Womans World, and no one whos heard Cher repeatedly ascend the pop charts since the 1960s would doubt it.

description: Jenna Rachel Martin and Michael George Hilzenrath were married Saturday evening at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. The officiant was Bruce Beck, the sports reporter at WNBC-TV and a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 9, 2014
description: I thought about asking for a recount. But now its too late.

title: Video Notebook: Nets Beat Heat in Game 3
description: Brooklyns Kevin Garnett talks about how the Nets were able to defeat the Heat at Barclays Center in Game 3 of their series.

title: Quotation of the Day for January 12, 2014
description: He was not an ideologue; he was a political architect. As a military man he knew one thing from the battlefield  you have to seize the initiative, you have to be the one driving the action.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 5, 2014
description: I think we are witnessing a turning point, and it could be one of the worst in all our history. The West is not there, and we are in the hands of two regional powers, the Saudis and Iranians, each of which is fanatical in its own way. I dont see how they can reach any entente, any rational solution.

title: Quotation of the Day: Wednesday, January 1, 2014
description: De Blasio matters. A lot of us are counting on his success.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 30, 2013
description: A father just wants to see his children grow up. Now my children are gone. My wife is gone. Can I ever be happy again?

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 29, 2013
description: We see a lot of these vehicles that are carjacked ending up on Craigslist. If the price is too good to be true, it probably is.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 23, 2013
description: I think the Russian problem is not just the president as a person. The problem is that our citizens, by a large majority, dont understand that their fate, they have to be responsible for it themselves.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 2, 2013
description: Im thinking Im going into the water. I was thinking of me, surviving.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 7, 2013
description: Yes, we were oppressed by white people; yes, it happened; yes, it hurt. But let us forgive each other so that we can move on fully and contribute fully to the South Africa we want to see in the future.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 16, 2013
description: Weve seen several red lines put forward by the president, which went along and became pinkish as time grew, and eventually ended up completely white.

description: We didnt cut to the bone. We cut into the bone.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 29, 2013
description: Well, I dont want to sound pigheaded, but theres a million people out there that want to make a dollar off of the name Hells Angels and the emblem Hells Angels, and we try to stop them.

description: In politics, money follows the winners.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 26, 2013
description: This is an attempt to make difficult problems disappear. Its both callous and ineffective.

title: Familiar Path for Mets Against Phillies
description: Not even two weeks ago, General Manager Sandy Aldersons goal of a 90-win Mets season did not seem so absurd. They finished April with a 15-11 record, and it seemed as if their long rebuilding project might show some results.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 27, 2013
description: In regular classes people are trying to distract you with music videos or saying, Hey, look at this cat playing a piano on their phones. Whereas in an A.P. class, they will show you something from the text and say, Hey, this is fun.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 23
description: Its going to go out of the family. But I think of it this way: Its not going anywhere. Its always going to be there, and it really doesnt matter who owns it.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 17, 2013
description: We were just a bunch of friends getting high and hanging out, doing what 20-year-olds do. Then we went to sleep, and Miles never woke up.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 18, 2013
description: Theres a problem with his lung!

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 25, 2013
description: You cant have a city of just rich people. A city needs restaurant workers, a city needs schoolteachers, a city needs taxi drivers.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 3, 2013
description: The entire region is addicted, whole villages. If you take off your shoes, the addicts will steal them.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 28, 2013
description: You do this because you like it, you think what youre making is beautiful. And if you think its beautiful, maybe they think its beautiful.

description: I did it for Boston.

description: Brooklyns Deron Williams talks about the Nets defensive effort against the Heats LeBron James in the second half of Game 3.

title: Bronx Man Is Charged in Double Murder
description: A 33-year-old man was charged on Saturday with killing two men who were found shot to death in the front seat of a car in the Bronx, the police said.

title: James Fades While Nets Broaden Focus
description: Halfway through the first quarter of Game 3 on Saturday, LeBron James fielded a rebound, ambled up the court, split two defenders, gathered his feet in the paint, leapt to score and was grabbed from behind over the shoulders with two hands by Nets forward Paul Pierce.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 17, 2014
description: My heart is turning to ashes.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 10, 2014
description: This tragedy tears at wounds still raw from five years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 6, 2014
description: Its absurd, and thats the nicest thing I can call it, how much test prep has grown, and how guilt-ridden parents have become about trying to prepare their kids for the test.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 11, 2014
description: Ive never experienced inflation. It doesnt seem real to me.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 2, 2014
description: The presence of Russian troops in Crimea now is unacceptable.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday March 1, 2014
description: There will be costs.

title: Quotations of the Day for Wednesday, March 5, 2014.
description: It is not appropriate to invade a country and at the end of a barrel of a gun dictate what you are trying to achieve.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) ROSEMARYS BABY In this two-part remake of the 1968 Roman Polanski thriller, the director Agnieszka Holland transfers the setting from the Dakota on Central Park West to the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, where Rosemary Woodhouse (Zoe Saldana, above) has moved with her husband, Guy (Patrick J. Adams), a writer with a teaching stint at the Sorbonne. Ms. Holland also transforms the dotty older couple next door, first played by Ruth Gordon and Sidney Blackmer, into French sophisticates (Carole Bouquet and Jason Isaacs) who offer the Americans their friendship and a spare apartment. This being Paris, they discuss the transaction in an elegant sex club. And when Rosemary, eager to get pregnant again after a miscarriage, visits an OBGYN, the examining room looks like the rare-books section of the Acadmie Franaise. Rosemarys Baby bends to current fashions, and, accordingly, is more straightforward and much gorier than the original film, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. But partly because the story has been so altered, it still has mystery and suspense. And because its Paris, it is possible to wonder, at least for a while, if maybe the problem is Rosemary, not her neighbors, who seem so serenely superior and all knowing. Part 2 will be shown on Thursday at 9.

title: A Soundtrack Made of Muscle
description: Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas is eclectic by design. Each of the institutions taking part in this citywide series has made its own programming choices. For the double bill it presented on Tuesday, Abrons Arts Center gravitated toward the outer edges of conventional definitions of dance. Both of the works  one by Claudia Triozzi, the other by David Wampach  were as focused on the sounds the body makes as on how a body might move. Both began with an open mouth, stretched as in the Munch painting, ready to scream.

title: Paying Homage, Vivaciously and Somberly
description: Toccata in D may sound like an innocuous title, but not for a work by an atonal composer like George Perle, who died in 2009 at 93. After a colleague told him that such a title would be inflammatory, Perle removed the offending letter. (Atonal and Serialist composers do not write in any particular key.)

title: Corrections: May 11, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Vietnam Fails to Rally Partners in China Dispute
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Vietnams prime minister, Nguyen Tan Dung, accused China on Sunday of dangerous and serious violations in a territorial dispute that has raised anger toward China here to the highest levels in years.

title: Vows | Grandmas a Bridesmaid
description: Three spunky grandmothers stole the show as bridesmaids in their granddaughters weddings.

title: Celebrate Mom With a Martian Crater All Her Own
description: If youre still looking for something special for Mothers Day, remember: Until this year, there has been no crater love.

title: In Our Pages: May 12
description: 1914: Germany Seeking Control of Hayti

title: Front-Runner in Afghan Election Secures a Key Ally
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdullah Abdullah, the front-runner in Afghanistans presidential election campaign, announced Sunday that he had won the endorsement of Zalmay Rassoul, the third-place candidate, as part of his effort to gather enough support to win in the next round of voting.

title: Ukraine Vote on Separation Held in Chaos
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Separatists in two provinces of eastern Ukraine conducted chaotic and sometimes violent plebiscites on Sunday that offered voters just one question about self-rule, while raising many more about where events in the region were headed.

title: African Rivers May Heighten H.I.V. Peril
description: Gynecologists working in Africa suspect that women there are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of waterborne parasites. An ambitious research project aims to revolutionize treatment for young women.

title: Protest of Planned Incinerator Turns Violent in Chinese City
description: SHANGHAI  A huge demonstration against a planned waste incinerator in one of eastern Chinas biggest cities turned violent on Saturday with protesters overturning and setting fire to police cars, leaving at least 10 demonstrators and 29 police officers injured, according to Xinhua, the official state-run news agency.

title: The Premier League Standings if Only Goals by English Players Counted
description: What would the standings look like in a hypothetical league in which a goal does not count unless it is scored by an English player?

title: Samsung Leader Stable After Heart Attack
description: The chairman of Samsung Electronics, Lee Kun-hee, who helped transform the business into a technology giant, was in stable condition Sunday after suffering a heart attack, the company said.

title: Manchester City Stands Tall in a Season of Dashed Hopes
description: The institutional memory of sports is typically built one highlight at a time. That is the way we remember players and games and seasons  by what goes right. It is more pleasant that way.

title: Hamilton Holds Off Rosberg at Spanish Grand Prix
description: Barcelona, Spain  On Saturday, after scoring his fourth pole position of the year and the 35th of his career, Lewis Hamilton said he had never driven a car that was so much faster than those of his immediate competitors.

title: Podcast: Spiders With Personality
description: Spiders in the Kalahari desert develop personalities that are affected by their spider peers, just like teenagers.

title: Sabathia Put on Disabled List
description: MILWAUKEE  C. C. Sabathia had swelling in his right knee after his start May 4, but he did not mention it to anyone because the Yankees rotation had already been hit with so many injuries. When he felt more pain in his knee in Saturdays game against the Milwaukee Brewers and encountered more swelling, he spoke up.

title: ScienceTake | Unlocking Spider Secrets
description: A new look at the social organization of some eight-legged predators.

title: Hagel Open to Reviewing Militarys Ban on Transgender People
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the military should continually review its prohibition on transgender people in the armed forces, calling into question whether the Pentagons ban may eventually be lifted, as was the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military.

title: Rubio on a Presidential Bid, and Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio on Sunday said that he was ready to be president, becoming the second potential Republican candidate recently to drop big hints about 2016 as he vies for early attention in a crowded field of maybes.

title: The Lives of Sociable Spiders
description: Of the worlds 43,000 known varieties of spiders, an overwhelming majority are peevish loners: spinning webs, slinging lassos, liquefying prey and attacking trespassers, each spider unto its own.

title: Seconds That Last an Eternity
description: The seventh game of the playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors on May 4 was about two and a half hours old and seemingly just about finished.

title: Rebuilding a Neighborhood, but Not a Community
description: Like relics from a past civilization, tiny chunks of cracked tile and smashed bricks rest in the dirt of parking lots or empty lots along the south side of Delancey Street, near the corner of Clinton Street. They attest to a community on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that vanished 47 years ago, when some 1,800 families, mostly poor and Puerto Rican, were uprooted and their tenement homes demolished in the name of urban renewal.

title: Austrian Singer Wins Eurovision Contest
description: PARIS  With a shimmering golden gown, trim dark beard and voice made for Broadway, an Austrian drag queen, Conchita Wurst, was the runaway winner of this years 59th annual Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday in Copenhagen.

title: Neighbors Tops Weekend Box Office
description: Sorry, Spidey. A raunchy fraternity just threw a bong through your web. The No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada over the weekend was Neighbors, an R-rated comedy that rode strong reviews and a well-oiled marketing campaign to an astounding $51.1 million in ticket sales, trampling The Amazing Spider-Man 2.

title: Growing Up Without the One Who Delivered You
description: Mothers Day weekend cant be easy for people who lost their mothers at a young age. Many no doubt just lie low, keep quiet and wait for it to be over. But the documentary The (Dead Mothers) Club, Monday night on HBO, gives voice to at least a few such people, and their stories will surely resonate with many others.

title: Newsletter of the Hurt and Lonely
description: Matthew, the chronically anxious 19-year-old played with consummate skill and grace by Gideon Glick in The Few, a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, moves with the herky-jerky rhythm of a puppet whose strings are being pulled by someone a little woozy. His long arms end in hands that are forever darting around like little birds, making expressive gestures that suggest Matthews inability to fully articulate his feelings.

title: Chamber Orchestra Works, From Intense to Zany
description: Part of the pleasure of hearing Ensemble ACJW, the group of young professionals formed under the auspices of Carnegie Hall and the Juilliard School, is considering the myriad options that lie before its members. Will they end up as soloists, orchestral players, educators, entrepreneurs?

title: Traveling Back in Time to Dance Her Case
description: For nearly 30 years, Miki Orihara has been a stalwart member of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Such dedication is an implicit statement of belief in the continued relevance of classic modern dance. But in the program notes for Resonance, the solo concert she performed at the La MaMa Moves festival Friday, Ms. Orihara was explicit, arguing for the timelessness of older works and their connections to present-day choreography and concerns. With five short pieces, she danced her case in chronological order.

title: Raging, Vaguely, Against the Machine
description: A bunch of years ago, Erika M. Anderson made it out of South Dakota to California. Eventually, recording under the alias E M A, she released an album, Past Life Martyred Saints, that captured the mood of the move  the terror, the pathos, the relief. A change in place saved her, sort of.

title: Sugar? Sure, but Salted With Meaning
description: With her stinging, site-specific installation at the former Domino Sugar compound on the edge of the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Kara Walker expands her imposing achievement to include three dimensions and monumental scale. In the process, she raises the bar on an overused art-spectacle formula as well as her own work. And she subjects a grand, decaying structure fraught with the conflicted history of the sugar trade and its physical residue to a kind of predemolition purification ritual.

title: A Music Festival Dies, and an Orchestra Mourns
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra ended the 2014 Spring for Music festival on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall by playing works that shared the theme of spirituality, but of a grim sort, touching on martyrdom, apocalyptic scenes and death and containing an element of gallows humor. This was not just the sixth and last concert of this years festival, but the final offering of the whole visionary venture.

title: Playing on Mothers Day After His Mothers Sudden Death, St. Louis Buoys Rangers
description: When Brad Richards learned Thursday that the mother of Martin St. Louis, his Rangers teammate and longtime friend, had unexpectedly died, his instincts were not about hockey.

title: Albert Dormer at the World Senior Pairs in 1990
description: A few bridge players have better reputations than they deserve. Perhaps more are underrated; one was Albert Dormer, who died at 88 on March 18 in Scotland, where he had moved upon retirement.

title: A Directors Tasting Menu Shows Off a Ballet Companys Strengths
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Pennsylvania Ballet, celebrating its 50th anniversary this season, is in transition. Last weekend it presented what it called a Directors Choice triple bill, which had been announced last year. Two weeks ago, the company said its artistic director, Roy Kaiser, would step down at the end of the season.

title: Walter Isaacson to Deliver Jefferson Lecture
description: Walter Isaacson, the best-selling biographer and president of the Aspen Institute, will deliver the 43rd annual Jefferson Lecture on Monday night at the Kennedy Center in Washington. The lecture is sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities and considered the federal governments highest honor in the humanities.

title: Driven to Accumulate and Dancing Till Nothings Left
description: The sidewalk in front of the Club at La MaMa on Friday night was teeming with people needing a fix of Merce past. The lure was a shared program featuring Ashley Chen and Dylan Crossman, two much-admired former members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, in a dual presentation by Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas, and La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival. Before the house opened, Mr. Chen joined the crowd to smoke a cigarette; as he put it, Its the French warm-up.

title: Dance Lineups Announced
description: Dance companies from France, The Hague and Denmark will appear in the Joyce Theaters fall and winter lineup, said Joyce officials, who recently announced that the National Ballet of Canada would open the season on Sept. 9 with Christopher Wheeldons Alices Adventures in Wonderland. The schedule will also include Pacific Northwest Ballet performing works by Mr. Wheeldon and Alejandro Cerrudo (Oct. 8 to 12), the all-male company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo (Dec. 16 to Jan. 4), and Royal Danish Ballet principals and soloists (Jan. 13 to 18). The French-Argentinean tango group Cia Unin Tanguera will perform from Sept. 23 to Oct. 5 as part of its Nuit Blanche North American tour, and the flamenco dancer Soledad Barrio is slated to bring her company, Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce from Oct. 29 to Nov. 9.

title: A Memoir From the Eye of a Financial Storm
description: One afternoon in the summer of 2008, as the financial system was careening toward the abyss that would send the United States into the worst economic emergency since the Great Depression, Timothy F. Geithner  then president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and later, President Obamas Treasury secretary  tried to lighten the mood in his office with an impromptu contest for the best metaphor for what was happening.

title: A Night of Gospel, Spanning Generations
description: NEWARK  Consider Erica Campbell, at the McDonalds Gospelfest Saturday night at the Prudential Center. Shes got the No. 1 album on the Billboard gospel chart, and co-stars in a successful reality show, Mary Mary, on We TV. Shes a personage in this precinct, a cross-media star, from whom youd expect some kind of show. She brought one: herself.

title: Stepping Up to a Host Spot
description: Larry Wilmore, named on Friday as host of The Minority Report, the show that will fill the 11:30 p.m. slot on Comedy Central, thought the time had passed for him to receive his own late-night show.

title: Making Organ Donations Worthwhile
What an Optimist Always Looks On
description: Quotation is a serviceable substitute for wit.  Deb Amlen, quoting Oscar WILDE

title: A Hot Topic at Princeton: Check Your Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Conversion Moves Forward
description: The effort to turn a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into an acoustically sound concert hall, recording studio, nightclub and center for composers is moving ahead, with organizers saying that they have raised the $16 million needed to finish construction. The space on North 6th Street, called the Original Music Workshop, has already drawn respected musicians and celebrities inside its weathered brick walls for concerts, even before it had a roof. Now its founder, Kevin Dolan, said that he had lined up what he called philanthropic investors to put up the money needed to finish construction. It is an unusual arrangement. Mr. Dolan said that the investors would become part owners of the building, which they would allow the Original Music Workshop, a nonprofit, to use rent-free. In the future they could then give their shares to the workshop, sell them to the workshop, or sell the building. Mr. Dolan, 62, said this would reduce the risk to people who might be reluctant to put money into a new organization without a long track record. He added that the space could open as soon as the fall of 2015.

title: My Kind of Town?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trust in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Latinos and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: A New York Premiere for a Scottish Play
description: The Events, a moving drama by the Scottish playwright David Greig, about the aftermath and community response when a tragedy takes place in a small town, will have its New York premiere at New York Theater Workshop next winter, the theater planned to announce on Monday. The show, directed by Ramin Gray, was first presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last summer, where it drew critical praise and won several awards, including the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh honor. In Edinburgh, a different local choir was featured at each performance, providing a musical element while also aiding the plot in other ways, much like a Greek chorus. New York Theater Workshop plans to take a similar approach. The Events, which makes its United States premiere in June at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven, will come to New York in February. The show rounds out the previously announced New York Theater Workshop season.

title: Protect Our Bats
description: DISEASE and heedless management of wind turbines are killing North Americas bats, with potentially devastating consequences for agriculture and human health.

title: Thailands Dilemma
description: The country runs straight into a fork in the road.

title: Follow the Money, China-Style
description: BEIJING  Since China introduced a floating exchange rate on July 21, 2005, the Chinese yuan has consistently risen in value against the United States dollar, from a low of 8.28 yuan to the dollar in July 2005 to a high of 6.06 in January of this year. But the appreciation of the yuan has failed to convince ordinary Chinese people that their money buys more; on the contrary, they feel its worth less.

title: Mets Finally Bring a Runner Home and End a Five-Game Skid
description: The only encouraging thing about the Mets play recently was that they had been able to put runners on base, which had somewhat tempered the panic of their losing ways.

title: The Dark Shadow of Agent Orange
description: The use of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese.

title: Agent Oranges Long Legacy, for Vietnam and Veterans
description: Britain was the first to use defoliants as a war tactic in Southeast Asia. That was in the early 1950s in Malaya, then a British colony, before it became the independent Malaysia. British planes sprayed Malayan jungles with chemicals to strip trees bare and deprive communist guerrillas of cover. They also destroyed crops that the insurgents relied on for sustenance. A decade later, in what was then South Vietnam, United States armed forces resorted to precisely the same methods on an enormous scale in their long struggle against Viet Cong and North Vietnamese fighters.

title: Party Chiefs Downfall a Central Act in Tiananmen Drama
description: In mid-May 1989, Zhang Gang was among a group of Chinese officials and scholars seeking to defuse the student protests that had filled Tiananmen Square for a month. They had been trying to coax concessions from the government and the demonstrators to end the volatile confrontation and protect the embattled Communist Party general secretary, Zhao Ziyang, who was increasingly at odds with the party patriarch, Deng Xiaoping.

title: A Discussion of the Danger and Promise of Tech
description: Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times recently conducted a series of interviews with seven people who helped provide a glimpse into the not-too-distant future. Last Monday, two of them  Sebastian Thrun and Clara Shih  joined her and readers in a chat on Facebook. Mr. Thrun is a co-founder and chief executive of Udacity, an inventor of driverless cars and a founder of Google X; and Ms. Shih is a founder and chief executive of Hearsay Social. The following are excerpts from the exchange, condensed and lightly edited.

title: Show Us the Drone Memos
description: WASHINGTON  I BELIEVE that killing an American citizen without a trial is an extraordinary concept and deserves serious debate. I cant imagine appointing someone to the federal bench, one level below the Supreme Court, without fully understanding that persons views concerning the extrajudicial killing of American citizens.

title: HUD, New Jersey and Sandy
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Developments new review of New Jerseys mismanaged Hurricane Sandy recovery effort uncovered no violations of federal law. But the report raised troubling concerns about the programs lack of transparency. And while it could have made the point more forcefully, it did warn that the state could end up violating civil rights regulations if it did not take sufficient steps to ensure that poor and minority households got a fair share of post-Sandy aid.

title: Secret Pension Fund Deals
A Lesson in Farming, Classroom to Cafeteria
description: HAGERSTOWN, Ind.  Beyond a stack of hay bales, past the site of Indianas first soil-judging contest, high school students in this tiny eastern town stroll down a grassy slope to reach their newest classroom: a fenced-in field of cud-chewing cattle.

title: Trailing by 22, Clippers Rally to Tie Series
description: LOS ANGELES  Arriving fashionably late, as the actor Mark Wahlberg, the singer Rihanna and the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. did to their courtside seats Sunday, is a very Los Angeles thing to do. They were, in a way, very much like the basketball team they came to see.

title: Its Ratings Sliding, Fox Looks for Hope in a Gotham City Before Batman
description: LOS ANGELES  Batman saves Gotham. Can he do the same thing for Fox?

title: Questions About N.F.L. Drafts Future Involve Location, Date and Length
description: If the 2014 N.F.L. draft was the events swan song at Radio City Music Hall, it was quite a number. From the hysteria around Johnny Manziel on opening night to Michael Sams selection near the end of the third day, it was one of the most memorable of the nine consecutive drafts held at Radio City, the venerable theater in Midtown Manhattan.

title: A Devotion to Language Proves Risky
description: BEIJING  A poet, linguist and globe-trotting polyglot, Abduweli Ayup had a passion for the spoken word, notably Uighur, the Turkic language spoken in his homeland in Chinas far northwest. In 2011, soon after finishing his graduate studies in the United States, Mr. Ayup returned home to open a chain of mother tongue schools in Xinjiang, the vast Central Asian region whose forced marriage to the Han Chinese heartland has become increasingly tumultuous.

title: Warnings Along F.C.C.s Fast Lane
description: The next time the loudmouth in the next cubicle interrupts you with yet another recap of his weekend, just start talking about net neutrality.

title: Democrats Look Dubiously at Joining Benghazi Panel
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats on Sunday made it clear that they do not expect fair proceedings from the Republican-led panel newly tasked with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, but offered no definitive answer on whether they would appoint any of their own members to participate.

title: Charles Marowitz, Iconoclastic Director and Playwright, Dies at 82
description: Charles Marowitz, who brought a thorny iconoclasm to a versatile theater career as a director, playwright, teacher and critic, died on May 2 in Agoura Hills, Calif. He was 82.

title: A Triumph of Enlightenment ... Eventually
description: By the time I arrived at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan on Saturday, the sixth round of the N.F.L. draft had started, but Michael Sam had still not been selected.

title: European Candidates See Opportunity on Extreme Edge
description: PARIS  The campaign  advertisement in the Czech Republic begins with a snake slithering out of a red European Union flag and a montage of pictures of supposed threats to Czech identity, including a 500-euro note, an Israeli flag and a gathering of Orthodox Jews.

title: Patrick J. Lucey, Governor and Vice-Presidential Candidate, Dies at 96
description: Patrick J. Lucey, who was twice elected governor of Wisconsin and ran for vice president in 1980 on an independent ticket with John B. Anderson, died on Saturday in Milwaukee. He was 96.

title: Programs on Demand, Just for PBS Members
description: As television viewers increasingly turn to video on demand to watch shows when they want, PBS and its local stations plan to follow them, but with a twist: They are creating a streaming video service that will be available only to members of local PBS stations.

title: Sterling Offers Apology in Interview With CNN
description: Donald Sterling, the embattled owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, broke his silence Sunday in an interview with CNNs Anderson Cooper during which he apologized for making racist remarks.

title: In Ukraine, Vote on Self-Rule Leaves Many Questions
description: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote.

title: Legal Alliance Gains Host of Court Victories for Conservative Christian Movement
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Alan Sears, who has run the Christian legal group Alliance Defending Freedom since its founding 20 years ago, turned to a picture of Abraham Lincoln in his office here and noted the decades of blood and tears it took to abolish slavery.

title: Island Fixer-Upper, Near the Madding Crowd
description: VENICE  A short boat ride from the elegant tourist horde that is Venice, Poveglia Island could be considered the anti-Venice. There are no souvenir shops, no gondolas and no people. A brick bell tower rises from a jumble of abandoned buildings. The overgrown gardens have been untended for decades.

title: Nadal Picks Up a Clay Title in Madrid, but the Victory Is Short of Convincing
description: MADRID  Rafael Nadal put his clay-court season back on track Sunday, winning the Madrid Masters 1000 in a final that was cut short when his opponent, Kei Nishikori, retired with a back injury.

title: Crazy Climate Economics
description: Everywhere you look these days, you see Marxism on the rise. Well, O.K., maybe you dont  but conservatives do. If you so much as mention income inequality, youll be denounced as the second coming of Joseph Stalin; Rick Santorum has declared that any use of the word class is Marxism talk. In the rights eyes, sinister motives lurk everywhere  for example, George Will says the only reason progressives favor trains is their goal of diminishing Americans individualism in order to make them more amenable to collectivism.

title: Rutgers Player Is Charged With Assault in Minnesota
description: A Rutgers quarterback has been arrested in connection with an assault in southern Minnesota that left another football player in critical condition, the police said.

title: In Town of Missing Girls, Sorrow, but Little Progress
description: CHIBOK, Nigeria  The women surged forward, anguish creasing their faces. Many were crying. A collective wail went up, but the officials traveling with the visiting local dignitary pushed them back, shushing them so he could speak.

title: In Washington, Walk on the Grass, but Step Gently
description: WASHINGTON  It has played host to civil rights marches, presidential inaugurations, fireworks displays and decades of picnics. But in recent years the National Mall, envisioned more than a century ago as a lush carpet of green connecting the nations most treasured monuments, has looked more like a West Texas dust bowl.

title: Impunity and the Border Patrol
description: If a Border Patrol agent beats, kicks, threatens or otherwise abuses you, you can file a complaint. What you cant count on, evidently, is anything being done about it.

title: Russia Revisits Its History to Nail Down Its Future
description: MOSCOW  As many Russians spent a holiday weekend reveling in the annual display of military might that marks their victory over Nazi Germany, the tension in Ukraine has fueled a passionate debate over how to exalt the countrys history without distorting it.

title: The City Council, Playing by Better Rules
description: A sardonic tip of the cap to Councilman Ruben Wills for getting arrested on Wednesday, the same day the New York City Council convened its first hearing on a package of rule changes meant to increase transparency and accountability. Nothing like a well-timed scandal  alleged theft of public funds  to help drive home a point.

title: A Long Way to Privacy Safeguards
description: A new White House report on big data and privacy includes several recommendations that could help protect the personal information of individuals from warrantless searches and abusive marketing practices. But it still does not do enough to advance the goal President Obama set two years ago for clear rules of the road on privacy.

title: Language Barrier Continues to Thwart Victims of Crimes
description: New York City now has more non-English speakers than ever, according to the Census Bureau: nearly two million. In response to this growing population, the city has assembled a host of programs to help it serve not just those who speak Spanish, Chinese and Russian, but also languages like Pashto, Punjabi, Uzbek and Urdu.

description: On television at least, it looks as if the beat doesnt go on.

title: Trying to Salvage Remains of Blackwater Case
description: WASHINGTON  The team of F.B.I. agents arrived in Iraq to investigate a shooting involving a private company that provided security for Americans in a war zone. It was October 2007, and the name of the company  Blackwater Worldwide  did not yet mean anything to the agents. But what they found shocked them.

title: A Stirring Homer, but the Yanks Tiring Trip Ends in a Loss
description: MILWAUKEE  The thrill of putting a dent in Francisco Rodriguezs previously unblemished record did not last very long. After being down to their final strike Sunday, the Yankees extended the game with a surprising home run from Mark Teixeira, sending the last game of this exhausting trip to the bottom of the ninth.

description: Advocates for an American couple held in Qatar since their adopted African daughter died there in January 2013 after not eating for days have posted a YouTube video about their story, which contains previously unpublicized footage and photographs depicting a happy multiracial family and offers new insights into the circumstances behind her death.

description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Inside the headquarters of BurgerFuel Worldwide is a spray-painted mural of a skull wearing a combat helmet emblazoned with the slogan Born to Grill.

Once a marginal model, it is now being trumpeted as the future of consumption by Spotify, Rhapsody, Rdio and Beats own service, Beats Music.

title: Penny Dreadful Recap: Up and Down the Ladder of Wealth
description: Early on in Showtimes premiere episode of Penny Dreadful, a pallid spiritualist named Vanessa Ives (Eva Green) confronts Ethan Chandler (Josh Hartnett) after his third-rate Wild West show comes through London in 1891. She fact-checks his tale of surviving the Battle of the Little Bighorn 15 years earlier and then subjects him to a bit of character analysis. Theres the tell-tale trembling hand of the alcoholic and the contusion that probably came from a cuckolded husband. But she mainly zeros in on Ethans expensive watch but threadbare jacket, along with a nice pair of boots that he has had resoled several times.

title: Inspiration Finds the Net as the Rangers Force Game 7
description: When Martin St. Louis scored the games first goal Sunday less than four minutes into the first period, the fans at Madison Square Garden started chanting his name. It was so loud that the building shook.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: Lynn R. Williams became head of the United Steel Workers union in 1983, early in one of the worst decades in history for steel and steelworkers in America.

title: Cuomo Works to Mend Fences With Liberals
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has won significant support from traditionally Republican constituencies, including business executives who like his tax cuts and Wall Street financiers delighted with his support of charter schools. But this courtship has come at a price: As he begins his bid for a second term, he is struggling to hold on to support from the left wing of his own party.

description: What you need to know about Indias elections on Monday: In the last of the nine phases of voting, all eyes are on the ancient holy city of Varanasi, in Uttar Pradesh, where Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party are vying for a spot in the lower house of Parliament. In Mondays elections, 41 parliamentary seats are up for grabs, across three states.

title: Times Minute | Eastern Ukraines Vote
description: Today on the Minute, voices from eastern Ukraine, where a vote for autonomy turned alternately celebratory and violent.

title: Rarified Perfume: The Perks of Membership at MiN New York
description: As the co-curators of the indie apothecary MiN New York in NoLita, Chad Murawczyk and Mindy Yang take a simple approach to stocking their shelves: If we cant find something we want, we make it, Murawczyk says. So far, thats lead to such varied creations as atmospheric candles gilded in precious metals, high-performance skin-care creams and hand-ticked silk scarves depicting photographs of Havana shot by Murawczyk himself. The latest addition to the MiN oeuvre: a series of abstract fragrances, called Scent Stories, debuting this week. Composed of notes that normally dont land in eau, such as pencil shavings and ozone, the collection of 11 unisex scents took a year to develop with a master perfumer in Grasse, France. The idea was to make each scent like a chapter or a short story: it would be vivid, visceral and disconnected from the others, but take you somewhere, Yang says. Indeed, many of the fragrances were inspired by the pairs own memories and journeys. Dahab, for example, evokes the deserts and deep seas of Egypt where Murawczyk spent time. Its incense-y, smoky and mysterious, he says of the saffron-, cumin- and nutmeg-laced blend. Yang, who is also a trained reiki healer, is particularly drawn to Shaman, describing it as a futurist nomad scent, with a mystical air. The violet leaf note is especially nuanced, she says, and conveys a sense of clairvoyance.

title: Plaintiff in Silicon Valley Hiring Suit Maligns Deal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple has more than $150 billion in the bank, eclipsing the combined cash reserves of Israel and Britain. Google, Intel and Adobe have a total of about $80 billion stored up for a rainy day.

title: The Drawbacks of Puppy Love
description: A few years ago, I came across a sign in the window of a New York City pet store near two bars. I dont recall the exact wording, but it was something like: Do not buy a puppy when drunk.

title: Theater Critics Group Announces Its Winners
description: The Outer Critics Circle, a group of theater writers outside of New York, announced today the winners of its 64th annual competition for Broadway and Off Broadway productions. A Gentlemans Guide to Love and Murder led the award tally with four honors, including best new Broadway musical and best actor in a musical (Jefferson Mays), followed by Bullets Over Broadway and The Glass Menagerie with three apiece.

title: Two Days After He Was Beaten, East Village Assault Victim Dies
description: A 68-year-old man who was attacked and beaten about a block from his home in the East Village has died from his injuries, the police said.

title: Popular Demand
description: General Sentiment scores social activity across sources like Facebook, Twitter, RSS feeds, blogs, forums and article comments. In the four weeks to April 27, fans of How I Met Your Mother and Game of Thrones drove frequent mentions of their TV shows on these so-called second screens.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 6:45 P.M. (Cinemax) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nlisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls dead mother? Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that dont often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you dont want anyone to take an ax to them, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director Guillermo del Toro, the reigning godfather of motion picture horror, is only an executive producer on the film, she wrote, it fits with the more successful movies hes signed on to. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home thats become a rattling cage.

title: Armed Police Begin Antiterrorism Patrols in Beijing
description: Updated, 12:24 a.m. ET| With China in a grim and complicated fight against terrorism, Beijing has deployed 150 special armed teams to carry out antiterrorist stability maintenance at key junctions throughout the city, Chinese news media reported. The mission of these teams, which began their patrols at 9 a.m. Monday, is to ensure that the capital is completely covered in space and time, direction and position against terrorist and other violent acts, the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau was quoted as saying.

title: Chinas Coal Dependency Threatens Efforts to Curb Warming

The police had earlier posted photos online of individuals they were seeking for their role in the mass gathering, traffic blocking, beating and smashing incident.

title: Staying on Parents Plan May Lead to Healthier Paychecks
description: One of the earliest pieces of the health-care law to go into effect  and one of the easiest to understand  was the one that allowed adults under age 26 to remain on their parents insurance plan. It has long been clear that the policy has somewhat increased the insurance rate among young adults. Now a new study suggests the effects may be much broader, also leading to increases in educational attainment and the wages of young adults.

I was tickled by the recognition so I shared the link with my Twitter followers. But minutes later a fellow food-policy advocate, a woman with two advanced degrees and a book to her name (but no children), tweeted back archly: Congrats. Does having a cat count?
