description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Lionel Shriver has said she is perversely nostalgic for her previous commercial failure. This week, Francine Prose and Mohsin Hamid discuss the draws and drawbacks of success for writers.

title: A Variety of Performances to Mark  Walker Art Centers 75th Anniversary
description: The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis will celebrate its 75th anniversary with an expansive season that will include world premieres by the multidisciplinary artist Ralph Lemon, the playwright and director Richard Maxwell, and the performance artist and filmmaker Miranda July. There will also be mini-festivals devoted to the music of Bryce Dessner, the guitarist in the National who also writes for classical ensembles, and the choreographer Steve Paxton.

title: The Things We Keep and What Makes Them So Special
description: The wedding section of The Times publishes an occasional series of readers wedding-related stories and photos, called Wedding Album. This months theme is: Wedding keepsakes.

title: Today in Small Business: Is Entrepreneurship Dying?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Privacy Group Challenges Surveillance Practices in Britain
description: LONDON  British privacy advocates introduced a legal challenge on Tuesday against one of the countrys intelligence agencies, saying the agency illegally hacked personal computers.

title: A New Line | Cory Arcangels Latest Conceptual Art Project: Fashion
description: Cory Arcangel keeps his laptop perched on a small elevated desk in his Sunset Park, Brooklyn studio. Lately, hes been trying to stand up while he works  not because its physically healthier, but because it helps curtail time-wasting. I find that when youre standing, theres a certain threshold for browsing, says the 35-year-old technology-based artist. You dont go on Facebook. Theres something about having to use physical energy. Im trying all these techniques so that I dont fall into a dangerous hole that Im prone to, that Ive been prone to for 20 years.

title: When Driverless Cars Break the Law
description: There is little doubt that the technology behind driverless cars is nearly advanced enough for mainstream use. Google plans to make its biggest public display yet of its cars on Tuesday, when it takes reporters on spins around Mountain View, Calif. Carmakers like BMW and Toyota are also preparing to sell cars that drive themselves.

title: In Performance: Gil Shaham
description: This weeks In Performance video features the violinist Gil Shaham in a performance of the Gigue from Bachs Partita No. 3. On May 18 Mr. Shaham will join the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall for a performance of Bergs Violin Concerto. His most recent album, 1930s Violin Concertos, a two-CD set released in February, is a compilation of performances of five works, mostly recorded live with major orchestras.

title: Nina Stemme to Sing Brnnhilde in Washington Operas Ring
description: One of the worlds most sought-after Brnnhildes, the Swedish soprano Nina Stemme, will sing the role in the nations capital in 2016 when Washington National Opera stages Wagners complete Ring cycle for the first time, after money woes curtailed a previous effort.

title: Yiddish Godot to Open Beckett Festival in Northern Ireland
description: Vartn af Godot, the Yiddish version of Samuel Becketts absurdist masterpiece Waiting for Godot, turns out to have legs. The production, a collaboration between the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater that played in New York last fall, has been invited to kick off the Happy Days Enniskillen International Beckett Festival in Northern Ireland. The production opens on July 31 and will run the length of the festival, through Aug. 10.

title: Sriracha Factory Irritates Some California Noses, but Entices Politicians
description: IRWINDALE, Calif.  Until a few months ago, Sriracha was a mere hot sauce, offering a spicy kick to eggs, soup, grilled cheese or a Bloody Mary.

title: A Postseason Full of Spotlights, Some Glaring
description: It was much like one of those great New York pro basketball nights in the 1990s, when the best player on the planet would bring down the house and, on very special occasions, close it down for the season as well.

title: Modern Style in Minneapolis
description: In the Uptown neighborhood of Minneapolis, Qais Munhazim, a Ph.D. candidate in international security, wants to show that Afghan men can be stylish and chic.

title: AT&Ts Deal Strategy Raises Questions
description: AT&Ts deal dialing is emitting a shaky signal.

title: Airbus Profit Beats Estimates
description: PARIS  Lower costs linked to production of its A380 superjumbo jet and favorable exchange rates helped lift Airbus Group, the European aerospace giant, to a better-than-expected profit in the first quarter, the company said Tuesday.

title: Finding Old Ireland in Handball Alleys
description: The most recent Look features handball courts, or alleys, in Ireland. For hundreds of years, outdoor handball was a popular sport there, but now scores of abandoned courts dot the landscape in various states of ruin. The pictures were part of the photographer Kenneth O Hallorans M.F.A. thesis at the University of Ulster last year. Its the latest in a series of his personal projects with Irish themes, including Tales From the Promised Land, which documented the collapse of the countrys real estate market. The magazine has featured O Hallorans pictures of dancers at the World Irish Dancing Championships and, most recently, from his trek up Croagh Patrick. Recently I asked him about this latest project of his.

title: Professor Trades Harvard for Rough-and-Tumble of Indian Politics
description: KOLKATA, India  One afternoon in April, Sugata Bose, a history professor at Harvard University, set out from his house in Sarat Bose Road to a lower-middle-class neighborhood in Jadavpur, the constituency in the eastern city of Kolkata where he is running for Parliament as a candidate of the Trinamool Congress, the governing party in the state of West Bengal.

title: Highbridge Capital Continues Hiring Spree in London
description: Updated, 2:06 p.m. |

title: For Late Arrivals, Airbnb Broadens Its Approach
description: In the popular imagination, Airbnb is something slightly complicated. It is best known, for instance, for making that long-awaited trip to Paris more interesting and less expensive. But how often does one go to Paris? So the company is broadening its ambitions to appeal to other sorts of travelers. It is introducing Tuesday two new features that cater to a different sort of guest: the impulsive type, the dawdler, the last-minute planner.

title: After Ticket and Arrest, Alec Baldwin Gives New York a Piece of His Mind
description: From the cover of a magazine this year, the actor Alec Baldwin threatened to leave New York City. The place has changed, he said.

title: NetSuite: Enterprise Software Still Follows a Manufacturing Model
description: The two most contentious of the next generation of enterprise software companies are at it again.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Alternative Therapies
U.N. Mediator on Syria Quits; French Envoy Says Chemicals Were Used
description: UNITED NATIONS  International efforts to end the war in Syria faltered further on Tuesday as the United Nations mediator quit, citing frustrations over the moribund political negotiations, and Frances top diplomat said there was evidence the Syrian government used chemical weapons more than a dozen times after it signed the treaty banning them.

title: The Brewing M.&A. Bubble
description: Stop worrying about the tech bubble  there may be an even bigger one inflating beyond the confines of Silicon Valley.

title: From Farm to Firing Range
description: The Iowa Senate candidate who charmed the Internet recently with her hog-castration ada disturbing metaphor for her claim that she would cut pork in Washingtonhas joined the distinguished club of political aspirants who shoot things they dont like, on camera.

title: Image of the Day: May 13
Ambassador From Jordan Freed by Captors in Libya
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The Jordanian ambassador to Libya, who was taken hostage by gunmen in the Libyan capital last month, was freed and returned to Jordan on Tuesday after his government agreed to release a Libyan citizen serving a life sentence on terrorism charges, officials in both countries said.

title: A Major Lift for Fannie and Freddie
description: WASHINGTON  The federal overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Tuesday announced a shift in policies intended to maintain the mortgage finance giants role in parts of the housing market, spur more home lending and aid distressed homeowners.

title: For Morgan Stanley, a Quiet Meeting of Shareholders
description: Morgan Stanleys annual investor meeting lasted 20 minutes, and no one asked any questions.

title: Kristin Chenoweth to Return to Broadway in On the Twentieth Century
description: The Tony Award winner Kristin Chenoweth will return to Broadway in February as the Hollywood diva Lily Garland in On the Twentieth Century, the 1978 musical comedy about antics aboard a luxury train trip from Chicago to New York City, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

title: Appeals Court Grants Stay of Execution in Texas Based on Mental Disability Claim
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  A little more than two hours before he was scheduled to be put to death here, a convicted murderer was granted a stay of execution by a federal appeals court on Tuesday so the courts could review his claim that he is mentally disabled  a disability, his lawyers argued, that state agencies had long known and concealed.

title: To Compete With PlayStation on Price, Microsoft Offers Xbox Without Kinect Motion Sensor
description: SEATTLE A few months ago, Microsoft talked about Kinect, the motion- and voice-controlled sensor for the Xbox, as an integral part of the companys video game plans.

title: Stuyvesant Town, Bastion of Affordable Housing, Is on Way Back to Auction
description: Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, the largest apartment complex in Manhattan, is most likely headed back to the auction block, in a real estate deal that would represent a test of Mayor Bill de Blasios goal to make New York an affordable place to live.

title: Willie Nelson Donates Collection to the University of Texas
description: Willie Nelson may have spent much of his life on the road, but a good part of his artistic remains will rest forever in Texas, thanks to a donation by the singer to the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History at the University of Texas in Austin.

title: Voting for Change: Researching the Issues at Stake in Indias Election
description: What happens when you ask 814 million people to decide the future of their country? The answer will be coming soon for India, which this week is concluding a huge, 35-day election for seats in the national Parliament. Observers say the results could be momentous, with polls suggesting that voters are fed up with slow economic or political progress and favor decisive change  even at the risk of upsetting the nations fragile balance between its religious and social groups.

title: After Hours | A Ribald Downtown Auction on Behalf of Creative Freedom
description: Last night offered a classic instance of a time-honored Manhattan tradition: arty downtowners doing a little song and dance to extract crucial funding from monied uptowners. The setting was the opulent subterranean bote the Diamond Horseshoe, which hosted its annual benefit for the not-for-profit performance space P.S. 122, which has been staging amazing and bizarre shows in the East Village for more than 30 years, with performers ranging from Eric Bogosian and John Leguizamo to Annie Dorsen and Young Jean Lee.

title: So Much Food, It Fills a Hall
description: Food halls are all about gratification, both immediate (a chorizo and potato taco to eat on the spot) and delayed (a chunky jar of anchovies to take home). These bounteous markets are not new to the city; Macys opened its Cellar nearly 40 years ago. In 1997, the former Nabisco factory was transformed into Chelsea Market on West 15th Street, setting off the modern proliferation of indoor markets.

title: Wheelies: The Wooden Volkswagen Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Times Minute | Newarks Next Mayor
description: Also on the Minute, new privacy protections in Europe and developing bird-safe glass.

title: Times Minute | Newarks Next Mayor
description: In the Video

title: Churchill Downs Owner Joins Bid for Casino in Upstate New York
description: ALBANY  One of the most recognizable names in horse racing is joining the field in New Yorks sprint into big-time gambling.

title: You Start in Spain, but Theres Room to Roam
description: The name means the fifth pine, a Spanish idiom for the boondocks, which was probably a stretch even seven years ago when El Quinto Pino opened on West 24th Street, across from the canyon wall of London Terrace. The thumbnail curve of the sardine-can tapas bar is just the way its been since the beginning, packed, every seat there and on the opposite wall a few inches away taken almost any time you show up.

title: Conservative Pick Set to Win G.O.P. Primary in Nebraska
description: WASHINGTON  Conservatives are poised to declare victory on Tuesday in Nebraska, where their preferred Senate candidate, Benjamin E. Sasse, is well positioned to win the Republican nomination in a race that the Tea Party has made a priority in a year that so far has favored the establishment.

title: What Exactly Was Donald Sterlings Offense?
description: We can probably agree that the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling made offensive comments. But was his offense thinking racist thoughts? Or saying them out loud? Had he not been recorded, Sterling would have received a lifetime achievement award from the N.A.A.C.P. The victim of his remarks was himself: Sterling managed to (further) trash his own reputation. No one else was really injured. Is purity of thought the expectation for team owners? MARK ALEXANDER, ST. LOUIS

title: Tech Star Is Leaving Goldman Sachs to Join Hedge Fund
description: At Goldman Sachs, Anthony J. Noto has won some big-name business, including leading the initial public offering of Twitter last year.

title: A Plush Bike Trip in Tennessee
description: Trek Travel has partnered with Blackberry Farm, a Relais & Chteaux property in eastern Tennessee, to host the Great Smoky Mountains/Blackberry Farm Bike Tour in November.

title: Detroit, From Both Side of the Coin
description: Bill Rauhauser spent much of his life taking pictures as a hobby while working as an engineer. But those twin tugs gave his work a range and balance few can match.

title: Lane Closings Were Idiotic, Christie Aide Testifies
description: TRENTON  The chief spokesman for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey testified on Tuesday that he was misled about why lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge were closed last September, and was shocked and disoriented when he learned that the motive appeared to be political vengeance.

title: Observed | At the Echo Park Craft Fair, California-Style Spirituality Rises Once Again
description: As far as Southern California festival style goes, the Echo Park Craft Fair is a long way from the bare midriffs and hippie posturing of Coachella. The biannual design and food festival, which celebrated its fifth anniversary last weekend, has evolved from an intimate backyard bazaar into the see-and-be-seen happening for a certain swath of the L.A. creative class. In a city without much pedestrian activity, the fair  which, despite its name, takes place in Silver Lake  generates plenty of it. And with all that foot traffic comes a uniquely Angeleno sort of fashion parade, one with a distinctly spiritual vibe.

title: Ex-Barclays Chiefs New Venture to Raise $400 Million in Private Placement
description: LONDON  The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., is seeking to raise another $400 million to fund its investments in the African financial sector.

title: In a Shift From Deficit Concerns, the Senate Will Take Up Tax Breaks
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday shrugged off the deficit concerns that were once an animating force on Capitol Hill, voting 96-3 to take up a package of business tax breaks without offering any way to pay for them.

title: Talking to Children About Their Disabilities, With Metaphors and Minecraft
description: Year-round, those of us who have kids with disabilities in our lives spend countless hours discussing them: meetings, consultations, casual conversations with friends. And yet we rarely, if ever, talk directly to children themselves about their challenges.

title: Get Rid of Condom Policing
description: New York City drove down its H.I.V. infection rate in part by flooding the streets with millions upon millions of free condoms each year. At the same time, the police have undermined this effort by using condom possession as evidence to support prostitution charges  and by simply seizing condoms from sex workers and destroying them.

title: Aging Tuscan Port Vies to Dismantle Costa Concordia
description: PIOMBINO, Italy  Workers are hurriedly revamping the aged port in this smoggy Tuscan city, trucking in boulders to construct and fortify jetties, and enlarging its facilities to refit and dismantle ships. They are scheduled to dredge and deepen the harbor next month.

title: Up for Discussion: Offering Parental Leave and Entering a New Market
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners touched on how they handle parental leave at their companies, before moving on to discuss Skylight Groups expansion into San Francisco.

title: Governor Christies Spokesman Testifies
description: Michael Drewniak, the press secretary for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, testified before a legislative committee on the investigation into the closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge.

title: Top U.N. Mediator in Syria Resigns
description: The United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and the Syria mediator, Lakhdar Brahimi, discussed Mr. Brahimis decision to step down after nearly two years of seeking an end to the conflict.

title: At Their Best on the Brink
description: PITTSBURGH  Henrik Lundqvist, the king of Game 7s, stood tall again for the Rangers on Tuesday night. He stopped 35 of 36 Penguins shots  even a couple without his stick in a chaotic goal-mouth scramble in the final minutes  to spearhead a thrilling 2-1 victory that capped a historic comeback from a three-games-to-one series deficit.

title: Federal Panel Appears Split Over Virginias Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In sharp exchanges pitting the right of states to set marriage rules against equal protection for gay and lesbian couples, a three-judge federal appeals panel here heard arguments on Tuesday on the constitutionality of Virginias ban on same-sex marriages.

title: Scene City: Art World Field Trip to Greenwich
description: Dan Colen retrospective opens at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ex-G.I. Gets Medal of Honor for Lifesaving Acts in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday awarded the Medal of Honor to Sgt. Kyle J. White, an Army radiotelephone operator who struggled for hours through enemy fire in Afghanistan to try to save the lives of wounded soldiers during a surprise attack by Taliban fighters.

title: Marta, a New Pizza Restaurant, Opens
description: Headliner

title: Cast-Iron Steak
description: To cook a fantastic steak on the stovetop, all you need is a cast-iron pan, a sprinkle of salt and a one-inch-thick cut of meat.

title: Theyre Together, but Not on the Same Wavelength
description: Intermission, by the Canadian playwright Daniel Libman, wants desperately to be clever and surprising, but its improbable plot requires too many characters who arent credible and conversations that are convenient rather than organic.

title: Fisherman Likes Sex but Hates the City
description: Sea Marks takes place in that distant, storied past before the invention of email. Still, its amusing to think of the online personals ad its hero, Colm (Patrick Fitzgerald), might have written: Single, virginal fisherman on remote Irish island seeks woman for conversation, companionship and whiskey tippling. Likes: Mackerel, the sea, ale. Dislikes: Organized religion, incense, small presses. Fondness for lyrical twaddle and small craft a plus. (Surely, Colm would have favored the Plenty of Fish site.)

title: Drugs to Aid Alcoholics See Little Use, Study Finds
description: Two medications could help tens of thousands of alcoholics quit drinking, yet the drugs are rarely prescribed to patients, researchers reported on Tuesday.

title: The Gun Report: May 13, 2014
description: Last month, 15-year-old Bayshawn Kelly was critically wounded in a drive-by shooting in Lakeland, Fla. Dayquon Raheem Longs, also 15, was wounded in the same attack. Earlier that day, Kelly had been a passenger in car that was fired at.

title: Lawyers on Olmerts Sentencing
description: Lawyers for the defense and the prosecution spoke after Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel, was sentenced to six years in prison for taking bribes.

title: West Islip: Backyards and Boat Slips
description: Not even a major February snowstorm kept Dragan and Dorota Dejkanovic and their three children, ages 8, 4 and 5 months, from moving into the five-bedroom country Cape on just over half an acre in West Islip, a pretty hamlet on the Great South Bay in Suffolk County.

title: Steak That Sizzles on the Stovetop
description: Like many home cooks, I gave up on steak a while ago.

title: A Tragedy of Silence in Badakhshan
description: ABI BARAK, Afghanistan  Hidden in a valley of the Hindu Kush range, the village of Abi Barik went mostly unnoticed for decades. The hour-plus journey it takes to get to the provincial capital from here, along a rugged and unpaved mountain road, ensured that the residents largely kept to themselves.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Iraq, Palestine and South Africa.

title: Obama Awards Medal of Honor
description: The president awarded Kyle J. White, a former Army sergeant, the Medal of Honor for his actions during combat in Nuristan Province, Afghanistan, on Nov. 9, 2007.

title: Behind the Poster: Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
description: Julie Furer Knutson didnt know much about Edward Albees 1962 play Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? before she started working on a poster design for the revival now at Seattle Rep. But once she started her research, one thing became clear.

title: Valeant and Pershing Square Put Pressure on Allergan
description: A day after rejecting an unsolicited $50 billion bid from Valeant Pharmaceuticals and the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, Allergan, the maker of Botox, faced renewed pressure from its suitors to strike a deal.

title: To Guide the Merger Giants, Strong Hands Are Needed
description: Oh, never mind.

title: Small Comfort as Parents Identify Kidnapped Nigerian Girls on Video
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  When the girls appeared on the screen, parents in the small room at the government compound here dissolved into tears.

title: The Whiteness of Snow, Reflected in Naked Human Bodies
description: In Melinda Rings ambitious new triptych  a dance, Forgetful Snow, and two daytime performance installations  the subject isnt too difficult to work out. Four white walls, including the risers, are painted a dazzling white. (Its Benjamin Moores Super White; the fumes linger.) In the center is a plush white carpet. The dancers are nude.

title: In Store | A Leather Goods Shop Where Everything Old Is New Again
description: Will Adler discovered the massive, 90-year-old saw blade that hangs in the entryway of Will Leather Goods, the store hes opening next week in NoLIta, on a hike with his wife in Webster, Ore. Right by this beautiful waterfall, we spotted an old timber mill, and thats where we found this, he says. We really wanted to bring the woods of Oregon to New York.

title: A Youthful Ensemble Turns Up the Intensity
description: Few concerts reach climaxes in the encores. After an hour or two of strenuous playing, its certainly not unusual for performers to be reluctant to push themselves too much further. Even if the party pieces unveiled when musicians are called back for more burst with dazzling notes, they often end up being merely pleasant.

title: Road to Civil Disobedience Began in South Africa
description: When the young Indian lawyer Mohandas K. Gandhi set sail in 1893 for Durban, the main port in Britains colony in Natal in southeast Africa, he expected his assignment to last no more than a year. Having found it difficult to establish a legal practice in his hometown in Gujarat, he had accepted a short-term commission to assist a Muslim merchant in Durban who was in a financial dispute with another Muslim merchant in Pretoria, capital of the neighboring Boer republic of Transvaal.

title: Derivatives Markets Growing Again, With Few New Protections
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

title: Newarks Voters Choose New Mayor and New Path
description: Councilman Ras Baraka, the fiery scion of a militant poet, was elected mayor of Newarkon Tuesday, signaling a likely shift in the direction that New Jerseys largest city had embarked upon for most of the last decade.

title: Daniel Levy
description: Mr. Levy, 42, is the president and chief executive of CityRealty, a real estate search website that provides information about residential sales and rental listings in New York City, with a focus on Manhattan and Brooklyn. The site also helps to connect buyers with brokers.

title: Paltry Office Pantries Give Way to Sleek Social Spaces
description: For 12 years, employees of Anbau, a luxury real estate investment and development firm, worked in a walk-up on Fifth Avenue with no kitchen pantry to heat lunches or make coffee.

title: Bearing Witness, Losing Her Life
description: Camille Lepage, a photographer who considered it her duty to delve into stories in often-overlooked places, was killed in the Central African Republic. Nicholas Kulish rememebrs.

title: A Renaissance in Rapid City, S.D.
description: In the shadow of monumental Mount Rushmore, Rapid City might suffer from a slight inferiority complex. But this city has always brimmed with resilience. After a devastating flood in 1972, the city landscaped the floodplain with a 10-mile-long bicycle and walking path. In recent years, its once-seedy downtown area has developed a surprising eco-sensibility and a thriving art scene. Along an alleyway, boldly hued murals and graffiti bracket building facades. Main Street Square, the downtown cultural hub, is the site of a newly commissioned public sculpture project. A car-free Memorial Park Promenade will open in June.

title: Larry McMurtry on the Power of the Plains
description: For Larry McMurtry  the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Lonesome Dove and co-author of the Oscar-winning screenplay for Brokeback Mountain  one of the most interesting, and overlooked, aspects of life in the Old West was just how profoundly isolating the westering experience could be. Those plains, those mountains, those deserts were empty, except for the Indians, who didnt make the settlers less lonely, said Mr. McMurtry, 77.

title: A Trail Helps Open Up a Dallas Neighborhood to New Development
description: DALLAS  The din begins around 5 oclock at the Katy Trail Ice House, as predominantly millennial-age beer drinkers grasping 18-ounce schooners spill out of the metal-framed bar and onto an oak-shaded patio in the booming Uptown neighborhood.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Concern for Health of 2 Political Prisoners in Egypt
description: Two young Egyptians detained last year during the military-backed governments deadly crackdown on dissent face serious threats to their health after more than 100 days on hunger strike, according to medical reports made public in recent days.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Senior Barclays Banker
description: Morgan Stanley has hired a senior Barclays banker. He is the latest top deal maker to leave the British firm in recent weeks.

title: Georgia Senate Race Becoming Less of a Long Shot for Democrats
description: New polling from NBC/Marist and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution mixed things up in our Senate model, with our forecasts in Arkansas and Georgia moving in a Democratic direction. The national outcome remains a coin flip, although the new data tipped our forecast from a 54 percent chance that the Republicans will take the Senate this fall to a slightly better than even chance (52 percent) that the Democrats will stay in power.

title: Miller Theater Season
description: The Miller Theater at Columbia University will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths  new music, early music and provocative combinations of the two  in its 2014-15 season. It will open Sept. 18 with Heart and Breath, a production by the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird in which the musicians play commedia dellarte roles and perform 17th-century Italian music filtered through 21st-century sensibilities. The halls signature series, Composer Portraits, will offer overviews of the works of eight living composers, four of them women, representing an expansive array of contemporary styles. The series begins with an evening of recent works by Chou Wen-Chung, performed by the ensembles for which he wrote them  the Brentano String Quartet, Talujon and the New York New Music Ensemble. The International Contemporary Ensemble, with Steven Schick conducting, will devote a program to the Israeli experimentalist Chaya Czernowin, and the string quartet Ethel will perform the world premiere of a new work by Missy Mazzoli on a program that also includes her Harp and Altar, a paean to the Brooklyn Bridge. Other installments of Composer Portraits include programs devoted to Bernard Rands, Keeril Makan, Stefano Gervasoni, Augusta Read Thomas and Anna Clyne. The Millers program also includes a jazz series and occasional pop-up concerts (with free beer), which will announced closer to the performances. The full schedule is at millertheatre.com.

title: Misstep in Re-election Filings May Fell Veteran Congressman From Michigan
description: DETROIT  For nearly 50 years, John Conyers Jr. has represented Detroit in the House of Representatives. He is the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, a founder of the Congressional Black Caucus and the second-longest-serving member of Congress still holding office.

title: A Tony for the Mantel? Maybe Not
description: A leading theater organization is developing proposals  sure to be unpopular with some producers  to stop selling the medallion-topped Tony Awards to scores of investors who help finance winning Broadway shows.

title: Latest Airplane Amenity: An Apartment
description: The airline that introduced the Flying Nanny for traveling families just announced more residentially inspired amenities, including a one-bedroom apartment in the air.

title: Kick-Starting a Season With Frolics and Feats
description: Slowly, cautiously, tentatively, American Ballet Theater is improving its spring gala, the motley extravaganza with which it annually opens its big eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Until a couple of years ago, this celebration had settled into a rut: a few too many nonerotic bedroom pas de deux; dozens too many fouett turns from one ballerina after another; and curtain speeches that sounded like shopping lists. Everything onstage encouraged the idea that ballet was the tritest and most predictable of all art forms.

title: Seeing God in Snakes, Strippers and Tattoos
description: Its not clear what Aram Garriga thinks he is accomplishing in his simplistic American Jesus, but hes not accomplishing much. Whatever hopes you might have had that this Spanish filmmaker would be able to do for American Christianity what another outsider, Alexis de Tocqueville, did for America as a whole are dashed as soon as the snake-handling minister shows up.

title: A Look Back at a Year of Top Voices
description: The Metropolitan Operas season closed on Saturday with a matinee of Rossinis La Cenerentola and an evening performance of Bellinis I Puritani. On this final day, the Met presented two of the three reigning bel canto tenors who had such success at the house this spring: Juan Diego Flrez as the prince in Cenerentola, and Lawrence Brownlee as Arturo in Puritani.

title: First Glimpse of Missing Nigerian Girls
description: Video released by Boko Haram in May 2014 is the first glimpse of the missing schoolgirls since they were abducted on April 14, 2014.

title: Without a Hit Wallet, Square Tries Another Approach
description: Square, the mobile payments start-up, is a testament to how tough it is to sell people on the idea of a mobile wallet. Even after scoring a big partnership with Starbucks Coffee and offering a futuristic app that lets people pay for things just by saying their name, Squares mobile wallet gained little traction. Now the company has stopped offering its wallet app in favor of a new approach.

title: Where Hope Is Scarce, Terrorism Takes Root
description: The residents of Sidi Moumen, a sprawling shantytown on the outskirts of Casablanca, Morocco, live in tin-roofed shacks without electricity, running water or modern sewage disposal. The area sits atop a garbage dump where boys run wild in packs and engage in fierce soccer matches that often explode into violence. Aerial shots depict this slum as a fetid, desiccated wasteland, in which the pickings are thin, even for scavengers. To sell oranges in a market for a pittance, you must fight for space.

title: Bearing Witness, Losing Her Life
description: I got to know Camille Lepage on my first trip to South Sudan last summer. A jaunty young Frenchwoman who tooled around the rutted dirt roads of Juba on the back of a beat-up old motorcycle, she was hoping to work with me on the story I had come to town to cover, and I had received a slew of email messages from her.

title: Chinas Demand Threatens Rare Hardwoods in Mekong
description: Chinas surging demand for luxury furniture and a revived cultural tradition are not only taking a toll on the forests of its Southeast Asian neighbors but also fueling a deadly crime wave across the region, according to an environmental monitoring group.

title: Walgreen Shareholder Opposes Potential Deal to Reincorporate Abroad
description: As the drugstore chain Walgreen considers a deal that would allow it to reincorporate abroad, many shareholders are elated, saying it could save millions of dollars a year on taxes.

title: Why Divestment Can Be Successful
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Data and Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: Research Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Raising the Costa Concordia in 2013
description: In September 2013, engineers in Giglio, Italy, worked all day to pull up the Costa Concordia cruise liner, which struck a reef and keeled over, killing 32 people on Jan. 13, 2012.

title: Different N.B.A. Loyalties for Black and White Neighborhoods
description: It is no secret that the N.B.A. is especially popular among black Americans. About 45 percent of people who watched N.B.A. games during the 2012-2013 regular season were black, even though African-Americans make up 13 percent of the countrys population.

title: French Ministers Statement
description: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said there were strong indications that the Syrian government had carried out attacks using chemical agents in recent weeks.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,306 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments at Collective 2 Fair
description: Sunday marked the end of the second annual collectible design fair, Collective 2. For the events sophomore edition, the organizers chose a new more central venue, Skylight at Moynihan Station  housed in the imposing former James A. Farley Post Office on 33rd Street  and added 17 new dealers. The fairs founder, Steven Learner, is determined to differentiate Collective from the rest of New York Design Week  and every detail, from the carefully curated roster of galleries to the vintage Cadillac exhibited by the events sponsor, reinforced its distinctiveness. Here, a few of the best in show.

title: Ruling in Airbnbs Case in New York
description: The Supreme Court in New York squashed a subpoena served to Airbnb by the states attorney general that sought information about the start-ups users.

title: A Victory for Airbnb in New York
description: Airbnb, the popular apartment-sharing service, won a legal standoff Tuesday when a state judge ruled that the company did not have to give up customer records as part of an investigation by the New York attorney general.

title: To Dream in Different Cultures
description: WHEN Doug Hollan arrived on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi for his anthropology dissertation fieldwork in a rice farming village, his Toraja neighbors wanted to take turns sleeping with him and his wife.

title: Ordering Google to Forget
description: In a ruling that could undermine press freedoms and free speech, the highest court of the European Union said on Tuesday that Google must comply with requests from individuals to remove links on search results pages to newspaper articles and other web pages that might cause embarrassment.

title: Labor Talks Begin at Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened labor talks on Tuesday with the Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, the union that represents the stagehands who build, move and light the sets and props at the opera house.

title: Eric Schmidt Has an Interest. Is It a Conflict?
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York last month appointed a three-person commission to offer thoughts on the use of technology in schools.

title: Justice Dept. Criticized on Spying Statements
description: WASHINGTON  Two Democratic senators accused the Obama administration on Tuesday of seeking to ignore or justify statements it made to the Supreme Court about warrantless surveillance by the National Security Agency, contributing to what they called a culture of misinformation by the executive branch.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 30
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: More Shonda Rhimes for ABC, Plus a Partnership With ESPN
description: AS the 2014-15 television upfront week continued on Tuesday, the presentations ran the gamut from A, for ABC, to U, for Univision, with some notable crossovers in between.

title: The Politics of Income Inequality
description: The years from the late 19th and early 20th centuries were not the most egalitarian in American history. Robber barons roamed the economy, living off lavish rents generated by powerful cartels and industrial monopolies.

title: 68 Pakistani Lawyers Are Charged With Blasphemy After Protesting the Police
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In the latest blasphemy case to highlight growing intolerance in Pakistan, the police in Punjab Province said Tuesday that they had filed blasphemy charges against a group of 68 lawyers at the instigation of a Sunni extremist leader.

title: An Inconvenient Truth About Our Food
description: Fed Up is probably the most important movie to be made since An Inconvenient Truth, to which its related in a couple of ways.

title: Rutgers Cuts Quarterback Charged in Minnesota Assault Case
description: Rutgers said Tuesday that quarterback Philip Nelson had been dismissed from the team after his arrest over the weekend in connection with an assault on a man outside a bar in Mankato, Minn.

title: A Trip in a Self-Driving Car Now Seems Routine
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Boring.

title: Punched Out: The Death of Derek Boogaard
description: Derek Boogaard was one of the N.H.L.s most feared fighters before overdosing on May 13, 2011. The New York Times examined the life and death of the professional hockey player in 2011.

title: Tunisian Discontent Reflected in Protests That Have Idled Mines
description: GAFSA, Tunisia  Tunisians often say the first uprising of the Arab Spring began not in 2010 after the self-immolation of a fruit vendor, Mohamed Bouazizi, but in 2008, when protests over corrupt hiring practices at the mines of Gafsa ran on for six months. It is a measure of the lingering challenges of Tunisias revolution that people here are still in revolt.

title: Sallie Mae to Pay Fine Over Loans to Troops
description: Sallie Mae, the giant student lender, and Navient, previously a loan servicing unit of Sallie Mae, have agreed to pay $97 million to settle allegations by federal regulators that military service members were charged excessive interest and fees on student loans.

title: A Trainer in Twilight and a Horse Poised for Its Day in the Sun
description: When California Chrome pulled away for a one-and-three-quarter-lengths victory in the Kentucky Derby on May 3, Art Sherman, 77, became the oldest trainer to saddle a winner in the United States most famous horse race.

title: Fognini Finds His Antics Dont Play Well at Home in Italy
description: ROME  The Italian Open embraces its natives with more passion than perhaps any other tournament, but the top Italian man did not feel that warmth this week.

title: Doubts Raised About Off-Label Use of Subsys, a Strong Painkiller
description: Almost overnight, a powerful new painkiller has become a $100 million business and a hot Wall Street story.

title: The Speakers Sand Trap
description: The Speaker is hitting the links.

title: Common Sense at the Library
description: The New York Public Library has abandoned its plan to renovate its landmark building in Midtown. There will be no hybrid lending-and-research library behind those stone lions on Fifth Avenue, no towering glass atrium looking out on Bryant Park. The dumpy Mid-Manhattan Library, across the street, will not be sold. No books will be banished to New Jersey.

title: In Season of Protest, Haverford Speaker Is Latest to Bow Out
description: Haverford College on Tuesday joined a growing list of schools to lose commencement speakers to protests from the left, when Robert J. Birgeneau, a former chancellor at the University of California, Berkeley, withdrew from this weekends event.

title: The Square People, Part 1
description: HANOI, Vietnam  I think Ill plan to go from Kiev to Hanoi more often. Its only when you go to two seemingly disconnected places that you see the big trends, and one of the big ones Ive noticed is the emergence of The Square People.

title: Lebanese TV Executive Is Summoned to Hague Court
description: PARIS  An international tribunal that has spent five years and more than $325 million investigating a political assassination in Lebanon without making a single arrest finally got on Tuesday its first look at an accused in the dock. But it was none of the five men charged with complicity in the 2005 murder of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

title: Judge Wants Trials for 3 in Bombing Case to Stay in Boston
description: BOSTON  A federal judge on Tuesday said he wanted to try to find juries in Boston for the trials of three friends of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the suspect in last years marathon bombings. But he indicated that if impartial jurors could not be found here, he might seek a jury from Springfield, Mass., about 90 miles west.

title: To See Baseballs Best Young Aces This Year, Try Operating Room
description: They are twin poles, for the moment, of a grim trend that has become the story of the baseball season: Matt Harvey and Jose Fernandez, must-see ace right-handers just starting their major league careers, sidelined suddenly by a serious elbow injury.

title: Around a Sardinian Table, a Fractious Debate
description: LU FRAILI, Sardinia  April was lovely, as always, in Sardinia. The summer tourists had not yet arrived; the island was covered with wildflowers and the wild asparagus was pushing up among the cork trees. This spring felt especially healing after the death and destruction wrought by cyclone Cleopatra last November. The storm had damaged my 84-year-old fathers house, and I had come to deal with the repairs.

title: Nets Down to Final Shot Against Heat
description: The Nets have several veterans with reputations as clutch performers.

title: A Call for Justice for Syrians
description: For three years, the United Nations Security Council has failed to end the violence in Syria, largely because Russia and China have stubbornly blocked constructive action and protected President Bashar al-Assad. A new French-led move to have the Council refer Syria to the International Criminal Court for possible prosecution of war crimes wont end the slaughter either. But it would underscore the worlds revulsion at atrocities by both sides and its insistence that those responsible be brought to justice.

title: Pets and Medication
Mets Pitcher Who Made the Most of One Hit Is in Australia
description: In their 52 years of existence, the Mets have had any number of players who had only one base hit in their time with the team, from Calvin Schiraldi to Turk Wendell to Aaron Heilman. Eric Campbell, who made his debut last weekend as a backup infielder, is the newest member of the club, though perhaps not for long.

title: A Safety Plan With Swedish Logic and City Smarts
description: STOCKHOLM  The quest to eradicate serious crashes here began with a happy accident.

title: Deadly Fire Roars Through Coal Mine in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  An explosion on Tuesday in a coal mine in western Turkey killed more than 200 miners and left hundreds of others trapped underground, Turkeys energy minister said early Wednesday.

title: Girding for a Fight, McConnell Enlists His Wife
description: WASHINGTON  At Harvard Business School, Elaine L. Chao kept card files on her classmates, then later kept tabs on their careers. As labor secretary, she had gold-colored coins minted with her name in bas-relief and employed a Veep-like staff member who carried around her bag.

title: Heading Out on Its Own, Citizens Bank Faces a Tough Climate
description: Being cast off from a struggling foreign parent company might bring on an identity crisis for some institutions. Not so for Citizens Bank, which is looking to turn its coming independence from the Royal Bank of Scotland into an opportunity to strengthen its consumer banking in the United States.

title: Sore Right Elbow Puts Beltran on a Long List of Injured Yankees
description: Carlos Beltran received a cortisone injection on Monday after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed bone spurs in his right elbow.

title: Barely Enough to Wet Ones Whistle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Just as I love a book or film that holds its secrets until close to the end, so do I love a crossword puzzle that does the same thing. Victor Barocass Wednesday puzzle does just that.

title: U.S. Envoys See a Rwanda Moment in Syrias Escalating Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Speaking at the State Department after being sworn in on Tuesday, Tom Malinowski, the new assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights and labor, said his daughter quizzed him recently about what role he had played 20 years ago, when the Clinton administration failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda.

title: Conservative Wins G.O.P. Senate Nomination in Nebraska
description: WASHINGTON  Conservatives claimed victory on Tuesday in Nebraska, where the Senate candidate they preferred won the Republican nomination in a race the Tea Party had made a priority in a year that so far has favored the establishment.

title: For Wheeler, 118 Pitches, All of Them a Struggle
description: This was a chance for Zack Wheeler to assert himself, to shake off his recent struggles, when he took to the mound against the Yankees at Yankees Stadium on Tuesday night.

title: Malik Bendjelloul, Oscar Winner for Sugar Man Film, Dies at 36
description: Malik Bendjelloul, a Swedish filmmaker who won the 2013 Academy Award for best documentary with his debut feature, Searching for Sugar Man, about a forgotten American balladeer who, unwittingly, had achieved fame halfway around the world, was found dead on Tuesday in Stockholm. He was 36.

title: Climate Change Deemed Growing Security Threat by Military Researchers
description: WASHINGTON  The accelerating rate of climate change poses a severe risk to national security and acts as a catalyst for global political conflict, a report published Tuesday by a leading government-funded military research organization concluded.

title: 26 Percent of Worlds Adults Are Anti-Semitic, Survey Finds
description: Twenty-six percent of all adults worldwide harbor anti-Semitic attitudes and nearly half have never heard of the Holocaust, the Anti-Defamation League said Tuesday in what it described as an unprecedented and sobering global survey that assessed the level and intensity of hostility toward Jews.

title: Videos Said to Show Force-Feeding of Detainees at Guantnamo Bay
description: The military has made videotapes of military medical officials force-feeding detainees on hunger strikes at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, according to a court filing on Tuesday. The filing asks a judge to issue an emergency order to the military requiring it to preserve the tapes. In 2007, it came to light that the C.I.A. had destroyed videotapes of its interrogation sessions showing the use of the suffocation technique called waterboarding. The militarys practice of force-feeding detainees has been a major issue in habeas corpus lawsuits. The procedure involves strapping a detainee into a restraint chair and inserting a gastric tube through the nose and down the throat, through which liquid nutritional supplement is poured into the stomach. In February, a federal appeals court in the District of Columbia ruled that the courts have jurisdiction to hear challenges of the conditions of confinement at Guantnamo as part of habeas corpus lawsuits.

title: Ethics Complaint Against Googles Chairman
description: A consumer watchdog group is arguing that Eric E. Schmidt, Googles executive chairman, is unethically participating in an advisory panel to dole out billions in funds for educational technology in New York.

title: A Resort in Galilee Rises Where Jesus May Have Taught
description: MIGDAL, Israel  For the Rev. Juan M. Solana, it was the spiritual equivalent of striking oil.

title: The Mine Collapse in Turkey
description: The Turkish energy minister, Taner Yildiz, spoke about the fire in a coal mine in Soma that trapped hundreds.

title: Groups Back Global Plan for Tracking Commercial Flights
description: MONTREAL  Airlines, governments, pilots and aircraft manufacturers all agreed at a conference on Tuesday that a global system for tracking commercial aircraft is badly needed, a United Nations aviation agency said. But the parties sidestepped a key question: whether aircrews should be able to turn off all the equipment that makes them visible.

title: The Hague: Court to Review British War Crime Inquiry
description: The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court, Fatou Bensouda, said Tuesday that she had reopened a preliminary war crimes investigation into accusations that British officials were responsible for the systematic abuse of Iraqi prisoners by Britains military from 2003 to 2008. A similar investigation was closed in 2006, but Ms. Bensouda said she would review whether new information she received in January justified reopening the case. Although Iraq has not signed the Rome Statute, which governs the courts proceedings, Britain has, and its citizens can in theory be prosecuted for crimes committed in Iraq or elsewhere. However, the court, which is based in The Hague, can proceed only if the allegations are not being properly investigated by the British authorities themselves.

title: How Person Retains Interest at Episode 23
description: The paranoid techno thriller Person of Interest, which ended its third season on Tuesday night on CBS, is subject to all the conventional wisdom about why broadcast drama is inherently inferior to cable. It presumably faces network censors and meddling executives; it passed through the homogenizing pilot process; its produced by committee over a long schedule (with 13 writers credited for this seasons 23 episodes).

title: From Vandals to Artists: Time Rouses More Appreciation for Graffiti
description: A few minutes before sunrise on Monday, a train left the subway yard in Corona, Queens, where most cars on the No. 7 line spend the night in slumber.

title: Theft Charges for 4 With Ties to a Provider of Special Ed
description: Four men with ties to one of New York Citys largest providers of preschool special education services were accused on Tuesday of stealing $12.5 million in state and city funds, according to the Queens district attorney.

title: List of Names in Sex Assaults Roils Columbia
description: The list of names first appeared last Wednesday, each scrawled in a different hand, on the wall of a womens bathroom in Hamilton Hall, an academic building at Columbia University.

title: Arrest Made in Fatal Beating of 68-Year-Old
description: The police arrested a 20-year-old man Tuesday in connection with the fatal sidewalk attack of a 68-old-man on Friday, the authorities said.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 13, 2014
Fargo Recap: Baring Teeth
description: Updated, 4:58 p.m. | Malvo has never sat more squarely in the drivers seat  quite literally  than in this fifth episode, the midpoint of the FX series Fargo. His dark eyes practically drill holes into the rear-view mirror as he unsettles his blackmail victim, Stavros Milos, by spinning tales of wolves whose only mission is to devour whatever stands in their way.

title: H. R. Giger, Artist Who Gave Life to Alien Creature, Dies at 74
description: H. R. Giger, a Swiss painter, sculptor and set designer who mined his own nightmares in creating phantasmagorical works, including the title character  slimy, eyeless and oddly sexual  in the 1979 hit film Alien, died on Monday in Zurich. He was 74.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 14, 2014
description: More and more Internet users want a little of the ephemerality and the forgetfulness of pre-digital days.

title: Top Court Champions Freedom to Annoy
description: The criminal defense lawyer William Kunstler used to say, This is New York and theres no law against being annoying.

title: Cleric Spars With Prosecutor at Terror Trial
description: Under a prosecutors rigorous cross-examination, the British cleric who has been testifying at his own terrorism trial in Manhattan turned combative and defensive on Tuesday.

title: Colin Pillinger, Who Set Europes Eye on Space, Dies at 70
description: Colin Pillinger, a British planetary scientist who in 2003 led a shoestring effort to put a European lander on Mars for the first time  a mission that failed to reach its destination but succeeded in elevating the profile of space exploration in a region not known for it  died last Wednesday in Cambridge, England. He was 70.

title: Judith Cummings, Chief of a Bureau for The Times, Dies at 68
description: Judith Cummings, who was the first black woman to head a national news bureau for The New York Times, serving as chief correspondent in Los Angeles from 1985 to 1988, was found dead on May 6 at her home in Detroit. She was 68.

title: Lorenzo H. Zambrano, Head of Cement Giant Cemex, Dies at 70
description: Lorenzo H. Zambrano, who turned his family-owned cement company, Cemex, into a giant spanning five continents, and who exemplified a generation of Mexican business leaders as they embraced globalization, died on Monday in Madrid. He was 70.

title: Changes Announced to Puerto Rican Day Parade
description: This year, the National Puerto Rican Day Parade is returning to its roots.

title: Former Head of Glaxo in China Is Accused of Bribery
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese authorities sent a strong warning to the pharmaceutical industry on Wednesday, implicating a top Western executive at GlaxoSmithKline in a long-running bribery scheme.

title: How to Arrange Flowers, the Brooklyn Way
description: Given the Brooklynization of the world, its no surprise that when the Little Flower School made its way from Brooklyn to London last month, formally trained florists from as far north as Scotland and as far south as Cornwall made the trek to learn how to craft the stunning, free-form arrangements coveted by New Yorks creative elite and fashion set. Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen hosted the two-day immersive workshop to help British florists break out of the dome (think: those compact bridal bouquets). An old courtyard filled with 5,000 cut flowers set the scene for Ryhanens opening lecture, in which she challenged their 14 pupils to ditch the flower foam, show no fear and let their imaginations run wild with the bucketfuls of foxgloves and peonies before them.

title: A Fresh Hub for Young Talent at New York Design Week
description: If locals have one complaint about New York Design Week, its that the city can seem over-reliant on foreign brands and ho-hum showrooms for content. In 2010, Monica Khemsurov (a T contributor) and Jill Singer of the online magazine Sight Unseen founded the NoHo Design District to counteract that problem with a neighborhood-wide festival of quirky installations, events and pop-ups that ran during Design Week. The duo, known for their knack for identifying new talent, originally looked to create the same neighborhood feel they had experienced when attending other global design weeks in London and Milan. However, by last year, the trials of securing real estate in a booming market had become overwhelming. In the end, it proved so difficult to find those spaces that we spent 80 percent of our time doing that, and zero percent curating, says Khemsurov. The only way for us to evolve was to let go of Noho and become nomadic.

title: Easy Blue-and-White Stripes
description: With Memorial Day just around the corner, the promise of prolonged mornings spent luxuriating in pajamas and warm afternoon naps beneath a cool summer breeze is enough to inspire a wardrobe reinvention. And perhaps nothing says summertime more than stripes  but instead of the usual maritime take, were looking to swaths of pale and azure blues, in varying widths, contrasted with ample amounts of white. The effect is reminiscent of the parasols that pepper the beaches of the Italian Riviera. With light-as-air fabrics and loungewear-inspired designs, these little patterned numbers are as easy to wear as neutral basics  and will keep you feeling, and looking, cool all season long.

title: Exercise Snacks to Control Blood Sugar
description: Multiple, brief, snack-sized portions of exercise may control blood sugar better than a single, continuous workout, according to new research that adds to a growing body of evidence about the wisdom of spreading exercise throughout the day.

title: Health Care Workers Under Attack in Syria, Doctors Say
description: Syrian government forces in the countrys civil war have systematically attacked doctors and other medical workers in rebel-held areas and are responsible for 90percent of the confirmed assaults on health care facilities in the country, Physicians for Human Rights, a leading advocacy group, said in a report released on Wednesday.

title: The Searchers
description: Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the 9/11 Memorial Museum, talks about one of the artifacts that most moves her - a hand rake used by workers who searched ground zero for human remains.

title: Where the Twin Towers Stood
description: The Sept. 11 memorial and museums location at ground zero in Lower Manhattan is one of its most notable features, according to Steven M. Davis, a partner at Davis Brody Bond, the lead architects for the museum. If you think about the notion of a traditional museum as an icon which contains exhibits, here we have the inverse, Davis says. These are exhibits that are in fact the icon. The museum opens to survivors and victims families on May 15; the public can visit starting May 21. In designing the space, which extends 70 feet below the memorial plaza, Davis says he wanted the experience to be physical  visitors enter by descending a ramp, as if drawn by gravity  but also heavy with symbolism and emotion. How does he hope people will feel when they leave? Optimistic about the future, he says. That we have the wherewithal as a society to create positive results from negative events. Julie Bosman

title: Times Minute | John Conyers Mistake
description: On the Minute, the congressional career of John Conyers Jr. is in jeopardy after a half-century; a former Israeli prime minister is going to prison; and secrets of a stovetop steak.

title: The Window Into Her Soul
description: Patricia Fagan died in the south tower of the World Trade Center, where she worked. When her bag was found a year and a half later, her sister Eileen donated it to the 9/11 Memorial Museum.

title: Everymans Grief
description: A teddy bear, a flag proclaiming We will survive, and a model of the twin towers are among the objects collected from a post-Sept. 11 vigil that are now on display at the 9/11 Memorial Museum.

title: The Letter That Survived 9/11
description: A letter that fell from a hijacked Sept. 11 aircraft was picked off the street by a fleeing businessman and posted to its rightful destination. It is now in the 9/11 Memorial Museum collection.

title: Times Minute | John Conyerss Mistake
description: In the Video

title: The Keepers of 9/11
description: As the 9/11 Memorial Museum opens, its chief curator and officials at other New York institutions describe how they selected the objects by which future generations will remember Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Word of the Day | throttle
description: throttle\thr-tl\ noun and verb

title: 9/11 Artifacts, and the Stories They Tell
description: At the National September 11 Memorial Museum, artifacts help tell the story of the nearly 3,000 people who died that day. A collection of videos looks at a few of those objects.

title: The National September 11 Memorial Museum
description: The museum sits below the plaza and extends to bedrock.

title: The 9/11 Story Told at Bedrock, Powerful as a Punch to the Gut
description: After a decade marked by deep grief, partisan rancor, war, financial boondoggles and inundation from Hurricane Sandy, the National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero is finally opening ceremonially on Thursday, with President Obama present, and officially to the public next Wednesday. It delivers a gut-punch experience  though if ever a new museum had looked, right along, like a disaster in the making, this one did, beginning with its trifurcated identity.

title: On a Long Night at Yankee Stadium, the Mets Look Right at Home
description: Time passed slowly at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night. It was about 11 p.m. when things wrapped up, 3 hours 58 minutes after the first pitch, and the teams packed their belongings for the short trip to Queens, where things may be a little less weird.

title: Thomas Piketty and His Critics
description: Many on the left see the popularity of Thomas Pikettys new book, Capital in the Twenty-First Century, as a sign of hope, but both optimists and pessimists share a belief more telling than Pikettys success: the idea that the traditional Democratic economic agenda is dead.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 7:30 A.M. (FX Movie Channel) STANLEY AND LIVINGSTONE (1939) In the first of two African adventures directed by Henry King, Henry Stanley (Spencer Tracy), a reporter for The New York Herald, travels to Zanzibar in search of the long-missing British missionary Dr. David Livingstone (Cedric Hardwicke). Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the lavish production  which helped to immortalize the famous greeting Dr. Livingstone, I presume  intelligent and restrained and dignified. In The Snows of Kilimanjaro (1952), at 9:30, adapted from the short story by Ernest Hemingway, an author (Gregory Peck, above with Susan Hayward) seriously wounded in a hunting accident reflects on the love (Ava Gardner) he lost and the novel he never wrote. Mr. King and the producer Darryl Zanuck have made a picture that constantly fascinates the eye and stimulates the emotions in small, isolated ways, Mr. Crowther wrote in The Times. He added: The shots of wild animals in Africa  elephants, lions, rhinoceroses, giraffes and all manner of lesser creatures  are as magnificent and exciting as any yet, and the atmosphere and beauty of a safari under the snowy peak of Kilimanjaro are superb. Especially one sequence in close-up of a swimming herd of hippopotamuses goes down in this reviewers notebook as the best one of game weve ever seen.

title: Anger Grows in Vietnam Over Dispute With China
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Thousands of workers rampaged through an industrial area in southern Vietnam on Tuesday in what reportedly began as protests against Chinas stationing of an oil rig in disputed waters off of Vietnams coast.  The riots were some of the worst civil unrest in recent years and appear to have prompted restraints on the local media by Vietnams authoritarian government. An article about the protests that was posted online by a Vietnamese state newspaper on Tuesday was removed by Wednesday morning.  The Chinese Embassy in Hanoi issued a notice on Wednesday that urged Chinese living in Vietnam to minimize unnecessary outings.  A staff member at the Chutex Garment Factory north of Ho Chi Minh City said 8,000 to 10,000 workers were involved in the rampage at his factory.  They burned the office, said the staff member who agreed to speak on condition that his name not be used. The rioters burned everything, all of the materials, computers, machines.  Police units and fire fighters arrived at the factory Tuesday and disbanded, the rioters, he said. On Wednesday morning police captured around 15 to 20 men who were attempting to loot the premises, he said.  The Chutex factory, located in Song Than Industrial Park 2 in southern Binh Duong Province, is described on its web site as one of the largest garment exporters in Vietnam. Chutex International, the parent company, was founded by a Taiwanese garment executive.  It is unclear why rioters targeted a factory linked to Taiwan. Media in Hong Kong said workers might not have been distinguishing between mainland China and Taiwan, a self-governing island which also has claims to territory in the South China Sea.

title: Corrections: May 14, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Asian Collectors Give Christies a High-Yield Night
description: In a nearly three-hour auction of postwar and contemporary art on Tuesday night, Christies managed to sell nearly $745 million worth of blue-chip paintings and sculptures, thanks in large part to the enormous wealth of Asian collectors.

title: The Clippers Lament Miscues and Bemoan a Costly Call
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Chris Paul leaned against a corridor wall, his hands in the pockets of his leather jacket as if he were feeling around for a morsel of comfort. He stared straight ahead for several minutes.

title: India Election Digest: May 14
description: What you need to know on Wednesday about Indias elections: People who are familiar with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party offer insights into his character and possible policy moves if he becomes prime minister, and Indian National Congress party leaders say its not Rahul Gandhis fault if the party has a poor showing Friday, when the votes are counted.

title: Angry Turks Demand Answers After Mine Disaster
description: SOMA, Turkey  As hopes began to fade for hundreds of coal miners still trapped underground in a hellish explosion, antigovernment protests broke out across the country on Wednesday while victims families demanded answers in what is emerging as perhaps the worst industrial accident in the countrys history.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 14, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: A New Story Told at Ground Zero
description: A guided tour of the National September 11 Memorial Museum.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Privilege at Princeton
description: In At Princeton, Privilege Is: (a) Commonplace, (b) Misunderstood or (c) Frowned Upon, Marc Santora and Gabriel Fisher write about a much-discussed student essay.

title: Judge Orders Psychiatric Evaluation of Pistorius
description: In a significant turn in a case that has generated drama and delay in equal proportions, the judge in the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius said on Wednesday that the defendant should undergo a psychiatric evaluation to determine whether he was affected by mental illness when he shot and killed his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, on Feb. 14, 2013.

title: Detroit, From Both Sides of the Coin
description: Photography was a hobby for Bill Rauhauser for much of his life. Born and raised in Detroit, a city that made things, he worked as an architectural engineer and took pictures on the side. That all changed on a business trip to New York City in 1947, when he caught an exhibit by Henri Cartier-Bresson at the Museum of Modern Art. He was amazed by the pictures, and even more so by the words he read in a booklet about the show.

title: A Spot of Tea Party?
description: After the warm-up speeches, a hush of expectation fell. The Forum in Bath is an Art Deco movie theater now used mostly for concerts and evangelical services, and on the last Tuesday of April, it had the air of a revivalist meeting. In the foyer, they were selling books, button badges and even tea towels, while inside a lively, if middle-aged, audience nearly filled the former cinema.

title: Pentagon Weighs Transfer of Chelsea Manning to Civilian Facility
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The United States Defense Department is considering a request from the Army to transfer Private Chelsea Manning, convicted of leaking national security data to WikiLeaks, to a civilian prison so that she can get treatment for her gender disorder, a Pentagon official said Wednesday.

title: What Are the Most Memorable Works of Visual Art You Have Seen?
description: The 35-foot-tall sugarcoated woman-sphinx pictured above, an installation at the former Domino Sugar compound in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is by an artist named Kara Walker. Would you want to see this piece if you lived nearby?

title: Taiwan Concerned Over Mistaken Identity in Vietnam Protests
description: Taiwan has voiced concern over the safety of its citizens doing business in Vietnam after protesters damaged several factories on Tuesday. The businesses based in Taiwan were targeted in an apparent case of mistaken identity by demonstrators angered by mainland Chinas placement of an offshore drilling platform in waters claimed by Vietnam.

title: New York Today: Meet Your Postmaster
description: Good morning on this cool, cloudy Wednesday.

title: Fresh Signs Point to Possible European Central Bank Stimulus Plan
description: FRANKFURT  Top officials of the European Central Bank sent strong signals on Wednesday that action to stimulate the economy was all but certain next month. But they also made it clear that the bank was unlikely to make a powerful injection of money into the economy.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Plenty of Words for Indias Fallen but Questions Are Met With Silence
description: In May 1999, Capt. Saurabh Kalia of the Indian Armys 4 Jat Regiment, an officer from Himachal Pradesh, led a patrol of five soldiers along the heights above Kargil, in Kashmir. They disappeared.

title: Unable to Afford Surgery, Farmer Amputates His Own Feet
description: For months, Liu Dunhe, a 44-year-old farmer in the southeastern province of Anhui, watched as what had begun as several seemingly innocuous blisters on his feet deteriorated into severe necrosis. By late April, his feet had become so rotten that he had already dug out several maggots from the dead, odorous flesh, according to a report in The Beijing News.

title: Pimco Weighs on Allianzs First Quarter as Profit Falls 3.9%
description: LONDON  Troubles at the giant asset manager known as Pimco weighed heavily on the German insurer Allianz in the first quarter, contributing to a 3.9 percent decline in earnings.

title: She Has the Look: Finding the Faces for T Magazine
description: Gina Liberto became the senior photo editor for print for T: The New York Times Style Magazine earlier this year. She has been a photo editor with T since November 2012. You can follow her on Instagram.

title: A Struggling Start-Up Dives Into the Shark Tank
description: In March 2013, we wrote about Bon Affair, a start-up in San Diego that makes an all-natural bottled wine spritzer. Its founder, Jayla Siciliano, described it as a lower-alcohol, lower-calorie alternative to wine, with electrolytes added to help, perhaps, with hangover symptoms.

title: Daily Report: Judge Says Airbnb Need Not Surrender Customer Data
description: Airbnb, the popular apartment-sharing service, won a legal standoff Tuesday when a state judge ruled that the company did not have to give up customer records as part of an investigation by the New York State attorney general, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: Sears Weighs a Sale of All or Part of Sears Canada to Bolster a Turnaround
description: At its height, Sears was the countrys biggest retailer. But that has not been true for more than two decades and now, the department store chain, struggling to execute on its latest turnaround, is looking to shrink again.

title: How to Turn Renters Into Savers
description: Some people didnt like my post on housing-as-food, which illustrated how pro-home ownership policies distorted behavior and the economy. The best pro-housing response Ive seen (from Megan McArdle, among others) was that homeownership encourages families to save.

title: Democrats Are Unified; G.O.P. Is Unified Only in Opposing Obama
description: Two prominent Republicans have broken with fellow party members on big issues in recent days: Rand Paul said Republicans shouldn't "go too crazy" with stricter voting laws, although he later softened that stance, and Mitt Romney said he favored raising the minimum wage. Similarly, Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio have indicated in recent years that they would be open to reworking the nations laws on illegal immigration, a stand that runs counter to the views of most conservatives.

title: China Targeted by Vietnamese in Fiery Riots
description: BINH DUONG PROVINCE, Vietnam  Dozens of foreign-owned factories near Ho Chi Minh City lay in charred ruins early Thursday after thousands of Vietnamese workers rampaged over Chinas latest efforts to control the South China Sea, this time off Vietnams coast.

title: New Music Meets Early Music in Miller Theater Offerings
description: The Miller Theater will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths  new music, early music and provocative combinations of the two  in its 2014-15 season, which opens on Sept. 18 with Heart and Breath, a production by the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird, in which the musicians play commedia dellarte roles and perform 17th-century Italian music filtered through 21st-century sensibilities.

title: Lessons From a Breakup
description: At a time when companies are reaching for ever bigger deals, the breakup of a $35 billion merger between two advertising giants offers some lessons, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column. The deal between Publicis of France and Omnicom, based in New York, seemed at first to make good sense, creating a company that would become the largest ad agency in a world where bigger may be better for ad buying. But the merger also raised cultural and integration issues.

title: Three Long Views of Life With Rising Seas
description: After finishing my post on the inevitability of substantial long-term sea-level rise from Antarctic ice loss, I sent this question to Curt Stager, a paleoclimatologist and author of Deep Future, Kim Stanley Robinson, the novelist focused on cli fi before that term was conceived, and the astrobiologist David Grinspoon:

title: Another Breezy Hearing for Obama Health Pick
description: WASHINGTON  Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obamas nominee for secretary of health and human services, appeared Wednesday to be on a swift path to confirmation after she sailed through another cordial congressional hearing without promising significant changes in federal health policy or regulations.

title: TBS Signs Conan OBrien to 4 More Years
description: The cable channel TBS has locked up its signature star, Conan OBrien, for four more years in a new deal it announced on Wednesday.

title: After 20 Years, Still Receiving Junk Mail
description: Dear Diary:

title: Communist Leader in India Stands Firm as His Party Shrinks
description: AGARTALA, India  This finger of land wrapped around Bangladesh is the last refuge for many of Indias most endangered species, including the pygmy hog, the white-bellied heron and, perhaps most critically, the dyed-in-the-wool Communist.

title: In Our Pages: May 15
description: 1914: Rebel Forces Preserve Order

title: Suitable Swimming
description: Shouldnt a queen have the right to swim wherever and whenever she likes? It ought to be a perk of the job. But in Queen Victorias Bathing Machine, by Gloria Whelan, with illustrations by Nancy Carpenter, and Elizabeth, Queen of the Seas, by Lynne Cox, illustrated by Brian Floca, two very different regents have trouble doing just that.

title: Casting Set for Bolshoi Performances at Lincoln Center Festival
description: When the Lincoln Center Festival announced its programming early this year, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet, appearing in New York together for the first time, was clearly one of the major drawing cards.
