But though the programs were announced: The Bolshoi Opera would present a concert version of The Tsars Bride, a Rimsky-Korsakov work better known from recordings than from live performances  at least in the West  and the Bolshoi ballet would offer Khachauryans Spartacus, Tchaikovskys Swan Lake and Ludwig Minkuss Don Quichotte, casting was a mystery. Even when the ballet company announced the casts for the first part of its American tour, not long after the Lincoln Center announcement, Lincoln Center was mum.

title: Some Predictions About the Internet of Things and Wearable Tech From Pew Research
description: Remember the prediction that one day your oven would be connected to the Internet and have the ability to talk to your car? In this world, when you left the office, your car would email the oven to say warm up dinner  well be home soon!

title: Number of People Displaced by Violence Highest in 20 Years, Agency Says
description: GENEVA  The crisis in Syria has pushed the number of people displaced from their homes by violence to the highest level in 20 years, the head of the Norwegian Refugee Council said on Wednesday, criticizing the failure of global powers to take timely to prevent conflicts.

title: Citi Fires 11 More in Mexico Over Fraud
description: Citigroup is moving quickly to try to put a costly fraud at its Mexican business behind it, firing an additional 11 employees, including four high-ranking executives in Mexico.

title: 5 Things to Consider in Choosing a Camp for a Special-Needs Child
description: Special needs is a broad category, including everything from orthopedic appliances and physical-care needs to speech defects, learning disabilities and behavioral deficits. What all of the children within that broad category have in common with respect to summer camp is that signing up isnt usually just a matter of filling out the forms.

title: 10 Ideas for a Smoother Road Trip
description: Road trips can be many things  thrilling, purposeful, strange  yet rarely are they glamorous. You can remedy that by renting a fancy car, but if youre on a budget or plan to drive your own car, there are other ways to hit the road in style. Below are 10 ideas that, while practical, can also add a touch of luxury for the driver, passengers, even the dog.

title: A Unified Theory of Timothy Geithner
description: Tim Geithner is not a creature of Wall Street.

title: How To | Arrange Flowers
description: Nicolette Owen and Sarah Ryhanen of Brooklyns Little Flower School share tips on how to create an effortless, whimsical floral arrangement.

title: Hagel Urges Gulf Arab States, Divided Over Policy, to Unite for Security
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday urged Gulf Arab states to unite against security threats as the United States sought to strengthen its influence in a region that has been splintering over how to deal with democracy protests in Egypt, the uprising in Syria and Irans nuclear program.

title: Today in Small Business: The Psychology of Buying Online
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Bank of England Tempers Expectations of a Rate Increase
description: LONDON  The Bank of England on Wednesday left unchanged its forecasts for growth and inflation in Britain, and indicated that the central bank was getting closer to the point at which it would need to gradually start raising interest rates. Analysts expect the bank to raise its record-low lending rate of 0.5 percent in the first half of next year.

title: Peer Pressure Can Be a Lifesaver
description: When we hear that someone succumbed to peer pressure or conformed to group expectations, we are inclined to think about it in negative terms. We imagine a young person smoking his first cigarette or an adult parroting the consensus of her community. We know that these social forces can cause people to act in ways that are harmful to themselves and others; but every day we are discovering more ways that they can be harnessed to solve problems in health, education and other areas. This is crucial. For decades, development organizations have spent billions of dollars developing medicines, installing wells, or building clinics or schools that people have not fully used, if they have used them at all.

title: Pistorius Ordered to Undergo Mental Exam
description: Thokozile Matilda Masipa, the judge in Oscar Pistoriuss murder trial, said Mr. Pistorius should have a psychiatric evaluation for mental illness, and his uncle, Arnold Pistorius, lauded the decision.

title: Seventy Years Ago Next Month Came Fury and Death on D-Day
description: Here is a rare color photograph from World War II. Taken 70 years ago next month, it reveals American warriors from E Company, Fifth Ranger Battalion, aboard their landing craft on Weymouth Harbor, Dorset, England. They are setting out to fight the Nazis on Omaha Beach on D-Day  June 6, 1944, one of the pivot points of the 20th century. In the foreground, they are, clockwise from far left, First Sergeant Sandy Martin, Technician Fifth Grade Joseph Markovich, Corporal John Loshiavo and Private First Class Frank Lockwood, with their Bazooka, Garand rifle, 60-mm mortar and Lucky Strikes.

title: Cannes Film Festival: Nicole Kidman Defends Grace'; Harvey Weinstein Skips Premiere
description: CANNES  As the 67th annual Cannes International Film Festival opened here today, Nicole Kidman diplomatically addressed criticism of the opening-night film, Grace of Monaco, in which she plays the title role.

title: House and Senate Dont Share Campaign Cash, Even When It Makes Sense
description: Vulnerable senators looking for campaign help from the other side of the Capitol probably wont find much, even if it would be in their partys best interests.

title: New Rowhouses Help Heal a Long-Open Wound in Brooklyn
description: On a sidewalk along State Street, cater-corner from the foreboding Brooklyn Detention Complex, new graffiti appeared over the weekend.

title: As Park Service Culls Deer in Washington, It Helps Charities Fill Bellies
description: WASHINGTON  The government sharpshooters worked so efficiently in the dead of the night in Rock Creek Park that by the end of this years short killing season, they had shot 106 white-tailed deer.

title: Republicans Cast de Blasio as a Leading Liberal Foe
description: Jeb Bush, a possible Republican presidential candidate in 2016, offered to help run a campaign to oust him. Bill OReilly, the Fox News titan, said he wanted to beat him up.

title: Cannes Film Festival: Jane Campion Accuses Film Industry of Inherent Sexism
description: CANNES  Strong women were in the spotlight as the 67th edition of the Cannes Film Festival got under way today. While Nicole Kidman defended her film Grace of Monaco, Jane Campion, the president of this years main competition jury, said she believed that inherent sexism was one reason there were so few female film directors.

title: Macys Profit Rises 3%, Despite Declining Sales
description: Macys reported a sluggish first quarter on Wednesday, dampening hopes for more positive spring spending news after an exceptionally frigid, difficult winter.

title: Rand Paul Walks Back the Truth
description: It is always impressive  by which I mean scary  to watch the Republican discipline machine swing into action. Its amazingly efficient, even when the target is a guy like Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who has staked out so many quirky positions that its hard to keep track.

title: Talks on Ukraine Crisis Open in Kiev Without Representation for Separatists
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Senior Ukrainian officials and leading public figures opened talks here on Wednesday that they portrayed as an effort to end the countrys six-month-old political crisis, but the provisional Ukrainian government offered little compromise and there was no one present directly representing the pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine.

title: AT&T Will Struggle to Justify a Deal for DirecTV
description: AT&T will struggle to justify buying DirecTV for an enterprise value of some $70 billion. Going headlong into the satellite television business requires some heroic assumptions to make the offer financially worthwhile. To cover its cost of capital, for example, AT&T probably would need to wring more than $2 billion of savings from its target. This deal gives off a whiff of desperation.

title: Social Experiments: Investigating Questions Related to Personality Attributes
description: Overview | What is the definition of personality, and how have scientists studied its attributes in animals? What can we learn about ourselves by studying the science behind personality? In this lesson, students learn about current research on social structure and personality attributes in a type of communal spider, then design their own research questions meant to investigate traits in humans like shyness, boldness or fear of the new.

title: Jaipur, City of Jewelers
description: Jaipur, the capital of the Indian state of Rajasthan, is one of the worlds most important centers for the cutting and polishing of precious and semiprecious gems.

title: Philippines Challenges China Over Disputed Atoll
description: HONG KONG  The Philippines said on Wednesday that it had protested signs of land reclamation by China aimed at expanding a disputed coral atoll near the southern Philippines, the latest in a series of disputes pitting China against its neighbors in the South China Sea.

title: How Student Debt May Be Stunting the Economy
description: Is student loan debt holding back the economy? Theres some new evidence that the answer may indeed be a big yes.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 29
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: China Responds to Riots in Vietnam
description: Chinas foreign ministry spokeswoman responded to the anti-China riots in southern Vietnam that damaged scores of foreign-owned factories.

title: Image of the Day: May 14
Living Colour and Robeson Opera Among Highlights of New Jersey Arts Center Season
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center, in Newark, has announced a schedule of more than 100 events for its 2014-15 season. John Schreiber, the centers president and chief executive, and David Rodriguez, its executive producer, said in a statement that they also expected to add another 60 performances and special events as the season progresses.

title: How Hobby Lobby International Resolved Its Trademark Dispute
description: Last week, we published a case study on Hobby Lobby International, a Brentwood, Tenn., company that makes and sells remote-controlled products, such as model airplanes and boats, and their accessories. For years, the company has been mistaken for Hobby Lobby Stores, a national art and craft supply chain with more than 600 stores.

title: Sony Pictures Buys Film Rights to Book on Snowden
description: LOS ANGELES  After a long, slow haul, the film rights to Glenn Greenwalds book about Edward J. Snowden and his revelations about electronic surveillance by United States security officials have found a home, at Sony Pictures Entertainment.

title: That Funny Man of 1,000 Faces
description: The title Just Jim Dale might seem to foretell something fairly straightforward. And, yes, this new show will feature the titular star alone onstage, supported only by the pianist Mark York. Yet the wide-ranging career of Mr. Dale has been anything but simple. He made his Broadway debut in Scapino in 1974, won a Tony for Barnum in 1980 and later appeared in the long-running hit Me and My Girl. More recently he was in the revival of Athol Fugards Road to Mecca. But did you know that Mr. Dale also wrote the lyrics for the title song of Georgy Girl, which won him an Oscar nomination in 1967?

title: Preparing a Veteran of D-Day for Its Return to Normandy
description: GENESEO, N.Y.  The plane has no fixed seats, no flight attendants, no in-flight movie and no bathroom. It is not heated, insulated or pressurized. And on its last tour over France, somebody tried to shoot it down.

title: An Upper West Side Apartment That Says Us
description: It wasnt really a need for a larger apartment that drove Maral Usefi and Neal Cimochowski from their 350-square-foot one-bedroom in the West 90s.

title: London Production of Miss Saigon May Come to Broadway
description: The producer Cameron Mackintosh is considering bringing his new London production of Miss Saigon to Broadway next year if the reviews are strong in Britain and a suitable theater becomes available in New York, according to two theater executives with knowledge of Mr. Mackintoshs plans.

title: Boy Loves His Mother, and His Mothers Friend
description: Broadway in the 1950s was extraordinarily good to William Inge until it wasnt. Then it turned merciless.

title: Putting Drama to Work to Soothe
description: LOS ANGELES  On a recent sweltering day, the actor and writer Daniel Beaty spent six hours at a high school near Watts, showing the students how their pain could turn into poetry. A few hours later, and about 20 miles north, he walked onstage at the Mark Taper Forum to portray the singer Paul Robeson, Robesons wife, the Soviet filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein and 40 or so other characters in The Tallest Tree in the Forest. After his performance  Mr. Beaty has all the speaking roles in the show, which he also wrote  he met with a couple from Omaha to discuss bringing his youth workshops there. He finally finished his work around midnight.

title: Looking for the Final Word on Treatment
description: The medical world is awash in new information.

title: Brand-New Bags
description: Every season has its It bag, but theres something to be said for foregoing the obvious designers in favor of carrying something more discreet. For spring/summer, a host of under-the-radar new labels  from a revamped Parisian import to a locally sourced line out of Portland  offer some of the most striking and contemporary carryalls around.

title: Times Minute | Turkeys Mine Disaster
description: A mining disaster in Turkey kills hundreds. Also on the Minute, Ras Baraka is Newarks new Mayor and an acclaimed Swedish director is found dead.

title: Times Minute | Turkeys Mine Disaster
description: In the Video

title: Will You Visit the National September 11 Memorial Museum?
description: The National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero will open to survivors and victims families on Thursday and to the public next Wednesday.

title: Senators Intend to Amend Federal Student Privacy Law
description: In an effort to beef up protections for the personal details about students that schools may share with app developers and other companies, two prominent senators said on Wednesday that they intend to modernize a decades-old federal education privacy law.

title: Bill Clinton Rebuts Speculation on His Wifes Health
description: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton said on Wednesday that Democrats should not run away from the Affordable Care Act in the midterm elections, and  weighing in on a recent topic of interest for the 2016 election  said his wifes health was just fine, Republican conjecture notwithstanding.

title: Use Airbnb, Break the Law?
description: A New York state judge issued a smart ruling on Tuesday that cut through the hyperbole clouding a dispute between the New York State attorney general and the apartment sharing company Airbnb.

title: 2014 Fantasy Football Preseason Player Rankings
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide player rankings for standard and PPR scoring formats. They will be updated throughout the preseason.

title: In Italy, the Targa Florio Rally Keeps an Eye on the Past
description: CAMPOFELICE DI ROCCELLA, Italy  It has been a long time since Nino Vaccarella won the Targa Florio. But Vaccarella, a former sports car and Formula One driver who won the Targa Florio in 1965, 1971 and again in 1975, is still venerated as a hero in his native Sicily. In a hamlet in the Madonie region, Collesano, along a route known as the Piccolo Circuito delle Madonie, huge white letters that spell out Nino can still be seen painted on a pair of concrete walls on one turn of the race course.

title: New Orleans Art Biennial to Return in October
description: Prospect, the biennial exhibition program founded by the curator Dan Cameron in New Orleans in 2008 as a way to respond to Hurricane Katrina, will hold its third iteration in the city starting Oct. 25 with a lineup of major artists including Theaster Gates, Carrie Mae Weems and Andrea Fraser, as well as historical works by Gauguin and Jean-Michel Basquiat, organizers said on Wednesday.

title: Whitney Museum to Donate Studio to Socrates Sculpture Park
description: As it prepares for a move downtown, the Whitney Museum of American Art will donate its freestanding educational studio to Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, the two organizations are to announce Thursday.

title: Roadside Poem Combats Pollution  Literally
description: Poetry makes nothing happen, Auden once wrote. But then he never got a chance to read In Praise of Air, a poem by Simon Armitage just installed on a building along a busy road at the University of Sheffield, England, and billed as the worlds first bit of air-cleansing verse.

title: Freedom From Fries
description: There is no better, more reliable restaurant dish than steak frites.

title: A Day in the Life of a Food Stylist
description: What does it take to make one of the magazines recipes come to life? Collaboration, good timing and a kit of tools, says Maggie Ruggiero, a freelance food stylist. She regularly works with a team to produce some of the photos seen in the magazine, including this weeks inventive twist on classic steak frites from Sam Sifton.

title: A Museum Tour With Blackstones Hill
description: J. Tomilson Hill, the vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, is known on Wall Street as a veteran deal maker.

title: Times Ousts Jill Abramson as Executive Editor, Elevating Dean Baquet
description: The New York Times dismissed Jill Abramson as executive editor on Wednesday, replacing her with Dean Baquet, the managing editor, in an abrupt change of leadership.

title: Wheelies: The New and Improved Batmobile Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Letter From France | A Family Goes to War Over Napoleons Nightshirt
description: A stained, V-neck cotton night shirt has set off a heated family battle in France.

title: Nationwide Theater Listings
description: ARKANSAS

title: A Note From the Publisher
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, sent the following email to Times employees this afternoon announcing the appointment of Dean Baquet as executive editor.

title: Bringing Arts to Brooklyn and Bronx Community Gardens
description: Spring is bringing more than new flowers to the community gardens operated by the New York Restoration Project. The nonprofit group, created by Bette Midler in 1995, is collaborating with the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Bronx Museum of the Arts on a new series, Arts in the Gardens, that will present music, performance art, poetry, dance and film at four gardens in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Gowanus neighborhoods of Brooklyn and three gardens in the Tremont, Melrose and Highbridge neighborhoods of the South Bronx.

title: App Smart | Create Your Own Comics
description: Kit Eaton tests out three apps that can help you get started creating your own digital comic book.

title: The Best Time to Book July 4 Trips
description: July 4 falls on a Friday this year, giving many a three-day holiday and time to travel. To get the best deal on Independence Day airfares in a potentially crowded season, the travel-planning website Hipmunk advises making plans by the end of May.

title: Transforming Your Photos Into Comic Strips
description: THE way a comic book artist can convey so much emotion, drama and narrative with just a few simple lines has always amazed me. Now, if you want to put a comic strip together and provide your own drama and emotion, there are many mobile apps that can do the basic artwork for you.

title: East Village Radio to Close, Citing Licensing Costs
description: East Village Radio, a commercial-free Internet radio station broadcasting from a storefront on First Avenue in Manhattan, said on Wednesday that it would be shutting down next week, blaming the high cost of music licenses.

title: Why Hedge Funds Dont Worry About Carried Interest Tax Rules
description: Hedge fund managers dont use the carried interest tax loophole. They need something more exotic.

title: Labs Are Told to Start Including a Neglected Variable: Females
description: For decades, scientists have embarked on the long journey toward a medical breakthrough by first experimenting on laboratory animals. Mice or rats, pigs or dogs, they were usually male: Researchers avoided using female animals for fear that their reproductive cycles and hormone fluctuations would confound the results of delicately calibrated experiments.

title: Copyright Licensing Organization Gets New Boss
description: Creative Commons, whose licensing system encourages the sharing of more than 500 million copyrighted works, on Wednesday appointed a veteran of similar open Internet projects to be its new chief executive.

title: Scene of the Mining Disaster
description: Diagram of the mine near Soma, Turkey, where hundreds of miners died after an explosion ignited a fire that produced noxious fumes.

title: The Gun Report: May 14, 2014
description: Two weeks ago, we brought you the story of Diren Dede, 17, a German exchange student who was shot to death after entering a neighbors garage in Missoula, Mont. On April 27, Markus Kaarma, 29, whod recently been robbed, opened the garage door to his four-bedroom home and set up a motion sensor and a baby monitor in an effort to entrap burglars. When Dede walked in shortly after midnight, Kaarma opened fire with a shotgun. It was later revealed that the teenagerhad not stolen anything from the garage.

title: Federers Tuneup for Paris Ends Stunningly Early
description: An improbable stab forehand cut short Roger Federers French Open preparations, as 47th-ranked Jrmy Chardy sprinted across the court Wednesday to run him out of the Italian Open in the second round.

title: Colorado Symphonys Marijuana Fundraiser Concerts to Proceed in Private
description: The Colorado Symphonys Classically Cannabis fundraisers will go on  a bit more discreetly.

title: What You Get for ... $4,250,000
description: SEATTLE

title: St. Marks Bookshop in East Village Signs Lease on New Location
description: The imperiled St. Marks Bookshop, which has been on life support because of declining sales and rising rent, has gotten a reprieve.

title: Fashion and Beauty at Cannes
description: Daily highlights from the 67th annual Cannes Film Festival.

title: Britain Expands Power to Strip Citizenship From Terrorism Suspects
description: LONDON  Britain has passed legislation that allows the government to strip terrorism suspects of their citizenship even if it renders them stateless, taking the countrys already sweeping powers to revoke nationality a step further.

title: Scene City: Art Blooms in Auction Season
description: Daniel Craig, Steve McQueen and Maja Oeri were honored at MoMAs annual garden party.

title: Spades Strike History in Galilee
description: While preparing to dig foundations for a religious retreat near the Sea of Galilee, archaeologists found the vestiges of first-century Magdala, where some believe Jesus and Mary Magdalene once walked.

title: Readers Respond on Bags, Airfares and Global Entry
description: For the last few hours, Ive been wincing, nodding, smiling, cringing, chortling and arguing out loud at my computer monitor, which can only mean only one thing: Im perusing reader comments.

title: A Melancholy Stroll Through the Past
description: Edgar Oliver has yellowed teeth, hooded eyes and a sagging jaw. If it werent for his gentle smile, you might mistake him for that portrait of Dorian Gray. A writer and performer, Mr. Oliver will put you in mind of the macabre. He has a tendency to turn even the most banal event  like drinking a Shirley Temple  into something out of Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Q & A: Making Steak on the Stovetop
description: The butcher Pat LaFrieda and Julia Moskin of the Dining section discussed cooking steak on the stovetop with you, our readers. (The master recipe for cast-iron steak is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

title: A Life in the Shadows in the Cold War Mideast
description: The first thing to understand about The Good Spy, Kai Birds cool and authoritative new biography, is that while its about a C.I.A. operative named Ames, it is not about Aldrich Ames, the United States counterintelligence officer and analyst who in 1994 was convicted of spying for the Russians.

title: Expressing Schubert With the Voice of Bitter Experience
description: Many singers perform Schuberts death-haunted song cycle, Winterreise (Winter Journey), whether well or poorly. A select few  like the Austrian baritone Florian Boesch, at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening and on a new recording from the Onyx label  seem to inhabit the work.

title: City Boy Turns Outdoorsy
description: Give credit to Steve Buscemi and AOL: Park Bench is honestly named. In every episode, Mr. Buscemi sits on a park bench and talks to someone.

title: Think Seeing Is Believing? Youre Asking to Be Fooled
description: A few other magicians and illusionists have made television shows by using their skills to punk the unsuspecting, but none have worked the gimmick better than Michael Carbonaro does in The Carbonaro Effect, which begins on Thursday night on TruTV.

title: Budget Agenda Plays Second Fiddle at Fiscal Forum
description: WASHINGTON  If anyone needed proof that Washington has exhausted its interest in deficit reduction, and given up seeking some bipartisan grand bargain, it came on Wednesday: At the annual fiscal summit meeting of the antideficit Peter G. Peterson Foundation, where V.I.P.s and reporters once flocked for budget news, the newsmakers talk often veered far from the fiscal. The main news was politics.

title: House Hunting in ... Antwerp, Belgium
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOME IN A CONVERTED CHAPEL

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, Afghanistan, Israel and South Africa.

title: Turkish Prime Minister Jeered After Mine Disaster
description: Last Updated, Friday, 9:12 a.m. | As rescuers battled Wednesday to save the lives of coal miners trapped underground in western Turkey, more than 24 hours after an explosion killed at least 274 at the site, anger at the authorities boiled over during a visit by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was booed and briefly forced to seek refuge in a shop in the nearby town of Soma.

title: Californias Thirst Shapes Debate Over Fracking
description: OROVILLE, Calif.  Enemies of fracking have a new argument: drought.

title: Looking for a Family That Is Looking to Eat More Vegetables
description: Martha Rose Shulman and the Motherlode are looking for a family of guinea pigs  a family that would like to eat healthier and occasionally vegetarian meals, but needs a push to get there.

title: The Language of Autism: Disease or Difference?
description: I first wrote about my son, Finn, shortly after his autism diagnosis: his limp, bony body, the distracted doctors and the unrelenting paperwork. And, of course, our grief. But it wasnt writing so much as keening, a scrawled lamentation that I wouldnt have shared with my friends, much less the public. Then in 2012 a friend asked me to write an essay for Money magazine on the unique financial burden of raising an autistic child. My research revealed two facts: First, special-needs children pose enormous, long-term challenges to all but the wealthiest of parents; second, my wife and I were utterly unprepared to meet those challenges.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Dylan Records a Sinatra Hit
description: Is Bob Dylan channeling his inner Sinatra? Or is it his inner Rachmaninoff? On Wednesday, Mr. Dylans website, bobdylan.com, posted what appears to be the cover of the singers forthcoming album, Shadows in the Night, as well as a single track  a gently sung cover of Full Moon and Empty Arms, in an ensemble dominated by a country-tinged steel guitar part. The song, written in 1945 by Buddy Kaye and Ted Mossman, is based on a theme from the third movement of Rachmaninoffs Piano Concerto No. 2, and was a hit for Frank Sinatra in 1946.

title: Gehry Design for Philadelphia Museum of Art to Be Displayed
description: The architect Frank Gehrys design for a renovation and expansion of the Philadelphia Museum of Art will be unveiled on July 1 in an exhibition at the museum on Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

title: Now Thats What I Call Music Ends Frozen Soundtracks No. 1 Run
description: After spending two straight months at the top of Billboards album chart, Disneys Frozen soundtrack has finally been bumped from No. 1. The new champion: the 50th volume of Now Thats What I Call Music!, a compilation series that has been coming out in the United States like clockwork  and regularly scoring high on the charts  for 16 years.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: I suppose we count this as progress: A Florida elementary school has agreed to stop its longstanding policy of giving kids Mountain Dew as brain fuel before the states most important standardized test.

title: Skin Deep: Bold Liners for Bright Eyes
description: Spring looks beg for more color in makeup: Heres how to handle it.

title: Good to Be Alive Again, but Whats This Body?
description: When an underinsured office temp from Staten Island and her entitled billionaire boss die in an elevator accident in Under My Skin, the new body-swapping comedy at the Little Shubert Theater, an angel from Eternal Affairs restores them to life, each in the others physique.

title: Selecting USA-1 Bridge Team for the Next Bermuda Bowl
description: The trial to select the USA-1 team for next years Bermuda Bowl world championship in India continues through Sunday in Phoenix. Sixteen teams entered. The bottom 13 seeds played a two-day round robin to eliminate two teams.

title: Fleeting Game Says Investing Is Rigged
description: Not long ago, committing to a video game was a costly decision, made deliberately. Largely because of the price, you were going to play only a few games a year, and you were going to spend scores of hours with each one. It was as if Netflix were charging $60 every time you wanted to start bingeing on a TV series.

title: A Haunting History Lesson With Your Hip-Hop
description: Conundrum, provocation, history lesson, ritual, chamber recital, jazz concert, elegy  the Roots performance at the Public Theater on Tuesday night was decidedly not a standard kickoff for a hip-hop album. That was clear when, near the beginning of the show, balloon animals were dropped onto the stage, covering it knee-deep; for the rest of the performance, each entrance and exit was accompanied by balloons popping underfoot like gunshots. Dozens of nooses also hung overhead.

title: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66
description: Jim and Jaylene Myers knew exactly what they wanted to do when they retired in 2008: Go wherever whim and chance might take them in their 45-foot recreational vehicle.

title: Classics That Throw Time Out the Window
description: Its an auspicious time at New York City Ballet, with new choreographic voices multiplying. Along with Justin Pecks well-received premiere last week came the announcement that he and two other young choreographers  the corps member Troy Schumacher and the Royal Ballets Liam Scarlett  will create new pieces for the company next season (a first for Mr. Schumacher).

title: Philharmonic Transformation, From Members to Mission
description: The New York Philharmonic is playing musical chairs in reverse these days, as retirements and a couple of unexpected departures have left it with more seats than players  and the most turnover of principal players, or section leaders, since World War II.

title: A Funny Name, a Serious Sport. Pickleball, Anyone?
description: GAINESVILLE, Va.  MAYBE it was the whimsical name  pickleball  that got baby boomers to try the game. A hybrid of racket and paddle sports, it was not notably new. Pickleball began on Bainbridge Island, Wash., where legend has it that Pickles, the resident cocker spaniel, would chase the errant ball. It was Pickless ball, thus the name.

title: When Singing the Blues Is a Performers Pleasure
description: The singer Carole J. Buffords love affair with the blues began when she was 13 years old and discovered Bessie Smith on a two-disc set, she recalled last Thursday at the Metropolitan Room. She has immersed herself in the genre ever since. And this supremely confident performer has brought her accumulated know-how to her new show, Shades of Blue.

title: The Searing Blues of the 9/11 Sky
description: Like many people who were in any proximity to the events of Sept. 11, the artist Spencer Finch often thought later about the color of the sky that day, the kind of crystalline blue that pilots and meteorologists call severe clear.

title: Birds Arent the Only Music Amid Nature
description: CALIFORNIA

title: Family and Church Feud Over an Eakins
description: The family of Msgr. Patrick J. Garvey, a Catholic priest who was once friendly with the realist painter Thomas Eakins, is trying to block the Archdiocese of Philadelphia from selling a valuable Eakins portrait of the monsignor through the auction house Christies.

title: Advocating Pill, U.S. Signals Shift to Prevent AIDS
description: Federal health officials recommended Wednesday that hundreds of thousands of Americans at risk for AIDS take a daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection with the virus that causes it.

title: For Eyes, Its the Year of Color
description: A wardrobe update for spring can start at the beauty counter, where this season both candied brights and matte pastels are sprinkled like sundae toppings. Though a rosy lip is still the hardy perennial, eyes have a new focus.

title: A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair
description: Sturgill Simpson is a top-notch miserablist, from the lyrics that pick at scabs to his defeated vocal tone, leaky even when hes singing at full power. His second album, Metamodern Sounds in Country Music (High Top Mountain), is a triumph of exhaustion, one of the most jolting country albums in recent memory, and one that achieves majesty with just the barest of parts.

title: Ask Well: New Truvada Recommendations
description: Do you have a question about Truvada? Or the new recommendation that all Americans at high risk for H.I.V. take this drug? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.

title: Colorful Pairings From Many Nations
description: CALIFORNIA

title: Museum Interpreters Breathing Life Into History
description: FOR 62-year-old Kent Brinkley, one day at work is pretty much like the next.

title: Turns and Romance, Lifts and Commitment
description: With its myriad acrobatic feats  one-arm lifts! dizzying fouett turns!  Don Quixote could trade its setting from a theater to a circus tent without skipping a beat. On Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater began its spring season with the companys well-worn 1995 version, a giddy fireworks display staged by Kevin McKenzie and Susan Jones.

title: Art Matters | Highlights from a Frieze Week of Art and Revelry
description: The third edition of Frieze New York cemented the second week in May as the highlight of the citys art calendar. The festivities official start date is fuzzy, but if social media is any indication, it might have been Tuesday at the heavily Instagrammed unveiling of the colossal sugar sphinx by Kara Walker at the Domino Sugar Factory in Williamsburg, where Creative Time, the public art organization that commissioned the work, held its annual gala.

title: Glowsticks, Banjos, Food Trucks for Miles
description: CALIFORNIA

title: Terms of Employment for Catholic School Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: In MoMAs Garden, a Gala for Patrons
description: On Tuesday night, as the spring art auctions were underway, the Museum of Modern Art held its annual garden party for art patrons who are not necessarily in the market for a $41 million Warhol.

title: Climate Change: Prophets and Deniers
Chiara de Blasios Journey
description: To the Editor:

title: Speakers on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Organizing Your Photos, Cloud-Free
description: About a week ago, I installed a small device in my home office that has been working to collect and catalog just about every photograph and video Ive ever captured with a digital camera.

title: Q & A: Leta Hong Fincher on Leftover Women
description: After the 1949 Communist revolution, Mao Zedong declared that Women hold up half the sky. It was a phrase that caught the imagination in China and the world. Yet as socialism has crumbled and a Leninist state, married with elements of a market economy, steers the country, womens position is slipping, as Leta Hong Fincher examines in her new book, Leftover Women: The Resurgence of Gender Inequality in China.

title: Sotomayor and Race
description: To the Editor:

title: The New York State Independence Party
Get to 100 and Life Actually Doesnt Feel so Bad
description: MANY studies of very old people seem to boil down to this: trying to figure out what they ate, drank and did, so that other people can try to live that long, too. Daniela S. Jopp, an assistant psychology professor at Fordham University, is more interested in how people actually feel once they approach 100.

title: Video Message From Jailed Egyptian Journalist
description: Al Jazeera released a brief video message on Wednesday from its detained West Africa correspondent, Abdullah Elshamy, recorded on the 106th day of his hunger strike in an Egyptian jail.

title: Its Now the Canadian Dream
description: It was in 1931 that the historian James Truslow Adams coined the phrase the American dream.

title: For a Day, a Reprieve From the New York Art Circuit
description: Frieze week is a nightmare, the artist Nate Lowman said. To have the same limp handshake 400 times? I dont go to anything except this.

title: Still Tinkering
description: Twenty years have passed since Justice Harry A. Blackmun, at age 85 and just months away from retirement, renounced the death penalty. From this day forward, I no longer shall tinker with the machinery of death, he declared.

title: After Prison, No After-Hours
description: At 10:50 a.m. on Monday of last week, outside the Mid-State Correctional Facility in Marcy, N.Y., which looked like an Ivy League school ringed in concertina wire, Michael Alig emerged from a white prison van.

title: Street Style in Minneapolis
description: In the Uptown section of Minneapolis, young professionals enjoy happy hour, motorcycle gangs hang out at sober coffee shops and true uptowners cling to the past with their punky aesthetic. Qais Munhazim, 29, moved there from Afghanistan five years ago to study political science. Wearing a leather jacket, slim-fit pants and combat boots, he said he pays attention to the cut of his clothes. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: What Hedge Funds Talk About When They Talk About Money
description: LAS VEGAS  Behind the dancing fountains of the Bellagio Hotel, hedge fund titans mingled with wealth managers at the Hyde nightclub on Tuesday night.

title: Volunteers Provide Backup to the Uniformed Ranks
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.  BERNARD ZARETSKY, 82, co-coordinator of the Delray Beach Police Departments Volunteer Program, devotes about 100 hours a month to preventing discord in the resort community, but his duties have the added benefit of keeping the peace in his nearly 60-year-long marriage.

title: Eyeing the Prize
description: In late February, on the second night of Paris Fashion Week, the corporate fashion giant LVMH hosted a cocktail party at its Paris headquarters on Avenue Montaigne to celebrate the LVMH Prize, a new award for young fashion designers. Over flutes of Champagne, fashion world notables like Karl Lagerfeld, Nicolas Ghesquire, Raf Simons, Anna Wintour and a recent Vogue cover subject, Kanye West, were stalking the atrium-turned-designer-showroom. The 30 semifinalists for the award were tucked away in jam-packed booths, accompanied by a rack of clothes, a model or two and a slight sheen of sweat.

title: Off-Kilter, Off the Racks
description: The current middleweight champion of bombast in Milan is a young designer named Massimo Giorgetti, who founded his label, MSGM, in 2009 on a few key principles: color, youth and energy. His bright, lavishly printed sweatshirts, T-shirts and dresses went wide fast. Label recognition is still on the rise (the mouthful name, the initials of the four founding partners, may not help), but the collection is available in some 500 stores worldwide, including Bergdorf Goodman and Kirna Zabte in New York.

title: Autodesk Unveils Open-Source 3-D Printing System
description: Autodesk is hoping to kick-start three-dimensional printing in much the same way Google spurred smartphone development, with a free operating system.

title: High Society, Mutually Admired
description: Slim Aaronss palmy photographs of celebrities, moguls and society molls could be taken for a rarefied exercise in social anthropology, if he werent so deferential to the people he portrayed.

title: A Swirl of Duality and Dueling Identities
description: You had to watch where you stepped as you entered Zoe/Junipers BeginAgain Installed. A thick layer of soil covered the floor of the cryptlike space at 3LD Art & Technology Center. Planted in the middle, sprouting out from one wall, was what looked like a massive glass chamber, a sort of triangular aquarium whose walls turned out to be both reflective and transparent. The floor inside was bare, more pristine than its outskirts. The audience sat on either side of this structure, two groups facing each other, just one of many mirror images that appeared over the next hour.

title: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada
description: ITS a nearby country where most natives speak English and there are few major cultural differences from the United States. Yet the number of Americans choosing to head north to retire in Canada has remained low  reaching a high of 1,675 in 2008 (for immigrants older than 49), then dipping to 1,060 in 2011, and rising again in 2013 to an estimated 1,565.

title: Obama to Attend Investment Bankers Fund-Raiser
description: President Obama has a rendezvous with Wall Street.

title: Reaction From Turkey on Mine Collapse
description: The Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, discussed the rising death toll in the mining disaster as more bodies were pulled from the rubble.

title: Laid-Back Summer Fashions
description: In a recent article on Phoebe Philo and the mythology of Cline, the uniform of the trendsetting label was characterized this way: large, slouchy trousers; a collarless shirt; flats; a tuxedo jacket. And that collarless shirt  modern, minimal  looks sharper than ever, a perfectly cut everyday top to match with tailored pieces and laid-back weekend wear. The stylist Marina Muoz had the right idea, effortlessly pairing her oversize tunic-like top with black trousers. Wear the longer styles with boyfriend jeans and loafers, the cropped versions with high-waist skirts and printed pants. And any of them, of course, the Cline way.

title: Muslim Weavers of Varanasi
description: Haji Mohammed Shamin of the Muslim weaving community on why he was not voting for Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

title: Boatman of the Ganges
description: Shyamlal Eshad was born and raised on the banks of the holy river. He sings about the rivers decline and whats needed to purify and conserve it.

title: A Day in Varanasi
description: Hindu pilgrims purify their bodies and souls and worship the goddess of the river at night.

title: Italian Glass, for Your Bidding
description: One of the most comprehensive collections of 20th-century Italian glass is on view in New York just as it is being dispersed. As a preview for a sale next Tuesday in Chicago, Wright auction house has packed its Manhattan showroom at 980 Madison Avenue with glass vessels and sculptures consigned by the photo stylist and art director Dimitri Levas. Hes been acquiring them since the 70s, focusing on celebrated makers and designers like Venini, A.V.E.M., Gio Ponti and Carlo Scarpa. Many are from the foresighted store Fifty/50. A few belonged to Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Levass former collaborator. A 1920s globular blue vase by Napoleone Martinuzzi is estimated at $20,000 to $30,000; an Ercole Barovier mosaic cylinder from the same decade, $25,000 to $35,000. Information: 212-585-0200 or wright20.com.

title: Reaching Back for Its Design Cred
description: Umbra is going back to its roots. This Toronto-based company, which started 34 years ago selling chic window shades to small, independent design stores, has grown into a $130 million global business. But Les Mandelbaum, Umbras chief executive, keenly missed its design cred. You get rich, but you lose your soul, he said. So Mr. Mandelbaum and the companys design director, Matt Carr, came up with Shift, a brand of goods being introduced this weekend at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York that are jaunty, relatively affordable and in many cases handmade. The new line includes whimsical works like Philippe Malouins wood folding chair with a built-in hanger ($250 each), Harry Allens Coiled stool with a thread-wrapped rattan tractor seat ($250) and Paul Loebachs Cup lamp, a combination desk lamp and pencil caddy ($180). These are all things we actually want to take home, Mr. Carr said. Information: 800-387-5122 or umbrashift.com.

title: She Says God Bless You
description: If youre like me, the majority of your spring is spent red-eyed, runny-nosed and violently sneezing. For those seeking allergy relief indoors, the Blueair Sense ($479), a sleek air purifier, promises to eliminate 99.97 percent of airborne irritants like dust, smoke and pollen.

title: Open Cover; Insert Brilliance
description: Tucker Nichols wanted to be a jotter of ideas, a scribbler of sketches. Part of the Moleskine mafia. But no notebook seemed right. He always ended up with half-filled pages and a vague dissatisfaction. Was it the notebooks? Was it him?

title: Sales at Luceplan, Ankasa, Haus and Alessi
description: During Luceplans moving sale, through Tuesday, all lighting on display is up to 70 percent off (the Mix table lamp, by Paolo Rizzatto and Alberto Meda, originally $550, is $165); 49 Greene Street (Grand Street), 212-966-1399.

title: Desk Clocks: Faces of Another Era
description: Even in the age of the smartphone, theres value in a traditional desk clock. True, its no longer necessary from a functional standpoint, but as Gideon Mendelson pointed out, thats not the only reason to have a clock.

title: Holleywood Ending
description: For years, Helen Klein Ross, a novelist and poet, and her husband, Donald K. Ross, a lawyer, lived on the Upper West Side with their two daughters and were content to spend weekends in an 1810 clapboard farmhouse in Amenia, N.Y. But that was before they were seduced by Holleywood.

title: Youre Planting That Old Thing?
description: The Catalpa Tree Appreciation Society needs fresh blood. There are no meetings to attend and no dues to pay. All you have to do is appreciate the catalpa tree. Maybe plant one in the yard.

title: Lifting From Others the Burden of Your Own Death
description: AS you journey toward your end, dreading and hoping all, to quote Yeats, there is a lot to ponder.

title: With Power Comes Ambivalence
description: LIVINGSTON, N.Y.  It took Andrea Tranchita and her husband, Paul, a few decades to fully build out their pine-and-spruce-planked handmade house here. For the first six months, the couple and their two young daughters lived in a tent on the 10 acres of farmland that Ms. Tranchitas parents gave them as a wedding present in 1970. But now Ms. Tranchita, 63, a third-generation farmer who grows lavender and herbs and raises sheep, alpaca, llamas and Angora rabbits on this patch of land, is worried about her ability to continue to maintain it.

title: Tangled Identities and Allegiances in Ukraine
description: Alexander Chekmenevs national and ethnic identities have whipsawed since the collapse of the Soviet Union and right through the current crisis.

title: The AIDS-Shaming of Magic Johnson
description: The sheer volume of bile spewing from the mouth of the Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, is staggering. But just as awe-inducing, and stomach-churning, is the unrestrained breadth of its variety, which makes putting the offenses in order  if one were inclined to  nearly impossible.

title: Store Openings and Fashion Events Starting the Week of May 15
description: Openings

title: The Looks That Go Straight to Their Heads
description: Last week, as designers and their famous muses walked the red carpet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the gala opening of the Charles James fashion exhibition, it wasnt only the parade of elaborate gowns that captured the attention of Twitter, Instagram and dozens of fashion blogs.

title: Frequent Matchup Yields Familiar Outcome: Montreal Moves On
description: BOSTON  There is so much history between the teams that to term it a rivalry would be an injustice. But history has mostly sided with the Montreal Canadiens, which may have made the Boston Bruins fans uneasy even this year, when their team was the better regular-season squad by far.

title: Social Security at 62? Lets Run the Numbers
description: FOR many retirees, Social Security benefits are seen as hot money on the table, to be devoured as soon as possible. But as with preparing and savoring a fine meal, a careful approach and delayed gratification may yield the highest rewards from the program.

title: The Truth About Sparrows
description: Ever since my mother joined the North American Bluebird Society, or NABS, shes had it out for the English house sparrow  a bird that, when it isnt devouring butterflies and yellow flowers, is pecking out the brains of bluebird mothers, dumping their lifeless bodies in the grass and then throwing their children out to die.

title: Playing Catch-Up While Retirement Remains Far Off
description: SO youre hurtling toward middle age but havent started saving for retirement.

title: Steve Kerr Will Coach Warriors, Spurning the Knicks
description: Steve Kerr stunned the Knicks on Wednesday by agreeing to a deal to become the coach of the Golden State Warriors.

title: Mirror, Mirror in the App: Whats the Fairest Shade and Shadow of Them All?
description: As any lipstick shopper knows, deciding between tropical coral, peony pink and fairest nude is not a straightforward choice.

title: With Master Limited Partnerships, Get a Piece of the Pipeline
description: Everythings coming up roses for the American energy industry. Well, maybe not actual flowers, but the final product is still quite fragrant and valuable.

title: Dont Force Google to Forget
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THE European Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday that Europeans have a limited right to be forgotten by search engines like Google. According to the ruling, an individual can compel Google to remove certain reputation-harming search results that are generated by Googling the individuals name. The court is trying to address an important problem  namely, the Internets ability to preserve indefinitely all its information about you, no matter how unfortunate or misleading  but it has devised a poor solution.

title: Ganges River: Revered, Soiled and Symbol of an Indian Election Campaign
description: VARANASI, India  For centuries, Hindus have brought their dead to banks of the Ganges River in this ancient city, with the promise that if their bodies are burned on the riverfront, their souls will escape the constant cycle of rebirth and attain moksha, or salvation. Transporting their souls is the goddess of the river, whose ebbs and flows have run through thousands of years of civilization.

title: The Kidnapping of a Country
description: CHIBOK, Nigeria  THE road to Chibok is eerily quiet, lined with checkpoints manned by civilians, many of them teenagers, wielding rusty rifles and serving as added security for an area that has little. In this northeast Nigerian village, where more than 300 teenage schoolgirls were kidnapped by the militant Islamist separatist group Boko Haram on April 14, their stunned families were still waiting this week for them to come home.

title: Editor of Le Monde Resigns Amid Discord
description: PARIS  Faced with a newsroom revolt, the editor in chief of Le Monde, Frances most prominent newspaper, stepped down on Wednesday after a 14-month tenure marked by staff resistance to her efforts to push the paper faster and more fully into the digital era.

title: William Bender, Time Editor and Music Critic, Is Dead at 83
description: William Bender, a critic and editor for Time magazine who covered the gamut of Americas musical scene in the late 1960s and 70s, from Leonard Bernstein to David Bowie, died on May 4 in Olathe, Kan. He was 83.

title: At Upfronts, CBS Breaks Up Comedy Block
description: AS the 2014-15 television upfronts draw to a close, Madison Avenue is scrutinizing the decisions that top executives are making as they draw up schedules for the coming season. Those strategies stood in sharp contrast at the presentations made on Wednesday by a leading broadcaster and two large cable channels.

title: Tales of Escapees in Nigeria Add to Worries About Other Kidnapped Girls
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  Among the lucky ones, there are pensive smiles but not much laughter.

title: South Sudan Cease-Fire Proves to Be Short-Lived
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  An agreement for a cease-fire in South Sudan that was signed Friday barely made it into the new week before violence resumed in the seething conflict that has already left thousands dead and displaced more than 1.3 million people.

title: Out for a Run, and Seeking Some Music
description: IF you like to exercise outdoors, you are probably exposing your headphones to sun, wind, rain and sweat. Fortunately, over the years, headphone makers have built plenty of durable options.

title: Beloved Rivals Endure on Ice and in the Office
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Emergent from the shadow of Wayne Gretzky, two gregarious goal-scorers have been adored as fixtures of the hockey landscape in Southern California for the better part of two decades. Luc Robitaille, 48, now an executive with the Los Angeles Kings, finds himself in the playoffs facing his old friend Teemu Selanne, 43, who still plays right wing for the Anaheim Ducks.

title: My States Prettier Than Yours
description: Our topic for today is state tourism slogans. Perhaps thats not what you had in mind. Perhaps you are from North Dakota (Legendary) or North Carolina (Beauty Amplified) and are already so self-satisfied you see no reason to worry about the subject at all.

title: The Age Premium: Retaining Older Workers
description: At a time when digital skills are prized and businesses place a premium on youth, some employers subtly seek to push out older workers. They deny them raises once awarded routinely, reduce their responsibilities or give evaluations that are cold and complain of waning productivity.

title: Fast Food Protests Spread Overseas
description: Even though fast food workers have staged several one-day strikes in the last 18 months, the protests have not swayed McDonalds or other major restaurant chains to significantly raise their employees pay.

title: One Court Ruling on Privacy in Europe, and 28 Regulators
description: LONDON  The ruling on Tuesday by Europes highest court that Google can be forced to remove links from certain searches will be carried out by data privacy regulators at 28 different agencies across the European Union.

title: Forward Has Goals Aplenty but Ground to Make Up
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  No American in the four years since soccers last World Cup has scored more goals in competition than Chris Wondolowski. Few of the other 29 players on the United States mens national teams provisional roster can match his story, either, partly because no others have scored three goals in an international game with their names misspelled on the back of their jerseys.

title: He Lost 3 Years and a Child, but Got No Apology
description: How do you reel back lost years? How do you reconstruct a life turned to dust and rubble? How do you retrieve a love so precious that the mention of it causes your eyes to well?

title: Women of the Senate Band Together Over Missing Nigerian Girls
description: WASHINGTON  All 20 female senators find themselves in fierce bipartisan agreement on at least one topic.

title: U.S. Projects Tough Stance to Both Sides of Syria War
description: With Syria peace prospects in a basic state of collapse, the United States sought to project a toughened posture on Wednesday, conducting military exercises with neighboring Jordan and designating two leaders of Syrian jihadist groups as global terrorists  a warning that they should be ostracized by other members of the Western-backed insurgency fighting President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Nitpicking a Lousy Policy
A Study on Prostate Cancer Relapses Suggests That Hormone Therapy Can Wait
description: Many men with an early sign of a prostate cancer relapse can safely wait before starting hormone therapy, avoiding side effects without shortening their lives, according to the results of a study released on Wednesday.

title: No Slowdown in Unfair Marijuana Arrests
description: When Mayor Bill de Blasio took office in January, community groups and juvenile justice advocates hoped that his administration would significantly decrease the numbers of black and Latino young people who are unfairly  and in some cases, illegally  arrested and dragged through the court system for possession of tiny amounts of marijuana. But a new analysis of state arrest data by a nonprofit called the Marijuana Arrest Research Project, which studies police policy, suggests that the de Blasio administration is on track to equal the more than 28,600 low-level marijuana arrests that were made under Michael Bloomberg in 2013. The administration needs to review Police Department policy to make sure these arrests are necessary and being fairly made.

title: Keeping the Wireless Business Competitive
description: For most of its history, the telecommunications industry has been dominated by a handful of large companies. The cost of laying wires, setting up antennas, signing up customers and getting government licenses makes it hard for new players to get into a business dominated by former monopolies with deep pockets.

title: Babys First Tweet
description: Some parents are creating accounts for their babies on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other services, long before those children are able to add posts themselves.

title: In a Democrats Efforts on Iraq, a Parallel for Boehner on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly before the 2002 midterm elections, Richard A. Gephardt, who was then the House minority leader, infuriated his fellow Democrats when he announced he would help President George W. Bush win authorization for the Iraq war.

title: Derby Victor a Heavy, and Heavier, Preakness Favorite
description: BALTIMORE  He is the Big Horse, California Chrome. He is the inhabitant of Stall 40 in the stakes barn here at Pimlico Race Course, the stall reserved for the Kentucky Derby winner. He is the 3-5 morning line favorite to win the 139th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday.

title: Discrimination in the Military
description: Three years after the demise of dont ask, dont tell, an estimated 15,000 members of the military still must lie about themselves in order to go on risking their lives for their country. When Congress eliminated the law against gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, the Pentagon left in place an equally unfounded prohibition on transgender people.

title: How Young Is Too Young for a Digital Presence?
description: HEY, new parents. Im sure you are swamped with this whole feeding, changing, trying to sleep, trying to sleep-train, child-proofing and searching-for-child-care rigmarole. But have you started planning your childs online presence?

title: Britain: Former Editor Testifies on Hacking of Royals
description: The long-running trial of the former tabloid editors Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson heard testimony on Wednesday that The News of the World had hacked the cellphones of the royal family and its closest associates. Clive Goodman, former royalty editor of the newspaper, which is now defunct, said that before his arrest and conviction for illegal eavesdropping in 2006 he listened to the voice mails of the former Kate Middleton 155 times, of Prince William 35 times and of Prince Harry nine times. Prince William is in line to become king, and Ms. Middleton, now his wife, was then his girlfriend. Mr. Goodman is charged with conspiring to pay officials for royal phone directories, and he said he had not previously disclosed his hacking of royal telephones because the police had never asked him. Earlier in the trial he testified that he had hacked only aides working for the royals, and he has been promised by the prosecution that he will not be further charged for hacking.

title: Judge Blocks Motion to Defend Oregon Gay Marriage Ban
description: SEATTLE  Oregons ban on same-sex marriage, which is under legal challenge, must face its fate alone, to survive or be struck down without anyone defending it in court, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.

title: Panel Questions Experts on Closed Reactor Risks
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate committee on Wednesday questioned a panel of specialists about the safety and security of nuclear reactors that have been retired or forced out of business.

title: Frances Sale of 2 Ships to Russians Is Ill-Advised, U.S. Warns
description: WASHINGTON  In a closed-door meeting in February 2010, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urged his French counterpart not to proceed with the sale of two amphibious assault ships to Russia because it would send the wrong message to Russia and to our allies in Central and East Europe.

title: Sabathias Knee Has a Degenerative Injury
description: C. C. Sabathia has a degenerative condition in the cartilage in his right knee, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, casting more doubt on when Sabathia will be able to return to the team and how much the condition could hamper him.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 14, 2014
Veterans Affairs Secretary to Face Senate Questions on Delayed Care
description: WASHINGTON  For many years, the Department of Veterans Affairs has been criticized for requiring veterans to wait long periods for medical appointments, and for having no foolproof system for holding hospital administrators accountable for those delays. So last year, the department took a fateful step intended to strengthen its oversight of part of the system: It established a goal for new patients seeking primary care to be seen within 14 days of calling for an appointment, with the date of that request logged into a computer file so that it could be tracked.

title: Aging Bridge Behind Him, Obama Pushes Infrastructure Projects
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  President Obama came to this Westchester County village on Wednesday to use the three-mile-long Tappan Zee Bridge as a backdrop to pressure Republicans in Congress to support infrastructure spending.

title: Prominent Hollywood Group Opposes F.C.C. Action on Net Neutrality
description: LOS ANGELES  The Caucus for Producers, Writers and Directors, a small but prestigious association of those who create television and new media programs, has staked out a position in the net neutrality debate. And it has done so not with a direct objection to proposed new rules that would allow Internet providers to create a so-called fast lane for companies like Netflix that are willing to pay for it, but with a blast at the Federal Communications Commission for the dictatorial manner in which it is proposing to alter the Web.

title: A Yankee Gets a Leg Up by Dropping One Low
description: Masahiro Tanaka introduced himself to the Mets on Wednesday with a captivating four-hit shutout in a 4-0 Yankees victory. Ron Darling, a former Mets pitcher and an SNY broadcaster, had seen something like it before.

title: Phone Company Pushed Back Against N.S.A.s Data Collection, Court Papers Show
description: WASHINGTON  In 2009 and early 2010, a telephone company raised questions about the legality of the then-secret National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting records of Americans calling habits, according to court documents declassified on Wednesday.

title: Soaring Earnings of Chipotles 2 Bosses Raise Investor Unease
description: In an era of what many perceive as outsize executive compensation, its not unusual for a successful public company to lavish its chief executive with a multimillion-dollar pay package. But what happens when there are two chiefs?

title: The Preakness Draw
description: Post positions for Saturdays 139th running of the Preakness Stakes.

title: Lawyer for Ex-Christie Aide Seeks Corrections to Lane Closing Report
description: The lawyer for a former top aide to Gov. Chris Christie issued a scathing statement on Wednesday rebutting assertions in an internal report on the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal, as well as the testimony of Mr. Christies spokesman before a legislative committee investigating the matter.

title: Many People in City Lack Proper ID, Lawyers Say
description: When Alec Baldwin took to Twitter to complain about his arrest on Tuesday, he got at least one thing right: If you dont have ID in NY when they write you a summons, he wrote, they can take you in.

title: Misinterpretation of a Biblical Code
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  We continue our biblical theme from yesterday with a crossword puzzle by John Lieb.

title: After Prevailing in Two Game 7s, Rangers Are Back at Square One
description: The Rangers took a well-deserved day off on Wednesday, luxuriating in the afterglow of rallying from a three-games-to-one deficit and eliminating the Pittsburgh Penguins. There could be no denying their resilient spirit; the brilliance of Henrik Lundqvist, the first N.H.L. goalie to win five consecutive Game 7s; or the team effort that gave the players on the Rangers current roster an 83-6 record in Game 7s.

title: Complaints of Food Poisoning at Citi Field Restaurant Dont Scare Off Customers
description: The culinary delights at Citi Field  as opposed to the baseball often played there  are hard to dispute, and as the Mets and the Yankees took to the field to warm up before Wednesday nights game, the smoke from the food court behind center field was already spreading temptation.

title: Newspapers Hooked Dean Baquet, New Editor of The Times, at an Early Age
description: In November 2006, Dean Baquet stood on a desk in the newsroom of The Los Angeles Times and announced that he had been fired as the papers editor after refusing to cut newsroom staff.

title: Obama Presses Infrastructure Spending
description: The president, speaking at the Tappan Zee Bridge, urged Republicans to support his new transportation program.

title: For Cisco, Higher Stock Price Is Still Chasing Ambition
description: Cisco was a Wall Street darling after trading hours on Wednesday, but not for the reasons John T. Chambers, the companys longtime chief executive, wants it to be.

title: Prosecutor Tells Jurors Not to Be Fooled by a Cleric
description: A prosecutor told a Manhattan jury on Wednesday that Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, the British cleric who testified recently at his own terrorism trial, was a skilled speaker who knew how to work a crowd and that the jury should not be fooled by him.

title: High-Power Tug of War Over Teachers Deal
description: Publicly, the news trickled out in humdrum fashion, in a jargon-filled statement that City Hall officials were quick to play down: The de Blasio administration would make a $725 million adjustment to its big-ticket settlement with the New York City teachers union.

title: Saudi Arabia: 5 More Deaths From Virus Reported
description: Saudi Arabia reported five more deaths on Wednesday from a mysterious respiratory virus that first appeared there two years ago and has since spread to at least 16 other countries, including the United States. The Saudi Health Ministry said the latest fatalities from infections caused by the virus, known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, brought the total in that country to 157. Saudi Arabia accounts for the vast majority of the 171 deaths and 571 infections from the virus globally. The Saudi announcement came as the World Health Organization said in a statement that its concern about MERS had significantly increased, but that there was still no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission of the virus.

title: Rangel, at Debate, Wields a Phone to Mock His Opponents
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel deployed an unusual weapon against his two Democratic primary opponents in a debate on Wednesday night: his iPhone.

title: Mayor-Elect of Newark on Election Win
description: The mayor-elect of Newark, Ras Baraka, and his opponent, Shavar Jeffries, spoke after the unofficial returns showed Mr. Baraka outpacing the former assistant state attorney general.

title: Rebuke of Charter Schools Is Seen in Newark Election
description: As Newark woke up to a new mayor-elect on Wednesday, the groups that backed him declared his victory one for the progressive wing of the Democratic Party, saying it was part of a rising tide across the country of voters speaking out against charter schools and other incursions against labor unions and public education.

title: $192 Million Nets Finish Season Empty-Handed
description: MIAMI  The $192 million experiment came to an end on Wednesday.

title: The Americans Recap:  Secrets in the Basement
description: Episode 12, the second to last of the season, begins in Philip and Elizabeths secret basement room. They have decoded a secret code telling them to get Jared out and they have a game plan  Elizabeth will deal with Jared, and Philip will get in touch with the Center, to make sure that the rogue U.S. military agent Larrick is still in Nicaragua, and unable to harm them.

title: Tanaka Gives Struggling Yankees Just What They Need
description: Their pitching staff was in tatters, their spirits at a season low after a four-game losing streak, and their bullpen weary from a heavy workload. With the Yankees teetering in a precarious place, who better to pull them out of their funk than the rookie from Japan who never seems to lose?

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 15, 2014
description: When an institution like the C.D.C. makes a statement, it makes a profound difference to the doctors who are ambivalent.

title: South Korea: Murder Charges in Ferry Disaster
description: The captain and three other crew members of the ferry that capsized off the southwestern coast of South Korea on April 16 were indicted on murder charges on Thursday, prosecutors said. The indictments were among formal charges leveled against 15 crew members of Sewol, the 6,825-ton ferry, after weeks of investigations into the causes of the sinking. As of Thursday, 281 people had been found dead and 23 remained missing. All 15 crew members had previously been arrested on various criminal charges, including accidental homicide. But on Thursday, prosecutors brought the more serious murder charges against the captain, Lee Jun-seok, and three others. They were accused of failing to try to rescue people on board and fleeing the vessel even though they knew that people were in danger and would die without their help. If convicted, the four could face death sentences.

title: The Secret World of the Photographer Mark Cohen
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Foraging in New Jersey With a Danish Chef
description: The Danish chef and foraging enthusiast Mads Refslund takes his crew on a field trip  to the wilderness an hour outside of Manhattan.

title: The Elegant, Thoughtful Furniture of Yabu Pushelberg
description: If youve had the chance to admire the elegant interiors and furniture design of the Waldorf Astoria in Beijing, the Hazelton Hotel in Toronto or Barneys New York, youve been witness to the creative hand of Yabu Pushelberg. Since starting in Toronto 35 years ago, the architecture and design firm has quietly but assertively set the bar for high-end residential, hospitality and retail design. With offices in Toronto and New York and more than 100 employees, Yabu Pushelberg boasts an impressive client list and projects in over 16 countries, including the Edition hotels in London and Miami, the Lane Crawford department store in Shanghai and the Park Hyatt New York and One Madison in New York.

title: Why Unbundling Cable Would Not Save You Money
description: If you have cable TV, you probably dont watch most of the channels you get. The average American television household receives 189 channels, up from 123 in 2003. But were watching only 17.5 of those channels  nearly unchanged from 11 years ago, according to a new report from Nielsen.

title: Word of the Day | rant
description: rant\rant\ verb and noun

title: Activists Praise Hong Kongs Destruction of Confiscated Ivory
description: Updated, 5:12 a.m. ET| The Hong Kong government began destroying nearly 30 tons of confiscated ivory on Thursday, a move conservationists said would send a powerful message about the Chinese territorys resolve to end a trade that had contributed to widespread poaching of elephants.

title: Debuting on Grand Stage, Montero Shows He Belongs
description: Rafael Montero sat at his locker Wednesday afternoon, hours before his major league debut, checking his phone and keeping to himself.

title: Times Minute | Wildfires in California
description: Fire forces evacuations near San Diego. Also on the Minute, the response to anti-China riots in Vietnam and the 9/11 Museums ceremonial opening.

title: Hopes of a Generation Ride on Indian Vote
description: Despite a period of rising incomes, a tide of economic discontent helped make Narendra Modi the prime minister-elect.

title: Times Minute | Wildfires in California
description: In the Video

title: Corrections: May 15, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: India Election Digest: May 15
description: What you need to know on Thursday about Indias elections:A day before the announcement of the parliamentary election results, a scholar weighs in on Narendra Modis possible governance model, Rahul Gandhi skips the prime ministers farewell dinner, and the Bharatiya Janata Party, anticipating victory, orders 4,000 kilograms of sweets in Mumbai.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (ABC) GREYS ANATOMY The doctors of Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital bid an emotional farewell to Cristina Yang (Sandra Oh) in this Season 10 finale, as chaos reigns in the emergency room after a possible act of terrorism (above, Kevin McKidd). Meredith (Ellen Pompeo), meanwhile, makes a life-altering decision. In Black Box, at 10, Bickman (Ditch Davey) tries to convince Catherine (Kelly Reilly) that, like him, she can never find happiness in monogamy after she introduces Will (David Ajala) as her fianc.

title: Lawmakers Real Powers Cant Match Voters Local Expectations
description: NEW DELHI In the ancient city of Varanasi, in the state of Uttar Pradesh, voters said they might pass over the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party because their current lawmaker, Murli Manohar Joshi, hadnt done much over the past decade to develop the town. And in Amethi, the Uttar Pradesh constituency of Rahul Gandhi, the vice president of the Indian National Congress, voters pointed to stagnant, trash-filled pools of water on the citys main street and spoke of wanting change.

title: Dont Call Me Dude, Boss or Bro. Its Comrade to You.
description: Even if you think the Chinese official youre dealing with is a bit of a dude, a bro or a boss  dont call him any of those things. Such terms are signs of unwanted bureaucratic sectarianism and ganglike behavior, according to the Communist Party discipline inspection commission of Guangdong Province.

title: After Two Christies Auctions Top Expectations, Pace of Sales Slows at Sothebys
description: After two consecutive nights of skys-the-limit bidding, Sothebys sale of contemporary art started out on a high, but quickly fell back to earth, with picky buyers passing up paintings and sculptures by major figures like Rothko, de Kooning and Takashi Murakami.

title: Anti-Chinese Violence Convulses Vietnam, Pitting Laborers Against Laborers
description: HA TINH PROVINCE, Vietnam  One Chinese laborer said angry Vietnamese workers had stomped on his hands, crushing them. Another said his son had been struck in the head with a metal rod by a Vietnamese mob that had sought out Chinese for beatings. At least one Chinese worker died.

title: Test Yourself | English, May 15, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: European Sales Help Luxury Group Richemont Balance a Decline in Asia
description: PARIS  Compagnie Financire Richemont, the Swiss luxury goods conglomerate, reported on Thursday a modest rise in annual profit as improved tourism-driven sales of jewelry and watches in Europe and the Americas offset weaker performance in mainland China.

title: A Grass-Roots Drive for Clean Elections in Karnataka
description: DHARWAD, India  Buying votes in Karnataka, like much of India, is ubiquitous during the election season, especially the one that just ended Monday, which may turn out to be the most expensive in Indian history. The Election Commission said it had seized a record amount of cash, as well as alcohol and drugs, earmarked to buy votes.

title: Public Discontent Rises as Families Gather to Bury Victims of Turkish Mine Disaster
description: SOMA, Turkey  With passport-size photographs of their loved ones fastened to their chests, family members of men killed in Turkeys worst mining accident shuffled toward the cemetery on Thursday in a mourning ritual repeated for hours. At least 30 miners were buried as gravediggers toiled to make room for the bodies of many men still trapped underground.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Sept. 11 Memorial Museum at Ground Zero Prepares for Opening
description: In The 9/11 Story Told at Bedrock, Powerful as a Punch to the Gut, Holland Cotter reviews the new museum just before it opens to the public.

title: Who Gets to Graduate?
