description: For as long as she could remember, Vanessa Brewer had her mind set on going to college. The image of herself as a college student appealed to her  independent, intelligent, a young woman full of potential  but it was more than that; it was a chance to rewrite the ending to a family story that went off track 18 years earlier, when Vanessas mother, then a high-achieving high-school senior in a small town in Arkansas, became pregnant with Vanessa.

title: Tangled Identities and Allegiances in Ukraine
description: Alexander Chekmenev began his mandatory military service in 1988 as a Russian citizen of the Soviet Union from eastern Ukraines Donbass region. By the time he left the army two years later  and after the collapse of the Soviet Union  he was an ethnic Russian and Ukrainian citizen.

title: Afghan Contenders Accept Results and Move On
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The two remaining candidates for president of Afghanistan said on Thursday that they accepted the final results of the first round of voting, which eliminated their other rivals, and they vowed to campaign hard to win the election in a runoff.

title: Do You Read for Pleasure?
description: A recent report by Common Sense Media found that a third of 13-year-olds and 45 percent of 17-year-olds say they read for pleasure only one or two times a year, if that.

title: New York Today: Dedicating the 9/11 Museum
description: Good misty Thursday morning to you.

title: Dixons and Carphone Warehouse Plan Merger to Create $6 Billion Company
description: Updated, 12:57 p.m. | LONDON  Two large British sellers of electronics, Dixons Retail and Carphone Warehouse Group, said on Thursday that they had agreed to an all-share merger that would create a company worth more than 3 billion pounds.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Malfunction Causes New Setback in Search for Missing Jet
description: HONG KONG  The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 suffered another setback on Thursday when the communications system for an American deep-sea submersible broke down, and the Australian vessel that had been towing it in the Indian Ocean was forced to head back to port.

title: Captain and 3 Officers Charged With Murder in Korean Ferry Sinking
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prosecutors brought murder charges on Thursday against the captain and three other crew members of a ferry that capsized off South Koreas southwest coast last month, leaving 304 people dead or missing.

title: The Wisdom of Partisan Crowds
description: Watching pundits and politicos speculate about what will happen in a coming election can feel like an exercise in futility. Most predict that their side will win, so what do we learn?

title: Head of Barclays Investment Banking in Asia to Step Down
description: LONDON The head of investment banking for Asia at the British lender Barclays is stepping down as the bank prepares to radically reshape its business.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: The Jerusalem Bureau Says Goodbye to a Four-Wheeled Combat Survivor
description: RISHON LeZION, Israel  The Timess Jerusalem bureau lost a loyal if not loved member last month.

title: How Changing My Body Language Helped Me Close Deals
description: In recent posts, I have written about my attempts to get better at pitching for investment capital in general and closing deals in particular. A related issue that Id like to address is my body language and what it says about me.

title: A Pina Bausch Revival at Tanztheater Wuppertal
description: WUPPERTAL, Germany  The stage is full of enormous cacti. A couple in head-to-toe leopard-skin outfits, cat-ears perched on their heads, wander around with beatific, fixed smiles. Punk-rock music pounds.

title: Euro Zone Economy Grows More Slowly Than Expected
description: PARIS  The European economy maintained its feeble overall growth in the first three months of the year, official data showed on Thursday, as relatively strong performances by Germany and Britain were offset by continued weakness in France and a step backward by Italy.

title: Not On The Mend
description: There have been many proclamations that the euro crisis is over, that Europes economy is on the mend. Behind these proclamations lie something very real  a huge convergence in interest rates, thanks to the ECBs support and growing belief that the political risks to the euro have receded  and something more dubious  a modest uptick in debtor-country growth.

title: Cleaning House at Citi
description: A SHAKE-UP AT CITIGROUP | Citigroup is moving quickly to try to put a costly fraud at its Mexican business in the rearview mirror, firing an additional 11 employees, including four high-ranking executives in Mexico, Michael Corkery and Elisabeth Malkin write in DealBook. On Monday afternoon, the board of the bank was briefed on an internal investigation into the $400 million fraud involving a large Banamex client, and by Tuesday evening, the 11 employees in Mexico were fired.

title: The Hot Seat
description: Hes written a really good book  we might as well get that out of the way, as so much else about Timothy F. Geithner remains unsettled. Geithner served as president of the New York Federal Reserve from late 2003 to 2008 and secretary of the Treasury from 2009 to 2013, and so sat near the center of the American financial system as it prepared to self-destruct. He then had a courtside seat to the global catastrophe. He has rich material to work with, and he has contrived to preserve its freshness. His inability as Treasury secretary to explain himself, or his actions, or the financial crisis, or his beliefs about financial reform, to the wider public will leave many readers, I suspect, feeling they are hearing his voice on these subjects for the first time.

title: How Net Neutrality Works
description: The future of protecting an open Internet has been the subject of fierce debate, and potential changes to the rules by the Federal Communications Commission could affect your online experience.

title: F.C.C. Backs Opening Net Neutrality Rules for Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators appear to share one view about so-called net neutrality: It is a good thing.

title: Pipe Ruptures, Spewing Oil in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  A ruptured pipeline sent about 10,000 gallons of crude oil spilling into the street in eastern Los Angeles early Thursday morning, with geysers that were at first spurting up to 50 feet into the air.

title: It Will Have Blood (Mud, Too)
description: Any new production of Macbeth has a lot to overcome, including history, tradition, expectation and the participants own relationship to the material. For the actor and director Kenneth Branagh, this meant years of thinking about the play, biding his time and concocting and discarding various ideas (some cleverer than others) for how to stage it.

title: Still Radioactive and Spoiling for a Fight
description: Godzilla shows up fairly late in the new movie that bears his name, and he also shows his age. Though this gigantic monster is, within the films own mythico-scientific terms, the long-slumbering reminder of a primordial, prehuman age, by the calendar of popular culture, hes a baby boomer. And now, roughly 60 years after he first appeared (as Gojira in the still unsurpassed, recently restored Japanese original), everybodys favorite skyscraper stomper is exhibiting some familiar generational traits. He seems grumpy and underslept, as well as thicker around the jowls and midriff. And though he arrives dragging the usual heavy allegorical baggage, you can detect a trace of wistful worry in his rampages, as if he had begun to doubt his own relevance.

title: In Our Pages: May 16
description: 1939: Princesses Ride Third Class

title: Report Says Fewer Bees Perished Over the Winter, but the Reason Is a Mystery
description: Honeybees could be on their way back, according to a new federal report.

title: Daily Report: Awaiting a Proposal on Net Neutrality
description: Rarely have so many people become so exercised about something they have not seen.

title: Retailers Feel Economys Effects on Their Shoppers
description: A growing chorus of retailers partly blamed the unusually harsh winter for a disappointing quarter on Thursday. But the sluggish results of chains like Walmart also underscored the sustained financial struggles of a lower-income customer base, while retailers that serve higher-income shoppers performed better.

title: Kindred Healthcare Makes Unsolicited Bid for Gentiva
description: Kindred Healthcare made an unsolicited offer to buy Gentiva Health Services for about $514 million in cash and stock on Thursday, setting up a potential battle over the health care services company.

title: Bayer Sells a Unit to Boston Scientific for $415 Million
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said on Thursday  that it would acquire a division of the German drug maker Bayer for $415 million.

title: RP Martin Fined $2.2 Million in Libor Rigging
description: LONDON  British and American regulators on Thursday fined a small British brokerage firm more than $2 million over misconduct related to the manipulation of global interest rate benchmarks known as Libor.

title: 3 Officials Were Killed in Xinjiang During Chinese Presidents Visit, Report Says
description: Updated, 7:25 a.m. ET| The police in the troubled far-western Chinese region of Xinjiang are seeking assailants who killed three government officials late last month, an act of violence that appears to have been timed to the visit of President Xi Jinping, Radio Free Asia reported on Thursday.

title: 2 Apollo Global Executives Reduce Their Stakes
description: Two of the three leaders of Apollo Global Management have reduced their stakes in the private equity firm by a small amount, regulatory filings show.

title: Tasers and Schools Dont Mix
description: The police rule by fiat in the hinterlands of Texas. Given that reality, no one is surprised that a Bastrop County grand jury has declined to indict the sheriffs deputy involved in the case of a high school student who suffered permanent brain damage last fall after being shocked with a Taser. But Adam Loewy, a veteran lawyer representing 17-year-old Noe Nio de Rivera, was particularly angry about what he described as a grand jury that was a sham process from start to finish. Mr. Loewy asserted in an email that prosecutors never contacted him, and never met with the victim, his parents or an eye witness.

title: Colson Whitehead: By the Book
description: The author of The Noble Hustle: Poker, Beef Jerky, and Death would like to host Flannery OConnor, because I dont think she knew a lot of black people, or got out of the house that much.

title: Rearranging Warhols Legacy
description: PITTSBURGH  Andy Warhol was, chronologically and by his own description, a nose picker, a pimp and a water guzzler. He was also (or therefore) one of the most various, complex and impressive talents the art world has produced. All those claims, however unlikely, can be confirmed by a visit to the Andy Warhol Museum here in his hometown. In honor of its 20th anniversary, the museum has been rethought from top to bottom, and the results are now being revealed to the public. There may not be another museum that digs as deep into a single artist, and gets as much out of the excavation.

title: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Shostakovich, Tigran Mansurian and More
description: SHOSTAKOVICH, KHACHATURIAN: Violin Concertos and QuartetsJames Ehnes, violinist; Melbourne Symphony Orchestra; Ehnes Quartet(Onyx) The Armenian composer Aram Khachaturian composed his Violin Concerto for David Oistrakh. James Ehnes conveys its lighthearted mood, folk elements and virtuosic passages with sweet tone and technical aplomb, deftly accompanied by the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra and the conductor Mark Wigglesworth. Shostakovichs String Quartets No. 7 and 8, which Mr. Ehnes performs with his quartet, offer a stark contrast in mood  particularly their searing rendition of the Eighth. (Vivien Schweitzer)

title: With Warriors, Steve Kerr Follows the Path of Least Tumult
description: On the verge of accepting his first head coaching position, Steve Kerr, in late-game negotiations, played it calculatingly cool. Even to Phil Jackson, a renowned sideline stoic and the man considered to be his mentor, Kerr never showed his true hand.

title: The Electric Neighbor
description: Dear Diary:

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 28
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: When Medical Students Make Errors
description: Im sorry. I messed up.

title: Interest Rates Are Falling. Thank Vladimir Putin.
description: If there was one thing that market analysts thought they could agree upon at the start of the year, it was that interest rates were set to rise. The economy was improving. The Federal Reserve was pulling away from its program of pumping money into bond markets. The era of cheap money seemed to be coming to an end after all these years.

title: Evil Stalks the Stage: Its Curtains!
description: Ghost lights. Traps. Bombs. You killed it. Hang around theater people long enough, and you might think the industry is a living slasher film. Theater and horror movies have been strange bedfellows since European filmmakers of the silent era incorporated Grand Guignol dramatics and expressionistic stage techniques into early movies like Waxworks and The Hands of Orlac. More recently, theater makers have tapped into the horror movie canon to concoct stage versions of Night of the Living Dead and The Exorcist.

title: Official Says Prosecutors Are Looking at V.A. Lists
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Veterans Affairs inspector general is working with federal prosecutors who are trying to determine whether criminal violations occurred at a medical center in Phoenix accused of falsifying data or creating secret waiting lists intended to hide monthslong delays for veterans to see doctors, a top official told a Senate committee on Thursday.

title: Deutsche Bank to Sell Cosmopolitan Casino to Blackstone
description: Updated, 11:15 a.m. | Deutsche Bank is finally leaving Las Vegas.

title: Under Cover: Strength in Numbers
description: This weeks cover story is about an innovative student-retention program at the University of Texas at Austin. For the accompanying cover image, the magazine recruited Bill McCullough, an Austin-based photographer, to shoot 24 students from the program. McCullough recently discussed some of what goes into pulling off a group shot.

title: Japans Constitution and the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Poetry Pairing | Diluvian Dream
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Diluvian Dream by Wilmer Mills and the article Saying Goodbye to the Farm by Anne Raver.

title: Retro-Hugo Prize to Honor Science Fiction of 1938
description: Have you ever found yourself engrossed in a science fiction classic  say, John Wyndhams Sleepers of Mars, C.S. Lewiss Out of the Silent Planet or Edgar Rice Burroughss Carson of Venus  and thought what a pity it is that they were published before 1953, when the Hugo Awards, one of science fictions most prestigious prizes (along with the Nebula Awards) were first given?

title: In This Election Season, 56 Million Tweets and Counting
description: NEW DELHI  With slightly over 200 million Internet users in India, this election marks Indias first that was contested both on the ground and online.

title: One Reason Health Insurance Premiums Vary So Much
description: If you live in Jackson, Miss., Obamacare is giving you a raw deal.

title: Obama Dedicates 9/11 Memorial Museum
description: President Obama on Thursday dedicated the long-awaited museum commemorating the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, with a mournful elegy to the victims, a stirring tribute to the heroes and a firm resolve to never let terrorists shatter the spirit of America.

title: G.M. Recalls 2.7 Million Vehicles, Bringing Its Total for Year to 11.2 Million
description: It seems that no car, truck or sport utility vehicle in General Motors vast product lineup is immune to the automakers blitz of safety recalls.

title: Zendesk Shares Soar in Debut
description: Zendesk, a cloud-based software start-up, had a buoyant trading debut on Thursday, defying a broader slump in the shares of young companies.

title: At a Memorial, Hundreds Pay Tribute to a Gujarat Human Rights Champion
description: AHMEDABAD  The last time I saw Mukul Sinha, a close personal friend and longtime human rights activist and lawyer, was on March 8 when a local newspaper, The Ahmedabad Mirror, held a special ceremony to designate him as a hero of Ahmedabad, the former capital of the state of Gujarat.

title: Car Bomb Kills More Than 40 at Syrian Border Crossing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A car bomb killed at least 43 people on the Syrian side of the Bab al-Salam crossing on the border with Turkey on Thursday and wounded dozens more, an antigovernment group said. It appeared to be the latest instance of civilians bearing the brunt of clashes between Islamist groups in insurgent-held territory.

title: When Your Teenager Wants a Car: The Money Conversations
description: Sooner or later, most teenagers dream of owning a car, and unless you live in a place with terrific public transportation, youll probably entertain the idea of letting them have one. One of the biggest questions, then, is who should pay for it?

title: The Cadets at New Market
description: On the evening of May 10, 1864, on the first anniversary of the battlefield death of Gen. Thomas Stonewall Jackson, who had been a professor at the Virginia Military Institute before the war, some 300 V.M.I. cadets paraded the lush grounds in full dress while bands played and nearby townsfolk came to pay their respects. Groups of girls in filmy garments set off with bits of color came tripping across the sod; and children and nurses sat about the benches at the guard-tree, one cadet recalled.

title: After European Court Decision, Google Works on a Tool to Remove Links
description: LONDON  Google will announce by the end of the month a mechanism for consumers to request that links to information about them be removed from the companys search engine, a leading European regulator said on Thursday. It was one of the first signs that Google was working through how to operate after a court ruling said consumers could make such requests.

title: Two New Murder Charges Brought Against Hernandez
description: BOSTON  The 2012 New England Patriots were an offensive force, setting a record for first downs in an N.F.L. season while scoring 557 points. Tight end Aaron Hernandez was a big part of that offense, catching 51 passes for 483 yards and scoring five touchdowns. He had 15 more receptions in the playoffs as the Patriots advanced to the A.F.C. championship game.

title: Happy in a World of Quirk
description: For Mike Myers, it is not the least bit humbling to go from making comedies for millions of viewers to performing for an audience of one, assuming that person is his 2-year-old son, Spike.

title: Art Matters | The Art World Eyes a New Destination: Gwangju, South Korea
description: Throughout most of the past week, Randalls Island seemed the most far-flung art destination anyone in the New York art world was paying attention to. But a dinner at the West Village club Norwood held during Frieze New York shifted attention to a locale halfway around the world. The curator Jessica Morgan of the Tate Modern in London announced the artists participating in her edition of the Gwangju Biennale in South Korea this fall, which runs Sept. 5 though Nov. 9. Founded in 1995, the event is South Koreas most important international exhibition, and arguably Asias as well, and has put the nations sixth-largest city on the map.

title: Andreessen Horowitz Bets on a Government Software Start-Up
description: The venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz has invested in a range of software companies, catering to different types of customers.

title: At Last, Recovery Heads Where the Fed Wants It
description: The Federal Reserve finally seems to be getting what it wants.

title: What Might Leadership Change Mean for Times Readers?
description: Updated, Friday, 12:55 p.m.Secrets dont normally last long at newspapers. But this was different: Most of the hundreds who gathered in the Times newsroom Wednesday afternoon were stunned by Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr.s announcement that Jill Abramson had been fired.

title: A Summer Dance Program for Children in New York City
description: Some of New Yorks best dance companies will be part of Victory Dance, a series over the summer that will provide free dance performances and classes to children in New York City Department of Education day camps and programs. The lineup, between July 16 and Aug. 1, includes Ballet Techs Kids Dance, Lil Buck, Michelle Dorrance, Doug Elkin, Full Circle Souljahs, Gallim Dance, Ballet Hispanico, Keigwin & Company, Lava, Monica Bill Barnes & Company and Ronald K. Brown/Evidence.

title: Hefty Global Goals from a Vatican Meeting: Stabilizing the Climate, Energy for All and an Inclusive Economy
description: A group statement has emerged from Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Planet, Our Responsibility, the Vatican meeting of scientists, economists, theologians and others that I participated in earlier this month. (If you missed it, click here to watch or read the summary I presented as the meeting ended.)

title: Now on Hotel Lists: Private-Label Wines
description: Guests can order wine just about anywhere they stay, but now they can swirl something a bit more exclusive in their glass: A number of hotels are offering private label vintages as a way to increase cachet and enhance the local dining experience.The Peninsula Hong Kong introduced its own Shaoxing Hua Diao, a 15-year aged Chinese wine made with fermented rice, in late 2013. The group also offers Champagne brut (by Deutz), pinot noir and chardonnay (both by Keller Estate) at all of its properties, served in dark bottles with the hotels logo inked on labels.The Ojai Valley Inn & Spa, north of Los Angeles, offers a Pink Moment sparkling ros in honor of the areas sunsets.

title: Philip Roth Receives Yaddo Artist Medal In Person
description: Philip Roth is back! Well, sort of.

title: A Father-Daughter Pas de Deux
description: A FEW years ago, more or less out of the blue, I began to take my daughter, Hattie, to dance performances. Shed turned 12, and we seemed to be losing each other, just a bit, to our changing lives and cooing cellphones. It seemed like a way to clear out some time to be together.

title: Cuomos Camp Rushes to Define His Republican Rival
description: ALBANY  Rob Astorino was still more than a month away from announcing his bid to challenge Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo back in January, but a political operative with ties to the governor was already busily researching Mr. Astorinos past.

title: Held Hostage in Sudan with Gabriel Garca Mrquez
description: Nearly four years have passed since I was kidnappedand held hostage for 105days while working to bring education to the children of the war-torn region of Darfur, Sudan. In some respects my captivity seems all but a distant memory. The passage of time, however, will never diminish my fond recollections of my only trusted companion during those long, death-defying daysGabriel Garca Mrquez. With his recent passing, all of the harrowing and heart-tugging memories of our time together came flooding back.

title: Clip: Jellyfish Eyes by Takashi Murakami
description: A battle scene from the artists first feature film that combines live-action and animation.

title: Executive Director, Like Artistic Director, Is Leaving Pennsylvania Ballet
description: Its all change at Pennsylvania Ballet. Just two weeks after the announcement that its artistic director, Roy Kaiser, would leave the company once a successor was found, the troupe has announced that its executive director, Michael Scolamiero, will also depart. He will take up the same position at Miami City Ballet.

title: Now Screening | Takashi Murakami Makes a Movie
description: Takashi Murakami is one of the few artists alive who might genuinely be considered a household name. The Japanese maestros hard-edged, big-featured monsters, beauties and flower-faces  famously executed by a vast network of studio assistants, some of whom have spawned their own cult iconographies under the umbrella of his art production and artist management company Kaikai Kiki Co.  are the progenitors of the self-explanatory art movement known as Superflat, which has long since exploded beyond the walls of galleries and onto Louis Vuitton bags, Supreme skate decks and any niche product that can be refashioned as a postmodern canvas.

title: Wheelies: The Mexican Minis Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Obama Speaks at 9/11 Museum Dedication
description: President Obama delivered remarks at the dedication ceremony for the National September 11 Memorial Museum in New York City.

title: De Blasio at 9/11 Museum Dedication
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York delivered his remarks during the dedication ceremony in Foundation Hall at the National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero.

title: Times Minute | A Honeybee Comeback
description: Also on the minute, a runoff in Afghanistans presidential election and the Times movie critics take on the latest return of Godzilla.

title: Today in Small Business: The Canadian Dream?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: When Predators Vanish, So Does the Ecosystem
description: Mark D. Bertness, an ecologist at Brown University, began studying the salt marshes of New England in 1981. Twenty-six years later, in 2007, he started to watch them die. In one marsh after another, lush stretches of cordgrass disappeared, replaced by bare ground. The die-offs were wiping out salt marshes in just a few years.

title: Times Minute | A Honeybee Comeback
description: In the Video

title: Image of the Day: May 15
Another Opponent of Obamacare Starts to Soften
description: Another die-hard opponent of the Affordable Care Act may be finding a way to expand Medicaid. Few have stood as firm against Obamacare as Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, but on Thursday he announced a new proposal that would accept federal funds for increased coverage of low-income state residents  though by giving them access to private insurance plans rather than standard Medicaid.

title: Scenes of Wildfires in San Diego
description: Firefighters battled blazes in Southern California.

title: Fire Season Starts Early, and Fiercely
description: LOS ANGELES  The fire season here in the hot, dry West now lasts roughly 75 days longer than it did a decade ago, and nearly three dozen fires have been burning up and down California in the last two days, weeks before a normal season begins.

title: How It Happens | Forest Fires
description: Fuel, oxygen and heat combine to start wildfires, which destroy millions of acres each year in the United States.

title: A Senate Battle Over Mortgage Rules
description: Lenders are slowly thawing as the financial crisis recedes, but many families with imperfect credit still find it hard to get approved for a mortgage. And just as winter fades to spring, the thaw leads to calls for  Congress to do more to foster affordable mortgages.

title: City College to Establish New Arts Center
description: The City College of New York is hoping to transform a $2.5 million renovation of its Aaron Davis Hall  the attractive concert building that opened in 1979, and has presented performances by Ella Fitzgerald, Mikhail Baryshnikov and the New York Philharmonic  into something bigger. Now the college is announcing the establishment of its new City College Center for the Arts, which will produce and present arts events at Davis Hall and elsewhere on the campus. Gregory S. Shanck is the centers managing director, and David Covington is its artistic director.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Godzilla
description: Gareth Edwards narrates a sequence from Godzilla.

title: Egypt Tells 3 They Must Pay to See Evidence
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court said Thursday that three jailed journalists must pay $170,000 for a copy of the video footage that prosecutors say shows the defendants fabricated news reports to foment unrest.

title: U.S. Report Addresses Concern Over Obamas Plan to Close Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations legal team has told Congress that if Guantnamo Bay detainees were relocated to a prison inside the United States, it is unlikely that a court would order their release onto domestic soil.

title: Women and the I Dont Know Problem
description: Katty Kay, anchor of the BBC World News America, and Claire Shipman, national correspondent for ABCs Good Morning America, explore in The Confidence Code  how men and women express their opinions differently. Women tend to speak up less on topics they arent well versed in, whereas men comfortably hold forth on topics they have little expertise on.

title: Gareth Edwards Narrates a Scene From Godzilla
description: In this video, the director Gareth Edwards discusses an action sequence from Godzilla involving a military parachute jump over the city of San Francisco.

title: Images of Turkish Official Kicking Protester Fuel Anger Online
description: Last Updated, Saturday, 9:25 a.m. | One day after Turkeys prime minister was jeered during a visit to the mining town of Soma, where at least 282 workers were killed this week in an accident, one of his senior advisers was forced to admit that he had kicked a protester being restrained by the police.

title: Investors Reject Chipotle Chiefs Pay Plan
description: Investors in Chipotle Mexican Grill voted overwhelmingly on Thursday against the companys executive compensation plans, sending a strong rebuke to a company that had awarded more than $300 million to its co-chief executives in recent years.

title: Error at IBM Lab Finds New Family of Materials
description: As a research chemist at an IBM laboratory, Jeannette M. Garcia spends her days mixing and heating chemicals in pursuit of stronger and more easily recyclable plastics. Recently she followed a simple formula that required mixing three components in a beaker. Somehow she missed a step, leaving out a chemical. She returned to find her beaker filled with a hard white plastic that had even frozen the stirrer.

title: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
description: On a Wednesday night in early March 1999, Barbara Walters invited a small group of friends and colleagues to her Manhattan apartment to watch her two-hour interview with Monica Lewinsky. During a commercial break, Ms. Walters stood by the window, looking out over Central Park, and noticed something peculiar. Theres no traffic on Fifth Avenue, she observed.

title: Close, Lithgow, Plimpton To Star in Delicate Balance on Broadway
description: The three-time Tony Award winner Glenn Close will return to Broadway for the first time in 20 years to lead a high-powered cast this fall in A Delicate Balance, Edward Albees Pulitzer Prize-winning dark comedy from 1966 about an upper-middle-class family facing terrors both real and amorphous. The producer Scott Rudin announced the casting and performance plans on Thursday. The director will be Pam MacKinnon, an Albee expert who won a Tony last year for staging a revival of his classic Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: To Campuses Without a Compass
description: The last thing a dad gets to really teach his daughter is how to drive a car.

title: Mel Patton, 89, Who Shattered a Leg and Then Sprinting Records, Is Dead
description: Mel Patton, who overcame a badly broken leg as a child to become known as the worlds fastest human in the 1940s and win two gold medals in the 1948 London Olympics, died on May 9 in Fallbrook, Calif., near San Diego. He was 89.

title: Times Issues Response on Abramson Pay
description: A day after The New York Times announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, its first female executive editor, after only 33 months on the job, its publisher was denying reports that her removal was related to complaints about unequal compensation in comparison with her predecessors.

title: Reader Idea | Creating Architectural Models of Literary Themes
description: We love publishing ideas from our readers about new ways to teach with The Times, and the project we feature below is one of the most creative we have ever encountered.

title: This Weekend | The Marvelous Sugar Baby
description: Visit Kara Walkers giant sugar coated sphinx in Brooklyn, see what a Don Quixote ballet looks like at the Met or check out some medieval stained glass at the Cloisters.

title: Wine Ingredient May Have Few Health Benefits
description: Resveratrol, an antioxidant found in red wine, chocolate and other foods, has gained wide public attention as a cancer and heart disease preventive.

title: This Weekend: The Marvelous Sugar Baby
description: In the Video

title: Workers Seize City in Eastern Ukraine From Separatists
description: MARIUPOL, Ukraine  Thousands of steelworkers fanned out on Thursday through the city of Mariupol, establishing control over the streets and banishing the pro-Kremlin militants who until recently had seemed to be consolidating their grip on power, dealing a setback to Russia and possibly reversing the momentum in eastern Ukraine.

title: Ousted Director Rejoins GrafTech Board
description: Investors of GrafTech, the small steel company at the center of a corporate governance debate, have re-elected an ousted director to the board, along with his two of his allies.

title: Rolls-Royce Aims Into the Blue With the Waterspeed Collection
description: A limited-edition, deep blue Rolls-Royce Phantom Drophead Coup, commemorating a 77-year-old world record speed run on water, will be unveiled to the public May 23-25 at the Villa dEste Concorso dEleganza at Lake Como in Italy.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 1
description: Success in fantasy football has as much to do with a players talent as it does with the state of the teams roster. The most talented players often earn the best opportunities, but sometimes that takes time.

title: New York Revives Talk of Hosting the 2024 Games
description: New York Citys bid for the 2012 Olympics ended badly. Might the citys political leaders try again?

title: The Right Price for AstraZenecas Stock
description: Investors are putting a lot of faith in Pfizer succeeding in its $100 billion-plus quest to acquire British pharmaceuticals rival AstraZeneca. The right price for the targets share price can be seen as the weighted average of two possible outcomes  a sale to Pfizer or a standalone future. A new Breakingviews calculator shows why the market seems to think a transaction will probably happen.

title: Convicted of Felonies, Banks Are Allowed to Stay in Business
description: Two large international banks  Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas  are expected to plead guilty to criminal charges within the next few weeks. If that happens, they will pay large fines and officially be felons.

title: Impossible? Only Until You Prove Otherwise
description: This interview with Rob Gough, president of Eckim, a marketing company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Created by Hand: Lock, Stock and Barrel
description: The antiques dealer and collector Joseph Kindig Jr. never fired a shot with any of his hundreds of American rifles made around 1800. He was not a hunter; he was a vegetarian who did not like to kill anything. At his store in York, Pa., he would refuse to sell his gun inventory to buyers who seemed snobbish or ignorant. He believed that the firearms represented the first major American artistic innovation.

title: One Singular Thai Sensation
description: This is it, the only dish on the menu, the reason the restaurant exists: chicken over rice on a paper plate, white on white on white. Pale-skinned moons of cucumber lie to one side, a lone stem of cilantro on top.

title: France Asserts It Has Authority to Block Mergers
description: PARIS  The French government has formally given itself the power to block foreign takeovers on strategic grounds as it seeks to sway the outcome of a battle between General Electric and Siemens for Alstom, one of Frances industrial crown jewels.

title: California Chrome Coughs, but Trainers Say He Is Fine
description: BALTIMORE  It is more a tickle than a hitch. At least that is how the trainer Art Sherman characterized the cough California Chrome came up with Thursday morning.

title: Prehistoric Skeleton in Mexico Is Said to Link Modern Indians to Earliest Americans
description: Most geneticists agree that Native Americans are descended from Siberians who crossed into America 26,000 to 18,000 years ago via a land bridge over the Bering Strait. But while genetic analysis of modern Native Americans lends support to this idea, strong fossil evidence has been lacking.

title: La Scala to Fire Incoming Director After One Season
description: MILAN  In what Mayor Giuliano Pisapia described as an agonizing decision, the board of La Scala on Thursday voted to dismiss that opera theaters incoming director general at the end of his first season, amid charges of a conflict of interest.

title: The Commencement Bigots
description: Its commencement season, cellphones off please, no texts or tweets. Even with a hangover from debt, alcohol or regret, grads across the land may be lucky enough to hear something on the Big Day that actually stays with them.

title: U.S. Mines Personal Health Data to Find the Vulnerable in Emergencies
description: The phone calls were part Big Brother, part benevolent parent. When a rare ice storm threatened New Orleans in January, some residents heard from a city official who had gained access to their private medical information. Kidney dialysis patients were advised to seek early treatment because clinics would be closing. Others who rely on breathing machines at home were told how to find help if the power went out.

title: Letters: Considering James Madison
description: Considering James Madison

title: The Funeral Buffet and Other Existential Issues
description: A man in a wrinkled sport coat perches on a bar stool. I was at your daughters wake, he tells the bartender (Evander Duck). Lets hope the customer (Noel Joseph Allain) likes that sentence. Hell say it more than 20 times in William Burkes brief, oblique the food was terrible, at the Bushwick Starr.

title: The Gun Report: May 15, 2014
description: Whenever a child opens fire at a school, wounding and killing classmates and teachers, we want to know why. If the shooter commits suicide during the rampage, all we can do is guess.

title: Life Could be a Dream (if Your Name Is Alice)
description: Alice in Wonderland has been adapted as an all-star Paramount production (1933), with Cary Grant as the Mock Turtle; as a British puppet animation (1949), eclipsed by the Disney animated musical (1951), later embraced as a head film by the drug culture of the late 60s; as Dennis Potters meditation on the old age of the real Alice (Dreamchild, 1985); and as Tim Burtons 3-D extravaganza (2010) starring Mia Wasikowska as a 19-year-old Alice. None, however, is stranger than Alice (1988), made by the Czech animator Jan Svankmajer, newly remastered and reissued on Blu-ray by First Run Features.

title: The March to War
description: In February 1933, President-elect Franklin Roosevelt was nearly murdered in Miami by a gunman whose errant fatal shot struck Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago. Cermak gallantly told Roosevelt, Im glad it was me instead of you. Todays Americans should not disagree. Had Roosevelt been killed, the 32nd president of the United States would have been his running mate, Speaker John Nance Garner of Texas, a neophyte in foreign and military affairs, isolationist by instinct and deeply rooted in a Congress determined, notwithstanding the growing threats from Hitler and the imperial Japanese, to keep another president from repeating what a majority of its members considered to be Woodrow Wilsons catastrophic mistake of needlessly dragging the nation into a distant foreign war.

title: All the Way
description: Over the past century, Congress has passed only a handful of truly transformative pieces of legislation. The Social Security Act comes to mind, as do the G.I. Bill, the Marshall Plan, the laws that created a mammoth military and laid down a web of highways, and the reforms that reopened the nation to immigration. Visionary laws  each and every one  meant to achieve policy aims of striking originality.

title: Russian Businessman Under Sanctions Fires Broadside at West
description: BERLIN  The president of Russian Railways, Vladimir I. Yakunin, a longtime associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, is persona non grata to Washington. Sanctioned by the United States in retaliation for support of Moscows annexation of Crimea, he has been banned from entering the country and any assets there have been frozen.

title: Rand Pauls Hard Road
description: It is fair to say, I think, that Rand Paul is one of the most interesting major contenders for the Republican nomination in 2016, and by extension for the presidency. (Thats why everyone at this newspaper keeps writing about him!) Its also fair to say that his path to both destinations would be unique, at least by the standards of modern G.O.P. presidential contenders: There are no obvious recent historical models for the kind of coalition Paul would need to put together to win either the nomination or the presidency, and there isnt even a recent near-miss candidate (his father, for all his grassroots success, was just a miss, with nothing near about it) whose almost-success he could try to build upon.

title: Russia Tells Ukraine: Cash in Advance for Gas
description: MOSCOW  Russia said on Thursday that it would stop supplying gas to Ukraine at the end of the month unless the country paid for it in advance, increasing the pressure on Kievs financially pressed government as it struggles to contain a growing rebellion in the countrys east.

title: Bonding Through Time, on Film and in Life
description: Shortly after arriving in New York from France to study film, Cdric Klapisch, then 23, was interrogated by a roommate: Where do you think youll be in 10 years? Though he knew he wanted to direct, Mr. Klapisch, now 53, recalled: I couldnt really answer that question. I knew that my life was ahead of me, and didnt know what my life would look like.

title: As Maman Lay Dying, Her Spirit Became Art
description: Wandering into the sumptuous neo-Gothic chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, you might think youd come upon the lovingly arranged setting for a funeral. Youve actually walked into a work of art by the French conceptualist Sophie Calle, an installation called Rachel, Monique. Its an elegiac but frustratingly oblique meditation on the life and the death of Ms. Calles mother, Monique Sindler. (The Rachel in the title was another name by which she was known.)

title: Relational Unveils Stake in B/E Aerospace
description: Updated, 6:43 p.m. | B/E Aerospace surprised many last week when the company, a maker of airplane seats, announced that it was weighing a potential sale, among other strategic options.

title: All About Fees
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Reverend Billy Brings a New Sermon to Joes Pub
description: During Occupy Wall Street a few years ago, the Miser moseyed over to Zuccotti Park for a firsthand look. A singular figure in a white suit over clerical garb and collar, his blond-highlighted pompadour bopping in sync with his sermonizing, stood out.

title: Home Equity Loans Make a Cautious Return
description: Home-equity lending is making a gradual comeback now that property values in some areas have risen to levels that give homeowners something to borrow against.

title: This Is How We Roll
description: IVE toyed with the idea of using a foam roller to help release muscle tension after rigorous workouts. The stretching area at my gym has several of these cylindrical self-massage tools. But Ive long been unsure about the right way to roll and too time-pressed to figure out how.

title: Marco Rubio on the Settled Science of Abortion
description: Sick of taking flak for his climate-change denial, Senator Marco Rubio tried to change the topic (a classic crisis-management move) by accusing his critics of hypocrisy (another classic).

title: U.S. Officials Question Ability of Nigeria to Rescue Hostages
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials on Thursday questioned whether the Nigerian military is able to rescue, even with international help, more than 260 schoolgirls abducted last month, giving impetus to a social media campaign calling for the United States to do more to free the hostages.

title: Federal Officials Ease Travel Rules for Instruments With Ivory
description: After weeks of pressure from musicians, the Obama Administration announced Thursday that it has relaxed rules that would have made it extremely difficult for performers and orchestras to travel abroad with instruments that contained ivory parts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, New York, California and England.

title: Lady Day at Emersons Bar & Grill
description: Audra McDonald sings God Bless the Child in Lady Day at Emersons Bar & Grill.

title: Les Misrables
description: Will Swenson sings Stars, in Les Misrables.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: National Gallery Finalizes Agreement to Obtain Much of  Corcoran Collection
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington  the nations oldest privately supported art museum but one that has struggled financially for many years  has completed an agreement with the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University to absorb its building, collection and its art college.

title: New Yoga Programs at Six Senses Resorts
description: Those looking to travel to a deeper state of consciousness on their next vacation might consider one of Six Senses new yoga-based retreats.

title: U.S. Seeks to Bypass Assad So More Aid Can Reach Syrian Civilians
description: LONDON  Increasingly flustered with the inability of the United Nations to deliver aid to war victims in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that the United States was considering ways to increase the delivery of aid without the consent of President Bashar al-Assads government.

title: Brazilian Mogul Starts to Fight Insider Trading Claims
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The onetime Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista has begun his formal defense against the insider trading allegations brought by Brazils main securities regulator.

title: A Song of the Country With Frog Chorus
description: After 9/11, Audra McDonald no longer felt safe living in New York City. I had recently given birth, was still quite hormonal and, like everyone else, I was frightened, recalled Ms. McDonald, now 43, and a Tony Award nominee for her starring role in the Broadway show Lady Day at Emersons Bar & Grill. And I kept saying to my husband we have to leave the city, we have to leave the city.

title: At Least You Dont Have to Buy a Gift
description: The son of a very close friend is getting married. My husband and I were not invited. My friend claims that the young couple is paying for the wedding themselves, that money is tight and that even relatives had to be excluded. But I know my friend invited some of her college friends. I have let her know that I will be hurt if I am not included. She seems embarrassed, and I dont think she wants to lose my friendship, yet I remain uninvited. Im afraid that I wont feel the same about her after the wedding. Whats the best way to handle this?

title: 36 Hours in Washington, D.C.
description: While most Americans associate Capitol Hill with Congressional misadventures and general dysfunction, thousands of people  senators, reporters, congressional aides, artists, working-class long-timers and young families  call it home. Amid the charming rowhouses and grand federal buildings, Capitol Hill is dotted with restaurants and night spots. Its history is vibrant and largely accessible, from the United States Capitol to the Navy Yard, where the banks of the Anacostia River were once lined with military ships, to dynamic H Street, the site of riots after the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And dont forget baseball. Take in a Nationals game, if possible, among cheering fans and very good stadium chow.

title: Clip: Words and Pictures
description: Juliette Binoche in a painting sequence from the film.

title: British Cede Le Brun Portrait to the Met
description: In 17th-century France, Charles Le Brun was as hot as any artist could be. He created work for the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris, for the Galerie dApollon in the Louvre, for Htel Lambert on le St. Louis, for the Chteau de Vaux-le-Vicomte and for much of Versailles. Louis XIV declared him the greatest French artist of all time. Whatever he produced made an impact.

title: Two Palestinians Killed in Clashes With Israeli Forces
description: JERUSALEM  Two young Palestinian men were killed Thursday in clashes with Israeli security forces during a demonstration for Nakba Day, which commemorates the destruction of Arab villages in battles that led to the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948.

title: Love, Sex, Marriage and Schopenhauers Ghost
description: The next Proust is the dubious marketing tag applied to Xavier Rousseau (Romain Duris), a flighty, footloose novelist, by his editor in Chinese Puzzle, the French filmmaker Cdric Klapischs airborne romantic comedy. So what if there is nothing remotely Proustian about Xavier, the womanizing charmer with an idiot grin from two earlier films  LAuberge Espagnole and Russian Dolls  also written and directed by Mr. Klapisch. Xavier, like the other returning characters from those movies, is about to turn 40. But in his carefree attitude, he might as well be 25.

title: Robert Heinecken, Master of the Photographic Juxtaposition
description: Robert Heinecken is having a posthumous resurgence. The artist  who founded the UCLA photography department andfamously described himself as a para-photographer,generated photographic images without using a camera has an exhibition called Object Matter at MoMA through Sept. 7, his first since his death in 2006. A second show, I Am Involved in Learning to Perceive and Use Light, opens tonight at Petzel Gallery and runs through June 21.The title is taken from a 1974 essay by the artist, which the gallery offers in lieu of a press release. In it, he discusses his intentions, methodologies and views on aesthetic value systems. My basic tenet is relatively simple, he explains. To relate the former to the future, the last to the next. Heinecken carries out this philosophy quite literally in one of the best known strands of his practice, a related series of double exposures made from the 1960s to the 1990s, in which he culled current events and womens magazines to find individual pages containing two faces that made unforgettable figurative abstractions when overlaid.

title: Life in the City as a Jazzy Medley of Movie Themes and Show Tunes
description: A thematically organized social history of New York City told through several decades of movie songs is the concept of Joanne Tathams tourist-friendly cabaret show Soundtrack New York, heard at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening.

title: Illuminating and Elevating What Is Familiar
description: Eight members of the St. Lukes Chamber Ensemble played at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday evening, but one kept catching the ear: the violinist Krista Bennion Feeney. Keen throughout, she followed the intermission with a riveting rendition of the Sonata in C from Jean-Marie Leclairs Quatrime Livre de Sonates.

title: A Mischievous Half-Smile, Cloaked in Mystery
description: In the midst of a frantic week of art fairs and auctions, a splendid Renaissance portrait made a quiet and dignified entrance at the Frick. Parmigianinos Schiava Turca, a painting of an unidentified woman with twinkling hazel eyes and a mischievous half-smile, invites us to settle in for a restorative session of close looking.

title: Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster: euqinimod & costumes
description: 303 Gallery

title: Anne Doran: Photo-works (1985-1991)
description: Invisible-Exports

title: Liz Deschenes: Stereographs #1-4 (Rise/Fall)
description: Miguel Abreu Gallery

title: Mika Rottenberg: Bowls Balls Souls Holes
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Matt Connors: Machines
description: Canada

title: Benjamin Butler: Green Forest
description: Klaus von Nichtssagend Gallery

title: Highlights and Milestones: Derek Jeter
description: The longtime Yankees shortstop is in his 20th and final season. His many milestones and career highlights are compiled here with related video, and articles and photos from the Times archive.

title: Rackspace Hires Morgan Stanley to Explore Options
description: Rackspace Hosting, a web-hosting company with a market value of more than $4 billion, has hired Morgan Stanley to evaluate a sale or other strategic options, after being approached by potential suitors.

title: Paul Taylor Sells Four Rauschenbergs at Sothebys
description: Four works of modern art were sold so that many works of modern dance could continue to be performed: the choreographer Paul Taylor sold four of his Robert Rauschenberg pieces on Wednesday and Thursday to help pay for the new center of modern dance he is creating.

title: Somber Ceremony for Museum Dedication
description: President Obama, former President Bill Clinton and two former mayors, Michael R. Bloomberg and Rudolph W. Giuliani, attended the ceremony at the National September 11 Memorial Museum.

title: The Internet Isnt Just for the Young
description: Early in the documentary Cyber-Seniors, you might find yourself saying, Ugh, are they really going to make me watch octogenarians poke fruitlessly at laptops for 75 minutes? But the film soon stops that torture and becomes a likable intergenerational tale with a bit of unexpected pathos.

title: Astorino, at G.O.P. Convention, Vows Fight to Save New York
description: RYE BROOK, N.Y.  Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, accepted the Republican Partys designation to run for governor on Thursday and painted a bleak picture of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos tenure as marked by economic doldrums, stifling taxes and a lack of political courage.

title: Tilting at Genres
description: DON PEYOTE

title: Musicians on Speed Dates
description: James Carter, a wildly charismatic tenor saxophonist, and Petra Haden, an equally irrepressible vocalist, had a moment halfway through A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets, at Town Hall on Wednesday. It started almost songlike, with a haunting, wordless vocal melody answered by a limpid saxophone obbligato.

title: Mirror Images, From Real Life or Fun House
description: The idea is often dismissed today, but one mandate of art is to reflect how we live. Im not talking about the flat mirrors of nostalgia polished and perfected by Norman Rockwell and Andrew Wyeth  a jagged shard of broken glass is just fine to gaze into  but rather art we can stare in the eye and say, Yeah, that kind of looks like me.

title: Should Young Children Learn Coding?
Cannes Film Festival: Major Deal for Denis Villeneuve Film
description: CANNES, France  In the first major sale at this years Cannes Film Festival, Paramount Pictures announced on Thursday that it had acquired distribution rights to Story of Your Life, a science-fiction blowout directed by Denis Villeneuve and starring Amy Adams as a linguist hired by the military to determine the intentions of alien spacecraft that have landed on Earth.

title: Grandes Dames of the Gardens
description: If you start your sojourn through the New York Botanical Gardens multipart Groundbreakers exhibition as you are meant to  looking at a show about photography in the gallery next to the library  then when you finally reach the conservatory displays, you will feel overwhelmed by a mosaic of color, texture and pattern, a fragrant alle of floral extravagance.

title: Bringing the Wisdom of Middle Age to Punk
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  Lifes rotten, reasoned Off!s frontman, Keith Morris, small and bothered, crease-faced, dreadlocked, pacing. This was somewhere around the middle of a 50-minute, 22-song set on Monday night at Asbury Lanes, a bar and bowling alley here with low ceilings and focused sound. And this was his version of crowd riling: bad news first, then a suggestion. So he continued, while youre out there being abused, used, being treated unfairly, have fun and enjoy yourselves.

title: Shes Just Off the Boat. Hes the Wrong Man.
description: In American popular culture, and in the private lore of millions of American families, the immigrant experience of the late-19th and early 20th centuries is often presented as a chronicle of struggle and triumph, a parable of dreams come true. In The Immigrant, James Gray (who directed the film and wrote it with Richard Menello) tries to push through this rosy nostalgia and recapture some of the terror and strangeness of the journey from the Old World to the New. The first shot is of the Statue of Liberty shrouded in harbor mist, and the film unfolds in the gap between the promise that lady embodies and the harsh realities a newcomer encounters once she gets off the boat.

title: See Me. Feel Me. Maybe Drool on Me.
description: The Museum of Modern Arts sprawling survey of the work of the influential Brazilian artist Lygia Clark has a singularly unpromising title: Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988 signals something of a letdown, especially if you like art. But once youve worked your way through this up-and-down massing of some 300 works, equally fitting and less stark alternatives may come to mind, including the expansion of art and the internalization of art.

title: Critical Thinking, From Socrates to the Ivory Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Alec Baldwins Bike Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: Electricity in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Edie Falco: Meditate. Then Its Time to Play.
description: For Edie Falco, star of the Showtime series Nurse Jackie, Sunday is a day for free-floating time with her son, Anderson, 9, and her daughter, Macy, 6. The childrens godfathers may pay a visit. There may be a movie or a play. Theres usually a meditation class. Ms. Falco, 50, has won four Emmys, one for Nurse Jackie and three for her role as Carmela Soprano in The Sopranos. A single mother, she lives in the West Village with her children and the familys rescue dog, Sami, a Brussels griffon. Ms. Falco often rides around town on her electric bike.

title: Charging Into the Minefield of Genes and Racial Difference
description: Few areas of science have contributed more to human misery than the study of racial difference. In the 1920s, eugenicists from top American universities promoted the sterilization of the unfit and later praised Hitlers racial codes while advocating laws that would exclude thousands of Jews from our shores.

title: Ideology and the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Pace University to Start Performing Arts School
description: Pace University is starting a performing arts school, which the university said will be Manhattans first new such school in nearly 50 years. The new school, Pace School of Performing Arts, grew out of Paces performing arts program.

title: A Meal Schedule for Diabetes
description: For people with Type 2 diabetes, eating two large meals a day may be better than consuming the same number of calories in six small meals.

title: Sommeliers Decanting the Madness of Cannes
description: CANNES  They know how to put on a good show at the Cannes Film Festival, even when forced to make do with an opening-night dud and the lack of a closing-night selection. No matter how serious and aesthetically high-minded, the festival always banks on its stars. This year Quentin Tarantino will help wrap up the proceedings by introducing a restoration of Sergio Leones 1964 red-sauce western, A Fistful of Dollars. Its a celebrity event that will bookend the one delivered on Wednesday, when Nicole Kidman  the star of the widely derided Grace of Monaco  drifted down the red carpet, reprising her familiar role as a supernova who transcends her every stinker.

title: A Balanchine Double Bill, With Heart-Stopping Pauses
description: The choreographer George Balanchine is seldom listed among the 20th centurys great dramatists, and yet many of his ballets take us as close to the essence of drama as any playwright. Whats more, few theater artists have anything of his vast expressive range.

title: Events in Westchester for May 18-24, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Reading Experience May Change the Brains of Dyslexic Students
description: Among the many challenges faced by children with dyslexia (and by their parents and teachers) is the nagging fear that their difficulties with reading are entirely hard-wired: predetermined by their genes and impossible to change. Recent research offers a balm for that fear. It suggests that experience plays a big role in dyslexia, both in exacerbating reading problems and, potentially, in easing them.

title: Arrests Made in Assault on Park Redwood Trees
description: Earlier this year I wrote about a spate of criminal assaults on redwood trees in a California park  all targeting the bulbous growths called burls that are prized by woodworkers and furniture makers.

title: Challenging Authority and Taking the Heat
description: Part of the reason the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei  the subject of a current exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and of the Danish filmmaker Andreas Johnsens new documentary, The Fake Case  is such an intriguing figure is that his recent career feels like the latest battle in the very old war between the imagination and the state. Especially since 2008, when the aftermath of the Chengdu earthquake in Western China awakened his conscience and made him a determined critic of his government, Mr. Ai has taunted, mocked and passionately denounced the authoritarianism, corruption and incompetence that he sees around him. He has made more-or-less conventional works of art reflecting these concerns, and made deft use of social media and his own celebrity.

title: Irelands Troubled Peace
description: FORTY years ago this Saturday, three no-warning bombs ripped through Dublin. Less than an hour later, another bomb shattered the rural quiet of the town of Monaghan. In all, 33 people were killed and more than 300 injured. In Dublin, sheets of newspaper were laid over the dismembered bodies to hide them from view. The headlines soaked up the blood: the news in advance.

title: Theater Listings for May 16-22
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Hapless Meal Tickets, Plucked From India
description: Baseball isnt just about business. You should have fun, too.

title: Attending Lifes First Breath and Its Last
description: Frankly, The American Nurse sounded unpromising. When Carolyn Jones, the director, had breast cancer, she was so touched by the nursing care she received that she wanted to pay tribute to the profession. Sweet, understandable, admirable. But you sort of want to say, Why not just send them a card? Ms. Jones, however, has delivered a solid, worthwhile documentary. If the film is workmanlike at times, it is also elegantly cleareyed.

title: Clip: Million Dollar Arm
description: A scene from the film.

title: Clip: The Discoverers
description: A scene from the film directed by Justin Schwarz.

title: At SALT Conference, Stocks Induce Anxiety
description: LAS VEGAS  At the the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference here, hedge fund managers are gathering at the Bellagio hotel to exchange views and ideas.

title: What Lewis and Clark Inspired
description: On paper, The Discoverers sounds like National Lampoons Vacation crossed with a self-help manual. Lewis (Griffin Dunne) is a struggling history professor in Chicago who,  la Grady Tripp in Wonder Boys, is preparing to publish a nearly 7,000-page tome. In the sort of excursion that might generously be described as a getaway, he piles his teenage kids, Zoe (Madeleine Martin) and Jack (Devon Graye), into the car, bound for a conference in Portland, Ore. The road trips destination suddenly changes when Lewiss mother takes a turn for the worse.

title: Coke and McDonalds, Growing Together Since 1955
description: It was early 1955 when Ray Kroc, an ambitious milkshake equipment salesman who had bought the right to expand McDonalds throughout the country, was opening his first restaurant, in Des Plaines, Ill.

title: Alzheimers, a Neglected Epidemic
description: The opening shots of The Normal Heart, HBOs adaptation of Larry Kramers 1985 play about the early days of the AIDS crisis in New York, reveal a crew of sinewy and amorous young men disembarking from a ferry on Fire Island on a beautiful July day in 1981. The tableau is meant to suggest the final hour of unburdened desire, the moment before so much youth and beauty would be sacrificed to the cruelest attacks of physiology and cultural indifference.

title: Remastering, Reflecting: Everything Still Turns to Gold
description: In Boston last week to deliver the commencement address at the Berklee College of Music, Jimmy Page, the founder of Led Zeppelin, learned to his surprise that the school had a course in which his guitar licks were minutely analyzed. They go into all these things and deconstruct them, he said, the harmonies and the voicings and the progressions, the arrangements.

title: It Was Open Mike at the Upfront Events
description: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of upfront week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2014-15 season.

title: In Nigeria, the Personal and the Political Clash
description: Perhaps the greatest challenge faced by literary adaptations that juxtapose a small group of characters against a seismic backdrop  Doctor Zhivago, say, or The Leopard  is one of proportion. Half of a Yellow Sun, adapted from the 2006 novel by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, emerges on screen as a well-acted, finely wrought epic that nevertheless struggles to balance the requirements of melodrama with its drive to capture a historical moment. The movie could easily have been a mini-series, but at just under two hours, it plays like a highlight reel.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Pepsi Challenges Coke in the Race to Design a More Tappable Soda Fountain
description: Thanks to new weaponry built with touch screens, Italian design and the latest technology, the cola wars are returning to an old battleground, the soda fountain.

title: Providing for the Dead
description: Gary Gotlin emerged from his black BMW on Monday at a Staten Island cemetery and approached 10 small white coffins, each topped with a bouquet.

title: Searching for Quality in Assisted Living Care
description: FINDING the right assisted living option for a family member can be a daunting task, and its not always easy to find data about the quality of various facilities.

title: Texas Chases New Business but Worries About Water
Obamas Had Up to $7 Million in Assets in 13, Records Show
description: The assets of President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were valued as high as $7 million last year, according to a financial disclosure form released by the White House on Thursday.

title: Mourners Attend a Mass Burial
description: Hundreds of mourners attended a mass burial for some of the miners killed in the Turkey coal mine disaster.

title: On the Range, With a Conscience
description: As Kirk Hanna did in life, Mitch Dickmans documentary Hanna Ranch wrestles with ecological concerns. But the biggest problems for Mr. Hanna were very, very human. This Colorado cattle rancher  a featured personality in Eric Schlossers 2001 best seller Fast Food Nation  was a forward-thinking cowboy who embraced Holistic Resource Management, a fruitful approach that, among other things, encourages herding methods less stressful to cattle and a more frequent rotation of livestock through pastures. Mr. Hanna used earth-friendly natural fertilizer; to attack weeds, he employed hungry goats.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 16, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Godzilla, The Immigrant and Million Dollar Arm.

title: A Menace Who Chops Up Bodies and Enjoys a Good Singalong
description: With Wolf Creek 2, the director Greg McLean returns once more to remind us that the back of beyond  in this case, the Australian outback  is a perilous destination for unwary tourists. But those of us who championed its 2005 precursor, the artfully petrifying Wolf Creek, neither need nor want reminding. Like Neil Marshalls The Descent, another crazy-good frightener released in America the following year, Wolf Creek deserved to stand alone, a uniquely moody and melancholy blood bath.

title: Foreclosed, Cantankerous and Heading South
description: Robert Duvall won his Oscar for his finely calibrated portrayal of a recovering alcoholic country singer in Tender Mercies, and much of his best work is in service to nuanced roles. Yet his most memorable performances also include some where he goes big, as in, for example, the napalm-loving Lt. Col. Bill Kilgore in Apocalypse Now. When he has fun, he lets us in on it.

title: A Depressed Writer, Distracted by His Ailing Parents
description: Though hes played a committed writer on television (October Road), Bryan Greenberg doesnt always come across as one in Michael Marens A Short History of Decay. That makes some sense, as Mr. Greenbergs 30-something character, Nathan, just switched from being a struggling novelist to being an inactive playwright. But the best parts of Mr. Marens well-observed film arent always to be found in its accessible setup.

title: After an Accident, a Test of Forgiveness
description: Atsushi Funahashis gloomy drama takes place in a depressed industry town in the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. But the hand of misfortune has yet one more blow in store, as Shiori, who works in a small factory, loses her husband, Kenji, to an accident. A pall is cast over life, felt in her stunned grief and in a dim workplace resembling a cluttered supply closet.

title: The Thin Line Between a Pest and a Reformer
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Reports of Gas Odors Surge After East Harlem Blast
description: After an explosion leveled two apartment buildings in East Harlem in March, killing eight people, officials of Consolidated Edison were exasperated that nobody had sounded an alarm until it was too late.

title: The Case for Soft Atheism
description: This is the sixth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Philip Kitcher, a professor of philosophy at Columbia University and the author of the forthcoming book Life After Faith: The Case for Secular Humanism.

title: Telling the Gypsies Tale Beyond the Stereotype
description: The subtitle to the documentary A People Uncounted  The Untold Story of the Roma  might lead you to expect a historical overview of the people known as the Roma, or Gypsies. Its a fascinating culture, which migrated to Europe from Northern India 1,000 years ago. The word Gypsy, derived from Egyptian, is a misnomer; equally misleading is a stereotype of joyfully itinerant musicians, dancers and petty thieves that persists in opera, literature, pop hits and movies.

title: N.B.A.s Replay Controversies Could Lead to a Review
description: LOS ANGELES  Clippers forward Matt Barnes was parked in front of the television at home Wednesday night, watching the end of the Nets-Miami Heat game while his twin 5-year-old boys busied themselves wrestling.

title: Travelers Move Past Their Own Limits
description: Traditions may vary, but Passover Seders typically end with the wish that the participants might celebrate again next year in Jerusalem. For eight pilgrims from the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, Conn.  average age, 91  next year was 2011, when they toured Israel, along with nursing aides, administrators and a film crew.

title: Divergent Paths
description: As economies in Northern Europe show signs of improvement, the southern rim nations continue to struggle. The uneven nature of the recovery has weighed on the overall European economy, which will probably take years to truly recover.

title: Full Recovery Still Years Away for Many in Euro Zone
description: PARIS  Despite recent optimism that Europes economy is finally turning a corner, a stark reality remains: The situation is still fragile.

title: F.C.C. to Help Small Firms Buy Airwaves
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday adopted new rules governing coming auctions of airwaves for use in mobile broadband, and the agency said it would set aside certain portions of the airwaves for purchase by smaller wireless companies.

title: News Groups Sue for Data on Missouris Executions
description: A group of news organizations sued the Missouri Department of Corrections on Thursday, arguing that the department is violating the First Amendment by refusing to identify the sources of lethal drugs used in its executions.

title: Points of No Return
description: Recently two research teams, working independently and using different methods, reached an alarming conclusion: The West Antarctic ice sheet is doomed. The sheets slide into the ocean, and the resulting sharp rise in sea levels, will probably happen slowly. But its irreversible. Even if we took drastic action to limit global warming right now, this particular process of environmental change has reached a point of no return.

title: M.T.A. Expanding Weekend Service on the L Line to Handle Growing Crowds
description: The math problem of the New York City subway system is no secret, its remainders spilling onto the platforms where luckless travelers watch full trains come and go.

title: For 160 Years, Always Something New
description: At the Brooklyn Womens Exchange, a nonprofit, volunteer-run shop selling handmade wares, the atmosphere is instantly soothing. Rows of baby sweaters in Jordan almond colors hang neatly on a rack. A gangly trio of stuffed rabbits shares table space with a stack of crocheted blankets. Nat King Cole music plays softly in the background. Two volunteers murmur to each other as they sort through a pile of tiny hand-knit bootees in pastel green, lemon and pink. The scent of lavender wafts delicately from the soap display. Call it retail tonic.

title: AIDS Groups Back Anti-H.I.V. Pill Amid Concerns Doctors and Patients Will Resist
description: Despite new federal guidelines urging gay men and others to take a daily pill to prevent AIDS, the idea may prove a tough sell to many doctors and patients.

title: Movie Listings for May 16-22
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,307 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Times Seeks to Reassure Its Staff After Abramsons Ouster
description: A day after The New York Times Company announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, The Timess first female executive editor, it found itself mired in controversy, having to reassure employees and rebut reports that her removal was related to her complaints about receiving less pay than her male predecessors.

title: The Man in a Red Bandanna
description: Among the many moving moments at the dedication of the National September 11 Memorial Museum in Lower Manhattan on Thursday was a story President Obama told about the man in a red bandanna. Bewildered and frightened, the people huddled in the smoke and darkness that day on the 78th floor of the World Trade Centers south tower heard a voice, clear and calm, leading them to the stairs and to safety. Their guide was a young man holding a red handkerchief over his face.

title: Jazz Listings for May 16-22
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 16-22
description: Dear Albert Einstein

title: Comedy Listings for May 16-22
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for May 16-22
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop Music Listings for May 16-22
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for May 16-22
description: Dance Parade and Festival (Saturday) Why walk down Broadway when you can twist, pirouette and boogie down the thoroughfare with thousands of other quick-stepping souls during this annual free dance celebration? More than 150 groups, demonstrating over 75 styles of dance traditional and contemporary, will be among the professional and amateur hoofers bounding their way from 21st Street to Tompkins Square Park.
