Setting feet in motion at 1 p.m. will be a ribbon cutting by the events grand marshals, the tapper Savion Glover; Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, the artistic director of the Urban Bush Women; and the D.J. and producer Hex Hector. The fun continues in the park from 3 p.m., with performances and lessons. Participants at last years spectacle included local members of the Fraternidad Folklrica y Cultural Caporales Universitarios de San Simon, demonstrating Bolivian moves, and the NYC Bhangra Dance Company, displaying Indian styles. The event is free for individuals, but registration is required for participants. Information is at danceparade.org. Now go shine those dancing shoes. (Anne Mancuso)

title: Classical Music Listings for May 16-22
description: Argento Chamber Ensemble  (Friday and Sunday) This excellent group offers works exploring the possibilities of different instruments, with music for piano, clarinet, viola and voice by Aaron Helgeson, Aaron Einbond, David Fulmer, Berg and Sebastian Currier. Friday at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free, $10 suggested donation. (Schweitzer)

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 16-22
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: At 9/11 Museum Dedication, Remembrance and Resilience
description: In a vast underground hall beside twisted and graffiti-adorned steel remnants of New Yorks twin towers, President Obama and other dignitaries joined rescue workers and families of Sept. 11 victims Thursday to dedicate the new National September 11 Memorial Museum.

title: Force-Feedings at Guantnamo
description: Nothing comes to light easily at the Guantnamo Bay military prison in Cuba where 154 detainees are held on suspicion of terrorist activities. Some have been incarcerated for more than a decade, in a legal limbo that remains a grave embarrassment to American justice.

title: A Once-a-Day Pill to Prevent AIDS
description: Federal health officials are urging hundreds of thousands of healthy people at high risk of contracting AIDS to take a pill every day to protect themselves from the virus that causes it. The recommendation could help reduce the stubbornly high number of infections, which has held steady at 50,000 new infections a year in the United States. But the pill carries risks that must be addressed as well.

title: Detroit Bankruptcy Deadline May Be Missed, Imperiling State Funds
description: The federal judge handling Detroits bankruptcy indicated on Thursday that the current timetable for finishing the case might be unrealistic given the many disputes outstanding, raising questions about whether Detroit can exit bankruptcy before the end of its emergency managers term.

title: Japan Moves to Scale Back Postwar Restrictions on the Use of Military Power
description: PUSAN, South Korea  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may be about to take one of his biggest steps yet to nudge Japan away from its postwar pacifism after a government advisory panel recommended Thursday that constitutional restrictions on the military be eased to allow Japanese forces to come to the aid of allied nations under attack.

title: Searching for Fairness on the Internet
description: After weeks of being criticized for a proposal that would have divided the Internet into fast and slow lanes, the Federal Communications Commission put forward a new plan on Thursday. While more balanced than its earlier approach, the commission still seems to be leaning toward creating a two-tiered system that could discriminate against smaller companies and restrict consumer choice.

title: Metro-North Takes Measures on Safety
description: For years, on-time performance figures flashed across monitors inside the offices of the Metro-North Railroad  a conspicuous reminder in an agency that prided itself on punctuality.

title: Stairway to Wisdom
description: Lets say you wanted to understand a social problem in depth. Lets say you wanted to move from a dry, statistical understanding of a problem to a rich, humane one. How would you do it? What steps would you take on your climb toward understanding?

title: ReBar Owners Arrest Is No Help for Ruined Wedding Plans
description: The owner of a popular restaurant and event space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, who abruptly closed the business last week amid rumors of financial difficulties, was arrested and charged with tax fraud and grand larceny on Thursday.

title: As Jeter Is Honored, So Is His Routine
description: A year ago, Mariano Rivera was the toast of baseball, celebrated around the league for his remarkable career. In each city that he visited for the final time as a player, he would meet with stadium workers and fans in small gatherings hours before a game, and then soak up the adoration in on-field ceremonies to honor him.

title: New York City Moves to Slow Growth of Popular Green-Cab Fleet
description: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose campaign relied heavily on contributions from the yellow cab industry, signaled on Thursday that it would slow the growth of a rival taxi fleet intended to expand street-hail service outside Manhattan.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. There is an alle of trees near the Hudson in Riverside Park around 148th Street, and the trees have these little numbered discs on them. What are they for?

title: A Decision That Helped Shape Michelle Obama
description: WASHINGTON  She was born into the segregated Chicago of the 1960s, when public schools actively resisted integration. But in 1975, the city, under pressure to comply with the landmark Supreme Court decision desegregating public schools, opened a racially integrated high school for high achievers that changed the young womans life.

title: Spirituality, Poetry and Inequality
description: Captain Kidd helped build it. The organist and the organ builder once came to blows. It granted the land for what became Columbia University. Robert Fulton is buried there. Its yearly rent to the British crown was one peppercorn. It is Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, now celebrated in Trinity: Near and Far, Now and Then (Trinity Wall Street).

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 15, 2014
F.D.A. Recommends Lower Dose of the Sleeping Pill Lunesta
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration announced Thursday that people prescribed the sleeping pill Lunesta should be starting with half the current recommended dose, part of the agencys continuing effort to reduce sleep aids risky side effects, such as drowsiness while driving.

title: Mideast Peace Effort Pauses to Let Failure Sink In
description: WASHINGTON  On May 2, a week after peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians fell apart, senior American diplomats gave an interview to a prominent Israeli journalist in which they said Israels aggressive pursuit of new Jewish settlements had sabotaged the negotiations.

title: Barbara Walterss Biggest Moments
description: A look back at the memorable interviews that Barbara Walters has done over her 50 years in television.

title: Ex-N.F.L. Star Who Spoke Out for Women Is Accused of Being a Rapist
description: Darren Sharper, a former N.F.L. standout who won a Super Bowl with the New Orleans Saints, posed with his teenage daughter, his deep dimples framing his wide, bright white smile, her head leaning on his shoulder.

title: In Colombia, an Election May Turn on a Dirty War
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  With the future of peace talks with Marxist rebels on the line, the presidential election in Colombia has suddenly turned nasty, with the main candidates and their backers leveling damning charges of payoffs from drug traffickers, illegal surveillance and even attempted murder.

title: Indiana Seeks More Coverage for Poor, but Many Would Pay
description: WASHINGTON  The governor of Indiana, Mike Pence, on Thursday proposed using federal Medicaid funds available under the Affordable Care Act to expand a state health insurance program to cover an additional 350,000 low-income adults. But unlike traditional Medicaid, the plan would require many participants to make monthly contributions toward the cost of coverage.

title: Mary Stewart, British Writer Who Spanned Genres, Dies at 97
description: Mary Stewart, the British author of romantic thrillers who jumped genres in her 50s to create an internationally best-selling trilogy of Merlin books, reimagining the Arthurian legend from a sorcerers point of view, died on May 9 at her home in the village of Loch Awe, on the west coast of Scotland. She was 97.

title: M.L.B. Panel Beginning Search for Seligs Successor
description: The announcement Thursday that Major League Baseball has created a succession committee is the latest sign that Commissioner Bud Selig might truly retire next January.

title: Nancy Malone, Actress and TV Director, Dies at 79
description: Nancy Malone, a child model in the 1940s who became a successful actress as an adult before moving to the other side of the camera as a television producer and director at a time when few women in Hollywood held those positions, died on May 8 in Duarte, Calif. She was 79.

title: What's Next for Net Neutrality?
Lundqvist Will Revisit a Weak Spot
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  There is one place where Henrik Lundqvist is not King, and that is Montreal, where the Rangers will open the Eastern Conference finals on Saturday afternoon.

title: Charges at the Door
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  The way this solve went for me was: Top, then bottom, and I wound up saving the middle for last. Im glad I did.

title: Shinseki Speaks After Testifying
description: Secretary of Veterans Affairs Eric Shinseki spoke to reporters after a hearing on Capitol Hill.

title: On Spains Galician Coast, the Hard Life of Barnacle Hunting
description: Poachers and dangerous conditions make it hard for those trained and licensed to collect the expensive treat.

title: Scraping for Sea Delicacy, and a Meager Living
description: A CORUA, Spain  Roberto Mahia, 44, was leaning against his car waiting for the sun to rise before pulling on the frayed wet suit at his feet when two vehicles pulled up not far away.

title: Possible Deal May Bring Money to Repair Pier 40 in Manhattan
description: For years, Hudson River Park officials have tried to generate funds to repair Pier 40, the dilapidated former cargo terminal at the foot of West Houston Street, by proposing an odd succession of projects on the pier: a professional soccer stadium, a $600 million entertainment complex and residential towers.

title: Facing Roster Questions, Nets Enter Off-Season With a Focus on Continuity
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Now that the business of playing basketball games is over, the Nets will tackle a rapidly growing off-season to-do list.

title: Beltran Put on D.L. With Elbow Injury
description: Hoping to avoid a surgical procedure that could sideline him for two months, Yankees right fielder Carlos Beltran began taking cortisone orally on Thursday to augment the cortisone injection he received in his right elbow Monday.

title: Live-Blogging the Vote Count in India
description: Over five weeks and nine phases, 550 million votes were cast in the massive Indian parliamentary elections that will usher in a new government. On Friday, India Ink followed the vote count with regular updates.

title: Runoff Near, Debate Shifts to a New Set of Issues
description: During the five-way race in the Republican primary to represent a 12-county Hill Country district in the Texas House, two candidates, Rob Henneke and Andrew Murr, largely focused on the states water policy and ensuring local control of decisions on education and infrastructure.

title: Sterling Tells N.B.A. He Will Not Pay Fine
description: Donald Sterling, the embattled owner of the Los Angeles Clippers who expressed contrition this week for making racist comments, does not plan to go away quietly.

title: Brazil: Troops Deployed to Restore Calm
description: Federal officials on Thursday sent troops to Pernambuco State in northeast Brazil as reports of looting heightened fears that crime could surge during a strike by police officers. Seeking to calm residents, the unspecified number of troops began patrolling cities, including Recife, one of the hosts of the World Cup soccer tournament in June. The police strike in Pernambuco is part of a broader wave of strikes and protests in several large cities around Brazil this month as labor unions representing teachers, bus drivers and street cleaners seek wage increases. Police unions across the country said they were considering a one-day strike next week. Separately, protests against Brazils spending on World Cup stadiums drew thousands into the streets on Thursday in So Paulo and other cities.

title: Iran: Oil Exports Continue to Decline
description: Irans oil exports declined in April for the second consecutive month, the International Energy Agency reported Thursday, moving much closer to levels permitted under a temporary accord on the Iranian nuclear dispute that is set to expire in July. Monthly data compiled by the energy agency, a 29-member group of oil importers, showed that Irans exports were 1.11 million barrels a day in April, down from 1.29 million barrels a day in March and 1.58 million barrels a day in February. The temporary accord specified that Irans monthly oil exports are not to exceed one million barrels a day on average for the six-month duration, and the excesses raised concern among critics of the accord that Iran was violating its terms. Obama administration officials have said they believe that Irans May, June and July exports will be lower. Under the accord, some Western economic sanctions were eased in exchange for a freeze on most of Irans nuclear activities, for the purpose of giving negotiators more time to reach a permanent agreement. Negotiators for the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council plus Germany are seeking guarantees that Irans nuclear fuel cannot be used to make bombs.

title: Afghanistan: U.S. Repatriates Pakistanis
description: The American military has repatriated 10 Pakistani prisoners whom it had held at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan. The transfer of the detainees to Pakistani custody was announced by the Justice Project Pakistan, which represents Pakistani detainees at Bagram. It said the International Committee of the Red Cross had told the mens families about the move. An American official familiar with the matter confirmed Thursday that the transfers had taken place. The military has already transferred to Afghan control the bulk of Afghan prisoners at Bagram but has retained custody of third country nationals, whom the Afghan government does not want to deal with. The transfers reduce the number of those prisoners to 39, according to the official. More than two dozen of them are Pakistani. Some of those just released will be detained in Pakistan, while others will be released but subject to monitoring, the official said.

title: In Rookie Duel, a Met Gets a Loss, and a Hit
description: The first 39 games of the baseball season had already taken their toll on the Yankees and the Mets, and the first three games of the Subway Series had been emotional, exhausting affairs. The Mets had battered the Yankees at Yankee Stadium, and Masahiro Tanaka had stifled the Mets at Citi Field. Everyone seemed a bit woozy.

title: Events on Long Island for May 18-24, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 16, 2014
description: Why dont we have better medical facilities, educational facilities, roads? Why? Who is answerable for this?

title: Pinterest Raises More Money, Fetching a Valuation of $5 Billion
description: The business of online scrapbooking is getting more valuable  at least in the eyes of investors.

title: On the Fourth Night of Contemporary Art Auctions, Rising Stars Go on the Block
description: After three consecutive nights of contemporary art auctions, the die-hards turned out for a fourth and final helping, which took place at Phillips, the smaller, third-place auction house.

title: Rangers Cam Talbot Has Experience Against Canadiens
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Cam Talbot grew up a Montreal Canadiens fan, watching every move of his idol, Patrick Roy. As a backup to Henrik Lundqvist this season, he has relished a front-row seat to goaltending greatness.

title: Tale of School Integration Wins Childrens History Book Prize
description: Kristin Levines Lions of Little Rock, the story of a black girl and a white girl who become friends during the integration of that citys schools in 1958, has been awarded the New-York Historical Societys first childrens history book prize.

title: Tracking Down the Deer Runner
description: Perhaps the biggest new idea in exercise research in recent years has been the endurance running hypothesis, the idea that as humans evolved, adaptations in our bones and muscles, along with an impressive ability to regulate our body temperature, made us good endurance runners. As a result, our ancestors were able to literally run down and kill game animals, providing the high-density calories and protein we needed to feed our ever-enlarging brains.

title: Times Minute | A Peek at the Preakness
description: The Timess Joe Drape with a preview of Saturdays second leg of horse racings Triple Crown, the Preakness Stakes.

title: Word of the Day | affidavit
description: affidavit\a-f-da-vt\ noun

title: Phil Jacksons Focus: His Inner Circle and the Triangle
description: In trying to decipher where Phil Jackson goes from here, it may be useful to take a look back.

title: Times Minute | A Peek at the Preakness
description: In the Video

title: A Ton of Cash Reported in Officials Home
description: The tempo of corruption investigations in China is so rapid that the cases begin to blur. Pick up a paper and there will be a photo of an official in his better days, a list of alleged misdeeds and a tally of corrupt cash.

title: Trading Danger for Delicacy
description: On Spains Galician coast, generations of licensed divers scrape gooseneck barnacles in roiling surf to serve eager gourmands who pay up to 100 euros a kilo for the cherished crustaceans.

title: Narendra Modis Ambitious Agenda Will Face Difficult Obstacles
description: NEW DELHI  Addressing a euphoric crowd Friday afternoon, Narendra Modi rallied the public to join him in taking on challenges of a vast scale. He has floated the idea of building a hundred new cities, of extending a high-speed rail network across the subcontinent and undertaking the herculean task of cleaning the Ganges River.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) CAPTAIN PHILLIPS (2013) Tom Hanks, above, portrays Richard Phillips, the commander of the Maersk Alabama, an American container ship with a crew of 20 sailors and a cargo including supplies from the United Nations World Food Program, that was seized in the Indian Ocean in April 2009 by four armed Somalis. Barkhad Abdi, a first-time actor who received an Oscar nomination, plays Muse, their leader, whose actions lead to the arrival of the American military and its warships. The existential realities that inform contemporary Somali piracy turn out to be one of the unexpected themes of Captain Phillips, which begins as something of a procedural about men at work and morphs into a jittery thriller even as it also deepens, brilliantly, unexpectedly, into an unsettling look at global capitalism and American privilege and power, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture nominee, adapted by the director Paul Greengrass from Mr. Phillipss book, A Captains Duty: Somali Pirates, Navy SEALS, and Dangerous Days at Sea. Phillips is unambiguously a heroic figure, but hes scarcely the sole point of interest in a movie that steadily and almost stealthily asserts the agonized humanity of his captors.

title: Corrections: May 16, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 16, 2014
description: Use the following question to test your ability to place commas correctly.

title: Europes Auto Market Continues to Recover at Slow Pace
description: PARIS  The European car market expanded in April for the eighth straight month, industry data showed on Friday, continuing its climb from the depths it reached last year.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Burials, Rage and Political Fallout in the Turkey Mine Disaster
description: In Burials, Rage and Political Fallout in Turkey Mine Disaster, Kareem Fahim, Sebnem Arsu and Alan Cowell report on a mining disaster in Turkey.

title: One Day, One China, 2 Foreign Policy Views
description: China is embroiled in intense territorial spats with Vietnam and the Philippines over competing claims in the South China Sea, and tensions continue to simmer between China and Japan over disputed islands in the East China Sea. Against that backdrop, on Thursday two top Chinese officials, President Xi Jinping and the militarys chief of staff, Gen. Fang Fenghui, presented starkly different views of their countrys foreign policy.

title: Numericable in Talks to Buy Virgin Mobile France
description: Updated, 12:30 p.m. |

title: What Rules Would You Like to See Changed in Your Favorite Sports?
description: Golf holes the size of pizzas? Bigger courts and four-point shots in basketball? Two-hand touch instead of tackle football? Tradition and history play an important role in sports, but like anything else, games evolve to keep up with changing times.

title: Latin Americas Mutating Cities, in Photographs
description: Evaporados  evaporated  is pasted in huge letters on an expressway wall in Lima, Peru. The artist Eduardo Villanes put them there in 1995, to protest the abduction and murder of nine university students and a professor by a military death squad, as well as the subsequent amnesty granted to the killers by Alberto Fujimori, Perus repressive and corrupt president.

title: Publics Outrage Over Mine Disaster Casts Harsh Light on Turkeys Premier
description: SOMA, Turkey  There was no one to treat in the first aid tents near the entrance to the mine, where an old woman nearby wailed, Our children are burning! A man and his wife, dazed from a lack of sleep, walked the muddy grounds near here, looking for information about their missing son that no one in the government could provide.

title: New York Today: Stalking the Urban Wildflower
description: Good morning on this damp Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Democrats Have Advantage on Issues, but It Wont Save Them in November
description: Democrats know they face a difficult midterm campaign landscape, but they can cling to one seeming reason for hope: The public agrees with them more than with Republicans on the issues.

title: Where Are the Gay Chief Executives?
U.N. Finds Rising Human Rights Violations in Ukraine
description: GENEVA  Armed groups are increasingly undermining the rights and basic freedoms of people in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations said Friday, expressing concern at the rising number of killings, abductions, beatings and detentions of journalists, politicians and local activists.

title: Daily Report: F.C.C. Advances Plan for Net Neutrality Rules
description: Federal regulators appear to share one view about so-called net neutrality: It is a good thing, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Betting That Quality Wont Feel Old
description: The story behind the cover of this weeks Book Review began almost exactly a month ago, which is actually on the late side when it comes to determining Book Review covers. Because we close our subscriber issues 10 days before they hit newsstands, we often plan our covers months in advance. Given that we are covering books, which generally have a set publishing date, the news in the book world is known well in advance. This gives us the luxury of time in planning what we think will be the most powerful and compelling cover for each issue.

title: Psst. Look Over Here.
description: Look inside your kitchen cabinet and odds are you have a collection of old friends gazing back at you  the Quaker Oats man, the Sun-Maid girl, Aunt Jemima and maybe a Keebler elf or two. The reason they are there may have more do with your subconscious craving for eye contact than the taste of the products.

title: Big Breaks for Banks
description: BIG BREAKS FOR BANKS | If, as expected, two banking giants  Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas  plead guilty to criminal charges in the next few weeks, they will probably pay large fines and officially be felons, Floyd Norris writes in the High & Low Finance column. But, he asks, does it matter that these will be criminal, not civil, punishments? The issue is not that banks may be too big to jail, but that, big or small, banks and other corporations are too inanimate to jail, Mr. Norris writes.

title: European Court Lets People Influence Web Search Results
description: The European Court of Justice ruled that Google search results should comply with individuals right to be forgotten.

title: Clippers Cant Believe Their Surreal Season Has Ended
description: LOS ANGELES  One by one, the boulders had been stacked upon their shoulders in recent weeks. If it was not listening to the racist rant by their owner, Donald Sterling, it was wondering what to do about it  were black socks enough? Then there were the camera crews from CNN and TMZ at their practices.

title: Actress, Artist, Sometimes Both at Once
description: In the new romantic comedy Words and Pictures, a rolling office chair becomes a tool for art creation. Juliette Binoche, playing an art teacher whose rheumatoid arthritis affects her ability to paint, lies on her stomach across the chair, grabs a paintbrush and swivels from one part to another of the canvas on the floor. Passion and pain become a part of each stroke, as Ms. Binoche both plays a visual artist and is one.

title: Amazon vs. Hachette: When Does Discouragement Become Misrepresentation?
description: For months now, Amazon has been trying to put the screws on Hachette, the smallest of the Big Five publishers, by discouraging people from buying its printed books. Amazons goal: force Hachette to give it better terms on e-books.

title: Nigerian Leader Cancels Visit to Village of Abducted Girls
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  A first visit by President Goodluck Jonathan to the village from which nearly 300 girls were abducted by Boko Haram was abruptly canceled on Friday because of security fears, according to an official in the presidents entourage.

title: Inside Kelly Wearstlers Studio
description: The designer offers a tour of her Los Angeles studio, where she and her team dream up and bring to life everything in her eponymous line, from home wares to womens accessories.

title: Uighur Biker Takes Message of Peace on the Road
description: Dolkun Tunurganjan, 31, a Uighur from the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, is on a mission to promote ethnic harmony.

title: Darden to Sell Red Lobster in a $2.1 Billion Deal
description: Updated, 8:19 p.m. | Investors argued publicly for months against Darden Restaurants plans to spin off Red Lobster, the 46-year-old seafood chain that was the root of the companys dining empire.

title: Ejected From the Doughnut Shop
description: Dear Diary:

title: Made in L.A. | Step Inside Kelly Wearstlers Sprawling Studio
description: The key to success is organization, says Kelly Wearstler. In this video, the designer offers a tour of her Los Angeles studio, where she and her team dream up and bring to life everything in her eponymous line, from home wares to womens accessories. Having everything created in one place, she explains, encourages the kind of cross-pollination of ideas and inspiration that makes everything in her label, from bangles and scarves to napkins and side tables, feel laid-back yet luxurious  much like the designer herself.

title: Abbott to Buy Latin American Drug Company for $2.9 Billion
description: Abbott Laboratories has agreed to buy a Chilean drug company for $2.9 billion, continuing a streak of major transactions in the health care sector this year.

title: Chesapeake Energy to Spin Off Oil Services Unit
description: Chesapeake Energy said on Friday that it would shed of its oilfield services business as the company works to streamline itself.

title: Ukraines Heart of Steel
description: In Mariupol, Ukraine, thousands of steelworkers patrol city streets, routing out pro-Russian militants who seized control several weeks ago.

title: For Democrats, Texas Push Gets an Early Shove
description: SAN ANTONIO  The instructions seemed simple enough: Knock on your neighbors doors and tell them to vote for Wendy Davis in Texas election for governor.

title: Unrest Poses a Risky Choice for Vietnam
description: HA TINH PROVINCE, Vietnam  The hundreds of men on motorbikes who roared into Lee Hsueh Yings factory compound north of Ho Chi Minh City were bent on revenge against China. Some clung to red-and-gold Vietnamese flags while they careened around overwhelmed security guards. And in a scene repeated elsewhere in the countrys industrial heartland, they destroyed the building, smashing furniture, snatching computers and shouting Long Live Vietnam.

title: Housing Is Recovering. Single-Family Homes Arent.
description: The headlines in the new report on home building activity  which is being closely watched, after many other kinds of data point to a softening in housing  are pretty terrific.

title: Explosions Kill 10 in Kenya as Western Embassies Warn of Threats
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Twin explosions hit a market area in downtown Nairobi on Friday afternoon, killing 10 people and injuring 76 others, officials said, adding to a series of deadly attacks in the country in recent months.

title: Garage Rocks Latest Nerve Center
description: FULLERTON, Calif.  Eleven a.m. on a Tuesday: time for business to begin at Burger Records, if it ever really ends. The nerve center of fourth-wave garage rock  a record label and a store  is in a small, square space, slotted along with a vaping emporium and a tattoo parlor in a strip mall along a four-lane artery, near industrial parks, a food-service-equipment manufacturing plant and the Anaheim town line. Its Orange County industrial suburbia, where most of what is visible  parking lots, buildings, grass allotments, signage, Dumpsters  has been city-planned into rectangles.

title: Whats Next, a Bouncer?
description: When a playroom opened in Michael Reillys Upper West Side building two years ago, he asked the concierge for a key to the space so his toddler could play there. The concierges answer stunned him: It was out of bounds to him and his child.

title: In Our Pages: May 17
description: 1889: Pensions Attacked

title: A History of New York Traffic Lights
description: Tired of cars  and bikes  running red lights? How about no lights at all? Thats the kind of traffic system New York had until 1920, when a series of tall bare-bones towers went up down the middle of Fifth Avenue, flashing red and green lights to the growing onslaught of automobiles. Two years later they were replaced with formidably elegant bronze and granite towers, sumptuous contributions to the City Beautiful, but destroyed within a decade, victims of increasing traffic.

title: On Mackinac Island, a Celebration of Lilacs
description: To celebrate its ubiquitous and most fragrant summer blooms, Mackinac Island, Mich., will hold the 65th annual Lilac Festival from June 6 to 15.

title: Consumer Debt Suggests Growing Confidence
description: CONSUMERS appear to be growing more confident and are less likely to be behind on their bills, according to figures released this week by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: TV Critics Buddy Up for New Book
description: Whether its Felix and Oscar, Bert and Ernie, Cagney and Lacey or Simon and Simon, television has consistently provided a home for memorable duos. Now a pair of veteran television critics are partnering up to write a book that will examine various series while chronicling the six-decade history of the medium. Alan Sepinwall, of HitFix.com, and Matt Zoller Seitz, of New York magazine and Vulture.com, will collaborate on a book of essays for Grand Central Publishing about the most artistically and culturally significant American dramas, comedies, mini-series, variety shows and more, including hits like Seinfeld and The Sopranos, as well as cult favorites like Freaks and Geeks and My So-Called Life, the publisher said in an email.

title: Upstate, and Back in Time
description: I followed the man off the river and into a labyrinth of creeks behind town, heading deeper into a thickening haze of marsh grass and listing trees. He paddled ahead in his green canoe while I trailed in my rowboat, picking my way around old dredging pipes and doubting that Id find my way back out of this fractal backwater. Through the trees, worlds emerged: a tiny island of R.V.s, a string of vacation cottages, a far bank of empty-eyed concrete houses.

title: Professor Simpson
description: Homer explains economics; Adam Silver vs. Silver Surfer.

title: Scott Aukerman Goes Off-Script
description: The host of Comedy Bang! Bang! talks to Willy Staley about the virtues of improvisation, his fellow podcaster Marc Maron and the drudgery of Disneyland.

title: Reply All: The 5.4.14 Issue
description: THE TALE OF TWO SCHOOLS

title: Jane Kleeb vs. the Keystone Pipeline
description: Terry Van Housen had a question. What he wanted to know from the 30 or so other Nebraska farmers and ranchers gathered in February at the York Community Center was this: What do you do with 10,000 dead cows?

title: Jack-and-Ginger, All Grown Up
description: I know Im not the only one whose first mixed drink was a whiskey-ginger highball. For many, the go-to will always be Jack Daniels and ginger ale  the pleasingly alliterative Jack and ginger  which is a snap to make and still delicious after all these years.

title: Who Made That Earbud?
description: In Fahrenheit 451, Ray Bradbury described a futuristic radio that could be worn inside the ear. It would be a hidden wasp snug in its special pink warm nest, he wrote, and the conduit for an electronic ocean of sound, of music and talk and music and talk, coming in on the shore of [your] unsleeping mind. That was more than 50 years ago, but its not a bad description of iPod headphones.

title: Ivy League Degrees, Elite Consulting Jobs, and Now Tea Party Candidacies
description: WASHINGTON  Ben Sasse and Tom Cotton have a lot in common: Republican candidacies for the Senate, Ivy League advanced degrees  a Yale Ph.D. for Mr. Sasse, a Harvard law degree for Mr. Cotton  and a tour of duty in the white-shoe world of management consulting.

title: Short-Seller Chanos Turns Attention to Valeant
description: Updated, 11:41 a.m. |

title: G.M. Is Fined Over Safety and Called a Lawbreaker
description: WASHINGTON  Saying that safety practices at General Motors were broken, federal regulators on Friday imposed the biggest punishment they could on the automaker and condemned it over its failure to promptly report a defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.

title: Skills and Strategies | Photo Projects Inspired by Humans of New York
description: Do your students follow Humans of New York?

title: Babe Ruth, Knocked Out
description: On a sunny July day in Washington, 90 years ago this July, the Yankees were in Griffith Stadium, playing a doubleheader against the Senators. In the fourth inning of the first game, before 24,000 fans, the home teams Joe Judge swung his bat; the ball sailed just over the right-field line, heading toward the bleachers in foul territory.

title: Opera Philadelphia Names Little as Composer in Residence
description: Opera Philadelphia, in a collaboration with Gotham Chamber Opera and the Music-Theater Group, in New York, has appointed the David T. Little as a composer in residence, a three-year position that begins on June 1. The program, which was started in 2011, includes a stipend and health benefits, and involves work with all three companies.

title: Baghdad Is a Setting, and a Character, Too
description: BAGHDAD  ON an evening just a few days before his novel would win a top Arabic literary prize, Ahmed Saadawi was relaxing with his writer friends at a Baghdad cafe, a place so special to him that he had written it into his book.

title: Chinese Developers Step Up
description: China-based businesses and investors have been buying into New York City condominiums, hotels and office towers for years, but more recently, these firms have stepped up to take the lead on several major city developments.

title: Ransom Center Pays $2 Million for Ian McEwan Papers
description: The British novelist Ian McEwan has become the latest top-tier contemporary writer to have G.T.T.  or Gone to Texas, as an abbreviation in the rare book trade calls it.

title: Always Hungry? Heres Why
description: FOR most of the last century, our understanding of the cause of obesity has been based on immutable physical law. Specifically, its the first law of thermodynamics, which dictates that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. When it comes to body weight, this means that calorie intake minus calorie expenditure equals calories stored. Surrounded by tempting foods, we overeat, consuming more calories than we can burn off, and the excess is deposited as fat. The simple solution is to exert willpower and eat less.

title: Itinerary | Cartagenas Burgeoning Style Scene
description: The sultry city of Cartagena has for some time been a weekend destination for wealthy Colombians and in-the-know international globetrotters. They come to stroll the cobblestone streets lined with faded colonial homes, dance and drink rum at the always bustling Club Havana, and then sleep off their hangovers on the postcard-perfect beaches on the nearby islands. Recently, though, Cartagena has seen an influx of more stylish restaurants, shops and hotels (the Ritz Carlton and Four Seasons are coming soon), which can make the city worthy of a longer stay. And with a new, direct JetBlue flight available from New York, its more convenient than ever.

title: Movie Review: Godzilla
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Godzilla.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 16
description: Subjects include the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the newly elected mayor of Newark, and a World War II plane embarking on a new mission.

title: Deal for Zales May Be Done In by Bank of Americas Conflicts
description: Signets $1.4 billion acquisition of the Zale Corporation looks increasingly beleaguered in the wake of opposition by the investment group TIG Advisors, Zales second-largest shareholder.

title: East Hampton: Secluded Showplace, $21.5 Million
description: A shingle-style house on 3.2 meticulously groomed acres just a short stroll from the pristine surf at Two Mile Hollow Beach in East Hampton Village is poised to enter the market at $21.5 million. Camouflaged by a berm with mature plantings, the two-story house sits on a bluff and is invisible from the road; its rooftop deck, dominated by a whimsical oversize cedar bench nicknamed the Giant Lifeguards Chair, has captivating views of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: One Daughter, One Mother, Two Wheelchairs and Nothing Remarkable
description: While exchanging pleasantries with a woman selling peanut brittle at an open-air market on Mothers Day, my mom and I were told that were really adorable.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bending Adversity
description: This week, David Pilling discusses Bending Adversity: Japan and the Art of Survival; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; John Schwartz talks about the audiobooks of four new celebrity memoirs; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: In the White House, Debating How Far to Go in Easing Deportations
description: WASHINGTON  At a recent White House meeting with immigration activists, President Obama told the group his hands were tied. Even if he wanted to halt the deportations of millions of illegal immigrants, the president told the group, he could not do so without congressional approval.

title: G.M. Consent Order Over Ignition Defect
description: Federal regulators announced that General Motors would pay $35 million in a civil settlement with the federal government over its failure to report in a timely manner a defective ignition switch in 2.6 million cars.

title: Faith-based Freaks
description: Noah Smith isnt very happy with Steve Levitt, who thinks he was being smart by telling David Cameron that he should scrap the NHS and let the magic of the marketplace deal with health care. Strangely, Cameron wasnt impressed.

title: The Bad Nurse
description: There are days I am not the woman I would like to be and when I am very lucky, they coincide with a new episode of Nurse Jackie.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bending Adversity
description: This week, David Pilling and John Schwartz.

title: Movie Review: Million Dollar Arm
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Million Dollar Arm.

title: Top Horse, From a Place Winners Arent Made
description: COALINGA, Calif.  There is no bluegrass here or limestone fences framing postcard-ready landscapes. A drought has drained the San Joaquin Valley of any color other than beige. There is no mistaking the smell in the air, either: It is cow manure from the feedlot of Californias largest beef producer.

title: Rising Sun
description: Three years ago this March, a 9-magnitude earthquake, the strongest ever known to hit Japan, created a tsunami that killed more than 15,000 people outright, displaced hundreds of thousands more and removed entire villages from the map. By triggering the failure of the Fukushima nuclear plant, it also left the landscape contaminated and led to Japans curtailing of its nuclear-power system.

title: An Incumbent Falls Afoul of Election Laws Designed to Protect Incumbents
description: Political pros know better than anyone that election laws are typically crafted by statehouse lawmakers with enough hedges, hurdles and moats to insulate party machines and shield incumbents against insurgent challengers. Thats the nature of the power game.

title: Venerable Poetry and a Premiere
description: Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, will make his New York Philharmonic debut on Wednesday, conducting two colorful works. The excellent young violinist Janine Jansen will be the soloist in Szymanowskis shimmering and sumptuous Violin Concerto No. 1, inspired by Tadeusz Micinskis poem May Night. Also on the lineup are selections from Prokofievs ballet Cinderella. (7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 2 p.m. Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

title: Prime-Time Slice of Baloney!
description: Fess up: who hasnt gawked in awe as Judge Judith Sheindlin slaps sense into a freak show of neer-do-wells with rejoinders we only wish we had queued up: Are you trying to justify to me that you are an idiot? Dont try to teach a pig to sing. It doesnt work, and it irritates the pig. Beauty fades. Dumb is forever.

title: A Polish Town, Before Its Infamy
description: Most people associate Auschwitz with the death camp. But it is also a town, Oswiecim, once home to a vibrant Jewish community in Poland. Now, the Museum of Jewish Heritage  A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in Lower Manhattan is examining that history in A Town Known as Auschwitz: The Life and Death of a Jewish Community, which explores how Jews and non-Jews coexisted peacefully in Oswiecim (Auschwitz was its German name) for centuries before World War II.

title: Dance Music, With a Warning
description: Last August, two deaths from drug overdoses at the annual Electric Zoo dance-music festival on Randalls Island caused the cancellation of the events final day, a reminder of the difficulty of adequately overseeing these sprawling, loosely supervised events. Next Saturday and Sunday, the New York incarnation of the Electric Daisy Carnival, the signature brand in American dance music festivals, takes over MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and will face the challenge of keeping tens of thousands of revelers safe. The music will take care of itself: The lineup includes pop-minded D.J.-producers like Calvin Harris and Afrojack; Steve Angello, one-third of the disbanded arena-house champs known as the Swedish House Mafia; the Chicago house legend Green Velvet; the pop aspirants Krewella; the teenage phenom Martin Garrix; and the French abrasionist DJ Snake. The festivals website warns of zero tolerance for drug use or possession. Fingers crossed. (201-559-1515, electricdaisycarnival.com/newyork.)

title: Long-Form Narratives, Without Words
description: We may be witnessing one sea change or several in full-length dance-theater productions. In the last 12 months, three of the worlds leading choreographers  Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky, Christopher Wheeldon  have staged new, important, mold-breaking, all-evening works. All three are flawed. But so are the ballets of Swan Lake and Romeo and Juliet (no matter which version you watch). The full-length Swan Lake took over 70 years before it became a mainstay of the international repertory. At what point does a new production turn into a hit, a war horse or a classic?

title: Temptress Returns to Tweak His Cowl
description: Hey, fanboys, before the superhero glut implodes, toast those who set the 1990s standard: the crew behind Batman: The Animated Series (and its spinoffs Superman and Justice League), in various TV incarnations from 1992 to 1999. Call it the Bruce W. Timm brain trust, after its producer and character designer; members included the writer Paul Dini and the voice director Andrea Romano. (And salute its writer Dwayne McDuffie, who died in 2011, and its composer Shirley Walker, who died in 2006.)

title: Trolling the Past for Fresh Insights
description: The latest round of Danspace Projects Platform series, which explores dance through the lens of a particular idea or theme, is dedicated to the work of the choreographer DD Dorvillier, who helped define contemporary dance beginning in the 1990s. For more than a decade Ms. Dorvillier lived and worked out of the Matzoh Factory, a loft she shared with the dancer and choreographer Jennifer Monson in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Stealth Lessons Sneak Up on Viewers
description: A tornado slams into Washington with winds exceeding 260 miles per hour. It topples the five-ton bronze statue at the Jefferson Memorial. It churns the roof of the Lincoln Memorial into a Cuisinart of broken glass and tile. It swiss-cheeses the Washington Monument. What will become of the Capitol? The dome, one expert predicts, is toast.

title: His Music, Entwined With His Faith
description: Religion guides all the processes in our lives, without us even knowing it, the Estonian composer Arvo Prt said in a recent phone interview. It is true that religion has a very important role in my composition, but how it really works, I am not able to describe.

title: Movie Review: The Immigrant
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Immigrant.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Poetry Profiles: Wave Books
description: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Joshua Beckman, editor at Wave Books, and Matthew Zapruder, Waves editor at large.

title: Checking In on Burger Records
description: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Burger Records, the label, store and cultural phenomenon.

title: Tom Colicchio, Citizen Chef
description: On a recent afternoon, the chef Tom Colicchio was sitting with his staff in his office, on East 19th Street in Manhattan, hashing out the details of the high-end hotel restaurant he plans to open this winter in Miami. What would he name the lobby bar? Would he serve small plates to bathers at the pool?

title: Big Ticket | An Aerie With Park Views for $30.5 Million
description: One57, the Extell Development Companys robust 90-story blue glass tower and billionaire magnet, already dominates the Midtown skyline, and in recent weeks has monopolized the citys closed residential sales: Yet another of its 4,483-square-foot A-line units sold in excess of $30 million, and it was the most expensive sale of week, according to city records.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SAVAGE WARS OF PEACE: Small Wars and the Rise of American Power,  by Max Boot. (Basic Books, $19.99.) Beginning with Thomas Jeffersons expedition against the Barbary pirates, Boot, the author of Invisible Armies, traces Americas long history of bloody military operations in the name of nation-building and peacekeeping  in the Philippines, Haiti, Cuba and elsewhere. This revised edition includes a discussion of Iraq, Afghanistan and the lessons of the post-9/11 world.

title: Today in Small Business: Lets Take This Offline
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: In Brooklyn, Union Avenue Gets Built Up
description: Once a desolate strip hugged by slightly forbidding warehouses, factories and garages, Union Avenue just north of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway has seen a significant transformation in recent years into the sort of glass-lined thoroughfare more typically found in trendier parts of Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Editors Choice
description: BOMBAY STORIES,  by Saadat Hasan Manto. Translated by Matt Reeck and Aftab Ahmad. (Vintage International, paper, $16.) Manto wrote most of these stories out of a longing for his old city, having moved to Pakistan after partition in 1947.

title: Inside the List
description: Something Different: Fans of long-running series can have a hard time letting go. When Arthur Conan Doyle tried to kill off Sherlock Holmes in 1893, readers objected so strenuously that Doyle  after trying to mollify them with a prequel  finally gave in and resurrected the character as a cross-dressing mixed martial artist played by Robert Downey Jr. More recently, Charlaine Harris has heard from readers livid at her 2013 novel Dead Ever After, which ended her beloved Sookie Stackhouse urban fantasy series (the basis for the HBO show True Blood). I had death threats, and people putting curses on me, she said in a recent phone conversation. All the usual stuff. But Sookie is well and truly finished, Harris insists: Shes in my rearview mirror. It was not a hard choice. Of course, its a little scary when youre making such and such dollars a year because of a character. But when Ive told the story I had to tell, its time to start something different.

title: The Preakness Dartboard
description: The horses for Saturdays 139th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses. The morning-line odds were set by Keith Feustle of Pimlico Race Course.

title: Cell Lit
description: This week, David Cole reviews Robert A. Fergusons Inferno: An Anatomy of American Punishment, about what Cole calls our proclivity for incarceration. The most enduring literary evocations of imprisonment have been written by those with firsthand experience; books like Aleksandr Solzhenitsyns One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich and Dostoyevskys The House of the Dead.

title: One Step at a Time
description: First, a confession: Words like liminal or luminous in a novels blurbs or flap copy work for me like flashing hazard lights. Generally, I set the book back down on the new releases table and reach for something else. Experience has taught me that novels so described favor style over story, and Im an old-school reader who values well-wrought plot and highly developed character more than exquisite voice and stylistic gymnastics.

title: Digging Out
description: I have a friend, the mother of twin boys, who recently confessed that the only way she had survived those early parenting years was by pretending she was someone else: a long-distance athlete in training, say, while jogging behind a double stroller before work; or a sexy, spaced-out au pair at the playground diddling on her iPhone during lengthy afternoons; or a bearded Bushwick mixologist whenever the clock struck 5. Any of these roles felt more endurable than her own.

title: Scandalous Women
description: The publication of Gustave Flauberts Madame Bovary in 1857 and of mile Zolas Thrse Raquin 10 years later roused the French literary establishment against two previously unknown authors who had gone beyond the bounds of all that was held to be morally admissible in fiction with their portraits of adulterous women starved by marriage of sex and romance. The state prosecuted Flaubert for gross indecency, despite the terrible punishment he metes out to his wayward heroine. Zola was not subjected to the same ordeal, but critics treated him as a rogue purveying smut in the name of realism. Both novels have appeared in countless editions since the 19th century. Both have been adapted to the screen. Now they are available as audiobooks, read by two gifted English actresses: Madame Bovary by Juliet Stevenson and Thrse Raquin by Kate Winslet.

title: Talk of the Town
description: It would be hard to think of two writers less alike  stylistically and, for that matter, personally  than Truman Capote and John OHara, yet they shared many preoccupations. Both were fascinated by society high and low, by how people climbed or toppled from one rank to the other, and by how sex and money underpinned the entire system. Breakfast at Tiffanys, Capotes charming 1958 novella about a self-invented cafe society girl and the admiring writer who lives upstairs, is set during World War II. Most of the stories assembled in the recent Penguin anthology of OHaras New York stories were written in either the 30s or the 60s, but some are set decades earlier. And yet in the newly released audio recordings of the two books, maybe even more than on the page, the versions of New York that are evoked seem virtually interchangeable: Its a city of people on the make or else clinging to their former reputations, where everyone drinks too much, and where you can easily wake up in bed next to someone you barely remember meeting.

title: Acting the Part
description: Lets be honest: Celebrities dont usually write great memoirs. But the best ones offer up dish and dirt and some sensationally bizarre yarns.

title: The Long, Long Road Ahead
description: In my home state, California, we listen to audiobooks mostly while driving. When stuck in freeway traffic, I sometimes wonder whether the guy in my rearview mirror is secretly absorbed in Harry Potter, or if the smiling woman in the next lane is hearing Mr. Darcy woo Elizabeth Bennet. When it comes to immersing yourself in the First World War by audio, however, youll need more than a short commute. The war was very long, the books about it tend to be very long, and about this cataclysm that so thoroughly changed our world for the worse, surely you dont want to listen to merely one book? So I suggest you reserve this listening for some road trip of epic length, like that drive youve always wanted to take from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego, or from Rotterdam to Vladivostok. Here are some suggestions for the journey:

title: The Unpossessed
description: In 2008, Rivka Galchen published her first novel, Atmospheric Disturbances, about a man who believes his wife has been replaced by a replica of herself. Enfolded into the story was also one Dr. Tzvi Gal-Chen, who shares his name (down to the hyphen) with Galchens own father, a meteorologist who died in 1994. Combining aspects of her own biography, the physical sciences and psychiatry  Galchen is herself a medical doctor, trained in psychiatry  she created a vertiginous narrative about the nature of love and loss. Even if the books momentum ultimately flagged, it showed Galchen to be a bold, inventive and smart young writer.

title: Book Review Podcast: How Japan Bounces Back
description: In The New York Times Book Review, James Fallows reviews David Pillings Bending Adversity: Japan and the Art of Survival. Mr. Fallows writes:

title: Doctor Doubt
description: Asked to create a list of brain-shatteringly dull topics for fiction, you might be tempted to include the following things that appear in Joshua Ferriss To Rise Again at a Decent Hour: modern dentistry, pseudobiblical esoterica, the death rattle of a relationship, insomnia, shopping malls, other peoples spiritual anomie, other peoples use of social media, the perils of said social media, and baseball.

title: Every Little Byte Counts
description: In On What We Can Not Do, a short and pungent essay published a few years ago, the Italian philosopher Giorgio Agamben outlined two ways in which power operates today. Theres the conventional type that seeks to limit our potential for self-development by restricting material resources and banning certain behaviors. But theres also a subtler, more insidious type, which limits not what we can do but what we can not do. Whats at stake here is not so much our ability to do things but our capacity not to make use of that very ability.

title: Punitive Damage
description: As freedom advances, the severity of the penal law decreases. Or so argued Montesquieu, an Enlightenment philosopher whose work profoundly influenced the drafters of our Constitution. Were he alive today, Montesquieu might need to reconsider. The United States may or may not be the leader of the free world, but it is indisputably the world leader in locking up human beings behind bars. We are less than 5 percent of the worlds population, but we warehouse 25 percent of the worlds incarcerated population. Our per capita incarceration rate is seven times greater than Frances, 14 times greater than Japans and 24 times greater than Indias.

title: Tell No One
description: The first thing we learn about New York tabloid journalism from INVISIBLE CITY (Minotaur, $24.99) is that a body in Gowanus takes precedence over a brothel in Chinatown. Rebekah Roberts, the narrator of Julia Dahls first novel, is fresh out of college and considers herself lucky to be working as a stringer for a bottom-feeding tabloid. Amateur sleuths with day jobs on a newspapers staff are usually battle-weary veterans, so its a treat to hear Rebekah and her friends trade horror stories about fighting for entry-level positions.

title: Women at Work
description: #GIRLBOSS  By Sophia Amoruso  Portfolio/Penguin, $26.95.

title: Video: Snowboard Star Mentors Fresh Talent
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: Snowboard Legend Mentors Fresh Talent
description: Five years ago, Jeremy Jones invited a young Ryland Bell to join him in Alaska. Since that trip, Bell has traveled to the state with Jones nearly every spring, revealing Bells growth as a rider.

title: Uncertainty About Jobs Has a Ripple Effect
description: THE immediate impact of the recession  widespread buyouts and layoffs  may be fading, but the fear of losing a job hangs over workplaces like a cloud of worry.

title: Events in Connecticut for May 18-24, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey for May 18-24, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Case Against the Bernanke-Obama Financial Rescue
description: Atif Mian and Amir Sufi are convinced that the Great Recession could have been just another ordinary, lowercase recession if the federal government had acted more aggressively to help homeowners by reducing mortgage debts.

title: Opera Glasses, Google Edition
description: Opera companies, particularly small experimental ones, have been toying in recent years with immersive performances, in which audiences and performers move through different spaces. Often, these have been new works in English, but for companies interested in reimagining the classic canon, one question regularly arises: How to give mobile audiences the supertitle translations to which they have become accustomed?

title: Ex-Trader at SAC Fund Is Sentenced to 3 Years
description: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | A federal judge seemed pained at times on Friday in sentencing the former hedge fund trader Michael Steinberg to three and half years in prison for his conviction last year on insider trading charges.

title: Bruno, Ex-State Senate Chief, Is Acquitted of Fraud in Retrial
description: ALBANY  Standing in a federal courthouse in a city he long called his political home, Joseph L. Bruno, the once-powerful majority leader of the New York State Senate, was found not guilty on federal fraud charges on Friday. The verdict put an end to a legal battle nearly a decade in the making.

title: Popcast: Checking In on Burger Records
description: On this weeks Popcast, we look at the scene around Burger Records, based in Fullerton, Calif.  a teen-centered, low-budget, hyper-productive explosion of the new garage rock, though it isnt exactly the scholarly, record-obsessed, semi-antiquarian kind weve seen in the past. Lee Rickard and Sean Bohrman, former bandmates in Thee Makeout Party!, started the Burger Records label in 2007 and opened a record store two years later; in that time theyve become the center of a scene thats generating excitement, loyalty and a sense of identity, especially among an Orange County contingent thats under the legal drinking age and hungry for local culture. Burgers pace has become manic lately  it released 300 items last year, between cassette-only editions or reissues and original albums on LP and CD  but it seems to be working: Burgerama, its annual two-day festival in Santa Ana, sold 10,000 tickets this year, and its bands (including Cherry Glazerr, Together Pangea, Audacity, the Garden and Gap Dream) have started to move onto the national radar. (Although if all Burger records ever did was to produce the wild, messy, energetic weekly videos for its YouTube channel, BRGRTV, it might have served its purpose on earth.)

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 27
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: My Marriage: A Course in Desert Survival
description: The psychiatrist gestured to a chair. I wore a hospital gown and rumpled cotton robe. To my left, a dirty window muted the glare. Placing his chair directly in front of mine, he asked, So how will you support yourself?

title: Feeling For | The Latest From a Chic Brooklyn Culinary Magazine  and Its Spicy Summer Salad Recipe
description: When Fiorella Valdesolo and Michele Outland first sat down to conceive of Gather Journal  the cult biannual food magazine, which debuts its fifth issue today  they initially envisioned the projects subject matter to be style. But every time we came up with ideas, says Valdesolo, a writer (and T contributor) based in Brooklyn, we kept coming back to food.

title: Wall Street Washes Traders Mouths With Soap
description: Wall Street now has its very own Emily Post.

title: The United States of Metrics
description: The map of the United States that appeared on Nerve.com this year was in many ways similar to the maps that pop up on the Internet during election seasons. States were divided into red or blue, then shaded from light to dark. Only in this case, the color did not indicate political preference; it indicated duration of sexual encounter.

title: Reaching (Gingerly) for His Inner Killer
description: Call it Method directing.

title: Times Minute | What Indias Vote Means
description: As Narendra Modi swept into power as prime minister-elect Friday, a look at what Indias vote means.

title: Summer Burgers, Hold the Meat
description: I come back to burgers in this column every year or two. My quest for good vegetarian burgers has nothing to do with wanting to create something that resembles a hamburger or turkey burger. Why try to mimic meat? Rather, my vegetarian cooking is about produce, which, it turns out, can be the foundation for a great burger.

title: Times Minute | What Indias Vote Means
description: In the Video

title: What Is This Child Doing in Prison?
description: LAST month a 16-year-old child was placed in solitary confinement at the York Correctional Institution for Women in Niantic, Conn. She has never been charged, tried or convicted. What is her crime? That she has survived.

title: All Aboard, for a Trip to the Past
description: It was the tail end of winter, and the trees outside the train car window were spindly twigs. Behind the bare branches, the sky was alight. To my half-asleep, hardly focusing, hung-over eyes, it was a blurry layer cake of blueberry, raspberry and tangerine. I had boarded the train in Chicago at dusk on Friday, three days before, and had rolled down 926 miles of rail. Id spent 20 frivolous, indulgent hours in New Orleans, where Id had fried oysters and fried green tomatoes at Upperline, midnight cocktails at the bar Cure and a hedonistic jazz brunch at Commanders Palace. Then, before I could acclimate to the warmth and the green, the music and the food, I was on the next northbound train.

title: U.S. Officials on G.M.s Ignition Defect
description: The transportation secretary and the acting administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration discussed the investigation into G.M.s vehicle recall for defective ignition switches.

title: Taking a Spin: Surprises in Georgia and Louisiana
description: It is again time to spin the Upshots Senate wheels, in our weekly demonstration of just how much uncertainty remains with six months until the election.

title: Death of a Hospital
description: In 1935, with the last inmates from the century-old penitentiary transferred to Rikers Island, a site south of the Queensboro Bridge was cleared for the modern Welfare Hospital for Chronic Diseases, which would become known as Goldwater Hospital.

title: Forgoing Sunrise for Sunset on Mauis Volcano
description: I was standing at the top of Mount Haleakala at 6 oclock on a March morning, bleary-eyed and nauseated. During the three-hour journey from sea level to 10,000 feet, a group of wretchedly jet-lagged adventurers and I had scissored through almost 40 miles of hairpin turns holding on to our coffee cups and stomachs, stopping to help a disoriented elderly woman, navigating through herds of cows and glumly watching as rain began to splatter the vans windshield.

title: An Intimate View of America, From Above
description: We are rolling down the runway, increasing speed. At 70 knots, my husband lifts the nose of our small plane and we are suddenly airborne. Looking down, I can see the treetops, then the diagram of the town, and soon a panorama of hills and highways. We are heading south and west, toward Mississippi.

title: Hotel Review: Brewhouse Inn & Suites in Milwaukee
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Josephs of Santa Fe
description: At 7 on an early winter evening, the buzz about Joseph Wredes new restaurant, Josephs of Santa Fe, had translated into an in-the-flesh dinner rush. The stranger dining next to me, a local who confessed hed eaten there seven times since the restaurant opened in October, offered me a duck-fat French fry. You didnt order them and you have to try one, he said.

title: David Balding, Producer Who Adopted an Elephant, Dies at 75
description: David Balding, a producer of Broadway and Off Broadway plays who may have been best known as a circus showman who acted as a parent to an elephant, died on May 9 in Weldon Spring, Mo. He was 75.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: On the Market in the Hamptons
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: A Clash of Ideals and Investments at Swarthmore
description: Kate Aronoff didnt arrive at Swarthmore College in fall 2010 expecting to be an environmental activist. Nor did she know much about the stock market. She knew even less about asset management and college endowments.

title: Black-Throated Blue Warbler: Listen, Stop and Watch
description: It has become clichd to call warblers the butterflies of the bird world, but it is a fair description of these tiny, colorful birds. In breeding plumage, male warblers are decked out in fluorescent reds, brilliant yellows, greens and metallic blues. A long look at a warbler as it flits from branch to branch may last just a few seconds, but even in that brief time, its colors astound.

title: Elaine Sturtevant, Who Borrowed Others Work Artfully, Is Dead at 89
description: Elaine Sturtevant, an American Conceptual artist whose work resembled that of Andy Warhol  and Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Rauschenberg and Marcel Duchamp and Jasper Johns and Keith Haring and a spate of other emblematic figures from the annals of contemporary art  died on May 7 in Paris. She was 89.

title: Think of Him as a Wingman for Hire
description: All the lonely people, the Beatles sang  identifying a consumer market of vast scale and almost limitless need. Which is to say, an opportunity. On a recent Monday night in the meatpacking district, that marketplace was in full swirl: stylish men and women circling one another, offering a line, a joke, a meeting of cellphones.

title: Former Executive Sues for Stake in Beats Electronics, Object of Apples Desire
description: A week after reports on its negotiations were first published, Apples pending $3.2 billion deal for Beats Electronics has still not been completed. But Beats is already finding itself defending a lawsuit against a former executive over what could be a lucrative stake in the company.

title: Russian Rocket Crashes After Takeoff
description: MOSCOW  A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a sophisticated communications satellite crashed after takeoff early Friday morning, reviving questions over Russias space program after a series of failed launches in recent years.

title: The Freedom of Boundaries
description: What I remember about boundaries when I was growing up is that I always wanted to violate them. Today, Im frustrated that I dont have more boundaries. I say that even though I have consciously built numerous boundaries in recent years, specifically to make up for the fact that technology has made it so difficult to have any.

title: Kenyans Describe Twin Blasts in Nairobi
description: The Kenyan president, Uhuru Kenyatta, urged citizens to help prevent any future attacks, and witnesses described the scene after two explosions at a packed market in Nairobi.

title: A Mixture for Geithner: The Moral Hazard
description: Central bankers and finance ministers are a famously sober bunch. That may explain why Timothy Geithner, despite being a senior federal policy maker through the better part of two decades of financial crisis, from Mexico to Thailand, Lehman Brothers to Greece, has, as far as we know, never had a cocktail named for him.

title: Drama League Honors Gentlemans Guide and All the Way
description: The Drama League, an association of thousands of theatergoers nationwide, announced on Friday that A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder has won its 2014 award for best musical and All the Way has won for best play. At a ceremony to present its 80th annual awards, the league also named Hedwig and the Angry Inch best revival of a musical and The Glass Menagerie best revival of a play.

title: Q. and A. | Marion Cotillard on Her New Role and the Pursuit of Happiness
description: When Marion Cotillard is presented with the notion that after more than 40 films, an Oscar for Best Actress (for La Vie en Rose), and roles in some of the last decades defining blockbusters, shes only now leading her first American film, even she seems surprised. Yes, thats true, she says with a laugh. I didnt even think about it. But The Immigrant, an operatic melodrama directed by James Gray that opens today, hardly feels like it belongs in a 21st century American multiplex. Its a grandiose throwback to an era when movies dealt with big emotions, not big explosions.

title: Transition in Leadership for BAMs DanceAfrica
description: Part lively dance performance and part spirited homage to ancestors, the DanceAfrica festival, founded at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1977 by Chuck Davis  who made it the largest such festival in the country  is getting a new artistic director.

title: Student Loan Calculator
description: A guide to student loans at various universities, and what it takes after graduation to repay that debt.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 2
description: Continuing our look at the rookie on each team who will have the most fantasy impact this season, whether for him or for the players around him, we turn our attention to the N.F.C. South and West.

title: Known for Films Like Ran, a Japanese Actor Turns to the Stage
description: Updated, 3:09 p.m. | The last and most indelible image most American moviegoers have of the actor Tatsuya Nakadai probably dates from 1985: haunted, haggard, desolate, more ghost than man, wandering the battlefield at the end of his stupendous performance in Ran, Akira Kurosawas adaptation of King Lear.

title: A Las Vegas Boutique Hotel With Star Power
description: In a market defined by size, the Cromwell checks into Las Vegas this month as the underdog, competing on style rather than scale.

title: Driven | Bentley GT Speed Convertible
description: Transportation that says youve arrived.

title: Video: The Bentley Continental GT Speed Is a Terrestrial Space Shuttle
description: I was lucky enough to see a space shuttle launch before NASA retired the fleet. On television, the shuttle seems to leave the ground at a slow, majestic pace. In person, it left the planet at the same violent velocity as the Estes model rockets I shot into the sky during my Cub Scout days. Whoosh! Just like that, it was gone.

title: Mark Ryden: Drawing a Dividing Line
description: LOS ANGELES  Leonardo DiCaprio is an ardent collector of his macabre paintings. Katy Perry refers to his imagery in Twitter posts, and Amanda Seyfried has practically begged to be his muse. (Id love for him to paint a caricature of me with blood trickling down my throat and me holding a dead cat, she told W magazine.) That gown of raw meat that Lady Gaga donned on MTV a few years ago? Derived from one of his best-known works.

title: Rhubarb Shake
description: Melissa Clark makes a refreshing rhubarb shake with rosewater and Greek yogurt garnished with chopped pistachios.

title: Yogurt Drinks, Not Too Smooth
description: When it comes to yogurt drinks, weve gotten ourselves into a smoothie rut. Smoothies are everywhere, at every juice bar, street cart and deli, and premixed in bottles lining supermarket shelves.

title: When Shingles Is Just the Beginning
description: You dont really need another reason to get the shingles vaccine, for yourself (if youre over 60) or your older relatives. A painful rash, possible damage to vision and a substantial risk of the condition called postherpetic neuralgia, which can hurt for a long time  arent those enough?

title: Some Wines Are Worth Not Drinking
description: MANY people who collect fine wine talk about it as an investment. But is something that pairs nicely with rack of lamb really an investment  or just a way to justify paying tens of thousands of dollars for a single bottle?

title: Partnerships That Blend the Skills of Two Generations
description: IN her late 50s, Wickham Boyle left her job as an editor to pursue a project she was passionate about, producing an opera about 9/11 based on a book she wrote. A few months later, when she was ready to go back to work, she discovered it wasnt so easy to find her next gig. Our play closed on the day Lehman crashed, and my world dissolved, she said, recalling the start of the financial crisis in 2008.

title: For Indias Persecuted Muslim Minority, Caution Follows Hindu Partys Victory
description: NEW DELHI  Like real estate agents the world over, Rahul Rewal asks his clients if they have children or pets, since both limit options. But there is another crucial but often unspoken question: Are they Muslim?

title: Facts & Figures: Californias Drought
description: All of California is in severe drought or worse, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor, with much of the state in exceptional drought  the most extreme level. The National Drought Mitigation Center writes that a heat wave hitting the West will only serve to exacerbate and accelerate drought impact concerns across the state. Increases on water demand and the increased risk of fire will ramp up as the heat does.

title: The Rows New Home, a Frieze Frenzy and Moschinos Plans for Men
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Finding the Right Note, Pure and Easy
description: Its funny what makes a hit: that often once-in-a-lifetime connection between an artist and an audience, or a piece of music and a specific moment in time.

title: Planners Adapt as Gay Unions Become More Common
description: Not very long ago, having a same-sex wedding was noteworthy enough, and those looking to wed often sought comfort and support in wedding websites and party planners whose orientation closely matched their own.

title: A Beginners Guide to Repaying Student Loans
description: Too many people, including plenty of brand-new college graduates, fall far behind on their student loan payments for no good reason.

title: Weekend Reading: The Hero and the Wall St. Puppet
description: Updated, 4:23 p.m., Saturday | Timothy F. Geithners new book defending his role in the financial crisis is drawing out his detractors and defenders on both sides of the political aisle.

title: Rainout Puts Yanks in Old-Time 2-Game Set
description: The Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates might as well wear throwback uniforms this weekend. The opener of their three-game series, scheduled for Friday night, was rained out, and now they are scheduled to play an afternoon game Saturday and an old-fashioned, single-admission doubleheader Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.

title: So Youre Not Desirable ...
