description: IT is one of the hard truths of romance: Desirable people attract other desirable people, while the rest of us  lacking in attractiveness, charisma or success  settle for the best partner who is willing to consider our overtures. In the scientific literature, this idea is enshrined in the concept of mate value, which determines who gets to mate with whom. In popular culture, it is reflected in the choice of comely contestants to vie for the equally comely spouse-to-be on TV shows like The Bachelor. Pairing off, it seems, is just one more example that life isnt fair.

title: A Southern Crossroads
description: The El Conejo bus depot in Laredo, Tex., serves as a crossroads for immigrants entering the United States.

title: James Gray on The Immigrant
description: The director discusses his film featuring Joaquin Phoenix, Marion Cotillard and Jeremy Renner.

title: Chipotle Experiments With Disposable Literature
description: The fast-food chain Chipotle announced on Thursday that it had enlisted 10 A-list writers to provide original notes and essays for the cups and bags in their restaurants as a way to foster thoughtfulness, without pushing a coporate agenda. The reviews for these new works of literature have ranged from enthusiastic to harsh.

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Joan of Arc
description: Various stuff keeping me frantic, so not much time to seek out new music. But I keep finding new gems from the latest AF album  or actually from the live performances, especially the stripped-down versions, which I often prefer. In this case the final violin dissonance really does it

title: Why G.O.P. Will Shift to Talking About Fixing the Heath-Care Law
description: In response to polling data showing that the Affordable Care Act has become more popular, a prominent Republican pollster said that he expected Republicans to change how they talked about the law.

title: Brooklyn Cantor Pleads Guilty in Sexual Abuse Case
description: A sexual abuse case that divided the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn and created rifts in the boroughs district attorneys office ended on Friday as a once-prominent cantor pleaded guilty to molestation.

title: The Gun Report: May 16, 2014
description: In the Carolinas, guns are allowed in bars. In Arkansas, you can take a gun into some churches and religious schools. In Indiana, you can keep a gun in your car on school property. In West Virginia, residents with concealed-carry permits can bring firearms into public recreation facilities such as tennis courts and swimming pools. Since the massacre in Newtown, 18 states have passed laws allowing guns in more placesbut in only four states can you bring a gun into state legislative chambers.

title: Brightening the Night With a Spring Palette
description: Walk beneath an animated rainbow, and then head through a tunnel of swirling fog. Meander past luminescent flowers, gigantic glowing mushrooms and a praying mantis towering more than 12 feet tall. Listen to the beat of a backdrop that blends natural noises with music. Welcome to Lightscapes, a fantastical garden of light, color and sound on the grounds of Van Cortlandt Manor.

title: Atelier de Troupe Shows Two Collaborations at Its I.C.F.F. Debut
description: Atelier de Troupe, the three-year-old furniture and lighting studio founded by the Los Angeles-based designer Gabriel Abraham, is exhibiting at the annual International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York for the first time this year. Abraham will introduce several new styles as well as two new collaborations: Core, created in tandem with the San Francisco-based ceramist Ian McDonald, and a collection of lighting designed alongside Roman Alonso of Commune.

title: A Dose of Top-Down Tonic to Drive the Winter Blues Away
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  Cabin fever is bad enough. But when you share your extended winter quarters with 8.4 million people, as one does in New York City, its no wonder the roommates get a little testy.

title: Spirited Sedan Inhabited by Pontiacs Ghost
description: General Motors has a long history of killing off worthy cars. The Pontiac Fiero is the most infamous example, an initially mundane two-seater that developed into a capable performance machine just in time for production to cease forever. A more recent casualty was the 2008-9 Pontiac G8, a rear-drive performance sedan that was canceled when its brand fell under the ax as G.M. approached bankruptcy.

title: Chevy SS: What Lies Beneath
description: A defunct General Motors divisions last hurrah has returned from Australia wearing a bow-tie disguise.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Ukraine, Serbia and Palestine.

title: Nuclear Talks With Iran Fail to Yield Pact, Officials Say
description: LONDON  The latest round of nuclear talks between Iran and six world powers ended on Friday in Vienna, with Iranian and American officials saying that progress was slow and difficult, with serious gaps between the two sides on basic issues like the size of any nuclear enrichment capability Iran would be permitted to retain.

title: Leave the Car at Home This Weekend
description: New Yorkers who were thinking about hopping in a car to get about town this weekend might want to think twice. Not only is the annual AIDS walk on Sunday, but between food fairs and street fairs, Norwegian pride parades and dance parades, half marathons and awareness walks, just about every corner of the city will have some street closed for a period of time.

title: Civilized Without Compromise
description: The 2014 Stingray convertible is simply the best Corvette in the nameplates 61-year history, as purely capable as a Porsche 911 Carrera S, but at barely half the price.

title: Clyde Snow, Sleuth Who Read Bones From King Tuts to Kennedys, Dies at 86
description: With ghoulish geniality, Clyde Snow liked to say that bones made good witnesses, never lying, never forgetting, and that a skeleton, no matter how old, could sketch the tale of a human life, revealing how it had been lived, how long it had lasted, what traumas it had endured and especially how it had ended.

title: From the International Desk: The Thinking on Ukraine
description: We talked to Kyle Crichton, who is coordinating coverage of the Ukraine crisis for The Times, about the news that steelworkers and miners are taking control of the streets from separatists and pro-Russian militants in Mariupol and some other cities.

title: On-Site Fixes for What Winters Potholes Wrought
description: Jennifer Franz of Sacramento scraped a wheel on her three-year-old Honda Accord last August in an encounter with a curb. To keep her mother from finding the damage, she made an appointment with a local business, Kelly Wheel Repair, that travels to its customers.

title: Serious Rock Star Fantasies, Fueled by Athletic Footwork
description: Imagine a teenage boy in his bedroom, pretending to be a rock star. He tries out postures. He swings his shirt around his head. It could be cute, right? Now imagine that the boy is actually a grown man and that he makes you watch him fantasize about being a rock star for 95 minutes. Not so cute.

title: A Scaleback in Die-Cast Cars
description: The decision by the Danbury Mint last month to stop selling die-cast model cars was symptomatic of a more serious shrinkage in a market where the vehicles are already pretty small.

title: GreenTech Scatters New Seeds
description: In its five-year existence, GreenTech Automotive has manufactured far more headlines than cars. Now, after a merger with another fledgling auto company, VL Automotive, GreenTech promises to deliver an eclectic mix of electric city cars, plug-ins converted into muscle machines and performance-tuned cars for the Chinese market.

title: Goldman Shareholders Give Pay Plan a Thumbs Up
description: Since the financial crisis, Wall Street has faced pressure to disclose more about how it rewards its top executives.

title: The Fruit of Feminist Mothers and Michael Jackson
description: After decades of radical questioning and cycles of reaction, which term is more difficult to define neatly these days: feminism or contemporary performance? That was one question raised by the Minneapolis collective SuperGroup in its smart and inventive New York debut on Thursday.

title: Straws Theyll All Grasp At
description: What should you serve when you serve drinks?

title: Week in Pictures for May 16
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the newly elected mayor of Newark, and a World War II plane embarking on a new mission.

title: Bolshoi Theater Plans Tchaikovsky Celebrations
description: MOSCOW  The Bolshoi Theater announced plans for the 2014-15 season this week, including productions to mark the 175th anniversary of Tchaikovskys birth.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Did Regulators Break the Internet or Did They Save It? Yes.
description: Ten years from now, well look back on this week as the moment federal regulators broke the Internet as we know it.

title: Feminism, One Conference at a Time
description: It was a month before Gloria Steinems 80th birthday, but on a Saturday evening in February, on the cliffs at a resort in Southern California, 500 women were helping her celebrate early. Ms. Steinem, the guest of honor, was flanked by her longtime friends Marlo Thomas and Jane Fonda. The three hugged, and then Ms. Thomas raised a glass. To Gloria, she said. The absolutely perfect leader to our revolution.

title: Mahler, Together With an Old Friend
description: It is always a pleasure to check in on a happy marriage of musical artist and repertory after many years and find that it still thrives.

title: True Crime, With an Analytic Leaning
description: There are several issues to consider regarding the premiere of The System, Joe Berlingers new eight-part series, which begins on Sunday night on Al Jazeera America. The most obvious and probably most pertinent is that the channel is trying to keep up with one of its cable news rivals: Its bringing in a recognizable figure (Mr. Berlinger is known for feature documentaries like the Paradise Lost series about the West Memphis 3 case and Metallica: Some Kind of Monster) to do original documentary-style programming before CNN gets its new shows with Lisa Ling, Mike Rowe and John Walsh on the air.

title: Kids Are Icebound by Frozen Fervor
description: If any parent doubts the power of the Disney animated film Frozen, perhaps they should talk to Willie Geist, a Today show host.

title: Within a Ships Walls, Songs of War in High Voices
description: Human fragility is a recurring theme in the music of David Lang, and battle hymns, an almost hourlong collection of choral songs about war, is no exception. On Thursday, this often moving but occasionally precious work received its New York premiere, sung by the Collegiate Chorale and the Manhattan Girls Chorus under the direction of James Bagwell in the 12,000-square-foot Hangar 3 inside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. The performance also included six singers from the Veteran Artist Program, a nationwide initiative to engage former service members in the arts. Mr. Lang sets repurposed Civil War texts by Stephen Foster, Abraham Lincoln and Maj. Sullivan Ballou in his trademark spare vocal lines and crystalline textures. The result is a portrait of the soldier as sleepwalker, caught in a no mans land between patriotism and private longing.

title: Parents Respond to the Frozen Frenzy
description: We have just a touch of Frozen fever at our house. Our spring break trip involved three long plane journeys, and my youngest daughter watched Frozen in every available language on the seat-back television screen. We are not big singers of Let it Go; we prefer the sprightly Do You Want to Build a Snowman? but my older daughter and the girls we visited over break did engage in vigorous debate over whose version of Let It Go was better (vigorous agreement might be a better phrase for their passionate preference for the Idina Menzel version over the Demi Lovato one). And anyone, anywhere, can get a laugh at any moment by declaring, Hi, Im Olaf, and I like warm hugs.

title: Night Out With Emilie and Mika Brzezinski
description: Last Friday night, Tina Brown held a cocktail party in her Sutton Place apartment for Emilie Brzezinski, an 82-year-old artist from Switzerland who carves monumental wooden sculpture using chain saws and chisels.

title: Hong Kong Cocoons
description: Buildings in Hong Kong are sheathed in colored nets and bamboo while being renovated. Peter Steinhauer tracks these cocoons on the urban skyline.

title: Where the Sylvan Settings Enhance the Art
description: Spring blossoms, clement breezes and some newborn farm animals make this a particularly delightful time to visit three outdoor sites where artwork is surrounded by the splendors of nature.

title: Sweetly Taking on Kanye and Double Standards
description: Lily Allen paused in her set at the Highline Ballroom on Thursday night  her first New York City show since 2009  to autograph an audience members eagerly proffered copy of Sheezus, her new CD. You guys think Im just being a really nice person, she said. But actually this is a really good advertising plan!

title: Cannes Film Festival 2014, Part I
description: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benot Peverelli.

title: With Narendra Modi, a Change in India
description: Narendra Modi, Indias presumed next prime minister, and his opposition Bharatiya Janata Party made history by delivering a crushing defeat to the ruling Indian National Congress party, which has controlled Indian politics for most of the past 60 years. Winning more than 272 parliamentary seats, the B.J.P. received the strongest mandate of any party in 30 years.

title: Recycling the Leftovers
description: Every week, some 14,000 households in Austin, Tex., dutifully roll not just one, or two, but three garbage bins to the curb.

title: Veterans Secretary Ousts Health Care Official Amid Criticism
description: WASHINGTON  One day after deflecting calls from unhappy senators to shake up his leadership team, Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, ousted the departments soon-to-retire head of health care. The move came amid snowballing allegations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide long delays many patients faced to see physicians.

title: Semifinals in the Bridge Trial for the Bermuda Bowl
description: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next years Bermuda Bowl world championship is nearing its conclusion.

title: For Sandra Tsing Loh, Change Is Good
description: PASADENA, Calif.  I just joined Twitter, the writer and performer Sandra Tsing Loh announced into a good old-fashioned microphone. She was deep in the warren of the KPCC-FM public-radio station (wall-to-wall carpeting, office kitchen copiously stocked with herbal teas, a sound engineer who keeps bees), recording a segment for The Loh Life, one of her two long-running broadcasts here. Ads for Golds Gym flashed noiselessly, reprovingly, on a television screen overhead.

title: Swiss Prepare to Vote on Worlds Highest Minimum Wage
description: BASEL, Switzerland  While Switzerlands booming economy has made the country synonymous with a superlative standard of living, the government estimates that approximately one worker in 10 struggles to pay rent, despite working full time.

title: Racially Themed Work Stirs Conflict at Whitney Biennial
description: The YAMS, a collective of artists who made a video on race and black identity for the current Whitney Biennial, have withdrawn the work to protest a project in the show that they contend is racially insensitive.

title: The Entire Audience Dozed Off? Perfect!
description: Its the unspoken fantasy of so many theatergoers: a highbrow cultural outing that, somewhere between the opening and the ovation, includes a nap. But most directors and performers conspire to, at the very least, keep their audiences awake.

title: Greek Banks Return to Risky Investment
description: Investing in Greeces banks was never for the cautious. But for the parade of hedge fund managers who have piled into the Greek financial giant Piraeus Bank, the banks latest deal has surely resulted in a dose of heartburn.

title: Icons at Leisure in Long-Ago Summers
description: A self-possessedlittle girl named Jacqueline Bouvier walking with her pony. Diana Vreeland wearing striped shorts with matching striped earrings. Gary Cooper impeccably dressed in a sport jacket and trousers as he enters a fashionable beach club. These are among the 30 black-and-white images of the rich and famous in Southampton Blue Book, 1930 to 1960: Photographs by Bert Morgan, on view at the Rogers Mansion of the Southampton Historical Museums and Research Center through Oct. 18.

title: A Pioneer Says Goodbye, Unfiltered
description: Barbara Walters got out while the gets were still good.

title: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
description: The fashion note at the Womens Committee of the Central Park Conservancy hat luncheon was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the suit.

title: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
description: On May 7, the Womens Committee of the Central Park Conservancy held its annual hat luncheon for 1,200 guests. The event, which garnered $3.5 million and honored Michael Bloomberg, featured whimsical headdresses masking a serious dedication to the restoration of the park and to the judicious spending of the money raised. Lela Rose arrived on her bike, with Gillian Miniter in the sidecar. The fashion note was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the luncheon suit, and a lovely surprise to the women in orange was the hue of the traditional umbrellas handed out.

title: Portland, Ore., Sheds Its Walmart Bonds
description: The city of Portland, Ore., announced this week that it had begun divesting itself of its holdings in Walmart, citing concerns over the companys ethics and labor practices.

title: Evening Hours | A Blossoming Calendar
description: Its a busy time, with benefits of all types.

title: Ask Well | Downsides of Taking Truvada?
description: Readers asked Well about the preventative drug Truvada following a C.D.C. recommendation that all Americans at risk for H.I.V. take this daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection.

title: Ask Well: AIDS and Truvada
description: New federal guidelines urge gay men and others who have unprotected sex to take a daily dose of the drug Truvada to curb H.I.V. infections and AIDS. Donald G. McNeil Jr. responds to reader questions.

title: Video Reviews of Godzilla, The Immigrant and Million Dollar Arm
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Godzilla, The Immigrant and Million Dollar Arm. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web, What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Coaxing Lyrical Voices From the Withdrawn
description: The Institute for Music and Health in Dutchess County occupies a big house in a deserted clearing at the end of a long and winding road. The main feature of the house is a room with two grand pianos, each with a so-called reflector  an obelisk-like plywood device that, placed under the pianos soundboard, is said to direct the sound waves back toward the pianist, easing feelings of isolation.

title: Bridging the Racial Divide in Tuscaloosa Schools
description: A ProPublica project in Tuscaloosa, Ala., had teenagers document the realities of resegregated schools.

title: Wheelies: The Top-Shelf Kia Edition
description: Michael Sprague, executive vice president for sales and marketing at Kia Motors America, said on Thursday that the automakers K900 luxury car, currently on sale in California, would be available in the Midwest this month. The $66,000 rear-wheel drive sedan is equipped with a 420-horsepower 5-liter V8 engine. (The Detroit Free Press)

title: Ways to Make a Citys Roads Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton on Nations Future
description: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton delivered remarks at the New America Foundation conference Big Ideas for a New America in Washington.

title: Understanding Dreams, and Fretting About Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoiding Foreclosure: A View From the Treasury Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncanny Representations of Humans in Distress
description: Two events from the last decade demonstrate how Edvard Munch (1863-1944) remains relevant in widely varying contexts today. One is the $119.9 million price paid in 2012 for a pastel version of The Scream (1895), which made it briefly the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction. The other is a proposal to use a version of The Scream to label a nuclear waste storage site, warning future generations  or visitors from other planets  of the toxic dangers lurking within.

title: Expanding Hydropower
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain, With a Touch of Denmark
description: American Ballet Theater has settled in at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the guest artists have started rolling through. Nearly a dozen, some well known here, some not, will appear in the next two months. At best, the system brings to New York world-class dancers we might not otherwise get to see. On Wednesday, the choice was especially welcome: Alban Lendorf, a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet.

title: Abbas Meets in London With Israeli Negotiator
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority met Thursday in London with Israels justice minister, Tzipi Livni, the first known face-to-face talks between the two sides since the American-brokered peace negotiations collapsed last month.

title: Bringing Star Power From the Windy City
description: Its hard not to have great expectations when a celebrity chef comes to town  never mind a pair of celebrity chefs, who together have racked up culinary awards, made dozens of television appearances and cooked at most of the countrys top food and wine festivals.

title: U.S. Setting Up Emergency Shelter in Texas as Youths Cross Border Alone
description: With border authorities in South Texas overwhelmed by a surge of young illegal migrants traveling by themselves, the Department of Homeland Security declared a crisis this week and moved to set up an emergency shelter for the youths at an Air Force base in San Antonio, officials said Friday.

title: Clinton Calls for Expanding Economic Opportunities
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton weighed in on the debate over income inequality on Friday, calling for policies intended to help the struggling middle class, in a speech that seemed suited to a campaign.

title: In Sparse Space, Flair for the House-Made
description: When Linizio took the place of the short-lived Italian Kitchen in January, I thought, here goes, another neo-Italian storefront run by young pioneers conversant in cavatelli, romanesco and semifreddo, with the usual local sourcing and house-made this and that. But the new owners, Scott and Heather Fratangelo, are making so many good things to eat with so much confidence that theres little room left for skepticism. Linizio means the start in Italian and the Fratangelos are off to a promising one.

title: Slowly Producing a Spirit England Can Call Its Own
description: ROUDHAM, England  Made with barley from a family farm and water from a local borehole, the slightly nutty-tasting single-malt whisky from a small distillery can cost more than similar products from Glenmorangie or Glenlivet. Matured for at least three years in bourbon casks, it is shipped around the world to the United States, Sweden, Russia, Hong Kong and China.

title: Apple and Google End Patent Fights
description: Updated with more reporting on the two companies as targets of so-called patent trolling.

title: Next Week on Retro Report
description: Before DNA testing, prosecutors often relied on microscopic hair analysis to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was it? Visit nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.

title: Rangers and Montreal Revive Historic Rivalry
description: Over nearly a century of coexistence, the Montreal Canadiens and the Rangers are at opposite ends of the Stanley Cup spectrum. The Canadiens have celebrated a record 24 Cups, though none since 1993. The Rangers have won only four  one in the last 74 years, in 1994.

title: Italian Food, the American Way
description: When Carl and Marie Ruiz opened Maries Italian Specialties in 2011, their intention was to maintain the sane hours of a deli-style restaurant, closing precisely at 6 p.m. Their intention was foiled on Day 1, when a well-dressed man entered the restaurant right at 6 and without even looking at a menu, said he wanted rigatoni with sausage and meatballs.

title: Mining Disaster Grows Into Political Crisis for Turkish Leader
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans response to the deadly mine explosion has fueled antigovernment sentiment.

title: His Future and Fortune at Stake, Formula One Chief Keeps It Breezy
description: MUNICH  For a man at risk of being rudely unseated from his position as one of the worlds most powerful sports moguls, Bernie Ecclestone seems improbably relaxed as the defendant in a criminal trial accusing him of bribery in the deal that ensured his continued control of grand prix motor racing.

title: Mother Accuses Doctors of Forcing a C-Section and Files Suit
description: After two cesarean sections, Rinat Dray wanted to give birth naturally.

title: Colombia and Rebels Agree on Drug Fight
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Negotiators for the Colombian government and the countrys largest guerrilla group said Friday that they had reached an agreement on ways to fight drug trafficking as part of broader talks aimed at ending five decades of war. The announcement came barely a week before a presidential election that could hinge on how voters view the peace talks.

title: The Name Is New, the Flavors are Familiar
description: When I announced, Were going to Din Din, my dining companions responded, laughing, with baby talk. In fact, the name of the restaurant comes from the Chinese baby name of its owner, Sophia Kang, Ms. Kang told me on the telephone after my visits.

title: Concerns Fade Over Weather and the Favorites Health
description: BALTIMORE  California Chrome galloped in the rain, took his medicine  a glycerin rinse for a small blister in his throat  and was declared fit, fast and ready for Saturdays 139th running of the Preakness Stakes by his father-son training team.

title: The Preakness Draw
Yearning for a Bigger (Apple) Smartphone
description: I have big phone envy.

title: As 9/11 Museum Opens, These New Yorkers Will Stay Away
description: The National September 11 Memorial Museum is meant to be an exercise in the cathartic power of memory. At its formal unveiling on Thursday, President Obama gave a somber speech, remarking that the lives of those who died in the terrorist attacks in 2001 would be honored by the stories told in the footprint of two mighty towers.

title: Times Co. Chief Addresses Executive Editors Firing
description: The controversy over the firing of Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, continued on Friday as the companys chief executive sent a letter to senior editors in an effort to further address the reasons for her dismissal.

title: Beware the City Dolls
description: COMMENCEMENT season is upon us again. In a tenuous economic recovery, many of the 1.6 million graduates at American colleges and universities will be listening intently for a bit of practical wisdom from their commencement speakers.

title: Producing Goals and Gall for Canadiens
description: BROSSARD, Quebec  Pernell Karl Subban thrives on being the center of attention. And that is what he has been in the N.H.L. playoffs, especially when his Montreal Canadiens faced the top-seeded Boston Bruins in the second round.

title: Ex-Duke Lacrosse Coach Rebuilds Shattered Career
description: SMITHFIELD, R.I.  There is more salt in the salt-and-cinnamon beard, but otherwise, Mike Pressler is about the same these days, eight years after he left Duke as the most infamous lacrosse coach in the nation.

title: Michelle Obama Cites View of Growing Segregation
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  Sixty years after the Supreme Court outlawed separate but equal schools for blacks and whites, civil rights advocates say American schools are becoming increasingly segregated, while the first lady, Michelle Obama, lamented that many young people are going to schools with kids who look just like them.

title: Passes Are No Longer Needed at 9/11 Memorial
description: The National September 11 Memorial is now truly open  unimpeded and permanently  to the public.

title: British Candidate Clarifies Just Which Immigrants Disturb Him
description: In a contentious radio interview that sounded at moments like Absurdist theater, the leader of the anti-immigrant U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, denied on Friday that his attacks on foreign-born migrants were racist.

title: City Now Expects to Authorize More Green Cabs by the Fall
description: One day after signaling that it would slow indefinitely the expansion of street-hail livery cab service outside Manhattan, Mayor Bill de Blasios administration said on Friday that it expected to issue new permits for the popular green taxis at the end of the summer.

title: No Reason to Delay Fair Wages
description: Come Jan. 1, 2015, a new federal rule will require that home care workers be paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. This rule would undo an indefensible policy, dating from 1974, that denied home care workers basic labor protections by deeming them companions rather than employees.

title: The Slippery Slope of Secrecy
description: If you want to keep a secret, George Orwell advised in 1984, you must also hide it from yourself. So the latest stricture seems to demand from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the federal uber-agency of all things secret. The office, which oversees 16 government intelligence agencies, issued a new policy in April that will seriously constrain the existing practice by which officials comment informally to the press and public when obvious issues are stirred by leaked information and unauthorized disclosures.

title: Little Time Left for Campaign Reforms
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is busy running for re-election, but he has yet to make good on a campaign promise from 2010: to clean up New Yorks abysmal campaign finance system. He can do that by coaxing the Legislature into passing a reform package that provides public matching funds for small donations.

title: California Wildfires Spread Across Hills, Leveling Homes
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif.  With fire rolling swiftly down the hill toward their houses on Thursday, Jeff Brown, his brother and his grandmother were forced by sheriffs deputies to flee the two homes here that the family has occupied since the 1960s.

title: Robbery Suspect Tracked by GPS and Killed
description: Relying on a GPS device placed in a decoy pill bottle, police officers tracked an armed man suspected of robbing a pharmacy on Friday afternoon and fatally shot him during a confrontation on the Upper East Side, police officials said.

title: Thousands of Toddlers Are Medicated for A.D.H.D., Report Finds, Raising Worries
description: ATLANTA  More than 10,000 American toddlers 2 or 3 years old are being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder outside established pediatric guidelines, according to data presented on Friday by an official at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: The New Inequality for Toddlers: Less Income; More Ritalin
description: About 15,000 American toddlers 2 or 3 years old, many on Medicaid, are being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to data presented Friday by an official at the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. As Alan Schwarz reports, toddlers from low-income families are disproportionately represented among those medicated.

title: De Blasio Chooses a City Planner to Lead Landmarks Preservation
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Friday that he had chosen Meenakshi Srinivasan, an architect and city planner, to be the new chairwoman of New York Citys Landmarks Preservation Commission, an appointment of great interest to developers and preservationists.

title: Friends of Hillary
description: The American economy has gone through some tough times lately. But, happily, we still lead the world in the production of corn, soybeans, beef, cheese and stories about Hillary Clinton.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 16, 2014
Humanist Foundation Reaches Out to Religious Groups, Testing a Divide
description: Six months after starting a humanist charity in 2010, Dale McGowan unveiled a philanthropists version of a beta test. He already offered donors to his organization, the Foundation Beyond Belief, the opportunity to designate their gifts for groups that worked in fields like refugee aid and environmentalism. Then, in an contrarian brainstorm, he decided to try adding a category for progressive religious bodies.

title: Democracy Triumphs in India, but Falters Again in Ukraine
description: It is often noted, correctly, that elections are not the whole of democracy. But when millions upon millions of people in an enormously diverse and complex land like India vote over several weeks for an orderly change of government, it is a heartening sight. Especially so when set against people taking the law into their own hands in Ukraine, Thailand or Vietnam.

title: Gray Ones Spark Debate
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Brad Wilber is a librarian at an East Coast college, so its not surprising that he knows a lot about a lot of different things. It definitely shows in his puzzles, where solvers can find very sophisticated references to art, music (Mr. Wilber is an opera fan, so that comes up a lot) and literature.

title: Key Figure in Libyas Revolution Leads Attack on Islamists
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A former general who was a central figure in Libyas revolution led a full-scale ground and air assault on several Islamist militia bases in and around the city of Benghazi on Friday, declaring war against the groups that have been accused of conducting a campaign of lawlessness and assassinations.

title: Jeb Magruder, 79, Nixon Aide Jailed for Watergate, Dies
description: Jeb Magruder, a former high-level aide to President Richard M. Nixon who went to jail in the Watergate affair and who years later made the startling assertion that Nixon himself had ordered the break-in that set the scandal in motion, died on Sunday in Danbury, Conn. He was 79.

title: Rethinking Campaign Finance
description: In 2006, shortly after being elected to Congress  indeed, as he recalls it, before he had even taken his oath of office  John Sarbanes was approached by several Washington lobbyists. They offered to do a fund-raiser for me, he said. I thought, I dont want to start down this road.  So he put the lobbyists off.

title: In California Race, Pedigree vs. Policy (and Bit of TV Nostalgia)
description: LOS ANGELES  Bobby Shriver, a gregarious Kennedy family transplant running for the county Board of Supervisors here, turned up for a debate in Sherman Oaks the other evening and spotted his main rival, Sheila Kuehl, a child actress who served 14 years as a California legislator, milling around the crowded room.

title: Jean-Luc Dehaene, Former Prime Minister of Belgium, Is Dead at 73
description: Jean-Luc Dehaene, a former prime minister of Belgium whose deft political deal-making helped hold together his countrys historically divided factions and for a time made him a leading contender to become the European Unions top official, died on Thursday in Brittany, France. He was 73.

title: Pakistan: Boy Kills a Jailed Man Who Was Accused of Blasphemy
description: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy. The boy, a student in the 10th grade, entered the station in Sharaqpur, 15 miles west of Lahore, wearing a fake police uniform and carrying a gun, the police said. He demanded to see Khalil Ahmad, a member of the minority Ahmadi community who was being held at the station. Mr. Ahmad had been arrested Monday after a dispute with a Muslim shopkeeper escalated and the shopkeeper sought help from local clerics, who accused Mr. Ahmad and three other Ahmadis of blasphemy. When the boy was taken to the detainees cell, he shot Mr. Ahmad, who died instantly, the police said. The boy was arrested.

title: Germany: The Flight of the Iguana
description: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week. During a routine inspection of luggage in transit, the official found 50 turtles, 30 arboreal alligator lizards, the snakes and the iguana in one suitcase. Several reptiles were stuffed into cloth bags or boxes, and the snakes were entangled in womens stockings, said Hans-Jrgen Schmidt, a customs spokesman. The owner of the bag, traveling from Mexico City to Barcelona, was detained Tuesday before boarding his flight to Spain, Mr. Schmidt said. The passenger, a 44-year-old Mexican, who cannot be named under German privacy laws, is under investigation to determine whether he violated laws on the protection of endangered species and the treatment of animals. Three turtles have died, and most of the reptiles, which have been moved to the Frankfurt zoo, were in bad shape, Mr. Schmidt said. The potential sale value of the cargo was as much as $82,000, he said.

title: Familiar Result as Nadal and Murrays Rivalry Resumes
description: ROME  The first match between Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray in nearly three years proved to be worth the wait.

title: Connecticut G.O.P. Weighs a Full Field for Governor
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  This states Republicans, counting on widespread concern over Connecticuts financial picture to lift their electoral fortunes, descended upon the Mohegan Sun resort in Uncasville on Friday to begin to select a challenger to the Democratic governor, Dannel P. Malloy.

title: As Usual, Mets Hitters Struggle. For Once, So Does Niese.
description: WASHINGTON  Juan Lagares appeared to have lost his starting spot this week. Earlier in the season, he was perhaps the Mets best all-around player, making spectacular plays in center field and appearing composed at the plate.

title: Corrections: May 17, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 17, 2014
description: A billion plus people have announced their mandate in no uncertain terms.

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Stop Force-Feeding Syrian Held at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  A Federal District Court judge on Friday ordered the military to stop force-feeding a hunger-striking detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, until at least Wednesday.

title: Conference Finals Preview: Familiarity in the East and Consistency in the West
description: The conference finals of the N.H.L. playoffs feature a contrast of recent Stanley Cup histories. In the East, two Original Six teams with long Stanley Cup droughts meet. The West involves the winners of three of the last four Stanley Cups.

title: Air Crash in Laos Kills Top Officials for Security
description: BANGKOK  A plane carrying senior Laotian government officials crashed Saturday morning, leaving at least four people dead, Laotian diplomats said Saturday.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) RETURN TO ZERO (2014) Maggie (Minnie Driver) and Aaron (Paul Adelstein, above with Ms. Driver) try to resume their picture-perfect existence after their son is stillborn, but cant escape their grief in this drama based on the personal experiences of the writer and director, Sean Hanish. They cope through denial, escape and alcohol, but when Maggie discovers that Aaron is having an affair with a colleague (Sarah Jones), she decides to end the marriage. But just as she believes that she is ready to move on, she discovers that shes pregnant. Alfred Molina portrays Aarons brusque father and boss; Kathy Baker is Maggies mother. And Connie Nielsen plays the doctor who, having experienced a similar loss, helps Maggie and Aaron begin their lives anew.

title: Congresss Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
description: The leafy boulevard leading up to the Indian National Congress partys headquarters in the Lutyens Delhi neighborhood was deserted early in the afternoon on Friday. Trends in voting were becoming more apparent, and it did not look good for the party that governs the central government. With time, it only looked worse.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: There are big changes in store for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-run mortgage financing giants that guarantee about two-thirds of all U.S. home loans. The new head of the agency that oversees the companies wants them to continue to play a major role in the housing market.

title: Secular Stagnation in the Euro Area
description: Most discussion about the possibility of secular stagnation has focused on US data, partly because most of the new secular stagnationists are American, partly because the data are easier to work with. But as Izabella Kaminska and James Mackintosh point out, the euro area seems closer to Japanification than the US. So are there structural changes in Europe that arguably will lead to persistently lower demand unless offset by policy?

title: Interest Rates and Inflation and Evidence
description: Just a brief belated note on the neo-Fisherite view that lower interest rates lead to lower inflation, which has produced some surprising diffidence from economists you would expect to ridicule it; why doesnt this debate emphasize the large empirical literature on the effects of monetary shocks?

title: Bridging the Racial Divide in Tuscaloosa Schools
description: Skin color doesnt define your intelligence.

title: Tiananmen, 25 Years Later
description: My Sunday column looks back at the Tiananmen student democracy movement in the spring of 1989 and the brutal repression that followed it. I was then a young reporter based in China, and it was a formative and searing experience for me. You dont forget when a government opens fire at the crowd youre in.

title: As Turkish Mine Yields the Last Body, Recriminations Remain
description: SOMA, Turkey  Rescue workers removed the last remaining bodies from a stricken mine here on Saturday afternoon as the death toll in Turkeys worst mining accident rose to 301 people, according to the prime ministers office.

title: Talks in East Aim to Ease Tensions in Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Senior Ukrainian officials on Saturday held a second session of national round-table talks aimed at ending the countrys political crisis, this time in the eastern city of Kharkiv, in the region that has been besieged by pro-Russian separatist violence.

title: Unemployment: Its Not Personal
description: Matt OBrien has an interesting if depressing piece on long-term unemployment, making the point that long-term unemployment is basically bad luck: if you got laid off in a bad economy, you have a hard time finding a new job, and the longer you stay unemployed the harder it becomes to find work.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, May 18
description: We are making progress, and we just need to keep moving with speed.

title: Taking the Earths Temperature
description: Geoff DiMego, 65, is a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in College Park, Md.

title: Tackling the Limits of Touch Screens
description: Touch screens are ubiquitous on tablets and smartphones, but their flat glass surfaces can hinder close reading and accurate typing. People flipping through electronic pages often retain less of what they read than on printed ones, studies suggest. And typing on a flat surface with no physical keys to guide the fingers requires heightened visual attention to avoid typos, draining concentration from the thoughts being expressed.

title: Geithner, Staying on Script
description: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, drew a large and respectful crowd last Wednesday at a Barnes & Noble store in Manhattan, where he was publicizing Stress Test, his new memoir about the financial crisis. Mr. Geithner left little to chance at the event: It consisted of a highly scripted chat with a friendly interviewer who screened audience questions. After an hour, Mr. Geithner was whisked from the building.

title: Invasion of the Nail Clippers, and Other Office Dangers
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: 1914: Brilliant Troupe of Dancers from Russian Imperial Theatres To Appear in Paris
description: The Russian ballets have become such an established feature of the Paris season that it seems difficult to realize that they were only introduced to the French public nine years ago. Perhaps it was their novelty and the charm of exotism which attracted western audiences first.

title: In B-School, Is That a Syllabus, or an Itinerary?
description: One weekend in February, about a third of Sean Pools classmates at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin went on a three-day ski trip to Park City, Utah. The event included nighttime, aprs-ski outings in town, as well as time to relax in a hot tub, according to the itinerary posted on Facebook. The Graduate Business Adventure Team, a student-run group, planned the trip.

title: Facial Recognition Software in Action
description: Aharon Zeevi Farkash, the founder of FST Biometrics, demonstrates how his companys technology can identify people from their appearance and movements.

title: Hannah Paramore, on Keeping Strengths From Running Amok
description: This interview with  Hannah Paramore, president of Paramore, the Digital Agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Never Forgetting a Face
description: Joseph J. Atick cased the floor of the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington as if he owned the place. In a way, he did. He was one of the organizers of the event, a conference and trade show for the biometrics security industry. Perhaps more to the point, a number of the wares on display, like an airport face-scanning checkpoint, could trace their lineage to his work.

title: The Harmony They Want to Hear
description: Apples reported plans to acquire Beats Electronics for $3.2 billion seemed downright strange to some of the people who follow Apple closely. Yet a deal could help jump-start two important industries.

title: Much Less Room at the Inn
description: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Rush of Tourists Early This Year appeared on May 14 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Americans Claim to Attend Church Much More Than They Do
description: The United States has long been unusually religious for an affluent, industrialized Western nation  in survey after survey, Americans report relatively high levels of belief in God, affiliation with religious institutions and participation in worship services.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 26
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Two California Chrome Owners Who Arent Fond of Spotlight Choose to Stay Behind
description: BALTIMORE  When California Chromes improbable journey reached Pimlico Race Course for Saturdays Preakness Stakes, two notable people from his entourage were missing.

title: Variety: A Mistaken Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Well, that was interesting. Todays acrostic did not fall for me the way I thought it would, although it was perfectly reasonable and I loved the quote. All Ill say is that by the time I typed in the final answer, I was ready for a GODMOTHER cocktail.

title: Making Room for Low Cost and High Style
description: On the heels of hotels like Yotel and Aloft, a crop of new brands is designed for millennial travelers.

title: Victor in India Promises to Make Country Strong
description: NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi, the man expected to become Indias next prime minister, swept into the capital on Saturday morning in a triumphal procession to the colonial bungalows here that still serve as Indias power center and promised that he will try to make India self-reliant and strong.

title: Connecting a Camera to a Tablet
description: Q. Can you connect a digital camera directly to a tablet computer to offload photos?

title: Inquiry by General Motors Is Said to Focus on Its Lawyers
description: DETROIT  As General Motors faces a number of continuing investigations into its handling of a vehicle safety defect linked to 13 deaths, its legal department has become a focus of a broad internal inquiry into how the company handled the issue, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: In Taking Crimea, Putin Gains a Sea of Fuel Reserves
description: When Russia seized Crimea in March, it acquired not just the Crimean landmass but also a maritime zone more than three times its size with the rights to underwater resources potentially worth trillions of dollars.

title: West African Nations Set Aside Their Old Suspicions to Combat Boko Haram
description: PARIS  The heads of state of five West African countries, including Nigeria, met Saturday with Western officials and agreed to share intelligence and strengthen military cooperation to combat the regional threat from the extremist Islamist group Boko Haram, which abducted more than 200 schoolgirls in northern Nigeria last month.

title: A Long-Shared Love of Racing and a Champion
description: BALTIMORE  Even before California Chrome romped in the Kentucky Derby, much had been made about his blue-collar owners  Steve Coburn and Perry Martin  and their tale of landing on thoroughbred racings biggest stage with the first horse they bred.

title: San Antonio Mayor Julin Castro Is Said to Be HUD Pick in Cabinet Reshuffling
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is preparing to nominate Mayor Julin Castro of San Antonio as his new secretary of housing and urban development, elevating one of his partys Hispanic rising stars as part of a cabinet shuffle that has possible implications for the 2016 presidential race, Democrats informed about the plans said on Saturday.

title: A Racing Prodigy Comes Into His Own After Hard Lessons
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C.  The boyish grin has not changed much over the years, although the boy who arrived in Nascar before he was even 18 is all grown up, is engaged to be married and has a hairline that is beginning to thin.

title: Taste of Postseason Doesnt Sway Pirates From Their Careful Path
description: Never has competitive balance come into sharper focus than it did early last October, when Yankee Stadium was dark and PNC Park in Pittsburgh crackled with postseason excitement. The teams, who play a doubleheader in the Bronx on Sunday, had been on opposite tracks for two decades. Now, Pittsburgh is not much different than New York.

title: Vietnamese Officials Intolerant of Violence as Standoff With China Continues
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Vietnamese officials signaled Saturday that further violence over a dispute with China would not be tolerated, declaring that more than 300 people involved in last weeks attacks on foreign-owned businesses would be prosecuted.

title: Googling While Expecting
description: Web queries indicate that pregnant women around the world tend to crave many of the same things: ice, salt, sweets, spicy foods. But searches (by anyone, men or women) also find differences among countries about pregnancy-related concerns.

title: Quixotic 80 Campaign Gave Birth to Kochs Powerful Network
description: He backed the full legalization of abortion and the repeal of laws that criminalized drug use, prostitution and homosexuality. He attacked campaign donation limits and assailed the Republican star Ronald Reagan as a hypocrite who represented no change whatsoever from Jimmy Carter and the Democrats.

title: Amid Tumult, N.A.A.C.P. Elects 18th Leader
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People elected its 18th leader on Friday night at an annual meeting of the executive board members in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: The World Cup in an Album
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Transactions are made at dozens of established meeting spots here: 122nd Street at 15th; the plaza in Pablo VI; 97th Street at 11th. They are made outside universities, office buildings and supermarkets, by young people, old people, men and women, all in search of stickers. Yes, stickers.

title: North Carolina Governor Tested by Own G.O.P. as Legislators Return
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  As legislators returned to town last week, 10 months after a tumultuous 2013 session when Republicans passed one deeply conservative bill after another, one Republican seemed a bit like the odd man out.

title: Thomas Was Alone Moves to the iPad
description: Thomas Was Alone, freshly arrived on the iPad for $9, is a different kind of game app.

title: Cannes Film Festival:  Timbuktu Director on Africa and Fundamentalism
description: CANNES, France  Theres a sad, powerful scene in Timbuktu, Abderrahmane Sissakos well-received new film about that ancient capitals recent takeover by Islamic fundamentalists, that resonates even more strongly in light of the schoolgirls kidnapped last month as child brides by Islamic fundamentalists in Nigeria.

title: Johns Hopkins Graduate, and an Umpire
description: TRENTON  A few days each week, before Dan Merzel heads to the ballpark to umpire in the Class AA Eastern League, he tutors high-achieving middle school and high school students participating in a program sponsored by Johns Hopkins. He communicates with them via Skype and email and uses a virtual whiteboard to solve math problems and answer questions.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 18
description: Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, fired the departments head of health care in response to a growing controversy that veterans hospitals in Arizona, Colorado, Texas, Wyoming and elsewhere were concealing the wait time for patients. Last year, Veterans Affairs set a goal for new patients seeking primary care to be seen within 14 days of requesting an appointment.

title: A Familiar Duel for the West Title
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks will not surrender the spotlight in the Western Conference.

title: Poorer Health of Surgery Patients on Medicaid May Alter Laws Bottom Line
description: WASHINGTON  Surgery patients covered by Medicaid arrive at the hospital in worse health, experience more complications, stay longer and cost more than patients with private insurance, a new study has found.

title: Medicines Top Earners Are Not the M.D.s
description: THOUGH the recent release of Medicares physician payments cast a spotlight on the millions of dollars paid to some specialists, there is a startling secret behind Americas health care hierarchy: Physicians, the most highly trained members in the industrys work force, are on average right in the middle of the compensation pack.

title: Glass Warfare
description: Welcome, tenant! We trust that your flight from Moscow, Dubai, London and/or Hong Kong was safe, smooth and private. By now you have had the opportunity to explore the palatial condominium in which your financial advisers have decided to park a modicum of your fortune. We are confident that you will enjoy your new home for whatever portion of the year you will be spending in New York, be it three hours or an entire fortnight.

title: What Farm-to-Table Got Wrong
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y.  ITS spring again. Hip deep in asparagus  and, soon enough, tomatoes and zucchini  farm-to-table advocates finally have something from the farm to put on the table.

title: The Promise, and Pitfalls, of Video
description: ADAM NOSSITERS first response to a now-famous video of the kidnapped Nigerian schoolgirls was caution.

title: Condis Lesson
description: WASHINGTON  THERE has been much mockery of political correctness run amok on college campuses this spring, with knots of know-it-all students and teachers knifing their commencement speakers.

title: Jan Glier Reeder
description: Jan Glier Reeder is a fashion historian and a co-curator of a retrospective of the work of the designer Charles James currently at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: What Do Pregnant Women Want?
description: I AM at the age when many of my friends are pregnant. I thought I had a pretty good idea of what pregnancy entails: the cravings for pickles and chocolate, the abstaining from wine and coffee, the nausea and stretch marks, the aloof but well-meaning husband.

title: Tears of a Rickshaw Driver
description: AS long as I live, Ill never forget the rickshaw driver, tears streaming down his cheeks, rushing a gravely injured student to hospital  and away from the soldiers who had just gunned him down.

title: The Square People, Part 2
description: IN a famous 1995 interview about her dysfunctional marriage and the infidelity of Prince Charles, Princess Diana noted that there were three of us in this marriage, so it was a bit crowded. I find myself thinking of that quote lately to describe the new politics and geopolitics that have been produced by The Square People  all those newly connected and aspiring middle classes who have gathered in the squares from Cairo to Kiev, Istanbul to Tehran, and Tunis to Moscow to demand a greater voice in their future and better governance. A lot of leaders are discovering that these Square People are like a spontaneous third party that has emerged between themselves and their tame traditional opposition and, as a result, their politics is getting a bit crowded  and a lot more interesting.

title: Grading Obamas Foreign Policy
description: SECOND terms are often a time when presidents, balked by domestic opposition, turn to the world stage to secure their legacy  opening doors to China, closing out the Cold War, chasing Middle Eastern peace.

title: South Sudan in Peril
description: Transforming South Sudan into a viable state after it declared independence from Sudan in 2011 was always going to be a huge challenge. President Salva Kiir and rebel commander Riek Machar have made that task vastly more difficult.

title: Children Dont Belong in Tobacco Fields
description: A new report from Human Rights Watch paints a grim picture of child labor in the United States, something that most Americans probably believe was banned years ago. Children as young as 7 are working on tobacco farms in North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia, and many are said to suffer from the symptoms of acute nicotine poisoning.

title: Self-Care Strategies
description: Readers discuss a doctors call for expanded use of mind-body techniques for both financial and health reasons.

title: Class, Cost and College
description: THE word crisis pops up frequently in Ivory Tower, a compelling new documentary about the state of higher education in America.

title: All Blurbed Out
description: LAST month, a disturbance rippled through M.F.A. programs, publishing houses and certain neighborhoods of Brooklyn. Gary Shteyngart, Emperor of Encomia, Prince of Panegyric, Baron of Blurbs, whose breathless endorsements have graced some 150 books in the past decade, was retiring from writing promotional copy for book flaps and covers.

title: A Life Beyond Do What You Love
description: Student advisees often come to my office, rubbing their hands together, furrowing their brows and asking me to walk along with them as they ponder life after graduation. Just the other day, a sophomore made an appointment because he was worrying about whether he should become a doctor or a philosophy professor. A few minutes later, he nervously confessed that he had also thought of giving stand-up comedy a whirl.

title: The House Ducks on Defense
description: The Pentagon has for too long been in denial about the changes it will have to make in a world of declining resources, skyrocketing personnel costs and changing global threats. This year, however, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel presented a more realistic, though still insufficient, cost-saving budget. Yet Congress seems firmly stuck in the past, loyal to campaign donors and frightened, as always, about local political fallout from closing excess military bases, modifying military compensation, reducing troop levels and cutting nonessential or older weapons.

title: Too Soon to Assume Anything in Baseball
description: Baseballs regular season reached its quarter pole on Friday. The 608th game was played, meaning that one-fourth of the 2,430-game schedule was complete.

title: Third Pick Gives Jets an Unofficial Coach
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The play that ruined Dexter McDougles senior season at Maryland did not ruin his life. It dislocated his right shoulder and fractured his scapula and ended his collegiate career and, for a few hours, sent his world tumbling down, as he put it. But he did not pout, and he did not sulk, and he did not withdraw from his teammates, who needed him as much he needed them.

title: A Powerhouse From the Berkshires
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  It is the middle of May, and Alison Swain is doing the same thing she has done for the last seven years: preparing her Williams College womens tennis team to compete in the N.C.A.A. Division III tournament.

title: Arizonas All-Points Bulletin: Who Can Take in a Chihuahua?
description: PHOENIX  A pack of 26 stray Chihuahuas rode 2,400 miles in the back of an S.U.V. in late March, a cross-country trip from an animal shelter here to another just outside Philadelphia, where all but one were adopted in days.

title: Billionaire Democrat Sets Eye on Senate Races
description: Tom Steyer, the billionaire climate activist, recently contributed $5 million to a super PAC dedicated to keeping Democrats in control of the United States Senate, cementing his alliance with the party as the 2014 campaign swings into high gear.

title: Late Recovery Yields an Expected Rematch Between Pacers and Heat
description: It should not be surprising that the two top-seeded teams in the Eastern Conference advanced to the conference finals. Over the 82-game grind of the regular season, the Indiana Pacers and Miami Heat demolished the rest of the conference, and each of their four meetings was billed as a conference final preview.

title: Warning: The Literary Canon Could Make Students Squirm
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Should students about to read The Great Gatsby be forewarned about a variety of scenes that reference gory, abusive and misogynistic violence, as one Rutgers student proposed? Would any book that addresses racism  like The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn or Things Fall Apart  have to be preceded by a note of caution? Do sexual images from Greek mythology need to come with a viewer-beware label?

title: Injuries to Key Players Loom Over Spurs-Thunder Series
description: Two left legs may decide this matchup of the best teams in the Western Conference.

title: Fare Dodging Is an Organized Rebellion in Stockholm, and Its Winning
description: STOCKHOLM  The first target stumbled through the Hornstull metro station here with her nose in her purse, too harried to notice the man sidling up behind her.

title: U.N. Seeking More Ways to Distribute Aid in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations is under pressure to ratchet up aid to nongovernmental organizations that can operate in the vast sections of Syria under opposition control, as most of the humanitarian relief sponsored by the organization ends up in the western slice of the country held by President Bashar al-Assad.

title: A Rangers Forward Amazes an Economist
description: According to a new study from the University of British Columbia, a typical N.H.L. player reaches his peak performance level from 27 to 29, with his best years ranging from 24 to about 34. After that, it is all downhill.

title: An Impenetrable Fortress Proves Porous as the Rangers Take Game 1
description: MONTREAL  For years, Bell Centre was a house of horrors for the Rangers. On Saturday during Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals, it became a house of horrors for the host Montreal Canadiens.

title: Ukrainians Working in Italy Do What They Can to Help
description: ROME  Maryana Tril, one of the more than 192,000 Ukrainians who live and work in Italy, took an unscheduled holiday from her job as a babysitter in February. As the rebellion against the government mounted back home, so did the anguish of being away.

title: Highlights and Analysis: California Chrome Adds Preakness Victory in Triple Crown Quest
description: BALTIMORE  The Kentucky Derby winner California Chrome easily added a victory in the 139th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course, keeping alive his bid to become the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978.

title: Comeback Carries Arsenal to F.A. Cup, Ending a Nine-Year Trophy Drought
description: LONDON  Arsne Wenger is not often an expressive man. Wenger, the longtime Arsenal manager, wears conservative suits while stalking the sideline, and typically has a dour demeanor to match. The Gunners last major trophy came in 2005, and over the past nine years, it was occasionally observed that perhaps Wengers last real smile was spotted around the same time.

title: In Connecticut, Republicans Face Primary in Race to Unseat Governor
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  It was seemingly the perfect place for the state Republican Convention  the Mohegan Sun resort  given the gambling nature of the vote for a candidate to unseat Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat.

title: Libyans Told to Leave City Amid Clashes
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Armed units loyal to a former general in eastern Libya told civilians to leave parts of Benghazi on Saturday as the troops prepared for a new assault on Islamist militias a day after heavy fighting there.

title: After Criticism, Times Publisher Details Decision to Oust Top Editor
description: Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times, released a statement Saturday afternoon detailing his decision to fire the newspapers executive editor, Jill Abramson. He was responding to a growing controversy over accusations by Ms. Abramsons supporters that gender played a role in her dismissal.

title: After Trade to Pittsburgh, a Former Met Finds a Career Renaissance
description: Pittsburgh Pirates Manager Clint Hurdle greets each new player on his team with a meeting in his office. It was no different upon Ike Daviss arrival, even though he had come from a tumultuous situation with the Mets.

title: Oh, Who?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  You can practically hear the shamrocks growing and the Irish coffee (which I know is not really Irish) a-brewing with Joe DiPietros puzzle. Also, I hope you like punny theme entries with Os in them. I know I did.

title: AT&T Is Said to Be Near a Deal to Buy DirecTV
description: AT&T is poised to announce a takeover of DirecTV Inc. within days, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, ushering in another sweeping transformation of the telecommunications industry.

title: Rowing Toward Hope in a Troubled World
description: CHICAGO  When Montana Butsch, the founder of a nonprofit organization that introduces inner-city youth to rowing, visited Daniel Reyess school on the Southwest side four years ago, Reyes had never heard of the sport.

title: Texas Noir, by Directors Who Arent From Texas
description: The new film Cold in July displays all the hallmarks of a country noir, a subgenre perhaps most famously embodied by Joel and Ethan Coens 1984 classic Blood Simple.

title: California Chrome Wins Preakness for Second Jewel
description: BALTIMORE  His big brother Jose was on hand, just as he was two weeks ago for the Kentucky Derby, just as he had always been in the right place at the right time for Victor Espinoza. It was Jose who taught him how to get along with horses when they were children in Mexico.

title: Caregivers Struggle to Untie a Confining Knot
description: Rose Okoro, a nurse practitioner who specializes in family medicine, opened the Daystar Family Clinic in Katy, Tex., in October. Seven months later, she has only enough patients to work there part time.

title: U.S. Title Event Could Be the Old Guards Last Stand
description: Gata Kamsky is the favorite this week to win the United States Championship for the fourth time in five years. But his nearest tournament rivals are closing the talent gap, and it is clear that there will soon be a changing of the guard.

title: Freedom to Act as Election Year Draws to Close
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Time to Exercise, if Not Place to Shower, at State Agencies
description: About 30 employees, from drivers license examiners to forensic scientists, filed into the gym at the Texas Department of Public Safety in Austin during lunch on Wednesday. The group spent half an hour lifting dumbbells to a heavy metal soundtrack, grunting as an instructor corrected their form.

title: After Homer of His Own, Lagares Steals Anothers
description: WASHINGTON  Juan Lagares tried to look serious as he puffed his chest and strutted around center field, but he could not help but grin. He had just sprinted, leapt at the wall and robbed Jayson Werth of a home run in a magnificent display of athleticism  after he had already crushed his own two-run homer.

title: A Restoration Puzzle
description: In Chinas Yungang Grottoes, a team is battling to restore ancient Buddhist artifacts broken by vandals and ravaged by pollution.

title: Outlasting Dynasties, Now Emerging From Soot
description: DATONG, China  The colossal Buddhist statues in the cliffside caves outside this northern Chinese city, carved from golden sandstone by Turkic-speaking nomad conquerors in the fifth and sixth centuries, were so covered in coal dust that when visitors blew on them, black clouds rose up.

title: Deep Ties, Tested on Mexicos Border
description: LAREDO, Tex.  The states standardized test approached like a spring storm, and Alina Quiroga knew her fourth graders could drown. Here at a school about a mile from Mexico along Interstate 35, most of her students rarely speak English outside class. Many, living with distant relatives, lack the confidence to speak up even in Spanish. Ms. Quiroga circled the room, her pearl drop earrings swaying, as the children read aloud about George Washington.

title: The Way North
description: Reporter Damien Cave and photographer Todd Heisler traveled up Interstate 35, from Laredo, Tex., to Duluth, Minn., chronicling how the middle of America is being changed by immigration.

title: William Worthy, a Reporter Drawn to Forbidden Datelines, Dies at 92
description: William Worthy, a foreign correspondent who in the thick of the Cold War ventured where the United States did not want him to go  including the Soviet Union, China, Cuba  and became the subject of both a landmark federal case concerning travel rights and a ballad by the protest singer Phil Ochs, died on May 4 in Brewster, Mass. He was 92.

title: Five Homers Lift Yanks, but Bullpen Doesnt Get Hoped-For Relief
description: It seems almost inconceivable that the Yankees, who spent nearly half a billion dollars in the off-season on free agents, are suddenly dependent on converted relievers to fill out their rotation. But that was where things stood on Saturday afternoon.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 7 to 11 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

title: McDonagh Returns to Top Form Against the Team That Sent Him Away
description: MONTREAL  They could have loved him here, and they would have, too, had Ryan McDonagh remained a member of the Montreal Canadiens organization. It was not his choice to leave five years ago. A trade was made, he was included, and off he went to New York, the Rangers elated that he had done so.

title: Orphan Black Recap: They Are Family
description: No spoiler warning, no episode description, no preview clip could have prepared me for the latest shocking development on this weeks installment of BBC Americas Orphan Black: No Alison! Thats right, everyones favorite cloned suburbanite did not even make an appearance on Saturday. But despite that particular tragedy, there were a few events worthy of discussion.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 17, 2014
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 18, 2014
description: The history of the U.S. until maybe the last generation or two was an east-to-west migration. Now, its south to north, and its on the highways.

title: Corrections: May 18, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Yeney Hernandez, Jason Wu
description: Yeney Hernandez and Jason Wu were married Saturday by Gerald E. Williams, a civil magistrate appointed by the Circuit Court of Arlington County, Va., who officiated in his office in Arlington.

title: Natalie Exner, Ethan Dean
description: Natalie Mae Exner and Ethan Wesley Dean were married Saturday evening at Tupper Manor, an event space in Beverly, Mass. Alan W. Ulrich, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Katie Horn, Samuel Kooris
description: Katie Annette Horn, the daughter of Marjorie E. Horn and Kenneth S. Horn of New York, was married Saturday evening to Samuel Thomas Kooris, the son of Anne L. Levine of Newton Centre, Mass., and Irvin H. Kooris of Marietta, Ga. Rabbi Brian D. Fink led the ceremony at Three Sixty Degrees, an event space in New York.

title: Kendall Swenson, Alexander Lee
description: Kendall Margit Swenson, a daughter of Michele R. Swenson and Gregory D. Swenson of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married Saturday evening to Alexander Decker Lee, a son of Judy M. Lee and Christopher P. Lee of Basking Ridge, N.J. Jason S. Morrison, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the chapel at Windsor, a residential community in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Leigh Ross, Roosevelt Monts
description: Leigh Christine Ross and Roosevelt Bernardo Monts were married Friday at A Voce Madison, a restaurant in New York. Timothy Cassedy, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Lily Kosner and Douglas Mirabello
description: Lily Josephine Kosner, the daughter of Julie Baumgold and Edward Kosner of New York, was married Saturday to Douglas Robert Mirabello, a son of Donna S. Mirabello and Robert B. Mirabello of Haddonfield, N.J. Maureen Duffy-Lewis, a judge of the Los Angeles County Superior Court, officiated at the home of Elizabeth and Richard Berman in Malibu, Calif., friends of the couple.

title: Stephanie Herschaft, Daniel Palmadesso
description: Stephanie Michelle Herschaft and Daniel Richard Palmadesso are to be married Sunday at the Woodlands at Woodbury, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y. Cantor George Lindenblatt is to officiate.

title: Kristina Demas and Enoch Woodhouse III
description: Dr. Kristina Lauren Demas, the daughter of Olivia P. Demas and Dr. William F. Demas of Richfield, Ohio, was married Saturday to Enoch ODell Woodhouse III, the son of Stella S. Woodhouse and Mr. Woodhouse II of Boston. The Rev. Samuel T. Lloyd III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marks Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, with the Rev. Dr. Ronald J. Fowler, a minister of the Church of God, taking part.

title: Ayanna McPhail, Shakur Walker
description: Ayanna Kai McPhail and Shakur Walker are to be married Sunday by Yves Gray, a Universal Life minister, at the Frazer Center in Atlanta.

title: Susan Rennie and Paula Lumbard
description: Susan Rennie and Paula Ann Lumbard were married Friday in their garden in Venice, Calif. Diana Gould, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Amy Hoch, Eric Morrow
description: Dr. Amy Heather Hoch, a daughter of Joyce G. Hoch and Dr. Gerald S. Hoch of Holmdel, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Eric Randall Morrow, the son of Bernice E. Morrow and Dr. Ira S. Morrow of North Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Matthew Reimer officiated at the Pierre hotel in New York.

title: Jessamyn Blau, David Kibler
description: Jessamyn Blau and David Kibler were married Friday at Cheshire, a bar in Rochester. Alexandra S. Epstein, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: They Practiced What They Preach
description: Laurie Anne Davis and Thomas Harry Edwards Jr., both dating coaches, were married Saturday at Artists for Humanity EpiCenter, an event space in Boston. Travis G. Milliken, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Fellowship Church, officiated.

title: Ashwin Phatak, Timothy Wilson Jr.
description: Ashwin Pradyumna Phatak and Timothy Lawrence Wilson Jr. were married Saturday under the District of Columbias self-uniting marriage statute at the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington. That evening, Nisha P. Phatak and Nicholas D. Wilson, a sister and the brother of the couple, led a nondenominational ceremony that incorporated the lighting of a unity candle and included a reading from Nietzsches Joyful Wisdom.

title: Katharine Reiner, Anthony van der Hoorn
description: Katharine Ariel Reiner, the daughter of Terry L. Berenson of New York and the late Charles A. Reiner, is to be married Sunday evening to Anthony Michael van der Hoorn, the son of Julie P. van der Hoorn and Michael J. van der Hoorn, both of Brisbane, Australia. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel is to officiate at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Kari Hexem, Adam Gordon
description: Kari Rebekah Hexem and Adam Michael Gordon are to be married Sunday at the Trebor Garth Estate, a historic home in Bridgeton, N.J. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann is to officiate.

title: Mary Friberg, Robert Wilson
description: Mary Elizabeth Friberg, a daughter of Susan Taubert Friberg of Charleston, S.C., and the late Eric G.
