Friberg, was married at her mothers home Saturday evening to Robert John Wilson, the son of Kathleen A. Lucas and Robert K. Wilson, both of Chesterfield, Mo. Karl A. Friberg, the brides uncle, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Amelia Glover, Paul Therattil
description: Amelia Lee Glover and Dr. Paul Jai Therattil were married Saturday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, Va., by the Rev. Robert L. Banse Jr., the churchs rector. The Rev. Mark Diters, the minister of theFlagg Road UnitedChurchof Christ in West Hartford, Conn., assisted.

title: Margaret Dickson, Andrew Siddons
description: Margaret Shields Dickson, a daughter of Mary Boyle Dickson and John S. Dickson of Pittsfield, Mass., was married in Lancaster, Pa., Friday to Andrew Larry Siddons, the son of Loren Elizabeth Siddons and Larry A. Siddons of Ramsey, N.J. Margaret C. Miller, an aunt of the groom and a judge of the Court of Common Pleas in Lancaster, Pa., officiated at the Lancaster County Courthouse.

title: Susan Shin, Eugene Jang
description: Susan Jungwon Shin and Eugene Jang were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Thomas H. Yorty at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Buffalo.

title: Abigail Teitelbaum and Jason Sheridan
description: Abigail Ilana Teitelbaum and Jason Christopher Sheridan were married Friday by Keith Gugliuzza, a minister of the Spiritual Humanist Church, at the Housing Works Bookstore in Manhattan.

title: Rachel Wolff, Jonathan Sanden
description: Rachel Shana Wolff, a daughter of Dr. Marla A. Mendelson and Stephen S. Wolff of Chicago, was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Bryant Sanden, the son of Elizabeth R. Sanden and John Howard Sanden of Ridgefield, Conn. Dr. Anne Klaeysen, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the powerHouse Arena, a gallery and events space in Brooklyn.

title: Risat Jannat, Imtiyaz Delawala
description: Risat Al Jannat and Imtiyaz Hussain Delawala were married Saturday by Imam Mahmudur Rahman at the clubhouse of the Lakes of Old Peachtree Home Owners Association in Lawrenceville, Ga.

title: Susan Thompson, Alexander Slater
description: Susan Leigh Thompson and Alexander Buck Slater were married Saturday evening at the Inn at Warner Hall in Gloucester, Va., by Thomas E. Davis, a marriage commissioner for Virginia.

title: A Drink Delayed, a Credit Card Denied
description: Mary Grace Northern, a daughter of Mary Lou Northern and Richard Northern of Louisville, Ky., was married Saturday evening to Tyler John Hudson, the son of Elizabeth A. Jenkins and Charles E. Hudson of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. John T. DeBevoise, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral in Louisville.

title: Emilie FitzMaurice, Zachary Rosner
description: Emilie Sarah FitzMaurice, a daughter of Martha S. FitzMaurice and Daniel L. FitzMaurice of West Hartford, Conn., was married Saturday to Dr. Zachary Conway Rosner, the son of Kathlyn M. Conway and David K. Rosner of Manhattan. Barbara Ann Michaels, an interfaith minister ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated at Shadow Lawn, a party space in High Falls, N.Y.

title: Lucy Cox-Chapman, Zachary Dagneau
description: Lucy Morgan Cox-Chapman and Zachary James Marquis Dagneau were married Saturday evening at Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford by the churchs senior pastor, the Rev. Matthew Laney, a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Salma Siddique and Sagor Hoque
description: Dr. Salma Siddique and Sagor Hoque were married Saturday at Villa Lombardis, an event space in Holbrook, N.Y. Imam Khalid Latif performed a Muslim ceremony.

title: Liz Robbins, Ricardo Reif
description: Liz Robbins and Ricardo Boris Reif were married Saturday evening in Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Daniel Fink, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Hevreh of Southern Berkshire.

title: Kathryn Antonacci, Matthew McConnell
description: Kathryn Joan Antonacci and Matthew Welsch McConnell were married Saturday afternoon at St. John Church in Old Saybrook, Conn. The Rev. Kevin Nadolski, a Roman Catholic priest and a friend of the grooms family, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily West and Eric McFeely
description: Emily Suzanne West, a daughter of Amy S. West and Steven A. West of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married on Cape Cod Saturday afternoon to Eric Daniel McFeely, a son of Karen E. McFeely and W. Drake McFeely of Chappaqua, N.Y. James Goodman, an uncle of the groom who received permission from Massachusetts, officiated at the vacation home of the grooms parents in Truro, Mass.

title: Laura Dowling, Marc Altshuler
description: Laura Beth Dowling and Marc Joseph Altshuler were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerks office officiated.

title: North Korea Reports Serious Collapse at Building Project Believed to House Dozens
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A 23-story apartment building that may have housed more than 90 families collapsed last week in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, a South Korean government official said Sunday after the North reported a serious accident at a construction site.

title: Libration Covering a Civil War. Its Own.
description: PARIS  What would Jean-Paul Sartre say?

title: Mapping Our Interiors
description: Sure, thats your office cubicle. Your corner store. Maybe even the layout of your furniture in your living room. But that doesnt mean that soon we wont all be peering at it, too.

title: Youre Not My Real Mother
description: In so many ways, my daughter Julia is a young soon-to-be 12-year-old. Though shes in middle school, shes unconcerned with fashion, boys or other pre-pubescent experimenting. Julia, adopted from a Siberian orphanage at 8 months old, is on track intellectually but is still catching up emotionally. She is a wonderful violinist and artist and an honor student, but she hasnt yet learned how to make a BFF, nor (and I suppose I should be thankful) has she attached herself to a clique. My husband and I are her whole world.

title: Vietnamese Police Block Anti-Chinese Demonstrators After Violence Over Oil Rig
description: HANOI, Vietnam  The Vietnamese government stopped anti-Chinese demonstrators from gathering outside the Chinese Embassy here Sunday, deploying a large number of police officers on the sidewalks around the building and urging the few pedestrians to keep walking.

title: Vows | Dating Coaches in Love
description: Laurie Davis, an online dating expert, reached out to the professional wingman Thomas Edwards to help build her client list, but they ended up using their pickup skills on each other.

title: Police Shoot Armed Man in an East Harlem Housing Project
description: Two police officers on routine patrol in an East Harlem housing development shot and wounded an armed man early Sunday morning, the police said.

title: Marc Andreessen on the Future of Silicon Valley(s), and the Next Big Technology
description: Silicon Valley is starting to feel a little less exuberant these days.

title: Cannes Film Festival: Strauss-Kahn Film Under Fire
description: Updated, 2:50 p.m. | CANNES  Late Saturday night at a beach club here, revelers gathered on the dance floor wearing unique party favors: white terrycloth bathrobes with black monograms that read WTNY. The letters stood for Welcome to New York, Abel Ferraras graphic and barely fictionalized film about the sexual assault case involving Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) 2014 BILLBOARD MUSIC AWARDS Ludacris, above, hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas and honoring Billboard chart toppers from March 11, 2013, through March 9, 2014, in genres including R&B, rap, pop, country, rock, Latin and alternative. Slave to the Rhythm, a never-released Michael Jackson song, is to be performed by a Jackson hologram. Jennifer Lopez will perform and accept the Billboard Icon award, given to an enduring legend in music. Lorde, Miley Cyrus, Ricky Martin, Miranda Lambert, Carrie Underwood, Ariana Grande, Iggy Azalea, 5 Seconds of Summer, Florida Georgia Line, Imagine Dragons, Jason Derulo, John Legend, Luke Bryan, OneRepublic and Pitbull are scheduled to appear.

title: G.M.s Ignition Problem: Who Knew What When
description: Events leading to G.M.s recall of 2.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch.

title: Nine Months Later, Still Working to Find a Job
description: Every night, Sharon Cabelly power-pedals on the exercise bicycle in her bedroom, clearing her head of any angst or anxiety. Then, before bed, she recites her favorite psalms, praying first for others in need and finally for her own peace of mind.

title: A Big Godzilla Has a Big Weekend
description: Fatty? Oh, yes. A remake of Godzilla took in an estimated $93.2 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, a huge No. 1 total that left this version of the radioactive lizard  mocked online in recent weeks for being too chubby  with the last laugh. (Or at least roar.) Godzilla, powered in part by strong Imax and 3-D screenings, cost a reported $195 million to make, with tax credits bringing the net cost closer to $160 million. Legendary Pictures and Warner Brothers collaborated on the picture, but Legendary put up 75 percent of the budget and will thus reap an outsize share of the profits.

title: California Chromes Nasal Strip Could Be an Issue in Belmont
description: BALTIMORE  Would the owners of California Chrome scrap a historic Triple Crown bid over an equipment issue? The trainer Art Sherman raised that possibility Sunday morning, saying the co-owner Perry Martin might decide to hold California Chrome out of the Belmont Stakes if the colt is not allowed to wear a nasal strip for the third leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Johnson Controls to Spin Off Auto Interiors Unit
description: Johnson Controls, the industrial conglomerate based in Milwaukee, said on Sunday that it would spin off its automotive interiors business into a new joint venture with a Chinese partner.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 25
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Court May Hold Fate of Children Knocked Off Citizenship Path
description: Desperate to fill classroom vacancies, New York City school officials sent recruiting teams around the world in the late 1990s, promising jobs and help in obtaining green cards that would be a path to citizenship.

title: The Dark Guest
description: Will China let the beast into the house?

title: Swiss Voters Defeat $24.65 Minimum Wage by a Wide Margin
description: Swiss voters resoundingly rejected on Sunday a proposed minimum wage that would have been the worlds highest, a move widely seen as reflecting an aversion to state intervention in the liberal economic policies that are the bedrock of Switzerlands prosperity.

title: When Going Lean Goes Wrong
description: In recent years, the Lean Startup movement, championed by Eric Ries, has really caught on. This philosophy encourages companies to find winning ideas through efficient cycles of building, measuring and learning, which has led to the widespread adoption of popular concepts like minimum viable products, data-driven decisions and failing fast.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Says Clintons Health and Age Are Fair Issues
description: WASHINGTON  Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, insisted on Sunday that Hillary Rodham Clintons health and age were fair targets for inquiry ahead of a possible 2016 presidential run, as both he and Karl Rove, the Republican strategist who injected those questions into the debate, suggested that such scrutiny might dissuade her from running.

title: Ex-Traders Pilgrimage Culminates in Jail Cell
description: PARIS  Two days after suspending what he had billed as an almost spiritual trek from Vatican City to Paris, the convicted rogue trader Jrme Kerviel crossed from Italy into France on Sunday and turned himself in to the French authorities, minutes before a midnight deadline.

title: Five Unite So the Future Will Know Their Tunes
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center has not only been commissioning new music but also assembling new, high-concept ensembles. For the New Jazz Standards quintet, which made its debut on Friday night in Jazz at Lincoln Centers Appel Room, melody was paramount. The quintet is an all-star group of composers whose daunting task was to come up with 21st-century jazz standards.

title: Deutsche Bank Plans to Raise $11 Billion in Fresh Capital
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Sunday that it would raise roughly $11 billion in new capital from existing shareholders and the royal family of Qatar, responding to regulatory pressure on banks to reduce risk.

title: Short Pieces That, Together, Span Centuries
description: In his late 50s, Brahms kept threatening to quit composing. But he could not help himself. Among the works he wrote during his last years were four collections of shorter pieces for piano, composed in 1892 and 1893. (He died in 1897, a month before turning 64.) Though these late piano pieces are ingenious, consequential and even experimental compositions, displaying a bit of impishness, Brahms called many of them intermezzos  a category that implies a short piece meant to be performed between longer ones.

title: Teams Split, as Do Many Fans
description: Shortly after the start of the second game of Sundays single-admission doubleheader between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates, it became evident that neither the teams nor the fans at Yankee Stadium were prepared for a daylong event that was a relic of another era.

title: Paul Rudd to Play Einstein at World Science Festival
description: After appearing in celebrations of dimwittedness like Our Idiot Brother, Dinner for Schmucks and Anchorman, Paul Rudd is taking on the ultimate high-I.Q. role: Albert Einstein.

title: AT&T to Buy DirecTV for $48.5 Billion in Move to Expand Clout
description: Updated, 10:06 p.m. |

title: In Last-Ditch Bid, Pfizer Offers $119 Billion for AstraZeneca
description: Pfizer has again raised its offer for AstraZeneca, making what it said was a final effort to bring the giant British drug maker to the negotiating table.

title: Sega and Nintendo Wage Battle That Was No Game
description: Video games have emerged as a vibrant, imaginative pursuit, the art form at the intersection of computers and interactivity. But they are also a business, one that was built by people with experience making and selling toys, consumer electronics and coin-operated amusements like pinball machines.

title: The Mighty Warriors Set Sail: Three Translations
description: TOLKIEN IN PROSE From J. R. R. Tolkiens 1926 prose translation of Beowulf, to be published this week:

title: Drugs Found to Aid Breathing in a Fatal Lung Disease
description: For the first time, researchers have found drugs that can slow the decline of people with a fatal lung disease, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

title: Waving His Wand at Beowulf
description: Theres more to J. R. R. Tolkien than wizards and hobbits. The author of The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit was also an Oxford University professor specializing in languages like Old Norse and Old English.

title: Obama Angry Over Falsification of Veterans Affairs Data, Chief of Staff Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is madder than hell about reports that some medical facilities run by the Department of Veterans Affairs have falsified data to hide substantial delays for veterans to see doctors, and he has demanded that the departments leaders fix these things, the White House chief of staff said in an interview aired Sunday.

title: First, Voices, Then Bodies
description: If you dont speak Portuguese or French, its hard to understand, in the conventional sense, the first half of Emmanuelle Huynhs A Vida Enorme/pisode 1. For about 20 minutes, two disembodied voices, male and female, converse in those voluptuous languages, broadcast from a stack of speakers in the middle of the otherwise empty space. The only activity happens in the form of light, which slowly fades and intensifies, singling out features of the sanctuary at St. Marks Church. The program contains English translations of the text, by the Portuguese poet Herberto Hlder, but how necessary are these? The sensuousness of the voices, their texture, say a lot in themselves.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of May 19
description: MAJOR RETAILERS SET TO REPORT EARNINGS

title: North Miami Fights to Keep Its Art Museum
description: NORTH MIAMI, Fla.  Anyone looking to meet the director of the tiny but highly regarded Museum of Contemporary Art here has two choices. Head into the museum, where its interim director, Alex Gartenfeld, has an office. Or go next door to City Hall, where the city managers appointee to the same position, Babacar MBow, is essentially working in exile.

title: Spotted at Cannes: Ice to Go With Steam
description: CANNES, France  Gabe! Gabe! Slava Fetisov, the former ice hockey god, was yelling across the sun-splashed courtyard at the director Gabe Polsky. A loud mechanical noise had begun whirring near Mr. Fetisov as he was being interviewed about Red Army, Mr. Polskys documentary about the rise and fall of Soviet hockey that is playing at the Cannes Film Festival. Mr. Fetisov  who helped lead the Soviet team to two Olympic gold medals and one silver as well as seven world championships in the 1970s and 80s  wanted his director to deal with it.

title: A Spring Season Unfolds With a Youthful Flourish
description: The dancing of New York City Ballet this spring has abounded in debuts and revelations. The illustrious Sara Mearns has reached new heights of eloquence. At two performances over the weekend she finally conquered the lofty ballerina role of the adagio second movement of George Balanchines Symphony in C. Its a part shes danced for years, but with a certain tension that has held her back. This time, partnered superlatively by Jared Angle (making his debut in this part), she demonstrated a tragic glamour and courage that bound everyone in her spell.

title: Going for Visceral Excitement in Popular Standbys
description: Recent reports on the activities of the eminent Latvian maestro Mariss Jansons raised questions, if not necessarily concerns, about the state of his health.

title: Cashless Customers Hold Riches for Retailers
description: Standing in line at Starbucks, customers are presented with an array of options beyond just flavors and foam: They can pay with cash, credit, debit, a Starbucks card or with their mobile phone in two different ways.

title: One Whose Work is Taxing
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Do you hear all the noise? Would someone please pick up that PHONE? It gets a little loud when PHONEs start RINGing inside the confines of a 15 x 15 crossword puzzle, so well just have to shout to be heard.

title: For Six Hours at a Festival, the Sound of Extremes Colliding
description: Hardcore Activity in Progress, a one-night, 15-act concert Friday at the Knockdown Center in Maspeth, Queens, represented an idea. The idea was the sound of extremes  going for it, boundary-testing, hardness  across musical languages. So, for instance, there was the noise band Wolf Eyes, the cello improviser Okkyung Lee, the grindcore group Napalm Death, the rapper Gunplay, the post-minimal piano rhapsodist Lubomyr Melnyk, the free-jazz trio the Thing, and the electronic musician Tim Hecker, presented in overlapping sets, in three different parts of a 50,000-square-foot former door-frame factory.

title: Slapdash Play Slaps Mets Psyche and Dashes Perceptions of Progress
description: WASHINGTON  Not much seemed to separate the Mets and the Nationals on Sunday. Neither starting pitcher was at his best, which created opportunities for both teams as the afternoon crawled along. Ultimately, the Nationals won, 6-3.

title: A Great Bid in Semifinals for USA-1 in Atlanta
description: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next years Bermuda Bowl world championship, in India, has reached the last match.

title: Student Debt Grows Faster at Universities With Highest-Paid Leaders, Study Finds
description: At the 25 public universities with the highest-paid presidents, both student debt and the use of part-time adjunct faculty grew far faster than at the average state university from 2005 to 2012, according to a new study by the Institute for Policy Studies, a left-leaning Washington research group.

title: Sailing Rios Spoiled Bay
description: Two years ahead of the 2016 Summer Olympics, sailors on Rios Guanabara Bay train in water tainted by sewage runoff and garbage from poor neighborhoods.

title: How DNA Changed the World of Forensics
description: Before DNA testing, prosecutors relied on less sophisticated forensic techniques, including microscopic hair analysis, to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was hair analysis?

title: Note to Olympic Sailors: Dont Fall in Rios Water
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Nico Delle Karth, an Austrian sailor preparing for the 2016 Summer Olympics, said it was the foulest place he had ever trained.

title: DNA Analysis Exposes Flaws in an Inexact Forensic Science
description: By now  despite the apparent infallibility of detectives from Sherlock Holmes to Lieutenant Columbo, despite the clinical genius of wizards from Dr. Quincy to Gil Grissom  it should surprise no one that forensic science is not the model of exactitude that popular culture might have us believe. The scientific rigor of entrenched forensic disciplines has been challenged for years. Still, we live in a C.S.I. world, and television viewers could be forgiven for assuming that laboratory techniques used to catch bad guys are unassailable. In real life, though, the soundness of criminal analysis is being regularly tested, both in Americas labs and in its courtrooms.

title: Composed Pacers Muscle Past the Heat
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Change the narrative. Alter the perception. Convince the basketball-viewing world that the team with the best record this season in the Eastern Conference could actually make it to the N.B.A. finals.

title: Blackstone to Sell Boston Office Buildings for $2.1 Billion
description: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Blackstone Group has agreed to sell five office properties in the Boston area for $2.1 billion, disposing of part of a sprawling real estate portfolio it bought before the financial crisis, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

title: Blackhawks Edge Ahead, Creating Traffic at Net
description: CHICAGO  When Chicago Blackhawks Coach Joel Quenneville is asked how to beat top goalies like Jonathan Quick, he preaches traffic in front of the net. That strategy worked twice for Chicago on Sunday, even though the most memorable goal might have been one that did not count.

title: On Anniversary, a Victory Parade and a Crackdown in Sri Lanka
description: NEW DELHI  Sri Lankas government on Sunday marked the fifth anniversary of its victory over Tamil insurgents with a military parade in the south and a broad crackdown on journalists, opposition politicians and students in the once-restive north and east.

title: BlackBerrys Partnership With Foxconn Signals Shifting Priorities
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesians have long loved BlackBerry devices. When the company introduced a new phone two and a half years ago, a crowd at shopping mall here became so unruly  in part because of a half-price offer for the first 1,000 buyers  that riot police were rushed in to stand by.

title: Djokovic Tops Nadal, Closing on No. 1 Spot
description: ROME  Novak Djokovic defeated the world No. 1 and seven-time Italian Open champion Rafael Nadal, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, in the mens final at Campo Centrale on Sunday.

title: Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  Sitting in the headquarters of the Wyoming Liberty Group, Susan Gore, founder of the conservative think tank, said new national science standards for schools were a form of coercion, adding, I dont think government should have anything to do with education.

title: N.B.A.s On-Court Leader Embraces Off-Court Mantle Without Fear
description: The N.B.A. might have breathed a sigh of relief last week when the Los Angeles Clippers were knocked out of the playoffs. The loss allowed the league to temporarily brush aside the embarrassing Donald Sterling fiasco. Sterling was barred for life by Commissioner Adam Silver and threatened with the forced sale of his team after the release of recordings in which he chided a female friend for associating with black people.

title: The Republican War on Workers Rights
description: Midterm elections are like fancy software: Experts love them, end-users couldnt care less. But if the 2010 elections are any indication, we might not want to doze off as we head into the summer months before November. Midterm elections at the state level can have tremendous consequences, especially for low-wage workers. What you dont know can hurt you  or them.

title: An Experiment: Is the Professor Biased?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking How Antibiotics Are Used and Developed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gift of Reading, to Last a Lifetime
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Data and Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking the National Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: Walden Media, PG Filmmaker, Seeks Studio Partners Across Cultural Divide
description: LOS ANGELES  William Wilberforce, the English abolitionist of two centuries ago, believed in the power of co-belligerents: those who fight for a common cause while disagreeing forcefully on most everything else.

title: Horse Racing Holds Its Breath Over a Nasal Strip
description: BALTIMORE  The name California Chrome sounds as if it belongs to a Triple Crown champion  it holds its own alongside Sir Barton and War Admiral, Citation and Secretariat. California Chrome looks the part as well, with his sculpted muscles and shiny-as-a-penny coat.

title: At F.B.I., Change in Leaders Didnt Change Focus on Terror
description: WASHINGTON  When James B. Comey was nominated last June to be director of the F.B.I., it seemed to herald the beginning of a new era at the bureau.

title: Killings Surge in North Bronx, Testing New Police Tactics
description: A teenager gunned down next to a Bronx playground. A U-Haul truck riddled with bullets after a deadly shootout that involved as many as five gunmen. A tattooed 25-year-old from Massachusetts executed, with three shots to the head, one to the back, on a housing project roof.

title: Political Procedurals Play Starring Role in Fall TV Season
description: IF the 2014-15 television season were to have a theme song, it might be Hail to the Chief  no, make that Chiefs.

title: Rangers Show Support for St. Louis at His Mothers Funeral
description: The Rangers attended the funeral of Martin St. Louiss mother, France St. Louis, on Sunday afternoon in Laval, Quebec, just outside Montreal.

title: Poverty Is Not a State of Mind
description: Paul Ryan and Jeb Bush, the didactic-meets-dynastic duo, spoke last week at a Manhattan Institute gathering, providing a Mayberry-like prescription for combating poverty in this country: all it takes is more friendship and traditional marriage.

title: Some Canadiens Fault Kreiders Collision
description: MONTREAL  The Montreal Canadiens may need a villain in order to play at their best, and on Sunday, they seemed to find one: the big, fast Rangers forward Chris Kreider.

title: Springtime for Bankers
description: By any normal standard, economic policy since the onset of the financial crisis has been a dismal failure. Its true that we avoided a full replay of the Great Depression. But employment has taken more than six years to claw its way back to pre-crisis levels  years when we should have been adding millions of jobs just to keep up with a rising population. Long-term unemployment is still almost three times as high as it was in 2007; young people, often burdened by college debt, face a highly uncertain future.

title: A Jihadists Face Taunts Nigeria From the Shadows
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  He was the quiet one who walked silently to meet fellow disciples in a house by the railroad tracks, declining to greet other men on the street. But when he became agitated  over taking up arms against the government, or about his hatred of Christians and Jews  it was no use arguing with Abubakar Shekau.

title: A Martial Art, Renewed
description: The ancient martial art of muay boran is making a comeback in Thailand, in the form of the first world championship tournament.

title: Photos: Old Art, New Title
description: Muay boran is an ancient, unarmed martial art that forms the basis of muay thai boxing, the national sport of Thailand. Muay boran entails strikes with eight contact points (hands, elbows, knees and shins), grappling sweeps and throws.

title: Europes Migration Emergency
description: Italys interior minister, Angelino Alfano, has given the European Union an ultimatum: Either step in to help Italy cope with the waves of African migrants who risk drowning in the Mediterranean to reach its shores or Italy will begin sending the people it rescues to neighboring European countries. After the sinking of an overloaded boat last week  206 people were rescued off the coast of Italy, 17 bodies were recovered, and an unknown number are missing  the European Commission responded. It said Italy should communicate what it expects. This is not an acceptable response.

title: In Coins, Man Found a Century of Learning
description: In 1918, when he was 7, Eric P. Newmans grandfather gave him a strange old penny.

title: Do Better on Predatory Colleges
description: The Obama administrations proposed rules that would deny federal aid to career training programs that saddle students with crushing debt and useless credentials are a clear improvement over the disastrous status quo. But they will need to be strengthened to fully protect students and taxpayers from predatory for-profit schools that rely on federal student aid for up to 90 percent of their revenue and are well versed in the art of evading the law.

title: Judges and Justice for Sale
description: Judicial elections have always been a bad idea. The special-interest money unleashed by recent Supreme Court rulings has made them even worse, greatly increasing the influence of political-action committees and supposedly independent groups financed by corporations, unions and other interests with issues before the courts.

title: Behind the Scenes in Hollywoods Power Circles, Another Political Adviser
description: LOS ANGELES  Dee Dee Myers, a former Clinton administration spokeswoman, is headed for Warner Bros. Mark Fabiani, another political veteran, has agreed to advise the boycott-plagued Beverly Hills Hotel. And, as it turns out, yet another high-powered political player, Craig Schirmer, has been working behind the scenes at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: More Specious Attacks on Reform
description: Conservative critics of President Obamas health care reforms are engaged in two long-shot lawsuits to overturn the Affordable Care Act or disable one of its central provisions. Both lawsuits should be recognized for what they really are  attempts to use the courts to scuttle a law that Congressional Republicans have repeatedly tried, but failed, to repeal through the political process.

title: How Strong Is the Tea Party?
Front-Runner in Ukraine Election May Be Shifting Putins Stance
description: KIEV, Ukraine  On a Sunday in December when the Ukrainian uprising seemed about to tip into wide-scale violence, Petro Poroshenko, a pro-Western billionaire, thrust himself between antigovernment protesters and riot police officers clashing outside the presidential headquarters, climbed on a bulldozer that was threatening to plow through the crowd and grabbed an orange plastic megaphone.

title: A High-Five Long and Wide
description: Kawhi Leonard is different. Jeff Ayres, a reserve center with the San Antonio Spurs, arrived at this conclusion during a game this season.

title: Betty Sherrill, Decorator to the White-Shoed and Wealthy, Dies at 91
description: Betty Sherrill, a socialite from the South who helped define the aesthetics of quiet wealth in New York for almost 40 years as the doyenne of McMillen Inc., the citys oldest interior design firm, died on May 12 in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Vows
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed on Monday to disband her countrys Coast Guard, saying that South Korea owed reform and a great transformation to hundreds of high school students who died in a ferry disaster last month.

title: Glass Ceilings in Statehouses in the Northeast
description: PHILADELPHIA  The industrial Northeast enjoys a reputation as a cradle of liberalism, a region that voted overwhelmingly for Americas first black president, started the push on same-sex marriage rights and can reliably be found at the forefront of causes for equality. But there is a notable gap: The Democratic Party has yet to elect a female governor in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island or Massachusetts.

title: Turkey Arrests Several Executives Over Mining Disaster
description: ISTANBUL  Under pressure from a public angered by the worst mining accident in Turkeys history, Turkish authorities on Sunday detained 25 people and arrested at least three mining company executives after an initial investigation suggested that the company had failed to heed safety warnings, the local prosecutors office said.

title: Abramsons Exit at The Times Puts Tensions on Display
description: Back in 2010, before she became executive editor of The New York Times, Jill Abramson sent me a handwritten attaboy note about a big story. It still hangs in my cubicle: You wrote a story about the trashing of a once great American institution and people never tire of that.

title: Workers at N.Y.U.s Abu Dhabi Site Faced Harsh Conditions
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  The strike had entered its second day when construction workers at Labor Camp 42 got word that their bosses from the BK Gulf corporation had come to negotiate. Mohammed Amir Waheed Sirkar, an electrician from Bangladesh, scrambled down the stairs to meet them. But when he got to the courtyard, he saw the truth: It wasnt the bosses who had come. It was the police.

title: Letter of Termination
description: The visa cancellation for a Bangladeshi worker from New York Universitys Saadiyat Island campus, one of hundreds sent home because of refusal to work last October. The men, employees of the BK Gulf company, went on strike, which is illegal in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Patch Sites Turn Corner After Sale and Big Cuts
description: In January, when AOL announced that it was handing over the majority stake in Patch, its troubled hyperlocal news division, to an investment firm, it seemed like the end of a long, tragic story.

title: Philippine Fishermen Caught in Geopolitical Tussle
description: Chinas claim to a coveted fishing area in the South China Sea is endangering the economy of a Philippine fishing town.

title: A Leviathan Turns Philippine Fishermen Into Desperate Darters
description: MASINLOC, the Philippines  On a scorching recent afternoon, fishermen from this sleepy Philippine town hauled blocks of ice onto a rickety, wooden fishing boat bobbing just off the shore. By nightfall, the boat would be on its way to coveted fishing grounds, and to a cat-and-mouse game with the Chinese Coast Guard.

title: 2 Heroines Braving Challenges
description: At some time or another, English majors have to deal with character and fate in the novels of Thomas Hardy.

title: Vacation? The Show Will Still Go On
description: Whats love got to do with it? Audrey Langham, an actress of modest fame and exceptional survival skills, has just set eyes on a man who might do nicely as her sixth husband. Or would it be her seventh? Audrey, played by the remarkable Linda Lavin in Nicky Silvers Too Much Sun at the Vineyard Theater, is fuzzy on personal math.

title: Ex-General Claims Responsibility for Libyan Parliament Attack
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A retired Libyan general claimed responsibility for an attack on the Parliament building here on Sunday, two days after his irregular force launched an attack aimed at eradicating powerful Islamist militias from the eastern city of Benghazi.

title: Long Day at the Stadium
description: The first single-admission Sunday double-header at Yankee Stadium since April 13, 1997.

title: Popular Demand
description: A strong weekend depends on factors like other potential blockbusters, star power and popular sequels. Fast and Furious 6 opened opposite The Hangover III last year, and in the second week of Star Trek Into Darkness.

title: Scheduling Oddity Is Product of Rainout
description: Two of the oldest franchises in baseball took the field Sunday at Yankee Stadium to take part in one of the pastimes fading traditions. Fans in yellow Roberto Clemente jerseys and pinstriped Mickey Mantle shirts walked through the turnstiles holding a rarity in their hands: tickets to a single-admission Sunday doubleheader.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of May 19
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Afghan Lovers Plight Shaking Up the Lives of Those Left in Their Wake
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  However matters eventually turn out for the Afghan Romeo and Juliet who eloped into hiding, a happily-ever-after ending is eluding many of those whose lives crossed theirs.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 18, 2014
As U.S. Looks to Nuclear Deal, Book Faults Handling of Iranian Defector
description: WASHINGTON  To those who lost loved ones in the suicide bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, in April 1983, it is often called the forgotten bombing  overshadowed by an even deadlier attack on a Marine barracks at the Beirut airport six months later.

title: Uprising at a French Paper
description: A memo sent to shareholders this year said the papers new owners wanted to eliminate the print edition and publish only on digital platforms.

title: For Long Island Rail Road, a Track Record to Tout: Matching Riders With Lost Items
description: In the corner sits a safe filled with jewelry. Along the walls, shelves are stacked with duffel bags and backpacks. Elsewhere there are piles of lost or abandoned smartphones. And then there is the carbon-fiber leg.

title: Catastrophic Floods Hit Balkans, Raising Fears for Land Mines and Power Plants
description: WARSAW  At least 33 people have died and tens of thousands have been evacuated in Serbia and Bosnia during three days of torrential rains that fed the most intense flooding the region has seen since records began to be kept more than a century ago.

title: Chief of Syrias Air Defense Dies in Battle Near Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The general in charge of Syrias air defense has been killed in fighting near Damascus, an opposition monitoring group and Syrian security officials said Sunday.

title: Penny Dreadful Recap: Cue the Seance
description: As anyone who ever had a friend with a Ouija board in high school can tell you, there was invariably at least one party that got a little  discombobulated thanks to said friends appearance. Not enough to break any mirrors or conjure any succubi or anything, just enough to have some other friends leave early, muttering about that weird [gender redacted] [name redacted] acting a fool in the basement.

title: Divergent Accounts of Plea Negotiations in an Occupy Wall Street Protesters Assault Case
description: The outrage among Occupy Wall Street sympathizers about the prosecution of Cecily McMillan for assaulting a police officer during a protest in Zuccotti Park has rested largely on a single idea: that zealous prosecutors, seeking to make an example of Ms. McMillan, had refused during negotiations to let her plead guilty to anything less than a felony.

title: Game of Thrones Recap: Through the Moon Door
description: Here be spoilers penned by a pinch-hitting spoilerette; Jeremy Egner will return next week.

title: Don Meyer, a Coach With 923 Victories, Is Dead at 69
description: Don Meyer, the head mens basketball coach at Northern State University in Aberdeen, S.D., was taking his players to a team retreat in September 2008 when his car collided head-on with a truck.

title: Robert F. Erburu, Who Led Times Mirror Company, Dies at 83
description: Robert F. Erburu, who as chief executive and chairman of the Times Mirror Company helped it become a diverse and powerful media enterprise that expanded well beyond its flagship property, The Los Angeles Times, before the paper and the company were sold, died on May 11 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 83.

title: Sidney J. Blatt Dies at 85; Developed Double Helix Theory of Depression
description: Sidney J. Blatt, a psychologist whose theory about the origins of depression guided treatment decisions for a generation of psychotherapists and helped deepen scientists appreciation of the diverse nature of chronic distress, died on May 11 in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.

title: Times Minute | Early Cannes Standouts
description: Also on the Minute, the Supreme Court could decide today whether it is possible to age out of the immigration system and Brazil faces unprecedented criticism ahead of the 2016 Summer Olympic Games.

title: Photo Replay: May 11-17
description: Athletes fully extended, though not always successfully.

title: This Summer, Safety First
description: Heeding some basic safety tips this summer could help to keep you and your companions in the game and out of the emergency room.

description: peripheral \p-ri-f(-)rl\ adjective and noun

title: Jerry Vale, Who Crooned Smoothly of Love, Is Dead at 83
description: Jerry Vale, a pop crooner known for his velvety voice and the classic love songs he recorded in the 1950s and early 60s, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 83.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) THE MAYA RUDOLPH SHOW In this newfangled take on the classic television variety show, Ms. Rudolph, left, uses the comedy skills she perfected on Saturday Night Live in sketches with Andy Samberg, Kristen Bell, Fred Armisen, Chris Parnell, Craig Robinson and Sean Hayes. Janelle Mone is the musical guest. Raphael Saadiq is the bandleader.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Note From the Cat Sitter
description: Dear Diary:

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 19, 2014
description: It can get really disgusting, with dog carcasses in some places and the water turning brown from sewage contamination.

title: A Restoration Puzzle
description: It was 1974 when a provincial archaeology institute was doing an excavation in a small village in the heart of Chinas coal country. The team had lost a cap to one of its measuring tools. They asked a local resident, Zhang Juncai, if he could make another.

title: Ryanair Feels the Squeeze as Rivals Lower Fares
description: PARIS  A decade of uninterrupted growth for the European budget airline Ryanair stalled last year, the company confirmed on Monday, as the regions flagging economy and high unemployment drove more rival carriers into the race for cost-conscious travelers.

title: AstraZeneca Snubs Pfizer Once More
description: Updated, 10:36 p.m. | LONDON AstraZeneca has to hope it can deliver on its vaunted drug pipeline.

title: Reporters on Gutter Oil Series Assaulted, Peoples Daily Says
description: Peoples Daily, the mouthpiece of the Communist Party, says its reporters were attacked and robbed on Sunday while investigating gutter oil, waste cooking oil that is illegally recycled and sold to unwitting consumers.

title: Analysts Have High Hopes for Big Economic Changes Under Modi
description: MUMBAI  Now that the Bharatiya Janata Party and Narendra Modi have won parliamentary elections, voters and foreign investors are expecting Mr. Modi, the front-runner for prime minister, to quickly shore up an economy that has been sputtering for some time.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Schools and Segregation, 60 Years After Brown vs. Board of Education
description: Saturday marked sixty years to the day since the U.S. Supreme Court handed down its decision in the Brown vs. Board of Education case, outlawing separate but equal schools for blacks and whites.

title: Cocooning at Home in Hong Kong
description: A short flight from Vietnam to Hong Kong to renew his visa in 1994 turned into almost a decade of work for Peter Steinhauer.

title: Should Discomfort Excuse Students From Having to Complete an Assignment?
description: Some colleges and universities are considering how to respond to students who request being excused from certain assignments on the grounds that the content of a book, film or other work may upset them or even trigger symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder. Some are considering making it mandatory for professors to warn students in advance about texts whose graphic nature could be upsetting.

title: Theres a Better Way to Measure Who Has Raised the Most Money
description: It seems like a simple question: Who has raised more money this cycle, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida or Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky? But its not very simple, although there is a way to tally it that makes sense in the real world of campaigning.

title: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed on Monday to disband her countrys coast guard, saying that South Korea owed reform and a great transformation to hundreds of high school students who died in a ferry disaster last month.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: Smell of the City
description: Good morning to you on this clear Monday.

title: In Our Pages: May 19
description: 1939 Gunfire Marks Bloody Harlan Coal Mine War

title: Demography and the Bicycle Effect
description: When Alvin Hansen first proposed the concept of secular stagnation, he emphasized the role of slowing population growth in depressing investment demand (and his warnings were made moot by the postwar baby boom.) Modern discussions return to that emphasis: Japans shrinking working-age population looks like an important source of its problems, and slowing population growth in Europe and America are important reasons to believe that we may be entering a similar regime.

title: After the Election: Writers Weigh in
description: Below are a selection of opinions and analyses on Narendra Modis Bharatiya Janata Party winning an absolute majority in the parliamentary elections on Friday.

title: That 80s Show
description: Ive been giving various talks and fireside chats here in Oxford, and one thing I keep coming back to is the pivotal role of the 1980s in the development of economic thought.

title: Among Polling Firms, Only One Got the Indian Elections Right
description: NEW DELHI  After the final vote was cast on May 12, exit polls pointed to a win by the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party led by its candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi. But only one polling firm, Todays Chanakya, predicted the magnitude of both the B.J.P.s victory and the governing Indian National Congress partys loss.

title: What to Watch for in Three Primaries
description: Not much matters six months before a midterm election, but Tuesdays primaries are an exception. Republicans will have an opportunity to nominate candidates in three potentially competitive Senate contests: in Kentucky, Georgia and Oregon. Heres what you need to know. [Update: We are following the primaries with tweets from Times reporters and others, here.]

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, May 19, 2014
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, and the Times Soccer section is counting down the days.

title: A Good Deed Crosses Two Cultures
description: Several years ago, I was huddled quietly in the gate area of an airport, waitingto board my flight. An older gentleman walked over, handed me a cup of coffee and said, Everything will be O.K.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | May 19, 2014
description: Update: May 20

title: Behind the Cover Story: Paul Tough on Keeping College Kids in College
description: Paul Tough wrote this weeks cover story about an experiment at the University of Texas to close the graduation gap between advantaged and disadvantaged students. Tough, a former editor at the magazine, is the author of two book about education, most recently How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity and the Hidden Power of Character.

title: The Advisers Behind the Deal for DirecTV
description: Updated, 10:13 a.m. |

title: Chinas Pollution Challenge
description: Chinas national legislature has adopted sweeping changes to the countrys Environmental Protection Law, revisions that have been hailed as major steps toward saving Chinas environment from rampant degradation.

title: AT&Ts Move for DirecTV
description: AT&T agreed on Sunday to buy the satellite television operator DirecTV for $48.5 billion in a bid to tilt the balance of power with media companies as the market for broadband Internet and video shifts, Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles write in DealBook. With the acquisition, AT&T becomes the latest telecommunications giant seeking to establish an even greater reach.

title: Boko Haram Suspected in Attack on Chinese Workers in Cameroon
description: Ten Chinese workers in northern Cameroon are missing following an attack last week by gunmen, the Chinese Embassy in the West African country said.

title: South Korea Searches for Answers
description: The April 16 ferry disaster in South Korea that left 304 people dead or missing did more than cause immediate outrage. It also forced ordinary Koreans to examine themselves and their country, and what they saw was a society and a national government that were not nearly as well put together as they and the rest of the world had believed.

title: A Navigation Program Switches to Maps Made by Volunteers
description: Crowdsourcing is used to rate restaurants in Rotterdam, dentists in Duluth and contractors in Kalamazoo. But should you trust free, user-generated content to find your way home?

title: 5 in China Army Face U.S. Charges of Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  In the Obama administrations most direct confrontation with China over its theft of corporate secrets, the Justice Department on Monday unsealed an indictment of five members of the Chinese Peoples Liberation Army and charged them with hacking into the networks of Westinghouse Electric, the United States Steel Corporation and other companies.

title: A Rare, Partial Victory in Saving Remnants of Old Beijing
description: As a 10-year-old boy, Cui Jinze remembers sitting on the desk of his grandfather, a local Communist Party official in Daxing, on Beijings southern outskirts, entranced by a map on the wall that marked the citys palaces, temples and libraries with the character gu (), or ancient.

title: Syria Death Toll Reported to Rise By 10,000 in Less Than 2 Months
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The death toll in the three-year Syrian conflict has risen to about 162,000, an increase of more than 10,000 in less than two months, according to an antigovernment monitoring group that is one of the few organizations still attempting to keep an exact count.

title: Two Police Officers Shoot and Kill a Brooklyn Man
description: Hours after police officers shot and wounded a man in East Harlem, two uniformed officers killed a man in a Brooklyn apartment on Sunday, the police said, after he lunged at the officers with a pair of scissors.

title: Cheating Death, and the Rumor Mill, in North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Hyon Song-wol is not quite North Koreas version of Beyonc. But as a popular singer and leader of the nations best-known girl band, which often performs in miniskirts, she attracts plenty of attention. Last Friday, millions watched on national television as she saluted the countrys leader, Kim Jong-un, for his heavenly trust and warm care in promoting the arts.

title: The Education of a Foreign Correspondent
description: Rick Lyman, who has been a reporter and editor at The Times since 1997, is reopening its bureau in Central and Eastern Europe. He will be based in Warsaw and responsible for covering more than a dozen nations in the region, from Estonia and the other Baltic States down to Slovenia on the Italian border. A former international correspondent, based in South Africa, he has most recently been a national correspondent based in New York, but has previously been an editor, a political correspondent and the Houston bureau chief and covered both the movie industry in Los Angeles and the theater in New York. We asked him about his approach to his new beat.

title: Kremlin Announces Ukraine Pullback, but NATO Doesnt See It
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin announced Monday that President Vladimir V. Putin had ordered Russian troops conducting exercises along the Ukrainian border to return to their home bases at the conclusion of the drills, apparently sending another loud signal that Russia is not planning any military action in eastern Ukraine ahead of that countrys presidential elections on Sunday.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Charges in Chinese Cyberespionage
description: The tensions between the United States and China over accusations over cyberespionage have reached a new level. The Justice Department is expected to announce charges Monday against several individuals in the Peoples Liberation Army, accusing them of stealing trade secrets from American companies, Michael S. Schmidt of The New York Times reports.

title: In Push for Deal, Ackman Aims at Allergan Chief
description: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | William A. Ackman, the activist investor who is trying to bring two drug companies together in a merger, is reaching into his customary toolbox to apply pressure to his target.

title: In Appeal, Scrutiny on Not One but 3 Confessions
description: WASHINGTON  Even Billy Wayne Copes supporters say the police had good reason to think he had committed a depraved murder.

title: Apiece Apart Debuts With J. Crew
description: Starr Hout and Laura Cramer of Apiece Apart create clothes that allow the wearer to be stylish without all the hassle of styling. The designers of thesix-year-old New York-based label(members of Ts Nifty 50 in 2010) offer chic, reasonably pricedlayers and separates that mix and match to accommodate a simplified lifestyle, they write in an email. We envisioned the wardrobe to go with that life, just a few perfect pieces that could be packed in a single bag. Slowly but surely, those pieces have developed a following among creative women  the sort who might appreciate the design and architecture on Apiece Aparts worth-bookmarking blogand in their seasonal printed zine  with better things to do than fret about what to throw on in the morning.

title: Verizon Wireless Names Faster Part of Its Network: XLTE
description: Data-guzzling smartphones and tablets are so ubiquitous that even Verizon Wireless, the No. 1 American phone carrier, was getting crushed by network trafficlast year in big cities like New York. The company now says it has fixed its network in problematic areas, and this week it is introducing an advertising campaign to make consumers aware of improved portions of its network.

title: Ruling Clears Way for California Chrome to Run in Belmont
description: California Chrome fans can breathe easy: New York regulators will allow the horse to wear a nasal strip in the Belmont Stakes on June 7, when he will try to become only the 12th horse to win the Triple Crown.

title: Many of Bangalores Young Chose Strong Leader Over Professionals
description: BANGALORE  Nandan Nilekani and V. Balakrishnan, the two high-profile former Infosys executives who ran for parliamentary seats in the information technology hub of Bangalore, styled themselves as professionals who knew how to get things done in the hopes of appealing to young voters who were clamoring for change.

title: At JW Marriott, a Video Keepsake
description: JW Marriott has begun to venture into the world of mobile applications, but not to assist with booking or check in.

title: In First Public Remarks After Firing, Jill Abramson Talks of Resilience
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, made her first public appearance since her abrupt dismissal last week, speaking about resilience in a long-scheduled commencement address on Monday at Wake Forest University.

title: In Our Pages: May 20
description: 1964: Microphones Found in Embassy

title: AstraZenecas Chairman on Pfizers Bid
description: Leif Johansson, the chairman of the British pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca, explained why the board rejected the $119 billion takeover offer from the American drug maker Pfizer.

title: Despite Calls for Release, Activist in Occupy Case Gets Three Months
description: A woman whose assault case had become a cause clbre, first among Occupy Wall Street supporters and then expanding well beyond the movement, was sentenced to three months in jail on Monday, as a judge rejected calls for her immediate release.

title: Mad Men Recap: Welcome Back; We Missed You
description: Season 7, Episode 6

title: In Modis Twitter Diplomacy, A Notable Omission
description: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party, who swept the countrys election results on Friday, has started to appear decidedly more prime ministerial by the day.

title: Why Ike Wouldnt Celebrate the D-Day Anniversary
description: President Obama is scheduled to speak next month on the battleground of Normandy, France, at the 70th anniversary celebration of D-Day  just as Presidents Clinton and George W. Bush spoke there in earlier such commemorations.

title: That Dream Apartment With a Crackling Hearth Is Losing Some Spark
description: There may be no feature of a New York apartment more sought after, yet less used, than a wood-burning fireplace: one of the citys great real estate holy grails, keeping company in the dream-apartment pantheon with walk-in closets and private outdoor space.

title: Billboard Awards Red Carpet
description: Red carpet fashion from the Billboard awards show.

title: U.S. Initiative on Hunger Aids Millions, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  An Obama administration program set up to reduce chronic hunger and poverty has contributed to rising incomes for farmers around the world and has helped save millions of people from starvation, according to a report released Monday by the United States Agency for International Development.

title: Rolex Mentors Announce Their Artist Selections
description: They are the chosen onesat least for the next year. The Rolex Mentor and Protg Arts Initiative has announced the names of the seven emerging artists selected to work with major figures in film, literature, dance, visual arts, music, theater and architecture in a program that pairs them with promising young artists. The pairings are intended to help foster a new generation of talent.

title: Hyundai Recalls 138,000 Tucson S.U.V.s
description: Hyundai is recalling nearly 138,000 Hyundai Tucson sport utility vehicles from the 2011-14 model years because the drivers-side air bag may not have been properly attached to the steering wheel, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 24
description: Fernando Santos, the coach of Greeces national team, hopes his gamble pays off.

title: Tracking Criminal Inquiries of Wall St. Giants
description: A lack of criminal prosecutions of banks and their leaders fueled a public outcry over the perception that Wall Street giants are too big to jail.

title: Holder Announces Espionage Charges
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced charges against Chinese army personnel for hacking into American companies including Westinghouse, United States Steel and Alcoa.

title: Food Curated | Amagansett Sea Salt
description: Steven and Natalie Judelson turned their passion for making sea salt at their house on Long Island into a business, harvesting seawater and setting it out to evaporate.

title: Video: Amagansett Sea Salt
description: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

title: Sweet or Hardcore, Nothing Is Quite What It Seems
description: STATE EFFECTS/TRAIT EFFECTS

title: AT&T Shareholders on Hold in DirecTV Deal
description: AT&T is putting its shareholders on hold to buy DirecTV. Its acquisition of the satellite TV operator, announced on Sunday, brings with it an unexpectedly robust $1.6 billion of cost savings. Even so, those savings will not quite cover the cost of the premium. In any case, AT&T says it will use the money to roll out rural broadband service. Customers and regulators are getting the first call.

title: Math for Loves Primo Puzzle
At Kartell, Theres Still a Great Future in Plastics
description: After 65 years producing plastic furniture, lighting and accessories, its safe to say that the Italian company Kartell knows a thing or two about how to elevate the utilitarian material into fashionable design. The trick? Balancing plastics cold and industrial characteristics with familiar, classic silhouettes. Philippe Starcks Ghost chairs for the brand  shaped in the style of French Louis XVI  have reportedly sold over 1.5 million units. Another historically inspired icon, Ferruccio Lavianis Bourgie table lamp featuring a baroque base and a corrugated shade, celebrates 10 years in production this year. It has also been a best seller in transparent, colored and metallic versions.

title: Times Minute | Kentuckys Primary Day
description: Jonathan Martin, The Timess national political correspondent on Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnells challenge in Kentuckys Tuesday G.O.P. primary.

title: Indictment Memorandum
description: The Justice Department said that the men were indicted on May 1 by a federal grand jury in Pennsylvania and charged with conspiring to commit computer fraud and accessing a computer without authorization for the purpose of commercial advantage.

title: Times Minute | Kentuckys Primary Day
description: In the Video

title: Canadiens Goalie Carey Price to Miss Rest of Rangers Series
description: BROSSARD, Quebec  Canadiens goalie Carey Price, who injured his right knee in a Game 1 collision with the Rangers Chris Kreider, will miss the remainder of the Eastern Conference finals, Coach Michel Therrien said Monday.

title: The Curious Incident of Pfizers Final Offer for AstraZeneca
description: In its bid for AstraZeneca, Pfizer is finding out that some merger offers need to be sweet enough for everyone.

title: To Lift the Poor, You Cant Avoid Taxing the Rich
description: Its tempting to think  and hope  that attacking inequality doesnt mean we have to hurt those at the top. This idea has become a central response from conservatives to the current debate inspired by Thomas Pikettys book and proposal for a wealth tax.

title: First Wolverine Comic Art Is Sold for Nearly $660,000
description: The original art for the comic book page that introduced Wolverine, one of the most popular heroes of Marvel Comics, sold on Friday for $657,250 at Heritage Auctions. The superhero is introduced in the final moments of issue no. 180 of The Incredible Hulk, from 1974, which finds the green Goliath wreaking havoc in Canada. Wolverine is called in to stop the Hulks rampage. As he makes his appearance in the final panel, he proclaims: If you really want to tangle with someone  why not try your luck against  the Wolverine! (His first full appearance would be in the following issue of The Incredible Hulk.)

title: Blueberry or Blackberry Compote With Yogurt or Ricotta
description: Modeled on Deborah Madisons recipe in her lovely book Seasonal Fruit Desserts, this simple compote will transform a plain bowl of yogurt or ricotta cheese into a dessert or a very nice breakfast.

title: Whole-Grain Blueberry Buckle
description: A buckle is an old-fashioned cake that has a crumble topping and fruit that makes the batter buckle, or sink, as it bakes. Or at least thats what all the recipes Ive read say is supposed to happen. When I made the cake the blueberries didnt really cause it to buckle at all, they just formed a layer on top of the cake. This is now a favorite dessert. Its not traditional at all, as I use whole-wheat flour, and oats and quinoa flour in the topping.

title: Resentment of China Spreading in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  A flare-up of resilient hostility toward China among its neighbors has infected central Myanmar, where a Chinese company operating a copper mine has local residents seething over what they call the operators arrogance and the projects seemingly unbridled expansion plans.

title: Beet and Arugula Salad With Berries
description: Berries and beets: a salad of dark green, blue and purple hues if there ever was one. I threw this together because I had these ingredients on hand  beets that Id roasted several days earlier, arugula that was bolting in my garden, and berries from the market  and it worked. The sweet-tart flavor of the berries contrasts beautifully with the earthy sweetness of the beets and the pungent arugula.

title: Cornmeal and Buckwheat Blueberry Muffins
description: Buckwheat contributes a rustic, earthy flavor to these not-too-sweet muffins. They are the antithesis of the cakey blueberry muffins you find in coffee shops. The berry quotient is generous here. If you find the buckwheat flavor too strong, swap the amounts of whole-wheat and buckwheat flours (that is, use 125 grams whole-wheat and 65 grams buckwheat).

title: Berry Clafoutis
description: Clafoutis, as you may know by now, are among my favorite vehicles for seasonal fruit. I love the way blueberries and blackberries bleed into the batter as this bakes. Let it cool for about a half-hour, or completely, before you serve it, and be careful when you cut into it, as the berries can splatter when theyre warm. My clafoutis are not very sweet, and I enjoy them for breakfast as well as for dessert.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: lab mice, fighting AIDS and exercises for back conditions. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: With Spy Charges, U.S. Draws a Line That Few Others Recognize
description: WASHINGTON  By indicting members of the Peoples Liberation Armys most famous cyberwarfare operation  called Unit 61398 but known among hackers as the Comment Crew  the Obama administration has turned to the criminal justice system to reinforce its argument that there is a major difference between spying for national security purposes, something the United States does daily, and the commercial, for-profit espionage carried out by Chinas military.

title: Louis Vuitton Comes to Monaco, Celebrities in Tow
description: On Saturday at 6:30 p.m, a tentlike structure in front of the Palace of Monaco was teeming with fashionistas. In came Carine Roitfeld wearing a snake-skin Givenchy jacket and a tight-as-could-be Rick Owens skirt. After that came Charlotte Gainsbourg and Adle Exarchopoulos, who were decked out in leather pants and shimmering tops by Nicolas Ghesquire, Louis Vuittons recently anointed head designer.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Image of the Day: May 19
Weekend Gun Report: May 16-18, 2014
description: Last month, Gama Droiville, 13, was shot twice in the head after getting caught in the crossfire of a gang-related gun battle while he waited for a bus in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, N.Y.. Eduardo Dolphy, 24, the intended target, was shot in the leg. Police arrested Kareem Potomont, 21, who has 13 prior arrests. Weeks earlier, 39-year-old Angel Rojas was caught in gang crossfire on a bus and killed in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. His assailant, 14-year-old Kahton Anderson, was aiming for another teenager.

title: $35 Million for G.M.? Thats Nothing.
description: The General Motors recall story has provided ample proof that federal laws are not strong enough to deal with car defects. Exhibit A is the ridiculously small fine that the Department of Transportation imposed on the company last week.

title: Asian-Americans Have Had the Sharpest Shift Toward Democrats
description: Asian-Americans make up the racial or ethnic group that has shifted most strongly toward the Democratic Party since 2000. They are also the countrys fastest-growing racial or ethnic group by percentage.

title: Marco Rubio As George W. Bush
description: While Rand Paul has been trying to map out a heretofore-uncharted path to the presidency, his potential rival Marco Rubio has been playing more of an inside game, delivering a series of policy speeches  on poverty, on higher education, and most recently on entitlement reform that make him seem more presidential to the kind of Washingtonian thought leaders (those are ironic quotation marks, people) who care about such things.

title: Abramson Touts Resilience After Ouster
description: Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, made her first public appearance since her dismissal, speaking in a commencement at Wake Forest University.

title: How AT&Ts Deal for DirecTV Could Affect the Industry
description: With AT&T having agreed to buy DirecTV for $48.5 billion, consumer advocates and industry analysts are sizing up how the deal could alter the media landscape.

title: Art Matters | The Hudson Valleys Newest Art Destination
description: The last time artwork adorned the walls of the Martin Van Buren school in Kinderhook, N.Y., it had been commissioned at the request of elementary school teachers. On Saturday, however, both new and retrospective pieces by the artist Nick Cave were installed throughout the newly converted 30,000-square-foot building, while dancers costumed in Caves idiosyncratic Soundsuits performed outside for a crowd of art-world cognoscenti and local residents. The early evening celebration feted both the opening of what is simply being called The School, Jack Shainman Gallerys colossal addition to two gallery spaces in Chelsea, as well as the 30th anniversary of the gallery itself.

title: Louise Wilsons High Standards Shaped Young Designers
description: London fashion lost one of its most influential champions this weekend with the death of Louise Wilson, the formidable doyenne of Central Saint Martins, one of the citys, and indeed the worlds, pre-eminent schools for design. She was 52.

title: Today in Small Business: When Does Financing Cost Too Much?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: An Ancient Shrimps Big Sperm, Preserved
description: The worlds oldest sperm has been found in tiny shrimp called ostracods that lived at least 17 million years ago in Australia, scientists are reporting.

title: Travel Magazine Goes Native With Lodging Collection
description: Its spring again, as the song goes, and birds on the wing again start to sing again the old melody. Also starting to sing again at this time of year are marketers gearing up their annual efforts to reach consumers who are making travel and vacation plans, particularly for the summer.

title: Using a Patients Own Blood in Heart Surgery
description: In heart surgery, a patients own red blood cells may be a better choice than blood transfusion.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Big River, Richmond, Va., hired two employees. Christina Dick joined as senior content strategist and Daniel Riddick joined as account director.

title: Parliamentary Wins May Seal Third Term for Iraqi Premier
description: BAGHDAD  Beating expectations, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki secured the largest number of seats in last months parliamentary elections, the first since the withdrawal of American forces at the end of 2011, putting him in a strong position to secure a third term as Iraqs leader as negotiations begin to form a new government.

title: Yankees C.C. Sabathia to Miss at Least Six More Weeks
description: Yankees pitcher C.C. Sabathia, who received a cortisone shot with stem cells Thursday as treatment for a degenerative condition in the cartilage in his right knee, will be out for at least six more weeks, General Manager Brian Cashman said Monday.

title: Chinese Vessel Will Map Ocean Floor in Search for Missing Jet
description: HONG KONG  The Malaysian government announced late Monday night that a Chinese vessel would survey the ocean floor at the last suspected location of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Its a Must-Have Book, Even if You Never Read It
description: I confess that for a stretch of time, I convinced myself that having The Economist lying around would make me smarter, even if I never picked it up. Just by being in the same room, Id somehow learn by osmosis about the news in each issue. Also, I liked having people think of me as the kind of person who read The Economist. But the osmosis thing didnt happen, and I finally stopped my subscription when I realized Id probably never read it on a regular basis.

title: Monday Motorsports: Ed Carpenter Wins Another Indy 500 Pole
description: Ed Carpenter hasnt run an IndyCar race since last October, but was back in top form Sunday as he posted a 231.067 mile per hour qualifying average that earned him the pole position for the 98th Indianapolis 500. Carpenter, who also was the fastest qualifier for last years Indy 500, collected a $100,000 prize for his wild ride around the Indianapolis Motor Speedways 2.5-mile oval.

title: Legacy of Hamas-Fatah Killings Complicates Palestinian Unity Efforts
description: GAZA  For 14-year-old Aseel Radi, the promised reconciliation between warring Palestinian political factions is viewed through a forlorn fountain in a crowded market on the eastern side of Gaza City.

title: In Cannes, Who Needs the Movies?
description: On Saturday night, Vanity Fair (the American edition) hosted a party at the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc, just outside Cannes, for a star-packed party that ran until 2 a.m.

title: Station That Mirrors East Villages Spirit Is Signing Off
description: For more than a decade, East Village Radio has operated out of a tiny storefront studio on First Avenue near First Street.

title: Wicked Writer Is Among Those Winning Lilly Awards
description: Winnie Holzman, who wrote the book for the blockbuster musical Wicked and has been a prolific television and film writer as well, will receive a lifetime achievement prize at the fifth annual Lilly Awards ceremony at Playwrights Horizons on June 2. She is one of 12 winners of a 2014 Lilly, a prize named for Lillian Hellman, and meant to honor women in the theater.

title: Cleric Convicted of All Terrorism Charges
description: The fiery British cleric who prosecutors said had devoted his life to violent jihad and sent young men around the world to train and fight was convicted Monday of all 11 terrorism-related charges against him.

title: Bookshelf | A Collection of Recipes Meant to Inspire Foodie Gatherings
description: Speaking to Diana Yen about food, it instantly becomes clear that shes a sucker for not just the fresh and seasonal  the Union Square farmers market is her first and favorite stop for groceries  but also for ingredients made great by attention to the smallest of details. My second stop would be Eataly. I love the way that they take care of their lettuce, she begins to explain, breaking into a fit of laughter as she realizes how neurotic this sounds. They have this really sophisticated sprinkling system, so the lettuce never gets too drenched, and its never dry  its just perfect. I see them pamper their vegetables, so I trust them.

title: Podcast: Memory Champs, Lessons of a Deadly Virus, Making Something Go Viral
description:
Scientists are learning that among memory competitors, a key to remembering to knowing how to forget. An image of H.I.V. stirs one writer to remember a pastors evolutionary thought, published 50 years before the Origin of Species. Why do we share the hilarious and the horrifying online?
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: Walkabout: Airlines Sticker Prices; Ryanair Competition
description: The Real DealShould an airline be required to tell you the full price of a ticket before you purchase it? Or should it be able to advertise only its base fares?Two billsin Congress offer different answers. (Bloomberg View)

title: Anti-Europe Parties at Odds, Despite Shared Cause
description: LONDON  Geert Wilders, the leader of the populist Freedom Party in the Netherlands, told cheering supporters two months ago that he wanted fewer Moroccans in the country. One of his partys most prominent and charismatic figures, Laurence Stassen, a former television reporter and a member of the European Parliament, promptly quit in protest.

title: Options for Rivals in Wake of AT&Ts Bid for DirecTV
description: Few industries have been as deeply embroiled in merger mania as the telecommunications industry, particularly after AT&Ts $48.5 billion bid for DirecTV.

title: Beyond Pretzel Logic
description: For years, lingering at the bar came with a penance: a bowl of stale peanuts or soggy pretzels. Even if you didnt start out wanting to drown your sorrows, the food made you want to. Bar snacks were meant to lace your mouth with plenty of salt, leading you to reach more often for your thirst-slaking gimlet.

title: Justices Reinstate Copyright Lawsuit Over Raging Bull
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday revived a copyright lawsuit against the owners of Raging Bull, the acclaimed 1980 movie for which Robert De Niro won an Academy Award as best actor for his portrayal of the boxer Jake LaMotta.

title: Creation, in the Eye of the Beholder
description: I remember the chill I felt, 27 years ago, when I picked up the latest edition of Scientific American magazine. Pictured on the cover was an object of unnerving beauty  a cutaway of a perfect blue sphere meticulously assembled from tiny identical parts and studded around the circumference with precisely placed green antennas. Inside this flawlessly honed outer shell was a smaller inner sphere, reddish tan in color, and suspended at its center was an ivory capsule, built from hundreds of still tinier spheres.

title: With World Cup in Brazil, Risk of Spreading a Virus
