description: Public health authorities are worried about a confluence of events set to happen soon: Brazil is suffering the worlds worst epidemic of dengue fever, with 1.4 million cases last year. And the country is about to play host to the World Cup, which attracts tourists by the millions.

title: Met Plans a Gut Renovation of Its Modern Wing
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to rebuild its wing for Modern and contemporary art  possibly from scratch  to create new, showcase galleries for its expanded collection from those periods, Met officials have confirmed.

title: Nissan Recalls About 200 Leaf E.V.s for a Faulty Weld
description: Nissan is recalling 211 Leaf electric vehicles from the 2014 model year for a welding defect that requires the automaker to give owners a new vehicle if necessary, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Mille Miglia Celebrates Cars From Motorsports History
description: ROME  From 1927 to 1957, with time off during World War II, the Mille Miglia was an important race that dazzled motorsports fans around the world, elevating drivers to godlike status and proving what was possible when new technology was pushed to its limits on treacherous mountain roads in Italy. The race planted the seeds of legend, particularly in the parts of Northern and Central Italy where the 1,000-mile race was run.

title: The Airline Lounge Gets Competition
description: MY first encounter with an airline lounge was in the early 1970s at the Philadelphia airport when I noticed an oak door with a small brass plaque that said Admirals Club. I figured it had something to do with the Navy.

title: A Pastors Greeting
description: Marco Linares, pastor of the Living Faith Family Worship Church in Cotulla, Tex., welcomes the congregation and two visitors to a Sunday service.

title: Police Official in New Hampshire Resigns Amid Uproar Over Slur Against Obama
description: BOSTON  With a terse letter of resignation, a police commissioner in Wolfeboro, N.H., has stepped down after a cascade of complaints objecting to his use of a racial slur to describe President Obama. The commissioner, Robert Copeland, 82, who is also a lawyer, confirmed that he had made the statement. He had said he was exercising his First Amendment right of free speech.

title: That Hang-Dog Look
description: Q. My dog has been depressed since I left for college and my family got a new puppy. How is depression treated in dogs?

title: To Lift Up the Poor, Must We Soak the Rich?
description: Over at the Upshot, Jared Bernstein chides conservatives who have responded to the inequality debate by arguing that we should focus on lifting up the poor instead of chopping down the incomes of the 1 percent; the reality, he argues, is that you cant have any sort of uplift without some good old-fashioned soaking of the rich:

title: A Guy Walks Into a Chicago Bar, and Sees Darth Vader
description: I TRAVEL all over the world to find geeks, the people who enjoy video games, comic books, science fiction and fantasy, and all other things pop culture. Im a geek and am obsessed with Legos. Im also global vice president of ReedPOP, a producer of pop culture events like New York Comic Con; Singapore Toy, Game and Comic Convention; and Star Wars Celebration.

title: Clock Ticks on Sterlings Potential Removal
description: The N.B.A. took the next step in its attempt to terminate Donald Sterlings ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers on Monday by formally charging him with conduct that has adversely affected the league and establishing a timetable for his potential ouster.

title: Presidents Tearful Statement
description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed to disband her countrys coast guard, and the commissioner general, Kim Suk-Kyoon, responded to her decision.

title: Sewage in Rio Waters and Other Challenges as Brazil Prepares for Sports Spectacles
description: For the fourth year in a row, a team of graduate and undergraduate communication students at Pace University has created a compelling short documentary focused on efforts to mesh human progress with the environment. (I admit a bias here, given that I co-teach the documentary course that produces these films with Pace Prof. Maria Luskay.)

title: People With Chronic Illness Fare Worse Under Cost-Sharing
description: Most health care plans ask that you spend some money out of your pocket whenever you use the health care system. This is known as cost-sharing, and it exists because research has shown us that people are, in general, less likely to spend their own money than someone elses. Cost-sharing works its way into insurance today through co-pays, deductibles and co-insurance.

title: Cubs Last Link to a World Series
description: READING, Mass.  With a sweep of his arm, Lennie Merullo rolled up the sleeve of his cardigan sweater to reveal a faint scar on his left forearm. He was in the dining room of his Victorian house, scrapbooks full of old newspaper clippings from his baseball career spread on the table before him.

title: Composers Converse Across Centuries
description: In the Miller Theaters enticing Bach, Revisited series, his works are paired with relevant pieces by living composers. A program on Thursday evening offering Bachs Cantata Christ lag in Todes Banden (BWV 4) and Steve Reichs Tehillim, inspired by this cantata, seemed a natural pairing.

title: A Math App That Offers an Unusual Human Touch
San Diego Opera Raises Money to Remain Open
description: The San Diego Opera, which was left for dead in March when its board of directors voted to shut it down after 49 years, citing dwindling ticket sales and philanthropic support, will live to see its 50th-anniversary season after all, the company announced on Monday.

title: In Performance | Jeremy Denk
description: The pianist Jeremy Denk performs Mozarts Rondo in F (K. 494).

title: Pop Music Recital With a Classical Veneer
description: The Tribeca New Music Festival is one of the most clearly defined brands in New Yorks teeming new-music scene. The festivals preferred label is avant pop, defined as the merging of pop culture taste and classically honed craft. Saturdays Poetry in Motion, an evening of new vocal music presented as part of a five-concert series at the Cell in Chelsea, was in many ways a typical sample. The songs by Andrew Norman, Christopher Cerrone, Jacob Cooper, Eric Shanfield and Ted Hearne were compact, direct and elegant; the soprano Mellissa Hughes performed them with grace and razor-sharp emotional acuity.

title: How to Censor a PDF File
description: Q. I have a file that I scanned to a PDF so I could email it to my accountant for reference, but the original contains some personal details, like my Social Security number. For email security reasons, is it possible to black out this information in the electronic file before I send it?

title: A Preference for Republicans, Gun Control and Immigration Reform
description: The new Politico poll of likely voters in swing states and competitive districts isnt all that bad for Democrats.Yes, the poll found that respondents would prefer to vote for a generic Republican over a generic Democrat, 41 percent to 34 percent. It also found that theyre not happy with Barack Obama: 59 percent said they disapproved of his job performance as president.

title: What Might Have Been, Expressed in Songs
description: Could Kate Baldwin, the redheaded firecracker who detonated in the 2009 Broadway revival of Finians Rainbow have been a rock star? That possibility was broached on Friday evening at 54 Below, where Ms. Baldwin opened her new cabaret show with bright, peppy rendition of Ian Axels Rockstar!, an insanely catchy what if? song whose narrator gazes fancifully into the future.

title: Weekly News Quiz | May 13-19, 2014
description: How many of the stories below have you followed this week?

title: In This Romantic Parting, Little Drama or Moodiness
description: Take two of the most popular crudits, vegetables that are neither too similar nor too different. (Zucchini and squash, maybe.) Cut a few slices of each, and serve  careful not to mix them  on the same plate.

title: When Polar Bears Said Goodbye to Brown
description: Polar bears diverged from brown bears less than 500,000 years ago, researchers who sequenced the polar bears genome reported in the journal Cell. The researchers also discovered several genes related to fatty acid metabolism and cardiovascular function in the polar bear. These genes may explain how the bear subsists on a high-fat diet without suffering from clogged arteries and cardiovascular disease.

title: A Victory Lap for a Heretical Neurologist
description: Sweet revenge comes in many delectable forms, among them the receipt of accolades for work long scorned. And then to get to tell the whole story at length and without a single interruption  small wonder that the Nobel laureate Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner, a renowned neurologist at the University of California, San Francisco, writes with a cheerful bounce. Once disparaged, his scientific work is now hailed as visionary, and his memoir takes the reader on a leisurely and immensely readable victory lap from then to now.

title: Credit Suisse Pleads Guilty in Felony Case
description: Updated, 10:12 p.m. | Credit Suisse has done what no other bank of its size and significance has done in over two decades: plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing.

title: Documents on Credit Suisse
description: Federal prosecutors demanded that Credit Suisses parent company plead guilty to helping thousands of American account holders hide their wealth and evade taxes.

title: When Doctors Treat Patients Like Themselves
description: Many years ago I spent a lunch hour in a doctors dining room eavesdropping on two white-coated men of a certain age idly discussing a colleague who worked at the city hospital next door.

title: The Big Melt Accelerates
description: Centuries from now, a large swath of the West Antarctic ice sheet is likely to be gone, its hundreds of trillions of tons of ice melted, causing a four-foot rise in already swollen seas.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Big City Book Club Discusses Brooklyn
description: That concludes the live conversation on Brooklyn. Thank you all who participated, and for those who were unable to make it, feel free to posts comments all week. The book clubs next selection will be announced shortly. Colm Toibins novel Brooklyn is at once a classic narrative of the immigrants conflicted passions and allegiances and a story of female self-questioning that transcends the immigrant-lit genre. It offers a New York that is both a grand escape and a small town. Brooklyn is the story of a young Irishwoman named Eilis Lacey whose bookkeeping classes in an Irish village are interrupted when a priest living across the Atlantic sponsors her passage to New York, a voyage that submerges her in the world of Bartuccis department store on Fulton Street and an Italian-American culture that slowly tempts her away from her own.

title: Cheers as Officer Hurt in Fire Goes Home
description: The officers chances of survival were barely 50 percent, doctors said. Even if she pulled through after the fire, the smoke inhalation was so severe that her commanders were worried she might never speak again.

title: Summers Winners: 20 Wines for $20
description: Drinking wine in the summer is different. Not because people tend to eat lighter, or because its hot. Its the vibe.

title: Race and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention Deficit in Toddlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Biomedical Research
description: To the Editor:

title: A Troupe and Its Leader, Bodies Willing, Try to Gain a Foothold
description: From the outside, the Sheen Center, a new arts complex in the West Village, looks inviting, its sleek gold awning standing out along a quiet, leafy block of Bleecker Street. Step inside, though, and the antiseptic interior makes you wonder if youve walked into a hospital. Descend the stairwell, and it deposits you in the gloomy black-box theater, where MorDance, a fledgling contemporary ballet company directed by Morgan McEwen, presented a triple bill on Saturday.

title: Skewering Britains High-Tone Scribblers
description: In recounting the story of his semi-autobiographical hero, Patrick Melrose, in a series of interlinked novels (Never Mind, Bad News, Some Hope, Mothers Milk and At Last), Edward St. Aubyn established himself as a dazzling writer with an utterly distinctive voice. The harrowing story of Patricks life  from being raped at 5 by his monstrous father, to his years as a heroin addict, to his achievement of a measure of perspective and peace in middle age  was simultaneously heartbreaking and funny, devastatingly sad and cuttingly acerbic: painful experience transmuted into art through beautifully hammered, aphoristic prose.

title: Benefits of Pesticides
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastoral Voyage Turns Into White-Water Rafting
description: In historical accounts and program notes, you read that of the four Brahms symphonies, the second is the sunny one. After struggling for some 20 years to write his first symphony, a turbulent work that ends in hard-won triumph, Brahms wrote his Symphony No. 2 in D during a few months of summer vacation in 1877. The music, overall, is thought to be genial and, despite some mysterious moments, affirming.

title: Speaking at Commencement (Maybe)
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedged Into Warship With Pen in Hand
description: The British author Geoff Dyer is known for being a genre bender  a writer of novels that sometimes read like nonfiction, and nonfiction that occasionally feels invented  and for being what he calls a gate crasher: someone who writes about whatever happens to interest him at the moment. His newest book, Another Great Day at Sea: Life Aboard the USS George H. W. Bush, recounts two weeks he spent embedded on an American aircraft carrier, a life for which he was almost comically ill-suited.

title: De Blasio Tells Citys Tabloids to Apologize to His Wife
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio issued an unusual and stern rebuke of New York Citys tabloid newspapers on Monday, calling on them to apologize for publishing front-page headlines that suggested his wife, Chirlane McCray, had admitted to being a reluctant mother to the couples daughter, Chiara.

title: Rating a Health Laws Success
description: Scientists will look to certain diseases to measure the effectiveness of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Serbia and Egypt.

title: A Cancer Treatment in Your Medicine Cabinet?
description: WE believe that it might be possible to treat breast cancer  the leading cause of female cancer death  with a drug that can already be found in nearly every medicine cabinet in the world: Aspirin.

title: Remembering, as an Extreme Sport
description: SAN DIEGO  The last match of the tournament had all the elements of a classic showdown, pitting style versus stealth, quickness versus deliberation, and the worlds foremost card virtuoso against its premier numbers wizard.

title: Listen Up | In This New Video From Walter Martin, Lily McMenamy Acts Like an Animal
description: After the indie-rock stalwarts the Walkmen went on hiatus last year, the Brooklyn-based groups multi-instrumentalist and co-songwriter Walter Martin consulted his inner child about what to do next. And also his actual children: He had recently become a dad to two girls, who influenced his musical direction. I had to step up to the plate and write my own album after being in a band my whole life, Martin says. It was hard to figure out what I wanted to do. I went through different styles, and they all seemed kind of phony. Then I wrote the first song that appears on my first solo record, and it didnt feel phony.

title: Why That Video Went Viral
description: There it was, virtual gold: a video of a firefighter resuscitating a kitten trapped in a smoky home.

title: Packaged Stylishly, Art Forms and Poetry
description: Like many dance start-ups, Satellite Collective springs from honorable intentions: to serve as an arts incubator, nurturing creative ventures of all kinds. Its structure is unusually egalitarian, with equal billing given to composers, choreographers, filmmakers, writers and designers. Fridays program at BAM Fisher featured two multimedia dance works, a stop-motion film, musical performances and a dramatic poetry reading. Twenty-seven artists contributed, including the creative director, Kevin Draper.

title: Memory Champs
description: Scientists are learning that among memory competitors, the key to remembering to knowing how to forget.

title: Bridges Closes With Big Emotions and a Box Office Upswing
description: While many other Broadway musicals had soft ticket sales last week, The Bridges of Madison County had the highest box-office total of its four-month run, with gross revenues of $590,791 as typical theatergoers as well as fans of the bittersweet romance caught its final performances.

title: With Twitch Acquisition Talks, Validation of Games as Spectator Sport
description: Video games have always been about participation, engagement and interaction. People watch television. They play video games.

title: New Releases From Conor Oberst and Brantley Gilbert
description: CONOR OBERST

title: Scoliosis Exercise, Not Braces (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Pets Driving With a Dog (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Storytelling via Scenery, vs. Drama in the Steps
description: Ballet comes in many shapes and sizes. At this time of year, you can alternate between Americas two foremost and largest ballet companies, New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, as they present their spring seasons on two sides of Lincoln Center. But other local troupes and schools have their performances, too.

title: A.D.H.D. Treatment Without Drugs (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: So Rowdy, They Discomfit the Royal Hell-Raiser
description: That man is an impostor.

title: A Young, Fresh Crowd Comes Out Bouncing
description: A few minutes before midnight on Sunday night, Bria Skonberg was onstage in the ballroom at the Players club, trumpet aloft, playing a punchy solo on the 1930s novelty tune Ill Be Glad When Youre Dead, You Rascal You. Two rooms over, in a parlor overlooking Gramercy Park, the ragtime piano specialist Dalton Ridenhour and the clarinetist Dennis Lichtman were leading an old-time jam. In both rooms, and in a library upstairs, well-turned-out young couples danced among the crowd. It was about 11 hours into the second New York Hot Jazz Festival, and the energy was far from flagging.

title: An Inconvenient Diet
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: In Georgia, Secrecy Is More Important Than Life
description: Does a citizen have a right to know how his government plans to kill him? In Georgia, the answer to that question appears to be no.

title: Hillarys Obstacle Course
description: Reince Priebus made a joke on Sunday.

title: At Ozarks Lodge, Natural History (and Golf)
description: Big Cedar Lodge in the Ozark Mountains in Missouri, will introduce a recreational and cultural complex called Top of the Rock in June that will feature a natural history museum, several restaurants, spa, golf courses and even a chapel.

title: Former Transportation Secretary to Join Investment Firm
description: The Obama administrations first transportation secretary is joining Meridiam, an investment concern focused on public infrastructure projects, the firm plans to announce on Tuesday.

title: New Web Portal Provides Access to Historic Materials on Jewish Life in Poland
description: A new Web portal, Jewish Life in Poland, is making directly accessible thousands of maps, photos, films and other everyday artifacts of what was once the largest community of Eastern European Jews before World War II.

title: Whisper Redesigns App to Reach Older Audience
description: Until now, using Whisper, the app that lets people anonymouslyshare secrets and gossip, could sometimes feel as if you were driving a car through a maze. When you ran out of things to see on the service, you were forced to turn around and start over.

title: Hotels Embrace the Campus Nearby
description: College pennant over your bed? Recent graduate available to answer questions? Rooms decorated in the school colors? Hotels near college campuses are gearing up to attract graduation weekend crowds, just as they compete throughout the year to attract visiting high-school families, graduates attending reunions and parents dropping off freshmen.

title: Georgia Court Upholds Block on Details of States Executions
description: ATLANTA  In a legal victory for supporters of capital punishment, the Georgia Supreme Court on Monday upheld a law allowing the state to block from public view certain details about how it administers the death penalty, including the sources of execution drugs.

title: Extreme Memory
description: The worlds best memory athletes in competition.

title: Questions Remain After Chinese Hacking Indictments
description: The indictments of five Chinese military hackers by the Justice Department on Monday has raised questions of what actions, if any, American officials plan to take against members of the more than 20 other hacking units that American officials and their partners are currently tracking inside China.

title: Deutsche Bank Vows to Focus on Clients With a New Culture of Ethics
description: FRANKFURT As the banking sector tries to distance itself from the industry practices that helped plunge the globe into financial crisis, Deutsche Bank is doing its best to show it has learned the lessons of the past.

title: Photographing, and Curing,the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
description: A road trip that started with heartache and a search for authentic blues led a photographer to the heart of the Mississippi Delta and its families.

title: Facing Shareholder Anger, Target Cuts Executives Pay
description: Targets former chief executive received $13 million in compensation in his last year at the companys helm, down from $20 million the year before, according to regulatory documents filed on Monday.

title: Lost Opportunity for Canadiens Rookie Filling In for an Injured Goaltender
description: MONTREAL  Canadiens lore is steeped with inexperienced goalies, from Ken Dryden to Steve Penney to Patrick Roy, all of whom sparkled during the playoffs as rookies. Another candidate awaited membership in that club on Monday night.

title: Gordon Willis, Godfather Cinematographer, Dies at 82
description: Gordon Willis, a master cinematographer whose work on The Godfather, Manhattan, Annie Hall, Klute, All the Presidents Men and other seminal movies of the 1970s made his name synonymous with that pathbreaking decade in American moviemaking, died on Sunday at his home in North Falmouth, Mass. He was 82.

title: Miamis Past and Future Clash at a Building Site
description: MIAMI  Here at the north bank of the Miami River, beside a luxury hotel where the water meets Biscayne Bay, sits Miamis Plymouth Rock, a recently discovered Indian village where 2,000 years ago the Tequesta people under thatched roofs feasted on shark.

title: Wiring the Amazon
description: This short documentary chronicles a remote Peruvian villages four-year struggle to get Internet access.

title: G.M. Brings Back a Former Executive to Polish a Battered Public Image
description: DETROIT  General Motors on Monday hired one of its former executives to manage public relations and help steer it through a safety crisis linked to 13 deaths.

title: Wiring the Amazon
description: This Op-Doc video chronicles the four-year struggle to get a remote Peruvian village connected with the outside world. I began filming the project in 2009, while making a feature-length documentary film about the global spread of information technology. I was following the work of One Laptop per Child (O.L.P.C.), a United States-based nonprofit that has designed inexpensive laptops for primary education. The organization is particularly active in Peru, where the government has purchased and distributed hundreds of thousands of O.L.P.C.'s laptops to its poorest communities. One such village is Palestina, deep in the Amazon rain forest. It has only 65 people.

title: Writing About a Life of Ideas
description: When an intellectual dies, there are no heaps of flowers or public mournings. The odd wistful editorial will be written in upmarket newspapers; colloquia organized in ivy-clad colleges. Few Americans will know, for instance, that Ronald Dworkin, a formidable figure in American liberal philosophy, died last year.

title: For Workers, Less Flexible Companies
description: He calls it one of the bright spots of his week: Before Jared Dalton, 32, starts his workday as a manager at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, he dresses his 5-month-old daughter, Olivia, and then places her on her tummy to play. Since he works from home on Mondays and Tuesdays, he can spend an extra hour with Olivia and an extra hour working  time that would otherwise be lost commuting into Manhattan.

title: Now Not Batting for the Mets, a Sorely Needed Designated Hitter
description: The Mets Bartolo Colon swung and missed, his body twisting so violently that his helmet fell off and he nearly toppled over. He sheepishly fetched his headgear from the dirt a few feet away, and then he returned to the batters box to take another hack. He feebly struck out swinging to end the embarrassment.

title: Civil Rights Battlefront Is Now Yearning for Jobs
description: SELMA, Ala.  For Allen Green, a native of this rural Alabama city known mostly for a violent confrontation between civil rights demonstrators and Alabama troopers nearly a half-century ago, Selmas prolonged economic slide began when Craig Air Force Base shut down in the 1970s.

title: N.Y.U. Apologizes to Any Workers Mistreated on Its Abu Dhabi Campus
description: New York University issued an apology on Monday to any workers on its newly completed Abu Dhabi campus who were not treated in line with the standards we set, after The New York Times reported widespread abuses among a labor force that numbered about 6,000 at its peak.

title: Koseler Counts the Cost of Its New Way of Life
description: The little village of Koseler, Turkey, with a population of 430 and nestled in a mountain valley, lost 14 men in last weeks coal mining disaster.

title: After Mine Disaster, a Painful Awareness of What Has Been Lost
description: KOSELER, Turkey  The framed photograph showed the smiling faces of 22 men, most of them coal miners, and Ali Toprak pointed first to the unlucky and then the lucky.

title: What AT&Ts Satellite Deal Might Mean
description: In the telecommunications industry, the big only seem to get bigger. Three months after the nations top two cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner Cable, announced they were merging, the nations largest telephone company, AT&T, said on Sunday it would buy the biggest satellite-TV business, DirecTV, for $48.5 billion.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Oregons Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The cheers erupted at exactly 12:08 p.m. as word filtered through the line of couples, friends and family members, some of whom had been on the sidewalk outside the Multnomah County building here since 5:30 a.m. on Monday.

title: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Churns Regulatory Waters
description: WASHINGTON  Many supporters of the blockbuster Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, when AT&T and DirecTV announced plans to merge, thinking the latest pairing would divert some regulatory scrutiny of the other high-stakes deal.

title: Miami Area Hotel Brings Its Past to Forefront
description: THE BILTMORE, an upscale resort in Coral Gables, Fla., is running its first ad campaign in 10 years to attract guests from the United States and overseas.

title: Primary Day on the Far Side
description: Wearing a black leather vest that barely covered the cigar tucked into his pocket, a man named Harley Brown was allowed to join the debate among candidates for governor of Idaho last week, holding forth on discrimination against bikers and the presidential seal tattooed on his shoulder after God told him he would one day occupy the White House. Another candidate, Walt Bayes, railed against a bunch of eastern idiots pushing the country toward Sodom and Gomorrah. If you thought that this was nothing but a stunt designed by Gov. Butch Otter to distract attention from his real opponent, youd be right. But youd also be missing the larger point: Republican primaries around the country have largely degenerated into self-parodies. They may lack the flowing beards of Mr. Brown and Mr. Bayes, but many of the other candidates in the partys primaries  a large number of which will take place on Tuesday  are running on ideas only slightly less extreme.

title: In Tax Case, Credit Suisse Is Denied Milder Penalty
description: On the eve of the year-end holidays, Credit Suisses top lawyer visited Washington to plead for mercy.

title: English League Wont Act on Chiefs Sexist Emails
description: LONDON  The chief executive of Englands Premier League, Richard Scudamore, escaped dismissal Monday after a panel controlled by Britains top 20 professional soccer clubs ruled that no further disciplinary action was necessary in respect to emails he exchanged with others that were laced with coarse sexual innuendo about women.

title: In California, Climate Issues Moved to Fore by Governor
description: LOS ANGELES  Portraying California as the front line of climate change, Gov. Jerry Brown said Monday that the effects of man-made global warming were devastating the state, drawing a direct link between climate change and both the record-setting drought that has left the state parched and the early-season wildfires that broke out across California last week. He declared that people must find a way to live with nature, not collide with it.

title: Flood Danger Persists in Serbia, Threatening Power Plant
description: WARSAW  The rain has stopped, at last, but the danger persists in flood-ravaged Serbia, where a lake of water is pushing its way down the Sava River, toward the Danube, threatening the capital, Belgrade, and the power plant southwest of the city that provides half of the nations electricity.

title: General Declares Martial Law Across Thailand Amid Paralyzing Protests
description: BANGKOK  Citing a century-old law, the head of Thailands Army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have paralyzed the government and blocked elections to stop their movement. The order also appeared to apply to pro-government demonstrators who are leading a separate protest.

title: Disabled Boy Found Safe, Days After Leaving School
description: It is a winding six-mile trip from Leon M. Goldstein High School for the Sciences, in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, to Eliceo Cortezs home in Flatbush. But Eliceo, a ninth-grader, never made it home on Friday because he vanished before boarding the yellow bus that usually takes him there.

title: Camera Maker GoPro Files to Go Public
description: The action camera maker GoPro filed paperwork on Monday to sell shares to the public, offering clues about how it navigated the treacherous waters of the digital photography business.

title: The Big Debate
description: Its now clear that the end of the Soviet Union heralded an era of democratic complacency. Without a rival system to test them, democratic governments have decayed across the globe. In the U.S., Washington is polarized, stagnant and dysfunctional; a pathetic 26 percent of Americans trust their government to do the right thing. In Europe, elected officials have grown remote from voters, responding poorly to the euro crisis and contributing to massive unemployment.

title: Economic Recovery Yields Few Benefits for the Voters Democrats Rely On
description: WASHINGTON  Signs that a long-awaited economic recovery may finally be gaining steam should be welcome news for President Obama and his party as they try to stem losses in this years midterm elections. But rising payrolls, lower unemployment and a buoyed stock market, while lifting the fortunes of the rich, are leaving behind major Democratic constituencies, including young women and blacks, just as the party tries to motivate them to turn out to vote in November.

title: Hibberts Turnaround Helps Stabilize the Erratic Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS  For the first round of the N.B.A. playoff season, and the beginning of the second, it was difficult to comprehend where center Roy Hibberts game had gone. With some retrospection, it was easier to know where he was coming from.

title: Ukraine Crisis Pushing Putin Toward China
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin said Monday that he was withdrawing Russian troops from the border with Ukraine, the second time he has said that in less than two weeks. He also praised the government in Kiev, which he had previously called an illegal, fascist junta, for its willingness to negotiate structural changes.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 19, 2014
Credit Suisses C.E.O. Is Called the Teflon Man
description: Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, has always been something of an anomaly on Wall Street. He is a low-key Midwesterner who prefers long-distance running to New York Citys high-octane charity scene. When he married for the second time a few years ago, it was not to a much younger woman but to his high school sweetheart. He drives a Prius.

title: Yankees Are Grasping for Starters
description: The first four times through their pitching rotation, the Yankees staff was a formidable group, with five starters all presenting imposing challenges for their opponents. But one by one three of those starters fell into various states of ill health, and the one area that had been the most dependable for the Yankees has become the most uncertain.

title: Video Shows Killing of Palestinians on Nakba Day
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 3:47 p.m. | Security-camera footage obtained by the rights group Defense for Children International appears to show the fatal shooting of two young Palestinians on Thursday during a demonstration in Beitunia, a West Bank town outside Ramallah.

title: Bankrupt Housing Policy
description: The publication of Timothy Geithners memoir, Stress Test, has caused all the old arguments that were fought during the financial crisis to come rushing to the surface again.

title: Looking for a Sure Thing in the Belmont Stakes? Bet on NBC
description: Forty-one years ago, CBS broadcast Secretariats victories at the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes  the last time a single network televised all three victories by a Triple Crown winner.

title: For Activist Investors, a Wide Reporting Window
description: William A. Ackman seemingly appeared out of nowhere.

title: Libyans Begin Taking Sides After General Wages Attacks
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Towns, tribes and armed groups across Libya chose sides on Monday in response to a renegade generals assault on the countrys Islamist militias and lawmakers.

title: Jack Brabham, 88, Who Raced and Built Formula One Winners, Dies
description: Jack Brabham, who quit school at 15 to work in a garage, became a race driver and won three world championships as a driver and two as a car builder in London, died on Monday at his home in Gold Coast, Australia. He was 88.

title: Unexpected Expense
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  In my estimation, this one was just  a cute idea. Ive seen much better from Peter A. Collins, but this one will suffice to get us through to our midweek and eventually our late-week challenges.

title: Appropriate and Octoroon Among Obie Award Winners
description: The critically acclaimed Off Broadway plays Appropriate and An Octoroon dominated the 59th annual Obie Awards on Monday night, with Branden Jacobs-Jenkins winning the best new American play award for writing both dramas. In addition, Johanna Day, star of Appropriate, and Chris Myers, star of An Octoroon, received Obie performance awards, and Liesl Tommy won a directing Obie for Appropriate.

title: Holder Announces Credit Suisse Plea
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the Swiss bank would plead guilty in a tax evasion case, pay about $2.6 billion in penalties and hire an independent monitor.

title: M.T.A. Riders May Still Be Swiping in 2020
description: Amid persistent delays in its plans to introduce a new fare payment system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority may be required to extend the MetroCards expected life beyond 2020, according to a presentation made on Monday to members of the authoritys board.

title: New York City Calls Halt to Overhaul of 911 System
description: New York Citys procurement of a new, state-of-the-art 911 system is hundreds of millions of dollars over budget, years behind schedule and will take at least three more years to complete, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.

title: A Political Dynasty in India After a Crippling Defeat
description: NEW DELHI  Ritual mortification is an essential element in Indian political life, and a Monday meeting of the Indian National Congress party, convened three days after the worst defeat in its history, seemed to call for something spectacular.

title: Court Declines to Review Deal for Gulf Spill
description: A federal appeals court has refused to reconsider a major decision in the long-running battle over the 2010 gulf oil spill, leaving in place an earlier ruling that forces the British oil company BP to pay some businesses for economic damages without the businesses having to prove the losses were directly caused by the spill.

title: Tongue-Tied on Campus
Crisis in South Sudan
description: War has led to the displacement of more than a million people and the death of thousands, as a food crisis intensifies.

title: Food Crisis Worsens in South Sudan as Civil War Is Displacing Millions
description: WAU SHILUK, South Sudan  At the beginning of the rainy season every year, Nyaaker Onwar, 34, would plant the sorghum and vegetables, while her husband and eldest son herded the cows and caught fish from the White Nile. They ate what they produced, and when the harvest was bountiful, they sold the rest in a nearby market town.

title: Vigil Marks 1,000 Days of Detention of American Marine in Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Family and supporters of Amir Hekmati, a former United States Marine who is being held in an Iranian prison for practical collaboration with the United States government, gathered for a vigil in front of the White House on Monday to mark the 1,000th day of his detainment.

title: As Popes Visit Nears, Hate Crimes a Concern in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  With Pope Francis set to arrive here this weekend, Israeli security officials say they are bracing for possible hate crimes designed to provoke outrage and to sour the atmosphere around the visit.

title: In New Jersey, a Prosecutors Office, an Indictment and Intimidation
description: William McGovern was a prosecutor out of central casting, a tough, careful fellow who has tried murderers and money launderers during a distinguished career in New Jersey.

title: Viktor M. Sukhodrev, Soviet Leaders Trusted Interpreter, Dies at 81
description: MOSCOW  Viktor M. Sukhodrev, the personal interpreter for Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev, who brought a flair for language and diplomacy to three decades of brinkmanship between leaders of the Soviet Union and the United States, died on Friday at his home outside Moscow. He was 81.

title: Savoring the Magic, One Run at a Time
description: In the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, California Chrome dazzled on the racetrack. Afterward, though, his team stole the show. The fairy-tale run of his working-class owners, Steve and Carolyn Coburn and Perry and Denise Martin, has captured even the most casual fans attention. At 77, the trainer Art Sherman finally made it to the sports biggest stage. His 41-year-old jockey, Victor Espinoza, battled back from a slump to partake in his second Triple Crown run. Most important, they are all having fun. Following are excerpts from their post-Preakness news conference, where they were cracking jokes as if they were part of an improv show.

title: Rejecting Bloomberg Policies, New York City Will Ease Some Hurdles to Public Assistance
description: The new commissioner of New York Citys Human Resources Administration on Monday announced a set of sweeping changes that would remove some work requirements and other barriers to receiving public assistance, cheering advocates for the poor and underscoring the sharp change in direction by Mayor Bill de Blasio away from the welfare policies of his predecessor.

title: Pastor Who Tried to Sell Fake Damien Hirst Paintings Is Sentenced to 6 Months
description: A Florida pastor who was convicted of trying to sell fake Damien Hirst paintings to an undercover police officer was sentenced on Monday to six months in jail and five years of probation.

title: The Netherlands: Heroin Seized
description: Nearly 1,700 pounds of heroin was smuggled into the Netherlands last week hidden in a shipment of Iranian raisins, Dutch police investigators said Monday. The heroin, valued at about $23 million, was seized by the investigators last Thursday after the raisin shipment had been transported from Rotterdam to Hagestein. Two men were arrested. Iran is a major transit point for heroin from Afghanistan. Iran also is believed to be the worlds third-largest exporter of raisins, behind Turkey and the United States.

title: New York Is a Hub in a Surging Heroin Trade
description: The flood of heroin coming into and going out of New York City has surged to the highest levels in more than two decades, alarming law enforcement officials who say that bigger players are now entering the market to sell the drug here and to feed a growing appetite along the East Coast.

title: Narciso Rodriguezs Uniform Designs for Park Hyatt New York
description: The fashion designer  who cites Manhattans architecture as one of his main inspirations  created the womens staff attire for the hotel, set to open this summer.

title: The Year of the Safari Look
description: This year, the classic safari look abounds, but the latest version sports a sleeker, urban edge. We first saw the style in January in a set of suede, cold-weather resort separates. Now its back for spring, thanks to ribbon belts, and utilitarian pockets and a Sahara-inspired color palette of dusty neutrals  all design elements adopted by the likes of Bottega Veneta, Alexander McQueen and Givenchy this season. Worn together in a tonal mix or simply paired with a white linen shirt, these neutral, rugged looks for the city set are investment pieces that wont go out of style.

title: Unfazed by Boos, Rangers Pad Lead
description: MONTREAL  The score was 1-1 when Chris Kreider rode the scorn of 21,273 Montreal fans into the Canadiens zone. Amid resounding booing, he passed the puck cross-ice to Rick Nash, whose one-time shot beat goaltender Dustin Tokarski. The boos abruptly stopped. Silence filled the Bell Centre.

title: Frozen Will Be a Disney on Ice Show, Too, Riding a Blockbusters Wave
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, scrambling to capitalize on unrelenting consumer interest in anything related to Frozen, has disclosed plans for an ice skating spectacular based on the blockbuster film that will begin touring arenas in September.

title: $5 Million Gift to Endow Directors Position at Brooklyn Museum
description: The Brooklyn Museum has received a $5 million gift from the Leon Levy Foundation to endow the position of director, the museum is expected to announce on Tuesday. The gift is the largest the museum has received from a donor who was not a member of its board of trustees. Arnold L. Lehman, the director of the museum since 1997, will become, formally, the Shelby White and Leon Levy Director of the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Word of the Day | sinuous
description: sinuous \sin-y-ws, -y-s\ adjective

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 20, 2014
description: Were kind of the head of the Hydra. This is highly organized, high volume, and its being moved much more efficiently and effectively to reach out to a broader user base.

title: U.S. Cites End to C.I.A. Ruses Using Vaccines
description: WASHINGTON  Three years after the Central Intelligence Agency set up a phony hepatitis vaccination program in Pakistan as part of the hunt for Osama bin Laden, the Obama administration told a group of American health educators last week that the agency no longer uses immunization programs as a cover for spying operations.

title: DSouza Expected to Plead Guilty to Charge
description: A federal court hearing has been scheduled forTuesday morning in which the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh DSouza is expected to plead guilty to a charge stemming from campaign finance violations, according to a notice sent out by the government.

title: Landmark Status Could Block Luxury Tower Plans at Upper East Side Site
description: For decades, one of New York Citys biggest real estate families has been trying to demolish a pair of historic tenements on the Upper East Side to make way for a luxury apartment tower many times their size.

title: Corrections: May 20, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Robert Stuart Jr., 98, Quaker Oats Chief and War Foe in 1940, Dies
description: Robert D. Stuart Jr., whose long career as a top executive for the family business, Quaker Oats, was preceded by his founding, with a handful of fellow Yale law students, of the America First Committee, the catalyst for a potent and polarizing movement opposing the nations entry into World War II, died on May 8. He was 98.

title: Times Minute | Chinas Wanted Hackers
description: How five men working for the Peoples Liberation Army in China ended up wanted by United States authorities.

title: Times Minute | Chinas Wanted Hackers
description: In the Video

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) JUDGE JUDY PRIMETIME Judge Judith Sheindlins verbal slap-downs of a freak show of neer-do-wells have made her among the best-paid television personalities, with an annual salary of $47 million, and have held her Emmy-winning daytime series, above, at No. 1 for the last four years. This special deciphers the guilty pleasure to be found in her courtroom drama by serving up new cases and classic Judyisms: Are you trying to justify to me that you are an idiot? Beauty fades. Dumb is forever. It also offers snippets from the 1993 60 Minutes profile that catapulted her from New York family court judge to pop culture fame.

title: Imposing Martial Law, Thai Military Denies Plans for Coup
description: BANGKOK  Citing a century-old law, the head of Thailands Army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have paralyzed the government and blocked elections to stop their movement. The order also appeared to apply to pro-government demonstrators who are leading a separate protest.

title: Taxi Commission Official Plans to Join Uber
description: At first, they were adversaries  the taxi agency leery of a smartphone app that could upend decades of street-hailing history and the business that responded by hitting the tech-friendly Bloomberg administration where it hurt.

title: How El Nio Might Alter the Political Climate
description: El Nio is coming. Above-average sea surface temperatures have developed off the west coast of South America and seem poised to grow into a full-fledged El Nio event, in which unusually warm water temperatures spread across the equatorial East Pacific. Models indicate a 75 percent chance of El Nio this fall, which could bring devastating droughts to Australia or heavy rains to the southern United States.

title: Australian Winemaker Rebuffs $2.8 Billion Takeover Bid by K.K.R.
description: HONG KONG  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was rebuffed on Tuesday in a nearly $3 billion takeover bid for Treasury Wine Estates, the Australian vintner that owns Penfolds and Beringer Vineyards.

title: Chinese Defense Statement on the U.S. Cyberspying Indictment
description: The Chinese Ministry of National Defense has issued a statement on its website condemning the United States indictments of five Chinese military officers on charges of hacking into commercial networks to steal corporate secrets. Following is a translation by The New York Times:

title: Panicked Workers Fled Fukushima Plant in 2011 Despite Orders, Record Shows
description: TOKYO  At the most dire moment of the Fukushima nuclear crisis three years ago, hundreds of panicked employees abandoned the damaged plant despite being ordered to remain on hand for last-ditch efforts to regain control of its runaway reactors, according to a previously undisclosed record of the accident that was reported Tuesday by a major Japanese newspaper.

title: The Europeans Are Coming, One City at a Time
description: LONDON  For many European start-ups, making it big in the United States remains the pinnacle of success.

title: London Stock Exchange in Exclusive Talks to Buy Russell Investments
description: LONDON  The London Stock Exchange moved closer on Tuesday to buying Russell Investments, saying it was in exclusive discussions to potentially acquire the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index.

title: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
description: A United States indictment accusing members of Chinas military of computer hacking against American companies has put a face on a practice the Obama administration has long complained of, the use of state cyberwarfare capabilities to steal corporate secrets. While little is publicly known about the five indicted members of the Peoples Liberation Army, the F.B.I. has released photos and aliases of the men accused of being members of the Chinese militarys computer espionage Unit 61398, also known as the Comment Crew.

title: Psychiatric Tests Raise Question of Pistoriuss Criminal Liability
description: In more than just miles, it is a long way from Olympic Stadium in London to the Weskoppies Psychiatric Hospital in Pretoria, South Africa, but that is the journey that Oscar Pistorius is about to complete.

title: Test Yourself | History, May 20
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil
description: In Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil, Motoko Rich writes about the debate in Wyoming over the new national science standards.

title: Vodafone, Under Pressure in Europe, Reports Sluggish Sales
description: LONDON  Europes financial woes continue to hurt Vodafone.

title: Hillary Speaks! (Not Really)
description: Next month, Hillary Clintons latest memoir, Hard Choices, a chronicle of her time at the State Department, will enter the expanding political subgenre of Inoffensively Clichd and Calculated Titles Composed of Inoffensive Clichs and Calculations. Hard Choices, which reportedly earned Clinton a high-seven-figure advance, will offer the standard promotional- book-tour-cum-possible-campaign prelude. It is much awaited in the same way that Vice President Selina Meyers Some New Beginnings and Senator Al Frankens Why Not Me? were. Of course, one was a fictional spoof on HBOs Veep and the other was real-life satire, but both occupy the broad canon of politician tomes that flicker through our news cycles before settling into our remainder bins.

title: Photographing, and Curing, the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
description: Brandon Thibodeaux was nursing a broken heart in 2009 when he stopped in the Mississippi Delta to look for a project that might salve the wound of a breakup. He rode his bicycle along a winding farm road, following a series of white, hand-painted signs nailed to trees that read Travel Rest Mount Baptist Church until he came to a white clapboard church by a small cemetery.

title: Does Your School Seem Integrated?
description: While last weekend was the 60th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision Brown v. Board of Education that ended legal segregation in public schools, the federal Department of Education just released a statement announcing that de facto segregation is very much alive.

title: Credit Suisse Investors Shrug Off Tax Plea
description: Updated, 7:12 p.m. | A day after Credit Suisse pleaded guilty to tax evasion in the United States, the Swiss bank says that it is able to conduct its business as normal despite its criminal conviction. Swiss officials and investors seemed to welcome the fact that the resolution allows the bank to put the matter behind it.

title: Cobham Acquires Wireless Communications Company for $1.46 Billion
description: LONDON  Cobham, the British aerospace and military contractor, said on Tuesday that it was buying the Aeroflex Holding Corporation for $1.46 billion.

title: New York Today: Out to Lunch
description: Good sunny morning to you.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Peoples Daily Apologizes for Gutter Oil Report
description: The website of Peoples Daily, the official publication of the ruling Communist Party, issued an apology on Tuesday for an error in its reporting on illegally recycled cooking oil, commonly known as gutter oil.

title: Retaliatory Attacks, Online
description: HONG KONG  Two large American steel makers, United States Steel and Allegheny Technologies, each lost confidential files in online attacks. The largest solar panel manufacturer in the United States, SolarWorld, lost technological secrets, production cost data, cash flow projections and details of its legal strategy.

title: Daily Report: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Complicates Regulatory Task
description: Many supporters of the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, when AT&T and DirecTV announced plans to merge, thinking the latest pairing would divert some regulatory scrutiny of the other high-stakes deal, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Killings Revive Fears in Egypt Before Election
description: CAIRO  Three riot police officers trying to break up a student protest against Egypts military-backed government were killed in a drive-by shooting in Cairo on Tuesday as early results from expatriate voters confirmed that the militarys former leader, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, was headed for a big victory in next weeks presidential election.

title: The Role of Elites in Holocaust Denial
description: Why do misperceptions become widespread? More often than not, they have been spread by elites seeking political advantage. Many of the most significant myths and false claims in American politics were popularized or promoted by elites like Sarah Palin and Michael Moore, for instance. The same logic often applies internationally.

title: My Eye-Opening Student Loan Moment
description: Last weekend, I wrote a column that Id been wanting to do for a long time: the basics of student loan repayment.

title: News Gets New Life When Exhumed From the Morgue
description: Jeff Roth, manager of The New York Times archives, shares some history and explains how past Times material was repurposed for a recent obituary.

title: A Web Platform Connects Start-Ups and Angel Investors
description: Finding angel investors can be an arduous process for start-up founders, involving meetings with hundreds of individuals and groups, most of whom will never invest. A web platform called Gust, introduced in 2011 by David S. Rose, who started New York Angels, offers an easier way for start-ups to share information with angels.

title: British Insurer RSA to Sell Canadian Unit to Arthur J. Gallagher
description: LONDON  The RSA Insurance Group of Britain has agreed to sell its Canadian insurance brokerage business to a subsidiary of Arthur J. Gallagher & Company for about $460 million.

title: Intersection | Eclectic Bushwick
description: At the Morgan Avenue stop on the L train in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the dancer and actress Madison Krekel fits into the young, artsy crowd with sushi socks, dyed green hair and a Cramps T-shirt.

title: In Our Pages: May 21
description: 1889: He Fought With Napoleon

title: Veterans Protest U.S. Involvement in Asia
description: A group of Peoples Liberation Army veterans gathered at a park in Shenzhen to protest what they called the United States involvement in Chinas territorial disputes.

title: What Were the 20s Like? Allow a Piano Man to Paint a Picture
description: New York City may be crawling with contenders for the coveted imaginary title Mr. Show Business, but my vote would go to Mark Nadler, the hyperkinetic piano man and pop nostalgist who displays such voracious exuberance that it is a wonder he doesnt collapse onstage from exhaustion. In his rambunctious new show, Runnin Wild: Songs and Scandals of the Roaring 20s, Mr. Nadler is out to demonstrate that the hedonistic excesses of todays New Gilded Age are a prim little tea party compared with the collective bacchanal of the Prohibition era, when New York was home to 32,000 speakeasies.

title: European Regulators Accuse 3 More Banks of Manipulating Interest Rates
description: European antitrust regulators on Tuesday accused JPMorgan Chase, HSBC and Crdit Agricole of having colluded to fix benchmark interest rates tied to the euro.

title: McConnell Win Leads Night of Victories for G.O.P. Establishment
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky decisively turned back the first well-financed Republican primary opponent he had faced since being elected in 1984, defeating a Tea Party-backed conservative who claimed the Senate minority leader had been too willing to compromise with Democrats.

title: A Critical Election in Ukraine
description: It is risky to see hopeful trends in the Ukrainian crisis. But a degree of calm seems to have settled over the rebellious southeast, which may bode well for the presidential election scheduled for Sunday. There are many things Moscow and its minions in Ukraine can still do to derail the election, of course, but President Vladimir Putin of Russia has refrained from publicly endorsing the peoples republics proclaimed by secessionists. His spokesman said on Monday that he had ordered Russian troops to pull back from the Ukrainian border, though NATO has not seen any change yet.

title: Satellite Firm to Release Data on Missing Malaysian Jet
description: PARIS  Amid pressure from the families of the passengers of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 for more transparency about the search for the missing jet, Inmarsat, the global satellite communications company, confirmed Tuesday that it would soon publish a full record of the communications received from the plane the day it disappeared.

title: In Performance: Jeremy Denk
description: This weeks In Performance video features the pianist Jeremy Denk playing Mozarts Rondo in F (K. 494). Mr. Denk, who was awarded the Avery Fisher Prize in March, will be the music director of next months Ojai Music Festival in California.

title: More Than Just a Booming Voice, Mr. Moviefone Is Now on Video
description: LOS ANGELES  Helloooo, and welcome to Mr. Moviefones new gig.

title: The Small Stuff
description: Theres a risk that a focus on small details in these critiques might suggest a lack of perspective, a trees/forest problem. And I realize that proper use of hyphens is a small detail in the broad scope of our journalistic efforts.

title: Credit Suisses Felony Plea
description: Credit Suisse has done what no other bank of its size and significance has done in more than two decades: plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing, DealBooks Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write. In a sign that banking giants are no longer immune from criminal charges, despite concerns that financial institutions have grown so large and interconnected that they are too big to jail, federal prosecutors demanded that Credit Suisses parent company plead guilty to helping thousands of American account holders hide their wealth, they write.

title: British Officials Welcome Clerics Conviction, but Some Britons Are Wary
description: LONDON  The conviction of a radical British Muslim cleric in New York this week drew praise from the British prime minister and home secretary on Tuesday, but some Muslims in the London neighborhood where the cleric once preached said they were troubled by his prosecution.

title: Rum and Tonic
description: Theres nothing wrong with a gin and tonic, but try a rum and tonic  a sweeter, deeper surprise.

title: Missing: A Painting in Progress
description: Dear Diary:

title: Developer Gives $30 Million to Establish City Planning Center
description: The developer Stephen M. Ross is giving $30.5 million to the World Resources Institute in Washington to establish a center that promotes sustainable city planning and growth in developing countries.

title: Food Matters | An L.A. Chefs Guide to Adventurous Backyard Cooking
description: Youve heard the term food orgy,  says Ben Ford. I love the loss of inhibition when people get in a big group and enjoy a feast. Thats why I did this cookbook. The chef and owner of Los Angeless Fords Filling Station gastro pub (and son of Harrison Ford) has authored Taming the Feast (Simon and Schuster, $34.99), a how-to guide for bringing Game of Thrones-size banquets to your own kitchen table, whether youre serving a phalanx of friends or just a family of four. The idea of working with whole animals, trying to close that proximity between the back door of my kitchen and the farmland, the book came out of that, says Ford. Readers will have a difficult time finding another cookbook with both instructions for rigging a pig for vertical roasting and everyday backyard fare, like grilled beer-braised bratwurst or a simple safflower oil aioli. Alternative, more manageable recipes are offered for each feast  in case you, or your landlord, prefers that your paella come from a Weber or stovetop and not an inferno in the backyard. While such projects as sourcing cedar planks on which to roast sturgeon may sound complicated, for Ford the book is actually about getting back to basics; for instance, he teaches techniques like using ones hands for testing not only the doneness of meat, but also the temperature level over a fire. Says Ford, Im very much a touch, feel, smell kind of chef.

title: China and Russia Fail to Reach Deal on Gas Plan
description: BEIJING  President Xi Jinping of China and the Russian leader, Vladimir V. Putin, were unable to announce an agreement on a natural gas deal on Tuesday, despite high expectations that mutual political interests would help finally push through the project.

title: Target Fires Chief of Unit in Canada, Which Lags
description: In a year of public setbacks and damaging missteps, Target made another move on Tuesday to try to right itself by firing the president of its struggling Canadian division.

title: Russias Relations With China
description: Vladimir V. Putin made conciliatory remarks about Ukraine perceived as being for the benefit of China ahead of a two-day visit there.

title: Pfizers Latest Offer Divides Some of Largest Shareholders in AstraZeneca
description: Updated, 7:20 p.m. LONDON  Some of AstraZenecas largest shareholders were publicly split Tuesday on whether the company should continue merger discussions with Pfizer.

title: Cleveland Hires Leader of Morgan
description: Seven months after David Franklin abruptly resigned as director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, with museum officials later saying he had lied to them about his extramarital affair with an employee, the institution has named a high-profile successor from New York, signaling a new chapter in its 98-year history. He is William M. Griswold, who has led the Morgan Library & Museum for nearly seven years. Mr. Griswold, 53, who will start his new job in the fall, said he decided to leave New York because he relishes running a bigger institution, with one of the most encyclopedic collections in the country.

title: Young Undocumented Immigrants Growing Disenchanted With Both Parties, Study Finds
description: Only about half of young immigrants who grew up in the United States without legal status identify with the Democratic Party, while nearly half say they are independents or have some other nonparty affiliation, according to a study published Tuesday.

title: The Demands of Book Promotion: Frivolous or Necessary?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Anna Holmes discuss whether they find the demands of book promotion  author photos, media campaigns, Twitter feeds  frivolous or necessary.

title: Beard Awards Move to Chicago
description: The James Beard Awards will move to Chicago next year, the first time in the award shows 25-year history that it will not be produced in New York City, the Beard foundation will announce Tuesday.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 3
description: Continuing our look at the rookie on each N.F.L. team who will have the most fantasy impact this season, whether for him or for the players around him, we turn our attention to the A.F.C. East and North.

title: Imagine No Possessions, and No Moving Van, Too
description: Mari folded herself over Bundy, pretending our rabbits white fur was a pillow and resting her cheek on it. Bundy squirmed, broke away and scampered around our apartment. Mari used to crawl after her. Now she runs.

title: To Save the Shore, Putting Hope in the Sand
description: It seemed a little like playing hooky. Micah Citti and about a dozen colleagues from the marketing department of ESPN were kneeling on the beach in the Rockaways in Queens on a gorgeous spring day, the kind of day that makes employees want to flee the office.

title: No Comment Necessary: The Common Core and Gay Conversion
description: Hysteria over the Common Core has reached new heights. Think Progress reports that, at an anti-Common Core event in March, Florida State Representative Charles Van Zant, a Republican, said the new educational standards were a ploy to make schoolchildren gay.

title: Today in Small Business: Does the S.B.A. Help Small Businesses?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Hotel Lutetia in Paris Auctions Off Historic Items
description: PARIS  The Hotel Lutetia, a Left Bank landmark during war and peace, started auctioning off some of its history this week  3,000 objects that range from champagne glasses and hotel china to Art Deco settees and the reception desk.

title: Video Renews Questions on Death of Young Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  A human rights group circulated a video on Tuesday that renews questions about last weeks killing of two Palestinian teenagers by Israeli forces during a West Bank demonstration.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 23
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Home Depot Leads Weak Retail Sector Ahead of Spring Spending Thaw
description: A variety of retailers reported disappointing earnings early this week, showing the strain of the slow, uneven economic recovery and weighing on the stock market on Tuesday. Home Depot; the TJX Companies, the parent of T.J. Maxx and Marshalls; and Dicks Sporting Goods all missed earnings expectations.

title: V.A. Accusations Aggravate Woes of White House
description: WASHINGTON  The White House fought on Tuesday to contain the growing political furor over allegations of misconduct at the nations veterans hospitals as Republicans, eager to use the issue in the midterm elections, seized on the reports as new evidence that President Obama is unable to govern effectively.

title: Wheeler Says F.C.C. Will Examine Peering Arrangements
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that the agency would examine the type of paid-priority arrangements that Netflix recently entered into with Comcast, a deal that created an uproar of accusations that the F.C.C. was allowing companies to buy fast-lane Internet access to consumers.

title: Gergiev, Under Fire for Support of Putin, Seeks to Reassure Munich
description: Valery Gergiev, the conductor whose ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have sparked protests at his performances in the West  over gay rights in Russia and the Ukraine crisis  wrote a letter on Tuesday seeking to explain himself to subscribers of the Munich Philharmonic, the orchestra he is set to take over as music director in 2015-16.

title: The Latest in Watches: The Old Way to Tell Time
description: They stop time, ring time, contain time, split its measure into infinitesimally calibrated segments. They are sleek and golden, burnished to Fred Astaire elegance or else bulky and steroidal, as cartoonish as Hulk Hogan. By far the majority of watches fall into some commercially secure Goldilocks middle ground, serviceable mechanical manacles locked in vestigial fashion to millions of wrists.

title: Lancet Study Calls for Action to Prevent Millions of Newborn Deaths
description: URAGAHALLI, India  About a year ago, Nagarathna, who uses only one name, was admitted to a local government hospital on the outskirts of Indias information technology hub of Bangalore, when she went into labor. A bone-rattling ride on a motorized three-wheeler transported her to the facility located a few miles from her village.

title: Study Gives E-Cigarettes Edge in Helping Smokers Quit
description: A large study in England has found that smokers trying to quit were substantially more likely to succeed if they used electronic cigarettes than over-the-counter therapies such as nicotine patches or gum. These results offered encouraging but not definitive evidence in the contentious debate about the risks and benefits of these increasingly popular smoking devices.

title: Cannes Film Festival: The Dogs of White God
description: Fur flies and blood flows in White God, a fierce and beautiful Hungarian parable about a girl, her dog, and the uprising thats sparked after they are separated. Directed by Kornel Mundruczo, 39, the movie is being presented in Un Certain Regard, a section of the Cannes Film Festival for work that tends to be more adventurous than that in the main competition. Such is the case with White God, which goes from melodrama to hallucination after the girls father throws the dog into the streets. As she searches for the male dog, Hagen, he takes up with other strays (including a scene-nipping Jack Russell), escapes from dog-pound baddies and ends up doped up with sharpened teeth in a fighting pit.

title: Checking in With Key Constituencies After the Vote
description: NEW DELHI  Throughout the campaign season, India Ink tracked several constituencies across India, gauging voters concerns and local issues there.

title: Times Minute | Putins Asia Pivot
description: A highly anticipated gas deal between Russia and China stalls. Also on the Minute, a Swiss bank pleads guilty for helping tax evaders and memory as an extreme sport.

title: A Flurry of Recalls at G.M. as Pressure Mounts
description: General Motors issued four new recalls on Tuesday, bringing its total for the year to 13.5 million vehicles, already the most in the companys history.

title: Times Minute | Putins Pivot in Asia
description: In the Video

title: Syrian Fighting Gives Hezbollah New but Diffuse Purpose
description: HERMEL, Lebanon  For many months, Shiite communities across Lebanon lived in fear as car bombs tore through their neighborhoods, punishing Hezbollah and its supporters for sending fighters to aid President Bashar al-Assad in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

title: Jeb Bush and the G.O.P., an Awkward Match
