title: Modi, Indias Next Prime Minister, Adopts a Softer Tone
description: NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi, the son of a provincial tea seller, was overcome by emotion on Tuesday after members of his political group, the Bharatiya Janata Party, endorsed him as Indias next prime minister, telling the assembled crowd, This is the power of our Constitution, which has given this power to the commonest of the common people.

title: The Champagne of Beers
description: Sometimes, all you need is a bottle opener.

title: McCartney Cancels Japanese Tour Because of Illness
description: Paul McCartney has canceled his remaining tour dates in Japan, which were to have included a concert at the Nippon Budokan Hall on Wednesday, and at the Yanmar Stadium Nagai, in Osaka, on Saturday. He still plans to play a concert at the Jamsil Sports Complex in Seoul, South Korea, on May 28.

title: Briere Living Out a Fantasy in the Twilight of His Career
description: BROSSARD, Quebec  Daniel Briere was born in Quebec to Canadiens-adoring parents in 1977, when the best team in Habs history won the Stanley Cup. Montreal won the next year, and the year after that, and again in 1986, when Briere was a hockey-crazed 8-year-old. He watched that series, against Calgary, and yearned to someday wear le bleu, blanc et rouge.

title: Bryan College Is Torn: Can Darwin and Eden Coexist?
description: DAYTON, Tenn.  William Jennings Bryan earned a permanent place in American history nearly nine decades ago in the Scopes trial, when he stood in a courtroom here and successfully prosecuted a teacher who broke the law by teaching evolution in a public school.

title: Image of the Day: May 20
A Journey Around Manhattan, on the Water
description: My sleeping bag was already damp as I rolled it out in Inwood Hill Park. I had stored the bag in my 16-foot sea kayaks front compartment, which I learned over the previous five days paddling the Hudson River was not quite watertight.

title: The Waiting Game
description: Editors Note: Nicole Sganga, a journalism student, is accompanying Nicholas Kristof on his annual win-a-trip journey in Burma. This is one of several blog posts she will write from the field. As always, reader comments and questions are welcome!

title: On Tap in Paris: Beer Week
description: The first ever Paris Beer Week (Saturday through June 1) will showcase the increasing number of French brewers who wield hops with panache.

title: Leslie Thomas, Author of the Novel The Virgin Soldiers, Dies at 83
description: Leslie Thomas, a top-selling British author who parlayed his experience as a soldier in Malaya into a darkly comic, wildly popular novel in which young troops strive to lose their virginity before they lose their lives, died on May 6 at his home near Salisbury, England. He was 83.

title: Emotional Modi Thanks Party for Election
description: Narendra Modi, the next prime minister of India, was overcome with emotion as the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party officially elected him as its parliamentary leader.

title: Senators Introduce Proposal to Curb Inversions
description: A group of 14 senators introduced a bill on Tuesday that would effectively place a two-year moratorium on so-called inversions, halting the rush by United States corporations to reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills.

title: Thai Officials on Countrys Martial Law
description: Thailands Army chief, Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, and the leader of the red shirts, Jatuporn Prompan, discussed the nationwide martial law to prevent further protest-related violence in the country.

title: Mixed Signals in a Corporate Felons Punishment
description: Updated, 2:04 p.m. | There is a new felon on Wall Street  Credit Suisse. Yet for the most part, the bank will be doing business as usual.

title: Loophole Offers Pfizer a Risky Way Back Into a Deal
description: Pfizer has a risky way back into a deal with AstraZeneca. An apparent loophole in Britains takeover code means that the American pharmaceutical giant could offer the 58.85 pounds-a-share demanded by Astra for a recommendation, even after declaring that the earlier 55-a-share pitch was final.

title: E.U. Antitrust Chief Casts Doubt on Google Deal Over Rivals Links
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions antitrust chief said Tuesday that he might yet take a tougher stance toward Google in a long-running case that he and the company have been in talks to settle for more than a year.

title: More Than the Cherry on Top
description: Say what you will about the renewed (some may say overheated) passion for cocktails, it has had the positive effect of turning attention away from the neon-red maraschino cherry and toward the other maraschino, the liqueur.

title: Keep Your Head on Lazy, Hazy Days
description: I like beer. I like cocktails. I dont like beer cocktails.

title: Microsoft Enlarges Surfaces Screen So It Can Be Used for Work, Too
description: Many people have both laptop computers and tablets and use them for different tasks. Microsoft on Tuesday redoubled its vision that the two devices should be one and the same, introducing a new version of its Surface tablet with a larger screen.

title: Soccer Fever: Learning About the World Cup in Brazil
description: Updated | May 27, 2014

title: Lesson in N.B.A. for Englands Old-Boy Network
description: When Richard Scudamore, the chief executive of Englands Premier League, insists that he is not sexist and that he treats women with respect, should anyone believe him?

title: Reflections on Witnessing Heroin Use Up Close
Before a Vote, a Challengers Reflections in Kentucky
description: WASHINGTON  Kentuckys Republican voters on Tuesday seemed likely to nominate Mitch McConnell to take on Alison Lundergan Grimes in a Senate contest that will be one of the countrys most watched, and important, elections. Such a result could render Mr. McConnells primary opponent, Matt Bevin, to a historical footnote best remembered for speaking after the director of the American Gamefowl Defense Network at a rally where he endorsed legalized cockfighting.

title: Morricone Cancels North American Concerts
description: The Italian composer Ennio Morricone has canceled a short North American visit in which he was to have conducted concerts of his film music  at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on June 13, at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on June 15, and at the National Auditorium in Mexico City on June 18. The concerts, originally scheduled for March, had been postponed after Mr. Morricone, 84, injured his back before he was to have traveled to the United States.

title: Video of Palestinians Killed at Protest
description: Video of two shootings taken from a security camera in the West Bank was released by Defense for Children International-Palestine, a human rights group.

title: Ready to Roll With the Punches
description: A bowl of punch turns a backyard of rugged individualists into a group with a mission, says the cocktail expert David Wondrich, who has written a book, Punch, on the subject.

title: Wheelies: The Luxury G.M. Trucks Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: DSouza, Set for Trial, Pleads Guilty to a Campaign Finance Violation
description: On the morning he was to go on trial in Manhattan, the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh DSouza pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of making campaign contributions in the names of other people, a violation of federal campaign finance laws.

title: An Old Flame Reignited
description: Back in the 1960s, when nobody except rats, longshoremen and gangsters needing to dispose of a wayward bookie saw much value in the Brooklyn waterfront, Michael OKeeffe saw romance. He saw enough flowers for a year of proms, he saw a piano player massaging a Steinway, he saw a curtain of glass framing the Brooklyn Bridge and the lights of Fortress Manhattan on the other side. All of this he saw floating on a barge in the East River. After pleading for permits for 12 years, he persuaded City Hall to see it, too, and in 1977 the River Caf dropped anchors.

title: What Is a Balanced Budget Anyway?
description: For nearly his last five years as mayor of New York City, Michael Bloomberg and the United Federation of Teachers failed to agree on a contract for the citys public schoolteachers. By the time Bill de Blasio took office as mayor in January, the teachers were demanding billions in retroactive pay increases for the years they didnt have a contract and therefore didnt get base pay increases.

title: A Manufacturer Learns Hard Lessons About Negotiating
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, Susan Parker talked about recent changes at her company,Bari Jay. These included hiring new designers and negotiating new distribution agreements.

title: A Cross-Atlantic Collaboration Results in Striking, Sculptural Jewelry
description: The spare, witty jewelry of Pice  Conviction is little-known in the United States, but the New York-based designer Mary Pinghas been collecting it for a decade, ever since she first discovered the ahead-of-its-time floating-style rings in a shop in Paris. I dont remember the name of the store, says Ping, who designsSlow and Steady Wins the Raceas well as a namesake line. Which is a testament to how struck by the rings I was, because I remember everything. After years spent wearing the jewelrydaily in her Manhattan studio  and getting asked about it all the time  Ping worked up the courage to approach the lines designer, Ghislain Ryckebusch, about collaborating. Ryckebusch invited her to his home and studio in Fontainebleau to work together, and the striking, sculptural results  a five-piece capsule collection including rings, bracelets and a necklace  will debut Thursday evening at Creatures of Comfort in New York, with more designs to follow in future seasons. These really are pieces that hum and breathe. There is a rhythm, a balance, Ping says. They are unique punctuation marks.

title: Far-Right Fever for a Europe Tied to Russia
description: LE CHESNAY, France  At a rally last week near the Palace of Versailles, Frances largest far-right party, the National Front, deployed all the familiar theatrics and populist themes of nationalist movements across Europe.

title: Do Not Resuscitate: What Young Doctors Would Choose
description: The researcher was presenting her findings to a room full of geriatricians, at the American Geriatrics Society annual scientific meeting last week in Orlando, Fla. So a slide revealing one particular statistic didnt cause an audible gasp or murmur. Talking to geriatricians about end-of-life treatment practically defines preaching to the choir, as a member of the audience told me later.

title: Florida State Holds Hearing Connected to Jameis Winston Allegations
description: Nearly a year and a half after a student at Florida State accused the future Heisman Trophy winner Jameis Winston of rape, the university on Tuesday held its first student disciplinary hearing in connection with the matter.

title: Not Enough Room at the Democratic Cash Trough
description: Organizing for Action, the ill-conceived support group for the Obama administration, is finally scaling back its fundraising efforts, and promising to move to the political sidelines.

title: Bound for the World Cup? Tips to Save You Money
description: The monthlong, 32-country soccer tournament known as the World Cup kicks off on June 12 in Brazil. And guess where the most tickets have been sold, outside of Brazil that is? Defying all logic, its the United States, the only country in the world you have to start an article about the World Cup by explaining what it is, when it starts and where its being played.

title: Soccer as Spectacle in the Pacific Northwest
description: The last thing I remember clearly, sometime around 4 a.m., was wondering how many people had fallen down the vertiginous back-hallway stairs that are the only way in or out of the Railway Club, the oldest continuously operating bar in Vancouver, British Columbia, a drinking and former gambling establishment that has seen its share of idiots and drunkards since it opened in 1931.

title: Obamas Indecision Points
description: I wrote my Sunday column on President Obamas foreign policy, which seems to be failing to achieve its objectives just about everywhere one might reasonably look. (And the column went to press before the latest turn of eventsin post-Qaddafi Libya,the latest sour news on the Iranian nuclear talks, and the acknowledgment from administration officials that actually, in its latest incarnations, al Qaeda may not actually be on the path to defeat after all.) In limning these failures, however, I diagnosed without prescribing: Im not sure I have a grand unified theory of whats going wrong  events, dear boy, events probably doesnt count  so its hard to offer a clear account of everything the president should be doing differently.

title: Counting Champagne Bubbles, Sake in Vending Machines and More
description: To Calculate: Counting the Bubbles in the Bubbly

title: Durbin Lends Support to Pro-Clinton Group
description: Add Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, to the growing list of lawmakers who supported Barack Obama in the 2008 Democratic primary and have now pledged early support to his former rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Gloria Estefan Musical Planned for Broadway Run
description: On Your Feet!, a new musical about the lives of the Grammy Award-winning singer Gloria Estefan and her husband, Emilio, will open on Broadway in fall 2015 under the direction of Jerry Mitchell (Kinky Boots), the producers announced on Tuesday. A try-out run is planned for Chicago next summer.

title: Lower Manhattan Will Undergo a Retail Revival
description: In Manhattan, where most of the citys stores are small, street-level boutiques, mammoth shopping malls are rare. But next spring, the endless maze of cranes and construction pits that has enveloped Lower Manhattan for more than a decade will be mostly cleared away, making room for not one, but two, massive retail centers.

title: Judge Strikes Down Pennsylvanias Gay-Marriage Ban
description: Continuing a rush of rulings that have struck down marriage limits across the country, a federal judge in Pennsylvania on Tuesday declared the states ban on same-sex marriage to be unconstitutional.

title: Inside a Conjurer of Characters
description: Tom Robbins, the author of such pie-eyed and hippie-deluxe novels as Another Roadside Attraction and Even Cowgirls Get the Blues, is rarely thought of as a Southern writer. But he was born in Appalachian North Carolina during the Great Depression and grew up there and in Virginia. Hes the grandson of two Baptist preachers.

title: Ian Flemings Villa, by the Room
description: The Fleming Villa, a three-bedroom home in Oracabessa on Jamaicas north coast where Ian Fleming wrote his James Bond novels, is usually available to rent only in its entirety, but starting on May 28  the day that would have been the authors 106th birthday  travelers will be able to rent a single bedroom.

title: After Thai Military Declares Martial Law, Protesters Continue Their Rallies
description: BANGKOK  Questions intensified about the intentions of Thailands militaryon Wednesday, a day after the head of the army declared martial law and curbed media freedoms but allowed protesters to continue their demonstrations  which they did with enthusiasm.

title: The Gun Report: May 20, 2014
description: While there may be a dearth of federal dollars going into gun violence research, journalists are attempting to fill the gap.

description: Headliner

title: Original Memo From 1964
description: The original memo from Mr. Steele acts as a reminder that the civil rights movement left gay and lesbian Americans behind.

title: Annette Bening Joins King Lear Cast for Shakespeare in the Park
description: When the Public Theater announced that John Lithgow (The Columnist, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels) would play the title role in this summers free Shakespeare in the Park production of King Lear, that seemed enough to guarantee long ticket lines at the Delacorte Theater. Now the company has sweetened the deal: Annette Bening, whose last Broadway appearance was in Coastal Disturbances in 1988, will join the cast as Goneril, the company announced on Tuesday. It will be her Public Theater debut.

title: Alarm Over Istanbuls Building Boom
description: ISTANBUL  We are invading Istanbul again, the real estate agent said enthusiastically as she ticked off the selling points of Turkeys most ambitious development extravaganza to date: Maslak 1453.

title: NPR Ending a Program With Focus on Diversity
description: NPR will end production of its midday program Tell Me More on Aug. 1 and eliminate 28 jobs across the newsroom in an effort to close a $6 million deficit, the public broadcaster said on Tuesday.

title: From Acid to Bonfire, an Archive That Sizzles
description: In March 1988, when Tom Wolfes The Bonfire of the Vanities was parked at the top of the best-seller list, 962 Fifth Avenue was known to seemingly everyone as the gilded home of the mistress of Sherman McCoy, the books high-living investment banker protagonist.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Battle Over Darden Leaves Little Room for Compromise
description: Can Clarence Otis Jr., the chief executive of Darden Restaurants, save himself by cutting off his claws?

title: Kathryn A. Korte
description: Ms. Korte, 51, is the chief executive and president of Sothebys International Realty, a residential brokerage firm that specializes in luxury property. The brand was founded in 1976 by the Sothebys auction house and includes 41 company-owned offices in 13 markets, including New York. Ms. Korte took the helm of the company in 2006.

title: Art Matters | When LACMA Sings for its Supper
description: On a rare rainy evening in Beverly Hills last month, the movie producer and New York Giants chairman Steve Tisch was warmly greeting guests, including fellow super-producers Brian Grazer and Bob Shaye, near the entrance to his estate. No one was there to talk shop. Instead, they had come to an exclusive dinner to celebrate the beginning of the Collectors Committee weekend to benefit the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. The annual fundraising event brings together heavy-hitter donors (who pay a minimum of $15,000 to $60,000 for the privilege of attending) to hobnob and help the museum acquire new works.

title: Arthur Gelb, Critic and Editor Who Shaped The Times, Dies at 90
description: Arthur Gelb, who by sheer force of personality was a dominant figure at The New York Times for decades, lifting its metropolitan and arts coverage to new heights and helping to shape the paper in its modern era, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: A Life Collecting Chinese Landscapes
description: Lois Conner has devoted three decades to making landscapes of China layered with detail and history.

title: Harper Lee Asks to Renew Lawsuit Against Museum
description: Harper Lee, the author of To Kill a Mockingbird, has asked a federal judge to reinstate her legal case against the Monroe County Heritage Museum, claiming that the museum was attempting to add new terms to an out-of-court settlement reached in February.

title: Statue Doesnt Appear to Be Looted, Museum Says
description: The Cleveland Museum of Art said it has determined that an ancient statue in its collection, which Cambodian officials have said they believe was stolen from a heavily looted jungle temple, did not come from that location.

title: Scott Brown Facing Uphill Fight in New Hampshire
description: Scott Brown, a former Republican senator, is struggling in his race for a Senate seat in New Hampshire. Despite a reputation for having smooth political skills  he handily won election in 2010 to the seat once held by Ted Kennedy in heavily Democratic Massachusetts  our model, which we call Leo, gives Mr. Brown only a 3 percent chance to unseat the Democratic incumbent, Jeanne Shaheen.

title: Make Mine Cool and Easy
description: There were those tallboys of Miller High Life cadged off picnickers on a Connecticut beach. Spritzers on a splintery deck on Fire Island. Long, cold shandies on suspiciously sunny Dublin days.

title: Reviews: Mario Kart 8, Child of Light, Kiwanuka and Super Time Force
description: MARIO KART 8

title: For a Pianist, a Chance to Impress Once Again
description: The players who do well in the Cleveland International Piano Competition are often perceived as thoughtful, introspective, even introverted  not your average finger-crashing young virtuosos. So it is with the Ukrainian pianist Stanislav Khristenko, the winner of last years Cleveland contest, who, as part of his first-prize reward, gave an impressive recital on Monday evening at Zankel Hall.

title: Malnutrition and the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Met Orchestras Players Turn to Social Media
description: Sometimes the musicians post behind-the-scenes tidbits, like some decades-old advice a viola player found penciled into her part for Andrea Chnier by one of her predecessors: whatcha da mice!  meaning watch the maestro in one tricky passage.

title: Ghosts Lurk in Some Sounds
description: The Argento Chamber Ensemble has made regular appearances at the Austrian Cultural Forum recently, championing artists like the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas and earlier Viennese composers. Its concert on Sunday was its first there without music by an Austrian; a piece by Alban Berg, of Vienna, was canceled because of a performers illness. The show went on with a focus on contemporary American composers.

title: British Citizenship Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrant Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Zicos New Coconut Water Pitch: Spandex Not Necessary
description: AS soda sales have decreased over the last decade while obesity concerns rose, one of the fastest-growing alternatives has been coconut water. The number of coconut water products introduced in the United States in 2013 increased 92 percent over the previous year, according to Innova Market Insights data cited in Beverage Industry, a trade journal. And the market research firm Euromonitor identified coconut water as one of the United States top five beverage trends of 2013.

title: Dealing With Debt Collectors
description: If youve ever been dunned by a debt collector, youre not alone: Roughly one in seven American adults is being pursued by a collector, for amounts averaging about $1,500.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, India, Ukraine and South Africa.

title: Punishing G.M. for Failing to Disclose Defects
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Cities, Carved on Site in Stone
description: Tiny limestone skyscrapers and tenements are rising within eyeshot of Christopher Columbuss weathered marble face at Columbus Circle, in the shadow of billions of dollars of real estate. On the sixth floor of the Museum of Arts and Design, the stone carver Chris Pellettieri has been chipping away at a limestone block, creating miniature buildings that represent New Yorks socioeconomic extremes.

title: Landmarks Panel Votes to Protect 2 Upper East Side Tenements
description: They might look more abandoned than historic, but two tenements on the Upper East Side will remain standing: New York Citys landmarks board on Tuesday denied the owner permission to tear them down.

title: Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too Happy in Tehran
description: Last Updated, 11:00 p.m. | Just days after Irans president denounced Internet censorship as cowardly, six young Iranians were arrested and forced to repent on state television Tuesday for the grievous offense of proclaiming themselves to be Happy in Tehran, in a homemade music video they posted on YouTube last month.

title: Aftermath of Car Bombings in Nigeria
description: People combed through the debris at the site of back-to-back explosions that killed at least 46 people in a crowded business district in the central city of Jos.

title: Mutual Admiration, Across the Sea, Across the Years
description: Ella Yelich-OConnor, better known as Lorde, the New Zealand-born teenage pop star, and Conor Oberst, the solo artist and frontman for Bright Eyes, are separated by 17 years and several continents. But in many ways they cover the same ground as confessional singer-songwriters. Mr. Oberst, now 34, started young, too, releasing an album on tape at 13 in his native Omaha, and earning accolades as a musical prodigy before he graduated from high school. His latest solo record, Upside Down Mountain, was released on Tuesday. For a time, Lorde had a quotation from him in her Twitter bio: No, I am not singing for you. Its my mantra in life, she said.

title: Kids and ...
description: 1. Lunch

title: Safety Commission Recalls Bed Handles After Deaths
description: WASHINGTON  The Consumer Product Safety Commission on Tuesday announced the first recall of adult portable bed handles, devices that are designed to help patients get in and out of bed. The metal handles are widely used in care facilities for older adults and people with disabilities.

title: 2 Explosions Kill Scores at Central Nigeria Market
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Two powerful explosions killed scores of people, many of them female vendors, in the central Nigerian city of Jos on Tuesday afternoon, officials and witnesses said. While no one claimed responsibility for the bombing, it occurred as international attention has focused on the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram following the abduction of hundreds of schoolgirls last month and may have been a bloody act of defiance.

title: What Are You Drinking?
description: Let the author and bartender Rosie Schaap make you a custom summer cocktail.

title: The Primary Results, via Twitter
description: Not much matters six months before a midterm election, but Tuesdays primaries were an exception.

title: Mouse Enjoys Exercise Wheel in the Wild
description: Scientists at Leiden University in the Netherlands set up exercise wheels with motion detectors and automated cameras, and found that animals such as mice ran on the wheels voluntarily.

title: Mice Run for Fun, Not Just Work, Research Shows
description: If an exercise wheel sits in a forest, will mice run on it?

title: Inwood: Always on the Brink of Coolness
description: Inwood, in the leafy northern stretch of Manhattan, has never really lacked for natural charms. Centuries ago, Native Americans plied its waterways; later, Gilded Age tycoons built their mansions on its hills for the best views; and today, residents say one of the benefits of living here is its many parks, which are popular for running, concerts and picnics.

title: Greeces Austerity Orphans
description: The photographer Nikos Pilos visited an Athens hospital to document the growing problem of child abandonment during the Greek financial crisis.

title: House Passes Bills Aimed at Stemming Human Trafficking
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Tuesday passed a package of bills aimed at stemming human trafficking, an issue that has slowly begun to gain national attention.

title: Deloitte Partner Sanctioned Over Conflict of Interest With Casino Client
description: James T. Adams, a partner at the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche, would not ordinarily have gotten in trouble for borrowing money at a casino where he liked to gamble.

title: The Limits of Armchair Warfare
description: BOTH of us have a deep appreciation for the work of drone pilots. Whether patrolling the Helmand Valley with a sniper team or relying on drone-driven intelligence to plan manned aerial missions, we often prayed that the drone operators supporting us were cool, calm and collected.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: JPMorgan Committing $100 Million Over 5 Years to Aid Revitalization in Detroit
description: JPMorgan Chase, the nations biggest bank, will provide $100 million to help debt-ridden Detroit with housing repairs, blight removal, job training and economic development projects over the next five years, according to two people with direct knowledge of the plans.

title: For Schools, Long Road to a Level Playing Field
description: In the American national mythology, there are few more revered ideas than the belief in educations power to provide every child a shot at success and to overcome entrenched inequality.

title: Four Words Going Bye-Bye
description: The more I read the news, the more it looks to me that four words are becoming obsolete and destined to be dropped from our vocabulary. And those words are privacy, local, average and later. A lot of what drives todays news derives from the fact that privacy is over, local is over, average is over and later is over.

title: Yum Brands Sets Plan for Transition at Taco Bell
description: Yum Brands said on Tuesday that an insider, Brian Niccol, would take the helm of Taco Bell, its thriving Mexican fast-food chain.

title: Health Site Under Fire, Nevada Alters Path
description: WASHINGTON  The board of Nevadas problem-plagued online health insurance exchange voted Tuesday to end its contract with the vendor in charge of building it and to rely on the federal enrollment system for at least a year.

title: The Military, Again, Takes Over in Thailand
description: Under the pretext of restoring peace and order, the military of Thailand imposed martial law in that politically troubled country early Tuesday morning. Its the latest in a series of disturbing developments that will further undermine the countrys democracy and its economy.

title: After Fed, Bernanke Offers His Wisdom, for a Big Fee
description: On Tuesday, Ben S. Bernanke spoke in Abu Dhabi; on Wednesday, he was in Johannesburg. By Friday, he was in Houston. That week in March was a particularly busy one for Mr. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Commissioner Details Policing Options and Use of Resources at Council Budget Hearing
description: To address pockets of rising violent crime, some New York City police officers formerly assigned to counterterrorism patrols are being redeployed to affected housing projects around the city, the police commissioner, William J. Bratton, said at a City Council budget hearing on Tuesday.

title: Uncovered Papers Show Past Government Efforts to Drive Gays From Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Days after President Lyndon B. Johnsons election to his first full term, an administration official asked a subordinate to explain the policy on firing gays. In particular, he wondered whether someone with a history of gay liaisons could, through years of marriage, be rehabilitated into a trustworthy civil servant.

title: Albany Expands Effort to Cap Regulated Rents for Older Tenants
description: For years, many older tenants of regulated apartments have been able to freeze their rents through a New York City program that will soon be expanded. But supporters of the program say that it has been underused and that unless the city does more to publicize the benefit, it will fall short of its potential to help older New Yorkers being squeezed by rising rents.

title: New York Fed President Sees Inflation Drifting Up
description: William Dudley, the president of the New York Federal Reserve, said on Tuesday he expected inflation to drift higher over the remainder of the year, though excess capacity in the economy is helping to moderate price pressures. Mr. Dudleys remarks come as the Fed grapples with several major issues, including when to raise interest rates, and when to start scaling back its more than $4 trillion balance sheet.

title: Pay Up or Go to Jail
description: User fees are a fact of life in America  those inscrutable administrative charges tacked on to everything from checking luggage to buying theater tickets to applying for college. For people with the ability to pay, they are an irritation. But such fees are increasingly being levied on people caught up in the criminal justice system, who are overwhelmingly among the poorest members of society.

title: For Third Time in 4 Years, Cavs Win Lottery
description: For a group of teams coming off dreadful seasons, the hours before Tuesdays N.B.A. draft lottery were a time of rare hope. They all had a crack at the grand prize: the opportunity to select a player like Dukes Jabari Parker or Kansas Andrew Wiggins, elite prospects who are expected to be among the top picks when the draft is held at Barclays Center on June 26.

title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on 12 Russians
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday leveled sanctions against 12 Russians for human rights abuses including the detention and death of a celebrated lawyer who the United States says sought to expose fraud by Russian officials.

title: Li Qualifies for U.S. Womens Open, at 11
description: The top female golfers from the United States and around the world will tee it up at Pinehurst in June for the United States Womens Open. And among the field at that major championship will be Lucy Li, an 11-year-old.

title: Changes to Surveillance Bill Stoke Anger
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of both parties in the House of Representatives, at the Obama administrations request, have changed a surveillance overhaul bill that restricts the power of the government to obtain Americans records in bulk.

title: Ex-Christie Aide Tells of Push to Win Over Fort Lees Mayor
description: TRENTON  The administration of Gov. Chris Christie worked to cultivate Fort Lees mayor for at least a year and a half before lanes were closed at the George Washington Bridge in an act of political retribution, according to testimony from a former aide to the governor on Tuesday.

title: Fine Line Seen in U.S. Spying on Companies
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency has never said what it was seeking when it invaded the computers of Petrobras, Brazils huge national oil company, but angry Brazilians have guesses: the companys troves of data on Brazils offshore oil reserves, or perhaps its plans for allocating licenses for exploration to foreign companies.

title: Conflict Fatigue Deepens in East Ukraine, Just Days Before Vote
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday faced an unaccustomed wave of anger from residents who expressed frustration over the violence and instability in the region, particularly recent mortar attacks around the embattled city of Slovyansk that have damaged several homes and terrorized residents.

title: Madrids Mostly Friendly Rivals Face Off for a Big Prize
description: MADRID  The century-old rivalry between Madrids two main clubs, Real Madrid and Atltico Madrid, will reach its zenith Saturday when they meet in the Champions League final in Lisbon, the first time that teams from the same city will play for the top prize in European club soccer.

title: Democrats, Seeing Opportunity, Nominate Businessman for Pennsylvania Governor
description: Tom Wolf, a wealthy businessman and a former Peace Corps volunteer, won the Democratic nomination for governor of Pennsylvania on Tuesday, setting up what his party hopes will be one of its best chances this fall to flip a governors mansion now held by a Republican.

title: After Neutrality Proves Untenable, a Ukraine Oligarch Makes His Move
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  For weeks, a seemingly unstoppable pro-Russian separatist movement steamrollered through eastern Ukraine. The governments soldiers proved incompetent or switched sides, and the police readily surrendered their weapons.

title: Inmates Newspaper Covers a World Behind San Quentins Walls
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif.  It is not every newspaper editor who can point to a black-and-white surveillance photograph from a 1996 bank robbery and say that he was the robber.

title: Remember to Forget
description: WASHINGTON  The Right to Be Forgotten.

title: With Price Out and Lundqvist Hot, All of Quebec Is Singing the Blues
description: MONTREAL  Cline Dion may be Quebecs most widely known singer internationally, but Ginette Reno, one of Dions inspirations, is its best loved back home. And for most of this years Stanley Cup playoffs, Reno had been a good-luck charm for the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Did the Bank Bailout Do Enough for the Country?
Russia: Train Crash Kills Six Near Moscow
description: A freight train collided with a passenger train near Moscow on Tuesday, killing at least six people and injuring 25. Russian officials said the crash occurred near the town of Naro-Fominsk, southwest of Moscow, when the train carrying about 400 passengers was on its way to Chisinau, Moldova. Russian television said the Moscow-bound freight train was operated by an unidentified Ukrainian company. The poor state of the tracks or the freight train is considered a possible cause of the crash, investigators said.

title: Long, Long Stories
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Mike Buckley reminds us that if a one-word homophone is punny, then a two-word homophone is even punnier. Dont you just love a twofer?

title: Ex-Senators on Both Sides of Aisle Join Forces on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  As a Republican senator, Trent Lott was among those who successfully dug in against the Clinton-era health overhaul. Tom Daschle, then the Senate Democratic leader, fought Republicans on their prescription drug plan. John B. Breaux, a centrist Democrat who led a blue-ribbon Medicare commission, often found himself at odds with both parties.

title: Iran: More Than One Million Said to Defy Alcohol Ban
description: Despite an officially enforced Islamic prohibition on alcoholic beverages, more than one million Iranians are drinkers, a medical toxicologist said Tuesday. The toxicologist, Dr. Reza Afshari, president of the Asia Pacific Association of Medical Toxicology, was quoted by the Iranian Students News Agency as saying the finding was based on a yearlong study that ended in March 2013. It also showed that 30 percent of the drinkers are women. Dr. Afshari spoke at what the news agency called the first conference on alcohol abuse in Iran, a reflection of the governments acknowledgment of the problem. Alcohol consumption, possession and production have been illegal since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, but smuggled and homemade liquor is said to be widely available. Government officials have said at least 200,000 Iranians are alcoholics.

title: Winning the Cup, and Starting to Win Over Critics
description: CHICAGO  On the ice at Bostons TD Garden, minutes after he had won his first Stanley Cup last year, Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford was approached by a local television host for an interview. He had been one of Crawfords fiercest critics during the season and through the playoffs, repeatedly questioning whether Crawford was a championship-caliber goalie.

title: G.O.P. Sees Chance as Schneiderman Seeks 2nd Term as Attorney General
description: ALBANY  Eric T. Schneiderman, the state attorney general, has a big problem for an incumbent seeking a second term: Many New Yorkers barely seem to know his name.

title: Memo Approving Targeted Killing of U.S. Citizen to Be Released
description: WASHINGTON  Facing the potential defeat of an appeals court nominee, the Obama administration decided Tuesday to publicly release much of a classified memo written by the nominee that signed off on the targeted killing an American accused of being a terrorist.

title: Regulator Wants to Know How Con Ed Is Handling an Increase in Reports of Gas Leaks
description: The chief regulator of utilities in New York demanded on Tuesday that Consolidated Edison explain how it is coping with the sharp rise in complaints about gas odors since an explosion in March leveled two buildings in East Harlem, killing eight people.

title: House Measure to Change Voice of Americas Mission Is Drawing Intense Debate
description: WASHINGTON  A bill to overhaul Voice of America has prompted an intense debate among supporters of the legislation who say it will better enable the broadcast news service to counter Russian disinformation and opponents who say it will turn the service into an American propaganda tool.

title: A Close Call for 2 Planes at Newark
description: Two planes at Newark Liberty International Airport had an unusually close call on April 24, the National Transportation Safety Board reported this week. But air traffic control experts said the hazard was reduced because both pilots were aware of the problem and took evasive action.

title: Nash Gets Hot for the Sizzling Rangers
description: Riding a five-game winning streak and getting close to the Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers are in top form, including one player who was all but invisible until recently: Rick Nash.

title: 32-Year Streak at the Garden: No Taxes Paid
description: The Rangers hockey team is ripping through the playoffs and is making a hard run for its first championship title in 20 years.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 21, 2014
description: We want to make certain that we view culture through the eyes of faith, that we dont view our faith through the eyes of culture.

title: Plan to Save Decaying Pier 40 Faces City Review
description: A proposal to save a former cargo pier on the Lower West Side of Manhattan by selling air rights to the owner of a huge industrial building must go through the citys land use review, a top official in Mayor Bill de Blasios administration said on Tuesday.

title: As Citys Elderly Population Swells, Concerns Rise Over Lack of Access to Retirement Plans
description: New York Citys elderly population is exploding: By 2030, the city will have 1.3 million people 65 and over, up from a million today. And few of them are likely to have a retirement plan.

title: By Rejoining Red Sox, Drew Completes Detour Into Free Agency
description: BOSTON  The Red Sox gave replica World Series championship rings to all fans at Fenway Park on Tuesday. Stephen Drew will be here Wednesday if he wants to pick up the real thing.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 20, 2014
As an Enigmatic Tension Mounts
description: Its been two years since Liz Santoro presented We Do Our Best at St. Marks Church, and still, sounds and images from that spartan trio linger in the mind: the repetitive, echoey click of high heels on a wooden floor; an interminable drone that enveloped everyone in the room, locking us into one tense, protracted moment. There was a peculiar placelessness to this world, only intensified by the exacting placement of everything within it.

title: Massachusetts: 3-Year Sentence for Theft From Marathon Fund
description: A Troy, N.Y., woman was sentenced on Tuesday to serve up to three years in prison after admitting to stealing from the One Fund Boston, which raised more than $60 million to aid victims of the bombing at the Boston Marathon last year. State prosecutors said Audrea Gause, 27, had falsely claimed that she sustained a brain injury in the blasts and collected $480,000 from the fund. On Tuesday, Ms. Gause pleaded guilty to one count of larceny over $250 in Suffolk Superior Court; Judge Carol Ball signed an order to return the money, which has been recovered, to the fund.

title: California Chrome Shows Star Quality in New York Arrival
description: At 10:40 a.m., outside Gate 6 at Belmont Park, a helicopter circled overhead. Past the security gate, a guard directed the unusually heavy traffic in front of the track kitchen. She smiled wide at passers-by and yelled, Five minutes until he gets here. Asked if she was excited, the guard replied, Im dancing in my shoes.

title: Inmate Who Fought With Another at Rikers Island Dies After Leaving Hospital
description: An inmate at Rikers Island who was taken to the hospital Tuesday morning after a fight with another inmate died hours later as he was being returned to the jail, New York City officials said.

title: Giants Look to Bolster Offense With Tight End Snubbed in the Draft
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Through three days and seven rounds, Xavier Grimble, a tight end at Southern California, waited with family and friends to hear which N.F.L. team would draft him. He had been advised that he might be selected as early as the third round or as late as the sixth. No one ever mentioned that 256 players would be chosen and he would not be among them.

title: Fargo Recap: Mayhem Fells Molly
description: Updated, 12:32 p.m. | Please tell me Molly doesnt die and Ill promise never to eat crispy whole fish again.

title: Even Absent, a Big Man Looms Over a Series
description: SAN ANTONIO  Only hours before Game 1 of the Western Conference finals, the San Antonio Spurs Kawhi Leonard and Tony Parker remained unconvinced that Serge Ibaka, the Oklahoma City Thunders starting center, would miss the game with a calf injury.

title: A Festival for Harlem
Tony Palladino, Designer of Psycho Lettering, Dies at 84
description: Tony Palladino, an innovative graphic designer and illustrator who created one of the most recognizable typographic titles in publishing and film history, the off-kilter, violently slashed block-letter rendering of Psycho, died on May 14 in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Tadeusz Rozewicz, Fierce Poetic Voice of Postwar Poland, Is Dead at 92
description: Tadeusz Rozewicz, a defiantly modernist, globally acclaimed Polish poet whose answer to the Holocaust and other 20th-century horrors was a renunciation of literary ornament and a call for poetry of not verses but facts, died on April 24 at his home near Wroclaw, Poland. He was 92.

title: The Great White Hope
description: Three unlikely sources are providing qualified encouragement to Republicans who are either openly or covertly committed to a campaign strategy that focuses on white turnout, as opposed to seeking votes from Hispanics and African-Americans.

title: In His Second Act, Montero Flops, and So Do the Mets
description: Mets starter Rafael Montero took a step back on Tuesday after a strong debut performance last week, failing to pitch past the fifth inning against the Los Angeles Dodgers on a pristine night at Citi Field.

title: California Urges Websites to Disclose Online Tracking
description: Every major Internet browser has a feature that lets you tell a website that you dont want it to collect personal information about you when you visit.

title: Brain Changes in College Football Players Raise New Concerns
description: The brains of college football players are subtly different from the brains of other students, especially if the players have experienced a concussion in the past, according to an important new brain-scan study that, while restrained in its conclusions, adds to concerns that sports-related hits to the head could have lingering effects on the brain, even among the young and healthy.

title: Word of the Day | negligence
description: negligence \ne-gli-jn(t)s\ noun

title: Times Minute | Scandal at the V.A.
description: On the Minute, President Obama under pressure over mismanagement at veterans hospitals; wheel spinning can be rewarding for lab mice; and the youngest golfer to qualify for United States Womens Open.

title: Times Minute | Scandal at the V.A.
description: In the Video

title: Late Burst by James Helps Heat Even Series
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Just when it looked as if the Indiana Pacers might have buried the memory of their mysterious bouts of performance dysfunction, they were reminded of an equally unpleasant reality of their Eastern Conference semifinal against Miami.

title: Second Time Around, Cubs Hand Tanaka His First Loss in Majors
description: CHICAGO  After 21 months and 42 starts in which he never lost in the regular season, Masahiro Tanaka finally felt the sting of defeat. Perhaps it was the rain that poured down upon him, or the fact that for the first time this year his opponent had seen him once before. Or maybe it was just because his teammates could not supply enough offense to bail him out of a substandard effort.

title: Beltran Will Swing a Bat, and the Yankees Hope He Feels No Pain
description: CHICAGO  Monday will be a critical day for right fielder Carlos Beltran and the Yankees. That is when Beltran, who was found to have a bone spur in his right elbow a week ago and placed on the 15-day disabled list, will try to swing a bat.

title: N.B.A. Is Said to Allege Duplicity By Sterling
description: As Commissioner Adam Silver vowed to push forward with terminating Donald Sterlings ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers, the N.B.A.s case against Sterling came into sharper focus Tuesday.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (MSG) RAGING BULL (1980) Robert De Niro, above, packed on nearly 60 pounds for his Oscar-winning portrayal of Jake LaMotta, the New York City boxer who pummeled his way to the world middleweight championship in 1948 before self-destructing, in this drama directed by Martin Scorsese. Joe Pesci plays Jakes brother and manager, Joey, who tries to help him battle his demons; Cathy Moriarty is Vickie, Jakes second wife, who fuels his sexual rage. Though its a movie full of anger and nonstop physical violence, the effect of Raging Bull is lyrical, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. To witness Jakes fury is to swing through the upper atmosphere of the emotions. Its breathtaking and a little scary.

title: Corrections: May 21, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Chinese Company Puts Death Toll in Vietnam Riots at 4
description: The recent outburst of violence by anti-Chinese demonstrators in Vietnam took the lives of at least four workers at a Chinese company, the company said, a count that would double the overall toll previously given by Chinese government officials.

title: Former Chief of JPMorgans China Unit Is Arrested
description: Updated, 7:52 p.m. | The former head of investment banking in China at JPMorgan Chase has been arrested by Hong Kongs anticorruption agency, a Chinese news report and a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, possibly opening a significant front in what has become a  global investigation into JPMorgans hiring practices in China.

title: Volunteers Spend 105 Days in Capsule in Dry Run for Space
description: Three Chinese researchers have emerged after 105 days in a sealed capsule, where they raised plants and ate bugs to help study the requirements for a space station or lunar base. The first test of Chinas Moon Palace 1 was seen as another step in the countrys rapid progression of achievements in space flight.

title: Extraordinary Elite Delusions and the Madness of Commissions
description: Sorry about slow posting  Ive been busy drinking too much port at high table both giving talks at Oxford and grading final papers from Princeton. But I did want to weigh in on this Matt OBrien piece on the problems or lack thereof with democracy.

title: A Note About Our Test Yourself Feature
description: The tool we use to create our quizzes is currently undergoing an upgrade, so we are suspending our Test Yourself feature until that work is done.

title: Pakistani Military Says It Killed 60 Militants in Raids
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military said it killed at least 60 militants, and injured at least 30, in aerial raids on terrorist hide-outs across the North Waziristan tribal region near the Afghan border early Wednesday. Local residents, however, said the dead included women and children.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Why That Video Went Viral
description: In Why That Video Went Viral, Natalie Kitroeff writes about what researchers are discovering about why certain links are click bait.

title: A Life Collecting Chinese Landscapes
description: Lois Conner calls herself a collector of landscapes. The fascination started in childhood, when she was mesmerized by the panoramas she glimpsed on family road trips. But it turned into an artistic mission over the last three decades as she traveled through China with her view camera in search of images layered with detail and history.

title: How Have You Handled Being the New Kid?
description: In a recent Motherlode post, a writer worries about her 6-year-old son making friends when they move to a new country.

title: Investors Await Cues on Modis Economic Policy
description: MUMBAI, IndiaAs the Bharatiya Janata Party and Narendra Modi, the prime minister-elect, begin to discuss the allocation of key cabinet positions, investors eyes are on one key appointment  that of the countrys finance minister, who will be responsible for steering Indias foundering economy to calm waters.

title: Thai Military Gathers Rivals for Talks on Standoff
description: BANGKOK  A day after imposing martial law, the Thai military on Wednesday put leaders of the countrys polarized political camps in the same room in an effort to end six months of political deadlock.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: Cuomos Show
description: Good Wednesday morning to you.

title: Goslings First Film as Director Debuts at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Ryan! Ryan! fans in the audience called out Tuesday night at the premiere of the actor Ryan Goslings directorial debut, Lost River, a dark fantasy about a family struggling against loan sharks in a creepy, post-apocalyptic Detroit-like exurb. The ever-dashing Mr. Gosling, dressed in a slim-cut tuxedo, took the stage and said what an honor it was to have his film at this years Cannes Film Festival, where it is showing in the Un Certain Regard category.

title: China and Russia Reach 30-Year Gas Deal
description: BEIJING  China and Russia signed a $400 billion gas deal on Wednesday, giving Moscow a megamarket for its leading export and linking two major powers that, despite a rocky history of alliances and rivalries, have drawn closer to counter the clout of the United States and Europe.

title: Commerzbank Suspends 2 Currency Traders
description: The German lender Commerzbank has suspended two currency traders in what it said was an isolated incident, becoming the latest bank to place employees on leave as regulators continue to examine potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Expands Its Tablets Screen, With Work in Mind
description: Many people have both laptop computers and tablets and use them for different tasks. Microsoft on Tuesday redoubled its vision that the two devices should be one and the same, introducing a new version of its Surface tablet with a larger screen, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: Under Pressure, Naked Official Chooses Early Retirement
description: The directive on naked officials came down in February in an internal document from the Communist Partys Central Organization Department: Bring back your family, or retire early.

title: If You Cant Raise $100,000, Ask for $1 Million
description: In my first post this year, The Start-Up Vortex of Doom,I wrote about how I scrounged for cash in 2013, trying to build a company and keep the team motivated. We often came perilously close to running out of money. At one point, I lent the company, Posse, money from my personal savings to make payroll. Other times, I raised $50,000 or $100,000  enough to stay alive for a couple of months but not enough to plan for the future. Those were not easy times.

title: Narrow Path to Senate for Michelle Nunn in Georgia
description: The Georgia Republican primary is over, and so are Democratic wishes for their dream outcome.

title: More Hispanics Declaring Themselves White
description: Hispanics are often described as driving up the nonwhite share of the population. But a new study of census forms finds that more Hispanics are identifying as white.

title: Mubarak Gets 3 Years for Embezzlement, and His Sons Get 4
description: CAIRO  A criminal court here convicted former President Hosni Mubarak on Wednesday of embezzling millions of dollars of public money for his personal use in private homes and palaces, in a case that rights advocates say could now implicate the current prime minister and spy chief.

title: Inversion Diversion
description: INVERSION DIVERSION | A group of 14 senators introduced a bill on Tuesday that would essentially disallow any more so-called inversions for two years, slowing down the rush by United States corporations to reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills, DealBooks David Gelles writes. The bill would give Congress time to pursue broad changes in the corporate tax code that could make the United States rates more competitive with other countries, reducing the incentive for companies to move overseas.

title: Larry Kramer: The Fighting Heart
description: It took more than 30 years for Larry Kramers play The Normal Heart, about gay New Yorkers struggling with AIDS, to be turned into a movie. But for the playwright, there is still work to be done.

title: A Lion Still Roars, With Gratitude
description: Most revolutionaries dont live to see as much dizzying change as Larry Kramer has.

title: Netflix Faces Hurdles, Country by Country, in Bid to Expand in Europe
description: LONDON  Netflix, whose digital distribution of movies and TV shows has made it a media force in the United States, now has wide eyes for Europe.

title: McIlroys Engagement Ends as Key Tournament Looms
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England  Appearing at times on the verge of tears, Rory McIlroy kept his date with the news media Wednesday in advance of this weeks BMW PGA Championship, the European Tours flagship event, holding a news conference the same morning that he announced the end of his five-month engagement to the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki.

title: Thane of Cawdor Plays the Armory
description: Its hard to believe that Kenneth Branagh is only now making his acting debut on a New York stage. Then again, much about Mr. Branaghs career is difficult to process. He wrote a memoir at the age of 28 (called, to be fair, Beginning), and he directed a very silly comedy on Broadway (The Play What I Wrote) inspired by the double act Morecambe and Wise. Perhaps the strangest shift is that Mr. Branagh, the wunderkind once considered Laurence Oliviers heir, is now directing Hollywood action movies (Thor). His is a complex, playful career that dabbles in many forms but always returns to what made him famous: Shakespeare. So its no surprise that his first starring role here is as Macbeth, in a critically acclaimed production from England, which he directed with Rob Ashford. Ben Brantley of The New York Times called it utterly assured and intelligent. Macbeth begins performances May 31 in the Park Avenue Armorys enormous Drill Hall. (Through June 22. 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street; 212-616-3930, armoryonpark.org.)

title: Obama Vows a Forceful Response to Veteran Care Issues
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday expressed outrage about allegations of misconduct at veterans hospitals and said that people in the Department of Veterans Affairs  including Eric Shinseki, its secretary  could be punished if investigations revealed wrongdoing.

title: Thank You, Musical Neighbor
description: Dear Diary:

title: Still Hurt by Data Breach and Losses in Canada, Target Lowers Forecast
description: The performance of several retailers on Wednesday put stagnant wage growth and the uneven economic recovery on display. But all eyes were on one company in particular that has struggled under its own additional set of problems in the last six months, and continues to feel the strain: Target.

title: In Store | An Inspired Space to Shop for Mens Wear
description: Popular with stylish musicians like Dev Hynes and Adam Bainbridge of Kindness, the Paris-by-way-of-Brooklyn mens wear brand tudes is a line full of bright and patterned separates and colorful, wide-brimmed hats that, when worn together, are the stuff that bold statement dressing is made of. But the co-founders Aurlien Arbet and Jrmie Egry have always seen tudes as more than just a clothing company; and with a new summer pop-up shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, which opens today, theyre creating a space that embodies the lifestyle their clothes tend to accompany. The idea with the pop-up space is to create an installation as if you were entering a gallery, with clothes, books, objects, furniture, music, Arbet says. Were a multidisciplinary studio and consider ourselves creative directors, curators. Every detail is equally important.

title: Groups Pool Funds to Protect More of Amazon Rain Forest
description: Brazil and a host of governmental and private partners agreed to create a $215 million fund to expand protected areas of the Amazon rain forest by more than 34,000 square miles and to help pay for its management for the next 25 years, the partners announced Wednesday.

title: Who Best to Plan a Surprise Party for a Teenager? Not Mom
description: I stood way, way in the background, my view of my daughter Hannahs shock and thrill obscured by a throng of teenagers swarming her and yelling, Surprise!

title: Meet Modis Potential Foreign Policy Team
description: NEW DELHI  As India attempts to understand the astounding contours of the electoral victory by the Bharatiya Janata Party last week, Prime Minister-designate Narendra Modi is said to be putting his cabinet together.

title: Democrats Seek Issues to Lure Midterm Votes After Races Buoy G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  With Tuesdays primaries reinforcing the strength of the Republican establishment, House Democrats are reassessing their electoral strategy based on a major internal research project that shows their candidates stand a better chance when they portray Republicans as uncaring toward working-class Americans while they continue to back policies favoring the wealthy and corporate America.

title: And What if the Sept. 11 Museum Had to Be Evacuated?
description: What if a bomb went off or a fire broke out in the National September 11 Memorial Museum, 70 feet below ground?

title: In Our Pages: May 22
description: 1889: Murderer Gets Guillotined

title: Lundergan Grimes on Winning Primary
description: Kentuckys secretary of state, Alison Lundergan Grimes, spoke after she won the Democratic nomination to face Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican, for a United States Senate seat.

title: Writing for Foreigners (Americans)
description: Quick question: Who is your favorite contemporary Japanese playwright?

title: Big Meatpacker JBS Plans I.P.O. for Brazil Operations
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  JBS, the worlds biggest meat processor and owner of international brands like Pilgrims Pride and Swift, has filed for an initial public offering of its Brazilian pork, poultry and food-processing operations.

title: Cheese-eating Job Creators
description: People are pretty down on European economic performance these days, with good reason. But mainly what were looking at is bad macroeconomic policy, the result of premature monetary union plus austerity mania. Thats a very different story from the old version of Eurotrashing, which focused on Eurosclerosis  persistent low employment allegedly caused by excessive welfare states.

title: Hedge Fund Sues McKesson Unit Over Celesio Deal
description: The hedge fund Magnetar Capital sued a subsidiary of the McKesson Corporation on Wednesday in connection with its acquisition of the German drug wholesaler Celesio, contending that McKesson violated German takeover law by paying more to some holders of Celesios convertible bonds than it did to shareholders.

title: When T.R. Saw Lincoln
description: Look at the open second-floor window between shutters in this photograph, and you will see two little boys. President Theodore Roosevelts widow, Edith, identified one of them as her husband at the age of 6, looking down from his grandfathers Union Square mansion onto the coffin of the assassinated Abraham Lincoln on Broadway in New York in April 1865.

title: Decades of The Normal Heart
description: Its been almost 30 years since Larry Kramers play The Normal Heart, an angry and autobiographical drama about gay men and the AIDS crisis, opened at the Public Theater. On Sunday, HBO will broadcast its new film version, starring Mark Ruffalo as the outspoken activist Ned Weeks, a character based on Mr. Kramer, and Matt Bomer as Felix, his lover who is dying of AIDS. Read more about it here.

title: United Nations Forecasts Persistently High Unemployment for the Young
description: The clouds of the global financial crisis may have lifted, but six years later, the world economy is not creating nearly as many jobs as it was before 2008, a United Nations report on Wednesday concluded, nor is it expected to in the near term. That is a particularly worrisome fact at a time when more young people are entering the job market than ever before.

title: The Koch Brothers Kick Detroit While Its Down
description: Over the last five months, a deal has come together that would solve some of the most contentious issues in Detroits bankruptcy. It would minimize the pension cuts for 30,000 retirees and city workers, save the citys art collection and give a reasonable amount of money to the citys bondholders.

title: McConnell on Winning Republican Primary
description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky spoke after he fended off a Tea Party challenger to set up an expensive November contest against the Democratic nominee, Alison Lundergan Grimes.

title: 22 Afghan Police Officers Are Killed in Attacks by Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was a particularly bloody Wednesday for Afghan police officers, as reports emerged that at least 22 had been killed in four assaults around the country by Taliban insurgents, who also pinned down 40 police officers and officials in a bunker, short on food and ammunition.

title: Questions About Student Writing
description: 1. How can we incentivize students to stop using impact as a verb?

title: Dodgers Puig Is Entertaining Fans and Detractors Alike
description: He hears boos at the opposing teams stadium from the moment he walks out of the on-deck circle. The fans anticipate his at-bat, and they jeer him with such rancor that it is hard to believe he has not yet been in the major leagues for an entire year.

title: 2 Brooklyn Pupils Accused of Putting Rat Poison in Teachers Water
description: Two Brooklyn elementary school students have been arrested on suspicion of putting rat poison in a teachers water bottle, the police said on Wednesday.

title: Q. and A. | Andr Leon Talley on Curating Stephen Burrows, Growing Up Southern and a Woman Named Vreeland
description: Yesterday, the SCAD Museum of Art opened An American Master of Inventive Design, an exhibition devoted to the career of the designer Stephen Burrows, who achieved legendary status for his dazzling combinations of color and for bringing African-American models, like the 70s superstar Pat Cleveland, to the runway. The man behind the show, Andr Leon Talley, is no less a legend in fashion circles. Its the third exhibition for SCAD overseen by the former Vogue editor. We caught up with Talley, who offered insights into what it means to curate, his Southern upbringing and learning from Diana Vreeland.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an e-mail. Sign up

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 22
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: From War Zone to Workplace, Can Veterans Fill a Void?
description: I work in human resources. And when it comes to hiring, its never easy. Finding qualified people to join company ranks can be a crapshoot. Think hirers remorse.

title: Geithner Book Reveals Consensus, Not Vision, During Financial Crisis
description: What are we talking about when we talk about Timothy F. Geithners new book? President Obama.

title: An Antidote to Overdose, in Time to Save Lives
description: Quincy, Mass., is a pleasant, working-class city of 92,000 people on Bostons South Shore. It is saturated with history and, for the past decade or so, saturated with opioids.

title: Grocery Deliveries in Sharing Economy
description: I hope you realize that you are about to witness a remarkable display in ineptitude, the technology investor Michael J. Moritz said as he entered a Whole Foods store in San Francisco one recent afternoon.

title: Today in Small Business: Why Most Successful Start-Ups Are Self-Funded
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Pfizer-AstraZeneca Talks Need a Rest and Then a Fresh Start
description: AstraZeneca should not re-engage with Pfizer in the dying days of the takeover timetable. Talks now would either be fruitless or delay a proper restart later.

title: McCartney Cancels Seoul Performance
description: The illness that led Paul McCartney to cancel his Japanese tour appears to be more serious than it at first seemed. When he canceled a Tokyo show last Saturday night because of what he described in a statement as a virus, Mr. McCartney optimistically rescheduled the show for Monday. On Sunday, he said that he wanted to perform that evening, but his doctors insisted he stay in bed, and by Monday evening, the rest of his Japanese dates, through Saturday, were canceled as well.

title: Before Taking Office in India, Modi Sends an Invitation to Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI  Indias incoming prime minister, Narendra Modi, on Wednesday invited his Pakistani counterpart, Nawaz Sharif, to attend his swearing-in ceremony next week, an unusual gesture that has inspired hopes that the change in government will lead to improved relations between the two countries.

title: One Childs Quest for Education, in a Burmese Refugee Camp
description: A graveyard is a bizarre playground for a 12-year old boy.

title: Shinseki in Line of Fire, From the Chief
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama stopped short of dressing down his veterans affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, during a blunt hourlong talk in the Oval Office on Wednesday. But the commander in chief made clear that a growing health care scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs had put the future of Mr. Shinseki  a retired four-star general and no stranger to Washington political uproars  once again on the line.

title: A New Restaurant for Campobello
description: The Roosevelt Campobello International Park is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a new restaurant, the debut of an online reservation system for its popular Tea with Eleanor history series, and, later in the summer, a preview of Ken Burnss coming documentary The Roosevelts, which examines the life of Franklin D., Eleanor and Theodore Roosevelt.

title: 21 Sun Ra Albums Are Released on iTunes
description: Sun Ra, the idiosyncratic jazz pianist and composer, used to say that he did not believe in birth or death, and he was able to keep his date of birth  May 22, 1914  a secret until shortly before his death in 1993. So presumably, he would look askance at celebrations of his centenary. For admirers of his often theatrical, sometimes experimental music who want to mark the occasion, however, the Sun Ra Music Archive on Tuesday released 21 of the musicians albums on iTunes, many of them in digital form for the first time (and others remastered).

title: Reactions to Mubarak Sentencing
description: Not all residents agree with the Egyptian court ruling that sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to three years on charges of stealing public funds.

title: Yellen Tells N.Y.U. Graduates to Expect Failure and Learn From It
description: Janet L. Yellen has long occupied a front-row seat as Washington grappled with the financial crisis and the weak economy that has plagued the nation. Standing over second base at Yankee Stadium, where she delivered a commencement speech on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen suggested that playing the game is a lot harder than it looks from the stands.

title: Image of the Day: May 21
Who Is a Feminist Now?
description: In a recent interview with Time magazine, the actress Shailene Woodley was asked if she considered herself a feminist.

title: Painless Shipping In a Few Easy Steps
description: PACKAGING and shipping an item isnt the worst task in the world, but it isnt exactly fun, either. Say youre sending a gift to your grandmother. First, you have to find a box. Then you need tape, one of those household items that is almost never where you thought youd put it. You might also need to weigh and measure the box, and research which shipper fits your budget and delivery preferences. Then you either have to go to the web to order a shipping label or hurry over to the post office to wait in line.

title: Q. and A.: Conor Oberst and Lorde Find Common Ground
description: Growing up in the suburbs of Omaha turns out not to have been much different than growing up in the suburbs of Auckland, at least to hear Conor Oberst, a Nebraskan, and Lorde, a New Zealander, tell it: both had to make their own fun. The two musicians and mutual fans bonded over their similarly forthright lyrical styles, in a conversation on Monday. They also shared a love for the debut albums of the British acts the Arctic Monkeys and the Streets, a certain distaste for social media (although Lorde, born Ella Yelich-OConnor, has more than 1.6 million Twitter followers), and discussed the high and low points of touring. Here are more excerpts from their conversation.

title: Statement Socks in Brooklyn
description: Getting off at the Morgan Avenue stop on the L train in Brooklyn is like stepping into a vintage version of New York City. The area is home to fledgling artists, industrial-looking buildings dripping in street art and the sounds of musicians practicing from nearby studios. Madison Krekel blends in easily wearing a bolo tie she bought at a flea market, socks with sushi printed on them and a Cramps T-shirt. Originally from Oakland, Calif., she moved to the area four years ago and recently dyed her hair green as a way to welcome spring. This interview has been edited.

title: Frieze Art Fair Brings Auto-Themed Displays to New York
description: Every spring, the Frieze Art Fair comes to New York, where international art buyers are drawn to a variety of shows and auctions. For luxury automobile manufacturers, it represents an opportunity to reach a select audience through the displays they have set up at the event.

title: Is There a Coup Underway?
description: WHO WEARS SHORT SHORTS? To quote the old Naircommercial. Specifically, who on Gods earth wears white denim cutoff short shorts for an afternoon stroll through a midtown business district?

title: Times Minute | Obama on V.A. Scandal
description: Also on the Minute, China and Russia strike a historic gas deal and a new study on the effect of brain concussions in college football.

title: Times Minute | Obama on V.A. Scandal
description: In the Video

title: A Green Thumb on the Touch Screen
description: IM no expert gardener, but I do like to care for the lovely flowers and fruit trees in my garden. And when I gather my tools, I also include my smartphone. This is a trick that has worked wonders, thanks to some helpful apps.

title: App Smart | Improve Your Garden
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that could help make your smartphone as indispensable as gloves and a shovel as you work on your garden.

title: Spotify Hits 10 Million Subscribers, a Milestone
description: Spotify, the streaming music service, said on Wednesday that it had grown to 10 million paying subscribers around the world, a long-awaited disclosure as the company faces potential competition from Apple and also prepares for a probable initial public offering.

title: A Survival Course for the Leaders of Companies in Pain
description: TIPP CITY, Ohio  On a Wednesday morning here in March, the owner of a California business explained that his company had enjoyed years of success selling products directly to consumers through TV  until the formula stopped working. People arent watching TV the way they used to, he said. Were Blockbuster.

title: Wheelies: The Pony Pricing Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: EBay Urges New Passwords After Breach
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the latest prominent breach of a companys computer network, hackers have infiltrated the online marketplace eBay, gaining access to the personal data of 145 million customers, the company said on Wednesday.

title: A Chef in the Field | Nettles
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Candidates Ace Geography in Their Ads
description: If there is one fact that political candidates wouldnt seem to need to mention, its the state in which they are running. And if there is one fact most relevant to voters during these partisan times, it is a candidates political party.

title: Delightful Difference
description: When is a moose not a moose?" could be the first line of an elementary-school joke. In Richard T. Morriss This Is a Moose, illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld, a moose is not a moose when he wants to be an astronaut. And in Froodle, written and illustrated by Antoinette Portis, a little brown bird causes revolution  or is it evolution?  among her avian friends when she decides to say something other than Peep! Both books explore the amusing idea of animals having the kind of free will humans enjoy. By playing up the contrast between people and wildlife, Morris and Portis subtly encourage children to make their own choices, even when told they cant.

title: Where Do You Turn for Advice Running a Business?
description: Weve just published an article about Aileron, a nonprofit organization based near Dayton, Ohio, whose goal is to help business owners shorten their learning curves.

title: Obama Vows Response to V.A. Issues
description: President Obama said he would take swift action, including punishing people in the Department of Veterans Affairs, if allegations of misconduct at veterans hospitals were found to be true.

title: AstraZenecas Shareholders Remain Sharply Divided Over Talks With Pfizer
description: LONDON  AstraZenecas decision not to pursue merger talks with Pfizer has caused a split among the British-Swedish drug makers shareholders, with several large shareholders publicly and privately voicing opposing views on Wednesday on the potential tie-up.

title: Turning Fashion Into Childs Play
description: At 7 p.m. on Monday, Alicia Keys took her front-row seat at a Ralph Lauren fashion show, held at the main branch of the New York Public Library. Hes walking today, my son, Ms. Keys said. Im very excited for him. He has a great personality.

title: Loudon Wainwright to Join Father in Posthumous Collaboration for Stage Show
description: Loudon Wainwright III has always been a first-class storyteller, but in the 44 years since his eponymous debut album, his mtier has mostly been the four-minute, folk-tinged pop song. Now he is broadening his canvas.
