title: Today in Small Business: Detroit Is Doing Something Right
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Kings Six-Goal Surge Steals a Chicago Night
description: CHICAGO  Wayne Gretzky appeared on a national radio show Wednesday afternoon, and the subject of the conversation was dynasties. Gretzky, of course, knows a thing or two about the topic, having won four Stanley Cups in five years with the Edmonton Oilers during the 1980s. He said if the Chicago Blackhawks won another title this year  it would be their third in five years  they could qualify for the exclusive club.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup: Day 21
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: House Passes Restraints on Bulk Data Collection
description: WASHINGTON  In a rare moment of bipartisan agreement between the White House and Congress on a major national security issue, the House passed legislation on Thursday that aims to end the National Security Agencys bulk phone records program that had prompted intense domestic debate about privacy and civil liberties.

title: Pastiche, Parody, Homage and Theft
description: The score for the Broadway musical A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder has been described as a pastiche of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. Songs from Jeanine Tesoris Violet, starring the amazing Sutton Foster, like the jaunty Surprised, owe an obvious debt to country and gospel.

title: A Critic Picks Songs of the Broadway Season
description: As someone who thinks a lot about the musical component of musical theater, I wrote an Arts & Leisure piece offering my impressions of some scores from recent shows in New York. I was particularly interested in the technique of pastiche, in which composers, and lyricists, too, evoke older song styles and genres in their new scores.

title: Door by Door, India Strives to Know More About Death
description: MAGADI, India  M. R. Gundappa, 60, died the way most Indians do: with no doctor present, no monitors beeping by his side and no written record. The only person present was his wife, Sushilamma, 48, who spent the day of his death trying to get him admitted to a government hospital where he could be treated for abdominal pain.

title: Letters: The Subcontinent
description: The Subcontinent

title: BlackRock Encourages AstraZeneca to Renew Pfizer Talks at Later Date
description: LONDON  AstraZenecas largest shareholder, BlackRock, wants the drugmaker to renew its talks with Pfizer about a potential deal at a later date, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: How Much Would Home Prices Fall if You Couldnt Deduct Mortgage Interest?
description: On Twitter, a reader, @SquarelyRooted, proposed that we create an alternate-universe version of our rent vs. buy calculator in which there is no mortgage interest tax deduction. Scaling back the mortgage interest deduction  and its inherent subsidy for owning a home  is a crucial piece of some proposals to overhaul the tax code.

title: Tom Leighton of Akamai, on the Professorial Side of Leadership
description: This interview with Tom Leighton, chief executive of Akamai Technologies, a web content delivery company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Brassards Condition Worse in French
description: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault likes to make a little joke as English-language reporters clear out of the room before he gives the French-language portion of his daily news briefings.

title: Exploring the Archives
description: Jeff Roth takes us on a basement tour of The New York Timess archives, known as the morgue.

title: Readers Say a Net Neutrality Vote Was Reported Upside Down and Backward
description: Should a speedy Internet be available to everyone equally or are some users, in Orwells terms, more equal than others? Should there be haves and have-nots on the Internet, with the winners being large corporate or commercial users, as opposed to small businesses or regular people?

title: Facebook Chat at 2 p.m. About the New Math of Rent vs. Buy
description: Archie Tse, a graphics editor who helped create The Timess new online Rent vs. Buy calculator, and Neil Irwin, a reporter who wrote about rising home prices around the country and five questions you should ask yourself before buying, are taking questions on Facebook today at 2 p.m.

title: Times Minute | Military Coup in Thailand
description: Also on the Minute, senators press the N.F.L. to change the Washington Redskins name and a New York Times summer reading list.

title: Times Minute | Military Coup in Thailand
description: In the Video

title: Koreas Trade Artillery Fire Across a Line in the Water
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Naval vessels from North and South Korea exchanged artillery fire on Thursday, raising tensions along a disputed maritime boundary. Neither hit the other.

title: Cannes Film Festival: The Bride, the Groom and His Lover
description: CANNES  Wild Tales, the Argentine director Damin Szifrns raucous anthology movie, which made its debut here, has one of the most memorable wedding scenes in some time: a furious bride spins her new husbands girlfriend into a mirrored wall.

title: For Luxury Collection, an Arts Partnership
description: Luxury Collection Hotels & Resorts, a group of more than 85 upscale properties that are part of Starwood Hotels, has a new partnership with the global arts nonprofit Outset Contemporary Art Fund, which gives its guests insider access to highly regarded artists and cultural institutions.

title: Image of the Day: May 22
Geriatricians: Beware Liquid Candy
description: Bottles of liquid nutritional supplements have become such staples in older peoples refrigerators, in nursing homes and assisted living facilities, and in hospitals, that its easy to assume they serve a useful purpose for seniors who are losing weight.

title: Loving a Sport Thats Totally Alien in New York City
description: Eugene Sorenson was plenty busy  he works as a global business manager at Bloomberg L.P. and is on the board of Trips for Kids Metro New York, a nonprofit group that introduces mountain biking to underprivileged children to provide exercise, expose them to nature and teach life lessons about setting and achieving goals. (His wife, Andree Sanders, is the groups executive director.)

title: The Star-Spangled Banner
description: Sebastien de la Cruz sings the national anthem for visitors at his home.

title: Dance Veterans Join Forces for the Betterment of Ballet
description: The dancer Cynthia Harvey, a principal for many years with the American Ballet Theater, has been coaching and staging ballets since she left the stage in 1996, but lately has had the feeling that there was something amiss in the ballet world  something that she and other retired dancers like Edward Villella, Isabelle Gurin, ngel Corella and Steven Heathcote could help fix.

title: The Thai Army Repeats History
description: On Tuesday, the Thai military imposed martial law on the country and insisted it was not staging a coup. On Thursday, the army dispensed with these niceties and took power, overthrowing a government that has been besieged by street protests since late last year.

title: Pennsylvania Gay Marriage Plaintiffs Suddenly Have a Wedding to Plan
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa.  Getting married was not a pressing priority for Christine Donato and Sandy Ferlanie, despite their being plaintiffs in the case that led a federal judge to strike down Pennsylvanias ban on same-sex marriage on Tuesday.

title: Yelp Reviews Help Track Food Illnesses
description: After a particularly bad restaurant meal, you may be moved to post a review on the website Yelp, warning other diners. But now someone else is listening in: New York City health officials, who may try to track you down if you complain that the meal made you sick.

title: Even Fruit Flies Need a Moment to Think It Over
description: Its easy to think of fruit flies as tiny robots that simply respond reflexively to their environment. But just like humans, they take time to collect information and to deliberate when faced with a difficult choice, according to a new study.

title: A Theory on How Flightless Birds Spread Across the World: They Flew There
description: Just a few centuries ago, Madagascar was home to a monstrous creature called the elephant bird. It towered as high as nine feet. Weighing as much as 600 pounds, it was the heaviest bird known to science. Youd need 160 chicken eggs to equal the volume of a single elephant bird egg.

title: Totokaelos Jill Wenger on Seattles Best Culture
description: The fashion and design emporium Totokaelo  pronounced Toh-toh-KYE-oh  may be the most innovative boutique in Seattle, but its more than just a local institution. The stores founder, Jill Wenger, has discovered and championed some of the most influential independent designers anywhere, while her elegant e-commerce site is a shopping resource bookmarked by stylish men and women around the world.

title: Memo From the United States Department of Justice
description: The policy, which applies to the F.B.I., the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Marshals Service and which will go into effect in July, also encourages officials to use electronic recording in other parts of their investigations, like witness interviews.

title: Songs of Love and Longing, and Retro Sounds From 60s On
description: Sharon Van Etten

title: Matthew Warchus Will Lead Old Vic Theater
description: Matthew Warchus, a British director whose work on Broadway includes Matilda the Musical and God of Carnage, for which he won a Tony Award, will succeed Kevin Spacey as the artistic director of the Old Vic theater in London. He will take up his new position in the fall of 2015, the company announced on Thursday.

title: In Policy Change, Justice Dept. to Require Recording of Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department said Thursday that the F.B.I. and other federal law enforcement agencies would be required to videotape interviews with suspects in most instances, bringing the federal government in line with the practices in many state and local jurisdictions.

title: Thai Army Chief Announces Takeover
description: The Thai Army chief, Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, announced a coup after his efforts to reconcile rival political factions failed, and Bangkok residents reacted to the news.

title: Commencement 2014 | Things to Read, Watch, Debate, Teach and Learn
description: Updated: May 29

title: Whats New? Ask the Philharmonic
description: The music world has long looked with envy at the art world for the way it succeeds in drawing people to embrace, or at least check out, contemporary works.

title: Ernesto Butcher, Who Managed Port Authority After 9/11, Dies at 69
description: Ernesto Butcher, a soft-spoken Panamanian immigrant who effectively took over management of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as its most experienced surviving operations officer, died on May 15 in Maplewood, N.J. He was 69.

title: Edward Snowden Talks to Brian Williams of NBC
description: The NBC anchor Brian Williams has landed an extensive interview with Edward J. Snowden, the source of numerous revelations about the spying activities of the National Security Agency.

title: When Madison Avenue Met Pennsylvania Avenue
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Advertising: Race for White House Costly appeared on May 24 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: The Particular Challenges of Polling Hispanics
description: One of the thorniest issues in polling today is how to capture an accurate picture of the opinions of Latinos.

title: James Corden in Talks to Return to Broadway in A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum
description: James Corden, who won critical acclaim and a Tony Award for his comic performance in Broadways One Man, Two Guvnors in 2012, is in negotiations to star in a Broadway revival of A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum next spring, a spokesman for the revivals producers confirmed on Thursday.

title: Getting Your Wages, Before Payday
description: Last fall, Stephen Prentice found himself short on money for rent after his girlfriend moved out. He was wary of using a payday lender, having incurred big fees using one previously. Instead, he said, he used a new service called Activehours to get an advance on his biweekly paycheck to help tide him over.

title: De Que Manera Te Olvido
description: Sebastien de la Cruzs rendition of a ranchera standard, written from the point of view of a forlorn lover. The title translates to How Can I Forget You.

title: Troops Move on Militants in Tribal Area of Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani soldiers seized control of a neighborhood dominated by foreign Islamist militants in the North Waziristan tribal district on Thursday as part of the most concerted military operation in the area in several years, a senior security official said.

title: Reactions to Market Blast in Xinjiang
description: Residents in Urumqi, capital of the Xinjiang region of China, described the aftermath of a blast that killed 31, and Chinas Foreign Ministry spokesman discussed the attack.

title: Fantasy Football: Analyzing N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 4
description: We turn our attention to the A.F.C. South and West while completing our look at the rookie on each N.F.L. team who should have a fantasy-league impact this season, whether compiling valuable statistics himself or helping players around him do so.

title: Type 2 Diabetics Face a Flood of Drugs and Tests
description: At the American Diabetes Associations traveling EXPO, many exhibitors have their eye on the prize: People with Type 2 diabetes. Clinilabs offers such patients more than $3,500 to join a drug trial. Sanofi-Aventis has 10-foot-tall insulin pens on display. Walgreens offers a free test to check long-term blood sugar levels, a promotion for a new home-testing kit.

title: At the Kings County Fair, See the Kangaroos
description: Round about August, the Miser often hauls his crew the hundred or so miles up the Taconic State Parkway to Rhinebeck, N.Y., for the Dutchess County Fair. The farm animals, deep-fried vegetables, Ferris wheel and butterfly farm provide a nice escape from the city summers oppressive heat, in spite of the drive.

title: Assembly Speaker Finds Fall Guy: Another Sheldon Silver
description: To Sheldon Silver, the powerful speaker of the New York State Assembly, it was nothing but a simple case of mistaken identity.

title: Clip: Frequencies
description: A scene from the film.

title: Potential Partner for Patton Boggs Suspends Merger Vote
description: Updated, 5:01 p.m. | The anticipated merger of two major legal firms was derailed, at least temporarily, on Thursday after one firm, Patton Boggs, a lobbying and legal force in Washington, D.C., faced a legal complication in trying to end its involvement in a bitterly contested case over damage to the Amazon rain forest.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Cold in July
description: Jim Mickle narrates a sequence from Cold in July, featuring Michael C. Hall and Sam Shepard.

title: This Weekend | The 9/11 Memorial Museum
description: This weekend you can visit the new Sept. 11 museum, see art that was made by ordinary people at the American Folk Art Museum or check out the Carpeaux exhibit at the Met before it ends.

title: This Weekend: The 9/11 Memorial Museum
description: In the Video

title: Theres No Such Thing as a Free Tax Cut
description: Its a recurring problem for conservatives: If you propose a tax plan, and it cuts taxes on somebody, it has to raise taxes on somebody else, or raise the deficit. Since conservatives have long been focused on cutting the top marginal tax rate on income without raising the deficit, their tax plans usually involve cutting taxes on the rich  and therefore raising taxes on some nonrich group.

title: Parents of Victim in Film Set Accident Plan Safety Campaign
description: LOS ANGELES  Speaking by telephone from a lawyers office in Atlanta on Thursday morning, the parents of Sarah Jones, who was killed in a film set accident on Feb. 20, said they were planning to create a permanent film safety campaign dedicated to her memory and built around the phrase Safety for Sarah.

title: The Gun Report: May 22, 2014
Safety Agency Says New Tests Are Needed on Boeing Battery
description: Tests on a new kind of battery for 787 planes were inadequate, and new tests should be devised for determining whether batteries with new chemistries are safe for use on airliners, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Cold in July
description: In this video, the director Jim Mickle narrates a sequence from Cold in July. The film takes place in 1989 and features Michael C. Hall as a man who has killed a burglar who broke into his home. That act sets off a series of events in this twisty thriller. Here, Mr. Halls character appears at the funeral of the man he killed, with surprising results.

title: A Belgian Sculptor Takes Antwerp by Storm
description: A storm is brewing at Middelheim Museum, a sculpture park outside of Antwerp, Belgium. The Storm, to be exact. Its the Belgian sculptor Johan Cretens newest show, an outdoor installation of 25 monumental works cast in bronze, clay and resin. Cretens work speaks to the storm within us all, as individuals and as a society, and deals with his usual themes: nature, the female form, power, politics and spirituality. As a preview to what is, to date, his largest and most ambitious exhibition, which opens this Saturday under the moody Flemish sky, the Paris-based artist talks to T about the processes and inspiration behind some of the works on view.

title: Financial Crisis, Over and Already Forgotten
description: Michael S. Barr, a law professor at the University of Michigan who was an assistant Treasury secretary when the financial crisis was at its worst, is working on a book titled Five Ways the Financial System Will Fail Next Time.

title: Must Conservatism Soak the Poor?
description: As I mentioned in my reading-list post earlier today, some of my friends in the small world of reform conservatism have been busy putting together a book of policy essays, whichincludes (among other ideas) proposals on tax reform and safety net reform that the authors, at least, think might help boost the fortunes of the working class and poor.

title: The Pen Is Mighty as a Message
description: Are prison movies the most escapist of Hollywood genres  or the least? Don Siegels explosive Riot in Cell Block 11, released on its 60th anniversary in an extras-laden Criterion dual-format edition, is one penitentiary movie in which busting out is never an option.

title: Wheelies: The Toyota Trouble Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: extreme weight loss, superior memory and swimming ability. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Small on Space, Big on Flavors
description: Lately, the restaurants I visit seem to have ever tinier and more makeshift kitchens, from which nevertheless issue ornate, ambitious, semi-avant-garde meals. Its as if a clandestine Top Chef challenge were in progress, with young-gun chefs goading one another into using the fewest, crudest tools possible to create spectacle and wonder.

title: Gavin Schmidt on Why Climate Models are Wrong, and Valuable
description: Im overdue to draw your attention to two fresh, and very different, discussions of climate science by Gavin Schmidt, the longtime climate modeler at NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies.

title: Is Work Your Happy Place?
description: Do you feel more stressed out at work or at home?

title: Preserving a New York Jewelry Legacy
description: The roster of small jewelry workshops in Manhattans diamond district keeps shrinking, but at least one company thats winding down is preserving the history of its designs. After six decades of making jewelry at various addresses in the West 40s, Henry Dankner & Sons is closing and donating its paperwork and molds to the jewelry design department at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Cuomo Boasts of New Yorks Rebirth, but Hits Snags
description: MELVILLE, N.Y.  For three years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo dominated New York State politics like no other chief executive in decades.

title: A Boy Lost in the Underworld
description: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors, a small miracle of a film, captures the grass-roots swirl of New York City with an extraordinary sensory attuning to urban life. Set largely inside the citys subway system, it observes the world through the eyes of Ricky (Jesus Sanchez-Velez), a bright but easily distracted 13-year-old boy with midrange autism who gets lost underground. Mr. Sanchez-Velez, the untrained actor who plays him, has Aspergers syndrome and is a hauntingly plaintive screen presence.

title: F.H.A. Loans Get Better with Credit Counseling
description: Tight mortgage lending conditions have largely shut out the millions of borrowers with credit scores below 640. In response, the Federal Housing Administration, which insures low-down-payment loans, has taken on the tricky task of trying to expand access to credit without increasing the rate of default.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Names Interim President
description: The Minnesota Orchestra, which is rebuilding after a long lockout, said Thursday that it had chosen an interim leader to take over after its president and chief executive, Michael Henson, steps down this summer: Kevin Smith, a former president of the Minnesota Opera.

title: Jason Wu Honored by Parsons
description: On Wednesday night at a black-tie dinner in Greenwich Village, Parsons the New School for Design honored Jason Wu, one of its graduates. The event attracted a crowd of fashion notables, including Donna Karan, Chris Benz and Tracy Reese.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Jutta Koether: Champrovent
description: Reena Spaulings Fine Art

title: Intellectual Dueling at a Prep School
description: Because Words and Pictures is a comedy of ideas couched in the format of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, the temptation for some critics faced with a film that dares to be ostentatiously smart is to blast it to smithereens. Which more or less describes the critical reaction to the movie when it was shown last year at the Toronto Film Festival.

title: Yo, Beau. Whats Up?
description: My boyfriend and I have been together for about two years. Last week, I overheard him on the telephone telling a good friend that he would like to break up with me. (Literally: Bro, I want to dump her.) He thought I was out of the apartment, so I havent said anything about it. It felt like eavesdropping to me. But hes not acting as if he wants to break up. In fact, hes been incredibly sweet lately. Im afraid Im being delusional. Should I say something to him? And if so, what?

title: Anicka Yi: Divorce
description: 47 Canal

title: August Sander/Bernd and Hilla Becher: A Dialogue
description: Bruce Silverstein Gallery

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Thailand, Ukraine, India and Turkey.

title: Attack Kills More Than 30 in Western China Market
description: URUMQI, China  Assailants driving two sport utility vehicles and tossing explosive devices plowed through a crowded vegetable market on Thursday in this city, the capital of the Xinjiang region in far western China, killing 31 people and wounding 94. It was the single deadliest attack here since ethnic bloodletting claimed hundreds of lives five years ago.

title: Lynda Barry: Everything: Part I
description: Adam Baumgold

title: Sam Moyer: More Weight
description: Rachel Uffner Gallery

title: Tunga: From La Voie Humide
description: Luhring Augustine

title: 2 Cities Withdraw Bids to Host 2016 G.O.P. Convention
description: WASHINGTON  Las Vegas and Cincinnati have informed the Republican National Committee that they are withdrawing from the competition to host the partys 2016 convention. The other four finalists, Cleveland, Dallas, Denver and Kansas City, will receive official site visits from the committees 2016 site selection delegation, according to a news release.

title: What I Learned on Paternity Leave: Im Glad to Be Back at Work
description: I was my daughters sole caregiver long enough to know that I was ready for it to be over. That doesnt mean I regret taking paternity leave. In fact, realizing that I felt that way was one of the best things about it.

title: Tasting France Through 5 Signature Dishes
description: Ive always felt that a map of France reads like a menu. The very names of regions can incite ravenous pangs. Each has a signature dish, from Brittanys butter-crisped crepes, to the generous cuts of pork draped over mounds of tangy sauerkraut in the eastern reaches of Alsace. Provence bursts with a rich soup of Mediterranean fish; the bounty of Languedocs flat, dry plains comes alive in the warmth of simmering cassoulet.

title: Must-Eat Dishes, From Myanmar to Mexico City
description: To accompany our cover article on regional food specialties around France, we asked some food experts to weigh in with their tips for must-eats in other parts of the world. Following is a selection.

title: How to Prep Before You Grill
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Stamps, Coins and Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Violinists Lucky Concerto? First, a Prize; Now, the Philharmonic
description: Two dominant figures from the British music scene made their Avery Fisher Hall debuts with the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday evening. The fiery Russian conductor Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra and music director, for over a decade, of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera, led the Philharmonic for the first time, drawing a strong performance that was especially memorable for the raw power of the musics climaxes. The 26-year-old Scottish violinist Nicola Benedetti, who had previously appeared only in a parks concert with the orchestra, stepped in to perform Szymanowskis Violin Concerto No. 1 at a moments notice when the Dutch star violinist Janine Jansen had to withdraw on doctors orders.

title: An Intellectual and His Lofty Contempt
description: When Gore Vidal declared in an old television debate with William F. Buckley Jr. that 5 percent of Americans had 20 percent of the income and the bottom 20 percent had 5 percent, he was raising an alarm. That observation may be the most shocking moment in Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia, Nicholas Wrathalls admiring documentary portrait of Vidal, who died in 2012 at 86.

title: Philip Roth to Appear on Colbert Report
description: So where on television can you get a really substantial discussion of the great American novel?

title: With Border Reopened, Crossing the Rio Grande to Mexico
description: On a May afternoon several years ago, my friend Drew and I took a day trip from Marfa, Texas, where we both lived at the time, to Big Bend National Park, about 100 miles away. Temperatures often reach into the 90s and 100s in the late spring in Far West Texas, so we were called to the water that day, and headed for the edge of the Rio Grande, at the east end of the park.

title: Hotel Review: Sir Albert Hotel in Amsterdam
description: Rates

title: An Appeal to Europe, From Ukraines Ambassador
description: To the Editor:

title: Creationism in College
description: To the Editor:

title: Natural Gas Race
description: To the Editor:

title: 9/11 Museum Fees Dont Faze Visitors
description: MARY LARSON and her family had come to New York City from Erie, Pa., this week for her sons graduation. Marlena and Edgar Dupre had flown in from San Antonio to board a cruise. Peter and Kirsten Abitz, from Denmark, were on vacation, as was Linda Christeaen from Belgium. The 40 or so students at Greenwich High School in Connecticut had taken a bus down for the day thanks in part to money raised by the PTA.

title: Limits of Health Networks
description: To the Editor:

title: Library Reveals Presidents Salary
description: Anthony W. Marx earned $781,000  including housing, tuition and other compensation  in his first full year as president and chief executive of the New York Public Library, according to the librarys most recent tax returns. According to the librarys Form 990, Mr. Marxs base salary for 2012 was $491,000, considerably lower than that of his predecessor, Paul LeClerc, who was making $667,000 when he left the library, in 2011. More recent salary figures are not available. Library salaries have been a topic of discussion in recent months as New York City officials review the salary of Thomas W. Galante, who gets about $391,000 as the director of the Queens Library system. Mr. Marx and other officers are paid with private funds.

title: Family Memoir in a Dreamscape
description: The Chilean-born filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky has recently been the subject of a revelatory documentary  Jodorowskys Dune, directed by Frank Pavich  about a movie he never made. There are a lot of those: Since his heyday in the early 70s as a midnight cult-film pioneer with El Topo and The Holy Mountain, Mr. Jodorowskys semimythic status as a cinematic wild man has outstripped his productivity as a director. So the arrival of a new feature  his first since 1990  would be grounds for excitement even, if the movie in question, The Dance of Reality, were not something very close to a masterpiece.

title: In Fields and Stadiums, Like One Long Concert
description: New York brims with summer entertainment, and that includes more choices than ever for those whose idea of it is to escape into a lost weekend of music festival revelry. Nearby options include the freewheeling Mountain Jam at Hunter Mountain (June 5-8), the folk and singer-songwriter hub Clearwaters Great Hudson River Revival in Croton-on-Hudson (June 21-22), the hip-hop- and rock-centric Made in America weekend in Philadelphia (Aug. 30-31) and many more. Here are six of the most-anticipated destination festivals in the region.

title: Golden Line Adds Tarnish to Sprawling Subway System
description: MEXICO CITY  There is music on the trains of Mexico Citys newest subway, the Golden Line, piped in at just the right volume to be pleasantly audible over the rumble. One recent morning, the playlist came to a classic: Midnight Train to Georgia.

title: 2 Major Time Inc. Magazines Will Run Cover Advertising
description: Time magazine and Sports Illustrated have started selling advertising space on their covers, breaking with a longstanding magazine industry tradition of keeping covers free of ads.

title: A Confederacy of Mavericks
description: Is there such a thing as artistic genius? In high-culture circles, it used to be taken for granted that there was, and there was a well-established canon of great artworks to prove it, from Leonardos Mona Lisa to Jackson Pollocks drip paintings. Then, at the end of the 1960s, scholars like Linda Nochlin, author of Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?, began to wonder why the canon consisted almost exclusively of works by male Caucasians. Is genius something that only white men are capable of? After that, belief in genius pretty much disappeared from serious art-historical discourse, except when it was disparaged as a patriarchal myth.

title: The Joys of Judging a Book by Its Cover
description: A womans melancholic eyes, heavy-lidded with desire, float in the nocturnal sky over a brashly lit skyline and amusement park.

title: Theater Listings for May 23-29
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Obama Revels in Quick Trip Through Baseballs Past
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  There are a few perks of office for any American president. And for President Obama, his broad smile on Thursday suggested that this was one of them.

title: Comedy Listings for May 23-29
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Street Chef of Gulshan
description: Follow a chef in the Gulshan section of Dhaka, Bangladesh, as he makes roti and eggs.

title: Hidden Lives: Street Chef of Gulshan
description: If our French and global food roundups didnt get your mouth watering, this might. Street Chef of Gulshan, produced by Fred Grace and Gemma Atkinson for Fat Rat Films, is part of the Hidden Lives series that we occasionally run. It takes you on a virtual trip to Bangladesh, and explores the idea that food is a means of understanding a place and its people.

title: Taiwan Activists Push for Same-Sex Marriage Bill
description: The young man in a Taiwan military uniform, a clear plastic bag over his head, stood before an array of paper tombstones along Ketagalan Boulevard in Taipei holding a sign that read: I am a soldier. I am gay. I passed the physical. Im not allowed to give blood.

title: Gleeful Museums Unpack a Bequest
description: The final group of paintings, drawings and sculptures bequeathed to museums by Paul Mellon before his death in 1999 have at last begun to arrive. Hidden away for decades, many are rarities that had never been seen by curators.

title: Women With Diabetes Face Greater Heart Risks Than Men
description: Type 2 diabetes substantially increases the risk for heart disease, but a large review of studies has found that women with diabetes are at much higher risk than men.

title: Transference? Ill Take It
description: I was in my early 40s, and my life was finally swinging into shape. I had a steady stream of work and warm, generous friends. But I had yet to find a viable, committed love. I kept falling for handsome artistic narcissists and their beautiful myths, while ordinary guys with decent looks, good jobs and kind natures simply didnt register on my radar.

title: Understanding the Thai Coup
description: The Thai military overthrew the countrys elected government on Thursday. It was the second time in a decade that the military has seized control. We asked Thomas Fuller, who is covering the coup for The Times, to recommend what to read on the political dynamics of Thai society. Here is his suggestion:

title: Architecture for the Upper East Side Horse
description: The legacies of the horse in New York include the stable street, where the well-to-do isolated their private stables to avoid the smells and noise, inflicting them instead on their lesser neighbors. Although the mansions they served are in most cases gone, a few of these stable streets survive, and one of the most significant is 69th Street, from Lexington to Third Avenues.

title: Lost in the Past
description: Ask a high school senior what the Great War was all about and youre likely to get a shrug or a stab based on a recent episode of Game of Thrones. Hint: its 100th anniversary is this year. Hint: globe-straddling old empires collapsed and new horrors, from genocide to slaughter by poisonous gas, were ushered in. Hint: its repercussions are with us still, from Syria to Russia to the American role as international cop.

title: Donovan Dropped From U.S. World Cup Team
description: Landon Donovan, widely considered the best male player in the history of United States soccer, was cut from the World Cup team on Thursday as Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed his roster to 23 players.

title: Sounds of All but Silence
description: The New Museum is alive with the sound of music, as well as talking, chanting, spitting, electronic tics and sputters and, occasionally, the tinkling of 47 small bronze bells. Its six current exhibitions all involve sound. One is almost nothing but sound. This loose, fluctuating connection illuminates some of the many roles sound plays in contemporary art while allowing the shows to, well, amplify one another in unexpected ways. It also mitigates the museums dark, awkwardly proportioned galleries.

title: The Pool Photographer, Literally
description: Marieke van der Velden is a pool photographer. Not the designated shooter, but one who photographs swimming holes  from deluxe to decrepit  around the world.

title: Events in Westchester for May 25-31, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: A Summer of TV Time Travel
description: For proof that summer is no longer the silly season of television  or at least not solely silly  just take a look at names involved in some notable shows from Memorial Day to September. Steven Soderbergh, Guillermo del Toro, Michael Bay, John Malkovich and Halle Berry are among the A-listers were not used to seeing attached to summer TV, or to TV shows at all.

title: Excavating the Past to Reshape the Present
description: From now until June 14, Danspace Project is all about DD Dorvillier, with programs exploring the work of that influential choreographer from multiple angles. In June comes a forward look, as Ms. Dorvillier debuts a solo. Starting on Friday are various sideways views, as longtime collaborators present solos of their own, examining shared connections. And the backward glance, befitting such an inveterate questioner of convention as Ms. Dorvillier, is nothing as standard as a remounting of past pieces.

title: Sunny Cannes Gets Lightning
description: CANNES, France  On Wednesday afternoon, the 83-year-old rock star Jean-Luc Godard shook up the Cannes Film Festival with his latest, a 70-minute 3-D extravaganza, Goodbye to Language. Finally, the competition lineup had something it has desperately needed all week: a thrilling cinematic experience that nearly levitated the packed 2,300-seat Lumire theater here, turning just another screening into a real happening. You could feel the electric charge  the collective effervescence  that can come when individuals transform into a group. Godard forever! a voice boomed out to laughter and applause, as the congregated viewers waited for their brains to light up with the screen.

title: Grabbing the Good Songs From Sources All Over
description: In contemporary songwriting, how true is the commonly voiced adage They dont write em like they used to? That received wisdom is powerfully challenged in the singer Marissa Mulders wonderful new show, Living Standards, which had its first performance on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room.

title: Movie Listings for May 23-29
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: They Want Your Blood
description: Can you judge the state of an actors career based on how he is required to die on camera? If so, Christopher Lloyd has cause for concern.

title: Ronaldos Toughest Move
description: FUNCHAL, Portugal  The roads of Madeira twist together like licorice ropes, their spindly curves beginning at the seashore and rising up the steps of this steep island in a maze reminiscent of Rio de Janeiros favelas. The slow climb here comes with a similar feeling to the Brazilian shanties, too: one of utter insulation, a complete removal from the tourist areas that lie below.

title: Ex-Leader Embodies a German Divide on Russia
description: BERLIN  It was an image that provoked consternation abroad and in an instant captured Germanys long-conflicted place between East and West: former Chancellor Gerhard Schrder embracing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as he arrived last month at a party in St. Petersburg for the Germans 70th birthday.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 23-29
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pakistans Media Under Attack
description: The Pakistani journalist Raza Rumi survived an assassination attempt in March that killed his driver. He and other liberals have been targeted for criticizing Islamist militancy and a blasphemy law.

title: Jazz Listings for May 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for May 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for May 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Me, My Mother, My Father, and I
description: A short view of Ragnar Kjartanssons exhibition.

title: Memorial Day Weekend Listings for the New York Area
description: Memorial Day Weekend

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 23-29
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Roberto Cuoghis Suillakku Corral
description: A short view of Mr. Cuoghis sound installation.

title: Youre Never Too Old to Be Studied
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  WHEN older patients seek health care, they are unwittingly enrolling in an experiment: Will medical procedures that have been proved effective mainly on the young also help the elderly?

title: Veterans Health Care, Under Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Food Firm That Popularized Sushi Looks Globally for Growth
description: The Mizkan Groups $2.15 billion purchase of Unilevers Ragu and Bertolli pasta sauce brands is the latest overseas foray by a storied and gutsy vinegar maker, one that helped transform sushi from an obscure delicacy into a global culinary phenomenon.

title: Camille Henrots Grosse Fatigue
description: A short view of Ms. Henrots installation.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 23-29
description: A YEAR WITH CHILDREN 2014

title: Saving Their Future, in Bell-Bottoms
description: Even compared with other self-serious superhero franchises  the brooding Dark Knight saga, the agonized Amazing Spider-Man, the hectic Avengers house party  the X-Men series wears its allegorical heart on its sleeve. In chronicling the adventures of a despised minority with extraordinary powers, the movies, like the Marvel comic books before them, poke around in some interesting social and political hot zones. The central conflict is the endless moral and political argument between Professor X and Magneto: in other words, between the accommodationist idea that the mutants should fight for the moral redemption of the humans, and the militant insistence that they should defend their own interests by any means necessary.

title: Monsters (the Human Kind) Slithering Through East Texas
description: The pulpy neo-noir Cold in July should propel the filmmaking team of Jim Mickle and Nick Damici further up the blood-spattered, zombie-infested hierarchy of B-movie auteurs with Hollywood ambitions. Last year, they advanced a few feet with their remake of the 2011 Mexican cannibal fest, We Are What We Are, which followed two microbudget cult favorites: the post-apocalyptic Stake Land (2011), and Mulberry St. (2007), a medical horror flick.

title: What to Do in New York City in Summer 2014
description: Winter was no picnic, but the amnesia that summer provides is just around the corner. The seasons lodestar, Macys Fourth of July fireworks show, is moving back to the East River, guided by the wishes of the Brooklynite mayor, Bill de Blasio. To witness another spectacle, find the camping gear and clear your calendar to ensure a ticket to King Lear, starring John Lithgow and Annette Bening, the Public Theaters free Shakespeare in the Park production. No matter the temperature, New York is the place to be. Heres a summer guide to make the most of it.

title: Former Defense Secretary Gates Is Elected President of the Boy Scouts
description: Robert M. Gates, the former secretary of defense and director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was elected president of the Boy Scouts of America on Thursday, formally taking leadership of an organization that continues to be roiled by its policy on gay Scouts and leaders.

title: Events on Long Island for May 25-31, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: When Single Parents Collide on a Safari
description: Because life is short and I have other things to be upset about, I will not dwell on the offensive aspects of Blended, the new Adam Sandler comedy: its retrograde gender politics; its delight in the humiliation of children; its sentimental hypocrisy about male behavior; its quasi-zoological depiction of Africans as servile, dancing, drum-playing simpletons; its ... Im sorry. Thats just what I said I wouldnt do.

title: Hit by Rivals, Hewlett-Packard Will Cut Jobs
description: Meg Whitman, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has said that it will take a long time to get the company on the right course. The quarterly results released Thursday underlined that a recovery was still in the distance.

title: Maintaining Hopes of Starting, Jets Vick Grapples With Backup Role
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Michael Vick is accustomed to being either the unquestioned starting quarterback or, at worst, knowing he would be given every opportunity to vie for that role. But on Thursday, he sounded very much like a proud but aging star intent on doing whatever necessary to extend a once-brilliant career.

title: Inside the Ropes, McIlroy Keeps It Together
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England  All Rory McIlroy wanted to do was take refuge on the golf course, inside the ropes, and play the first round of the rest of his life at the BMW PGA Championship, the European Tours flagship event.

title: An 18th-Century Korea, Swarming With Assassins
description: The title of Lee Jae-kyoos The Fatal Encounter is a misnomer: The film teems with fatal encounters. It is 1777, in the Joseon dynasty in Korea, and King Jeong-jo (Hyun Bin)  known historically as the king of misfortune  is surrounded by enemies. Two factions, the Noron and Soron, are at each others throats, and everyone, it seems, has it in for him. Even his trusted clerk, Sang-chaek (an effectively understated Jung Jae-young), a quiet minder of this philosopher-kings library, was trained in childhood at a kind of assassin school for slaves. He has positioned himself to strike but discovers that the monarch is a benign ruler and a friend.

title: Dominican Republic Passes Law for Migrants Children
description: Under international pressure, the Dominican Republic is poised to create a path to citizenship for tens of thousands of people of Haitian descent whose legal right to reside in the country had been thrown in doubt by a court ruling last year.

title: Crisis of the Eurocrats
description: A century ago, Europe tore itself apart in what was, for a time, known as the Great War  four years of death and destruction on an unprecedented scale. Later, of course, the conflict was renamed World War I  because a quarter-century later Europe did it all over again.

title: Too Much Looking, Not Enough Listening?
description: The reviews of the production of Der Rosenkavalier that opened this years Glyndebourne opera festival in England have gone viral, but not in a way that either the performers or the critics who wrote them probably expected. At issue: the way several prominent male critics harped on the shape, and not just the sound, of the young mezzo-soprano portraying Octavian: Tara Erraught.

title: Status Quo Gets a Nod, but Arizona Is Changing
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks started so poorly this season that their management team had reason to worry. With only five wins in their first 23 games, after consecutive .500 seasons, some kind of change seemed inevitable.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 23, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review X-Men: Days of Future Past, Cold in July and Blended.

title: Finding Central Parks Hidden Gems
description: Ive been visiting Central Park regularly since I moved to New York three years ago, but I remain a total novice when it comes to navigating within it. Ive only intermittently been able to find a beautiful fountain I once stumbled upon, and I was hoping that the recently redesigned app from the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that runs the park, could help.

title: Family of Detained Egyptian Journalist Says Leaked Images of Him Were Staged
description: The family of an Egyptian journalist who has been detained for nine months without charge expressed outrage on Thursday that images of him were leaked to a Facebook page run by sympathizers of the Interior Ministry.

title: Televising Sizzling Meat to Bump Up Sales of a Brisket Sandwich
description: TELEVISION commercials have  grown shorter over the decades, with 60-second spots the norm at the dawn of the medium, 30-second spots growing popular in the 1970s, and 15-second spots catching on in the 1980s. The number of 15-second ads grew more than 80 percent between 2008 and 2012, according to Nielsen, which notes the popularity of mobile devices, where commercials must impress quickly as users toggle among apps.

title: Competing Visions for Russias Economic Future
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  A panel at an annual economic forum here was deeply divided over the direction of the Russian economy. The isolationists in the group favored relying on state banks for its financing needs. Others called for Russia to deepen its ties with China, while a different contingent said global trade and commerce remain critical.

title: Near-Average Hurricane Season Is Predicted for U.S. as El Nio Develops in the Pacific
description: The Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico are highly likely to experience an average or below-average number of hurricanes and tropical storms this year, including fewer of the most dangerous hurricanes with winds above 110 miles per hour, government forecasters said Thursday.

title: Old Mystery for Clippers Fill-In C.E.O.
description: For years, as the business rsum of Richard Parsons swelled, a bit of his early life remained unexplored or ignored: his college basketball career at the University of Hawaii nearly 50 years ago.

title: Events in Connecticut for May 25-31, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: $200 Million Could Curb Pension Cuts in Detroit
description: In a series of votes that could be critical for Detroits emergence from bankruptcy, the Michigan State House on Thursday agreed to contribute nearly $200 million in state money for a deal to spare Detroits retirees from larger pension cuts and to avoid selling artworks from the citys museum.

title: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, Rolling Stones Money Manager, Dies at 80
description: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, a Bavarian aristocrat and money manager who guided the Rolling Stones to riches and through financial crises  helping to elevate them to an economic behemoth  without ever acquiring a taste for rock music, died on Tuesday in London. He was 80.

title: A Hedge Fund Highflier Comes Back to Earth
description: ENGLISH BICKNOR, England  The chickens of the one percent could roost comfortably here.

title: Really Good Books, Part I
description: People are always asking me what my favorite books are. Ive held off listing them because it seems self-indulgent. But, with summer almost here, I thought I might spend a couple columns recommending eight books that have been pivotal in my life.

title: Wade Is Flourishing in Playoffs Despite His Worrisome Knees
description: MIAMI  Dwyane Wade objected  in unquestionably polite and good-natured ways  to the wording of two questions posed to him by reporters after the Miami Heats workout here Thursday morning.

title: No Gap to Mind
description: French commentators are scrambling to find just the right words to describe a costly bureaucratic blunder that came to light on Wednesday, thanks to some digging by the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchan. Was the foul-up only comically tragic, as a French transportation minister sheepishly described it, a vaudeville farce, as a rail workers union saw it, or a howler verging on madness as a leading French newspaper suggested.

title: Path to an Asylum Request, From Egypt Jail to California Fair
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As he walked out of a Cairo electronics store the night of April 24, Abdullah Assem, 17, was met by several police officers who told him he was under arrest for creating an antigovernment rebel group and for shooting at a government security building.

title: Misdiagnosis? Youd Be Angry, Too
description: From the director of Field of Dreams comes one of those movies about someone who learns he has a terminal diagnosis and desperately tries to take stock. In Phil Alden Robinsons The Angriest Man in Brooklyn, Robin Williams plays an irascible New York lawyer who gains a sudden window of self-awareness when a doctor says he has 90 minutes left to live. The movie is predictably sentimental at its root, but its also meant to be comedy, partly resting on Mr. Williamss energetic but failed attempt to play a jerk.

title: The Secret Shame of the Death Penalty
description: Sooner or later, someone like Russell Bucklew was going to come along and throw a big wrench into the predictable back-and-forth debate over the constitutionality of executing people by lethal injection.

title: Evacuation at Sept. 11 Museum Is Revealed
description: Last week, five days before it opened to the public, the National September 11 Memorial Museum was briefly evacuated, sending dozens of startled visitors scrambling up seven stories to daylight.

title: Events in New Jersey for May 25-31, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Fans in Spain Reveal Their Prejudices, and Social Media Fuels the Hostilities
description: MADRID  Spains sports fans have given Europe a version of the Donald Sterling racism scandal roiling America.

title: A Surveillance Bill That Falls Short
description: A year ago, it would have been unimaginable for the House to pass a bill to curtail the governments abusive surveillance practices. The documents leaked by Edward Snowden, however, finally shocked lawmakers from both parties into action, producing promises that they would stop the government from collecting the telephone data of ordinary Americans and would bring greater transparency to its domestic spying programs.

title: I.R.S. Delays New Rules on Taxation for Activists
description: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it has delayed and is revamping new rules intended to curb political activity by tax-exempt groups and that were proposed after the agency was accused last year of targeting Tea Party groups.

title: Keeping Track: Gay Marriage, Patent Reform and Airbnbs Data
description: Marriage Equality Advances

title: Twitter Agrees to Block Blasphemous Tweets in Pakistan
description: At least five times this month, a Pakistani bureaucrat who works from a colonial-era barracks in Karachi, just down the street from the former home of his countrys secularist founder, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, asked Twitter to shield his compatriots from exposure to accounts, tweets or searches of the social network that he described as blasphemous or unethical.

title: Officials Cast Wide Net in Monitoring Occupy Protests
description: When the Occupy protests spread across the country three years ago, state and local law enforcement officials went on alert. In Milwaukee, officials reported that a group intended to sing holiday carols at an undisclosed location of high visibility. In Tennessee, an intelligence analyst sought information about whether groups concerned with animals, war, abortion or the Earth had been involved in protests.

title: The Politics of Breastfeeding
Facebooks New Privacy Mascot: The Zuckasaurus
description: So why a dinosaur?

title: Baseball Lords Vexed by Plan for a New King
description: The search for Major League Baseballs next commissioner has been unusual for an organization that has $8 billion in annual revenue and regards itself as a Fortune 500-caliber company. A search firm has not been hired, and there has been no attempt to vet a wide-ranging list of internal or external candidates.

title: A Prisoners Unflagging Claim of Innocence Meets an Unexplained Intrusion
description: How does time pass for a person in prison who says he is innocent?

title: Clip: The Angriest Man in Brooklyn
description: A scene from the film.

title: From Virginia, Chasing Down Credit Suisse
description: Hundreds of miles from Credit Suisses Madison Avenue office tower and an ocean away from its headquarters in Zurich, the bank found an unlikely opponent in Alexandria, Va.

title: U.S. Case Offers Glimpse Into Chinas Hacker Army
description: BEIJING  One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not have much ambition but wanted to wander the world with a sword, an idiot.

title: Life With, and Without, Father
description: Nicolas Merciers reassuring Grand Dpart explores relationships painfully familiar to anyone who has dealt with an aging parents declining health and mental faculties. Often, in such situations, fraught connections with siblings  rivalries and unforgiven childhood slights  can be as stressful as tending to a dying loved one.

title: Nets Deron Williams to Have Ankle Surgery
description: Nets point guard Deron Williams will have surgery on both of his troublesome ankles, the team said Thursday.

title: After Prison, a Life on the Ropes
description: Wolf follows Majid  a second-generation Dutchman of Moroccan descent recently released from prison and back living with his disapproving family  as he works in a warehouse and begins to make a career as a kickboxer in prize fights. His best friend, though, keeps involving him in robberies that grow bigger and bolder, and Majid eventually draws the interest of Hakan, a mob boss who sees potential in him.

title: Northern Ireland Police Sue for Boston College Interviews
description: LONDON  The police in Northern Ireland said on Thursday that they were taking legal action against Boston College to obtain all transcripts and recordings of interviews with paramilitary members on both sides of the sectarian divide who took part in an oral history project there.

title: Government Surveillance of the Occupy Protests
description: The following documents are a selection from among about 4,000 pages of unclassified emails and reports about the Occupy protests distributed by people working with counterterrorism and intelligence-sharing offices known as fusion centers.

title: Home for the Summer, in a Refugee Camp
description: Exiles at home, the generations of family depicted in the documentary A World Not Ours live in Lebanon without completely being part of it. This affecting, humor-tinged debut feature from Mahdi Fleifel goes back to the old neighborhood in southern Lebanon: the refugee camp Ain al-Helweh, a Palestinian pocket of hemmed-in buildings and stifled hopes.

title: Felony Charges Are Filed in Case of 2004 Disappearance
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Ten years after absconding with his girlfriends 15-year-old daughter, Isidro Medrano Garcia was charged by prosecutors on Thursday with raping and kidnapping the girl, who subsequently became his wife and the mother of his child and who lived with him for the past decade.

title: Indictment Details 3 Kidnappings Linked to Coerced Divorces
description: When several rabbis and ultra-Orthodox men were accused in October of being a part of a ring that kidnapped and tortured Jewish husbands who refused to grant divorces to their wives, the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey said the number of victims might run into the dozens.

title: Jersey City Sues Port Authority Over Taxes on Property
description: After months of threatening and some grudging negotiations, Jersey City sued the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday, seeking more than $300 million in unpaid taxes.

title: If Life Gives You Baloney, Make a Sandwich
description: As the stacks of cold cuts and the sliced Cheddar dwindle, so do the prospects of staying financially afloat for the three beleaguered central characters in American Hero, a sweet and sour new comedy by Bess Wohl that opened on Thursday night at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in the annual Uptown series from Second Stage Theater. Cast adrift when the owner of the new sandwich franchise where they work mysteriously disappears, the stores employees alternate between despair at the latest dead end in their lives and fragile hope that by keeping calm and carrying on making sandwiches, somehow things will turn out all right.

title: Inside Opening
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This puzzle by David Steinberg is an optical illusion, a feature Ive never seen in a puzzle before. It reminds me of this illusion, where two different pictures can be seen, depending on how you look at it. Can you see the two visual aspects of the grid? At first glance, you might see two arrows running in opposite directions, but as you fill in the puzzle  especially as you get to the center of it  you will begin to realize that there is more than meets the eye with Mr. Steinbergs grid.

title: We Feel Your Vibe
description: Before summer tent poles are fully erected, and science fiction is dominated by spaceships, superheroes and special effects, Frequencies arrives to remind us that all sci-fi truly requires is a slightly surreal twist on life.

title: Assads Forces Break Yearlong Rebel Siege of Prison
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Government forces broke through a protracted rebel siege of one of Syrias largest prisons on Thursday, dealing yet another blow to their opponents and highlighting the suffering that the countrys war has brought to those caught between the warring parties.

title: Poll Finds Only Narrow Majority Supports Egypts Expected Big Winner
description: CAIRO  The former general who is universally expected to win a landslide victory in next weeks presidential election has the support of only a narrow majority of Egyptians, according to a poll released Thursday by the Pew Research Center.

title: The Plagiarists Love Interest
description: A recent surge in cachet for Daniel Brhl  he played the methodical Formula One driver Niki Lauda in Rush and the sniper turned movie star in Inglourious Basterds  hasnt quite blown the dust off Lila, Lila, a glossy trifle released in 2009 in Germany thats belatedly opening in New York.

title: Anything to Save Their Pensions
description: The French Riviera scenery from this months Cannes Film Festival may act as an enticement, but onlookers are advised not to imitate the drastic measures taken in The Love Punch, a good-natured if strenuously wacky caper comedy about a divorced British couple who plot a diamond heist to save their pensions.

title: A Striking Success
description: One week after winning Spains top league, Atltico Madrid can add a second trophy on Saturday if it beats its city rival, Real Madrid, in the UEFA Champions League final in Lisbon. But regardless of the result, Atltico has already had the kind of success that any club would envy, replacing players without missing a beat.

title: The End for Long Island College Hospital
description: Evelyn Valdez, an intensive care nurse at Long Island College Hospital, had already been asked to turn in her identity card. She was taking photos on her tablet on Thursday, to remember the place where she had worked for nearly 30 years and which she called her second home.

title: In Search of Space and Creativity, a Start-Up Is Headed to Brooklyn
description: When 3rd Ward, the educational, art and design work space based in Bushwick, Brooklyn, closed its massive warehouse complex last fall amid financial troubles, the creative community it had housed scattered  some to smaller studios, workshops and schools in Brooklyn, others to strike out on their own.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 22, 2014
Sanctions Imposed Against Boko Haram
description: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday added Boko Haram, the Nigerian extremist group, to its Al Qaeda Sanctions List, a blacklist of individuals and organizations affiliated with Al Qaeda. The designation subjects Boko Haram members to penalties that include a freeze on assets, a travel ban and an arms embargo. Nigeria had sought the designation as part of a broader response to a wave of attacks on schools and other targets by the group and its kidnapping of nearly 300 schoolgirls last month. The Security Council designation announcement cited the groups avowed affinity and collaboration with Al Qaeda and its violent insurgency utilizing terrorist tactics. The designation was welcomed by Samantha Power, the United States ambassador, who said the Councils action had helped to close off important avenues of funding, travel and weapons to Boko Haram, and shown global unity against their savage actions.

title: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 35 Pilgrims
description: Suicide bombers and car bombs killed at least 35 Shiite pilgrims and wounded dozens more in attacks in Baghdad on Thursday, security officials said. The pilgrims were on their way to the shrine of a Shiite saint in Kadhimiya, in northern Baghdad, to commemorate the anniversary of his death. A day earlier, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki urged the security forces to protect pilgrims traveling to the shrine. The deadliest attack took place in the Ur neighborhood of eastern Baghdad, where a car bomb exploded near a tent for pilgrims, killing 14 people, including four children, security officials said. We need a new government that is able to protect us from those terrorists that are the enemies of God, said a man wounded in the Ur bombing, Jafar al-Musawi. An attack in central Baghdad by a suicide bomber killed 12 pilgrims and wounded 26, and in the western Baghdad neighborhood of Mansour, a car bomb killed nine people and wounded 20, officials said.

title: Guatemala: Ex-President Sentenced
description: Former President Alfonso Portillo was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattanon Thursday to nearly six years in prison for conspiring with others to launder millions of dollars through United States bank accounts, federal prosecutors said. Mr. Portillo, 62, who was extradited to the United States in May 2013 after fighting extradition for three years, pleaded guilty in March before Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. In courton Thursday, speaking through an interpreter, he apologized and said that he felt profoundly remorseful and embarrassed, adding, God and history will know whether I was a good or bad man during my time on this earth, The Associated Press reported.

title: Nod, Smile and Wave While You Can (Wink!)
description: MELVILLE, N.Y.  Kathy Hochul bounded up the stairs to the podium, full of vim, vigor and enthusiasm. Shed just been nominated as the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, replacing our current Lt. Gov. Whatshisname.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 23, 2014
description: There was a huge financial crisis that rocked the world, and it didnt matter to us if the frauds occurred within the four corners of our district or around the globe.

title: Recalling a Title Run and Trying to Stop One
description: Like so many others his age in the New York region, Max Pacioretty became a Rangers fan during the spring of 1994 as the team surged to a title.

title: Sinkhole Cant Stop the Pastrami
Struggling Mets Stand Up to an Ace
description: As Zack Greinke took the mound for the Los Angeles Dodgers on Thursday night, he did not look especially intimidating. He was not particularly tall. He was not overly muscular. His face looked boyish as he paced around the mound, kicked at the dirt, toed the rubber and stared down the first batter.

title: Obama to Nominate Julin Castro as HUD Secretary
description: CHICAGO  President Obama on Friday will nominate Mayor Julin Castro of San Antonio to be the secretary of housing and urban development, a White House official said Thursday.

title: Suzuki Would Relish a Chance to Pitch One More Time
description: CHICAGO  On Wednesday, for the first time since 1970, the Yankees used 21 players in a game before the Sept. 1 expansion of rosters to 40 players. They used every position player and every relief pitcher in the 13-inning game. Only the four other starting pitchers did not play.

title: A Speaker Who May Have Less of a Say
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Fraud Unit Gone, Some Fear Increased Fuel Tax Evasion
description: Piqued last year over the refusal by the Travis County district attorney, Rosemary Lehmberg, to resign after her drunken driving arrest, Gov. Rick Perry exercised his veto and withheld more than $7.5 million in state money from her offices public integrity unit.

title: A Longer, Costlier Grind for Primary Candidates
description: The primary runoff contests on Tuesday might be as much a test of voter memories as a referendum on which candidates made the most successful appeals to the electorate.

title: Gerald M. Edelman, Nobel Laureate and Neural Darwinist, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Gerald M. Edelman, who shared a 1972 Nobel Prize for a breakthrough in immunology and went on to contribute key findings in neuroscience and other fields, becoming a leading if contentious theorist on the workings of the brain, died on Saturday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 84.

title: Allan Folsom, Whose First Novel Sold for $2 Million, Dies at 72
description: Allan Folsom, a struggling screenwriter whose first novel, an intricate thriller called The Day After Tomorrow, was by some accounts the highest-priced fiction debut in publishing history when its rights sold for $2 million in 1993, died on May 16 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72.

title: Catherine M. Abate, 66, a State Senator and Corrections Chief, Dies
description: Catherine M. Abate, a former New York state senator and commissioner of New York Citys Correction Department whose campaign for attorney general was derailed by questions about her fathers connection to organized crime, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 66.

title: Ask Well: For Fitness, 2,000 Calories a Week?
description: Question:

title: Word of the Day | predetermine
description: predetermine \pri-di-tr-mn\ verb

title: Rangers March to Stanley Cup Turns Wobbly
description: Greasy goals, they are called in hockey parlance  goals that bounce in off skates and bodies, goals that are not pretty.

title: A Dominant Return Sinks the Yankees
description: CHICAGO  As Chris Sale worked his way almost effortlessly through Yankee after flailing Yankee, a curious notion began to take shape.

title: With an Early Hit, the Canadiens Agitator Restores Feistiness to a Series
description: There were players skating on the Madison Square Garden ice Thursday night whose best assets were their booming slap shots, or their effortless skating strides, or their soft hands around the net.

title: Times Minute | Facebook Privacy Moves
description: Also on the Minute, the latest N.S.A. bill is weaker than expected, and A.O Scott reviews X-Men: Days of Future Past.

title: Times Minute | Facebook Privacy Moves
description: In the Video

title: Corrections: May 23, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Billionaire Leader of Mafia-Style Gang Sentenced to Die
description: A Chinese tycoon and his brother have been sentenced to death for murder and running a mafia-style gang that engaged in a two-decade crime spree, accumulating a business empire amounting to more than $6 billion.

title: Swedish Cable Company Hopes to Raise $830 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Swedish cable company Com Hem Holding said on Friday that it was seeking to raise about $830 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq OMX Stockholm exchange.

title: Boeing Agrees to Acquire British Aviation Software Firm
description: LONDON  The aircraft maker Boeing said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire ETS Aviation, a provider of fuel-efficiency management and analytics software.

title: A Conversation With: Meena Menon, The Hindus Former Correspondent in Pakistan
description: On May 13, the only two Indian journalists in Pakistan, Snehesh Alex Philip of the Press Trust of India and Meena Menon of The Hindu, were told by the countrys Ministry of Information that their visas would not be renewed and that they would have to leave Pakistan in a week.

title: Okinawa Mayor Takes Fight Against U.S. Base to Washington
description: WASHINGTON  To some, the long-stalled agreement to relocate a United States Marine base from a heavily populated area of Okinawa, Japan, to a smaller city might finally be seeing the light of day. During his visit to Japan in April, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel said, We look forward to the facilitys construction beginning soon. A few weeks later at a news conference in Tokyo, President Obama and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed that progress had been made.

title: Britains Discontent Lifts Populist Party to Even Stronger Vote Tally Than Expected
description: LONDON  Voters in Britain sent a forceful message of discontent to established political parties on Friday, as returns from local elections showed an even stronger following than expected for the anti-European Union, anti-immigration United Kingdom Independence Party.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 23, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: A Scholarly Response to Tiger Mom': Happiness Matters, Too
description: Its a joke among parents in Beijing  where people are acutely aware of the differences between China and the United States and where there are many mixed-culture families and styles of parenting  that when a child scores 99 on a test, an American parent will lavish praise. But a Chinese parent will say: What happened? Why didnt you get 100?

title: 6 Qs About the News | Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too Happy in Tehran
description: In Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too Happy in Tehran,  Robert Mackey reports on the YouTube video that landed six Iranians in jail.

title: Saga, Seller of Insurance and Travel Packages, Raises $928 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Saga, the British seller of insurance, travel packages and other products aimed at people over 50 years old, said Friday that it raised about $928 million in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Can Students at Your School Talk Openly About Their Mental Health Issues?
description: Two students published an Op-Ed essay in The New York Times on Thursday about the difficulty they had trying to foster an open and honest dialogue about depression in their high school.

title: The Pool Photographer, Literally
description: What traveler hasnt gotten off a plane after a long flight and, suddenly trying to adjust to a warm climate, thought about a dip in the water?

title: German Photographer Wins Prix Pictet
description: LONDON  Waiters passed around glasses of champagne in the grand atrium of the Victoria and Albert Museum here on Wednesday night as Kofi Annan, the former secretary general of the United Nations, announced that the German photographer Michael Schmidt had won this years Prix Pictet, an award that asks photographers to contribute work centered on an environmental or social theme.

title: After Urumqi Bloodshed, China Warns of Increasing Threat of Terrorism
description: As China reels from its deadliest terrorist attack in recent memory, officials and the state news media acknowledged that the frequency of such assaults had grown and called for greater preparedness to deal with the threat of violence against civilians.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today:  Memorial Day, Writ Small
description: Good morning to you on this damp Friday.

title: Syrian Rebels Claim Attack on Assad Supporters
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebels in southern Syria killed more than 20 people in a mortar attack on a tent put up as part of presidential elections next month, antigovernment activists said on Friday.

title: Atlas Mara to Acquire Majority Stake in Arm of Rwandan Bank
description: LONDON  The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by Robert E. Diamond Jr., theformer Barclays chief executive,said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the commercial arm of the Development Bank of Rwanda.

title: Regulator Fines Barclays Over the Pricing of Gold
description: Updated, 7:53 p.m. | A British financial regulator has fined Barclays $43.9 million after accusing a former trader at the bank of improperly influencing gold prices at the expense of a customer.

title: North Korea to Send Team to South Korea for Asian Games
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Friday that it would send a delegation to the Asian Games in the South Korean city of Incheon this autumn.

title: Speaking Their Minds
description: Anger is at the forefront of Sundays European Parliament elections.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Indictments Shed Some Light on Chinas Hacker Army
description: One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not have much ambition but wanted to wander the world with a sword, an idiot, Edward Wong reports.

title: Q. and A.: Gardner Bovingdon on Uighur Discontent and Chinas Choices
description: Thursday morning a series of explosions ripped through a crowded market in Urumqi, capital of the northwestern region of Xinjiang, killing 31 people and injuring 94. The incident was labeled a violent terrorist attack, and President Xi Jinping vowed to severely punish terrorists and spare no efforts in maintaining stability.
