It was the deadliest incident in Xinjiang this year, and it follows a series of attacks across the country carried out by members of the regions Uighur ethnic minority, some of whom want Xinjiang to break off from China to become an independent East Turkestan.

title: Thai Military Detains Ousted Leaders as Coup Sets Off Small Acts of Protest
description: BANGKOK  Former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra and leading members of Thailands deposed government surrendered to the military on Friday after being summoned by the generals now leading the country.

title: On Our Walls
description: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: Are We Ready for H.I.V.s Sexual Revolution?
description: PRETEND its 1960, and the Food and Drug Administration has just done something startling. It has taken a drug it had previously approved for infertility  brand name Enovid  and approved it for the opposite use: birth control.

title: For Apartment Dwellers, a Memorial Day Barbecue in a Glass
description: Its Memorial Day weekend, which marks the official start of barbecue season. But as my colleague Neil Irwin has noted, the recent uptick in housing construction is almost entirely about apartment construction. That means, in coming years, a declining percentage of American households will have a backyard to grill in.

title: As Publishers Fight Amazon, Books Vanish
description: Amazons power over the publishing and bookselling industries is unrivaled in the modern era. Now it has started wielding its might in a more brazen way than ever before.

title: The Brotherhood Will Be Back
description: WASHINGTON  After being ousted from power last July, Egypts Muslim Brotherhood, the Arab worlds original Islamist movement, faces an existential moment. The group has been targeted with extreme repression, prompting a wave of commentary about the failure  or even death  of political Islam.

title: In Our Pages: May 24
description: 1939: Queen Marys Limousine Hit

title: December 2011 Political Awareness Quiz
description: In research about voters who split their tickets, Lynn Vavrek came up with a quiz to test political awareness. These questions, which were fielded in December 2011, asked a representative sample of 45,000 people about legislative and executive branch leaders. Her article is here.

title: The Power of Political Ignorance
description: Split-ticket voting is quite rare for top offices like president and senator. But those who do choose candidates from different parties on Election Day have at least one thing in common: They know less about politics than people who vote the straight party line.

title: Class Field Trip Stops at a Local Pawnshop
description: READING, Ohio  The last time Brian Page had to file the paperwork to evict a tenant from a rental property he and his wife own, he noticed all the check-cashing services and pawn shops on his drive home from the courthouse. A clerk tipped him off to what was going on: Every day, lots of people leave court with checks theyve received in legal settlements. They often stop to cash their checks right away, paying a big fee for the privilege, and then go shopping with the money.

title: Research on Malaria-Resistant Children in Tanzania Leads to Promising New Vaccine Target
description: The quest for effective malaria vaccines has been long and challenging, so its important not to overplay a single study. But there is real promise in fresh findings reported by researchers in Science today. The work centers on a parasite protein, named PfSEA-1 by the authors, that was isolated after analysis of blood samples in resistant and susceptible Tanzanian toddlers. Paul Rodgers has a really nice piece on the paper in Forbes. Heres an excerpt:

title: U.S. Gains in a Spat With China Over Tariffs
description: WASHINGTON  The World Trade Organization sided with the United States on Friday in a dispute over punitive Chinese tariffs on American exports of cars and sport utility vehicles.

title: Spinning Country
description: Dee Jay Silver spins country music with a unique mix of multiple music genres.

title: A Hot Start for JD.com
description: JD.COM STARTS HOT | The online Chinese retailer JD.com started life as a publicly traded company with a rousing start, closing up 10 percent on the Nasdaq stock exchange on Thursday, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. At that price, shareholders valued the company at more than $28.6 billion, more than other United States technology names like Twitter and LinkedIn. Shares of the retailer closed at $20.90 for each American depositary receipt.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 2 A.M. (LMN) WINTERS BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence received her first Oscar nomination for her role as Ree Dolly, a teenager living in the Ozarks of southwestern Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. (Above from left, Ashlee Thompson, Ms. Lawrence and Isaiah Stone in the film.) John Hawkes plays her uncle, whose silent menace soon erupts into violence, though hes more compassionate than most. The harshness in Debra Graniks regional-realist morality tale, based on the novel by Daniel Woodrell, is not there to illuminate a sociological condition, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in Winters Bone, and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.

title: Country Music Opens Its Ears
description: NASHVILLE  About a year and a half ago, as the country superstar Blake Shelton was working on songs for his latest album, Based on a True Story , he reached out to John Esposito, the president of his label, Warner Bros. Nashville.

title: Celebrating Memorial Day and Looking Ahead
description: A veteran of the Iraq war finds new meaning in Memorial Day.

title: From Cheap to Cool, Revamped Car Is Aimed at Indias Young Buyers
description: NEW DELHI  When Tata Motors rolled out a supercheap compact vehicle in 2009, the automaker heralded the car saying it would change the lives of millions of Indians, particularly its aspirational middle class. But the egg-shaped car, the Nano, failed to impress and sales have been sluggish, undercut by an image of poor quality and underwhelming power.

title: Video Reviews of X-Men: Days of Future Past, Cold in July and Blended
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review X-Men: Days of Future Past, Cold in July and Blended. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Back to Normal Swedish Teenage Angst
description: Ingmar Bergman, Swedens most celebrated auteur, anointed his countryman Lukas Moodysson a young master. Mr. Moodysson was a published poet at 17 and, thanks to his first film, Show Me Love, was widely considered the new voice of Swedish cinema before he hit 30. Yet he has reacted with a kind of overgrown teenage disdain for the establishment: He has berated and made obscene gestures toward audiences and critics at awards receptions, avoided the press and once declared himself the most hated man in his native country. The guy was a stone punk.

title: Location Services in Desktop Browsers
description: Q. The web browser on my computer says a site wants to use my location. Why, and how does it know where I am, anyway?

title: In Chinas Far West, a City Struggles to Move On
description: URUMQI, China  They were hard-core bargain hunters, gray-haired bus drivers and bureaucrats on modest pensions who woke up early to find the cheapest produce in this increasingly expensive city. For the driver of the sport utility vehicle seeking to maximize the mayhem, they were the easiest of targets.

title: Being Called a Plain Jane
description: Dear Diary:

title: Younger Turn for a Graying Nation
description: THERE are now more young adults than there are baby boomers.

title: Assuming a Role, Putting the Story First
description: Many actors have heard the dreaded question: How did you learn all of those lines? But naturally, there is more to a characterization than memorizing sentences and speaking with conviction; the art of acting is mysterious, as difficult to explain as it is to do.

title: Targets Newest Designer Collaboration, Instagrams Latest Offender and Kate Mosss Little Sisters Big Modeling Plans
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Elliott Management Backs Skyscraper Revival
description: For decades, the building at 5 Beekman Street  the site of one of Manhattans first skyscrapers  went largely unused.

title: In the Newly Elected Indian Parliament, Worrying Trends
description: Satish Chandra Dubey faces charges including murder, attempted murder, rioting armed with a deadly weapon, robbery, theft and killing or maiming cattle, to name but a few.Mr. Dubey, who is alsosuspectedof involvement in drug smuggling and has previously been charged in abank robbery, is one of several criminals-turned-politicians in India. He is known as a bahubali, or a powerful person.

title: Got Nerves of Steel? Meet the Thunderbolt Roller Coaster
description: It may resemble a giant Erector set. But the new Thunderbolt roller coaster, which was manufactured in Italy and Slovakia and shipped to New York in pieces, is not childs play, at least when it comes to assembly.

title: Lindy Hop: Celebrating Frankie Manning
description: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze Lindy hop.

title: The Trends that Helped Sweep B.J.P. to Landslide Victory
description: NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Partys sweeping success in this years parliamentary elections has stunned most political observers, who have scrambled to explain it since the results were announced on May 16.

title: A Resurrection of Eternal Joy
description: For three decades, the album sat on a shelf.

title: Terrorists With Familiar Faces
description: Explosions and mayhem are a staple of summer blockbusters, whether brought about by hundred-foot robots or averted by superheroes. But what if the people blowing things up have a political agenda  like the radical environmentalists of Kelly Reichardts new drama, Night Moves? And what if theyre homegrown, not the stereotypical accented villains? Then it gets trickier: Everyone from moviegoers to producers to politicians can become sensitive when the characters are plausible, their politics real and their tactics deadly.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 20
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Fire Island Poetry Festival to Honor Frank OHara
description: Frank OHara, a founder of the New York School of poets, died at age 40 in the summer of 1966, after being hit by a dune buggy on Fire Island.Now, his reputation only burnished by posthumous publications of several collections of his work, the Fire Island Pines Arts Project is sponsoring the first national poetry festival in his honor.

title: Must the Captain Always Go Down With the Ship?
description: In light of the South Korean ferry tragedy, I have been thinking about the maxim that the captain goes down with the ship. I find it outdated and in need of re-evaluation. Clearly the captain has a duty and responsibility to ensure the safety of his passengers, and he should do everything in his power as the ship is sinking to save the lives of others. But should he be morally obligated to effectively commit suicide because he made a mistake, even if it was a result of gross negligence and leads to hundreds of deaths? RYAN CAIN, NEW YORK

title: Tom Robbins, Cosmic Lounge Lizard
description: The author talks to Rob Liguori about "Tibetan Peach Pie," the downsides of conventional wisdom and the reason Hunter S. Thompson never had a real LSD trip.

title: The Doctor Is In
description: Let me give you some free advice: If you give people free advice for a living, think twice before you tell anyone you know about it. Because when people who actually know you find out that you, of all people, are doling out advice, it can get uncomfortable.

title: The MacGyver Cure for Cancer
description: Two decades ago, David Walmer went on a volunteer mission with his church to Haiti. He was sent to paint walls at a hospital in the seaside town of Logne, but when the people there learned that Walmer was a doctor  he was a fertility specialist at Duke University  they asked him to spend the week with a local obstetrician-gynecologist named Jean-Claude Fertilien. Walmer was shocked by what he saw: Fertilien finishing a hysterectomy with the aid of a flashlight when the hospital generator failed to restart, for instance, or when an anesthesiologist wasnt available for an emergency C-section, the doctor just numbing the skin and cutting. At one point, Walmer was called to the bedside of a young woman in her mid-20s with undiagnosed cervical cancer who had gone into septic shock. There was nothing to be done for her, and she died right in front of him. Walmer was appalled. In the United States, cervical cancer is considered a preventable disease.

title: Avian Divorce
description: Meh-levators; Judge Hodgman rules on loud kissing.

title: Who Made That Weather Icon?
description: As a design student at the Norwich School of Art in the early 1970s, Mark Allen watched the weather broadcast every afternoon on the BBC. Back then, TV presenters slid magnetic symbols around a metal map: dots for rain, asterisks for snow, lines to mark off areas of equal pressure. They were just hieroglyphics as far as everybody was concerned, Allen says. Why was a triangle a rain shower?

title: Reply All: The 5.11.14 Issue
description: WHAT TIMOTHY GEITHNER REALLY THINKS

title: On Lockdown
description: The duck and cover drills of the 1950s, when American schoolchildren crawled under their desks in preparation for a nuclear bomb, have given way to regular lockdown drills in many states to counter the threat of school shootings. The photographer Alec Soth recently visited the Belle Plaine public high school, an hour outside Minneapolis, to witness its routine. When the principal announced that a lockdown was in effect, classroom doors were quickly locked; students who were in the middle of gym class moved to locker rooms and secured the doors behind them. For several minutes, they sat on the floor, heads lowered. It was pretty silent, Soth says. They were fairly nonchalant about the whole routine. Julie Bosman

title: Can the Nervous System Be Hacked?
description: One morning in May 1998, Kevin Tracey converted a room in his lab at the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research in Manhasset, N.Y., into a makeshift operating theater and then prepped his patient  a rat  for surgery. A neurosurgeon, and also Feinstein Institutes president, Tracey had spent more than a decade searching for a link between nerves and the immune system. His work led him to hypothesize that stimulating the vagus nerve with electricity would alleviate harmful inflammation. The vagus nerve is behind the artery where you feel your pulse, he told me recently, pressing his right index finger to his neck.

title: Joyces Town
description: In 1905, James Joyce wrote to the publisher Grant Richards: I do not think that any writer has yet presented Dublin to the world. It has been a capital of Europe for thousands of years, it is supposed to be the second city of the British Empire, and it is nearly three times as big as Venice.

title: True Crime
description: LITTLE DEMON IN THE CITY OF LIGHT  A True Story of Murder and Mesmerism in Belle poque Paris  By Steven Levingston  Doubleday, $26.95.

title: Paperback Row
description: FLORA,  by Gail Godwin. (Bloomsbury, $16.) Its the summer of 1945, and the still, humid days are fraught with impending consequence in Godwins 14th novel. Isolated in a decaying family home in North Carolina, two lonesome souls  motherless, 10-year-old Helen and her hopelessly earnest guardian, Flora  wait out a polio scare while Helens father is off doing secret war work in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE POSSIBILITIES,  by Kaui Hart Hemmings. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Hemmingss first novel since The Descendants is about learning to move forward, as a Colorado woman struggles with grief over her sons death in an avalanche.

title: On the Road Again
description: Much like smell (its all very well to say that something smells like an orange, but how do you describe the smell of an orange?), music is notoriously difficult to evoke on the page. The fact that language has musical attributes  rhythm, melody, tone  isnt much help when youre trying to express Bartok or Captain Beefheart in words. Even when music has lyrics, its essence is antilanguage, or at least in another language  and an inability to translate explains why so many album and concert reviews are unreadable. Thus Stacey DErasmos most impressive accomplishment in her fourth novel, Wonderland, is to write about music well.

title: By the Booker
description: Edward St. Aubyn is that thing beloved by heritage series from the BBC, a man of ancient and aristocratic pedigree. He writes of an upper-class world so central to the English novel of the 19th and early 20th centuries, it has shaped the modern imagination: You might think we all sprang from big houses with handmade wallpaper and quietly smoldering servants. St. Aubyn cuts through the fantasy of privilege, however, with lacerating precision; once you have read his Melrose cycle of novels, there is no going back. These books  Never Mind, Bad News, Some Hope, Mothers Milk and At Last  set a marker in the English tradition by changing our view of what preceded them. The narrator, Patrick Melrose, is raped at the age of 5 by his sadistic, patrician father and later partially disinherited by his cold and foolish mother. After Melrose, the aristocratic novel, from Richardsons swooning Pamela to the affectless cruelties of Waugh, can never look the same again.

title: Please Turn to the Chapter on Obscurity . . .
description: The woman at the counter in Barnes & Noble had silver hair in a bun and a smile like breakfast. I was with a friend, for whom I was buying a copy of my latest book. I do this often  buy my own books for friends, then wonder why Im broke. May I take a moment to sign it? I asked the smiling woman. Did you write it? she asked. No, I said. I just like signing books. Unmoved, she asked, Is this your first book? I shook my head no, and continued inscribing. It must be fun to write books, she said. Superfun, I said.

title: A Celebration of the Lindy Hops Founder
description: Jana Grulichov came from Barcelona, Spain. Alevtina Kapusta came from Kiev, the Ukrainian capital. Veno Hirosuke, who in this context prefers to be known as Amore, came from Tokyo.

title: Irrational Rash
description: Every doctor told her it was eczema, but why wasnt it responding to treatment?

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Done in the Sun?

title: Billionaire Boys Club
description: In 2010, two of the Koch brothers, Charles of Wichita, Kan., and David of New York, rather suddenly became the top-of-mind conservatives for American liberals. That was partly because at that moment the Democratic Party controlled the White House and both houses of Congress, so there wasnt a dominant conservative politician to focus on; partly because of a wave of news media attention, notably an influential story on the Kochs political activities by Jane Mayer in The New Yorker; and partly because of the rise of the Tea Party movement, of which the Koch political apparatus was a primary backer. The conservative victories in the Congressional elections that fall looked like conclusive proof of the Kochs power. The very first television ads the Obama re-election campaign ran in 2012 were attacks on the Kochs, not on the Republican Party.

title: Wielding the Knife
description: At its best, food is a sensory pleasure that also fosters less tangible joys. At its worst, to paraphrase one of the many vivid characters in Simon Wroes first novel, Chop Chop, watching someone eat is like watching a body convert food to waste right in front of your eyes. The character phrases it less delicately, but many of the books funniest moments  and they are plentiful  are also its most unprintable.

title: Hive Mentality
description: Laline Paulls ambitious and bold first novel, The Bees, follows Flora 717, a sanitation worker doomed by her birth to the lowest caste of her community. She is large and ugly and  oh, yes  a bee. What could feel gimmicky or cute never does; Flora 717 is a brave and spirited soul, and it is a pleasure to follow her through the hive and the air. The brief prologue and epilogue are the only sections of the book with humans, aside from a single scene halfway through in which a man harvesting honey comes off something like Godzilla. Truly, who needs people when bees provide this much pathos?

title: Britain Proposes Easier Access to Tap Shale Rock Energy
description: LONDON  While most western European governments are opposed to developing oil and gas from shale rock through hydraulic fracturing, the British government continues to plug away at the obstacles inhibiting the countrys fledgling shale industry.

title: Man With Many Qualities
description: On Page 92 of the slate-gray third volume of the six-part Norwegian novel My Struggle, by Karl Ove Knausgaard  an autobiographical work that offers detailed accounts of events like the teenage Karl Ove trying to sneak alcohol to a New Years party (Book 1), the paternal Karl Ove attending a childrens birthday party (Book 2) and the child Karl Ove eating, on two different occasions, cornflakes (Book 3)  we learn that the headmaster of Karl Oves grade school was a diver who discovered a slave ship sunk off Norways coast in 1768.

title: The Things She Carries
description: When a soldier on the battlefield shoots an innocent civilian, what goes through his or, in this case, her mind? What did she see between the cross hairs, or hear or sense that made her feel she had to pull the trigger, and what becomes of her afterward?

title: Writers Retreat
description: A doctoral dissertation not getting written is never just a doctoral dissertation not getting written. Its always a stand-in for something more consequential (take it from a former grad student who knows). But when we encounter Cressida (Cress) Hartley, the protagonist of Michelle Hunevens fourth novel, Off Course, she doesnt realize this yet. In fact, she has just persuaded her parents to allow her to live in their vacation cabin in Californias Sierra Nevada for three months free and clear, so that she can bang . . . out her dissertation in economics. The 28-year-old, high-achieving Cress comes from cautious, stingy stock, a foundation that gives her a natural aptitude for her field: Her father is a traumatized victim of the Great Depression, and his fears and obsessions had imprinted her with thought patterns that, superficially at least, were indistinguishable from the mind-set of a trained economist: What is given up to get this? What is the true cost? Whose self-interest is going to prevail?

title: Problem Child
description: Its not that the protagonist of Susanna Kaysens novel Cambridge, a 1950s elementary-school student also named Susanna, is trying to be difficult. Its just that getting in the way of herself and others comes so naturally. Bright, sensitive and deeply neurotic, Susanna sees malevolence in certain toilets and thinks, as she shucks corn in advance of a dinner with adored family friends, Something about corn was sad. Visiting famous monuments sends her into an existential tailspin, and by the time shes 9 shes already mourning her lost youth. At school, shes bored and disdainful. When her sixth-grade teacher gives examples of solids, liquids and gases, Susanna raises her hand to ask, What about mayonnaise?

title: And ... Theyre Off (Fingers Crossed)
description: It is easy to spot California Chrome on the racetrack as the sun glistens off his chestnut body and white blaze face. It is even easier to spot him in the barn, when his leg wrappings are removed and his four white feet, or socks in horse parlance, are exposed.

title: Putin Indicates Hell Respect Result of Ukrainian Election
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Addressing an economic forum haunted by the prospect of more sanctions against Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday gave his clearest indication yet that he would work with the winner of this weekends presidential election in Ukraine.

title: HSBC, Like Rivals, Hears Earful on Banker Pay at Annual Meeting
description: Updated, 12:03 p.m. | LONDON  Banker pay has been a hotly debated topic among shareholders at annual meetings in Europe this year, particularly in Britain.

title: The Transformative Power of Transparency
description: Doctors dont traditionally apologize for medical errors; in fact, they usually dont even disclose them. That is why I have long been interested in how the University of Michigan Health Systems has bucked tradition with its Michigan Model, a collaborative and transparent approach to patient safety and medical mistakes.

title: An Inconvenient Past
description: During the night of June 3-4, 1989, when the Chinese Army was slaughtering demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, Wang Nan, a young student, was shot in the head. As he lay dying at the side of the road, soldiers threatened to kill anyone, even some young doctors, who tried to help him. In the morning, finally dead, he was buried in a shallow grave nearby. A few days later, the smell of Wang Nans body was so great that it was dug up and moved to a hospital.

title: Foreign Affair
description: Theres a scene in My Accidental Jihad in which Krista Bremer visits her husbands relatives in Libya and sees a wheezing, skeletal old woman lying on a hospital bed in their living room.

title: Inside the List
description: Dog Days: Jeffery Deavers new Lincoln Rhyme thriller, The Skin Collector, makes its debut on the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Part of the perverse allure of this series  which now numbers some dozen books  has always come from the demented nature of its villains, and The Skin Collector is no exception: It features a serial-killing tattoo artist who makes his own ink out of a slow-acting and painful poison. But a person can spend only so many hours a day inventing gruesome murder schemes, and one of the ways Deaver likes to unwind is by breeding show dogs with a business partner near his North Carolina home. Im not as creepy as the things I write about, he told The Associated Press in 2007. That doesnt mean you cant question his priorities  he once passed up dinner with Angelina Jolie to tend to a dogs matted coat. But Deaver knows what hes doing: His briards have won Best of Breed more than once at the Westminster Kennel Club show in New York. Your hearts pounding, he told a reporter in 2005, comparing the experience to that of a father watching a Little League game. Youll still love the dog just as much if he doesnt win. But I cant help it. I hope he wins. Given the elaborate plot twists and psychological head games in his novels, is Deaver ever tempted to mess with his dogs minds, just a little? I couldnt possibly do that, he told The Sun Herald newspaper in Australia in 2006. The dogs are much cleverer than me.

title: Ghosts of Hanoi
description: In Boat Story, the first offering from The Frangipani Hotel, Violet Kupersmiths subversively clever debut collection, a teenage girl in Houston, from a family of Vietnam War refugees, asks her grandmother to recount her sea journey to the United States for a school assignment. Communists! Thai pirates! Starvation! the girl says. Thats an A-plus story.

title: As Summer Driving Beckons, Gas Prices Are All Over the Map
description: HOUSTON  With the Memorial Day weekend representing the beginning of the summer driving season, it might be a good time to plan a trip to the Gulf Coast or the Rocky Mountains. Gasoline prices in the nations midsection should be 10 to 50 cents cheaper per gallon than a year ago.

title: Guantnamo Inmates Case Reignites Fight Over Detentions
description: WASHINGTON  The seemingly unending struggle over Guantnamo Bay  the prison President Obama vowed to close shortly after he was sworn in  is again reverberating over an anguishing case of force-feeding a Syrian detainee.

title: Celebrating Frankie Manning and the Lindy Hop
description: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze the Lindy hop.

title: Celebrating Frankie Manning and the Lindy Hop
description: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze the Lindy hop.

title: Today in Small Business: The Rest of America
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Baseballs Role in J.F.K.s Life
description: Here a frail 28-year-old John F. Kennedy, still not fully recovered from injuries sustained in 1943 when his PT-109 was struck by a Japanese destroyer in World War II, poses at Fenway Park in Boston in April 1946 with Ted Williams and Eddie Pellagrini of the Red Sox and Hank Greenberg of the Detroit Tigers. The neophyte J.F.K. is about to face nine opponents in a Democratic congressional primary  and he is seeking the reflected glory of being seen in the proximity of baseball stars.

title: Strangers Come to the Village
description: Great film stylists still roam the earth. For evidence, look no further than the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, whose lovely, oblique movie The Wind Will Carry Us is being shown at IFC Center, beginning Friday, in honor of its 15th anniversary.

title: A Desperate Mothers Search Leads to a Fight Against Sex Trafficking
description: SAN MIGUEL DE TUCUMN, Argentina  HERE in the impoverished north of Argentina, sex traffickers search among the vulnerable for targets. Typically, they lure women with deceitful job offers and then traffic them to big cities, mining towns and agricultural regions, where they are forced into sex slavery.

title: Judge Rules That Harper Lee Can Renew Suit Against Museum
description: The wheels of justice apparently turn quickly in Alabama. When lawyers for Harper Lee filed to reinstate her lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum for what she says is the unauthorized marketing of merchandise based on her 1960 novel, To Kill a Mockingbird, a federal judge said that he needed more information. (The lawyers sought to reinstate the suit because, they said, the museum was backtracking on an out-of-court agreement reached in February.)

title: No MetroCard Needed
description: It was cheaper rent that initially drew Jesse Warner-Levine, 34, and Hallie Nickelson, 33, to Wallabout, a fairly isolated Brooklyn neighborhood on the fringe of Clinton Hill near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But it was bicycling that made them stay.

title: Hague Court Sentences Congolese Warlord to 12 Years for Role in Tribal Massacre
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court in The Hague sentenced a Congolese militia leader, Germain Katanga, on Friday to 12 years in prison for his role in an attack on a village in 2003 where, within hours, more than 200 civilians were shot or hacked to death, limb by limb.

title: After Hours | A Family-Style Fete to Honor Robert Longo
description: The New York artist Robert Longo may be most famous for his black-and-white Men in the Cities images of the early 80s  which became such icons of yuppiedom that they appeared in Patrick Batemans apartment in the film adaptation of American Psycho. Like other New York art-world royalty, including Cindy Sherman, Philip Glass, Bill T. Jones, Laurie Anderson and Vito Acconci, he has long been a champion of the 43-year-old arts space The Kitchen, where he worked as a video curator for four years beginning in 1977.

title: New Online Magazine Honors the Mighty Schwa
description: The schwa  the vowel sound at the end of the word America, represented in dictionary pronunciation guides with a backward and upside down e ()  is the most common vowel sound in the English language. And now it is also the namesake of a new online magazine about language and life.

title: Cannes Film Festival: A Movie That Challenges Putin
description: CANNES  The Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsevs latest film, Leviathan, tells the story of Kolia, a man fighting to keep his seaside house in a justice system all but beholden to a corrupt local mayor. The family drama can be read as the story of Job filtered through Chekhov, but also as a scathing indictment of Russia under President Vladimir Putin.

title: In Chicago, a Dramatic Expansion of the Riverwalk
description: In an effort to bring people together near the citys second shoreline, Chicago has begun updates to its original Riverwalk with certain sections expected to be completed by summer 2015.

title: Feeding the Financial District
description: If youve spent any time in Lower Manhattan and had a cappuccino at a patisserie, a 10-inch pie at a pizza place, or a pint of Guinness in a wood-paneled pub, chances are you were patronizing an establishment owned by Peter Poulakakos.

title: Traveling with Elderly Parents
description: Caring for an aging parent can be stressful. And one thing that could help  a long-needed vacation  sometimes only adds to the stress.

title: Never Mind Stocks. Just Buy the Company.
description: AFTER years of litigation against the side of his family that controlled his grandfathers coffee business, Steven D. Crowe woke up on New Years Day 2004 with a lot of money in the bank  $111 million, according to reports at the time. Having developed and managed real estate for decades, he said he knew little about the stock market, so he invested the money broadly for his mother and sister and his own family.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
description: This week, Nicholas Lemann discusses Sons of Wichita; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Louisa Lim talks about The Peoples Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Blueberries for All
description: Ive been saving up blueberry recipes. I know that blueberries wont show up in farmers markets in northern states until mid-June, but there are plenty now available in supermarkets from places like Georgia, which grows 10 percent of the nations crop. In California, where blueberry production is a recent thing, begun successfully only in the 1990s, the harvest started in February. So Ive been biding my time.

title: Women Alert to Travels Darker Side
description: Between sun-seared shrubs and the collapsed remains of Istanbuls Byzantine city walls, police found the body of an American tourist, Sarai Sierra, 33, in February 2013. Ms. Sierra, a New Yorker and a first-time traveler abroad, disappeared after near-constant contact with her family for two weeks. What happened to her is still a little unclear, but a Turkish man has reportedly confessed to killing her after supposedly trying to kiss her.

title: U.N. Panel Says Vatican Is Lax Over Abusive Priests
description: GENEVA  The Vatican on Friday faced criticism from a United Nations panel for the second time this year over failures to report priests accused of sexually abusing children to civil authorities or to ensure redress for victims.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
description: This week, Nicholas Lemann and Louisa Lim.

title: Amazon Unveils Childrens Show
description: Amazons deliberate rollout of original online series  comedy series in November, drama pilots in February  continued Friday with the posting of six episodes of its first childrens series, Tumble Leaf. The initial episode is free from Amazon Instant Video while the other five require a Prime membership.

title: At French Open, a Rare Early Meeting Is Possible for the Williams Sisters
description: PARIS  Rafael Nadal, an eight-time winner of the French Open, cringed and smiled nervously as the 25th chip he pulled at the draw ceremony for the womens singles tournament at Roland Garros set up 29th-seeded Venus Williams into a possible third-round meeting with her sister Serena, the top seed and defending champion.

title: A Health Nominee Who Can Disarm Republicans
description: Now that Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obamas nominee to head the embattled Department of Health and Human Services, has been endorsed by a bi-partisan majority of one Senate committee and treated cordially by another, the full Senate ought to vote promptly to confirm her nomination. She is extremely well-qualified to handle the departments most pressing administrative tasks and seems able to reach consensus with, or at least disarm and charm, Republican opponents who are often adamantly opposed to cooperating in any way with the Obama administration.

title: Pea Salad With Creamy Cheese
description: Melissa Clark makes a salad that is the perfect balance between freshness and richness, featuring crunchy sugar snap peas, pea shoots and ripe, runny cheese.

title: Peas Love Cheese, and Vice Versa
description: File this under the easiest party recipes youll ever make: Take a runny, stinky, washed-rind cheese, scrape the top off with a spoon, then serve the oozing disk as a dip with raw sugar snap peas on the side. It requires about five minutes of effort if you trim the peas (fancy), two minutes if you dont (rustic). Its a dish more about shopping than cooking, but the result is voluptuous, unexpected and impossible to stop eating.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: A Rare Capitol Hill Sighting: The Legislative Process
description: On Thursday the Senate did something remarkable: it passed a conference report to a bill.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Nicholas Lemann reviews Daniel Schulmans Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became Americas Most Powerful and Private Dynasty. Mr. Lemann writes:

title: Image of the Day: May 23
Together Again to Go the Distance
description: On a summer day in 1981, Ray Mancini attended a pool party at the home of Tina Rozzi in Campbell, Ohio.

title: Apax Partners Selling Majority Stake in Travelex Group
description: LONDON  Funds advised by the private equity firm Apax Partners are selling their majority stake in the Travelex Group, a foreign exchange specialist, to a group led by the billionaire Bavaguthu Raghuram Shetty, Apax said Friday.

title: European Regulators to Start Inquiry Into eBay Data Breach
description: LONDON  The fallout from the data breach at eBay has reached Europe.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: HPs Whitman on PC Decline and Job Cuts
description: Hewlett-Packard, until recently the worlds largest technology company in terms of revenue, released tepid quarterly results on Thursday. They showed a once industry-leading computer maker continuing to limp along in a world increasingly defined by smartphones and cloud computing.

title: In Era of Humble Pope, Earth Shifts Under Cardinal Dolan
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan lives in a 19th-century Madison Avenue mansion that connects to St. Patricks Cathedral. A cook and two housekeepers serve him and three other priests. A driver chauffeurs him around, though in a Chrysler minivan.

title: Praise Poems: Ellen Bass Talks About Like a Beggar
description: Ellen Basss new poetry collection, Like a Beggar (Copper Canyon), pulses with sex, humor and compassion. Ms. Bass takes her cues as a poet, and as a person, from Rilke, whom she quotes to open Beggar: But those dark, deadly, devastating ways,/how do you bear them, suffer them?/ I praise. Her poetry, and this book in particular, fairly bursts with such praise. Below are edited excerpts from an email conversation with Ms. Bass about poetry and more.

title: U.N. Chief Urges Aid Delivery Without Syrias Consent
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Syrian government is failing in its responsibility to look after its own people, the secretary general of the United Nations has said in a confidential report to the Security Council, in which he urged it to authorize the delivery of food and medicine to Syria without the governments consent.

title: A Farewell, With Beer and Pizza
description: Some peoples version of culinary heaven is tournedos of beef with a supple cabernet at a white-clothed table under candlelight. Others might prefer the offerings at the new Fornino restaurant in Brooklyn Bridge Park: thin-crust pizza and local beer at a picnic table with a view of New York Harbor. On a roof deck, just across the water from Manhattan, this latest outpost of the Brooklyn pizza franchise  its sister shops are in Williamsburg and Greenpoint  has already proved popular with visitors to the park, which opened its manufactured beach and pop-up pool on May 22. On a recent evening, the place was crowded with frolicking families, post-work drinkers and a large party from the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation celebrating the imminent departure of one its workers.

title: Alibabas American Aspirations
description: Herb and Martha Oberman have made a good living on eBay for 17 years, selling paper collectibles like a $5,000 limited-edition menu from the Hotel Bel-Air, the Los Angeles hotel once frequented by Marilyn Monroe.

title: A Quick Take on Ukraine From the International Desk
description: Whats the likely takeaway from the presidential election in Ukraine on Sunday? We asked Kyle Crichton, the editor in charge of coverage there, to weigh in.

title: With a New Exhibition, the Mexican Artist Gabriel Kuri Makes His Home in L.A.
description: New Yorkers might recognize the work of Gabriel Kuri from the wheat-pasted posters that were plastered around town in 2011, when his signature repurposed tickets and receipts were the graphic identity of that years Armory Show. The Mexican artist is known for incorporating a range of detritus and found objects into his practice, combining man-made and organic materials to hint at a borderless global economy of objects. Eight months ago, he became one of a number of prominent artists to relocate to Los Angeles, moving from Brussels, where hed spent the last decade. His first show at Regen Projects, his new West Coast gallery, opens Saturday.

title: Report of the Secretary General on Security Council Resolution 2139
description: The strongest push to date for a resolution that would enable United Nations agencies to deliver aid inside Syria.

title: Fire Engulfs Historic Building at Glasgow School of Art
description: LONDON  Firefighters in Scotland were battling to control a blaze on Friday that engulfed large parts of the Glasgow School of Art, one of Scotlands most treasured buildings. There were no reports of any casualties, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said.

title: Hagels Sex-Assault Remarks Resonate for New Navy Officers
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, speaking to the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy on Friday, told the new officers he was counting on them to lead in helping eliminate sexual harassment and sexual assault of your sisters and brothers in uniform.

title: Go Shop? Go Fish.
description: Shopping till you drop doesnt really work for merger targets. The so-called go shop strategy of seeking higher bids after signing up a buyer is designed to ensure top dollar is paid. More often, it leads to final prices that are lower than they otherwise would be, new research suggests. Tweaks to deals like Media Generals buyout of Lin Media may mean sellers are wising up, though, portending better value for shareholders.

title: Safety Agency Investigates Ram Pickups; Suzuki Recalls 184,000 Cars
description: After receiving a report that a child was struck and killed, federal regulators have opened an investigation into whether 2004-6 Dodge Ram heavy-duty pickups equipped with manual transmissions can be started without the driver depressing the clutch pedal, causing the vehicle to move. The investigation covers about 110,000 Ram 2500 and 3500 pickups, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Country Experiments With Rap
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff talk about the overlap of hip-hop and country.

title: Dick Zigun: Surveying His Coney Island Realm
description: As the unofficial mayor of Coney Island, Dick Zigun, 61, craves the craziness of summer. He is the founder of Coney Island USA, which runs the Coney Island Museum, the Coney Island Circus Sideshow and the Mermaid Parade. He spends Sundays strolling the boardwalk, chatting with locals and tourists, eating hot dogs and checking out the rides. He also spends time with his wife, Patience Mukoro White, 50, who performs in the sideshow as an escape artist, as a glass walker and as Madame Twisto, a contortionist. They live with their cat, Buddy, in a Coney Island loft that is being renovated, a project that was delayed by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright and Norah Jones to Perform at the Clearwater Festival
description: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright, Richard Thompson and Norah Jones are among the musicians who will perform at the Clearwater Festival  or, more formally, the Great Hudson River Revival  at Croton Point Park, Croton-on-Hudson, on June 21 and 22.

title: Cardinal Dolan Reflects on the Pope Francis Effect in his Life and Work
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, New Yorks archbishop, traveled to Rome for the canonization of two popes, stayed on to speak at a communications conference there, jetted to Jordan to see the work of a Catholic charity he chairs, and once home, spoke at two graduations in the diocese  all in the past month. In other words, it was a typically busy month for him. So when The New York Times asked him, through a spokesperson, how the election of Pope Francis had changed the diocese and his own personal life, he asked that we submit a series of written questions.

title: Sympathy for the Working Mother
description: One morning recently I received a call from a friend who told me she had decided to leave her job after many years, one in which she commanded a lot of authority and was very well paid, to begin a new and as yet undetermined phase; she was taking advantage of a lucrative buyout her company had offered. I pointed out the fortuitous timing  it was May, which meant she would have the summer off, which meant she could leave the city, which meant she would be envied by a great number of people (arguably this year more than others because The Farmers Almanac is predicting a summer so hot, wet and muggy that New York will essentially feel like Biloxi, Miss.).

title: Kerry Agrees to Testify on Benghazi, as Republicans Squabble Over Rival Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry agreed on Friday to testify before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform over the 2012 attacks on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, possibly exacerbating tensions between Republicans over competing inquiries.

title: A Better Way to Measure Fund-Raising? It Depends
description: My recent article offering a more accurate way of judging campaign fund-raising drew several responses, one from Bob Biersack, a former Federal Election Commission employee now with the Center for Responsive Politics. When journalists have needed to understand campaign finance during the past 30 years, Mr. Biersack has often supplied the answer, so his opinion is worth noting.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
description: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical.

title: William Forsythe to No Longer Run Forsythe Dance Company
description: Starting in September 2015, William Forsythe, widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, will no longer run the company that is named for him. He will continue to be associated as an artistic adviser, a press statement announced on Friday. Jacopo Godani, a former dancer with Mr. Forsythes Ballet Frankfurt who is now a freelance choreographer, was named as the new artistic director.

title: Speaking of Identity: Choosing Between Latino and Hispanic
description: Writers who cover demographics and politics are often confronted with the tricky matter of describing racial and ethnic groups. One particularly challenging question is whether to refer to people from Latin America as Hispanics or Latinos.

title: Cuban Talks His Way Onto a Limb Occupied by Sterling
description: For nearly a month, Adam Silver, the commissioner of the N.B.A., has managed to isolate Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, on an island. With one salvo of explosive comments, Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, has put his fellow team owners on that island as well.

title: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
description: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical. It seemed to sell out immediately and is now a collectors item. Shown here, it is carried in daytime by all but two of the women. And for those who cant get enough of the perfume bag, theres a smartphone cover. We havent seen a novelty like this since Schiaparellis Surrealist accessories in the late 1930s. There are even Chanel sunglasses, with mademoiselle perched atop the frame.

title: Weekend Reading: Grading Credit Suisses Plea and Memorial Day Travel Spots
description: Credit Suisse pleaded guilty this week to helping American account holders hide their wealth. The Swiss bank agreed to pay about $2.6 billion in penalties, but it kept its license to operate. The banks clients and shareholders welcomed the deal, but the Justice Department has been criticized for not pursuing a harsher penalty.

title: Plan B: Open a Country Hotel in Upstate New York
description: When Rebecca Bales, a real estate agent in Brooklyn, and her husband, Kiley Thompson, assessed their financial and vocational prospects in 2012, they realized how hard it would be to get ahead. We were either going to double down in our careers to do more than just pay the rent on our Park Slope apartment, or do something else, said Mr. Thompson, an art director, sommelier and record label owner.

title: Phone Swindlers Tap Into Fear and a Sense of Duty
description: BEFORE Betty Bell, 88, even got out of bed, the telephone jolted her awake at 7 a.m. The male voice on the line said that a police officer was coming to arrest her for shirking her civic duty.

title: Game 3 Fallout: Stepans Jaw Is Broken, and Suspensions Are Issued
description: There will be no need to manufacture animosity between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens heading into Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday. After Brandon Prusts hit on Derek Stepan in Game 3 on Thursday night, the hostility is there for all to see and hear, and the question is how much it will shape a series that the Rangers now lead by two games to one.

title: The AmfAR Gala: A Night for Movie Stars, Supermodels and Billionaires
description: AmfAR hosts its 21st annual Cinema Against AIDS gala at Cannes.

title: Times Minute | Pope Visits the Holy Land
description: Pope Francis embarks on a three-day trip to the Middle East. Jodi Rudoren, the Timess Bureau chief, on what to watch from the visit.

title: Times Minute | Pope Visits the Holy Land
description: In the Video

title: Podcast: Lessons of a Deadly Virus
description:
An image of H.I.V. stirs one writer to remember a pastors evolutionary thought, published 50 years before the Origin of Species.
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: A Creationists Influence on Darwin
description: In my last column, about the eerie machine-like nature of the AIDS virus, I mentioned William Paley, the 19th-century theologian best known today for his argument supporting creationism: Something as complex as a mechanical watch clearly would not exist without a creator. Thus we can infer that the intricacy of our bodies  and those of all creatures  is the work of God.

title: Driven | Mudfest S.U.V. of the Year
description: Finding the best crossovers or sport utilities means getting a little dirty.

title: Popcast: Country Embraces Hip-Hop
description: On this weeks Popcast: the slow and circuitous loosening of modern country music. The perpetual story of the country music industry, our critic Jon Caramanica explains, is always how well it polices its own borders, how it maintain its core identity and resists assimilation into the rest of popular culture. But his cover story in Arts and Leisure this weekend analyzes how things may be decisively shifting right now, especially around rapping in country songs. The power of hip-hop reached critical mass across the country a long time ago; there are, he writes, a generation of stars  mostly in their mid-late 30s, old enough to have grown up with hip-hop as a fact of life, even in the small towns they hail from, who think nothing of sprinkling a little bit of it into their music.

title: Silver Too Small to See, but Everywhere You Look
description: Several years ago, a mosquito bite on Elizabeth Loboas right leg became infected, turning into an oozing sore that refused to heal. Her doctor prescribed a stiff course of antibiotics. But Dr. Loboa decided to try another remedy.

title: Norman Rockwells Art, Once Sniffed At, Is Becoming Prized
description: Rockwells greatest sin as an artist is simple: His is an art of unending clich.

title: Video: Crossovers and S.U.V.s Hammered at Mudfest
description: SNOQUALMIE, WASH.  Pushing a car to its limit is a great way to find its strengths and weaknesses. The only thing better? Doing it with someone elses vehicle.

title: When Do Political Endorsements Matter?
description: Voters are generally quick to acknowledge to pollsters that candidates stances on issues influence their votes much more than candidates personal attributes. However, the impact of political endorsements, pollsters have found, is more ambiguous.

title: Drilling Down on School Lockdown Drills
description: This weeks Look features pictures taken by Alec Soth during a recent lockdown drill at a high school in Belle Plaine, Minn., about an hour southwest of Minneapolis. I was curious to find out more about these drills, so I put a few questions to Kenneth Trump, president of National School Safety and Security Services, which, among other things, evaluates school security and emergency crisis plans.

title: A Trick Play to Close Guantnamo Bay
description: The closing of the detention camp at Guantnamo Bay  promised by President Obama in 2008, prevented by Congress ever since  may still be far off, but on Thursday a bipartisan Senate committee laid out a pathway that could make it happen.

title: Putin to Honor Ukraine Election Results
description: President Vladimir V. Putin announced that Russia would recognize the outcome of Ukraines presidential vote this weekend, and said he hoped Ukraine would stop its military operations in the east.

title: Raised on Racing
description: In its 100 years, Maserati has been owned and disowned by some half-dozen entities, and now, under Fiat Chrysler, is undergoing a resurgence.

title: Its the Time You Spend on an Elementary School That Makes It Special (and Hard to Leave)
description: We pull into United Skate for the last school fund-raiser of the year. My friend pulls her minivan in beside mine. Were late! yell the four children between us and we hurry in, pay the $6 per child and head to the skate checkout line. Once all the children are out on the rink, after we have checked our work emails one last time, we turn to lacing up our own skates.

title: Big Ticket | A Park Avenue Duplex at $25 Million
description: A two-bedroom duplex on the 30th and 31st floors of 515 Park Avenue, held by the estate of Christopher H. Browne, the former managing director of the mutual fund company Tweedy, Browne, sold for $25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A Cover With an Artistic Challenge
description: Pamela Paul is the editor of the Book Review.

title: Rocker of the Rockaways
description: Just let me put on my Rockaway tuxedo, said Simon Chardiet, musician, surfer and defender of old-school Rock, Rock, Rockaway Beach, as he grabbed a wet suit draped over the fence of his bungalow.

title: When the Going Gets Tough
description: The third generation Toyota Highlander provides tranquil, comfortable family transportation and is a good antidote to rough roads.

title: Over-the-Top Stuff for One-Percenters
description: Gifts for couples who have everything and for gift-givers for whom price is no object.

title: Taking a Spin: A Democratic Victory With Limits
description: In this weeks spin of Leos Senate wheels, we get a forecast in which Democrats have an excellent election night. They hold the Senate by winning every competitive, Democratic-held Senate seat except Louisiana, while pulling off an upset in Montana.

title: Author Changes His Mind on 70s Manifesto
description: For more than 40 years, Eduardo Galeanos The Open Veins of Latin America has been the canonical anti-colonialist, anti-capitalist and anti-American text in that region. Hugo Chvez, Venezuelas populist president, even put a copy of the book, which he had called a monument in our Latin American history, in President Obamas hands the first time they met. But now Mr. Galeano, a 73-year-old Uruguayan writer, has disavowed the book, saying that he was not qualified to tackle the subject and that it was badly written. Predictably, his remarks have set off a vigorous regional debate, with the right doing some we told you so gloating, and the left clinging to a dogged defensiveness.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Independent Music Labels Are in a Battle With YouTube
description: YouTubes plans for a subscription music service have stalled over a dispute with independent record labels, which contend that the online video giant has offered unfair licensing terms and threatened to block their music from the site.

title: In Twist, Sterling May Allow His Wife to Sell the Clippers
description: The nightmare scenario for the N.B.A. in its efforts to end Donald Sterlings ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers has been simmering for weeks: a protracted legal battle against a man who is no stranger to the courtroom.

title: Dispute Over Banking Groups Analysis of Mortgage Denials to Blacks
description: The Mortgage Bankers Association, one of the nations most influential financial lobbying groups, made a startling claim this week about the access of black borrowers to credit.

title: A Seaside Escape, Off the Belt Parkway
description: At the first breath of warm weather, the hostess at Clementes Maryland Crab House offers diners two seating options: Indoor? Or indoor-outdoor?

title: Raise Your Hand for an Engagement Selfie
description: It was the stuff of Marie Valencis dreams: a 3.9-carat, princess-cut, platinum engagement ring with a diamond band  which her fianc picked out by himself. But after the initial elation wore off, a seemingly more practical matter popped into her head: What about the selfies she would invariably post on Facebook, Instagram and elsewhere?

title: The Gun Report: May 23, 2014
description: Some good news going into what will undoubtedly be a violent holiday weekend: A new report from Everytown for Gun Safety found that the number of mental health records submitted to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has tripled since 2011, preventing 65 percent more mentally ill people from purchasing firearms through licensed dealers. The reason? Increased federal funding and stronger record collection laws in 18 states.

title: A Violent Intruder Is Welcome to Stay
description: Most of Tamer of Horses occurs in an old barn, and the Passage Theater Companys production of William Mastrosimones play benefits from the setting designed by Matt Campbell, who neatly incorporates the peaked ceiling and rough stone walls of Trentons Mill Hill Playhouse into his beams-and-planks realization of these rustic premises.

title: The Closest of Strangers
description: EARLIER this month, I helped reunite the fraternal twins Ann Hunt and Liz Hamel, who had been apart for 78 years. Born in England in 1936, they were separated at birth when their unmarried mother decided she could not care for both. Ann, the prettier sister, was given away, while Liz, the less adoptable baby marked by scoliosis, remained at home. Ann Hunt was unaware that she was a twin until last year, when her daughter made the discovery while researching their ancestry.

title: Warhols Entourage Speaks His Truth
description: Scenes from the 20th-anniversary gala for the Andy Warhol Museum, which is hosting a show about Halston and Warhol.

title: Opposites Attract, Then Fall Apart
description: Jamie is glad he married Cathy. Really.

title: King Richard III to Be Reburied in Leicester, British Court Says
description: LONDON  A British court ruled on Friday that King Richard III should be reburied in a cathedral in Leicester, the city where his remains were found in a parking lot two years ago. The ruling was a defeat for the kings descendants who wanted his remains to be reburied in York, arguing that he had spent much of his life there. But archaeologists who discovered the kings remains decided to keep the body in Leicester, a decision backed by Britains Justice Ministry. The judges said, "There were no public law grounds for the court interfering with the decisions in question.

title: Warhols Entourage Speaks His Truth
description: PITTSBURGH  Andy would have loved this! Patrick McMullan, the party photographer, said last Saturday as he boogied with his camera around a dance floor set in a tent outside the Andy Warhol Museum. Bob and Jane, let me get you together, said the man who claims to have shot six million photos and to know 25,000 people by name, to Bob Colacello and Jane Holzer, a onetime Warhol superstar.

title: What Happened to Some Banksy Pieces?
description: Q. Nine years ago, Banksy put a few of his works on walls of several New York City museums. What ever happened to the pieces?

title: Donation-Induced Amnesia
description: In the business section of The Times today, Floyd Norris had a great column on the amnesia affecting many Republican lawmakers regarding the causes of the Great Recession. Exhibit A was Jeb Hensarling of Texas, chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, who said it was inconceivable that a money manager could cause widespread risk to the financial system (forgetting about Long-Term Capital Management) and that insurance companies posed no danger because they are already regulated by the states (forgetting about AIG).

title: John Dukas Memorable Pieces
description: John Duka, the former style reporter at The New York Times who died in 1989 at age 39, wrote a series of witty and incisive fashion pieces and celebrity profiles during his tenure at the newspaper from 1979 to 1985. Here are some of his most memorable articles:

title: Did Thomas Piketty Get His Math Wrong?
description: One of the most common approaches for people writing about Thomas Pikettys blockbuster book Capital in the 21st Century, about global inequality, has been to critique his theories and predictions while effusively praising his data collection. Mr. Piketty, after all, did yeomans work compiling data from tax and other records to try to determine a history of wealth inequality around the world.

title: All Fancy Hat and No Horse
description: WHAT WAS IT? 2002 Lincoln Blackwood

title: Recalled-Car Bargains May Prove Elusive
description: Used-car bargain hunters hoping to score a deal on one of the 2.6 million General Motors cars recalled for faulty ignition switches may find prices have proved more resilient than they expected.

title: Maseratis Image Builds on a Racing Reputation
description: Maserati, one of Italys classic automotive nameplates, celebrates its centennial this year in better shape than in any of its first 99.

title: Reporting for Pothole Duty
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.  While there are many delights in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the potholes, broken pavement and launching ramps known as frost heaves are not among them. But the reworked 2014 Toyota Highlander offers succor, deflecting impacts and protecting its occupants from the North Countrys rough-rider roads.

title: Silencing Underhood Complaints
description: Convertibles with balky tops and Scions suffering insect invasions are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Its Cheap, but Is It Overpriced?
description: TESTED 2014 Mitsubishi Mirage

title: Doubt Comes Knocking
description: Theyre a classic odd couple. Mary is all angles, with crisply tailored outfits, quick, sharp elbows and an attitude problem: There is some chemical in my brain that says, Let em have it! Her younger sister, Margaret, is soft and fluttery, with unruly strands escaping from her hairdo and a rumpled, distracted air. They live together in the well-worn house where they were raised, each having learned long ago to tolerate the others foibles.

title: John Duka, a Fashion Wit, Returns in Larry Kramers Film
description: As she worked on her video about Paul Cavaco, who will be honored by the Council of Fashion Designers of America in June, Nian Fish, a producer of that event, came across an image of her old friend John Duka, a colleague of both herself and Mr. Cavaco nearly three decades ago.

title: Movie Review: Blended
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Blended.

title: Movie Review: X-Men
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews X-Men: Days of Future Past.

title: Movie Review: Cold in July
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Cold in July.

title: Love and All That Comes With It
description: Tyne Daly needed a bowl of rice  but not to eat. No, the six-time Emmy-winning actress (four for Cagney & Lacey and one each for Christy and Judging Amy), Tony winner for the Broadway revival of Gypsy and current Tony nominee for Terrence McNallys new play, Mothers and Sons, wanted to submerge her ancient flip phone in a bowl of uncooked rice to leach the moisture from it. My toilet exploded! she cried. Water everywhere. All over my outfit and the phone in my pocket.

title: Dropping Donovan, Klinsmann Shows His Clout
description: In most cases, coaches of national soccer teams are like presidents: one four-year term at a time, with little certainty about how re-election will go until the numbers come in. Unlike political incumbents, though, coaching incumbents do not often receive a boost; coaching a team for two World Cup cycles is not the norm.

title: Amazons Tactics Confirm Its Critics Worst Suspicions
description: Amazon is confirming its critics worst fears and it is an ugly spectacle to behold.

title: Dorchester Hotels Falling Out of Fashion
description: With the next round of European fashion shows quickly approaching, some of fashions biggest names are facing a dilemma: Should they boycott their favorite hotels in Milan and Paris because they are owned by the sultan of Brunei?

title: Evening Hours | Indoors and Out
description: Off to a garden, or perhaps a dance floor.

title: Exposing the Foundations of Documented Motion
description: In the prospectus accompanying Animal Locomotion (1887), an 11-volume collection of 20,000 photographs documenting human and animal movement, Eadweard Muybridge described how he became interested in the subject in the 1870s and was convinced that he could demonstrate many novel facts, not only interesting to the casual observer, but of indisputable value to the Artist and to the Scientist.

title: Judge Allows Conyers to Be on the Ballot in Michigan
description: Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan narrowly escaped a political fiasco on Friday when a federal judge granted him a place on the Democratic primary ballot in August, allowing him to survive a campaign misstep that left him hundreds of valid signatures short on his petitions for re-election.

title: Wheelies: The G.M. Trucks Hiccup Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: If Liver Doesnt Strike Fear in Your Heart
description: When it comes to enjoying offal, I have found that one either does or does not at all. There is no middle ground. Ill confess to have always been a lover of liver  and kidneys, gizzards, hearts, sweetbreads and tongues for that matter. I grew up on chopped chicken liver, and always considered pan-fried chicken livers a treat. I still do.

title: Pictures of the Day  China and Elsewhere
description: China and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Warhol at the Dali
description: Devotees of Salvador Dalis fascination with the world of dreams can now examine his work and contrast it with that of Andy Warhol, whose paintings, drawings, photographs and films of the everyday are on display at the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: A Rulings Chilling Effect on Corporate Litigation
description: In the clubby world of corporate litigators, the hysteria over a change to corporate bylaws that would shift responsibility over legal fees is perhaps one of the more recent strange events.

title: Weekend Calendar: Muscle Madness and Southern British Charm
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Staten Island Gets a Craft Brewery of Its Own
description: The three Staten Island guys  tall and broad, with their hair cut short  stood behind their keg with trepidation and pride, as though they had sent their child into the playground for the first time. They were in a cacophonous event hall in Queens, presenting their beer at the Five Boro Craft Beer Fest, a showcase for New Yorks craft breweries. Guests approached with petite tasting glasses, holding the pours to their noses for an aromatic inhale.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photos from China, Ukraine, Afghanistan and India.

title: Week in Pictures for May 23
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the planting of grass at a beach in Queens, and the sentencing of an Occupy Wall Street protester.

title: Dark Lullabies and Twisted Witches
description: Putting together a concert of works linked by an overall theme may seem a surefire way to lend coherence to a program. The risk is that in searching for pieces that support a chosen theme, especially unfamiliar scores, you wind up with novelties of lesser musical interest.

title: Spring Break at Cannes
description: CANNES, FRANCE  Dollars. Euros. Dollars. Euros. By 11 p.m., the bids were coming in so fast that Sharon Stone, who was handling part of the auction, couldnt even keep the currencies straight.

title: McDonalds Indigestible Excuse for Low Pay
description: When Henry Ford realized it was good business to pay employees enough to buy the products they built, it was a breakthrough, not only because the idea challenged the reflex to pay as little as possible, but because the product was a car. He was talking real bucks.

title: Liu Announces Bid to Unseat Queens State Senator
description: John C. Liu, the former New York City comptroller whose mayoral aspirations fizzled amid a criminal investigation into his fund-raising, declared his bid on Friday to unseat a Democratic state senator in Queens.

title: Spring in the Air, Wild Leeks on the Table
description: When I saw ramps on the menu of At the Corner Restaurant and Pub, in Litchfield, I knew that spring had arrived in full. Ramps, a wild form of leek, are available fleetingly, from mid-April through late May, and a restaurant that serves them clearly embraces the change of seasons.

title: Support for Breakup Songs, Even a Vibraphone
description: Forlorn love is transmuted into myth and metaphor in songs by Mirah, who performed her entire new album, Changing Light, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Wednesday night. Her voice stayed airborne, a sweet soprano with a steadfast core, as the songs moved through laments, recriminations and resolve.

title: Apps for the Lovelorn
description: Summer is almost here, and if youre a typical Other Woman, youve already wasted precious hours (O.K., months) brooding about it: those romantic summer nights when the man you love will be off on vacation  with his wife (not that they have sex anymore, but just the idea of the two of them at some idyllic beach makes you crazy).

title: California Chrome Preps for Triple Crown
description: California Chromes assistant trainer, Alan Sherman, and his exercise rider, Willie Delgado, talked about how training has been going for the racehorse.

title: Vocal Birds
description: The squawks and honks of pink flamingos greet Jeremy Sanders, a senior wild animal keeper, at the Bronx Zoo each day.

title: San Antonio Mayor Is Nominated as Housing Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  Mayor Julin Castro of San Antonio, a rising star in the Democratic Party, is expected to soon have a platform that might kick-start a national political career.

title: Friday Night Music: Beirut
description: Continuing on the grumpy old man theme, may I say how much I hate what passes for handwriting? Not only did I have trouble making out what they wrote, I had trouble figuring out who wrote it  when the blue book appears to come from a student named grzzmph, entering his grade in the spreadsheet is hard.

title: Under Cover: Body Building
description: To illustrate Michael Behars cover story about how electricity delivered through the nervous system might be used to fight disease, the magazines art department turned to Kyle Bean, a conceptual artist in London. Gail Bichler, the art director, and Jason Sfetko, a designer, chose Bean because, in Bichlers words, he makes graphically striking dimensional pieces. Bean, for his part, says that after reading Behars story, he was inspired by scientific diagrams in old textbooks to make the electrified body seen on this weeks cover.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: A luxury chicken coop, a China-Russia gas deal and more car recalls at General Motors.

title: G.O.P. Sues for a Loophole to Raise Unlimited Money From Individuals
description: The Republican National Committee filed a complaint on Friday to force federal election officials to allow the party to raise unlimited money from individuals, opening a new front in its legal battle on campaign regulation.

title: Down to the Sea Again
description: Americans may rhapsodize about their cars or amber waves of grain, but when it comes to putting wind in their sails, nothing does it quite like wind and sails.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Adding Technology to Animal Instincts
description: CLEVELAND  To the pantheon of operas unforgettable couples, from Mozarts Figaro and Susanna to Puccinis Tosca and Cavaradossi, Id like to add a pair that lies a considerable distance from them: two foxes.

title: The Attack of the Killer Theme Weeks
description: Assuming you make it through the weekend, congratulations on surviving Monster Week. Unfortunately, theres no time to relax. Meat Week and Psych Week start on Monday.

title: Federal Regulators Seek to Stop Sale of Students Data
description: Last month, ConnectEDU, a popular college and career planning portal in Boston that had collected personal details on millions of high school and college students, filed for bankruptcy.

title: Exhibit A in G.E.s Case for Alstom Deal
description: VILLAROCHE, France  In a cavernous factory planted in farmland here south of Paris, workers assemble the best-selling aircraft engine in history, in a feat of trans-Atlantic industrial cooperation that has few parallels.

title: Where Winners Play, and Losers Pay
description: The real way to win many of todays popular video games is to figure out how to avoid paying for them. This isnt a matter of stealing or borrowing them. Its about enjoying them to a limit, of being among the millions who indulge in so-called free-to-play games like Angry Birds or League of Legends only enough to have some fun and not enough to have to pay.

title: The Frenchman Who Loved Westerns
description: As the Cannes festival has recently reminded us, the French adore movies. And that enthusiasm was on delightful display onstage and in the audience Thursday at Gould Hall, at The Exercise Was Beneficial, Sir (La Loi du Marcheur is the French title), Nicolas Bouchauds solo portrayal of the editor and critic Serge Daney. (It was the end of a two-night run.)

title: Generations Share a Program Whose Theme Is Follow the Leader
description: New York City Ballets program on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was titled Classic NYCB I, but it might have been called Masters and Apprentices.

title: The Game to Select USA-1 for the Bermuda Bowl
description: We are looking at the last six boards of the final match in the trial to select the USA-1 team for next years Bermuda Bowl world championship.

title: Court Approves F.C.C. Plan to Subsidize Rural Broadband Service
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday upheld the Federal Communications Commissions effort to convert its $4.5 billion program that pays for telephone service in rural parts of the country into one that subsidizes high-speed Internet service in high-cost areas.

title: Powerful Law Firms Patton Boggs and Squire Sanders Will Join Forces
