description: Patton Boggs, a Washington lobbying and legal powerhouse for decades, is no longer a stand-alone firm.

title: A New Critique of Piketty Has Its Own Shortcomings
description: My colleague, Neil Irwin, has written an outstanding account of the charges leveled by Chris Giles of the Financial Times that the conclusions of Capital in the 21st Century, Thomas Pikettys blockbuster book, do not appear to be backed by the books own sources.

title: Bike Shares Rough Ride
description: ITS been a year since Citi Bike started in New York City, and the program has been a tremendous success, with more than 100,000 annual members and over seven million trips to date. Or, if you prefer, in Citi Bikes first year, the program has struggled financially and is in urgent need of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Obama Nominates New HUD Secretary
description: The president tapped Julin Castro, the mayor of San Antonio, to be the secretary of housing and urban development, replacing Shaun Donovan, who was promoted to run the White House budget office.

title: Victims and Officials on Xinjiang Attack
description: As residents of Urumqi, China, mourned the deaths in the market blast on Thursday, Chinese and Uighur officials and survivors discussed the terror attack.

title: Giving Small Donors a Bigger Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: At Pig Roasts, the Guest of Honor Is Edible
description: When Erik Wood started planning a birthday party for his wife, Emily, he wasnt trying to pick a theme that would help his 50 guests break the ice; they were friends who already knew one another, he said. But the Woods got a conversation starter anyway.

title: House Inquiry on Grimm Is Deferred as U.S. Pursues Case
description: A subcommittee formed to investigate Representative Michael G. Grimm, Republican of Staten Island, has voted unanimously to defer its work while federal prosecutors in Brooklyn pursue a fraud indictment against Mr. Grimm, the House Ethics Committee said on Friday.

title: Who Visits the 9/11 Museum, and Who Doesnt
description: To the Editor:

title: Studying if Aspirin Helps Prevent Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Go Away Again, He Was Told. But He Did.
description: Kenneth Cory Smith was born 35 years ago, but it was a matter of days before the boys father inadvertently set him up for a lifetime of jokes, up to and including this sentence, by changing his name to one that is, well, unique.

title: A Strong Case for Leaving Room for Dessert
description: Latitude 121 Coastal Grill is a new restaurant that walks a line between the past and its present aspirations. It opened in March, replacing a decades-old Stony Brook favorite, Brook House, an ice-cream parlor and family restaurant.

title: Leaving Islam for Atheism, and Finding a Much-Needed Place Among Peers
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Women talked about coming out, being open with their families, leaving the closet at a conference here this month. But the topic was not sexuality. Instead, the women, attending the third Women in Secularism conference were talking about being atheists. Some grew up Catholic, some Jewish, some Protestant  but nearly all described journeys of acknowledging atheism first to themselves, then to loved ones. Going public was a last, often painful, step.

title: A Gastropub Thats Sophisticated and Homey
description: One of the biggest restaurant trends in recent years is the rise of the gastropub. Combining the comfort of a relaxed, local hangout with a serious, often farm-to-table approach to food, these places can have a high-low combination that is tremendously appealing  but not that easy to achieve.

title: 2 States Getting More Money for Storm Recovery Efforts
description: The federal government has drawn up plans to send an additional $2.5 billion in aid to New York and New Jersey to help pay for the recovery from Hurricane Sandy, government officials said on Friday.

title: Iran Is Providing Information on Its Detonators, Atomic Agency Says
description: WASHINGTON  For six years, international nuclear inspectors have been demanding that Iran turn over evidence of experiments that they suspect could have been part of a secret effort to solve the complex science of detonating a nuclear weapon.

title: Chang vs. Lendl: 25 Years Later
description: In 1989, few people thought a 17-year-old American named Michael Chang would beat the No. 1-ranked tennis player, Ivan Lendl, in the fourth round of the French Open.

title: Agency Expects More Deaths From G.M.s Ignition Flaw
description: The number of deaths linked to defective ignition switches in General Motors cars is likely to rise above the 13 fatalities acknowledged so far by G.M., according to the nations top auto safety regulator.

title: From Secret Agent to Hollywood Agent
description: Clark Gregg has been dead before, but he always seems to recover. In his most famous movie appearance, in the superhero blockbuster Marvels The Avengers, his by-the-book lawman, Agent Phil Coulson, was impaled by the villainous Norse god Loki  only to return, no worse for the wear and in a leading role, in the ABC television spinoff Marvels Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

title: Charges Against Chinese, and U.S. Policy on Hacking
description: To the Editor:

title: A Housing Revival in San Antonio
description: Mayor Julin Castro, nominated to be housing secretary, has steered a housing renaissance in the city, getting new apartment buildings built in areas once ignored by developers.

title: Fear of Job Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Anger at Killing of Bystander During Protest in Turkey
description: One day after a bystander was shot to death as he attended a funeral near a protest in Istanbul, there was criticism Friday on social networks in Turkey over the pace of the investigation into his death.

title: IAEA Report on Irans Nuclear Program
description: A report by the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency details major progress Iran has made in diluting most of its stockpile of medium-enriched uranium.

title: Budget Woes May Hurt Christie More Than Bridge Scandal
description: For months, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has kept a low profile, waiting for new headlines to distract from the George Washington Bridge scandal. Now they have: The news has been a dire drumbeat about his states economy.

title: Studying Humans Who Study Apes
description: Krista Knights Primal Play is really a mother play. You know what they say, behind every great woman is her mother, Cynthia Naymark says. And there seems to be nothing Cynthia wont do for her daughter, Valerie, a primatologist with less self-awareness than the chimpanzees she studies.

title: Its No Picnic in the Senate
description: Happy Memorial Day Weekend! Time for summer fun! So lets discuss Congressional gridlock.

title: Why I Blew the Whistle on the V.A.
description: PHOENIX  MY decision to become a whistle-blower after 24 years as a physician in a Veterans Affairs hospital was, at first, an easy one. I knew about patients who were dying while waiting for appointments on the V.A.s secret schedules, and I couldnt stay silent.

title: Others Fade, but Judge Judy Is Forever: At 71, She Still Presides
description: LOS ANGELES  Judge Judith Sheindlin, the straight-talking star of Judge Judy, peered down at a sassy defendant with disgust. Listen to me, Miss Fibby, Judge Sheindlin snapped at a recent taping here. They dont keep me here because Im gorgeous. They keep me here because Im smart.

title: Credit Suisse Gets Off Easy
description: The sham continues.

title: On the Town, Sort Of: Fleet Week Shrinks
description: Inside his Chelsea apartment on Wednesday morning, Bob Rowen donned a desert-camouflage utility jacket and a sun-stained military cap before heading out onto 26th Street. He marched west, as he has done since the first ships arrived 30 years ago, and took up his regular position along the shore.

title: Fat-Cat Administrators at the Top 25
description: Confronted with punishing state budget cuts, the public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of this countrys students have raised tuition, shrunk course offerings and hired miserably paid, part-time instructors who now form what amounts to a new underclass in the academic hierarchy. At the same time, some of those colleges and universities are spending much too freely on their top administrators.

title: G.O.P.s Foreign Policy Hawks Wary of Pauls Evolving Views
description: WASHINGTON  Rand Paul had just finished his opening remarks at a private gathering of Republican power brokers at the Four Seasons in Georgetown last fall when Phil Gramm, the former senator from Texas, shot up his hand with the first question.

title: With 2,583 Games at One Position, Derek Jeter Reaches Another Milestone
description: CHICAGO  It seems that barely a day goes by without Derek Jeter breaking a record or passing a milestone.

title: Gender Imbalance in the Lab
description: Federal health officials are taking steps to correct a longstanding gender imbalance in laboratory research on potential drug treatments. For the past two decades, federal law has required that women be included in clinical studies funded by the National Institutes of Health in recognition of the fact that drugs often have vastly different effects in men and women. As a result, more than half of the participants in N.I.H.-funded clinical research are women. But there has been no similar requirement to eliminate the sex bias from more basic laboratory research that can lead up to a clinical trial or doom a drug to the discard pile if it seems not to work.

title: Pfizers Ploy and the Porous Tax Laws
description: Pfizers $119 billion offer to buy AstraZeneca, the British drug company, is driven largely by its desire to cut its tax bill. It is a ploy made possible by porous tax laws in the United States that encourage corporate tax avoidance and by laws in Britain and elsewhere that abet it.

title: Jackie Kennedys Letters Taken Off the Auction Block
description: BOSTON  It was an unlikely friendship, between a shy, 21-year-old American socialite and a 73-year-old Irish priest. But in 1950, they began an extraordinary correspondence in which the American revealed her private thoughts as she dated, then married, then witnessed the assassination of the president of the United States. Now the fate of their letters, which had been headed for the auction block, is in question.

title: A $2 Ferry Ride Away, 30 Transformed Acres
description: A broad carpet of new parkland has been unfurled in the middle of New York Harbor and the public is welcome, beginning Saturday, for the price of a boat ride: two dollars.

title: After Revival in San Antonio, Washington Comes Calling
description: SAN ANTONIO  When Mayor Julin Castro of San Antonio and local officials traveled to Washington in 2012 to meet President Obamas housing secretary, Shaun Donovan, the agenda was about housing policy. But for Mr. Castro, it was personal, too.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 23, 2014
Ukraine Faces Struggle to Gain Control of Militias, Including Those on Its Side
description: KARLOVKA, Ukraine  In a secluded wood in eastern Ukraine, a group of 120 men who call themselves the Donbass Battalion had commandeered a childrens summer camp to prepare for war.

title: Cuomo to Earn Over $700,000 From a Memoir, Filings Reveal
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is set to earn more than $700,000 for a memoir that will be published this summer, according to a new ethics filing.

title: Michael Chang Returns to French Open, With a Protg
description: PARIS  Twenty-five years later, Michael Chang still has not talked about the 1989 French Open with Ivan Lendl. Nor has he hit another underhand serve in competition.

title: A Specter of Past Executions Resurfaces in Tennessee
description: A man who had shot to death his four young children, for reasons known only to him, sat in the wooden chair reserved for him at the Riverbend Maximum Security Institution in Nashville. His body was strapped tight and his head was freshly shaved, to enhance the conductivity.

title: Calm Streets Mask Deep Divisions in Donetsk
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  To the casual observer, this is not a city at war. Masked men are confined to a few buildings in the center of town, where children on in-line skates pass by. City workers tend to flowers in meticulously planted parks. Crowded open-air cafes spill onto sidewalks and into parks. Pfizer is holding a conference at the Ramada, where grilled sea bass is on the menu.

title: Andr Popp, French Composer of Love Is Blue, Dies at 90
description: Andr Popp, a French composer whose instrumental Love is Blue became a 1960s standard and an easy listening hit in the United States, died on May 10 at his home in Puteaux, France. He was 90.

title: Cornelia G. Kennedy, a Pioneering Federal Judge, Dies at 90
description: Cornelia G. Kennedy was one of the first women to serve as a clerk at the prestigious United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and the first woman in the nation to serve as chief judge of a federal district court. Three presidents shortlisted her for the United States Supreme Court.

title: Civilian Militias Face Russian Foes
description: A group of Ukrainians loyal to Kiev formed the Donbass Battalion to provide a new front against pro-Russian militias that have attacked military units and taken over government buildings.

title: Pie-in-the-Face Scenes
description: UPDATE: The Across Lite link in the box is not working, and I am trying to get hold of someone to change it. For now, please click here or use the link on the main puzzles page.

title: Nigerias Army Hampers Hunt for Abducted Schoolgirls
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Intelligence agents from all over the globe have poured into this city, Nigerias capital, to help find the nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls abducted by the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram more than a month ago  but there has been little or no progress in bringing the young women home.

title: Jaime Lusinchi, Ex-Leader of Venezuela, Dies at 89
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Jaime Lusinchi, a former president of Venezuela who caused a national stir by installing his mistress as his private secretary and making her a powerful force in government, then fled with her amid a corruption scandal, died here on Wednesday. He was 89.

title: As Regimes Shift Worldwide, China Signs Gas Deal With Russia
description: Someone who tries to blow out anothers oil lamp will set his beard on fire, the president of China told an Asian regional security forum in Shanghai on Wednesday. The old Kazakh saw, explained the China Daily, was Xi Jinpings veiled way of telling the United States to get used to Chinas rise and to stop interfering in Asian affairs.

title: Shirley Walton Fischler, Hockey Writer Who Broke a Barrier, Dies at 74
description: Shirley Walton Fischler, who in 1971 became the first woman allowed to report on hockey games from the Madison Square Garden press box, died on May 13 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

title: Mets Try to Lift Public Relations
description: The Mets on Friday hired Harold Kaufman, a former longtime N.B.A. executive, to expand their public relations efforts off the field. Kaufman, who spent nearly two decades as a vice president of communications for the Charlotte and New Orleans Hornets, was named the Mets executive director of communications.

title: Dragons Return to the Bronx Zoo
description: Many of the popular residents of the Bronx Zoo are soft and cute. But you would not want to cuddle its newest stars. Komodo dragons, known for their size and their deadly bite, are returning to the zoo after more than 50 years.

title: Why Journalists Need to Squint
description: If you squint, and peer into the dark back room of the bamboo hut, you can barely make them out. Women huddled together in a cluster peek out from behind an open kitchen door. As the camera shoots back and forth between a community leader and the only villager with formal English trainingboth menthe women take turns retreating further into the scenery so they might shush the crying baby.

title: Europes Right and Left on March to Populism
description: ROME  For weeks, Beppe Grillo, the Italian political insurgent, has crisscrossed the nation in what might be called his vitriol tour. He has let loose zesty, bellowing insults against journalists, businessmen, Italian politicians and Angela Merkel, the German chancellor and avatar of European austerity. He has even taken a swipe at Dudu, the fluffy white poodle belonging to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

title: After a Horrendous Start, an Invigorated Granderson Has Found His Swing
description: Entering the May 12 start of the Subway Series, Mets outfielder Curtis Granderson appeared to be another one of the teams free-agent busts. Granderson was earning unflattering comparisons to Jason Bay, the former outfielder signed to a disastrous four-year, $66 million contract before the 2010 season.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 24, 2014
description: People take comfort in order. I also move swiftly, as opposed to a justice system and a government that is slow and meandering.

title: Happy in Tehran Video Spurs Harsher Censorship
description: The judicial authorities in Iran appeared to harden their clampdown on expression Friday, moving to block Instagram, imprisoning the director who made the now-famous Iranian version of the Pharrell Williams Happy video and warning women to comply with a police campaign on the proper wearing of mandatory headscarves.

title: Upheaval in Thailand
description: Thailands military leaders tried to tighten their hold on the country a day after a coup, but some signs of defiance emerged.

title: Turkey Says 2 Have Died After a Protest in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  Two men have died after clashes in Istanbul between the police and a group of demonstrators who had gathered to protest last weeks mine disaster in Soma, Gov. Huseyin Avni Mutlu of Istanbul said Friday.

title: In Letter, Redskins Defend Name
description: The Washington Redskins defended the teams name in a letter to the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada,two days after 50 Democratic senators urged Roger Goodell, the N.F.L.s commissioner, to support a change.

title: Dunns Homer Ends Game and Closers Perfect Season
description: CHICAGO  All closers know that, despite their best efforts, their jobs will inevitably include the dreaded blown save. Even Mariano Rivera blew save opportunities, sometimes in big games.

title: Corrections: May 24, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE WORLDS END (2013) In the summer of 1990, five British teenagers set out on a pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, vomiting, fighting and having drunken sex along what is known as the Golden Mile. But they failed to make it through the 12 requisite watering holes, the last of which was called the Worlds End. Twenty years later, they give it a second try in this comedy directed by Edgar Wright, the final installment in his Cornetto Trilogy, following Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz. Nick Frost, Simon Pegg and Paddy Considine, along with Martin Freeman and Eddie Marsan, play the Golden Milers. Four have traded their wild youth for adult respectability; the fifth decidedly has not. Then the robots show up, and these men just may be humanitys only hope for survival. The Cornetto Trilogy is named after a popular ice cream treat, and the buzz of The Worlds End is more like an antic sugar high than a reeling, drunken stupor, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. There are no headaches, dry mouth or crushing shame at the end  no Hangover, in other words. Ill drink to that.

title: In Possible Thaw, Pakistani Leader Agrees to Attend Swearing-In Ceremony in India
description: NEW DELHI  Ending days of hesitation, Pakistans prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on Saturday accepted an Indian invitation to attend the swearing-in of the new prime minister, Narendra Modi, offering a fresh opportunity to revitalize the moribund peace process between the two countries, which have had particularly frosty relations since early 2013.

title: Is Piketty All Wrong?
description: Great buzz in the blogosphere over Chris Giless attack on Thomas Pikettys Capital in the 21st Century. Giles finds a few clear errors, although they dont seem to matter much; more important, he questions some of the assumptions and imputations Piketty uses to deal with gaps in the data and the way he switches sources. Neil Irwin and Justin Wolfers have good discussions of the complaints; Piketty will have to answer these questions in detail, and well see how well he does it.

title: Analytics: Blood Dosas
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 25 issue of the magazine.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, May 25
description: We deeply regret the past misconduct that led to this settlement.

title: Strikes, Spares and Bruised Shins
description: In high school, I had one of the rarer jobs for a teenager in modern America. The time-honored types of teenage employment  jobs in fast food or in retailing at the mall  didnt exist in the rural Pennsylvania town where I grew up. The few positions for restaurant servers, grocery stockers and cashiers were filled mostly by older women who needed that work to get by. Strangely, the job readily available to me was at the town bowling alley, where I worked one night a week as a pin boy.

title: A Custodian of Kauais Secrets
description: Robert Miguel, 35, works for Kukuiula, a second-home development on Kauai in Hawaii.

title: Pope Calls for Solutions to Conflicts in Mideast Visit
description: ON THE EAST BANK OF THE JORDAN RIVER  After visiting a site on Saturday where Jesus is believed to have been baptized, Pope Francis spoke about Jesuss humility, the fact that he bends down to wounded humanity in order to heal us.

title: The Ripple Effects of Rising Student Debt
description: What are the roads not taken because students must take out loans for college? A collection of studies shows that the burden of student debt may well cause people to make different decisions than they would otherwise  affecting not just individual lives but also the entire economy.

title: Home Sweet Headquarters for an App Start-Up
description: A sense of place

title: The Computerized Voice That Wasnt
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Maybe Theres Life in the Old Bull Market Yet
description: Worried about the stock market? Theres no shortage of reasons to fret.

title: Buying Insurance Against Climate Change
description: The third National Climate Assessment report  released on May 6 by the White House, and representing the work of more than 240 scientists  warns us about our hazardous future and offers many good ideas for dealing with it. But a most important point may be lost in the crowd.

title: For Brett Wilson of TubeMogul, Its All in the Follow-Through
description: This interview with  Brett Wilson, chief executive of TubeMogul, a video advertising software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: 1914: The Most Radiant Stars Shine in the May Skies
description: If May is the spring month par excellence, that personifies the return of fine weather, it is also the month whose mild evenings best lend themselves to reveries by moonlight and contemplation of the star-studded skies.

title: Video Rant, Then Deadly Rampage in California Town
description: ISLA VISTA, Calif.  A college student who posted videos that documented his rage against women for rejecting him killed six people and wounded 13 others during a spasm of terror on Friday night, the police said. He stabbed three men to death in his apartment and shot the others as he methodically opened fire on bystanders on the crowded streets of this small town.

title: Gordons 736-Race Streak Is in Peril
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Jeff Gordon, the Sprint Cup standings leader and a four-time series champion, said Saturday that back spasms could force him out of Sundays Coca-Cola 600.

title: Easing the Way for East Africa Visitors
description: Visas have long presented a real barrier to ease of travel in many African countries. They can be pricey and require tedious forms.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Ive gone on record as saying that when it comes to cryptics, Im best at the ones constructed by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon. Thats not a put down of any other constructor of cryptic crossword puzzles; its just how my own brain works. Im more on their wavelength.

title: The Deals Done. But Not the Fees.
description: There was joy on Park Avenue as the news arrived from Warsaw, a small Indiana city.

title: Inside the Cannabis Factory
description: New federal regulations in Canada make way for the large-scale legal production of marijuana.

title: When Cannabis Goes Corporate
description: Hershey stopped producing chocolate in Smiths Falls, Ontario, six years ago. The work went to Mexico, but the factory remains, along with reminders of the glory days: A sign that once directed school buses delivering children for tours. A fading, theme-park-style entrance that marks what used to be the big attraction  a Chocolate Shoppe that sold about $4 million of broken candy and bulk bars a year.

title: YouTube Video: Retribution
description: Investigators are reviewing a video posted online by Elliot Rodger, 22, who has been identified as the suspect in the shooting and stabbing deaths of six people near the University of California, Santa Barbara.

title: The True Cabrera, So the Blue Jays Hope
description: Manager John Gibbons sat in the Toronto Blue Jays dugout at Fenway Park last Tuesday and motioned toward the Green Monster, where the American League East standings are updated daily.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 19
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: No Time but Present for the Heat and LeBron James
description: MIAMI  There is a calm about LeBron James now, evident in his interactions with the horde of reporters that surrounded him last week on the Miami Heat practice court and, twice in two days, pelted him with rapid-fire questions on a range of subjects. Each one he answered swiftly, with a practiced grace and panache, deploying disarming tones and the most appropriate facial expressions.

title: Militants Attack Somalias Parliament
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Militants attacked Somalias Parliament building on Saturday, with a bomber detonating a car filled with explosives at the buildings entrance followed by several other explosions and an assault by gunmen, witnesses and Somali officials said.

title: Vigneaults Firing by the Canadiens Led to His Success
description: In matters of hockey, patience is not a virtue in Montreal, where it is late even when it is early. The Canadiens travails determine whether the city beams or frowns. Bearable Stanley Cup droughts are measured not by the season but by the week.

title: Tempting Europe With Ugly Fruit
description: LISBON  Isabel Soares went shopping for produce on a recent morning, carefully selecting her fruits and vegetables with a discriminating eye. She picked up some spinach whose leaves had turned an unappealing yellow. Then some tomatoes whose skin had been damaged by sunburn and insect bites. Finally, she set on some zucchini that had grown so large and deformed that they curved almost into a doughnut shape.

title: Observers Go to Ukraine for Election Separatists Plan to Disrupt
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  A delegation of international election observers arrived in this troubled eastern Ukrainian city on Saturday on the eve of a critical national vote, just hours after separatist leaders from several eastern provinces met here and reiterated their promises to disrupt it.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: Memorial Day may not be the official start of summer, but it certainly feels like it. This weeks Money Talking kicks back a bit to talk about books on climate change, leveraged buyouts and the Koch Brothers.

title: Suspects in China Market Attack Identified
description: BEIJING  Law enforcement officials in the western region of Xinjiang on Saturday identified five men they said were responsible for an attack on an outdoor vegetable market on Thursday that killed 43 people and injured more than 90, many of them elderly shoppers.

title: In a Fathers Footsteps, Chasing a Triple Crown
description: One early morning in late April, the trainer Alan Sherman rested his arms on the rail as he watched one of his horses gallop at Los Alamitos Race Course in California. The call to the post played, but the sound did not come from a bugle. It came from Shermans cellphone.

title: Chinas Leader, Seeking to Build Its Muscle, Pushes Overhaul of the Military
description: BEIJING  Driven by ambitions to make China a great power, President Xi Jinping is staking his political authority on a huge task: overhauling the Chinese military, which is still largely organized as it was when a million peasant soldiers mustered under Mao Zedong.

title: The Immigrant Advantage
description: IF you want to die a successful American, especially in the heartland, it helps to be born abroad.

title: Memorial Day 2050
description: OF the many things being said about climate change lately, none was more eloquent than the point made by Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington State in the Showtime series Years of Living Dangerously, when he observed: Were the first generation to feel the impact of climate change and the last generation that can do something about it.

title: Nir Kalron
description: The former Israeli commando Nir Kalron is the chief executive of Maisha Consulting Ltd., a security and risk management firm based in Tel Aviv that focuses on deterring environmental crime in Africa.

title: Read These Lips
description: A KISS is nothing. On the sidewalks, in the park, I see one every few minutes, a real kiss, lip to lip. It barely registers. Its as unremarkable as a car horn in traffic, as an umbrella in rain.

title: Fitness Crazed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  IM no scientist, but I sure like reading about science. Im always looking through newspapers for the latest research about saturated fat and whether its still bad for you, or if maybe sugar is poison.

title: America, China and the Hacking Threat
description: Over several years of trying to persuade China to stop cyberattacks against corporate America, the Obama administration has gotten nowhere. What officials say is the most aggressive effort by any country to steal secrets from some of the most prominent and successful American companies is still going strong. Losses are estimated at billions of dollars in profits and thousands of jobs.

title: Graduate of the Year
description: LONG AN, Vietnam  TAY THI NGUYEN is one of the mightiest people Ive met, at 94 pounds. She has a towering presence, at a bit more than 5 feet tall. She is so strong that she probably could bench press 25 pounds.

title: Willful Ignorance in Wyoming
description: The year has already produced three alarming reports involving climate change.

title: Deterrence Revisited
description: WASHINGTON  THE graduation exercises at West Point have long been a moment for American presidents to offer midcourse adjustments  or something more radical  in their strategies for dealing with foreign adversaries. A dozen years ago, George W. Bush offered the first taste of his pre-emption strategy from the bluffs over the Hudson River, reviving a 165-year-old concept to warn anyone who might threaten the United States that Washington could act first to neutralize them. It was more than a rhetorical exercise: 10 months later American forces were on their way to Baghdad.

title: Who Are Womens Colleges For?
description: FOR hundreds of years, universities excluded women. Denied access to these institutions, they created their own. Attempt great things, the founder of Mount Holyoke, Mary Lyon, told her students. Accomplish great things. These schools, including the elite Seven Sisters  Mount Holyoke, Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley  were where the nations most promising young women went to do just that.

title: The Tea Party Legacy
description: THE Tea Party is finished: smashed, at last, by the power and dollars of the Republican establishment, whose candidates  including Mitch McConnell, the most establishment Republican of all  easily turned back right-wing primary challengers last week.

title: My First Year
description: Checking in with college students, before and after their freshman year in New York City.

title: Offer a Caveat Lector?
description: Readers discuss whether teachers should warn students about disturbing literature.

title: Finding Niche on Other Side of the Bargaining Table
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The windows in his new office face west, away from MetLife Stadium, about a mile away. Mike Tannenbaum could have gone about anywhere to restart his career after being fired as the general manager of the Jets in 2013. But he chose a small office enclave inside the practice home of the Nets.

title: End Mass Incarceration Now
description: For more than a decade, researchers across multiple disciplines have been issuing reports on the widespread societal and economic damage caused by Americas now-40-year experiment in locking up vast numbers of its citizens. If there is any remaining disagreement about the destructiveness of this experiment, it mirrors the so-called debate over climate change.

title: Some Like It Hot
description: WASHINGTON  SOME people have such a radical vitality, such an electric consciousness, such a lifelong love affair with the world that when they stop breathing, its like a wind dying, like the waning and disappearing of a light.

title: Faking Cultural Literacy
description: LOS ANGELES  I CANT help it. Every few weeks, my wife mentions the latest book her book club is reading, and no matter what it is, whether Ive read it or not, I offer an opinion of the work, based entirely on ... what, exactly? Often, these are books Ive not even read a review or essay about, yet I freely hold forth on the grandiosity of Cheryl Strayed or the restrained sentimentality of Edwidge Danticat. These data motes are gleaned, apparently, from the ether  or, more realistically, from various social media feeds.

title: Poet vs. Novelist
description: The word novel carries for me a weight as ominous, all-consuming and unforgiving as any Job encountered. I was 17 when I decided to write stories as big as cathedrals, overflowing with the kind of memorable and audacious characters Walker Percy, Ernest Hemingway and Saul Bellow created. I stayed up all night, writing description, dialogue, plot curlicues, stories within stories, convinced that anything fewer than 10 pages was wasted time. One wrote the way Thomas Wolfe did, I thought, with fury and hubris, translating everything one read, experienced and felt into glistening, unswerving prose. I didnt need drugs, cigarettes or caffeine; writing was my drug of choice. And the novel was the high point of literary achievement.

title: Election of President Seen as a Beginning to Repairing Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For some Ukrainians, the election on Sunday to replace their ousted president might be viewed as the triumphant culmination of six months of protests and at times violent upheaval. But for the young journalist whose Facebook post is credited as the virtual trumpet call that ignited his countrys revolution last fall, there is nothing to celebrate  yet.

title: Why D.S.K. Wont Go Away
description: HES back. It took Monica S. Lewinsky 16 years to face the cameras, but for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, three years was already too long a purgatory.

title: Iran Billionaire Hanged for Fraud
description: TEHRAN  Irans judiciary on Saturday executed a billionaire businessman who had been convicted of playing a central role in a $2.6 billion corruption case that has roiled the countrys banking system and political leaders.

title: Kid Gloves Off, and a Relief Ace Emerges
description: In 2007, the Joba Rules were the talk of baseball. To protect the developing arm of Joba Chamberlain, the Yankees prized 21-year-old pitcher, the team limited how often and how much he could pitch.

title: On World Fish Migration Day, Recalling When Americas Rivers Ran Silver
description: [If youre visiting thanks to Tom Friedmans kind Dot Earth mention in his column on acting with a long-term perspective, heres a link to the piece hes quoting from.]

title: Junta Targets Scholars for New Detentions as Thai Forces Are Sent to Protests
description: BANGKOK  Thailands military junta on Saturday ordered two dozen professors and writers to turn themselves over to the military authorities, broadening a sweep in which nearly 200 political officials have already been detained, and sent more troops into the streets of Bangkok and other cities to discourage protests.

title: Kurt Busch Intends to Drive 1,100 Miles in a Day
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Kurt Busch, discussing why he was planning to race Sunday in the Indianapolis 500 and then in the 600-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event in North Carolina, recalled a week in 1997 that was kind of my fork in the road.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 25
description: President Obama made it clear in a conversation on Wednesday with the veterans affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, that there will be accountability for the revelations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide the long delays many patients experienced in getting primary care. Many Republicans and a few Democratic lawmakers have called for Mr. Shinseki to resign.

title: Lebanons Political Standoff Leaves Leadership Vacancy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Waving to television cameras and assembled dignitaries, President Michel Suleiman departed the presidential palace on Saturday, the last day of his six-year term, leaving behind a political vacuum caused by the failure of the countrys political powers to agree on a successor.

title: A Wins-First Mentality Has Not Lifted Nascar
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Marcos Ambrose, the Tasmanian Nascar driver and road course ace who has raced for small and midsize teams throughout his six-year Sprint Cup career, has never qualified for the annual playoff. But this may be his year. With a new qualifying format putting stronger emphasis on winning, Ambrose figures he has perhaps his best shot at making the expanded 16-team field for the playoff, the Chase for the Sprint Cup.

title: Sinn Fein Benefits as Ireland Moves Left
description: DUBLIN  Ireland has taken a decisive step to the left in local and European elections, where early returns on Saturday showed that the big winners were Sinn Fein, formerly the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and Socialist independent candidates.

title: Obama to Detail a Broader Foreign Policy Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, seeking to answer criticism that he has forsaken Americas leadership role, plans to lay out a retooled foreign-policy agenda on Wednesday that could deepen the nations involvement in Syria but would still steer clear of major military conflicts.

title: Kings Coach Says Plenty With Little
description: The Los Angeles Kings have reached three consecutive Western Conference finals, and that means we hear more from Kings Coach Darryl Sutter.

title: 3 Shot Dead at Brussels Jewish Museum
description: BRUSSELS  An unidentified gunman opened fire on Saturday at the Jewish Museum in the center of Brussels, killing at least three people in what officials said appeared to have been an anti-Semitic attack.

title: Composers Struck by Homeland Fever
description: A century after the outbreak of World War I, the fervent embrace of belligerent nationalism by educated Europeans continues to puzzle and fascinate historians. The conductor and scholar Leon Botstein investigates this question in a fascinating program of rarely performed works by composers swept up in nationalist movements. The American Symphony Orchestra will be joined by the Collegiate Chorale Singers and three fine soloists: the pianist Blair McMillen, the bass Denis Sedov and the tenor Corey Bix.

title: One More Round for a Wartime Soap
description: Its common these days for a made-for-television movie to serve as a test run for a possible series; if the movie draws a decent audience, a series will be created from its characters and setting. The Canadian series Bomb Girls received the opposite treatment: an exit movie.

title: For a Cuban Troupe, a Gift of Rootedness
description: Danza Contempornea de Cuba, the national modern dance company, first performed in the United States in 2011. The date is noteworthy, since the troupe was founded more than 50 years earlier, in the same year that Fidel Castro came to power. The 2011 visit offered a look, long delayed by American policy toward Cuba, at the official version of modern dance in a dance-mad culture. New York critics praised the Cubans for their virtuosity, versatility and charm. Too bad, more than one wrote, that the choreography was not up to the same level.

title: When Seascapes Left Stodgy Behind
description: Whether you agree with the Victorian critic John Ruskin that the British painter Joseph Mallord William Turner was a talent on par with Shakespeare, you have to acknowledge that Turner revolutionized the stodgy tradition of marine painting. On Saturday, more than 100 of his seascapes  including his frothy, experimental renderings of wind-whipped oceans  will go on view at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass.

title: Leaping to Honor a First-Name Guy
description: Almost everyone involved with dance knew him, and they all just called him Freddie. Frederic Franklin, who died at 99 last May, was one of modern ballets most irrepressible figures. He was always onstage, performing mime roles in his later years. Blessed with an amazing memory and an ability to communicate, he also staged ballets, including American Ballet Theaters Copplia, the 19th-century comic classic, which the company will dance in his honor. (7:30 p.m. Friday, 2 p.m. and 8 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; 212-362-6000, abt.org.) From the Horses Mouth, a group that brings dance people together, is presenting three evenings dedicated to Franklin, featuring reminiscences, films and videos. Participants will vary from night to night, and presentations will emphasize his contributions to male dancing. (7:30 p.m. Friday through Sunday, Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715, schimmel.pace.edu.)

title: Young Man With a Horn
description: The jazz trumpeter Theo Croker is the grandson of Doc Cheatham, who played the same instrument with great beauty and economy until his death at the age of 91 in 1997. In a reverse of the typical trumpeters story, Cheatham seemed to reach his peak in the last phase of his life. Mr. Croker, 29, may have learned something from his grandfathers pacing. He started with plenty of promise and made a very good record in his early 20s (The Fundamentals, on Left Sided), but rather than speed-track his career, he worked in Shanghai for seven years, in clubs and on TV. He has a new album, Afrophysicist (DDB/Sony), showing his breadth, with plush funk and rock idioms, some subtle and complex new-jazz ones, a ballad standard (Moodys Mood for Love) and high-wire soloing. Hell play this week with his band DVRK Funk, including the pianist Sullivan Fortner and the drummer Kassa Overall, with the singer Dee Dee Bridgewater as guest. (7:30 and 9:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, 212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com.)

title: Prepping for Indy 500 and Awaiting World Cup
description: Last year, the veteran Brazilian driver Tony Kanaan won his first Indianapolis 500 in 12 attempts. This year, Kanaan, who won with the KV Racing team, is part of the IndyCar giant Target Chip Ganassi Racing, replacing the retired Dario Franchitti. Kanaan met recently with New York Times editors to discuss the aftermath of his victory, the new season and his interests outside racing. The interview was edited and condensed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Voices of the Post Soviet Voting Bloc
description: A look at the spectrum of opinions surrounding the hopes and reality of the future of Ukraine as it plans its vote May 25.

title: The Law of the Land, Edited
description: The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions, sometimes years after they were issued.

title: Top-Seeded Duke and Notre Dame Advance to Final
description: BALTIMORE  The shootout that was expected between the high-powered offenses of Duke and Denver took about three quarters to develop Saturday in their N.C.A.A. mens lacrosse Final Four matchup at M&T Stadium.

title: Final Word on U.S. Law Isnt: Supreme Court Keeps Editing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, altering the law of the land without public notice. The revisions include truly substantive changes in factual statements and legal reasoning, said Richard J. Lazarus, a law professor at Harvard and the author of a new study examining the phenomenon.

title: Debussy, Wine and B.Y.O.M. at a Fund-Raiser in Denver
description: DENVER  The musicians stuck to the classics at the Colorado Symphonys first-ever Classically Cannabis fund-raiser on Friday night. They played Strauss and Wagner, not Marley and Garcia. Their only concessions to the evenings marijuana theme, it seemed, were the bright green ties they wore with their black suits.

title: As Wars End, Military Gives Its Trademarks New Vigilance
description: WASHINGTON  United States Marine G-string underwear. The Starfleet Marine Corps Academy. And the motto from a human resources company: The Few. The Proud. The Well-Paid.

title: The Fight Against the Slot Parlors Around the Corner
description: LAS VEGAS  Five miles from the flashing lights and scantily clad dancers of the Las Vegas Strip, Dottys Gaming and Spirits lounge on Tropicana Avenue hardly resembles a casino. Decorated with red-and-white checkered tablecloths, plastic flowers, knickknacks and old clocks, the place, like most of the other 64 Dottys outposts scattered across this metropolis, looks more like your grandmothers living room  if your grandmother happened to be an avid gambler.

title: Two Extra Sets, Little Added Drama
description: The N.B.A. continually fights the perception that fans do not need to tune in to games until the second half, or the fourth quarter. At the four Grand Slam tennis events, the opposite is true, especially in the early rounds.

title: Six Contenders Who Are on Rise or Bouncing Back
description: MEN

title: Jeb Bush Gives Party Something to Think About
description: As governor of Florida, Jeb Bush flew in Ivy League social scientists for daylong seminars with his staff and carved out time for immersive brainstorming sessions he called think weeks.

title: In the N.B.A., a Billion-Dollar Distressed Sale of the Clippers
description: Six weeks ago, no one would have suggested that the Los Angeles Clippers could sell for as much as $1 billion. The Lakers, yes. The Clippers, absolutely not.

title: Will Faint for School
description: My Sunday column is about an inspiring young woman who personifies gritand also underscores the power of girls education. Since the Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapping, Ive been thinking about the issue (and writing about it here, here and here). Its obviously important to educate boys too, but I do think that theres evidence that the returns for focusing on girls education are particularly high.

title: Gareth Bales Goal Helps Lift Real Madrid to Its 10th Champions League Title
description: LISBON  Real Madrid Manager Carlo Ancelotti was in the midst of giving a calm, measured response to a question about his teams tactics when the door to the news conference room burst open. Suddenly, seven of Ancelottis players were on the dais with him, jumping around, singing and spraying Champagne.

title: Phil Jackson Has at Least Three Great Choices to Lead Knicks
description: Does Phil Jackson want a coach or does he want a marionette?

title: Change of Program
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  This must have been a tough theme set to pull together. Besides the letter count symmetry, Dan Schoenholz is working with the constraint of having all of his entries be well-known television programs, and then on top of that, he tries to change the names using soundalike words and clue them in a punny way.

title: Turkish Film Winter Sleep Wins Top Honor at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  The 67th Cannes Film Festival came to a restrained close Saturday night when the Palme dOr was awarded to the Turkish film Winter Sleep. Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the 3 hour and 16 minute philosophical talkfest about life and death, good and evil, the beauty of the natural world and art of conversation, had been a critics favorite in a competition lineup many deemed solid if lacking in revelations.

title: Hitters Erase Deficit, Closer Erases Memory, and Yanks Escape With Win
description: CHICAGO  As much as every closer claims a short memory and a tough skin as part of his skill set, the sting of a blown save can be agonizing, especially if it lingers for days. When a closer gives up a two-run homer on the road to instantly lose a game, as David Robertson did Friday night, the agony can be intense.

title: Pope Francis Visits Jordan
description: Pope Francis, while visiting Amman, Jordan, called urgently for a peaceful solution to the Syrian crisis, and a just solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Disney Executive Gains Supporters
description: Robert A. Iger began his career as a local television weatherman in upstate New York. Concerned that he was not good enough, he took a job behind the camera at ABC, ultimately climbing to the top of its parent, the Walt Disney Company, as Michael Eisners deputy.

title: Derision and Suspicion Abound Entering Game 4
description: Gamesmanship and mutual mistrust between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens ruled at Madison Square Garden on Saturday as the teams prepared for Sunday nights continuation of the increasingly prickly Eastern Conference finals.

title: Egypts New Strongman, Sisi Knows Best
description: CAIRO  Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army officer soon to be Egypts president, promises to remedy Egypts crippling fuel shortage by installing energy-efficient bulbs in every home socket, even if he has to send a government employee to screw in each one.

title: YouTube Removes Video Posted by Shooting Suspect
description: As news spread of a shooting in California that left at least seven people dead, YouTube on Saturday afternoon took down a video clip that the police have connected to the rampage. The website was seemingly caught between its mission and its morals, between making information available to all and spreading material that could be construed as offensive, even dangerous.

title: Czars Winery Faces New Era: Annexation
description: A winery in the Crimean seaside resort of Yalta has been around since Nicholas II. It has survived the 1917 revolution, two world wars and the fall of the Soviet Union. Now it faces new uncertainty.

title: Down to the Sea Again
description: In the opening pages of Moby-Dick, the narrator, assessing the insular city of the Manhattoes, notes how even the landlocked are driven to stand and stare out to sea. But look! he says, here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the extremest limit of the land.

title: For Crimea, Its Russian Troops In, Tourists Out
description: YALTA, Crimea  When choosing the idyllic setting for an extramarital affair, Anton Chekhov opted for Yalta, and this seaside resort proved so grateful that it erected a bronze statue of the fictional enchantress with her Pomeranian on the main boardwalk.

title: Vows | Adapting Together
description: Adventurers Eve Hampton and Robert Pratt met while coaching wheelchair basketball at a summer camp. They recently spent 75 days camping together in national parks.

title: Sisis Thesis on Democracy in the Middle East
description: As a student at the United States Army War College, in Carlisle, Pa., during the Iraq war in 2005 and 2006, Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi wrote a 17-page thesis about potential paths to democracy in the Arab world.

title: Wheeler Shakes Off Early Trouble, but Mets Fall to Arizona
description: Lucas Duda stood at his locker with a blank stare on his face and his hands on his hips. He had come to bat in three crucial moments of the Mets 3-2 home loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks on Saturday, with the game close and men on base, and had failed each time. He finished the game 0 for 4, with seven runners left on base.

title: A Met Finds a Place on the Diamond: Everywhere
description: Eric Campbell had planned to go golfing with his father. It was June 2008, and as a tall, athletic third baseman from Boston College, Campbell was expected to be selected before the 15th round of the baseball draft. But instead of obsessing over where he would be taken, he decided to ignore the thing.

title: Hacker Helped Disrupt 300 Web Attacks, Prosecutors Say
description: A prominent hacker set to be sentenced in federal court this week for breaking into numerous computer systems worldwide has provided a trove of information to the authorities, allowing them to disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks on targets that included the United States military, Congress, the federal courts, NASA and private companies, according to a newly filed government court document.

title: Hacker Group Lashes Out Against Informant
description: SAN FRANCISCO  While Hector Xavier Monsegur awaited sentencing for charges that could bring him a lengthy prison term, his former partners in the hacker collective Anonymous and the groups sympathizers expressed their feelings online.

title: Using Jailed Migrants as a Pool of Cheap Labor
description: HOUSTON  The kitchen of the detention center here was bustling as a dozen immigrants boiled beans and grilled hot dogs, preparing lunch for about 900 other detainees. Elsewhere, guards stood sentry and managers took head counts, but the detainees were doing most of the work  mopping bathroom stalls, folding linens, stocking commissary shelves.

title: Finding Tomorrows Classical Fans
description: As orchestras see audiences age and dwindle in size, the Cleveland Orchestra is trying to attract the youngest audience of any in America by its 100th birthday in 2018.

title: Concerns Over Police Brutality After a Bronx Arrest Goes Awry
description: Last Saturday, just before midnight, Javier Payne and a friend stood handcuffed outside a hookah store on a street corner in the Bronx. The teenagers had been arrested, accused of assaulting a 49-year-old man who refused to give them cigarettes.

title: U.S. Champs Retain Titles in Playoffs After Late Rallies
description: It was a struggle for them, but both Gata Kamsky and Irina Krush successfully defended their national titles on Tuesday by winning three-way playoffs at the United States Championship in St. Louis.

title: Orphan Black Recap: So a Clone Walks Into a Bar
description: One of the highlights from the first season of Orphan Black came in Episode 6, when Sarah (Tatiana Maslany), Felix (Jordan Gavaris), Paul (Dylan Bruce) and Victor (Michael Mando) crashed a neighborhood potluck at Alisons home. In the midst of this suburban party  while guests congregated in the living room and kitchen, laughing, drinking and listening to 90s pop hits like Lovefool by The Cardigans  the clones and their associates engaged in and/or tried to cover up various forms of torture in the basement and the garage. The resulting juxtaposition from that setup illustrated how different the clones lives are from the rest of the general populace. It was also a goldmine for both comedy and dramatic tension.

title: Francis T. Purcell, Three-Term Nassau County Executive, Dies at 95
description: Francis T. Purcell, a three-term Nassau County executive who in the late 1970s and 80s promoted the development of downtown business areas and the transformation of Mitchel Field, a former air base, into a recreational and educational center, died May 18 at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 95.

title: Robert J. Flynn, Shot Down in Vietnam War and Held in China, Dies at 76
description: Navy Cmdr. Robert J. Flynn, who spent five and a half years in a Communist Chinese prison during the Vietnam War, almost always in solitary confinement, after he was shot down on a bombing mission, died on May 15 in Pensacola, Fla. Commander Flynn, one of only two American servicemen known to have been held by the Chinese during the war, was 76.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 24, 2014
Protesters Urge Guggenheim to Aid Abu Dhabi Workers
description: Protesters critical of the Guggenheim Museums planned franchise in Abu Dhabi smuggled artworks into the museum on Saturday evening, placing them in an exhibit of Italian Futurism.

title: Festival Showcases a Lifestyle Lost by Closing a Border
description: LAJITAS, Tex.,  Hundreds of people gathered recently along the banks of the Rio Grande for the second Voices From Both Sides festival held along the edge of Lajitas, Texas, and Paso Lajitas, in the Mexican state of Chihuahua.

title: Candidates on the Right Ride Out Attacks
description: A conservative talk radio host with a history of bankruptcy, litigation and attention-grabbing on-air moments, Dan Patrick is a candidate out of an opposition researchers fantasy.

title: Cost of New Drug Complicates Access for Inmates and the Poor
description: A new treatment for hepatitis C is considered a breakthrough for people with the liver disease. But the high cost of the drug  about $1,000 a pill  has complicated efforts to get the medication to Texans who receive government-subsidized health care.

title: A Voyage Into Dark Side of Politics
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Gunman Made Threats in 141-Page Manifesto and YouTube Videos
description: Updated, 12:20 p.m. | Elliot O. Rodger, the 22-year-old gunman who the police said killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, on Friday night, expressed his frustration with women in multiple YouTube videos and a 141-page autobiography titled My Twisted World.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 25, 2014
description: In Supreme Court opinions, every word matters. When theyre changing the wording of opinions, theyre basically rewriting the law.

title: Melissa Saiontz, Jeffrey Luse
description: Melissa Ann Saiontz, a daughter of Leslie Miller Saiontz and Steven J. Saiontz, both of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Jeffrey David Luse, a son of Susan Shaskan Luse and Eric Luse of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Gary A. Glickstein officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Key Biscayne in Miami.

title: Michelle Liszt, Nathan Sandals
description: Michelle Sarah Liszt and Nathan Andrew Field Sandals are to be married Sunday at Beth El Synagogue in St. Louis Park, Minn. Rabbi Alexander M. Davis will perform the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Brooks, Nathan Wentworth
description: Elizabeth Brooks and Nathan Benjamin Wentworth were married Saturday at the Seagle Music Colony in Schroon Lake, N.Y. John R. Fulton III, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Rachel Karnovsky and Sidney Coren
description: Rachel Kaplan Karnovsky, the daughter of Sue A. Kaplan and David M. Karnovsky of New York, is to be married Sunday in Brooklyn to Sidney Alexander Coren, a son of Sara Glantz Coren and Michael R. Coren of Dallas. Rabbi Felicia L. Sol is to lead the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, with Cantor Ari Priven participating.

title: Emily Copenhaver and Daniel Fetter
description: Emily Ward Copenhaver and Daniel Schroeder Fetter are to be married Sunday. Susan N. Herman, a Universal Life minister and the president of the American Civil Liberties Union, will officiate at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Salvatore Lopes, Brandon Moyer
description: Salvatore Anthony Lopes and Jack Brandon Moyer were married Saturday. Benjamin M. Adams, a minister affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, officiated at the River Caf in Brooklyn.

title: Jon Fox and Darrell Hotchkiss
description: Jon Gilbert Fox and Darrell Alan Hotchkiss were married Saturday. Jean K. Burling, a retired judge of the New Hampshire Superior Court, officiated at the hay farm of Jeanie and Bayne Stevenson in Lyme, N.H.

title: Juliet Fraser, Wade Gibson
description: Juliet Anne Fraser and Fletcher Wade Gibson IV are to be married Sunday evening at Maguire Gardens in Los Angeles. Robert Gregory, a Universal Life minister and a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Graber, Andrew Bentley
description: Elizabeth Paull Graber and Andrew Martin Bentley are to be married Sunday. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan will officiate at the Nicollet Island Pavilion in Minneapolis.

title: Kiera Butler, Nikhil Swaminathan
description: Kiera Eve Butler and Nikhil Rajesh Swaminathan are to be married Sunday. Kim Triedman, a Universal Life minister, will officiate at the Lawrence Hall of Science in Berkeley, Calif., with Meenakshi Rajachudamani, a cousin of the groom, leading a ceremony with Hindu elements.

title: Joshua Crouthamel, Kurt Fulepp
description: Joshua David Crouthamel and Kurt Nicholas Fulepp are to be married Sunday at the Hotel Americano in New York. Jeremy Crouthamel, a cousin of Mr. Crouthamel who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the event, will officiate. On Thursday, Wayne Tunnicliffe, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony before family and friends at the Winery in Sydney, Australia.

title: Shiela Lee and Andrew Chow
description: Shiela Lee and Dr. Andrew Chow were married Saturday evening by Franny A. Civitano, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the bride, at the Golden Unicorn restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Heidi Skolnik, Michael Glantz
description: Heidi Beth Skolnik and Michael Jonathan Glantz are to be married Sunday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. Rabbi Kenneth A. Stern is to officiate, with Cantor Margot Goldberg taking part.

title: Melanese Moody, Chad Richens
description: Melanese Moody and Chad Voit Richens were married Wednesday at the home of the grooms father, Voit Richens, in Pendleton, S.C. Danielle M. Baker, a minister ordained by First Nation Church in New York, officiated.

title: Amrita Singh and Sam Bhatia
description: Amrita Singh, the daughter of Surinder Kaur and Gurcharan Singh of New York, was married Saturday to Sam Anil Bhatia, the son of Asha A. Bhatia of Edison, N.J., and the late Anil J. Bhatia. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Pierre hotel in New York.

title: Jillian Rothstein, Benjamin Solomon
description: Jillian Brooke Rothstein and Dr. Benjamin Alan Solomon were married Saturday night by Rabbi Steven Fink at the Woodholme Country Club in Pikesville, Md.

title: Sara Mosbrucker, Aaron Hecht
description: Sara Jo Mosbrucker and Aaron Michael Hecht were married Saturday under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute at the Sunnehanna Country Club in Johnstown, Pa.

title: Allyson Davis, Adam Breitman
description: Allyson Jena Davis and Adam Jeffrey Breitman are to be married Sunday at East Meadow Jewish Center in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Marcus L. Burstein is to officiate.

title: Abigail Coyle, Christopher Caponetti
description: Abigail Marie Coyle, a daughter of Janet M. Coyle and David J. Coyle of West Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Christopher Cartier Caponetti, a son of Paula A. Caponetti and Dr. Richard F. Caponetti of Colts Neck, N.J. The Very Rev. Raymond Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Boston.

title: Karen Kucinski, Robin Fukuyama
description: Karen Marie Kucinski and Robin Ann Fukuyama are to be married Sunday, on the 16th anniversary of their first date. The Rev. Dr. Bonnie Bardot, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will officiate at the Jacky Durrell Pavilion in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Ami Fisher, Justin Lilien
description: Ami Sara-Ann Fisher and Justin Mark Lilien are to be married Sunday afternoon by Cantor Matthew Axelrod at Atrium Country Club in West Orange, N.J.

title: Eva Talmadge, Mattathias Schwartz
description: Eva Talmadge and Mattathias Schwartz are to be married Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Cantor Lisa B. Segal will officiate.

title: Rose Karon, Douglas Tilley
description: Rose Leah Karon, a daughter of Cynthia S. Karon and Stuart C. Karon of Newton Highlands, Mass., was married Saturday to Douglas William Tilley, a son of Suzanne Smythe of Essex, Conn., and Christopher W. Tilley of St. Helena, Calif. Stephanie B. Turner, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at V Madrone, a winery in St. Helena that is owned and operated by the grooms father and stepmother, Pauline C. Tilley.

title: Brian Rubin, Toby Sowers
description: Brian Michael Rubin and Thomas Benjamin Sowers are to be married Sunday at the Hudson Theater in New York. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum will officiate.

title: Jenny Chamoun, Marco Guanilo
description: Jenny Chamoun, a daughter of Georgette Chamoun and Said Chamoun of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and Marco Guanilo, a son of Rosa Suarez of Lima, Peru, and the late Victor Guanilo, were married Saturday. The Rev. Gabriel Adde, a priest of the Syriac Orthodox Church of Antioch, officiated at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Yael Buechler, Yair Kramer
description: Rabbi Yael Miriam Buechler, a daughter of Laura A. Buechler and Rabbi Howard R. Buechler of Dix Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Yair Kramer, a son of Deborah Kramer and Rabbi Michael Kramer. The brides father will officiate at the Dix Hills Jewish Center, where he is the rabbi, with the grooms father participating in the ceremony.

title: Allison Hayford, Grayson Fahrner
description: Allison Gordon Hayford and Grayson Dane Fahrner are to be married Sunday at St. Christopher Roman Catholic Church in Hobe Sound, Fla., by the Rev. Aidan Hynes, the churchs pastor.

title: Stephen Billick, Bruce Yolton
description: Dr. Stephen Bates Billick and David Bruce Yolton were married Tuesday evening at Lglise Franaise du St. Esprit, a French church in New York. The Rt. Rev. Mark S. Sisk, the former Episcopal bishop of New York, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Nigel J. Massey, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, taking part.

title: Meghan Keck, Matthew Thurlow
description: Meghan Allison Keck and Matthew David Thurlow were married Saturday at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington. The ceremony was led by Ray LaHood, the former federal transportation secretary, who officiated with permission from the District of Columbia.

title: Danielle Veilleux and Ryan Holland
description: Danielle Catherine Veilleux and Lt. Ryan Christopher Holland are to be married Sunday at the Church of St. Joseph in Newport, R.I. Jack Shea, a Roman Catholic deacon, is to perform the ceremony.

title: A Love Worth the Trip
description: Eve Nicole Hampton and Robert Anthony Pratt are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Yohanna Kinberg in the Great Hall at IslandWood, a nonprofit environmental learning center on Bainbridge Island, Wash.

title: Their Life Is a Laugh Riot
description: Casey Wilson and David Caspe are to be married Sunday at the Ojai Valley Inn in Ojai, Calif. Fletcher T. Wilson, the brides brother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: When City Met Country
description: Eleni Papademetriou Belisonzi and William John Fritze III are to be married Sunday at the St. George Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Philadelphia. The Rev. Spyridon C. Papademetriou, a Greek Orthodox priest and a grandfather of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Heat Show Glimpse of Their Best, and the Pacers Can Only Watch
description: MIAMI  Even after his team notched a crucial victory Tuesday to tie the Eastern Conference finals at 1-1, Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra did not feel as if his players had expressed their best collective identity.

title: Corrections: May 25, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Chinese Flybys Alarm Japan as Tensions Escalate
description: TOKYO  In an ominous display of growing territorial tensions between China and Japan, the Japanese Defense Ministry said Sunday that Chinese jet fighters had flown dangerously close to two of its reconnaissance planes in overlapping air defense zones claimed by both nations.

title: Pope, in Mideast, Invites Leaders to Meet on Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Pope Francis inserted himself directly into the collapsed Middle East peace process on Sunday, issuing an invitation to host the Israeli and Palestinian presidents for a prayer summit meeting at his apartment in the Vatican, in an overture that has again underscored the broad ambitions of his papacy.

title: Suspects in China Market Attack Are Identified
description: BEIJING  Law enforcement officials in the western region of Xinjiang have identified five men they said were responsible for an attack on an outdoor vegetable market on Thursday that killed 43 people and injured more than 90, many of them elderly shoppers.

title: Thai Military Moves to Stifle Dissent and Tighten Grip
description: BANGKOK  As protests demanding elections grew in Bangkok, Thailands military junta on Sunday warned Thais against opposing military rule, saying the process of democratization cannot be carried out right now.

title: When Hospital Systems Buy Health Insurers
description: Another hospital system wants to buy another health insurance company, and consumers may well wonder what this trend could mean for them.

title: Pro-European Businessman Claims Victory in Ukraine Presidential Vote
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Caught in a battle for influence between Russia and the West, Ukrainians elected Petro O. Poroshenko as president on Sunday, turning to a pro-European billionaire to lead them out of six months of turmoil.

title: Change Is Not Loss. It Only Feels That Way.
description: Of course, it was good news. Great news, in fact. What mother wouldnt be thrilled to learn that her son had won a generous fellowship to study for a semester in Greece? Travel expenses were thrown in too  for visits to Crete and Istanbul (When was he going to study?).

title: Trail of Violence in Isla Vista
description: Locations of violence in the shooting spree.

title: In Our Pages: May 26
description: 1914: Part Of Mr. Morgans Art Works To Be Sold

title: Acquitted of Murder, Rapper Is Convicted on Weapons Charge
description: An aspiring Virginia rapper, on trial for the 2007 killings of two men in part because of lyrics he wrote, was acquitted of the murder charges Friday. But the jury found him guilty on related weapons charges and recommended a sentence of 16 years.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49); 10 P.M. (21) THE NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT 2014  Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna host this 25th-anniversary broadcast from the West Lawn of the United States Capitol, which will commemorate the 70th anniversary of the World War II D-Day invasion on the beaches at Normandy. The American Idol winner Caleb Johnson will sing the national anthem. Danielle Bradbery, Megan Hilty, Jackie Evancho and Anthony Kearns will perform with the National Symphony Orchestra, above, conducted by Jack Everly. Other participants include former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, the actress Dianne Wiest, members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Army Herald Trumpets, the Army Chorus, the Soldiers Chorus of the United States Army Field Band, the Navy Band Sea Chanters and the Air Force Singing Sergeants.

title: The Manifesto of Elliot Rodger
description: Elliot Rodger, the 22-year-old who the police said killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, expressed his frustration in an autobiography.

title: A Role That Blurs the Line Between Drama and Reality
description: Grandma Angelina Nunzio weaves through Times Square in her wheelchair, pushed by a rubber-faced, spiky-haired groomsman and trailed by dozens of revelers on their way to a wedding reception. Like a queen with a scepter, she waves a cane with a dangling red plastic horn.

title: Obama Makes Surprise Trip to Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The last time President Obama visited Afghanistan, he came to sign a strategic partnership agreement with President Hamid Karzai.

title: Camping Inside the Indy 500
description: Some fans of the Indianapolis 500 are, for the first time, spending race weekend camped out in luxurious tents on the speedways infield.

title: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Solidaritys Foil, Dies at 90
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last Communist leader of Poland, who sent tanks to crush Solidaritys stirrings for democracy in 1981 and went on to preside over the death of the system that had nurtured him, died on Sunday in Warsaw. He was 90.

title: Fringe Groups Gain in European Voting
description: BRUSSELS  After four days of voting in a sprawling election with nearly 400 million eligible voters spread across 28 countries, fringe political groups pugnaciously hostile to the European Union scored dramatic gains in voting for the European Parliament and delivered a blow to the bruised but still dominant mainstream parties.

title: X-Men Thrives at Holiday Box Office
description: The strongly reviewed X-Men: Days of Future Past gave 20th Century Fox its best opening-weekend result since Avatar in 2009, ending a bumpy box office stretch for the studio and demonstrating the ongoing strength of superhero movies. But as strong as ticket sales were  Days of Future Past took in about $90.7 million over the first three days of the holiday weekend  Memorial Day 2014 will also be remembered for the crash of yet another Adam Sandler vehicle, Blended, which arrived with a dismal $14.2 million.

title: Venus Williams Subdues a Teenager Mentored by Williamss Ex-Rival
description: PARIS  Pick a number, any number, to best represent Venus Williamss first-round match against Belinda Bencic on Sunday at the French Open.

title: Gunman Covered Up Risks He Posed, Sheriff Says
description: The gunman involved in a killing spree in Southern California on Friday night was able to persuade sheriffs deputies who visited him in April that he was not a threat to himself or to others, the sheriff of Santa Barbara County, Bill Brown, said on Sunday morning.

title: My T-Shirt Told Me to Take a Chill Pill
description: My T-shirt tells me things.

title: Shots Grow Sharper, and the Coaches Deliver Them, Too
description: In two languages  and despite some moments of levity  Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault and his Montreal Canadiens counterpart, Michel Therrien, continued to trade jabs before Sunday nights Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Rosberg Wins Monaco Grand Prix
description: MONACO  The Monaco Grand Prix on Sunday was one of the most dramatic in recent years at a track known for its processional racing, with several accidents, two safety-car sessions, many overtaking maneuvers and eight car retirements.

title: Making Bachs Symphony for Solo Cello Look Easy
description: One of the many enjoyable aspects of concerts in small spaces like the Park Avenue Armorys recently renovated Board of Officers Room is the chance to enjoy the intimacy of the music making and to see the players up close. Watching Istvan Vardais slender fingers dance over the strings during his superb performance of Bachs Cello Suite No. 6 on Thursday added a fascinating visual component to the experience.

title: Daring Pass Produces Narrow Victory at Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Ryan Hunter-Reay nearly ran into the infield grass to pass Helio Castroneves with one lap to go and then held on to win by 0.06 of a second in the 98th Indianapolis 500 on Sunday.

title: Cannes Film Festival: Director Asia Argento on Giving Up Acting
description: CANNES  Its no surprise that many viewers here saw Misunderstood, a funny, free, tough-minded film by Asia Argento, through the lens of autobiography. Set in the 1980s, it centers on a 9-year-old, Aria (Giulia Salerno), the underloved daughter of two monstrous narcissists, an actor (Gabriel Garko) and a pianist (Charlotte Gainsbourg). Soon after it opens, the parents separate and Aria  Ms. Argentos original name  starts toggling between them even as they reject her, often brutally. Cast aside, she takes refuge in her love of a cat and in her imagination, which soars movingly both in her writing and in some wild fantasies.

title: A Young Soldier Feels Encouraged, Then Disillusioned, Singing All the While
description: The Saturday before Memorial Day and the centennial year of the outbreak of World War I seemed the ideal occasion to present Nancy Van de Vates All Quiet on the Western Front, a two-act opera based on the novel by Erich Maria Remarque.

title: Twists, Turns and Tall Tales on the Path to the Stanley Cup
description: War of attrition, war of wills. Thats what the Stanley Cup playoffs are  more intense, more physical and more prolonged than the playoffs of any other sport.

title: Bunny Yeager, Pinup Portraitist, Dies at 85
description: Bunny Yeager, a model-turned-photographer whose images of a scarcely clad Bettie Page, embodying feral sexuality and winsome navet all at once, helped propel Ms. Page to international stardom as a midcentury pinup queen, died on Sunday in North Miami, Fla. She was 85.

title: Surrounding a Love Triangle With Spectacle
description: During American Ballet Theaters spring season, with its panoply of full-length ballets, the business of telling a story can feel more or less urgent, depending on the night. There are works in which the narrative seizes you and sweeps you along, investing you in the fate of each character. And there are others in which the plot, if you could call it that, seems like mere scaffolding for spectacular dancing, an excuse for putting on an extravagant show.

title: Spotted in a Chic Sand Dune, a Well-Dressed Cos
description: LOS ANGELES  Somewhere, somehow, Gustavo Dudamel has become an opera conductor.

title: Campaigning for a Desk Job in Late Night
description: When Norm Macdonald was fired from his role anchoring Weekend Update on Saturday Night Live in early 1998, there was little recourse for his hard-core fans.
