description: NEW DELHI  After Narendra Modi was sworn in as Indias next prime minister, his new cabinet ministers took the oath of office.

title: She Wasnt So Ungrateful After All
description: Last November, the week of my mothers 86th birthday, her essay ran in this blog under the headline, A Very Ungrateful Old Lady. She explained  somewhat humorously, more than a little bitterly  that because of her very limited vision and her weakening, aging body, she was increasingly dependent on her children, and that it made her feel like a burden to be cared for and tended, even when the care came with love.

title: Look Back, in Danger
description: Peter van Agtmaels new book, Disco Night Sept 11, focuses on Americas involvement in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. It is a hauntingly beautiful work, which includes intimate diarylike texts by Mr. van Agtmael, a Magnum photographer. The book is published by Red Hook Editions, an imprint created by Mr. van Agtmael, Jason Eskenazi and Alan Chin.

title: How Has Exercise Changed Your Health, Your Body or Your Life?
description: The value of physical exercise is well known.

title: Politburo Vows to Improve Living Standards in Xinjiang
description: Days after a deadly blast in Xinjiang killed scores of people in a busy market, Chinas ruling Communist Party vowed to increase employment and educational opportunities in the region, in a sign that it recognizes that it must improve living standards for the regions ethnic Uighur minority to combat an increasingly violent separatist movement.

title: New York Today: August in May
description: Happy post-holiday Tuesday to you.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Its Not as Simple as Asking to Be Forgotten by Google
description: Mario Costeja, the Spanish lawyer who spurred the European Unions controversial right to be forgotten ruling  this month, was livid that a Google search for his name brought up a newspaper article from more than a decade ago about his debts, so he waged a war against Google.

title: China Said to Deport Models for Working Illegally
description: The Chinese authorities have deported scores of foreign models whom they detained earlier this month in Beijing on accusations that the models were working illegally, said a model who once worked in China.

title: The Writing Is on the Wall
description: SYDNEY, Australia  For decades it was thought that the reason street art was almost exclusively male was because men were more comfortable with peril; many sought it. After all, street art is notoriously dangerous, exhilarating and risky.

title: Daily Report: Technology Companies Push for Privacy Reforms in Washington
description: A law that allows the government to read email and cloud-stored data over six months old without a search warrant is under attack from technology companies, trade associations and lobbying groups, which are pressing Congress to tighten privacy protections.

title: China Pulls Cisco Into Dispute on Cyberspying
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Amid heightening tension between Washington and Beijing over online espionage, a Chinese state media outlet has sharply criticized the American network equipment maker Cisco Systems, saying it is complicit with United States cyberspying. Cisco denied the accusations.

title: Stop the Presses!
description: David Geary has worked as the late-night news editor for 10 of his 14 years at The Times. In that role, he has found himself responsible for calling the printing of the paper to a halt three times for major news events. He shares with Insider what a truly rare occurrence it is.

title: Want to Know How Your Business Is Really Doing? Ask Your Customers
description: A customer advisory board is a first cousin to a peer group; the difference is that the peers are all customers or clients of your company. The purpose of the board is to help you make your business better.

title: Fringe Parties Triumph in E.U. Elections
description: Voters across the European Union rejected traditional parties at the polls.

title: After Vote Upset, E.U. Grapples With Filling a Key Post
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders consigned a decision about who should lead the organizations most important agency to a potentially lengthy and acrimonious selection process on Tuesday, two days after populist upstart parties on the right and left surged in legislative elections.

title: Anger Over Coup Trumps Payouts to Thai Farmers
description: CHIANG YUEN, Thailand  They emerged flush with cash, the rice farmers who traveled to a state-owned bank here to retrieve the money that Thailands military junta had ordered they be paid.

title: Pilgrims Pride Makes a $6.4 Billion Proposal to Buy Hillshire Brands
description: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | When Hillshire Brands announced its intention this month to buy Pinnacle Foods for $4.3 billion, analysts and investors scratched their heads over the wisdom of the combination.

title: Bright Passages
description: Heres another small sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions.

title: Pfizer Lets AstraZeneca Go
description: Pfizer said on Monday that it had abandoned its bid for AstraZeneca, bringing an end to a monthslong takeover effort that would have created the worlds largest drug company, Jenny Anderson writes in DealBook. The decision  made on the final day for Pfizer to decide whether to abandon the deal  came in the wake of AstraZenecas rejection of what Pfizer called its final offer earlier this month. The cash-and-stock bid valued AstraZeneca at about $119 billion.

title: Chemical Weapons Inspectors Escape Attack in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An international team sent to investigate allegations that chlorine gas had been used as a weapon in Syrias civil war came under attack on Tuesday, forcing it to abort its mission to reach a village where numerous such attacks have been reported.

title: Pizza Man Meets Subway Terror
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pacific Equity Partners to Sell Peters of Australia to R&R Ice Cream
description: LONDON  The private equity firm Pacific Equity Partners said on Tuesday that it was selling the Peters Food Group, one of Australias oldest food brands, to R&R Ice Cream.

title: A Sporty Timepiece Inspired by Race-Car Oil Gauges
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Chopard.

title: Low-Cost Water Is Hard Sell in Delhi Colony
description: SAWDA GHEVRA, India  In October last year, the resettlement colony of Sawda Ghevra, tucked away in the northwestern outskirts of Indias capital, became the site of an urban experiment.

title: Allergan Seeks to Discredit Would-Be Buyer Valeant
description: Allergan has gone on the offensive, waging a public relations battle to discredit Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, which made a surprise offer to acquire Allergan last month and plans to raise its bid on Wednesday.

title: In Our Pages: May 28
description: 1939: Divers Toil to Salvage Sub

title: Whats the Best Bad Book Youve Ever Read?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and James Parker discuss supposedly terrible books that left a lasting impression.

title: Li Na Ousted in First Round of French Open
description: PARIS  On Monday night Stan Wawrinka, the mens singles champion at the Australian Open in January, lost in the first round at the French Open.

title: Another Reason to Consider Renting
description: Todays new house-price numbers are another reason for people in many markets to think seriously about renting. Home prices in the 20 largest metropolitan areas rose a whopping 12.4 percent between March 2013 and March 2014, according to the the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices. Thats clearly unsustainable, and its a reminder of how strongly home prices have rebounded in many markets.

title: When a Family Move Falls Through: Who Died and Made Me Not Boss?
description: Matt and I found out that income we were depending on  related to his books  fell through. We sat for hours going over the figures. A day earlier, we had asked a real estate agent in Rockland County, N.Y., to visit a property. Can you hear the noise from the Palisades Parkway? we wrote. The rent was a little higher than we had wanted, but it was on a cul-de-sac, and after apartment living I imagined the kids being in heaven there.

title: Podcast: Genetics of Beer
description: To understand why beer varies in taste, you need to know its yeasts.

title: Have You Seen Filming in New York City?
description: The film industry is increasingly turning to Brooklyn for production locations, expanding its reach into boroughs outside Manhattan. While more films have been shot in Manhattan than any other borough, half of the 29 television series produced in New York City last season were based in Brooklyn. The Good Wife, The Carrie Diaries, Blue Bloods and Hostages, to name a few, have embraced Brooklyn, as have recent feature films like The Amazing Spider-Man 2 and Cymbeline.

title: Pope Francis to Meet Victims of Sexual Abuse
description: ROME  Pope Francis says he plans to meet soon with abuse victims to underscore the Vaticans determination to move forward with zero tolerance toward clergy members accused of abusing minors.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Warren Billington joined the Sydney office of BrightTag in a new post, managing director for Australia, New Zealand and Southeast Asia. He had been managing director for Australia and New Zealand at Acxiom.

title: Bookshelf | A Surrealist Ode to a Radical Era in Furniture Design
description: Theres a photograph in 1968: Radical Italian Furniture  the new book (out May 31) by the artist and provocateur Maurizio Cattelan and his frequent collaborator, the photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari  of a woman dressed in pink trousers, standing on top of a desk. Crouched down expertly in heels, she stares blankly into the camera and urinates  quite deliberately, it seems  onto the piece of furniture beneath her.

title: Letterman to Moderate Seinfeld Discussion
description: Now that David Letterman is staring retirement in the eye, hes suddenly considering all kinds of opportunities he probably thought hed never agree to before  like appearing at public events.

title: Intersection | Fashion in Eastern Congo
description: In Goma, Sunday is the day that people dress up and Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-professed sapeur who designed his own unique tie skirt, is no exception.

title: Pharrell Williams and Spike Lee to Team Up at the Apollo
description: Pharrell Williamss debut at the Apollo Theater on June 3 is bound to be an occasion. After working behind the scenes for more than two decades as a songwriter and producer, the 41-year-old singer is having his moment, with a hit album (G I R L), a single that has been at or near the top of the chart for weeks (Happy), a Vivienne Westwood mountain hat that has been an unmistakable trademark ever since he turned up at the Grammy Awards wearing it in January, and a childrens book  plus an online interactive game  in the works.

title: Complaints and Warnings About Plan to Replenish Fire Islands Dunes
description: DAVIS PARK, N.Y.  As a longtime summer resident of Fire Island, Robert Spencer was in favor of the federal governments $170 million effort to replenish the dunes washed away during the ravages of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Rolling Stones Resume Performing in Norway Following Death of LWren Scott
description: Was there any doubt that the Rolling Stones would be rolling again? On Monday night, the Stones played the first concert of their European tour at the Telenor Arena in Oslo. It was the groups first concert since the death of the fashion designer LWren Scott, who was also the girlfriend of the bands singer, Mick Jagger. At the time of Ms. Scotts death, which was ruled a suicide, the Stones were about to begin a tour of Australia and New Zealand. Those concerts were postponed until October and November.

title: U.S. Troops to Leave Afghanistan by End of 2016
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, declaring that it was time to turn the page on a decade in which so much of our foreign policy was focused on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, announced on Tuesday that he planned to withdraw the last American troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2016.

title: Americans Varied Views of Global Warming and Climate Change
description: Anthony Leiserowitz, the director of theYale Project on Climate Change Communication, has distributed a note summarizing the findings of Whats In A Name? Global Warming vs Climate Change, an interesting new study of Americans perceptions of the two dominant shorthand phrases used to describe the building human influence on the climate system.

title: The Lessons of a Drug Makers Failed Deal
description: The failure of Pfizers $119 billion bid for AstraZeneca leaves the frustrated buyer no worse off. But AstraZeneca has much to prove. Some of its shareholders welcomed a possible takeover  and could again.

title: Simple Sour: Easy Summer Drinking
description: Almost by accident I discovered a perfect summer beer, light and refreshing yet packed with tangy flavor. Nursing a thirst on one of the first hot days of the season, I had stepped into the Pony Bar, which always has a great selection of American craft beers on tap at its two Manhattan locations. Examining the list, I was intrigued by Peekskill Brewerys Simple Sour.

title: Once Allies, Ex-Obama Aides Face Off in British Campaign
description: LONDON  David Axelrod stood on a stage in the Buckingham Room of the Labour Party headquarters this month, rallying British progressives who are hoping, and paying, for Barack Obamas message maven to help lead them back into power.

title: Hacker Who Helped Disrupt Cyberattacks Is Allowed to Walk Free
description: The New York man whose cooperation helped the authorities infiltrate the shadowy world of computer hacking and disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks on targets that included the United States military, courts and private companies was given a greatly reduced sentence on Tuesday of time served and allowed to walk free.

title: Q. and A. | Fujiko Nakaya on Making Sculptures Out of Fog
description: Over the last 40 years, the Japanese artist Fujiko Nakaya has been installing sculptures made of fog throughout the worldin fields and forests, in public plazas and atop parking garages, even in a park designed for kids. A new fog sculpture called Veil is on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., through Nov. 30. To create it, the 82-year-old artist spent nearly a year testing wind patterns and carefully calibrating the 800 mist-generating nozzles that are now installed across the landscape. The temporary sculpture alternately envelops and reveals Philip Johnsons iconic modernist structure, creating an effect that is at once romantic and contemporary.

title: So Many Pharmacies, Too Few Doctors
description: Most schools have a soccer field. Khin Nilar Myints school has a pharmacy.

title: Luggage Brand Unpacks New Theme and Ads
description: A line of high-end luggage is introducing a campaign that seeks to burnish its brand image by promoting its products as designed for travel in a real world of harried travelers, packed airplanes and fierce scrums for space in overhead bins.

title: Court Extends Curbs on the Death Penalty in a Florida Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday continued a trend to limit capital punishment, ruling that Floridas I.Q. score cutoff was too rigid to decide which mentally disabled individuals must be spared the death penalty.

title: Times Minute | Scene in East Ukraine
description: Andrew Roth reports from the eastern region of Ukraine as attacks continue between pro-Russian separatists and the Ukrainian military.

title: Times Minute | Scene in East Ukraine
description: In the Video

title: Massimo Vignelli, Visionary Designer Who Untangled the Subway, Dies at 83
description: Massimo Vignelli, an acclaimed graphic designer who gave shape to his spare, Modernist vision in book covers and shopping bags, furniture and corporate logos, even a church and a New York City subway map that enchanted aesthetes and baffled straphangers, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: ScienceTake | Tournament of the Ants
description: When the queen dies, female Indian jumping ants compete to reproduce.

title: The Ant Queen Is Dead. Let the Battles Begin.
description: The upheavals that take place in the highly social societies of insects would not be out of place in Game of Thrones. Queens die. New queens arise. Wars are fought. Slaves are taken.

title: Today in Small Business: The End of Cupcakes?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

title: Radu Florescu, Scholar Who Linked Dracula and Vlad the Impaler, Dies at 88
description: Have you ever seen Count Dracula and Vlad the Impaler in the same place at the same time?

title: China Defends Vietnam Boat Sinking
description: The spokesman for Chinas Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Qin Gang, defended the countrys actions in the sinking of a Vietnamese fishing boat in the disputed South China Sea.

title: At London's Heathrow, a New Terminal and an Uncertain Future
description: With the arrival of United Airlines flight 958 from Chicago, scheduled at 5:55 a.m. on June 4, Heathrow Airport will inaugurate a consumer-conscious Terminal 2, replacing another of its ramshackle hubs and giving the Star Alliance a modern, unified London presence that can compare with the home teams Terminal 5, devoted to British Airways. That is, unless UA918, taking off from Washington, D.C., gets better tailwinds and lands first.

title: Egypt Scrambles to Raise Turnout in Presidential Vote
description: CAIRO  After Egypts revolution three years ago, so many voters eager for democracy turned out for elections that officials had to scramble to accommodate the throngs.

title: S.E.C. Vows More Use of a Little-Used Tool
description: It is rare that the Securities and Exchange Commission announces a new approach to pursuing violations. Mary Jo White, the agencys chairwoman, did just that last week when she pointed to a seldom-used provision of the federal securities laws that the S.E.C. will employ against people who use others to do their bidding.

title: New Curbs Sought on the Personal Data Industry
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday called on Congress to protect consumers against the unchecked collection and sharing of their digital data  from websites visited to their marital status  by providing people with tools to view, suppress and fix their information.

title: Image of the Day: May 27
To Age Well, Walk
description: Regular exercise, including walking, significantly reduces the chance that a frail older person will become physically disabled, according to one of the largest and longest-running studies of its kind to date.

title: Kings Paying Back Blackhawks, Scoring Early and Often
description: LOS ANGELES  For the second straight year, the N.H.L.'s Western Conference finals have shifted to Chicago for a potentially decisive game. But this season the Los Angeles Kings have turned the tables to take a three-games-to-one lead on the Blackhawks, who eliminated them in five games last season.

title: Bens Cream Cheese: A Favorite Wrapped in Mystery
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  When the gastronomes of America dream their farm-raised, barrel-aged, artisanal dreams, they arent usually envisioning a dingy strip mall a short drive west of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Quick Turnaround for Struggling Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls will try to avoid a descent into a prolonged funk ahead of Major League Soccers two-week hiatus for the World Cup when they take their three-game losing streak to the Midwest to face the defending league champion, Sporting Kansas City (5-4-3, 18 points), Tuesday night.

title: Premiers of India and Pakistan Meet
description: The Pakistani prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, spoke after his meeting with Indias new prime minister, Narendra Modi, and the Indian foreign secretary discussed relations between the two countries.

title: Blaring the Horn for Food Trucks
description: LOS ANGELES  Sitting on his sofa in the Venice section of this city, Matt Geller let out an exasperated sigh as he spoke to a familiar official from the county health department. Food trucks represented by Mr. Gellers group, the Southern California Mobile Food Vendors Association, had been caught dumping waste water down storm drains. Thats absolutely disgusting, he said. A state, federal and county violation.

title: David Burke Fabrick Opens
description: Headliner

title: Robert Morse on His Big Mad Men Number
description: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sundays episode of Mad Men.

title: Clinton Signals New Memoir Will Be for a Wide Audience
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she wrote her memoir about her time as secretary of state for Americans and people everywhere who are trying to make sense of this rapidly changing world, and not for followers of Washingtons long-running soap opera.

title: Early Shaker Spirituals
description: Rehearsal footage of the Wooster Groups new show, which interprets historical songs and dances.

title: A Site That Matches Hotels With Prospective Guests
description: Interested in a partner that makes you feel special just for being yourself?

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 16
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. The Times is counting down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Globalizing Wisely
Art and Fashion Stars Toast a Pharrell-Curated Exhibition in Paris
description: WhoPharrell Williams was in Paris last night to fete the exhibition he curatedatthe new Emmanuel Perrotin space there: G I R L, inspired by Williamss new album of the same name. The multitasking man of the moment referred to the process of putting the exhibition together as another day of school for Pharrell Williams. The artists Daniel Arsham, Sophie Calle, Marina Abramovic, JR, Mr. and Laurent Grasso, who contributed works to the show, were on hand, as were the fashion-world luminaries Haider Ackermann, Peter Lindbergh, Alber Elbaz and Vanessa Bruno. The Korean superstar rapper G-Dragon arrived with his entourage, including the stylist Xin Yang, who will be launching his own line of too-cool-for-school mens wear in Paris next year.

title: The Bad Father, and Other Childhood Memories
description: Karl Ove Knausgaard, the powerful Norwegian novelist, is a weeper. Life gets to him. He cries all over the place in the first three volumes of his six-part autobiographical novel, My Struggle, especially in Books One and Three. His emotions are right on the surface.

title: Stepan Returns to Lineup And Has Immediate Effect
description: MONTREAL  Derek Stepan, wearing a full plexiglass face shield to protect his broken jaw, returned to practice with the Rangers on Tuesday morning at Bell Centre before Game 5 of the N.H.L.s Eastern Conference finals. Stepan then returned to the ice after the teams medical staff gave him the go-ahead to play in the game.

title: Unit Testing With Block Captures
description: We recently added read-only comments to our iPhone and iPad apps. We have started writing features that can be shared across our apps as CocoaPods, and the comments feature was an excellent candidate for a pod. Going forward, all of our iOS apps will be able to use this feature. We have been striving to add as much test coverage as we can to these pods, and the comments pod was no exception.

title: Kinsley, Greenwald and Government Secrets
description: Updated, 9:22 p.m. Michael Kinsleys review of Glenn Greenwalds new book, No Place to Hide hasnt even appeared in the printed Book Review yet  that wont happen until June 8  but its already infuriated a lot of people. After the review was published online last week, many commenters and readers (and Mr. Greenwald himself) attacked the review, which was not only negative about the book but also expressed a belief that many journalists find appalling: that news organizations should simply defer to the government when it comes to deciding what the public has a right to know about its secret activities.

title: Donmar Warehouse to Present All-Female Henry IV
description: Londons Donmar Warehouse, which attracted considerable attention with its all-female staging of Shakespeares Julius Caesar set in a high-security prison, will take a similar approach with Henry IV, the theater announced on Tuesday.

title: Now You See It, Then You Dont
description: When perturbed, Hippopodius hippopus will blanche milky white to make its presence known. It can take a half hour for all of the color to drain from the creatures skin.

title: A Breath of Fresh Air From the I.M.F.
description: Some lawmakers in Washington have been exhibiting symptoms of amnesia when it comes to the causes of the financial crisis, as David Firestone wrote last week in Taking Note. Thankfully, another senior Washington-based policy maker  the managing director of the International Monetary Fund  has not forgotten what caused the crisis and why we are still a long way from making sure it doesnt happen again.

title: A Designers Legacy
description: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.

title: Ukraine Faces Hurdles in Restoring Its Farming Legacy
description: ZIBOLKY, Ukraine  Like many of her neighbors in this old Soviet collective farm, Maria Onysko prefers to be paid in grain instead of cash for the modest plot of land she rents out.

title: Detroit Urged to Tear Down 40,000 Buildings
description: DETROIT  A task force convened by the Obama administration issued the most detailed study yet of blight in Detroit on Tuesday and recommended that the city spend at least $850 million to quickly tear down about 40,000 dilapidated buildings, demolish or restore tens of thousands more, and clear thousands of trash-packed lots.

title: Chilling Images of Gunman at Brussels Jewish Museum
description: The gunman who killed at least three people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels on Saturday has yet to be identified, but investigators have released images of the attacker, captured on security cameras before, during and after the shooting.

title: A Man Is Missing, and the Toll Is Ever-Present
description: The family in Gebo and the Shadow, Manoel de Oliveiras 2012 film adaptation of a play by the early-20th-century Portuguese writer Raul Brando, has been stuck in a limbo of anguish and tedium. A young man named Joo (Ricardo Trpa) has been missing for eight years, and every evening his father, Gebo (Michael Lonsdale), loses himself in ledgers and business documents. Joos mother (Claudia Cardinale) and wife (Leonor Silveira) bring Gebo coffee and pester him for news of the prodigal. Joos fate is ambiguous, which makes the grief and anxiety of his wife and mother all the more acute, and his fathers evasiveness all the more troubling.

title: When Assessing Investment Advice, Consider the Source
description: It can be very difficult to separate the good advice from the questionable and the questionable from the downright irresponsible. Unfortunately, good advice doesnt always walk around wearing a sign, but there are some red flags to help you avoid the so-called advice thats actually irresponsible.

title: 70 Years After the Date, Still So Much to Recall
description: The 70th anniversary of D-Day isnt until next week, but the commemorative programming has already begun. Two offerings in the next few days do a nice job of incorporating some of the few remaining veterans who took part and also remind us just how complex the invasion was.

title: New Ice Creams and Caramels, and Spreads With an Exotic Touch
description: To Indulge: Surprising Flavors From an Ice-Cream Fan

title: A Trump Makeover for Washingtons Old Post Office
description: WASHINGTON  The landmark 1899 post office tower on Pennsylvania Avenue  the second-tallest building in Washington  looked out of place in the Federal Triangle of neoclassical government buildings constructed mostly in the 1930s.

title: The Insider | Kris Kim, Founder of the Online Boutique La Garonne, on Her Offline Style
description: Too often, online clothes shopping is a task  find your size, pick a color, point, click, buy  rather than a pleasure. One notable exception, however, is La Garonne the thinking womans e-tailer, whose spare design, offhandedly cool styling and mussed-haired, makeup-free models make its minimalist merchandise come alive.

title: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: May 23-26, 2014
description: By now, we all know the details. On Friday night, 22-year-old Elliot Rodger stabbed his two roommates and one of their friends to death; shot and killed two women at a University of California, Santa Barbara sorority house; shot and killed a U.C.S.B. student at a deli; shot and wounded five people while driving the streets of Isla Vista, Calif., in his black BMW; and hit four people with his car before putting a bullet in his head.

title: With a Hashtag, Women Take On Our Fears for Our Daughters and Ourselves: #YesAllWomen
description: Because I never walk through a dark parking lot w/o a second thought, and soon I have to teach my daughters to fear. #YesAllWomen

title: Such a Charming Old Lady, but Hide Your Diamonds
description: Fleet-fingered jewel thief, compulsive liar, one-woman race crusader, parasite, parent, performer: Doris Payne could be identified in many ways (in addition to her multiple aliases). But she has also clearly had the time of her life. The Life & Crimes of Doris Payne, a rough-edged, brief documentary about this octogenarian career criminal, sketches a peppy and beguiling portrait of a convict whose defiant streak of independence has a way of outshining her wrongdoing.

title: First Lady Rebuts Effort to Weaken School-Lunch Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama turned uncharacteristically political on Tuesday, pushing back against a measure pending in the Republican-controlled House that would let some schools opt out of federal dietary standards for school lunches.

title: Crowdfunding a Documentary About Moondog, a Departed New York Institution
description: Long before the Naked Cowboy prowled Times Square, wearing nothing but jockey shorts, a broad-brimmed hat, decorated boots, and a guitar, visitors to New York were often startled by a more darkly imposing apparition  a tall, weatherworn figure with long salt-and-pepper hair that flowed from under a Viking helmet, and who stood nearly stone still at the corner of Sixth Avenue and 54th Street holding a hefty spear.

title: In Minneapolis, a Blueprint for a Bustling Downtown
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The building of a nearly $1 billion Minnesota Vikings stadium has become the impetus for resuscitating a barren stretch of this citys downtown that Gov. Mark Dayton called a concrete oasis.

title: Who Wants Free Love Anyway?
description: When Misty Terrell turned 28, she happened to see an ad for a special deal on the dating site eHarmony and decided it was time to get serious about her love life. Terrell felt pretty optimistic. The site claims responsibility for 542 marriages a day through its scientific approach to finding soul mates: an exhaustive questionnaire, the trademarked 29 dimensions of compatibility algorithm and its clinical labs where psychologists spend hours analyzing couple interactions. For this sort of comprehensive matchmaking, the company charges $60 a month, which is far more than most dating sites, but perhaps something of a bargain when it comes to finding true love. Terrell signed up to receive five potential matches a day for six months.

title: Walking to Age Well
description: We all know that exercise is good for us, regardless of age. Now a new study, one of the largest and most rigorous to date, proves it. As Gretchen Reynolds writes in this weeks Phys Ed column:

title: Everything New Is Old Again
description: Artisanal gefilte fish. Slow-fermented bagels. Organic chopped liver. Sustainable schmaltz.

title: A Test for Mets Hitters From the Fans
description: It is not easy being a Mets fan  in fact, it often makes little sense at all. Consider that the team collapsed in September 2007, then, for good measure, did the same thing in 2008, each time being eliminated at home on the final day of the season.

title: Detroit Blight Removal Task Force Plan
description: The Task Forces report is a detailed accounting of the extent of Detroits blight, including recommendations for how to both clear up the decay and prevent it from happening again.

title: Cosmic Sounds, Divine Setting
description: From a critical perspective, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine is no place to hear a full orchestra perform. For all its architectural splendor, this beloved cathedral has almost impossible acoustics for symphonic music, with an excess of reverberation and echo.

title: Elections Put Europes Centrists on Notice
description: The surprise in elections for the European Parliament over the weekend wasnt that candidates of the far right and far left made huge gains. The surprise was that it took this long.

title: Can a Hotel Boycott Change a Sultans Policy?
description: There are few hotels as fundamental to a place as the Beverly Hills Hotel. The pink palace, around which the town grew and celebrities flocked, is 102 years old, two years older than the city itself.

title: Former Goldman Trader Tourre Says He Will Not Appeal
description: Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader found liable for defrauding investors in a soured mortgage deal, will not appeal his case to a higher court.

title: How Americans View the Afghan War
description: Polling suggests that most Americans would support the plan President Obama announced Tuesday to keep some United States forces in Afghanistan for a period even as he withdraws most combat troops.

title: Obama Announces New Afghanistan Plan
description: The president said the United States planned to leave 9,800 troops in Afghanistan after 2014 and complete the withdrawal of all combat troops by the end of 2016.

title: Pimco Rehires a Former Top Executive
description: Updated, 6:32 p.m. | Before he resigned as chief executive of Pimco, Mohamed A. El-Erian lent the asset management firm a measure of gravitas, opining frequently on the economic issues of the day.

title: Red Sox Announcers Son Gets Life Term After Admitting to Girlfriends Murder
description: BOSTON  Wearing a gray sweatshirt and with a relaxed demeanor, Jared Remy, the son of a popular Red Sox broadcaster and former player, went to court on Tuesday to change his plea to guilty in the stabbing death of his girlfriend, Jennifer Martel.

title: With a Farm in the Wings
description: Gather around the old Victrola, kids. Grandpa wants to tell you a story about wealth, power, real estate, pornography, carrots and a sweet-faced dairy cow named Narcissa.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Stronger Brains, Weaker Bodies
description: All animals do the same thing to the food they eat  they break it down to extract fuel and building blocks for growing new tissue. But the metabolism of one species may be profoundly different from anothers. A sloth will generate just enough energy to hang from a tree, for example, while some birds can convert their food into a flight from Alaska to New Zealand.

title: Obama Hosts White House Science Fair
description: The president celebrated the student winners of a range of science, technology, engineering and math competitions from across the nation.

title: Brunch, From Sleepy to Showoff
description: Youve seen them on weekend mornings, the long lines of brunchgoers on sidewalks everywhere  the exhausted parents with small children, bleary-eyed late-nighters ready for a hair of the dog, hollandaise addicts. Elsewhere, still in pajamas, are the brunch skeptics  namely anyone who has ever worked an 8 a.m. brunch shift and those who are philosophically opposed to waiting an hour for a Belgian waffle.

title: Share Your Experience With Veterans Affairs Health Care
description: New York Times journalists would like to hear from veterans about their experiences with health care at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics

title: Fog Sculpture at the Glass House
description: Fujiko Nakayas fog sculpture Veil, which is generated by 800 mist-generating nozzles installed across the landscape, is on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., till Nov. 30.

title: Obama Meets Scientists, One Age 6
description: WASHINGTON  A teenage girl was inspired after dropping her cellphone to create concussion-reducing cushions for football helmets. A team of Girl Scout Brownies designed a bridge that could withstand flooding. And an adolescent boy in a suit and tie told President Obama about his pending patents.

title: 2014 Sasquatch! Festival
description: Scenes from the 2014 Sasquatch! Festival diary of Holly Andres.

title: Retiring a Four-Wheeled Combat Survivor
description: The Timess Jerusalem bureau lost a loyal if not loved member last month: an armored Mitsubishi Pajero.

title: Weekly News Quiz | May 19-27, 2014
description: How closely did you follow the news this week? Fill in the blanks below to test yourself.

title: How Careless of Goya to Lose His Head
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In the musical presentations of the Spoleto Festival USA this year, its Minimalism to the max.

title: BookExpo Keeps It Breezy
description: For enthusiasts of The Hunger Games, there will be a trivia quiz on the intricate details of Katniss Everdeens dystopian world. Tina Fey and Jason Bateman will be there to discuss turning the humorous best seller This Is Where I Leave You into a humorous movie. The best 10-word love story will win a prize. And there will be a book-swapping/speed-dating cocktail hour. (Participants are advised to bring a favorite book and write their name and phone number inside.)

title: A Designers Legacy
description: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.

title: Fundrise, a Crowdfunding Website, Raises $31 Million
description: Fundrise, a website that aims to draw in a broad range of investors to finance commercial real estate deals, has raised more than $31 million in its first round of funding from a group of prominent technology, real estate and other backers.

title: Holder of a Cabinet Position
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Im worried about Tim Croce. We havent seen him since January, and now that hes back hes kvetching up a storm about himself. Were going to have to help him with his self-esteem.

title: A Vigilante and a Techie, Too
description: To the pantheon of lawbreaking folk heroes in American culture, alongside the mobster and the Wild West gunslinger, we can add the computer hacker. Matthew Brodericks character in the 1983 movie WarGames may have been Patient Zero for this strain, followed by figures from William Gibsons cyberpunk novels, The Matrix and a parade of forgettable 1990s Hollywood thrillers.

title: As Information Flows, S.E.C. Faces Difficulty Bottling It Up
description: On Wall Street, information is the most valuable commodity, to quote a line from the 1987 movie Wall Street.

title: African Dance, Rhythms and Folksy Beats, Pitched to Fill a Basket
description: No matter the lineup at DanceAfrica, one performer always delivers: Charles (known as Chuck) Davis, the revered and beloved master of ceremonies, who founded the festival in 1977 and who, it was recently announced, will step down as director in 2016. Can anyone charm and command a crowd as he does? On Monday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Howard Gilman Opera House, even his no flash photography announcement drew wild cheers from the audience. His successor, Abdel R. Salaam, has a tough act to follow.

title: Some Sparkle in the Noir
description: Fargo, on FX, is Billy Bob Thorntons first television series in two decades. Crossbones, beginning on Friday on NBC, is John Malkovichs first TV show, period (not counting mini-series). Looking for a third movie star to complete the trend? Id nominate the excellent, underrated actress Thandie Newton, beginning the second season of Rogue on Wednesday night on DirecTV.

title: White House Orders Review After Spys Name Is Revealed
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has ordered a review of how officials accidentally revealed the name of the Central Intelligence Agencys top spy in Afghanistan during President Obamas surprise trip to the country over the weekend.

title: Jazz Enigma of the 60s Has an Encore
description: In the jazz of the 1960s, Eric Dolphy was an original: a hero to some, but also a mystery, a virtuosic improviser searching for ways of expression outside of common practice. He died of an undiagnosed diabetic condition in Berlin in June 1964, at 36, old enough to consolidate his experience and wisdom but perhaps too young to settle his reputation, which had by then taken some knocks from those who found his music abstract or abrasive.

title: To Get Snowden Interview, NBC News Relied on Secrecy
description: Brian Williams met Edward J. Snowden in the Kempinski Hotel in Moscow last week after months of negotiations between NBC News and intermediaries for Mr. Snowden.

title: Should the Government Grade Colleges?
Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Thailand, Israel and Washington.

title: Joseph A. McMillan Jr.
description: Mr. McMillan, 42, is a founder and the chief executive and chairman of DDG, an investment, architecture, construction and development firm that focuses mainly on residential and mixed-use projects. Past developments include the 41 Bond and 345meatpacking condominiums; DDG is currently working on several other downtown projects, among them 325 West Broadway, a former chocolate factory, and 100 Franklin Street.

title: Prison Terms in Iran Hint of New Reins on Internet
description: Escalating their assault on Internet access, the judicial authorities in Iran have sentenced eight Facebook users to prison terms as long as 20 years and have ordered Mark Zuckerberg, the multibillionaire American founder of Facebook, to testify in a lawsuit that contends the companys social media applications violate privacy, Iranian news sites reported on Tuesday.

title: The Sterlings Are Going in Opposite Directions
description: Rochelle Sterling continued to entertain offers from potential buyers of the Los Angeles Clippers on Tuesday as her husband, Donald, sent the N.B.A. a 32-page response in which he strongly objected to charges that he had engaged in conduct that damaged the league and its partners.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Pregnant Pakistani Woman Is Beaten to Death by Her Family
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A pregnant Pakistani woman was beaten to death by her family outside a courthouse in the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday because she had defied their wishes and married the man of her choice, police officials said.

title: Army Ousts Commander of Hospital After Deaths
description: The Army ousted the commander of one of its busiest hospitals and suspended three top deputies on Tuesday after two patients in their 20s unexpectedly died in the past 10 days, shortly after they sought treatment at the hospitals emergency room.

title: Bringing the Nigerian Schoolgirls Into View
description: The plight of the kidnapped girls has eclipsed a basic question: Who are these young women? A photographer discovered clues in their belongings.

title: Justices Bar Michigan From Suing Tribe Over Casino
description: WASHINGTON  Michigan may not sue an Indian tribe to shut down a casino opened far from the tribes reservation, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 5-to-4 decision.

title: Auction Ends Heated Battle at Philadelphia Newspapers
description: The legal battle over the ownership of The Philadelphia Inquirer ended on Tuesday when its minority owners, Lewis Katz and Gerry Lenfest, prevailed in an auction for the newspaper.

title: World Bank Revamping Is Rattling Employees
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank, a famously bureaucratic institution, is undergoing its first restructuring in nearly two decades. The overhaul is intended to keep it relevant at a time when even the poorest countries can easily tap the global capital markets, but with just weeks to go, the process has turned into what several staff members described as a nightmare, stalling their work and sapping morale.

title: Lawyer on Hackers Reduced Sentence
description: Peggy Cross-Goldenberg, the lawyer for the hacker Hector Xavier Monsegur, discussed her client after he was given a reduced sentence of time served.

title: Dissenters in Egypt Mock Election Turmoil
description: With dissent in the streets effectively banned by law, Egyptians appeared to register their lack of enthusiasm with the presidential election organized by the military-backed government by staying away from the polls in large numbers, some spoiling their ballots or mocking the process online.

title: Climate Change Doomed the Ancients
description: THIS month, a report issued by a prominent military advisory board concluded that climate change posed a serious threat to Americas national security.

title: Rebelling Against Abuse, Afghan Women See Signs of Change
description: PUL-I-KUMRI, Afghanistan  Zahra said a neighbor raped her in her home on Friday. It was the most humiliating event in her unremittingly painful life, and the next day she begged her husband, Najibullah, to move their family so the man could not attack her again. He refused.

title: Why Cant Doctors Identify Killers?
description: MASS killers like Elliot Rodger teach society all the wrong lessons about the connection between violence, mental illness and guns  and what we should do about it. One of the biggest misconceptions, pushed by our commentators and politicians, is that we can prevent these tragedies if we improve our mental health care system. It is a comforting notion, but nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Lawyers for Immigrant Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Rampage in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyes on the China-Russia Natural Gas Linkup
description: To the Editor:

title: A Girl Gets Mothers to Start Biking Again
description: WHILE women have been flocking to spin classes in recent years, they have shown less enthusiasm for bicycles that actually go somewhere.

title: When the Justices Alter the Language of a Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin Blinked
description: There was a moment at the height of the Cuban missile crisis in October 1962 when Soviet ships approached to within just a few miles of a U.S. naval blockade and then, at the last minute, turned back  prompting then-Secretary of State Dean Rusk to utter one of the most famous lines from the Cold War: Were eyeball to eyeball, and I think the other fellow just blinked.

title: Tiananmen Square Anniversary Prompts Campaign of Silence
description: BEIJING  Even by the standards of the clampdowns that routinely mark politically sensitive dates in China, the approach this year to June 4, the anniversary of the day in 1989 when soldiers brutally ended student-led protests in Tiananmen Square, has been particularly severe.

title: Foods Big-Picture Guy
description: I wish Olivier de Schutter had the power to match the acuity of his analysis, but its great that weve had an advocate whose vision is as broad as that of the corporations who have for the last 50 years determined global food policy. Since 2008, the human rights lawyer has had the title of United Nations special rapporteur on the right to food. (His second three-year term ends this week.) This is obviously not a genius marketing title and, even worse, the position carries no real power.

title: The Shrinking Death Penalty
description: Twelve years after it banned the execution of intellectually disabled people, the Supreme Court on Tuesday clarified and thus reaffirmed the essence of its ruling by striking down a Florida law requiring that a defendant claiming that condition show an I.Q. score of 70 or below.

title: Trapped in Afghanistan
description: For years, the American people have been asking when the war in Afghanistan will end. On Tuesday, President Obama said not for at least two and a half more years.

title: As Congress Sleeps, More People Die
description: Richard Martinez has a message for the politicians who have been calling to express condolences on the death of his son, Christopher Michaels-Martinez, in the massacre of six people in Isla Vista, Calif., on Friday: I dont care about your sympathy, he said. Get to work and do something.

title: 12 Years Later, a Fund Manager Gets to Give His Side
description: For 12 years, Nelson Obus, a hedge fund manager accused of insider trading, has been waiting  and waiting  to defend himself.

title: Concentrated Markets Take Big Toll on Economy
description: Nobody believes AT&Ts $48 billion shot at buying DirecTV will be the last attempt by the nations communications leviathans to get even bigger. Verizon will inevitably try to bulk up in response to Comcasts $45 billion grab for Time Warner Cable. Sprint, the No. 3 wireless carrier, is lusting for No. 4 T-Mobile.

title: With July 4th Fireworks Leaving the Hudson, Jersey Citys Show Will Return
description: Macys decision to move its Fourth of July fireworks show off the Hudson River this year will not leave residents of northern New Jersey in the dark on that holiday, Jersey Citys mayor said on Tuesday.

title: Eyes on Stats, Players Hire Help to Crunch Them
description: MIAMI  For many players, a professional entourage is as much a part of the N.B.A. lifestyle as yacht-size wristwatches.

title: For Middle East, Region of Religious Conflict, Pope Suggests a Respite in Prayer
description: JERUSALEM  Pope Francis returned home from his three-day sojourn in the Holy Land with the typical bag of ceremonial gifts, including, from the children of Bethlehems refugee camps, a mock-up of an identification card in the name of Jesus that lists family members as Mohandas K. Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat and Martin Luther King Jr. But the pope also carried with him a promise from the Israeli and Palestinian presidents to come soon to the Vatican for a joint peace prayer, an unprecedented effort to lend a spiritual lift to a desperate political stalemate.

title: Home Prices Start Easing, to the Relief of Experts
description: A steep gain in home prices in many markets that helped lift millions of Americans out of the red on their mortgages is now markedly slowing, with new data from the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller national home price index on Tuesday showing that the annual growth in prices had eased in March to 10.3 percent, from the previous years increase of 11.4 percent.

title: The Value of College: Its Not Just Correlation
description: Comparing the earnings of college graduates and nongraduates is an imperfect way of measuring the value of a degree, as I noted in my Tuesday column. Hypothetically, college graduates could earn more because theyre innately smarter  and would have earned just as much if they had never attended college or even any school. As a reader named Shawn posted in the comments section of the column, The useful comparison is not between those who do and do not attend college but, rather, between equally intelligent students who do and do not choose to attend college.

title: Nigeria Denies Formal Talks on Captive Schoolgirls
description: DAKAR, Senegal  With reports swirling in the Nigerian media of a possible negotiation to free hundreds of schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamist extremists, and the countrys top armed forces commander ruling out force to do so, the governments chief spokesman again denied Tuesday that any formal, official talks were underway with the extremist group Boko Haram.

title: After California Attack That Killed 6 Students, Classmates Pause and Seek Closure
description: ISLA VISTA, Calif.  Across the street from the IV Deli Mart, one of the places where Elliot O. Rodger opened fire on Friday night before killing himself, people wrote mournful and inspiring messages in chalk on Tuesday. On the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, students stood by a bike path holding Free Hugs signs and shouting Have a great day! to cyclists and skateboarders. Flags at all 10 University of California campuses remained lowered.

title: 21 Die in Fire at Hospital in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A fire broke out at a hospital annex in southwestern South Korea early Wednesday, killing 21 people and injuring seven others and further rattling a country still traumatized by a recent ferry disaster.

title: Finding Some Solace, if Not a Victory
description: PARIS  If love is cruel, how about sport?

title: De Blasios Latest Break With His Predecessors: Ending a Ban on Ferrets
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio prides himself on confronting New Yorks knottiest civic problems, such as expanding classroom time for preschoolers and lowering the cost of urban housing.

title: Win by Far-Right Party Rattles the French Establishment
description: PARIS  The stark victory of Frances far-right National Front in the European Parliament elections has badly rattled the countrys political establishment, eroding support for President Franois Hollandes policies within his own Socialist Party and calling into question whether France was in danger of losing its place alongside Germany at the center of the European stage.

title: Fringe Group in Britain Forces Others to Listen
description: LONDON  Nigel Farage boasts that his United Kingdom Independence Party is now the fox in the Westminster henhouse. But in reality, without a single seat in Parliament, he is still prowling the boundaries of the farm.

title: Giulianis Take on Ferrets
description: Voices were raised on both sides in 1999 when David J. Guthartz, the executive president of New York Ferrets Rights Advocacy, called into Mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis radio show.

title: Lieutenant Governor Loses Texas Runoff as Tea Party Holds Sway
description: HOUSTON  Dan Patrick, a state senator who has taken outspoken stands against abortion, same-sex marriage and illegal immigration, won a Republican runoff for lieutenant governor on Tuesday, handily defeating David Dewhurst, the longtime incumbent, in a race that illustrated the continuing power of the Tea Party in Texas.

title: Columbia Baseball Has Repeating Theme: Team
description: Columbia has achieved success recently by relying on cornerstones of any good baseball team: pitching and defense. But it has also put an emphasis on something else: character over athleticism.

title: Artist or Gang Leader? Rappers Trial Begins
description: To his fans and friends, the rapper known as Ra Diggs was a hero from the Brooklyn projects, a charismatic artist whose music videos chronicled life there.

title: Etchings at 9/11 Memorial Are Called Both Anguished Tributes and Vandalism
description: The panels at the National September 11 Memorial containing the victims names must constantly be inspected for graffiti scratched into the bronze surfaces, a memorial spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: The Google Car Takes a Step Away From Boring
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Not so boring?

title: Googles Next Phase in Driverless Cars: No Steering Wheel or Brake Pedals
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Humans might be the one problem Google cant solve.

title: Googles Video of Its Self-Driving Car
description: The company has begun building a fleet of experimental electric-powered vehicles that cant be driven by people and are summoned with a smartphone app.

title: Double-Parking Is Exception on Liability in Rear-End Crashes, Judge Says
description: From huge potholes to a taxi door suddenly swinging open into traffic, New York City drivers must routinely avoid all manner of unexpected events and hazards.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 27, 2014
In Schools Where Sports May Be Most Vital, New York City Offers Least Help
description: The pitch screamed through the muggy late-afternoon heat of Rainey Park in the Bronx, and the batter, an infielder with International Community High School, just managed to tip it so that the ball flew over the backstop, in the opposite direction of the field. A toddler, legs churning, grabbed the ball and handed it to Stanley Hernandez, an assistant coach. He gave the boy a big smile.

title: Retired Officer Fatally Shoots Armed Assailant During Carjacking Attempt
description: A retired New York City police officer shot and killed an armed 18-year-old who tried to rob him and steal his car early Tuesday in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: How to Catch a Bike Thief
description: Bike theft is a serious problem in San Francisco. Now the police are using every tool they have, including GPS trackers in bikes, social media and thousands of stickers that ask thieves a question.

title: Police Use High-Tech Lures to Reel in Bike Thieves
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Officer Matt Friedman fights crime with modern tools: Twitter, which he uses to publicize pictures of suspects and convicted criminals, and a GPS device, which he uses to track down stolen property.

title: Amid Split on Bank Case, U.S. Seeks a Middle Path
description: WASHINGTON  Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. faced a legal and bureaucratic dilemma this year: Obama administration officials could not agree about what he should tell the Supreme Court about a lawsuit in which American victims of terrorist attacks in Israel are suing Arab Bank, the largest financial institution in Jordan.

title: Libya: State Dept. Urges Americans to Leave
description: The State Department issued a travel warningon Tuesdayurging Americans against traveling to Libya and asking those already there to leave. The department cited the continuing fighting among militias, including an attack on the Parliament building 10 days ago; the Tripoli governments inability to stop the violence; and repeated threats against American interests. The United States Embassy, the State Department said, is only able to offer very limited emergency services to U.S. citizens in Libya.

title: South Sudan: U.N. Shifts Focus of Its Mandate
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed a resolution on Tuesday that shifts its peacekeeping operations in South Sudan away from nation-building and toward safeguarding civilians threatened by ethnic violence and political instability. The resolution, which extended the mission until Nov. 30, retains its size but authorizes all necessary means to protect civilians, to police rights abuses, to ensure aid delivery and to enforce cease-fires among rival factions in the country, which became independent in 2011. Thousands have been killed, and more than 1.3 million people have fled their homes since December, when fighting erupted between loyalists to President Salva Kiir, an ethnic Dinka, and his former vice president, Riek Machar, a Nuer. A recent United Nations report described atrocities on a massive scale by both sides. The United Nations refugee agency reported Tuesday that 76,000 South Sudanese had fled fighting since the latest cease-fire was signed on May 9.

title: Sierra Leone: Ebola Virus Spreads From Guinea
description: West Africas Ebola outbreak appears to have spread to Sierra Leone, the World Health Organization said Monday. One death in a village near the border with Guinea has been confirmed by a laboratory as Ebola, and four other deaths are considered suspect. Sierra Leone health officials told the Voice of America that the confirmed case was a woman who had just returned from the funeral of an Ebola victim in Guinea; the suspect cases included her relatives. The outbreak began in Guinea in March and spread to Liberia; of the 259 cases reported to the W.H.O., 175 have been fatal.

title: Defining Blight in Detroit
description: More than a fifth of Detroits properties are plagued with blight, according to a report by the Blight Removal Task Force.

title: Holder Hints Reporter May Be Spared Jail in Leak
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. hinted Tuesday that the Justice Department might choose not to jail a New York Times reporter for defying a subpoena forcing him to discuss his confidential sources  even as the Obama administration continues to pursue the right to do so before the Supreme Court.

title: New York Assembly Passes Medical Marijuana Bill
description: ALBANY  For the fifth time in seven years, the State Assembly on Tuesday passed a bill legalizing medical marijuana, backing a measure that would far surpass a program Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this year.

title: Questioned About Body, Townsend Rises and Inspires
description: PARIS  Taylor Townsend had found her footing on far slipperier surfaces than the red clay of Court 16 at Roland Garros.

title: Obama Asks Homeland Security Secretary to Delay Deportation Review
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has directed the secretary of Homeland Security to delay until after the summer a deportation enforcement review that officials feared would anger House Republicans and doom any lingering hopes for an immigration overhaul in Congress this year, officials said Tuesday night.

title: Matthew Saad Muhammad, Boxing Champion, Is Dead
description: Matthew Saad Muhammad, a former boxing champion known for his bruising style whose rags-to-riches-to-rags life story began in abandonment and nearly ended in homelessness, died on Sunday in Philadelphia, where for many years he had been a local hero. He was thought to be 59.

title: Should Ferrets be Allowed as Pets?
description: In a memo from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, health officials weighed the pluses and minuses of allowing ferrets to be kept as pets.

title: In Early Voting, Jeter Is on Pace to Start All-Star Game for Ninth Time
description: ST. LOUIS  Derek Jeter is a virtual certainty to make his 14th American League All-Star team in July, whether through fan voting or a selection to the team by the A.L. manager, John Farrell. After the first vote tabulation announced by Major League Baseball, Jeter is on his way to earning the spot through voting by fans who recognize this is his last season.

title: Fargo Recap: Fools Paradise
description: Well, Molly did survive. Granted, Deputy Gus Grimly, the haphazard cop and postman wannabe, fired one shot as Mollys backup, into the blizzard swirling all around them during last weeks gun battle.

title: Justices, in 2 Cases, Side With Law Enforcement Officials
description: WASHINGTON  In a pair of unanimous decisions favoring law enforcement officials, the Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled for Arkansas police officers who had used deadly force to end a high-speed chase and for Secret Service agents who had moved protesters away from President George W. Bush.

title: Chased Back to the Garden
description: MONTREAL  There was no celebration for the Rangers on Tuesday night, no triumphant passage to the Stanley Cup finals. Instead, there was nastiness, chaotic defense and uncharacteristically flawed goaltending, with Henrik Lundqvist chased from the nets by a deluge of Montreal goals and with his substitute, Cam Talbot, faring little better.

title: Times Minute | A U.S. Diplomacy Reboot
description: The White House correspondent Mark Landler on what to watch for as President Obama prepares to lay out foreign policy changes at West Points graduation ceremony.

title: Times Minute | A U.S. Diplomacy Reboot
description: In the Video

title: Stepan Roars Into Fray With Broken Jaw and Comes Away With Two Goals
description: MONTREAL  Derek Stepan can eat only soft food, and he has been taking painkilling medication. But after the singing of the national anthems Tuesday night, he skated to the Rangers bench, placed his gloves on the boards and put on the unwieldy contraption that would allow him to play.

title: Angelinas Makeup Artist on How to Use the New Cheekbone-Contouring Products
description: Last month, the British makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury visited the States to introduce her beauty line, which arrives here later this year, and proudly present her Filmstar Bronze & Glow product to a small group of beauty editors. Its a miracle-working compact designed to make the roundest of facest appear toned, and is filled with two kinds of powder: a darker one, which creates depth when brushed into the hollows of the cheeks, and a lighter, shimmery one, which makes the cheekbones rise and pop. These nature-defying contouring and highlighting products have cropped up on beauty counters everywhere in recent months, like the Nars Contour Blush palettes, introduced back in March, and the MAC Maleficent Sculpting Powder, unveiled earlier this month as part of the brands new collection inspired by the Disney blockbuster of the same name, which stars Angelina Jolie and hits theaters this Friday.

title: Warm, Versatile Minimalism from Calvin Kleins Latest Furniture Collection
description: Calvin Klein is known for its sleek, streamlined apparel. And since 1995, when the company first opened its flagship store designed by the architect John Pawson, the brand has offered home furnishings with a similar aesthetic. But you dont have to live in a temple of minimalism to enjoy its latest furniture collection. Individually or together, the brass-plated Radiant accent table ($2,000) and the Facet folding stool made of natural oak ($1,100) possess a warmth and materiality that will find a place in almost any home.

title: Word of the Day | inadvertently
description: inadvertently \in-ad-vrt-tnt-le\ adverb

title: Some Calming News Caps a Tumultuous 24 Hours for the Mets
description: Around 5 p.m. Tuesday, Sandy Alderson finally had some good news to deliver about the Mets. A magnetic resonance imaging exam for Noah Syndergaard came back clean, meaning Syndergaard, the organizations top pitching prospect, was not in any danger of needing surgery on his sore right arm. A little bit of rest would presumably solve the problem.

title: Mets Hammer Out a Victory
description: The Mets offense did just enough Tuesday to get the team its third win in the last eight games, rapping out four extra-base hits to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-2, at Citi Field.

title: Phelpss Return Home Is Short of Sweet as Yankees Stumble in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  When David Phelps walked to the outfield to begin preparing for his first start against his hometown team, the club he adored in his youth, he squatted down and took a moment to absorb his surroundings.

title: Amazon Defends Itself in Dispute, Suggests Hachette Customers Go Elsewhere
description: Amazon issued a statement late Tuesday defending its right to discourage customers from buying books from Hachette, one of the countrys biggest publishers.

title: A Fiery Duncan Cannot Rescue the Spurs
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  As the San Antonio Spurs have won admirers and championships over the years, one of their defining characteristics has been the monochromatic mien of Tim Duncan.

title: Intense Holiday Retires Prior to Belmont
description: Intense Holiday, who finished 12th in the Kentucky Derby on May 3 and was being pointed toward the Belmont Stakes on June 7, was retired from racing Tuesday, the owner Starlight Racing said. The horse had surgery May 26 for a nondisplaced condylar fracture to his right front leg, which he sustained while training at Belmont Park on Sunday. The colt had two wins in nine starts, earning $551,900, including a second in the Louisiana Derby.

title: Corrections: May 28, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) INSIDE THE MIND OF EDWARD SNOWDEN In this NBC News exclusive, Brian Williams travels to Moscow to conduct the first interview for American television with Mr. Snowden (above right, with Mr. Williams), the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked documents about the governments surveillance. Mr. Williams then speaks with Mr. Snowden together with Glenn Greenwald, the journalist and lawyer who published articles based on those documents in The Guardian, his employer at the time.

title: A Conversation With: Yogendra Yadav, a Leader of the Aam Aadmi Party
description: A scholar of the science of elections, Yogendra Yadav, 50, has become one of the most prominent faces of the Aam Aadmi Party, which won only four seats in the Indian Parliament, a disappointing result for a party that had a surprisingly strong showing in the state elections in Delhi in December.The party was able to lead the state government there, with its leader, Arvind Kejriwal, as the chief minister, but he resigned after only 49 days in office.

title: Hong Kong Considers Limits on Mainland Chinese Visitors
description: The politically sensitive idea of reducing the number of mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong seemed, until last week, a far-fetched notion. But that changed on Monday, when the territorys chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, was quoted as saying that a 20 percent cut in mainland visitors was one option being considered by a government panel.

title: Patient Is Held After Fire at South Korea Hospital Kills 21
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A fire broke out at a hospital annex in South Korea early Wednesday, killing 21 people and injuring seven others and further rattling a country still traumatized by a recent ferry disaster. The police were holding a patient in connection with the fire.

title: Elderly Suicides Reported After City Announces Phase-out on Burials
description: Officials in China have a rule and target for almost everything the legacy of thousands of years of bureaucratic thinking and the Communist Partys own planned economy  even for a persons final resting place.

title: GlaxoSmithKline Under Investigation by Serious Fraud Office
description: LONDON  The British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline said late Tuesday that the Serious Fraud Office of Britain had opened a formal criminal investigation into its commercial practices.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 28, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: Nestl to Pay Valeant $1.4 Billion for Skin Care Sales Rights
description: LONDON  Nestl, the Swiss food giant, said on Wednesday that it had acquired the rights to sell certain skin care products in the United States and Canada from Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, based in Quebec, for $1.4 billion in cash.

title: 6 Qs About the News | U.S. Will Complete Afghan Pullout by End of 2016, Obama Says
description: In U.S. Will Complete Afghan Pullout by End of 2016, Obama Says, Mark Landler reports on the presidents plan to withdraw American troops from Afghanistan.

title: Weir to Drop Takeover Pursuit of Finnish Rival Metso
description: LONDON  The Scottish engineering company Weir Group said on Wednesday that it was dropping its pursuit of a Finnish rival, Metso.

title: The Smutty-Metaphor Queen of Lawrence, Kansas
description: Just before she took the microphone one soggy night in Portland, Ore., the poet Patricia Lockwood downed a shot of cheap bourbon. She had never had a drink right before a reading, but she often enacts some private joke when she speaks in public. It might be slurping her water loudly into the microphone, or rolling (instead of stepping) onto a stage, or, in this case, ingesting something that tasted to her like a puddle in a forest  anything to erase what she calls the anxiety kegels leading up to a performance.

title: Do You Think You Will Have a Career That You Love?
description: Many students, when seeking career advice from a guidance counselor or teacher, will be told, Do what you love. But that isnt a realistic option for many, if not most, of us. And it may not always be whats best for our families and communities either, if not ourselves.

title: Irish Regulator Finds Himself at Heart of Privacy Debate
description: BERLIN  Billy Hawkes might be the most important tech regulator youve never heard of.

title: Bringing the Nigerian Schoolgirls Into View
description: Hauwa Mutah wants to be a biochemist. Monica Enoch loves to sing. Dourcas Yakubu is a shy girl who exchanged hand-written notes with a boy who called her the remote control of my life.

title: Syrians in Lebanon Flood Polling Place, Choosing Assad Out of Fervor or Fear
description: YARZE, Lebanon  Syrians living in Lebanon swarmed their countrys embassy here on Wednesday to cast early ballots in a sharply disputed presidential election that is virtually sure to keep President Bashar al-Assad in power, turning out in numbers that surprised even embassy officials and brought a major highway from Beirut to a standstill for much of the day.

title: Alibaba to Buy Stake in Singaporean Postal System
description: HONG KONG  The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant, said Wednesday that it would pay about $250 million for 10 percent of Singapore Post, the national postal system of Singapore, extending the Chinese companys push into the logistics business and into new overseas markets.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: Some Animals Allowed
description: Good Wednesday morning to you.

title: Gone Boy (Prince of Denmark)
description: Gillian Flynn, the author of Gone Girl, will write a new version of Hamlet for Hogarth, joining a trans-Atlantic roster being put together by the publishing company to present Shakespeare in a more modern, accessible form.

title: Tibetan Protest Singer Is Said to Be Under Arrest
description: A popular Tibetan singer was arrested in Sichuan Province last week after a concert at which he performed songs from his banned album, according to Free Tibet, a London-based advocacy group.

title: French Police Expel Migrants From Makeshift Camps
description: LONDON  Days after populist anti-immigration parties scored broad successes in European elections, the French riot police moved in to dismantle makeshift campsites housing hundreds of migrants seeking to reach Britain from the port of Calais in northern France.

title: Violence Leads Xinjiang to Propose Paying Tourists to Visit
description: The authorities in the far western region of Xinjiang, which has been hit by a series of terrorist attacks targeting civilians, are considering offering cash bonuses to tourists from other parts of China this summer, the state news media reported.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Daily Report: Google Testing a Completely Driverless Car
description: Humans might be the one problem Google cant solve, John Markoff reports.

title: A Do-Nothing Congress? Well, Pretty Close
description: After a burst of legislative activity in the past decade, representatives in the House are now proposing fewer bills.

title: Even Sun Microsystems Had Its Roots at Xerox PARC
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  As a Stanford University graduate student in 1978, Andy Bechtolsheim took full advantage of a consulting appointment at Xeroxs fabled Palo Alto Research Center. He was able to experience the Xerox Alto, a then-revolutionary office workstation which would become the prototype for the modern PC.

title: My Pricing Problems Continued: Responding to Readers
description: I would like to thank everyone who took time to offer guidance as I addressed my pricing problems. As usual, I received a range of answers after I asked whether it is a good idea to mess with a system that is, on aggregate, producing numbers that allow us to make a profit, but that on closer inspection is not working very well.

title: Threatening a Proxy Battle, Valeant Raises Its Offer on the Botox Maker Allergan
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is prepared to play the waiting game as it pursues what would be its largest and most transformative acquisition yet.

title: Obama Warns U.S. Faces Diffuse Terrorism Threats
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  President Obama tried once more to articulate his vision of the American role in the world on Wednesday, telling graduating cadets here that the nation they were being called to serve would seek to avoid military misadventures abroad, even as it confronts a new set of terrorist threats from the Middle East to Africa.

title: The Fringe Gets Bigger
description: As expected, angry Europeans across the Continent delivered a drubbing to establishment parties in elections to the European Parliament that ended on Sunday. It was not only fringe parties in smaller states that did it: Marine Le Pens National Front in France and Nigel Farages UKIP (U.K. Independence Party) in Britain each took about a quarter of the votes in their countries, the second- and third-biggest economies in the European Union.

title: Relational Takes Stake in Magnum Hunter, an Oil and Gas Driller
description: Relational Investors has long been known for its shareholder activism, calling for change at companies like Timken and Genzyme. But the investment firm is trying a different path.

title: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Azerbaijan (0)
description: In the first of its three exhibition matches ahead of the World Cup, the United States national mens soccer team overcame a lackluster start to defeat Azerbaijan, 2-0, Tuesday night at Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

title: Jailhouse Blues
description: On a rainy morning in May, six women gathered in the penthouse of a luxury hotel in downtown Manhattan, greeting one another with affectionate hugs and kisses, comparing their designer attire and chatting excitedly about parties they had been to or would soon attend. Then they sat down to talk about their lives in prison.

title: New Standards for Companies Revenue Accounting Will Begin in 2017
description: Accounting for revenue  one thing that every company has, or at least needs if it is going to stay in business  will be significantly changed in 2017, the two boards that set accounting standards for companies in most major countries around the world announced on Wednesday.

title: Whats News in Washington: Obama to Outline Foreign Policy Agenda
description: Good Wednesday morning from an already steamy Washington.
