President Obama is on his way to West Point where he is expected to explain during a commencement speech at the United States Military Academy how the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan will help the administration confront the emerging terrorist threat that stretches from the Middle East to Africa, The Timess Mark Landler reports.

title: Valeant Turns Up the Heat
description: VALEANT RAISES BID FOR ALLERGAN | Valeant Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday raised its takeover bid for Allergan, turning up the heat in its pursuit of the Botox maker, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The new offer comes on the heels of a separate deal in which Nestl will buy the sales rights to some of Valeants skin care products for $1.4 billion. It also arrives a day after Allergan unveiled a more pointed defense against the takeover bid, questioning the sustainability of its unwanted suitors business model and stock price.

title: Presidents Choice for South Korea Premier Steps Aside
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A former justice handpicked to be South Koreas new prime minister stepped aside on Wednesday, dealing a blow to President Park Geun-hyes efforts to regroup her government in the wake of a fatal ferry disaster.

title: An Old Friend, Safe in the Park
description: Dear Diary:

title: Steel, Ex-Deputy Mayor, to Become Perella Weinberg C.E.O.
description: Updated, 6:56 p.m. | Late last year, Robert K. Steel was pondering his next career move as his job as deputy mayor to Michael R. Bloomberg was about to end. He had already worked as a Goldman Sachs investment banker, as the chief executive of Wachovia, and once before in public service, at the Treasury Department.

title: WikiLeaks-Inspired Recital Among Next Wave Festival Premieres
description: World premieres of new works by the indie classical composers Ted Hearne and Bryce Dessner, the jazz pianist and composer Vijay Iyer, and the choreographers Jessica Lang and Jodi Melnick  as well as the previously announced 50th anniversary celebration of Nonesuch Records  are among the highlights of the 2014 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The festival runs from Sept. 9 through Dec. 20.

title: A Lifelong Student of Williams Learns How to Defeat Her
description: PARIS  When Garbie Muguruza was growing up in Venezuela and in Spain, her favorite player was Serena Williams.

title: Mayor of Chicago Seeks to Further Tighten Gun Laws
description: CHICAGO  Mayor Rahm Emanuel outlined a plan on Wednesday to make Chicagos gun laws, already some of the strictest in the country, even tougher.

title: Nas Scholarship Fund Aims to Ease Transition From College to Work
description: Just six months ago, the rapper Nas visited Harvard University to put his imprimatur on the Nasir Jones Hip-Hop Fellowship, to be awarded in his name to two musicians or hip-hop scholars every year. But he has also been thinking about how those scholars  and other college students  will put their degrees to use. Koru, a year-old Seattle company that has partnerships with universities and employers, and runs a four-week training program meant to smooth the transition from academia to gainful employment, announced on Wednesday that Nas has become a partner.

title: Defending His Actions, Snowden Says Hes a Patriot
description: WASHINGTON  Edward J. Snowden said that he still considered himself to be an American patriot even after leaking thousands of classified documents, and that he was frustrated to be stuck in a place  Russia  that did so little to protect individual rights when he was trying to help protect American freedoms.

title: Maya Angelou, Lyrical Witness of the Jim Crow South, Dies at 86
description: Maya Angelou, whose landmark book of 1969, I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings  a lyrical, unsparing account of her childhood in the Jim Crow South  was among the first autobiographies by a 20th-century black woman to reach a wide general readership, died on Wednesday at her home in Winston-Salem, N.C. She was 86.

title: A Thaw in France in G.E. Bid for Alstom
description: PARIS  The French government appeared on Wednesday to be softening its opposition to General Electrics $13.5 billion bid for the power business of Alstom, the industrial conglomerate that the countrys lawmakers view as a national champion.

title: CreatureCast: Suddenly Visible
description: Being invisible has its advantages, but also its perils. A marine creature called Hippopodius gets the best of both worlds by transforming from glassy clear to bright white and back again.

title: Democrats, to Counter G.O.P., Turn Their Focus to Local Issues for Midterms
description: WASHINGTON  In Senator Jeanne Shaheens first television ad of her re-election campaign, a Vietnam War veteran talks about how Ms. Shaheen, a Democrat, cut through the red tape to help open a veterans clinic in Keene, N.H.

title: A Marine Magicians Vanishing Act
description: Being transparent comes with obvious benefits  and some hidden costs. A transparent animal can hide in plain sight from predators that would eat it, and can easily ambush its own prey. But many other animals use sight to navigate their environment, and if you are clear they can bump right into you.

title: In Our Pages: May 29
description: 1964: Apollo Capsule Put in Orbit

title: Former Trader at SAC Capital Seeks a Lenient Sentence for Insider Trading
description: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader convicted of insider trading in February, does not think he should get more jail time than the 11 years in prison that Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon hedge fund, is serving for insider trading.

title: Massimos Last Letters
description: Massimo Vignelli, the acclaimed graphic designer who died Tuesday, reads from letters sent by those inspired by his work. His son put out a call for the letters when his fathers health deteriorated.

title: Massimo Vignelli: A Master in the Grammar of Design
description: What would it be like to read your own obituary? Massimo Vignelli, the renowned designer who died Tuesday at the age of 83, had that chance a thousand times over.

title: Turnout Rises in Egypt, but the Vote Raises Doubts
description: CAIRO  Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army field marshal who led last summers military takeover, won election as president with more than 90 percent of the vote, according to preliminary tallies Wednesday night. But it was the reported turnout that caught some by surprise.

title: Maya Angelou at the Clinton Inauguration
description: The memoirist and poet recited her poem On the Pulse of Morning in 1993 at President Bill Clintons first inaugural ceremony.

title: Spurning Suitors, This American Life Opts for Self-Distribution
description: Five suitors came calling, including satellite radio company SiriusXM, but in the end public radios This American Life decided to go it alone. The popular weekly program is notifying stations on Wednesday that it will distribute the show itself beginning in July when its distribution contract with Public Radio International ends.

title: After Pearl Harbor, F.D.R. Showed Confidence That U.S. Would Exist in 1956
description: This is Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., who was idolized from coast to coast as one of Americas first World War II heroes in the immediate aftermath of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. As Life Magazine reported in December 1941, Kelly dove his plane straight into the Japanese battleship, Haruna, released a stick of high explosives almost into the mouths of flaming guns, and then vanished himself in the mighty explosion that ushered the 29,000-ton ship to the bottom of the sea.

title: Former Top JPMorgan Banker in Britain Loses Appeal in Insider Case
description: LONDON  A former top banker at JPMorgan Chase has lost his appeal of a ruling by British regulators two years ago that he improperly disclosed inside information.

title: Monsters, Updated
description: Are todays children really afraid of monsters? Movies like Hotel Transylvania and Monsters, Inc. and even shows like Sesame Street have made them more sweet than threatening, more funny than ferocious. My own kids, whove never mentioned being scared of anything supernatural, fear the same things I do: eels, sharks and home invasion. Try writing a picture book about that! But monsters are a literary commonplace, embodiments of whatever dark and unexpected things lurk in childrens imaginations. Big Bad Bubble," by Adam Rubin with illustrations by Daniel Salmieri, and Rules of Summer, by Shaun Tan, imagine alien landscapes inhabited by monstrous creatures. Whether they strike a chord with  or terrify  children depends very much upon the child.

title: Highlights of the West Point Speech
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama laid out a foreign policy vision on Wednesday for his final two and a half years in office in a speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Here are some of his key points:

title: Snowdens Interview With Brian Williams
description: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked classified documents, said in his first interview with an American television network that he had been trained as a spy.

title: Koch Subsidiary to Buy Propylene Maker for $2.1 Billion
description: PetroLogistics, a maker of propylene, announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to be bought out by a subsidiary of Koch Industries for $2.1 billion in cash, including the assumption of debt.

title: Pfizer Gives Up, For Now
description: Pfizers $119 billion plan to skimp on its taxes by buying AstraZeneca, the British drug company, has expired  for now at least. But rest assured, there will be another offer, or others like it, unless Congress acts to shut down the tax loophole that Pfizer was trying to exploit in its bid for AstraZeneca.

title: The Push to End Chronic Homelessness Is Working
description: Sometime in June, the 100,000 Homes Campaign  an initiative launched four years ago to help communities around the country place 100,000 chronically homeless people into permanent supportive housing  expects to announce that it has reached its goal. Its a significant milestone: It means that many American cities are currently on track to end chronic and veteran homelessness by the end of the decade or earlier.

title: A Brief Sampler of Alan Ayckbourn
description: Is anyone still counting? Though the exact total is open to debate, Alan Ayckbourn has definitely written more plays than he has years.

title: Tony Shalhoub in a Scene From Act One
description: The Tony nominee Tony Shalhoub performs a scene as Moss Hart from the Broadway play Act One.

title: Thomas Tait Wins the Inaugural LVMH New Designers Prize
description: So the long, breath-bated wait is over and the winner of the richest fashion prize ever has been revealed: Thomas Tait has taken the inaugural LVMH New Designers Prize. Mr. Tait gets 300,000 euros (about $409,000) plus a years mentorship from one of the LVMH Groups uber-execs. The runners-up were Shayne Olivers Hood by Air and Miuniku by Tina and Nikita Sutradhar, who each get 100, ooo and a one-year mentorship.

title: Iglehart Performs Friend Like Me
description: The Tony nominee James Monroe Iglehart performs Friend Like Me from the Broadway musical Aladdin.

title: Sutton Foster Sings Lay Down Your Head
description: The Tony nominee Sutton Foster sings Lay Down Your Head from the Broadway musical Violet.

title: Broadways Mueller Sings Carole King
description: The Tony Award-winning actress Jessie Mueller performs Youve Got a Friend from the Broadway show Beautiful: The Carole King Musical.

title: Kelli OHara Sings To Build a Home
description: The Tony nominee Kelli OHara sings To Build a Home from the Broadway musical The Bridges of Madison County.

title: Clippers Draw Some High-Profile Offers
description: The potentially frothy bidding to purchase the Los Angeles Clippers began Wednesday with at least three offers submitted to Rochelle Sterling, whose husband, Donald, has been barred for life by the N.B.A. for racist statements made in a recorded conversation.

title: After Months of Infighting, a Major Faction Splits From the Pakistani Taliban
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Seven years into a bloody campaign to overthrow the Pakistani state, the Pakistani Taliban split in two on Wednesday when a major faction publicly rejected the movements leader, Maulana Fazlullah, and said it would continue the fight on its own.

title: Today in Small Business: A New Subprime Market
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Woodside, Queens: An Affordable, Convenient Triangle
description: In March, the Icon 52, a new building on Queens Boulevard in Woodside, opened to renters. Its 66 units were marketed as affordable luxury apartments with amenities that included a roof deck with views of Manhattan.

title: Removing the Ads From a Kindle
description: Q. I know I have to pay extra, but how do I turn off the commercials on my Kindle Fire screen?

title: Image of the Day: May 28
A Return to Rural France, and to Childhood Memories
description: Last summer, for the first time in decades, I turned off a French country road into an alle of tall trees that led to an old brick farmhouse where I spent some of the most joyous moments of my childhood. The farm was in the province of Nivre, two hours south of Paris, and the family that had lived there years ago had raised Charolais cattle. They had five children; but in the summer of 1979, when I was 12, and again in 1981, they folded me into their household as if I were an honorary sixth. The kids closest to my age, Virginie, ric and Benot, treated me like a sister, not like a tourist from Indiana, where I came from. Together we gathered eggs, rode on Mobylettes to the village candy store, set the table when the cur came to lunch, watched the French version of The Avengers, and squabbled over who got to ride shotgun on car trips.

title: Obama Lays Out Foreign Policy Vision
description: President Obama gave a commencement speech at West Point on Wednesday, describing his foreign policy vision as one in which American isolationism is not an option.

title: Obama Announces Counterterrorism Plan
description: President Obama pledged $5 billion for a network of partnerships to help train countries in the Middle East and Africa to carry out operations against extremists.

title: Obama Discusses Efforts in Afghanistan
description: President Obama followed up on Tuesdays announcement to withdraw all troops from Afghanistan by 2016, telling West Point graduates that empowering partners is a large part of their mission.

title: Transcript of President Obamas Commencement Address at West Point
description: Following is the full text as delivered of President Obamas commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: A Record Week for Broadway
description: Broadway shows grossed $30.9 million last week on sales from 299,090 audience members, the highest dollar amount and best attendance ever recorded for the week leading into Memorial Day, according to box office data released on Tuesday. The comparable gross and attendance figures for the same period last year were $25.5 million and 240,878.

title: This Time Around, Let There Be Light
description: For six years, Aaron and Jill Ginsberg lived in the ground-floor rental of an owner-occupied brownstone in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. They had their own washer-dryer and a shared backyard with a grill.

title: In Performance Live: 2014 Tony Awards
description: A special series featuring live concert performances by five Tony-nominated performers.

title: Looking Back at Maya Angelous Life and Work, in The Times and on Twitter
description: Maya Angelou, the poet and performer who died on Wednesday at 86, was a regular presence in The Times throughout her varied career.

title: Times Minute | Memorials in California
description: Also on the Minute, democrats run on local issues in midterm elections and a new Google car without a steering wheel or driver.

title: Times Minute | Memorials in California
description: In the Video

title: Small Companies Use Low-Cost Technology to Increase Foreign Sales
description: Paul Bennett, chief executive of Context Travel, was concerned that his 400 highly qualified tour guides  including professors and architects  were spending too much time on scheduling logistics. He wanted them focused instead on making customers happy, offering erudite tours in 24 countries.

title: Making Vegetables the Star in a Meat-Loving Familys Kitchen
description: Dear Martha and KJ,

title: What Have You Learned About Selling Into Foreign Markets?
description: Weve just published a small-business guide that looks at how companies are using new technologies to extend their sales into overseas markets.

title: Rules of Style | Jenna Lyons on Modern-Day E-Card Etiquette
description: Since Jenna Lyons took the reins as creative director at J. Crew, the brand has launched a seemingly endless stream of covetable designer collaborations in clothing, accessories and beauty products. Now, the brand is bringing its casual-chic aesthetic to the realm of digital correspondence. In a project launched this week with Paperless Post, Lyons has overseen a line of electronic stationery that includes thank-you notes, invites and greetings. The overall tone of the language is one Lyons deems essential for any e-card: humor and a touch of sarcasm. A birthday card reads, Happy Whatever Age You Wish You Were; another says, Thinking of You But Not in a Creepy Stalker Kind of Way. The design is quintessentially J. Crew, too, with neon hues, bold prints and carefully chosen fonts that are as tasteful yet playful as the looks in the catalog.

title: Hachette and Amazon Dig In for a Long Fight Over Contract Terms
description: Amazon and Hachette took their cases to the public on Wednesday as a dispute over contract terms became clashing visions about the distribution of information in the digital age.

title: Obama on Combating Climate Change
description: President Obama discussed climate change in his speech at West Point, saying he intends to make sure America is out front in putting together a global framework to preserve our planet.

title: Style in Goma, the Democratic Republic of Congo
description: In Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Sundays are when most people dress up for church. Recently, Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-proclaimed sapeur (the Congolese term for a dandy), was wearing a skirt made out of ties. He said he rejects the idea that only Sundays are a day to dress up. This interview has been edited.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Deep secrets abound in this months books: A boy living off the grid in Montana reveals his familys chilling history, an artist driven to violence tries to cover his tracks, a woman on a British island remembers what caused her to flee her home in Australia, and a soldier helps a captain prepare for a covert mission.

title: U.S. Seeks to Censor More of Memo That Approved Drone Strike on American
description: WASHINGTON  One week after the Obama administration said it would comply with a federal appeals court ruling ordering it to make public portions of a Justice Department memo that signed off on the targeted killing of a United States citizen, the administration is now asking the court for permission to censor additional passages of the document.

title: A Plan to Sell Cialis, an Erectile Drug, Over the Counter
description: Men with erectile dysfunction may be able to avoid the awkwardness of a doctors visit by buying the drug Cialis without a prescription, under a proposal announced Wednesday by the drugs maker, Eli Lilly, and the French pharmaceutical company Sanofi.

title: Severe Report Finds V.A. Hid Waiting Lists at Hospitals
description: In the first confirmation that Department of Veterans Affairs administrators manipulated medical waiting lists at one and possibly more hospitals, the departments inspector general reported on Wednesday that 1,700 patients at the veterans medical center in Phoenix were not placed on the official waiting list for doctors appointments and may never have received care.

title: The CerviScope in the Field
description: You dont often hear about cervical cancer killing women in the United States, where Pap smears are routine, but in the developing world, it is one of the most lethal cancers for women. While reporting my article that appeared in the May 25 magazine  about how David Walmer, a fertility specialist, created a device to help prevent cervical cancer despite knowing next to nothing about the disease  I spoke to a gynecologist named Kristina McCain. Her experience abroad using a field-test model of the CerviScope to treat poor women, many of them former sex slaves, hints at how the finished product can be useful.

title: Coldplay Hits No. 1
description: Coldplays latest album, Ghost Stories (Parlophone/Atlantic), enters the Billboard 200 chart at No. 1 this week, with sales of 383,000 for the week ending May 25, just six days after the album was released. Of that total, 245,000 (or 64 percent) of the albums sales were as digital downloads, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

title: Mornings Glory
description: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey, the cabaret artists, have a bit they do about being New York parents who work at night. Theyre the ones at school drop-off in sunglasses and pale skin, they say. Theyre the ones gripping their coffee cups tight, jittery and yawning.

title: Dozens of Palestinian Detainees on Hunger Strike Are Hospitalized
description: JERUSALEM  Sixty-eight Palestinians detained in Israel have been hospitalized after refusing food for almost five weeks, a spokeswoman for the Israel Prison Service said on Wednesday.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 15
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: TimesTalks | Hedwig: Preview
description: The star and creators of Broadways Hedwig and the Angry Inch reflect on the shows journey from downtown clubs to the Broadway stage, and talk about the implications of a mainstream-ready Hedwig.

title: Hedwig: Inappropriate Scaffolding
description: Part 5: The star and creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch reflect on the challenge of adapting the former club show for the Broadway stage.

title: Hedwig: Neil Patrick Harris
description: Part 4: Neil Patrick Harris, star of Hedwig and the Angry Inch, talks about why he wanted to do the show, and recalls the first time he met John Cameron Mitchell.

title: Hedwig: The SqueezeBox Days
description: Part 2: The creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch recall the origin of their collaboration, and describe the downtown scene where they developed the stage show that would become Hedwig.

title: Hedwig: The German Babysitter
description: Part 3: The creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch share the story from John Cameron Mitchells childhood that led to the idea for the character of Hedwig.

title: Hedwig: Dr. Seuss and Lou Reed
description: Part 8: The creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch reveal the music and theater that most influenced them when writing Hedwig.

description: Part 9: John Cameron Mitchell, author of Hedwig and the Angry Inch, recalls the audition that ultimately made the Hedwig movie possible.

description: Part 10: The star and creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch discuss how reactions to the show and the character have changed over the years.

title: Hedwig: I Get Free Rein
description: Part 12: The star and creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch share some of Neil Patrick Harriss onstage antics, and talk about the task of updating the shows music for the Broadway production.

title: Hedwig: David Letterman
description: Part 11: The creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch talk about what it was like performing songs from the show on television 15 years ago, and discuss plans for a Hedwig sequel.

description: Part 7: The star and creators of Hedwig and the Angry Inch talk about what makes the show such a challenge to perform.

description: Part 6: Neil Patrick Harris, star of Hedwig and the Angry Inch, describes how he prepared for the role of Hedwig.

title: App Smart | Summer Music Festivals
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that could help you make the most of music festivals this summer.

title: Teaching Maya Angelou With New York Times
description: Updated: May 31

title: Snowboarders Downtime Leads to Pranks
description: Professional snowboarders may pass hundreds of hours waiting for ideal weather. These hours can serve as a catalyst for pranks  and sometimes these pranks go farther than expected.

title: Gunmen in West Tunisia Attack Interior Ministers Home, Killing 4 Guards
description: LONDON  Gunmen in western Tunisia attacked the family home of Interior Minister Lotfi Ben Jeddou in the early hours of Wednesday, officials there reported, killing four guards in one of the most brazen assaults by Islamist militants to hit the country in months.

title: Giulianis Take on Ferrets (1999)
State of the Internet: Still Growing but More Mobile Than Ever
description: Mary Meeker puts out an annual report on Internet trends every year that is a sort of farmers almanac for the tech industry. It puts all the crucial data in one place, with Ms. Meekers particular spin on whats most important.

title: Off-Broadway Troupes Will Debut Works by Doug Wright and Neil LaBute
description: Off Broadways Atlantic Theater Company will produce new plays by Doug Wright (a Pulitzer Prize winner for I Am My Own Wife), Rajiv Joseph and Halley Feiffer during its 2014-15 season, as well as a new musical whose creators include Hunter Bell ([title of show]), the theaters leaders announced on Wednesday.

title: Cannes Film Festival 2014, Part III
description: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benot Peverelli.

title: Cheap Climate Protection
description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce just came out with its preemptive strike against Obama administration regulations on power plants. What the Chamber wanted to do was show that the economic impact of the regulations would be devastating. And I was eager to see how they had fudged the numbers.

title: Antidepressant May Ease Hot Flashes of Menopause
description: The hormone estrogen is the recommended treatment for menopausal night sweats and hot flashes, but some women are unable or unwilling to use it. Now a clinical trial suggests that the antidepressant venlafaxine, often used as an alternative, is equally effective.

title: Valeants Latest Move Disappoints
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International comes off oddly defensive in its latest advance on Allergan.A sweetened, $49 billion bid for Allergan, the Botox maker, disappointed investors in both companies. The use of a messy financial instrument probably didnt help, especially after the target pushed back hard on the deal math and compared its suitor to Tyco. Valeant has more work to do to reclaim the role of aggressor.

title: What You Get for... $2,450,000
description: ANDOVER, N.H.

title: Mobile Companions to Summer Music Fests
description: BACK in the 1990s, the British pop band Pulp sang a verse about summer music festivals that went, Is this the way they say the futures meant to feel? Or just 20,000 people standing in a field? Well, now it is the future, and if youre a festivalgoer, you have a futuristic tool to add an extra zing to the music, food and fun: apps on your phone.

title: I.Q. Cutoff Ruling May Spare Some Inmates on Death Row
description: MIAMI  A Supreme Court ruling on Tuesday throwing out Floridas strict I.Q. cutoff in death penalty cases could increase the number of inmates exempt from execution because they are deemed mentally disabled, legal experts said Wednesday.

title: Legal Weasels
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios administration wants to repeal New York Citys ban on pet ferrets, which is good news for ferrets, and their outlaw owners, who will no longer have to live a lie.

title: Syria to Miss Deadline On Weapons, Official Says
description: The United Nations secretary general has for the first time acknowledged that the eradication of Syrias chemical arms stockpile will not be completed by June 30, the deadline imposed by a diplomatic agreement last September in which President Bashar al-Assad renounced the weapons and avoided a threatened American military strike.

title: Reaction to President Obamas West Point Speech
description: President Obama laid out a foreign policy vision on Wednesday for his final two and a half years in office, responding to critics who have said the United States has been rudderless amid crises. Mr. Obamas critics were quick to respond to his speech. A few of those responses are highlighted below:

title: Goldman Predicts Brazil Will Win the 2014 World Cup
description: The thousands of screaming soccer fans who root for their national teams at the World Cup every four years probably arent rooting for their local stock market.

title: A Galaxy Far, Far Away...Will Hit Ours
description: From 2014: Hubble Space Telescope measurements have confirmed that the Milky Way will collide with a sibling galaxy known as the Andromeda nebula in billions of years.

title: Scene City: Tea Time for the Tonys
description: Julianne Moore hosts a tea party for LaTanya Richardson Jackson.

title: Andromeda and the Milky Way: A Merger of Galactic Proportions
description: The Andromeda nebula, which rarely feels the pull of the social media orbit, had a moment in the spotlight on Wednesday. Astronomers operating NASAs Swift satellite spied what looked like a giant burst of radiation from Andromeda, the nearest big galaxy to our own Milky Way, about 2.5 million light-years from here. They tentatively diagnosed it as the collision of two neutron stars, the dense remnants of dead stars. Such collisions are among the most violent known conflagrations in the universe, but they rarely occur so close to our own neck of the cosmic woods.

title: Did Obama Make His Case?
Trot Out the New Blue
description: Denim is something you can always justify more of. Youll want a new pair of baggier jeans now that skinnies are finally slipping as the style of choice (as are, it seems, jeans in tutti-frutti colors). Could it be that denim is getting back to its roots? Here are some ways to work blues back into your summer wardrobe.

title: Classical Playlist: Bang on a Can All-Stars, Meredith Monk, Kojiro Umezaki and More
description: JULIA WOLFE: Steel HammerBang on a Can All-Stars; Trio Mediaeval(Cantaloupe)Theres grit in Julia Wolfes Steel Hammer. No, really. The blue-collar song cycle is scored for the versatile forces of the Bang on a Can All-Stars and the ethereally pure female voices of Trio Mediaeval, but a recurring sound is that of sand, pouring down the inside of wooden tubes. The result is a fiercely beautiful homage to manual labor, its endless repetitions and occasional moments of magical transformation. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

title: A Shrinking Majority Support Capital Punishment
description: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court ruled that a Florida law setting a minimum I.Q. test score for the death penalty was too rigid.

title: The Gun Report: May 28, 2014
description: The nation, still reeling from last Fridays rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., is now confronted by the same questions that arise after each mass shooting: How did a future killer go undetected? How could someone so disturbed have been allowed to legally purchase firearms? Why does this keep happening? How can we prevent it from happening again?

title: Maya Angelou: An Earlier Stage
description: Maya Angelou was best known for her poetry and prose, but she first appeared in the pages of The New York Times in an entirely different context: the stage.

title: Delay Sought in S.E.C. Case Against Steven Cohen
description: It could be months, maybe even years, before there is a resolution of the Securities and Exchange Commissions administrative case againstthe billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, whose former hedge fund pleaded guilty to insider trading.

title: After Lundqvist Is Pulled, Rangers Say He Doesnt Need a Push
description: MONTREAL  Henrik Lundqvist does not get pulled from playoff games often. Tuesdays 7-4 loss was only the fourth time in 86 postseason starts that he was yanked from the nets. He might have looked bad, but his record and reputation are above reproach, and his teammates harbor no doubts about how well he will play in Game 6 of the N.H.L. Eastern Conference finals Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Rihanna Looks Styled by Mel Ottenberg
description: The stylist Mel Ottenberg is tasked with keeping up with, or even staying ahead of, the fashion tastes of Rihanna.

title: Where Wild Spirits Make a Home
description: Patricia Lockwoods sexy, surreal and mostly sublime poems seem to have been, as James Joyce said in Ulysses about a batch of folk tales, printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind. They scatter lightning and lawn debris across your psyche.

title: Rihannas Style Has a Name: Mel Ottenberg
description: When your star client is an internationally obsessed-over, unfailingly photographed clotheshorse, a peculiar problem presents itself.

title: A Look Into the Lives of Nigerias Kidnapped Girls
description: Glenna Gordon photographed some of the belongings of the schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram, providing a glimpse into their lives.

title: Hanging in a Park With Danish Royalty
description: A small boy in shorts plopped down cross-legged on the stone steps at Bryant Park, between Hamlet and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, watching intently until an adult crawled over to extricate him. A little girl in a tank dress stood far stage right, so riveted by Ophelias funeral that she shrugged off an attempt to pull her back when Hamlet scuffled with Laertes.

title: The Poconos for a Pittance
description: A few weeks ago, my upstairs neighbors Beata and Mirek Piszczek were helping me fix my door when they started talking about their house in the Poconos. Just 100 miles from New York City, they said. Mirek goes every weekend. Hes obsessed, Beata said.

title: Apple to Pay $3 Billion to Buy Beats
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Apple, the company that turned digital music into a mainstream phenomenon, said on Wednesday that it was buying Beats Electronics, a rising music brand, for $3 billion, in a move that will help it play catch-up with rivals that offer subscription-based music services.

title: In the Wrinkle Wars, a New Weapon
description: As she aged, Sandi Bachom, 69, a filmmaker and producer in Manhattan, tried Botox to keep the inevitable wrinkles away, but she was wary of anything more invasive. She wanted, as she explained recently, to avoid going under the knife.

title: House Hunting in ... Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
description: BALINESE BUNGALOW

title: Facebook Wants European Blessing for WhatsApp Deal
description: LONDON  The European Union will have a chance to weigh in on Facebooks deal to buy the Internet messaging application WhatsApp for as much as $19 billion.

title: For Tea Party, Senate Race in Mississippi Is the Last Chance to Oust an Incumbent
description: WASHINGTON  The feud between the Republican establishment and the Tea Party has engendered more whimpers than war cries so far. The notable exception is in Mississippi, where the campaign to unseat Senator Thad Cochran has become the nastiest, and most personal, in the nation.

title: Maya Angelou in Pictures
description: In her writing, Ms. Angelou explored identity and resilience through the multifaceted lens of race, sex, family, community and the collective past.

title: Hugo McCloud: Artist by Design
description: AGE 34

title: At St. Regis Hotels, New Family Excursions
description: The luxury chain St. Regis Hotels & Resorts has a new Family Traditions program that gives parents and their children the chance to experience destinations together in a way unique way.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: A Bunch of Friends? Yeah, Again
description: It doesnt take much.

title: Is This Music Ideal for Ballet? A Leaping Reply
description: What could Bachs Double Violin Concerto have in common with the songs of George Gershwin? George Balanchine, who found both to be appropriate music for ballet, might have answered, They both got rhythm. Or at least that correspondence was apparent at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, when his Concerto Barocco (1941) and Who Cares? (1970) opened and closed a program of New York City Ballet.

title: Spark Capital Raises $375 Million for Later-Stage Investments
description: Spark Capital has reaped wealth and prominence through its early investments in start-ups like Twitter and the virtual reality headset maker Oculus.

title: Stefan Zweig, Austrian Novelist, Rises Again
description: In the decades between the two world wars, no writer was more widely translated or read than the Austrian novelist Stefan Zweig, and in the years after, few writers fell more precipitously into obscurity, at least in the English-speaking world. But now Zweig, prolific storyteller and embodiment of a vanished Mitteleuropa, seems to be back, and in a big way.

title: A Queens Accidental Gospel
description: Mariah Careys perplexingly titled new album, Me. I Am Mariah . . . The Elusive Chanteuse,  begins with a meditation and ends with a sort of confession.

title: Dudas Homer Caps Winning Finish to a Trying Stretch
description: At the crack of the bat, there was not a doubt about Lucas Dudas home run. It sailed high and deep and glanced off the spandrel of the Shea Bridge beyond the bullpens in right-center field, giving the Mets a five-run lead over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the eighth inning Wednesday afternoon.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and More
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: At the Marlton Hotel, Like Moths to a Flame
description: No one can say for sure why the fashion world has migrated en masse to the Marlton Hotel, and its restaurant, the Margaux, over the last few months. It didnt even exist during last years September fashion shows. But everyone does agree: Its a thing now.

title: Voices of Syrians Voting From Lebanon
description: Syrian expatriates living in Lebanon discussed Syrias election as they cast their votes abroad for the countrys president.

title: The Tonys, a Tea and Toasts
description: Samuel L. Jackson is not used to being arm candy.

title: Owning a Big Voice, and Willing to Use It
description: Wherever you find boys of a certain age with a gleam in their eye, you will find glittering material girls ready to make them feel like kings  in return for favors, of course. Its a law of nature that no amount of hand-wringing can overturn. And its why Lorelei Lee, the gold-digging siren from Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, is here to stay.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, Iran, India and Japan.

title: How Big a V.A. Scandal?
description: The inspector general of the Department of Veterans Affairs has confirmed allegations that the agencys medical center in Phoenix kept veterans waiting unconscionably long times to see a doctor and hid the fact by creating fictitious wait lists. However, the report issued today did not address the most explosive charges  that veterans have died because of delays in getting treatment and that hidden delays are endemic throughout the Veterans health care system.

title: New York Pro-Am Tournament Raises $125,000
description: The 51st UJA-Federation of New York Womens Philanthropy bridge pro-am, which raised over $125,000, was played on May 20 at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. It was organized by Tubby Stayman and Marci Miron; Nancy Brown was chairwoman.

title: Just for Kicks and Company
description: Sneakers are making new footprints.

title: Sneakers: Where Cant They Go?
description: If sneakers have cracked the rarefied world of couture, where cant they go?

title: The Extremist Organizations on the Front Lines
description: In outlining his foreign policy priorities at the United States Military Academy on Wednesday, President Obama called on Congress to authorize up to $5 billion to support countries on the front lines in the fight against terrorism.

title: Kirkus Announces 3 New $50,000 Prizes for Literature
description: Kirkus Reviews, the literary journal best known for its pre-publication reviews of forthcoming books, said on Wednesday evening that it was creating three new literary prizes  for fiction, nonfiction and young readers literature. The prize in each category, bestowed annually, will be $50,000, a relatively large amount in the world of literary awards.

title: A Young Company, Yes, but Taking More Than Baby Steps
description: Some dance troupes might need a few years and a few false starts to develop a program fit for international touring. Not the 10-member MalPaso Dance Company, from Havana, which made its United States debut  its first appearance outside Cuba  on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. Founded less than two years ago by Osnel Delgado and Daile Carrazana Gonzalez, former members of Danza Contempornea de Cuba, the company already has at least two knockout pieces: 24 Hours and a Dog, created by Mr. Delgado, the artistic director, in collaboration with the dancers; and Why You Follow, a Joyce commission by New Yorks much-loved Ronald K. Brown.

title: A Reinvention by the Sea
description: Yellow tape cordoned off guest rooms, walls were being smashed and paint fumes overpowered the salty sea air. But Jennifer Oz LeRoy exuded calm as she stared out at the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Cool and Calm at Center of an E.R. Maelstrom in the Bronx
description: The woman, in the midst of a seizure, moaned from a row of stretchers parked in the hallway of the emergency room at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

title: Good Enough to See, Maybe Not to Eat
description: Sartre walks into a Quiznos sounds like the setup to a glum philosophers sorry joke. But its actually the inspiration behind the set design for American Hero, a new comedy by Bess Wohl that takes place inside a failing, faux-cheery corporate sandwich shop in Anywhere, U.S.A.

title: Funding Round Pushes Korean E-Commerce Sites Valuation Above $1 Billion
description: When Bom Kim dropped out of Harvard Business School to start a Korean e-commerce company in 2010, he found it difficult to attract workers. Start-up did not have a good connotation in Korea, he recalled.

title: Michael Kinsley Responds to Criticism of Greenwald Review
description: In a post yesterday, I took up Michael Kinsleys review of Glenn Greenwalds book, No Place to Hide, which many Times readers had written to me about. Mr. Kinsley has asked The Times for the opportunity to respond and I am providing it here:

title: At the Piano, and Under the Hood
description: You might have thought that the pianist David Greilsammer, looking focused but a little frantic as he hovered over a piano at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night about 90 minutes before his program there was set to start, was actually a technician. Or even a kind of carpenter foraging through a pile of screws crammed into an inside corner of the pianos steel frame.

title: Ranger Suspended as Canadien Returns
description: The N.H.L. on Wednesday barred Rangers defenseman John Moore for two games for a hit that staggered Montreal Canadiens forward Dale Weise and may have left him with a concussion.

description: Sales

title: $650 Million to Settle Blood Thinner Lawsuits
description: The German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim has agreed to pay $650 million to settle thousands of lawsuits involving its blood thinner Pradaxa, the company said Wednesday.

title: Are They Nuts?
description: A person who wont work for peanuts has no business trying to grow them in New York.

title: A New Way for Silver to Keep Its Sparkle
description: Put away the silver polish. The French silver company Christofle is introducing SilverEver, a coating for its products that it says will significantly delay tarnishing. Its a very thin nanometer coating applied to the surface of the product, said Thierry Oriez, Christofles chief executive. The result is safe for food and invisible, he said, and has no effect on the feel of the metal.

title: A Midcentury Classic, Reissued for the Masses
description: Like many midcentury-modern furniture designs, William Hainess Malibu Sofa still looks fresh today. Unlike many midcentury pieces, though, it was never intended to be mass produced.

title: Global Dcor in Brooklyn Heights
description: The husband-and-wife designers Paul and Sophie Yanacopoulos-Gross were living in Switzerland but contemplating a move to New York when a real estate listing in Brooklyn Heights caught his eye: a parlor-floor storefront with a fabulous fanlight window on Montague, a tree-lined street that reminded him of his hometown, London. The couple snapped up the lease. This weekend, their new store, HomeStories, opens there, selling contemporary and artisanal wares from around the world.

title: Obamas New Troop Withdrawal Plan for Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales at Flavor Paper, Gracious Home and OnOurTable
description: Flavor Papers sample sale on Saturday, from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., will offer discounts of up to 75 percent on slightly imperfect hand-screened or digitally printed wallpaper, discontinued throw pillows and one-of-a-kind art prints (Brasilia wallpaper, originally $150 a roll, will be $75; Bubbly wallpaper, originally $200 a roll, will be $100); 216 Pacific Street (Court Street), Brooklyn, 718-422-0230, flavorpaper.com.

title: Night Lights for Sweet Dreams
description: As the creative director of the French childrens clothing company Bonpoint, Christine Innamorato spends a lot of time thinking about fashion. But interior design, she said, deserves just as much attention.

title: Bluegrass Portraits, With a Twist
description: Pieter Estersohn, a veteran architecture and interiors photographer, really stretched himself for his new book, Kentucky: Historic Houses and Horse Farms of Bluegrass Country ($60; Monacelli Press). For aerial shots of barns and thoroughbreds, as well as portraits of historic homes, he made five extended visits to Lexington over two years. At one point, he insisted on removing the passenger-side door of a helicopter he was riding in. I was cantilevered out, contorting my body for three hours in 20-degree temperatures to get those images, he recalled recently during lunch not far from his home and studio near Gramercy Park.

title: Partnering to Spread the Whimsy
description: The whimsical designs of Rifle Paper Company have embellished many a wedding invitation, phone case and coaster. Now, thanks to a collaboration with Hygge & West, theyll adorn walls as well.

title: The Innkeepers
description: At more than 9,000 square feet, the sprawling house that Kathy and Dennis Brekken built on a remote stretch of the Cannon River, miles from the one-stoplight downtown of historic Cannon Falls, Minn., has the feeling of an old-world inn.

title: A Government Rating of Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is This a Hospital or a Hotel?
description: Hospitals today offer even general amenities for patients, like room service and nail salons, more associated with hotels than health care.

title: Worse Than Jeff Davis?
description: That Twelve Years a Slave won the Oscar for best picture is a stunning achievement in Hollywood cinematic history. Solomon Northups autobiography, upon which the movie was based, provides a powerful insiders account and critique of one of the nations founding institutions, while the film rendition disrupts the long tradition of derisive and romantic portrayals of slavery in motion pictures.

title: The Day of Forgetting
description: I was 25 when I lost my memory. It happened on Jan. 16, 2012. I woke up, not knowing where I was. I was lying in bed, sure, but whose bed was it? There was no one in the room, no sound that I recognized: I was alone with my body.

title: On the High Road Again, With Willie Nelson
description: An exhibit of country music stars explores how photography helped shape the musics public image. It also sparked memories of a favorite assignment.

title: Reflections on the Magic of the Journal Gallery, From the Artists Who Show There
description: Julia Dippelhofer had come to the United States from Germany to work as an au pair when she met Michael Nevin in a photography class at the Montserrat College of Art in Beverly, Mass. Then 19, Nevin had recently started a photocopied zine out of his dorm called The Journal that was dedicated to his twin passions: snowboarding and art. The two formed a bond based on their shared aesthetic sensibility, and soon moved to New York and turned The Journal into an effortlessly stylish publication at the crossroads between the citys downtown fashion and art worlds.

title: Maya & Me & Maya
description: The news of Maya Angelous death arrived with the abruptness of a great twister  violent, without warning, tearing things up and flipping things over.

title: Polar Vision
description: Almost any commentary on the Supreme Court these days will include an observation about how polarized the court is: how for the first time in history, all the Republican-appointed justices (there are five) are to the right of all the Democratic appointees, and how the two groups diverge (Justice Anthony M. Kennedy occasionally excepted) in many of the courts most ideologically charged cases.

title: Finding Space for the Living at a Memorial
description: Some fences have come down at the World Trade Center. The site isnt finished yet, but theres no longer the regime of barricades and snaking line to see the pair of matching fountains approximating the footprints of the former towers. The other morning, New Yorks police commissioner, William J. Bratton, trailed by seconds, marched under the rows of swamp white oaks toward the newly opened Sept. 11 museum.

title: Intel Shows Off Smart Wearable Shirt
description: In my column this week, I wrote about my new T-shirt, which is connected to the Internet. The shirt,made by the Canadian company OMsignal,can track my exercise, or tell me to take a breath and relax if Im stressed.

title: Google Releases Employee Data, Illustrating Techs Diversity Challenge
description: Google on Wednesday released statistics on the makeup of its work force, providing numbers that offer a stark glance at how Silicon Valley remains a white mans world.

title: Home Is Where the Horses Are
description: DEVON, Pa., the town where I grew up, is the place I loved with all my heart, and that I could not wait to leave. It was there, in a house on Waterloo Road, that I lost my virginity and saw my sons take their first steps, and there that my parents drew their last breaths.

title: Wheelies: The Maybe Someday Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the web:

title: If You Work in Silicon Valley, Odds Are Youre a Man
description: Its good to be a man, particularly a white or Asian one, in the tech industry. Other people arent so lucky.

title: Want to Write Verse With Patricia Lockwood?
Clip: A Million Ways...
description: A scene from A Million Ways to Die in the West, directed by Seth MacFarlane.

title: Self-Driving Challenge: Jaywalkers
description: John J. Leonard, an M.I.T. roboticist, demonstrated the challenge a self-driving car could face when people run across streets when theyre not supposed to.

title: Advisory Group Opposes Re-election of Most of Targets Board
description: An influential shareholder advisory group said that most of Targets board did not deserve to be re-elected, directly linking what it said was a lack of adequate oversight by the board to the extensive breach of customer data late last year.

title: After Success in Denver With Manning, New Jet Is Making a Sharp Pivot
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Eric Decker took more than a tumble in the standings when he left the Denver Broncos, the defending A.F.C. champions, to sign as a free agent with the Jets, who finished 8-8 and missed the playoffs for the third consecutive season.

title: Self-Driving Challenge: Traffic Officer
description: John J. Leonard, an M.I.T. roboticist, demonstrated a scenario of a police officer stopping traffic as something an autonomous vehicle might be challenged with.

title: Why License a Florist?
description: MINNEAPOLIS  IN Minnesota, more classroom time is required to become a cosmetologist than to become a lawyer. Becoming a manicurist takes double the number of hours of instruction as a paramedic. In Louisiana, the only state in the country that requires licenses for florists, monks were until recently forbidden to sell coffins because they were not licensed funeral directors.

title: Prosecutor Says Bump at Club Led to Shootings
description: BOSTON  Aaron Hernandez, a former tight end for the New England Patriots, murdered two men in the summer of 2012 because one of them had accidentally bumped into him and spilled a drink while dancing in a Boston nightclub, a prosecutor charged Wednesday.

title: Presidential Building Is Stormed in Restless Georgian Region
description: MOSCOW  Hundreds of demonstrators occupied the presidential headquarters of Abkhazia, a breakaway enclave of Georgia, on Wednesday, demanding the resignation of the regions leader and the dismissal of the government in the latest tumult to grip a separatist area supported by Russia.

title: In Search of Star Power, Fender Enlists Members of U2
description: Few guitar makers can claim the same perch in the rock music pantheon as Fender, whose Stratocasters and Telecasters have been favored by musicians as diverse as Jimi Hendrix and Kurt Cobain.

title: Safeguarding Louisianas Coastline
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  After decades of watching our state being ravaged to support the nations oil and gas addiction, the people of Louisiana have had enough.

title: Obama to Host Concussions Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday will seek to elevate a national conversation about the dangers of sports-related concussions, especially among children and other young athletes, by pushing for more medical research and more money spent on public awareness campaigns.

title: Self-Driving Challenge: Turning
description: John J. Leonard, an M.I.T. roboticist, demonstrates the challenge self-driving cars might face when they come upon an intersection with traffic approaching from both sides.

title: Self-Driving Challenge: Resurfaced Roads
description: John J. Leonard, an M.I.T. roboticist, demonstrates how features of a highway obscured by weather or roadwork could pose a challenge to a self-driving car.

title: Crimean Vineyards of Last Czar Withstand Time and Tumult
description: YALTA, Crimea  The cavernous cellars of the Massandra vineyards bear testament both to the tumult of history and to the enduring appeal of the wine produced on Crimeas steep, volcanic slopes.

title: Special Parking Rules in New York

title: Israel Suspends Soldier in West Bank Shooting Investigation
description: The Israeli military suspended a soldier who was captured on video this month firing his rifle at protesters in the occupied West Bank. Video evidence showed that the soldier fired his weapon within seconds of a Palestinian boys collapsing to the ground with what proved to be a fatal gunshot wound.

title: When Polling Is More Like Guessing
description: Election analysts and forecasters depend on accurate polling. Unfortunately, theres not much of it so far this cycle.

title: Taste Test: Could Soylent Replace Food?
description: A sommelier, a gastroenterologist, a personal trainer and a Times dining reporter tested out Soylent to see if it could one day replace food for them.

title: A Rival Can Serve As a Good Model for Jackson
description: A query was delivered to Pat Riley recently through a Miami Heat employee, asking if Riley, the teams president, would talk about the challenge of becoming an N.B.A. franchises guiding spirit after a long career as a coaching great.

title: The Soylent Revolution Will Not Be Pleasurable
description: I just spent more than a week experiencing Soylent, the most joyless new technology to hit the world since we first laid eyes on MS-DOS.

title: Myanmars Appalling Apartheid
description: SITTWE, Myanmar  Minura Begum has been in labor for almost 24 hours, and the baby is stuck. Worse, its turned around, one tiny foot already emerging into the world in a difficult breech delivery that threatens the lives of mother and child alike.

title: The Campaign for Junk Food
description: WHEN we began our Lets Move! initiative four years ago, we set one simple but ambitious goal: to end the epidemic of childhood obesity in a generation so that kids born today will grow up healthy.

title: Health Officials Reverse Diagnosis of MERS in Illinois Man
description: Reversing an earlier announcement, federal health officials said Wednesday that an Illinois man who met with an Indiana man who later fell ill with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, did not pick up the virus from him. Officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said a first lung sample from the Illinois man had tested negative for the coronavirus that causes MERS, but two preliminary blood samples had then tested positive for antibodies to it. That led the C.D.C. to announce on May 17 that the man had been infected but had not fallen ill; this would have been the first transmission of the virus within the United States. On Wednesday, they said that a more sensitive blood test that takes at least five days to produce results showed that he never had the virus. The most likely explanation, one of the officials said, is that the preliminary test had cross-reacted with antibodies the man had to a previous coronavirus infection. At least six coronaviruses are known to infect humans: Four normally cause common cold symptoms, while the other two, MERS and SARS, are more serious. Only two MERS cases have been found in the United States  the Indiana man and another in Florida. Both had recently arrived after working in Saudi hospitals where there have been hundreds of cases since March. Thus far, C.D.C. officials said, extensive testing indicates that the two men did not pass on the virus to any family members or health care workers treating them.

title: Finally Breaking Up the Cable Bundles
description: IM in a relationship that just hasnt been working out. I still want to be connected, just not as connected as before.

title: Bidders for 2022 Winter Games Are Melting Away
description: PARIS  As if the Winter Olympics did not have enough existential problems with concern about rising temperatures and melting glaciers, it now seems that nobody is much interested in staging them even while the planet still has snow.

title: Primary Loss Means End of Era for World War II Veterans in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Combat veterans of World War II have served in every Congress for the last 70 years, shaping foreign policy and a vision of the United States as the worlds benevolent leader, willing to use its economic and military might as a global force for freedom.

title: Upset G.M. Engineer Spoke in House Inquiry
description: An engineer at General Motors who is at the center of accusations that the company covered up a deadly defect appeared distraught during lengthy questioning by congressional investigators, according to people familiar with the session.

title: Trying to Keep Peace at Home, While Losing Her Peace of Mind
description: PARIS  Timea Bacsinszky won it all before she had the chance to decide if she really wanted to.

title: Adding Delay to Immigration Failure
description: President Obama asked the homeland security secretary, Jeh Johnson, in March to review the administrations immigration enforcement policies. He was under intense pressure from immigrant advocates, frustrated at Congresss inaction on reform, who were imploring him to act on his own to end or slow the pace of deportations. Now hes backing off and asking Mr. Johnson to delay the review.

title: Santander Bank to Face Suit Claiming Bias in Mortgages
description: As the housing bubble expanded in the early 2000s, mortgage lenders aggressively handed out money in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, though often at exorbitant rates and in ways that made the loans unaffordable to more vulnerable borrowers. Now, the pendulum has swung the other way, raising concerns that some banks are shutting out blacks and Hispanics in favor of white homeowners.

title: President Obama Misses a Chance on Foreign Affairs
description: President Obama and his aides heralded his commencement speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point on Wednesday as a big moment, when he would lay out his foreign policy vision for the remainder of his term and refute his critics. The address did not match the hype, was largely uninspiring, lacked strategic sweep and is unlikely to quiet his detractors, on the right or the left.

title: Maine: Ethics Panel Fines Group Opposed to Same-Sex Marriage
description: The state ethics board voted Wednesday to fine the National Organization for Marriage $50,250 for keeping its donors secret during the successful campaign, in 2009, for a referendum to repeal a law legalizing same-sex marriage. The Maine Commission on Governmental Ethics and Election Practices said the group contributed about $2 million to that campaign but did not register with the commission as a ballot committee, in violation of election law. The organization has argued that its donors did not specifically earmark contributions for the campaign and so it did not have to make disclosures about them to the commission. It said it would appeal. The fine is the highest imposed by the ethics board, which will also direct the group to register as a ballot question committee and to list its contributions. Voters in Maine legalized same-sex marriage with another ballot question in 2012.

title: A Pushback on Green Power
description: As renewable energy production has surged in recent years, opponents of government policies that have helped spur its growth have pushed to roll back those incentives and mandates in state after state.

title: Suicide Bomber in Syria Was U.S. Citizen, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  A United States citizen working in Syria with a militant group backed by Al Qaeda conducted a suicide bombing there Sunday, in what is believed to be the first time an American has been involved in such an attack, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Of All the Track Coaches to Bring Aboard
description: How sad for USA Track & Field. It has clearly run out of credible coaches.

title: Belmont Park Hopes Old Song Will Break Triple Crown Drought
description: Between 1919 and 1978, 11 horses that won both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness went on to win the Belmont Stakes. In the 36 years since then, though, the 12 horses that won the first two legs of racings Triple Crown faltered before they got to the finish line  or even the starting gate  at Belmont Park.

description: CAIRO  The Benghazi militant group Ansar al-Shariah is under attack by a renegade former general trying to rid Libya of political Islam. But in response, the militia has taken aim squarely at Washington.

The process would be similar to the one currently used for restraining orders in cases of domestic violence.

Lacy cutouts  whether laser-cut or embroidered  turn summer whites into bona fide statement pieces. These ventilated items from the likes of Tods, Isabel Marant and Tabitha Simmons allow the wearer to keep cool in the heat, while their graphic patterns prove that eyelet fabric doesnt always have to be sweet and innocent.

When the odds have been longest, Chicago has been at its best, winning two Stanley Cups in the past four years. In reserve, there has always seemed to be a key goal, an extra gear  even a lucky bounce.

title: Iran: MERS Virus Reaches Its 20th Country
description: A deadly respiratory virus that originated in Saudi Arabia two years ago has reached Iran, infecting two sisters in the southeast province of Kerman, the health ministry reported. In a statement posted on the ministrys website, it said two other members of the same family had the symptoms of the disease, known as Middle East Respiratory Syndome or MERS, but their cases had not been confirmed. According to the World Health Organization, 636 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS have been reported, including 193 deaths. Most of the deaths have been in Saudi Arabia. Iran is the 20th country to report MERS.

title: Driver in Crash Posted About Speeding
description: An unlicensed teenage driver who struck and killed a 4-year-old girl last year while fleeing from the police in his familys S.U.V. had driven recklessly before and had bragged in Facebook posts and text messages about speeding, a prosecutor said in court on Wednesday.

title: Jury Awards $172 Million in Verdict Against New York City

title: A Farewell to Maya Angelou
description: Maya Angelou, the memoirist, poet and author of I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings, died Wednesday. Her manuscripts are being preserved at the Harlem-based branch of the New York Public Library.

title: A Juggled Yankees Lineup Turns a Nine-Game Trip Into a Winner

title: With Foul-Plagued James Forced to Sit, the Pacers Remain Standing
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Frank Vogel, the coach of the Indiana Pacers, was asked Wednesday about a positive stretch of play his team had compiled about 48 hours earlier against the Miami Heat. Was there anything the Pacers could build on heading into Game 5 against the Heat that night?

title: Oscar Dystel, Who Saved Bantam Books, Dies at 101
description: Oscar Dystel, who combined sharp editorial judgments, shrewd marketing and attention-grabbing covers to propel Bantam Books from the brink of collapse to pre-eminence in paperback publishing after World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 101.

title: Harold Baer Jr., Judge Whose Civil Liberties Rulings Drew Fire, Dies at 81
description: Harold Baer Jr., a federal judge in New York whose expansive interpretation of civil liberties drew intense criticism from Republicans and Democrats alike and became a partisan issue in President Bill Clintons re-election campaign in 1996, died on Tuesday in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 81.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 6:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (Before Sunset) in Paris that began nine years before that (Before Sunrise) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and Hank (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick), the son he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with Hank. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. And so they will fight about this  and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women  throughout the course of a day. Before Sunrise, Before Sunset and Before Midnight are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. This final installment, he added, is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect. Before Sunset (2004) will be shown at 8:15 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Happenings | A Literary Festival in Paradise

This weekend, 27 modern literary legends will descend upon the rural seaside town of Treasure Beach for the annual Calabash International Literary Festival, a three-day conference consisting of readings and themed discussions with Salman Rushdie, Zadie Smith, Colum McCann, Jamaica Kincaid, Paul Muldoon and other luminaries. It began in 2001, when the novelist Colin Channer joined forces with the poet Kwame Dawes and the producer Justine Henzell, whose mother built Jakes, to bring a world-class cultural event to their favorite place on the planet.

title: The Jobless Rate for Community-College Graduates Is Also Low
description: The federal governments main educational-attainment categories are fairly blunt. In particular, the some college category includes a wide array of people: Those who have dropped out of college without earning any degree, those who have earned a two-year degree meant to lead directly to a job (such as in nursing) and those who have earned an academic two-year degree that is often a first step toward a bachelors degree.

title: Alan Furst: By the Book
description: The author of Mission to Paris and, most recently, Midnight in Europe is a great fan of John le Carrs Karla trilogy. George Smiley is the all-time harassed bureaucrat of spy fiction.

title: If a Reference Cant Accentuate the Positive
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Black Lawyers Lose Ground at Top Firms
description: For black lawyers, the countrys top law firms are lonely places, according to a newly released tally.

title: Boehner and Pelosi Resist Cries for Ouster of Veterans Affairs Chief
description: WASHINGTON  As the list of lawmakers calling for the resignation of Eric Shinseki as secretary of veterans affairs grew by the hour Thursday, leaders in both parties worked to quiet the politics and find a legislative solution to the crisis of care at veterans health centers.

title: Abbas Seeks a New Government That Would Seal Alliance With Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority asked Rami Hamdallah, the prime minister, on Thursday to form a government of national consensus that would unite warring Palestinian factions for the first time in seven years and could send Israeli-Palestinian relations into a tailspin.

title: What Did You Think of Our Text-to-Text Lessons?
description: Last September we introduced a new lesson-plan format called Text to Text, in which we pair two texts that we think speak to each other in interesting ways, then pose questions and suggest a few activities for students to bring the writings together.

title: Senates Legislative Inactivity
description: The House has introduced fewer bills this Congress, but what about the Senate? The number of legislative proposals in that chamber has fallen by 23 percent compared with the last Congress, an even steeper decline than in the House. But in other respects, the changes in bill introductions in the Senate have roughly mirrored what has happened in the House.

title: Dish Network Says It Will Accept Bitcoin
description: Most of Dish Networks 14 million subscribers are probably not Bitcoin users. But that will not stop the company from accepting payments in the virtual currency later this year.

title: Man Group in Deal Talks With Numeric Holdings
description: LONDON  The British hedge fund manager Man Group said on Thursday that it was in discussions to possibly acquire Numeric Holdings, an investment manager based in Boston.

title: Latest News on V.A. Health Care Scandal
description: Bipartisan calls for the resignation of Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki are growing louder  and more bipartisan  and two House committees are meeting on Thursday to discuss the agencys problems treating veterans. The hearings follow a report that validated accusations that the departments hospital administrators manipulated patient waiting lists. Well be tracking the developments live throughout the day.

title: Advice From a New Yorker: Mind Your Own Business
description: Dear Diary:

title: What Brian Williams Should Have Asked Snowden
description: Updated, 11:16 a.m. | I miss Barbara Walters already.

title: Investment Chief Named for New York City Pensions
description: Scott Evans, a former head of asset management for TIAA-CREF, will be the next chief investment officer of New York Citys $150 billion pension system, according to the city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer.

title: In Expansion of No. 7 Line, One Problem: An Elevator
description: The fate of the newest addition to the New York City subway system could be traced last summer to the foothills of Appiano Gentile, at a work site beneath the northern Italian sun.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 14
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Brad Jefferson of Animoto, on Knowing Your Companys Heartbeat
description: This interview with Brad Jefferson, chief executive of Animoto, a video slide show service, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Life Beyond the Cancer Clinic
description: Three years.

title: Deceptive Dip in G.D.P. Points to Perils of Election Forecasting
description: An economic report issued this morning provides a good example of the hazards facing election forecasters. The Bureau of Economic Analysis reported that in the first quarter of this year, Gross Domestic Product, a broad indicator of the health of the economy, shrank at an annual rate of 1 percent. Even worse, an alternative and more accurate measure, called Gross Domestic Income, shrank at an annual rate of 2.3 percent. If that persisted, wed call it a sharp recession.

title: Americans More Worried About Warming Than Climate Change
description: Many scientists have come to prefer the term climate change over global warming. Climate change is a broader term that encompasses not only the warming of the planet in recent years but also the rise of severe storms, droughts and damaging winds. The choice of terms has important implications for polling because Americans give different answers to questions depending on which is used.

title: A Wine Week in London
description: As Paris, the capital of wine-loving France, wraps up its beer week festival, London, more known for ales and pubs, is uncorking its first wine week.

title: Elisabeth Moss in Talks to Star in The Heidi Chronicles on Broadway
description: On Sundays finale of the 2014 episodes of Mad Men, the copy chief Peggy Olson was single (but making eyes at the repairman), childless (yet loving to the neighbor boy, Julio) and newly 30 (though only Don knew). Her concerns and conflicts called to mind the life choices of Heidi Holland, the brilliant, lonely art historian in The Heidi Chronicles, the beloved Wendy Wasserstein play that won the Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award in 1989, with Joan Allen as Heidi. If a group of Broadway producers have their way, Peggy and Heidi will have something else in common: the actress Elisabeth Moss.

title: In Our Pages: May 30
description: 1914: Liner Empress of Ireland Sinks

title: Rape Allegations in a Haryana Village Underscore a Social Fracas
description: BHAGANA, India  On March 23, M., a 13-year-old girl in this Haryana village, said that she performed a nightly ritual with three of her friends. She joined them outside their neighboring houses and walked to the middle of the harvest-ready wheat fields belonging to the majority Jat community, where the girls relieved themselves.

title: Brad Pitt Punched at Maleficent Premiere
description: Brad Pitt was signing autographs outside the El Capitan Theater in Hollywood on Wednesday evening, on his way to the premiere of Maleficent, which stars his partner, Angelina Jolie, when suddenly, for a few seconds, it seemed as if he were back in Fight Club. While Mr. Pitt was signing and Ms. Jolie was posing for photographs, someone jumped over a metal barrier and took a swing at Mr. Pitt, striking him in the face. The alleged assailant, whom the police identified as Vitalii Sediuk, 25, was led away in handcuffs. Gus Villanueva, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Police Department, told Reuters that he was being held in lieu of $20,000 bail.

title: Sebastian Junger on His Companion Film to Restrepo
Urban Renewal, No Bulldozer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It has gone widely unremarked, maybe because its so obvious to people here, that tech firms in San Francisco have not (yet) been moving into new buildings; theyve been taking over old ones. Twitter has leased a onetime furniture mart on Market Street, and AirBnB has renovated a century-old industrial warehouse south of Market. Yelp occupies part of 140 New Montgomery downtown, the magnificent Art Deco former Pacific Telephone tower from the 1920s, lovingly revamped by Cathy Simon, an architect with Perkins & Will, and the developers Wilson Meany Sullivan.

title: It Rocks When Girls Go Punk
description: There is hardly a shortage of movies about rock n roll, but there are few as perfect  which is to say as ragged, as silly, as touching or as true  as We Are the Best!, Lukas Moodyssons sweet and rambunctious new film. The setting is Stockholm in 1982, hardly a legendary place or moment in the annals of modern music, but thats kind of the point. Rock n roll glory is wherever you find it, and whatever you make of it.

title: Thomas Piketty Responds to Criticism of His Data
description: Six days after The Financial Times launched an attack on the data behind Thomas Pikettys much-debated tome on inequality, Capital in the Twenty-First Century, Mr. Piketty has offered his first detailed response to the newspapers criticism.

title: Delaying Vaccines May Increase Seizure Risk
description: Childhood vaccinations like those for measlesmumpsrubella carry a small risk of seizures. Some parents postpone their childrens vaccinations because they believe the delay decreases the risk. But a new study finds the opposite may be true.

title: Laverne Cox: Blending In Was Never an Option
description: The actress talks to Eric Spitznagel about growing up in the South, the difficulties of writing a memoir and the fortuitous casting decision that landed her on "Orange Is the New Black."

title: Today in Small Business: A Square Deal?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Whoever Gets the Tony, He Wins
description: As campaign stunts go in this springs race for the Tony Award for best musical, Operation Liza went like clockwork.

title: A Chicago Hotel Honors a Street Photographer
description: A street photographer who worked in obscurity from the mid-50s until her death in 2009, Vivian Maier is now the subject of a theatrically released documentary, a BBC special and, most recently, the lobby of the Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel, Chicago.

title: Director of Happy in Tehran Video Is Reportedly Freed
