description: Sassan Soleimani, the director of Happy in Tehran, a viral YouTube tribute to Pharrell Williams that offended Irans conservative judiciary, was released on bail Thursday, according to the International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran, a New York-based advocacy group.

title: Italy Seeks $1.6 Billion in Damages From Roche and Novartis
description: PARIS  The Italian government is seeking $1.6 billion in damages from two of the worlds biggest drug companies  Novartis and Roche  for losses that it says the national health service incurred from the companies efforts to restrict competition in ophthalmic drugs.

title: Fund Within a Fund Creates a Conflict
description: Updated, 3:00 p.m. |

title: White House Stresses Widespread Energy Progress Ahead of New Climate Rule
description: The White House has released a report charting progress on several energy fronts that is clearly aimed at setting the stage ahead of President Obamas expected announcement next Monday of the first regulations restricting carbon dioxide from existing power plants. (Its been a very long journey  abetted by an important Supreme Court decisionsince President George W. Bush tried to restrict carbon dioxide from such plants and quickly reversed course.)

title: Image of the Day: May 29
Inside In Performance
description: A behind-the-scenes look at the making of our 2014 Tony Awards interactive.

title: House Panel Advances Bill on School Lunch Options
description: WASHINGTON  The House Appropriations Committee on Thursday passed an agriculture budget bill that included nearly $21 billion for child nutrition that would allow schools to opt out of White House nutritional guidelines passed in 2012. The vote was 31 to 18.

title: A Special Tony Awards In Performance
description: Scott Heller is the theater editor and deputy editor for Arts & Leisure at The New York Times.

title: To Young Minds of Today, Harvard Is the Stanford of the East
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In academia, where brand reputation is everything, one university holds an especially enviable place these days when it comes to attracting students and money. To find it from this center of learning, turn west and go about 2,700 miles.

title: Listen Up | Roisin Murphys Electronic Covers of Italian Pop Standards
description: Now is the time for me to make a record only I could make, says the inimitable Roisin Murphy. The 40-year-old singer is speaking in a charming Irish brogue over Skype, with birds singing in the background, about the full-length album of original material she plans to release later this year after a seven-year absence. But the comment could just as easily refer to her current project, Mi Senti an EP of electronic covers of Italian pop standards made famous by 60s and 70s icons like Mina and Patti Pravo, plus one Italian-language original. A remix of a track from the release, Ancora Ancora Ancora, debuts here.

title: Silicon Valley May Be in a Bubble, but Its Not 2000
description: Mary Meeker says Silicon Valley is not in a bubble.

title: Lawmakers Modest Proposal: To Pass Spending Bills on Time
description: WASHINGTON  The state of Congress is such that the performance of its most basic task  the orderly passage of annual spending bills that fund the government  has become this year a test of whether it can function at all.

title: International Observers Find Egypts Presidential Election Fell Short of Standards
description: CAIRO  Egypts presidential election fell short of international standards of democracy, two teams of foreign observers said Thursday, a day after the former military officer who led last summers military takeover won a landslide victory with more than 95 percent of the vote.

title: Turning Sturgeon Into High-Tech Sensors
description: Sturgeon in the Hudson River are being fitted with transmitters to see if noise from pile driving and construction on the new Tappan Zee Bridge is harming imperiled Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon.

title: Batting Practice Pitcher Cherishes Rise to the Big Leagues
description: On a charter flight from Toronto to New York for the Yankees home opener, on April 7, Derek Jeter called Danilo Valiente to the back of the plane.

title: Times Minute | The Pressure on Shinseki
description: With more findings about extended health care waits and malpractices for veterans, pressure mounts on the Veterans Affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, to resign.

title: Times Minute | The Pressure on Shinseki
description: In the Video

title: An Offer to Let the Mind Wander
description: The shiny black table reflects blue sky, banana fronds and distant birds with eyelash wings. Outside, signs for mortgages and driving lessons loom over this tired stretch of Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. But inside Spicy Lanka, clouds drift, as does the mind.

title: Scientists Report Finding Reliable Way to Teleport Data
description: Scientists in the Netherlands have moved a step closer to overriding one of Albert Einsteins most famous objections to the implications of quantum mechanics, which he described as spooky action at a distance.

title: Rapes in India Fuel Charges of Conspiracy by a Caste
description: NEW DELHI  The rape and murder of two teenage girls in an Indian village threatened to touch off wider strife on Thursday, when the father of one of the girls said the crime was the product of a conspiracy among Yadavs, members of the dominant caste in the area.

title: As Liberal Leaders Test Cuomo, de Blasio Stands by Him
description: They smiled at each other, trading gentle jokes and the political equivalent of sweet nothings. (The mayor was exactly right. I give the governor a lot of credit.) There was a high-five, and a manly half-hug.

title: Imperiled Sturgeon Watched in Tappan Zee Bridge Construction Zone
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  Call him the sturgeon surgeon.

title: When Union Membership Was Rising
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. U.S. Finds Unions Gaining Members, Reversing Trend appeared on May 25, 1964, and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: Lionboy a Highlight of New Victory Theater Season
description: As a house specializing in works for families and young audiences, the New Victory Theater may seem an unlikely place for Complicite, the British company known for shows that combine surreal imagery and psychological intensity. But the 2013 production of Lionboy, Marcelo Dos Santoss adaptation of material from Zizou Corders Lionboy novels  Complicites first family production in its 31-year history  will be coming to the New Victory in January. Lionboy, a highlight of the New Victorys 2014-15 season, will run from Jan. 23 to Feb. 1.

title: North Korea Will Investigate Fate of Abducted Japanese
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has agreed to open a new investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens abducted by its agents during the Cold War, the two countries said Thursday, signaling a possible diplomatic breakthrough in an emotional issue that has divided Japan and the North.

title: Surviving at the Poker Tables: Colson Whitehead Talks About The Noble Hustle
description: Colson Whiteheads new memoir, The Noble Hustle: Poker, Beef Jerky and Death, began as an assignment for the online magazine Grantland, which commissioned him to compete in and write about the World Series of Poker in Las Vegas. In the book, Mr. Whitehead writes about his anhedonic personality (I have a good poker face because I am half dead inside, it begins), his training with the help of a coach named Helen Ellis and his fate at the high-stakes tables. I recently spoke to Mr. Whitehead in a phone interview. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: F.D.A. Announces Stricter Rules on Tanning Beds
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced stricter regulation of tanning beds that are used by millions of Americans. The agency said that it would require manufacturers to put a black-box warning  one of its sternest  on the devices stating that they should not be used by anyone under the age of 18, but stopped short of banning their use by minors.

title: French Will Host Putin at D-Day Rites
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France will use D-Day commemorations next week as an opportunity to assume a more direct diplomatic role in the Ukraine crisis, becoming the first European leader to meet face to face with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia since the Western effort to isolate him for his annexation of Crimea.

title: An Increase in Recalls Goes Beyond Just G.M.
description: The growing number of recalls is spreading beyond General Motors.

title: Danspace Project to Showcase a New Generation of Artists
description: Six surprising pairings, putting major ballet figures with a new generation of New York dance artists, form the cornerstone of Danspace Projects Platform 2015, curated by the critic and poet Claudia La Rocco. Ms. La Rocco, who was a dance critic at The New York Times between 2005 and 2013, has named the platform after Edwin Denbys seminal compilation of dance writings: Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets. (Ms. La Rocco still contributes articles and reviews on theater for The Times.)

title: Kevin Reilly, Head of Foxs Programming, Is Stepping Down
description: The drastic falloff of American Idol has cost the Fox network dearly in terms of ratings and profits, and now it has contributed to the loss of its top entertainment executive, Kevin Reilly.

title: The Gun Report: May 29, 2014
description: Of all the shootings we cover, perhaps the most disturbing is when a parent shoots their own child.

title: Doctor Shortage Is Cited in Delays at V.A. Hospitals
description: Dr. Phyllis Hollenbeck, a primary care physician, took a job at the Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., in 2008 expecting fulfilling work and a lighter patient load than she had had in private practice.

title: Sculptors to Bring Works to City Parks
description: Seven sculptors from the Art Students League have been chosen to take part in this years edition of the Model to Monument program, a joint venture between the league and the Department of Parks and Recreation that places public sculpture in Riverside Park South on the Hudson River and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Businesses Less Gloomy About A.C.A. Impact on Hiring
description: Are American businesses coming to terms with the Affordable Care Act? A new survey suggests so, though its a tentative peace at best.

title: This Weekend: A Cuban Dance Troupe
description: This weekend be sure to check out the MalPaso Dance Company at the Joyce Theater. Also, there is a BookCon at the Javits Center and Ubisofts new adventure game, Watch Dogs is now available.

title: This Weekend: A Cuban Dance Troupe
description: In the Video

title: Rules of Style | The Founders of Juicy Couture on How to Succeed in Business
description: Not only are we designing 1o collections a year now, Pamela Skaist-Levy says, but theres a crazy big-player bidding war to turn our book into a TV show. Shes referring to The Glitter Plan, out today. Its the first memoir from the designer and her longtime business partner, Gela Nash-Taylor, the co-founders of Juicy Couture. Written in collaboration with the journalist Booth Moore, the book tells the story of two best friends who took a simple idea and turned it into one of the most successful fashion companies in history. We didnt go to Harvard Business School, Nash-Taylor says. Or any business school, for that matter. But we wanted to inspire and work off of an idea that came from a real passion to empower.

title: Moving Toward Digital First': A Talk With the Day Editor
description: Pitching and evaluating news. Deciding when to release stories. Planning the front page and the home page. This is the stuff of two daily news meetings held at 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. by The Timess masthead in the Page One conference room on the third floor.

title: The Flaws of Apples iMessage
description: [ Editors note: The columnist of this Bits post responded to several reader comments about iMessage. ]

title: Measles Cases in U.S. Reach a 20-Year High
description: Largely because of resistance to vaccination, cases of measles have reached a 20-year high in the United States, federal health officials said on Thursday.

title: New Appraisal of Detroit Institute Art Collection Is Underway
description: Officials handling Detroits federal bankruptcy proceedings, who have been accused by creditors in recent months of underestimating the value of works held by the city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts, told a judge on Wednesday that a comprehensive appraisal of the value of the collection is now underway.

title: Tiny Hot Rods Will Get Your Letters to Their Destination
description: Even as politicians debate ending Saturday mail delivery, the Postal Service is commemorating one of the enduring symbols of Saturday night youth rituals, the American hot rod, with a new stamp issue on June 6.

title: Concussions and an N.F.L. Paradox
description: WASHINGTON  In 2009, Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was skewered by lawmakers on Capitol Hill for denying the severity of concussions and failing to do more to help retired players with brain injuries.

title: Navigating Medicare Policy on Physical Therapy and Other Services
description: For years, some people on Medicare had difficulty getting insurance coverage approved for physical therapy, occupational therapy and other treatments. The prevailing approach was that if the therapy was not helping to improve a patients condition, then it was not eligible for coverage.

title: Jakkai Siributr: Transient Shelter
description: Tyler Rollins Fine Art

title: Darren Bader
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: Nancy Grossman: The Edge of Always, Constructions from the 1960s
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: Ohio Rolls Back Renewables
description: The big-money coalition attacking solar and wind power scored a huge trophy this week. On Wednesday, the Ohio legislature became the first in the country to roll back renewable-energy standards for power generation, a victory for fossil fuels, soot and greenhouse gases. Gov. John Kasich is expected to sign the bill shortly.

title: Image and Matter in Japanese Photography From the 1970s
description: Marianne Boesky

title: Mary Carlson: paradise
description: Elizabeth Harris

title: Mexican Authorities Arrest Head of Company Tied to Bank Fraud
description: Amado Yez Osuna, who headed Oceanografa, the oil services company at the center of a $400 million fraud involving Citigroups Mexico subsidiary, has been arrested, according to Mexicos attorney generals office.

title: A Jeff Koons Sculpture Is Coming to 30 Rock
description: FLOWER-COVERED KOONS COMING TO 30 ROCK

title: So Potent, They Were Fated to Be Smashed
description: A hotly debated issue among theologians in medieval Europe concerned what has since been called the cult of images. The controversy turned on beliefs about how people related to and used images of Christian subjects rendered by painters and sculptors. Proponents of images argued that they were educational and edifying. Iconoclasts feared that people would become enthralled by images and fall into the sin of idolatry.

title: A Chef in Search of a New Food Chain
description: Not long ago, Dan Barber, the chef and a co-owner of Blue Hill in Manhattan, and the animating force behind the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Westchester County, came up with a dish he calls Rotation Risotto. Its a manifesto on a plate, a tricky play on the Italian classic that uses, instead of rice, a medley of lesser-known grains: rye, barley, buckwheat and millet.

title: Friendship Was Their Medium
description: WASHINGTON  The friendship between Mary Cassatt and Edgar Degas is one of the few remaining mysteries of Impressionism. She was a wealthy, independent American suffragist who painted upper-class women tending children and taking in the opera; he was a Frenchman, a decade older, who spied on nudes in brothels and once said that women couldnt understand style.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: His Airness
description: Michael Jordan is the greatest basketball player who ever lived. Of that, there is very little dispute. He was also, at the apex of his career, a global ambassador for the game and for Nike (not necessarily in that order), a veritable A.T.M. for various corporate partners, a hero to millions, if not billions, of fans, and very likely the most famous person in the world. I know this because everyone knows it, and also because I witnessed at least a little bit of it all. I covered Jordan and the Bulls for an all-sports radio station in Chicago for four years while he was at the height of his power and fame.

title: Ex-Canadien Welcomes Chance to Play
description: Rangers defenseman Raphael Diaz was all smiles hours before Game 6 on Thursday at Madison Square Garden, thanks to a chance to re-enter the playoff fray and deny his former team, the Montreal Canadiens, a trip to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: 65-Story Tower Planned Near Grand Central Terminal
description: A developer plans to build a 65-story tower directly west of Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan that would soar 1,200 feet above 42nd Street, 150 feet taller than the landmark Chrysler Building, under a proposal by the de Blasio administration.

title: Gardening
description: It may be that, like the feckless Candide, we should quit tormenting ourselves about the terrible things over which we have no control  and just cultivate our gardens. Except we have very little control over whats happening there either. Plants inexplicably wilt, rot and shrivel; they suffer the depredations visited upon them by voles, moles and deer. And then theres global warming, giving booster shots to the poison ivy and generally wreaking havoc with droughts, downpours, blue northers and scalding heat waves.

title: Diffa Marks 3 Decades of Designers Fighting AIDS
description: The charity known as the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, or Diffa, turned 30 in April.

title: Our Shakespeare
description: Who is the American Shakespeare? The question has an odd, anxious quality that it wouldnt quite have if applied to Germany, say, or Russia. Its not just that in those cases, there is an answer ready at hand (Goethe, Pushkin), but that in the international context we know what the question means. Who is the founding poet to whom all subsequent writers must relate? Who established the parameters of the language within or against which all subsequent writers labor? Understood that way, the answer to the question for America isnt an American at all: Its William Shakespeare himself.

title: A Sister in the Shadow of Georgia OKeeffe
description: Georgia OKeeffe was disappointed in her painter sister Ida OKeeffe. A wasted life, she told the family when Ida died in 1961, at 71. The Dallas Museum of Art will tell Idas side of the story with an exhibition scheduled for 2017, Ida OKeeffe: Escaping Georgias Shadow.

title: Ghana Seeks More Than Just Another Cup Win Over U.S.
description: ACCRA, Ghana  The questions poured out of the official from the United States Embassy at the mere mention of a visit to Ghanas World Cup training camp.

title: Illusion
description: Magic, as Martin Strauss, the narrator of Steven Galloways novel The Confabulist, tells it, has four elements: An effect, which is one element, is achieved by way of the magicians method, which is another; method is hidden in misdirection, and a reconstruction is attempted afterward, by the audience. A magician seeks to choreograph a way through the trick with these component parts, Strauss explains. If he does so he will have achieved magic. If not, he is a failure.

title: Lenders Easing Up on Jumbo Mortgages
description: Underwriting guidelines remain rigid on the conforming loans guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, but lenders are becoming more accommodating on nonconforming, or jumbo, loans.

title: A Stonehenge for the Modern Age
description: BEACON. N.Y.  Minimalism was the late 20th centurys great hope for a heroic American art on the Abstract Expressionism model. Even after an upstart movement, Conceptualism  idea art  wafted in and blew old notions of heroic and art to bits, tradition-minded art lovers stayed loyal, and still do, to the Minimalist paradigm of greatness: abstract work thats commanding in scale, cleanly made and destined for expensive rooms.

title: An Art Weekend in Bushwick
description: Bushwick Open Studios, a free art event organized by a group of local volunteers, will run from tomorrow until Sunday in the Brooklyn neighborhood thats been lauded (and in some cases, decried) as the next coolest thing. What began as a midsize festival in 2006 with 85 studios has become an enormous, hectic jumble with more than 600 participants. For the duration of the weekend, galleries, studios, warehouses, basements, parking lots and other locales will be open to the public daily, with artists (such as Samantha French, whose work is pictured above)milling around to discuss their works. There will also be music, panel discussions and local food. Even with an online directory, an appand printed maps that can be found at one of B.O.S.s nine hubs, its an overwhelming amount of art to take in, so here is a shortlist of galleries and group shows not to be missed.

title: Following the Smoke Trail
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Exalting the Egg, as Star of the Show or a Sidelight
description: I never stopped eating eggs.

title: Bulletproof Jacket On
description: A bail bondsman in Brooklyn becomes a bounty hunter to search for missing clients.

title: To Get an A in Philanthropy Class, Give Away $50,000
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Vinay Sridharan must make it through microeconomic theory and the writings of Proust before the end of his senior year at Northwestern in June. But in one course, the final project is far less abstract: give away $50,000.

title: 85 Degrees, 100 Percent Free
description: Summer sure sneaked up on the Miser, who was looking forward to a nice long public whine about the brutality of the winter just past. But here we are, a couple of days from June, and theres no time for looking back. Not with months of fun FREE events on the way. Herewith, a summer Misers guide to New York City.

title: Wanted: Backup for Iron Man and Captain America
description: IT has been two years since the Avengers stopped alien forces in New York, preventing the Chitauri army from invading the planet. Now, they need backup to defend against the next attack. This is your opportunity to join the elite support network of S.H.I.E.L.D. agents that helps superheroes like Captain America, Iron Man and Thor protect Earth.

title: Clip: Maleficent
description: A scene from Maleficent, featuring Angelina Jolie.

title: Working to Upend His Own Identity
description: For a young artist, finding your voice is the ultimate quest. By the time midcareer rolls around  should the artist make it so far  that voice, long established, risks calcifying into something more like habit, what once seemed novel now overused, tired from repeated exertion.

title: WilmerHale Partner Named as S.E.C. Deputy Enforcement Director
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filled a hole in its enforcement roster on Thursday, naming a senior white-collar lawyer to the enforcement divisions No. 2 spot.

title: Artifacts With a Life All Their Own
description: WASHINGTON  What magic do museum artifacts wield? What gives these objects, documents, books, recordings and images such power? They arent artworks but are often encased in humidity-controlled vitrines. They arent amusements but are often offered up for visitors pleasures. They can be haunting, mysterious, resonant, provocative.

title: Dumped by Her Prince, So Watch Out
description: Angelina Jolie makes a fabulous monster. As the title character in Maleficent  a divertingly different rethink of an awfully old story  she breezes through the movie, part superstar, part superfreak.

title: Letters: American Punishment
description: American Punishment

title: Inner Childs Cuss Words and Zany Sondheim
description: Katie Finneran has that look in her eye. You know, the one in which a slightly crazed glint of mischief announces a personality that just cant help injecting a zany sense of the absurd into the most unlikely situations. I have a fast brain, she announced at Wednesdays opening-night performance of her cabaret show It Might Be You  A Funny Ladys Search for Home, at 54 Below.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | We Are the Best!
description: Lukas Moodysson narrates a sequence from his feature.

title: Of Missed Connections and Missteps Taken
description: The Chocolate Factorys white-walled performance space looks as if a bunch of drunken carpenters had competed in building eccentric structures with scrap lumber, wires and light bulbs. This setting reinforces the ideas that drive Karen Shermans One With Others, a dance-theater piece that opened Wednesday night about missed connections, inappropriate strategies, shaky relationships and the need for community among artists.

title: Lets Not Pretend to Be Who We Arent
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Kimberly Hbert Gregory in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below or subscribe on iTunes or Google Play Music.

title: Poes Lost Lenore Lives in Song and Dance
description: Last year, in announcing the inaugural NY Phil Biennial  an 11-day festival of contemporary music with 21 performances of 13 programs  Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, unabashedly invited comparisons with similar events in the visual arts. Not just the Whitney Biennial in New York, which focuses on American artists, but also the Venice Biennale, perhaps the worlds most prestigious showcase of international contemporary art.

title: If the Size Fits
description: I am a man of a certain age. (Lets just say I remember World War II.) I have a closet full of suits and ties when the occasion calls for them. But my true tastes run to the tightest, skinniest jeans I can find, fine wool sweaters, flip-flops or boots, and long colorful scarves. I am in pretty good shape for an old guy and like to think I look good packaged this way. But friends have criticized me for not dressing my age. Is there a cutoff at which men should burn their skinny jeans and opt for pleated khakis?

title: A Producer and His Pulsating, Rhythmic Ways
description: The event on Wednesday night at Webster Hall was billed Hudson Mohawke & Friends, and certainly, this Scottish producer who meshes thunderous dance music with tense hip-hop has plenty. Most notable: Kanye West, whom he worked with last year on Mr. Wests corrosive, rumbling, outstanding album Yeezus (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam). But also plenty of others: He is a frequent remixer and collaborator, spreading his monster-truck sound widely.

title: Theater Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for May 30-June 5
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Central African Republic, South Sudan, Ukraine and Israel.

title: Twitters Head of Engineering Steps Down
description: Christopher Fry, Twitters senior vice president for engineering and one of its highest paid executives, stepped down Thursday after little more than a year in the job.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for May 30-June 6
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Church-State Clash in China Coalesces Around a Toppled Spire
description: WENZHOU, China  For nearly a year, the Sanjiang Church was the pride of this citys growing Christian population. A landmark in the fast-developing northern suburbs, its 180-foot spire rose dramatically against a rocky promontory. Wenzhou, called Chinas Jerusalem for the churches dotting the cityscape, was known for its relaxed ties between church and state, and local officials lauded the church as a model project.

title: The Wars Not Fought
description: We owe Mother Jones, the magazine, a public service nod for a graphic tour last year of all the countries that John McCain has wanted to attack. Spanning the globe, the fist-first senator has called for violent regime change in more than half a dozen nations, ranging from all-out ground invasions to airstrikes to arming sides in endless sectarian conflicts.

title: Jazz Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Teenage Depression: They Spoke Out
description: To the Editor:

title: China Chafes at Christianitys Growth
description: As Christianity continues its rapid rise in China, some believers feel discriminated against by public policies and say that the government favors traditional Chinese religions.

title: Classical Music & Opera Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Obamas West Point Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: The European Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Augustine Who?
description: To the Editor:

title: Guantnamo Hunger Strike
Experimental Interludes
description: In 12 concerts during a six-day residency at the Stone, the intimate East Village space for experimental and avant-garde music, the Flux Quartet is presenting a range of pieces, including electroacoustic works, scores by drone pioneers and jazz. At the 10 p.m. show on Wednesday, Max Mandel, the Fluxs violist, was joined by the pianist Eric Huebner for a one-hour program featuring five works that spanned an array of moods and textures.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of We Are the Best!
description: In this video, the director Lukas Moodysson narrates a sequence from We Are the Best!, a film set in 1982 about three Stockholm girls who form a punk band.

title: Land, Ho! A Cerebral Blackbeard
description: In Crossbones, an adventure series that NBC rolls out on Friday night, John Malkovich makes his delightful Blackbeard considerably more cerebral than pirates generally are. And cerebral takes on a hilarious new connotation in one scene in the premiere: Blackbeard turns up with a porcupines worth of needles sticking out of his bald head, an effort to relieve headaches.

title: A Very Difficult Crosstown Move
description: At 220 tons, Cleopatras Needle appears to be the heaviest piece of stone brought into Manhattan since the time of the glaciers. Its journey in 1880 from Alexandria to America was routine, but its progress from the Hudson River at West 96th Street to Central Park was one of the sights of New York.

title: Dance Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 30-June 5
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for May 30-June 5
description: JAZZED! THE CHANGING BEAT OF 125TH STREET

title: Spare Times for May 30-June 5
description: HOUSING WORKS STREET FAIR AND OTHER EVENTS (Sunday, Monday and Wednesday) Books  and the people whose lives revolve around them  are the stars of several events at this SoHo bookstore at 126 Crosby Street, near Houston Street. Thousands of donated books, records and CDs can be scooped up for $1 each at a street fair, a fund-raiser for outreach programs run by Housing Works, on Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.

title: Saving the Earth With a Big Kaboom
description: Realism is too imprecise a term for Kelly Reichardts filmmaking. She is a more of a materialist, determined to capture how the world looks, how it feels and, at a granular level of detail, how it works. Her stories tend to be simple and starkly told. In Old Joy, two friends take a camping trip that tests their intimacy and raises painful, unspoken questions about their identities as 21st-century American men. In Wendy and Lucy, a young woman and her dog are stranded by car trouble en route to Alaska. In Meeks Cutoff, settlers in mid-19th-century Oregon lose their way.

title: This Weeks Movies | May 30, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Maleficent, Night Moves and A Million Ways to Die in the West.

title: Canadiens Defend Handling of Head Hit
description: Whether or not the Montreal Canadiens properly followed the N.H.L.s concussion protocol in dealing with forward Dale Weise was at issue Thursday before Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. At times, the controversy over Weise, an important fourth-line forward, seemed to overshadow the elimination game itself.

title: Storme DeLarverie, Early Leader in the Gay Rights Movement, Dies at 93
description: Storme DeLarverie, a singer, cross-dresser and bouncer who may or may not have thrown the first punch at the 1969 uprising at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, but who was indisputably one of the first and most assertive members of the modern gay rights movement, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. She was 93.

title: De Blasio Children to Be Saluted at Coney Island Mermaid Parade
description: New York Citys first family is officially becoming royalty.

title: Employees Suit Accuses Tiffany of Racial Bias
description: A group director for the jewelry retailer Tiffany & Company sued the company in federal court on Thursday, accusing his employer of a systemic, nationwide pattern and practice of racial discrimination.

title: Quoting Victims Mother, Judge Sentences Killer to 24 Years to Life
description: Over three days of testimony, detectives and a medical examiner had spoken of the crimes brutality, and a forensic psychiatrist had said that the admitted killer had a history of mental illness, and had stabbed the victim to death because he believed she was the Devil.

title: With a Little Bit of Pluck, a Mandolin Orchestra Revives
description: On a recent Tuesday evening, members of the New York Mandolin Orchestra crammed their music stands into a sitting room at the Atria Assisted Living Residence on the Upper West Side and played for an audience of two: an old man tapping his orthopedic shoes, and a woman in a wheelchair who appeared to be sleeping.

title: For Palestine, a Final May Be Just the Start
description: As an ambitious college student in Memphis, Omar Jarun dreamed of one day playing for the United States in the World Cup. But Jarun, a 6-foot-4 central defender who plays for the Ottawa Fury in the North American Soccer League, never made it onto the roster, and he is not headed to the 2014 tournament in Brazil.

title: Cutting Back on Carbon
description: Next week the Environmental Protection Agency is expected to announce new rules designed to limit global warming. Although we dont know the details yet, anti-environmental groups are already predicting vast costs and economic doom. Dont believe them. Everything we know suggests that we can achieve large reductions in greenhouse gas emissions at little cost to the economy.

title: Teaching an Old Law New Tricks
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  PRESIDENT OBAMA is expected to announce his much anticipated rule for power plants on Monday, requiring for the first time that older and dirtier plants reduce their carbon dioxide emissions, which account for a sizable share of the nations carbon pollution.

title: Obama Calls for Concussion Awareness
description: The president, representatives of professional sports leagues and young athletes at a White House summit called for more robust research into youth concussions.

title: The Price of a Sex-Slave Rescue Fantasy
description: WITH a sensational story of surviving child sex slavery in Cambodia, Somaly Mam became a worldwide icon, the best-selling author of a memoir and the head of a foundation raising millions in the name of saving girls and women from the sex trade, victims she recounted rescuing in dramatic brothel raids. Last year, introducing the State Departments annual Trafficking in Persons report, Secretary of State John Kerry called Ms. Mam a hero every single day.

title: After Crisis, a New Spirit of Reining In the Banks
description: It is widely believed that there has long been something that could be called a regulator-banker complex. People with similar views on the proper level of regulation move back and forth between the two groups. Their hats change, but not their policy preferences.

title: Searching for Her Sister, as Well as for Herself
description: The title character of Petra Costas poetic, intensely personal documentary essay, Elena, is her older sister, a Brazilian dancer and aspiring actress who settled in New York City and eventually committed suicide when Petra was 7. Years later, Petra, also an aspiring actress, followed in Elenas footsteps and moved to New York to study theater at Columbia. My mother always said I could live anywhere in the world, except New York, she recalls. I could choose any profession, except actress.

title: Underscoring Success of Live TV, Music Specials Will Make a Return
description: A MEDIA executive who has had a high profile on Madison Avenue is returning to the spotlight by reviving a pair of music-centered television specials he developed, signing sponsors and partners like AOL, Cumulus, LOral, Macys, Mazda, Time Inc. and Verizon.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Council Passes Bills Aiding de Blasios Quest to End Traffic Deaths
description: Cabbies who strike pedestrians in New York City can be prohibited from driving a taxi.

title: Clip: Filth
description: A scene from the film, directed by Jon S. Baird and featuing James McAvoy.

title: Public Defender System for Immigrants Facing Deportation Would Pay for Itself, Study Says
description: Every year, tens of thousands of people appear in immigration court to fight deportation orders without a lawyer to assist them. Many are poor and adrift, unable to speak English or understand the laws determining their fate.

title: A Dirty Cop. No, Really Dirty.
description: James McAvoy goes whole hog in Filth, an adaptation of a 1998 novel by Irvine Welsh, the Scottish author of Trainspotting. And by whole hog, I mean exactly that. His character, Bruce Robertson, who narrates the film, is an Edinburgh police detective sergeant on a catastrophic downward spiral. As he loses his sanity, he suggests a wounded wild boar on the rampage, dragging his entrails behind him as he charges around in circles. Compared with this maniac, the rotten policeman of two Bad Lieutenant films is a garden-variety bad boy.

title: An Island Marred by a Ferry Disaster and Sustained by Dogs
description: DONJI-RI, South Korea  This hamlet of cinder-block huts with blue and red roofs slumbered in a drowsy repose. Weeds with yellow flowers grew in the corners of dusty front yards and through cracks in the pavement of deserted alleys. The towns only hagwon, a private cram school, stood empty, because so many families with school-age children had moved away.

title: A World War II Veteran Works to Help Comrades
description: Jack Lombardi served his three years in the Pacific in World War II, repairing Navy ships and manning gun stations when Japanese planes appeared overhead.

title: Pacers Stephenson Gets in Jamess Ear, but Not in His Head
description: MIAMI  While LeBron James was preaching the importance of forward thinking, his coach, Erik Spoelstra, was acknowledging the value of addressing past issues.

title: Common Core School Standards Face a New Wave of Opposition
description: Opposition to the Common Core, a set of reading and math standards for elementary, middle and high school students that were originally adopted by 46 states and the District of Columbia, has gathered momentum among state lawmakers in recent weeks.

title: With Main Parties in Disarray, Frances Far Right Benefits
description: PARIS  Marine Le Pen, the leader of Frances far-right National Front, could not have come up with a better script if she had written it herself.

title: Jack Walsh: Brooklyn Without an Exclamation Point
description: Born and raised in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Jack Walsh, 54, grew up playing roller hockey behind the Prospect Park band shell. And he hasnt really left the neighborhood. This is Mr. Walshs 21st year as executive producer of the Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival run by BRIC, a nonprofit arts and media organization where he is also the director of performing arts. The festival, which opens June 4 with a concert by Janelle Mone, presents music, movies and dance parties at the band shell  all free, without reservations (except for benefit performances). He lives in Windsor Terrace with his wife, Trilby, who works at the Maurice Sendak Community School in Park Slope, and their son Colin, 17, a junior in high school. Another son, John, 20, is a student at the State University of New York at New Paltz.

title: Diego Cordovez, U.N. Envoy and Conflict Mediator, Dies at 78
description: Diego Cordovez, an Ecuadorean diplomat who, as a United Nations under secretary general, negotiated the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan in the 1980s, died on Saturday in Quito, Ecuador. He was 78.

title: Take a Mans Horses, Expect a Reckoning
description: Brooding and intransigent, Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas undertakes a brave and foolhardy act, not unlike the prideful horse merchant of the title. Its striking story of rebellion in an age of aristocracy is set in 16th-century France, adapted from a 19th-century novella by Heinrich von Kleist, a text ripe for reappraisal. But the severely beautiful film is painted in a dauntingly austere manner, as if lost in a war against itself, with confrontations underplayed and the rural landscapes making more of an impression than the detoured drama.

title: A Lifeline for Veterans Waiting for Care
description: In the wake of revelations that patients have waited for months to see a primary care doctor at a veterans medical center in Phoenix, the Obama administration announced in the past few days some reasonable steps to mitigate the problems. One important measure will move veterans who have been stuck too long up the waiting list. Another will offer those still facing waits of more than 30 days the option of using private hospitals and clinics.

title: Can Therapists Prevent Violence?
Time to Move on Dangerous Tank Cars
description: The main railway lines in New York have become superhighways for railroad tank cars filled with combustible crude oil. They rumble by the hundreds across the state as part of a surge in shipments from booming oil fields in North Dakota to terminals and refineries in the Northeast. It is up to the Obama administration to make those cars safer for everyone in their path.

title: At Belmont, No Bets on Race Weather
description: California Chrome has continued to train with ease at Belmont Park, and after a routine two-mile gallop Thursday, he schooled in the paddock for the first time since his arrival 10 days ago.

title: Sliding Toward Autocracy in Thailand
description: After taking power in a coup last week, Thailands top army general said the military would establish a genuine democracy in the country. But in practice, the military is operating an increasingly authoritarian government intent on silencing all forms of dissent or disobedience.

title: Maya Angelou Often Left New York, but She Always Came Back
description: Maya Angelous first New York City apartment was a modest place in Brooklyn. But when she left the city behind about a year ago, she also left behind a capacious brownstone in Harlem that she had transformed into a kind of salon, mixing dancers with activists, musicians with writers.

title: Clip: The Grand Seduction
description: A scene from the film featuring Brendan Gleeson and Taylor Kitsch.

title: The Arms Struggle in Chicago
description: The city of Chicago, bedeviled by street gang violence, refuses to give in to ever more restrictive court rulings against enactment of sensible gun safety laws. The Supreme Courts misguided 2010 decision ended the nearly 30-year-long ban on handguns in Chicago. In January, a federal judge ruled that the citys ban on retail gun shops was unconstitutional.

title: Brooklyn Yankee; Lonely Island; Food City
description: Willie Randolph played for almost as many New York professional sports teams as Gladys Gooding (the organist for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field and the Rangers and Knicks at Madison Square Garden). A graduate of Brooklyns Samuel J. Tilden High School, Randolph spent most of his playing career with the Yankees, capped it with the Mets, returned to coach for the Yankees and then managed the Mets.

title: Village, Suffering From Cuteness, Seeks a Doctor
description: Ah, those wacky foreigners and their impossibly charming villages. If theyre not posing naked for fund-raising purposes (Calendar Girls), theyre trying to collect a dead mans lottery winnings (Waking Ned Devine). The latest entry in this tradition is The Grand Seduction, and its adorable.

title: Major Reports and Testimony on V.A. Patient Wait Times
description: Problems with waiting times for veterans seeking medical care have been documented dozens of times by federal agencies over the past 15 years.

title: Who Would Want to Be Powerless Sleeping Beauty When Maleficent Roars?
description: Is every little girl born with a set of wings? Thats what I found myself wondering while watching Disneys new feature film Maleficent, which stars Angelina Jolie as the title character, also known as the mistress of all evil, first introduced to fans in the animated 1959 Disney classic Sleeping Beauty.

title: Steve Ballmer Said to Sign $2 Billion Deal to Buy Clippers
description: The former Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer has agreed to pay $2 billion for the Los Angeles Clippers, according to a person briefed on the negotiations. If approved by the National Basketball Association, the sale would end a troubling situation for the league and rank as one of the largest deals in sports history.

title: Global Investors Looking for Real Estate Bargains Flock to Spain
description: As one of the most moribund housing markets in Europe, Spain has become a magnet for global bargain hunters. Real estate prices are down as much as 50 percent from their peak during a housing bubble, and investors from Asia to the United States and Britain are flocking to Spain to try to catch the uptick.

title: The Autocracy Challenge
description: Its hard to remember, but back in the early 1990s there was a debate about how nations should emerge from Communism  the Russian way or the Chinese way. The Russians did political and economic reform together. The Chinese just did economic reform.

title: When 70s Guys Hit Their 70s
description: Theres much sympathy but little tension in P J Ravals new documentary, Before You Know It, a gentle portrait of three gay men of a certain age. As it hops across the country, the film depicts a generation that has seen profound advances in gay rights but struggles with common issues of aging.

title: Right to Be Forgotten? Not That Easy
description: LONDON  Eoin McKeogh knows how hard it can be to make the Internet forget.

title: Clip: Lucky Them
description: A scene from the film featuring Toni Collette and Thomas Haden Church.

title: No Boys Allowed (but Pageboys Abound)
description: To passers-by, Crops for Girls, a salon on East Ninth Street, resembles any of the dozens of chic beauty parlors in the neighborhood. The paint is rosy and bright, the mirrors are gilded and portraits of starlets dot the walls. But look closer and a subtle theme emerges. Each of those women  Audrey Hepburn, Louise Brooks, Jean Seberg  has short hair.

title: Tracking Down a Rock God, Despite the Emotional Risk
description: In Lucky Them, a seen-better-days critic, Ellie Klug (Toni Collette), writes for a seen-better-days magazine that covers alternative rock as if it were the only music in the pop universe. Ellie ignores deadlines and the marketplace, and is burdened by the kind of integrity that looks more like self-destructiveness. (In the real world, she would have been fired years ago.)

title: N.S.A. Releases Email That It Says Undercuts Snowdens Whistle-Blower Claim
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency on Thursday released what it said was the sole internal email from Edward J. Snowden before he fled with a trove of agency secrets, and officials asserted that the message undercut his argument that he protested the legality of surveillance programs before he released any of the documents he stole to journalists.

title: Teaching Landowners to Get Their Due
description: LIVE OAK, Tex.  At the front of a cramped classroom at the Alamo University Center, George Wilson, in a singsong voice, lectured about two dozen students on the finer points of the states laws on oil and gas royalties, spouting terms like Mother Hubbard clause, habendum clause and force majeure.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 29, 2014
Obamas Conference on Concussions Was Too Long in Coming
description: WASHINGTON  Not a single seat was empty in the East Room of the White House on Thursday during a conference, organized by President Obama, on the dangers of sports-related concussions.

title: Clip: Korengal
description: A scene from the documentary directed by Sebastian Junger.

title: Haunted by Combat, Yet Missing the Brethren
description: How boring is a soldiers life in the mountains of Afghanistan during the lulls between firefights? A serviceman interviewed in Korengal, the sequel to the 2010 documentary Restrepo, recalls that one day he and his Army buddies spent five or six hours arguing who would win in a fight between George Clooney and Fabio.

title: In Report, State Comptroller Is Cautious About Benefits of Casinos
description: ALBANY  Sounding a cautionary note about expanded gambling in New York State, Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli warns in a new report that casino complexes planned for upstate will face stiff regional competition and that much of the new revenue anticipated from the casinos will come from New Yorkers, not necessarily from out-of-state visitors.

title: At Core of Church-State Clash, Unease Over Christianitys Rising Influence in China
description: Buddhism and Daoism are embedded in Chinese traditional culture, the Rev. Matthew Zhen said after an early morning mass in Latin at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Beijing. But Islam, Christianity and Catholicism have a relatively short history in China. People need time to accept them.

title: Under Pressure, Hagel Promises to Act on Guantnamo Transfers
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, who is under pressure from within the Obama administration to step up his pace in approving the transfer of low-level Guantnamo Bay detainees, has told reporters that he would decide soon whether to accept a months-old offer to resettle six prisoners in Uruguay.

title: Going Into a Taliban Stronghold
description: When the history of the long war in Afghanistan is written, Kunar Province, the mountainous region near the Pakistan border that has been a Taliban stronghold, will fill more than one chapter. It is already a film source: Lone Survivor, the Mark Wahlberg feature, and Restrepo, the Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, both take place there. (Another new film, Korengal, revisits the Restrepo troops.)

title: Songs, Jokes and Twirls? Just Dont Tell Ayn Rand
description: It would be folly to adapt Ayn Rands pedantic novella Anthem as a straight stage drama, though some have recently tried. Far better to give that belabored paean to individualism a goofy, spoofy spin, as The Anthem, an exuberant musical adaptation at the Culture Project, does. The source material may be hopelessly schematic, but the show pours on dazzling trimmings, including a critical element absent in Rands didactic prose: humor.

title: Will Jonny Be Good? Hell and Heaven Wager
description: Once upon a time, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater and Rising Phoenix Repertory mounted A Fable, a saggy, perplexing parable by Rattlesticks artistic director, David Van Asselt. Imagine shredding the scripts of August Strindbergs A Dream Play and Bertolt Brechts A Mans a Man and forcing them into a Vitamix with the Book of Job, Voltaires Candide and a couple of Occupy Wall Street blog posts. Bottoms up?

title: Songs of Devotion, Songs of Rapture
description: The gift of being simple has never been widely associated with the Wooster Group, whose austere and profoundly affecting Early Shaker Spirituals opened on Thursday night at the Performing Garage in SoHo. Throughout its almost 40, unceasingly fertile years of existence, this genre-bending troupe has taken theatergoers through twisting labyrinths of productions, in which reality and its representations are splintered by technology and irony.

title: Star of Bombay
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  There are cross-referenced clues in puzzles that are there for no apparent reason, and there are cross-referenced clues in puzzles where you wind up learning something new. Todays puzzle by James Mulhern contains the latter.

title: Love Is Out of This World. Far Out.
description: People who fall in love actually physically fall down, weak-kneed, repeatedly. A woman with a broken heart carries it around in a brown paper bag. Thats the way the world works in John Carianis plays.

title: Billy Crystal Wins Top Audiobook Prize
description: The publishers and performers of audiobooks celebrated with a gala dinner and awards ceremony in New York on Thursday night. The big winner: Billy Crystal, whose recording of his best-selling book on turning 65, Still Foolin Em: Where Ive Been, Where Im Going, and Where the Hell Are My Keys?, won the prize for audiobook of the year and two other categories.

title: Feeling Tongue-Tied? Send a Manic Selfie
description: Adoption, unexpected pregnancies, blended-family tensions, May-December relationships: Emoticon ;) is stuffed with complexities. So why does it feel as facile as that irksome title?

title: Sweep Coincides With Delay on Deportation Policy Changes
description: On the same day that White House officials revealed that President Obama had delayed for two months making any decisions on changing his deportations policy, enforcement agents fanned out in immigrant neighborhoods in Milwaukee, detaining 21 foreigners in homes and workplaces.

title: Working Families Party Warns Cuomo of a Possible Opponent
description: For weeks now, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, a Democrat seeking re-election this year, has been working behind the scenes to soothe misgivings by the leadership of a small but influential political party made up of labor unions and liberal activists who believe his policies have veered too far to the right.

title: Mannings Quick Recovery Speeds Up Giants Transition to a New Offense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning, who sustained a high left ankle sprain in the Giants regular-season finale, against the Washington Redskins on Dec. 29, faced a hard decision when his ankle was slow to heal.

title: Events on Long Island for June 1-7, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: In Puerto Rico, Cocaine Gains Access to U.S.
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  With its navigation lights off, the 35-foot speedboat raced north toward Puerto Rico one night this month, its two large engines at full throttle. Above, a Coast Guard helicopter chased it and then let loose a few warning shots. But the boat roared ahead. Then, thwack, the crew on the copter shot out one of engines.

title: Clinton-Obama Lunch Hints at Continuing and Close Ties
description: President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton shared a private lunch on Thursday, a meeting that never appeared on any official schedule and that White House officials acknowledged only after People magazine posted on Twitter about it.

title: Mets Prevail Where Boos Arent Meant for Them
description: PHILADELPHIA  Over the last few weeks, as Chris Young fell into a funk and his average dipped below .200, he was booed mercilessly at Citi Field, and it felt as if the boos grew louder, deeper and meaner each time he walked back to the dugout.

title: Times Minute | Americas New It School
description: How Stanford passed Harvard as to become the top ranked university in the US. Also on the Minute, a White House concussion summit and Manohla Dargis reviews Maleficent.

title: Lundqvist Leads Rangers Back to Finals for First Time Since '94
description: Henrik Lundqvist leapt into the air as the final horn sounded, almost levitating with joy. He had just won the most important hockey game at Madison Square Garden in 20 years. The Rangers were headed to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Times Minute | Americas New It School
description: In the Video

title: Foreign Jihadis Fighting in Syria Pose Risk in West
description: LONDON  Two years ago, a young man who now calls himself Abu Muhajir slipped into Syria with a few friends and $80,000, forsaking what he said was a job as a high school science teacher in North America to wage jihad.

title: U.S. Strategy to Fight Terrorism Increasingly Uses Proxies
description: WASHINGTON  During the height of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the United States military often carried out dozens of daily operations against Al Qaeda and other extremist targets with heavily armed commandos and helicopter gunships.

title: Events in New Jersey for June 1-7, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles Selects New Chief Curator
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles  which has climbed back from the brink of financial dissolution and secured donations and pledges of more than $100 million for its endowment in recent months  has selected Helen Molesworth, a widely respected scholar and writer, to be its next chief curator.

title: North Carolina: Another Death Investigated at Army Hospital
description: The Army is investigating the death Thursday of an 11-month-old baby who had been treated and released less than a week earlier at the emergency room at Womack Army Medical Center at Fort Bragg for a viral infection. In the past two weeks, two patients in their 20s died shortly after treatment at the hospitals emergency room. The hospital commander was stripped of his post on Tuesday and three deputies were suspended after those deaths. An Army spokesman said emergency workers responding at the babys home on the base were unable to resuscitate the child.

title: Envestra Directors Endorse Li Ka-shing Takeover Bid
description: HONG KONG  Li Ka-shing, Asias richest man, gained the upper hand on Friday in a bidding war for Envestra, an Australian natural gas distributor, after the target companys independent directors endorsed a $2.2 billion takeover offer from companies controlled by Mr. Li.

title: A Wisconsin Farm Fights Warming, With Californias Help
description: Pagels Ponderosa Dairy benefits from a California initiative that invests in projects to cut greenhouse gasses as part of the battle against climate change.

title: Online Chats Between Sexes Denounced in Saudi Arabia
description: A senior Saudi Arabian cleric has issued an edict against online chatting between the sexes, equating such activity to the prohibitions on the physical mingling of unrelated men and women, the news agency Al Arabiya  reported Thursday. It said the cleric, Sheikh Abdullah al-Mutlaq, a member of the Saudi Committee of Senior Scholars, had warned that such conversations were religiously forbidden and might lead to sin. Al Arabiya quoted the cleric as saying the devil would be present when women talk to men on social media network sites. It was unclear how seriously the clerics declaration would be enforced in Saudi Arabia, where roughly half the population of 27.3 million are Internet users, an estimated six million use Facebook, and online chat forums appear to be common. Social media for political messaging in Saudi Arabia is strictly forbidden, however. Reporters Without Borders, a press freedom advocacy group, has classified Saudi Arabia as among the most repressive countries in a global ranking on news and information censorship.

title: Rory McIlroy Puts Troubles Aside and Continues His Hot Streak
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  On the 20th shot of his opening round at the Memorial Tournament, Rory McIlroy tweaked his left knee when his spikes got stuck in the ground. For the rest of the day, McIlroy said, his thought process was stripped to the bare essentials: find the fairways, hit the ball close and make the putts.

title: Events in Connecticut for June 1-7, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: After a Lifetime of Obscurity, a 77-Year-Old Ceramicist Finally Hits the Big Time
description: Stan Bitters is one of the art worlds best-kept secrets. The 77-year-old ceramics sculptor from Fresno, Calif., has been creating large-scale architectural works, like the two-story outdoor fireplaces at the Ace Hotel in Palm Springs, for more than half a century. Yet he remains relatively unknown outside his home state. That may change this Saturday when his first solo show in more than 35 years, Stan Bitters: Modern Primitive, opens at Heath Ceramics Boiler Room event and exhibition space in San Francisco.

title: Ask Well: Exercise After Knee Replacement
description: Question:

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 30, 2014
description: A simple way of understanding what happened here is that you have a collision between a right to be forgotten and a right to know.

title: Word of the Day | ghastly
description: ghastly \gast-le\ adjective

title: Iraq War Inquiry Gets Bits of Leaders Talks in Britain
description: The British government agreed on Thursday to give the gist of conversations between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President George W. Bush while they were in office to an inquiry panel looking into the Iraq war. The agreement between the government and the inquiry, led by John Chilcot, will allow publication of some selected quotations from Mr. Blairs exchanges with Mr. Bush, but will not include any of Mr. Bushs replies, Mr. Chilcot said in a letter to Jeremy Heywood, the British governments top civil servant. Detailed consideration of gists and quotes requested by the inquiry has now begun, and quotations will be kept to the minimum necessary to enable the inquiry to articulate its conclusions, Mr. Chilcot said. The deal comes after months of deadlock over what would be released; the report is expected to be published before the end of the year. At issue are about 25 written notes from Mr. Blair to Mr. Bush and more than 130 records of conversations. The inquiry was set up in 2009 and was expected to report in 2010. The last public hearings took place in 2011.

title: A Price Tag on Carbon as a Climate Rescue Plan
description: KEWAUNEE, Wis.  Bryan T. Pagel, a dairy farmer, watched as a glistening slurry of cow manure disappeared down a culvert. If recycling the waste on his familys farm would help to save the world, he was happy to go along.

title: Spurs Take Another Step Toward Redemption
description: SAN ANTONIO  When the San Antonio Spurs returned from Oklahoma City to regroup from two convincing defeats that had evened the Western Conference finals, they had the opportunity to sleep in their own beds, shoot at familiar rims and be surrounded by their supportive fans.

title: Events in Westchester for June 1-7, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: More Emergency Centers Are Gearing Up to Receive 911 Texts
description: With eight of 10 Americans using their cellphones to send or receive text messages, some emergency response centers are updating their technology. Among them are centers in 12 Texas counties, hoping to accommodate situations in which calling 911 may be risky or impossible.

title: Primaries Signal a Turn Right in Senate
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Moore Shows Knack for Playoff Heroics
description: If there was a player destined to score the goal that sent the Rangers into the Stanley Cup finals for the first time in 20 years, it was Dominic Moore.

title: Marion Bartoli Has No Regrets Over Tennis Retirement
description: PARIS  The first order of business, with Marion Bartoli sitting across the table at the French Open, was to reconfirm.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 11 P.M. (TV5Monde) MONSIEUR HIRE (1989) When a young woman is killed in a Paris suburb, the police immediately suspect the resident loner (Michel Blanc), a tailor who was once jailed for indecent exposure, and whom nobody seems to like. Sandrine Bonnaire plays his pretty neighbor, who never thinks to pull down the shades on the windows facing his, whether shes dressing or undressing or even making love to her neer-do-well boyfriend. This French melodrama, directed by Patrice Leconte from a novel by Georges Simenon, has the makings of a first-rate psychological study, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. But here, he added, Mr. Lecontes normally lighthearted touch is both artificial and heavy, filled with movie gestures that are not entirely fresh.

title: Turkish Court Says YouTube Ban Is Unconstitutional
description: Turkeys highest court ruled Thursday that a government ban on the video-sharing site YouTube was unconstitutional and a violation of freedom of expression. The Constitutional Court sent its ruling to the Telecommunications Authority, but it was not immediately clear whether the agency would lift the ban. Last month, the government removed a ban on Twitter a day after the court issued a similar ruling. YouTube was blocked in Turkey on March 27 after recordings from a secret meeting between Foreign Ministry officials detailing plans for possible military intervention against Syria were leaked to the site. The telecommunications agency said the ban was a precautionary administrative measure amid concerns over national security.

title: Naked Officials Feel Heat of China Anticorruption Drive
description: Bureaucracy is something of a national obsession in China, where its an old and honored tradition, with a secure government job regularly ranking as the most popular employment choice of many of the countrys elite students.

title: Corrections: May 30, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mediobanca Bolsters Roster in London With Ex-Barclays Banker
description: LONDON  The Italian bank Mediobanca said on Friday that it had hired Francesco Canzonieri, a former Barclays and Goldman Sachs banker, to bolster its investment banking roster in London.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 30, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: For One Woman, Uighur-Vietnamese Days in China
description: Thanhtu Dao was working for a Vietnamese company at a commercial exhibition in Shenzhen in mid-May as anti-Chinese rioting flared in Vietnam, in reaction to Chinas deployment of a deep-sea oil rig in disputed waters in the South China Sea.

title: Indian Police Seek 2 in Rape and Murder of Girls
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian police said Friday that they were scouring the countryside to find two more men accused in the rape and murder of two teenage girls in an Indian village this week, an attack that threatened to stir angry passions against the dominant caste in the area.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Americas It School? Look West, Harvard
description: In Americas It School? Look West, Harvard, Richard Prez-Pea writes about how and why Stanford may be becoming the gold standard of American education.

title: What Can You Predict About the Future of the Music Industry?
description: Vinyl albums, eight-track tapes and cassettes are old school. But so are CDs now. Will digital downloads, like MP3s from iTunes, be next? Are we deep into a new revolution where we get most of our music from streaming services, like Spotify, Pandora and now Beats? And whats the next big thing after that?

title: Bulletproof Jacket On
description: Correction appended.

title: China Moves to Calm Restive Xinjiang Region
description: BEIJING  As the Communist Party struggles to tamp down a deadly wave of ethnic violence in Xinjiang, the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, has called for tighter state control over religion and for better assimilating Uighurs into Chinese society, including moving more Uighurs from Xinjiang to other parts of China, where they can live among the Han, the nations dominant ethnic group.

title: Modi Opposes Efforts to Include Him in History Books
description: NEW DELHI  Three Indian states  Rajasthan, Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh have proposed including the life of the new prime minister, Narendra Modi, in classroom textbooks and in school curriculums, though Mr. Modi has expressed his reluctance to be included.

title: Extensive Security Displays Follow Attacks in China
description: Following a series of deadly terrorist attacks, Chinese cities have seen an increase in public displays of security.In Beijing, the police battled mock rioters on Thursday in a drill to respond to mass disturbances. Some of the Chinese capitals subway stations have begun airport-style security checks, creating long lines of passengers waiting behind security fencing.

title: European Agency Reports Surge in Illegal Migration, Fueling a Debate
description: LONDON  Even as its leaders grapple with populist demands for curbs on migrants, Europe is facing a surge of asylum seekers risking their lives to escape war and poverty in Syria, Afghanistan and elsewhere, according to new assessments on Friday.

title: New York Today: Go Play Outside
description: Good morning to you on this pleasant Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: How Old Is Too Old for President? Depends Whos Running
description: Does a candidates age matter in presidential elections? Its less relevant than you might think.

title: Obama on Americas Role in the World
description: In a speech to cadets at the United States Military Academy, President Obama described his vision of American foreign policy.

title: In Our Pages: May 31
description: 1914: Giant Liner on Maiden Voyage

title: Google Takes Steps to Comply With Right to Be Forgotten Ruling
Daily Report: Hurdles to Privacy on Web in Europe
description: Eoin McKeogh knows how hard it can be to make the Internet forget, Danny Hakim reports.

title: Russia and Ukraine Keep Talks Alive in Gas Feud
description: BERLIN  Russia and Ukraine on Friday agreed on a murky compromise in their gas price feud that would allow negotiations to resume in earnest on Monday, according to ministers from the two countries and the European commissioner brokering the talks.

title: Egypts Looted Antiquities
description: Since 2011, Egypts police force and other governmental authorities, overwhelmed by political upheaval, have let their protection of the countrys thousands of archaeological sites and museums fall to a bare minimum. Looters have taken full advantage of this opportunity.

title: We Met the Story, and It Was Us
description: Sometimes a story hits very close to home. Sometimes it lands on top of you. Peter Lattman, a former DealBook reporter, became media editor late last year. Earlier this month, he was placed in the particularly tricky position of having to oversee coverage of the firing of The Timess executive editor, Jill Abramson, which was announced on May 14. Since the dust appears to have settled  at least for now  we asked him to discuss what that was like.

title: Dots, a Highly Addictive Game, Now Has a Successor
description: I was a little groggy and tired this morning, and thats entirely my own fault. I was up most of the night playingTwoDots,a new version of Dots,the highly addictive iOS game.

title: Return of the Brilliant Jerk
description: It caused a bit of a stir (and elicited more than 150 comments) when I wrote in 2012 that, no matter how painful it may be, fast-growth entrepreneurs have to fire the Brilliant Jerk if they want to take their companies to the next level. Now we have a surprising postscript to add: what happens when the business owner decides to rehire the Brilliant Jerk.

title: Why Is Amazon Squeezing Hachette? Maybe It Really Needs the Money
description: Over the course of nearly two decades, Amazon has hewed to a consistent philosophy: Its all about the customer. The retailer is so devoted to its customers that it takes the profits that would normally go to shareholders and gives them to shoppers in the form of faster delivery and lower prices. It was a brilliant strategy that has propelled the company to the top ranks of American businesses.

title: Whats News in Washington: V.A. Scandal Comes to a Head
description: GoodFridaymorning on this holiday-shortened week. Washington is on Shinseki watch, following a flood of calls for the Veterans Affairs secretary to resign.

title: Young Players in Womens Draw Continue Their March
description: PARIS  After 20-year-old Garbie Muguruza upset No. 1 Serena Williams on Wednesday, she said now is the moment for the next generation in womens tennis.

title: The Wrong Afghan Friends
description: At a checkpoint on a dirt road in southeastern Afghanistan in 2012, Rahim Sarobi, a farmer, braked to a stop behind a knot of idling cars. Up ahead, Afghan gunmen were piled into the back of a Toyota Hilux. On the ground, tied to the rear fender by their wrists, lay two bloodied men, laboring to breathe.

title: Food Fight
description: FOOD FIGHT | A week ago, many shareholders of Hillshire Brands were complaining about its planned acquisition of Pinnacle Foods, the maker of Birds Eye frozen vegetables. But in the last week, Hillshire  the home of its namesake lunch meats, Ball Park hot dogs and Jimmy Dean sausages  has gone from would-be pursuer to pursued, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. On Thursday, Tyson Foods bid $6.8 billion for the company, only two days after a $6.4 billion proposal by Pilgrims Pride, one of the countrys big poultry producers.

title: Master of the Game (Diploma Says So)
description: On the eighth floor of a building in Downtown Brooklyn, college students gather regularly  in a library, no less  to play video games. They arent procrastinating. Theyre doing their homework.

title: Another Moratorium on State-Sponsored Killing
description: The way things are going, Tennessee may not be alone for long in choosing to revert to killing its citizens with electricity rather than drugs.

title: V.A. Chief Eric Shinseki, Set to Meet Obama, Apologizes for Systemic Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, apologized to veterans and lawmakers on Friday for the agencys mismanagement of the nations veterans hospitals as he prepared to meet with President Obama, his job on the line, over the widening scandal.

title: Pasta, Wine and Laughter
description: Dear Diary:

title: Oh, Magoo, Youve Done It Again
description: As Mickey Mouse was for the Depression and Bugs Bunny for World War II, so the acutely nearsighted Mr. Magoo was for the atomic age: an animated mascot, whose 53 theatrical cartoons have been repackaged in Mr. Magoo: The Theatrical Collection (1949-1959), a four-DVD box from Shout! Factory.

title: Luxe Bohemian Wear, Just in Time for Summer
description: At a time when fashion moves at an ever-more-rapid speed, Talitha  a London-based label founded in 2013 by the fashion editor Kim Hersov and the textile entrepreneur Shon Randhawa  offers a welcome change of pace. With an emphasis on traditional Indian craftsmanship, exceptional fabrics and fuss-free silhouettes, it provides an elevated vision of bohemian chic. From kimono wrap jackets to hand-embroidered peasant blouses, butter-soft suede capes and block-printed tunics with tassel adornments, each piece is designed with longevity in mind.

title: Companies Quietly Apply Biofuel Tools to Household Products
description: Consumer products containing ingredients made using an advanced form of engineering known as synthetic biology are beginning to show up more often on grocery and department store shelves.

title: Flights of Scaly, Fire-Breathing Fancy
description: This is a particularly good time for lovers of cinematic dragons. Thanks to advances in animation software and live-action visual effects, and a growing skill set among the artists who use them, scores of scaly beasts are taking over screens big and small: Theres Maleficent, which opened Friday, featuring a CGI homage to the dragon from Disneys 1959 animated classic Sleeping Beauty; How to Train Your Dragon 2 this month, which revisits the Viking fliers of the 2010 original; the current Godzilla, starring an honorary dragon if there ever was one; and Game of Thrones, whose threesome of dragons will continue to terrorize goats and assorted humans through the season finale on June 15.

title: U.S. Officials Say Most Russian Troops Have Left Ukraine Border
description: SINGAPORE  Russia has withdrawn most of its troops from the Ukrainian border, Pentagon officials said, but cautioned that some seven battalions, amounting to several thousand men, remain.

title: Suspects Friend Accused of Hindering Boston Bombing Inquiry
