description: BOSTON  A citizen of Kyrgyzstan who federal prosecutors said bought dinner for the two brothers accused of the Boston Marathon bombing on the night of the attack was charged Friday with obstructing the investigation into the bombing.

title: For Lessons About Class, a Field Trip Takes Students Home
description: Some of us have more toys and bigger homes than others. We all have a lot in common, but there are certain things that make us unique, too. Lets talk about those things and celebrate them, even.

title: India Continues Slow Pace of Economic Growth
description: MUMBAI  Indias economy grew 4.6 percent in the three months ended in March, the last full quarter under the Congress party-led administration, demonstrating the challenges ahead for the newly elected government under Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

title: Thomas Doubting Refuted
description: OK, Thomas Piketty has replied at length (pdf) to the attempted takedown of his work by Chris Giles, and done it very effectively. Essentially, Giles tried to compare apples and oranges, and the result was a lemon.

title: Video Reviews of Maleficent, Night Moves and A Million Ways to Die in the West
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review Maleficent, Night Moves and A Million Ways to Die in the West. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Steve Ballmer Said to Sign $2 Billion Deal to Buy Clippers
description: Steve Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive, has agreed to pay $2 billion for the Los Angeles Clippers, according to a statement released by Rochelle Sterling, a co-owner of the team. If approved by the National Basketball Association, the sale would end a troubling situation for the league and rank as one of the largest deals in sports history.

title: New York City Trying to Help Households Turn Waste Into Compost
description: For the first week or so, the brown bins hunkered on the streets like alien capsules that had fallen to Earth: gingerly stepped around, uneasily eyed, tenaciously ignored. One was pressed into service as a wastebasket for empty liquor bottles. Another was unceremoniously tossed in a street-corner trash can.

title: Horror
description: Reading a book is a dangerous thing, says Remshi, the protagonist of Glen Duncans BY BLOOD WE LIVE (Knopf, $25.95), speaking, you might say, the wisdom of the ages: Hes the worlds oldest vampire, 20,000 years young, give or take. A book, he goes on to say, can make you find room in yourself for something you never thought youd understand. Or worse, something you never wanted to understand. Although its always risky to attribute the thoughts of a fictional character to its creator, its a reasonably safe bet that this bloodsuckers sentiments arent far from those of the novelist, who has made a habit of writing books about things most of us would rather not understand too well.

title: Cooking
description: Cookbooks come in all sorts. Some offer new twists on old recipes or update a familiar cuisine. Others are lavishly tricked out, with production values worthy of Masterpiece Theatre. Still others have the brute functionality of car-repair manuals. There are star-vehicle cookbooks, travelogue cookbooks, definitive magnum-opus cookbooks and I love America cookbooks, not to mention quasi-religious farm-to-table, vegan and vegetarian manifestoes.

title: $2 Billion for Clippers? In Time, It May Be a Steal for Steve Ballmer
description: Men with vast fortunes who have bought professional teams as toys are not uncommon. Whether they considered the franchises sound investments is almost beside the point.

title: More Cookbooks
description: This season, theres a cookbook to suit every possible taste, including some from authors whose names will be familiar to regular readers of The Times:

title: Damon Lindelof Promises You His New Show Wont End Like Lost
description: A few months ago, inside a house in Douglaston, Queens, Justin Theroux, the star of the new HBO show The Leftovers, was in the kitchen, having his feet blow-dried. Theroux had been shooting a scene in which he had to run outside in the snow in bare feet, jump a fence, then put out a fire  over and over. When he retreated to the living room between takes, a conversation about the limitations of human feet ensued among the various people assembled, which led seamlessly to a vigorous and enthusiastic discussion about the magician David Blaine, who was once frozen in a giant block of ice.

title: The Mark of Cane
description: Take off your jacket; everything out of your pockets, the officer said. Now. Everything. I stripped my jacket inside out and fumbled through my jeans, torn receipts fluttering to the carpet as I emptied my pockets. I dumped everything on the table in front of me: wallet, phone, eyedrops, matches, lighter.

title: Reply All: The 5.18.14 Issue
description: WHO GETS TO GRADUATE?

title: Novel Gaming
description: A melding of forms; graduation groaners.

title: Slaughter for Hire
description: I have recently been worrying about eating meat, but not for health, religious or even environmental reasons. I worry about whether it is ethical for another reason: Could I kill an animal myself? And eat it? Would I have the stomach to do that? If the answer is yes, then I am paying for the service out of convenience. But if the answer is no, then am I a hypocrite for paying someone else to do my dirty work? Is it ethical to pay someone else to kill an animal because I cant, or dont want to know whats involved? M. R., NORTH CAROLINA

title: Who Made That French Press?
description: From the beginning, the French devoted more attention than any other people to coffee brewing, William Harrison Ukers wrote in All About Coffee, published in 1922. The first French coffee maker appeared around 1800, Ukers claimed, and the first one made of glass followed 40 years later. Though Ukerss encyclopedic work defined dozens of devices, it never mentioned the simple plunger-style vessel that weve come to call the French press.

title: The Moat, the Millions and the $50 Timex Watch
description: For the last four years, my brother and his family lived in a house with a moat. The house  a four-bedroom French villa in Bel Air previously owned by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony  is pretty impressive even without the moat, but that unnecessary protective trench gives the house a certain surreal charm. Its nice to know that when you visit your family for the holidays, you dont have to worry about Spanish conquistadors.

title: Reading Goals for the Dog Days
description: Its that time of year for guilty reading, but the leisurely months also offer an opportunity for more ambitious projects. I asked people at The Times if they had any goals for the coming weeks.

title: Comic Relief
description: Bob Mankoff is The New Yorkers cartoon editor as well as a cartoonist himself. I may not have the best job in the world, but Im in the running, he writes in the introduction to his book How About Never  Is Never Good for You? My Life in Cartoons, which is not just a charming memoir but also a charming grab bag of cartoon history, cartoon theory (nothing too woolly) and shoptalk. The title is taken from Mankoffs best-known drawing. Businessman on phone, consulting datebook: No, Thursdays out. How about never  is never good for you? As its author points out  false modesty is not one of his faults  that line has entered the vernacular, alongside other classics from the magazine such as I say its spinach, and I say the hell with it (drawing by Carl Rose, caption by E. B. White); Well, back to the old drawing board (Peter Arno); and On the Internet, nobody knows youre a dog (Peter Steiner).

title: Drawn From Life
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: Housing on the Mend, Ever So Gradually
description: ONE way to tell the housing market is beginning to show signs of health would be that builders of new homes are selling more houses than banks do.

title: They Love Paris
description: Cole Porter isnt the only American to have fallen in love with Paris in the springtime, which may explain why four books about Europes most beguiling city have appeared all at once. By pure serendipity, their four authors have independently succeeded in producing a chronological quartet.

title: The Dark Side
description: Robert Louis Stevensons The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is an oblique and artful Gothic tale framed as a detective story. The truth seeker is Jekylls lawyer, Utterson, the books most prominent character. Jekyll  the gentleman who dabbles in chemical self-transformation  appears only intermittently, never fully speaking for himself until the end, when he discloses the details of the disastrous experiments that unleashed his primitive alter ego. The novel isnt a conventional horror story, lingering on the macabre for its own sake, but an allegory of the divided self, perhaps also a meditation on addiction. Stevenson dramatizes human duality but doesnt analyze its causes, treating it as pervasive and fundamental. For him, the Jekyll-Hyde split is the split in all of us, between the animals we evolved from and the angels we aspire to be.

title: Life Out Loud
description: When Brittney Griner was a senior in high school, a 6-foot-8 center on her way to an all-American basketball career at Baylor University, she feared telling her father that she was a lesbian. His explosive, curse-filled response upon finding out, Griner writes in a painful, searing and ultimately liberating memoir, In My Skin: My Life on and Off the Basketball Court, was exactly what she had dreaded.

title: Science Fiction
description: In Annihilation, the first book of Jeff VanderMeers Southern Reach trilogy, readers were introduced to Area X, a stretch of coastal wetland whose conspiracy-theory name is the icing atop a mille-feuille of layered, slow-building, deliciously creepy horror. Twelve teams of researchers, stripped of names to somehow protect them from the identity-warping effects of the danger zone, have traveled into Area X; Annihilation followed the biologist as she seemingly became the only survivor to actually understand what was happening.

title: Thrillers
description: I had the wrong idea about beach books. It came from Goodbye, Columbus, where Neil Klugman tells Brenda Patimkin that his cousin Doris always has War and Peace by the pool: Thats how I know its the summer, when Doris is reading War and Peace.  Pool and beach being the same to me back then  an idiot kid forced to sit outside with no TV, uncomfortable with my shirt off as my grandfather paraded around to show off he still had a body  I didnt see that Philip Roth was mocking Doris, and so for years protected myself from the water and sand I resented and feared by lugging along a classic. This is how I read Swanns Way at the Mamaroneck Beach Club as a guest of Uncle Marty and Aunt Lee. It took many visits. Here I would like to thank them personally.

title: Success Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: I smile and sign autographs no matter what. Most fans dont seem to care much if we won or lost. They dont know if I had the game of my life or a complete shocker. They say, Great game! You were awesome! Sometimes they even tell me I was wonderful when I didnt play a single minute. I thank them whether I feel on top of the world or have a lump of disappointment in my throat.

title: Travel
description: Paul Bowles observed that an important difference between a tourist and a traveler is that the former accepts his own civilization without question; not so the traveler, who compares it with the others, and rejects those elements he finds not to his liking. This difference also separates writers about travels from travel writers. Is the voyaging writer telling us canny stories from a romping trip or using his peregrinations to relocate his place in the world? Sometimes its difficult to tell. D. H. Lawrence knocked off travel essays about places in which he had arrived only a few hours before, but he was writing about himself and his intuitions. Bowles, for his part, lived for years in Morocco but traveled through the desert with a suitcase filled with his favorite neckties. Do we read either man for profound and meticulously earned insights about Sardinia or the Sahara, or for their ability to convey something about themselves as they pass through those places? Most writers are passing through, and we expect no more of them. Its part of their charm, if they have any. And part of the sometimes dubious premise of travel writing itself.

title: Pop Music
description: All rock biographies/memoirs agree on one point. As Gregg Allman tells it in One Way Out, an exhaustive oral history of the Allman Brothers Band by Alan Paul, escaping the workaday lot of a shock-absorber washer-jammer in Detroit . . . is why I became a musician in the first place. Or as Joey Ramone sang: Its not my place in the 9-to-5 world.

title: Humor
description: Writing seriously about humor is a tricky proposition. If you approach the subject too analytically, you risk losing sight of what made it worth writing about in the first place. If you try to leaven your analysis with a little humor of your own, theres a good chance youll end up reminding your readers why making people laugh is best left to the people who do it for a living.

title: One Man, Two Wives and Many Accepted Forms of Violence in Pakistan
description: LONDON  The murder case of Farzana Parveen, it seemed, could hardly have turned more tragic or gruesome: a 25-year-old pregnant woman, bludgeoned to death with a brick by family members on a busy street, for having married the man she loved.

title: Shall We Dance?
description: All movies are musical, film being as reliant on rhythm and tempo as sonatas are. Only a few movies are musicals, though, and the fewness isnt going away. Live-action musicals are nearly as endangered a movie species as westerns. Whether you think those few are too many or nowhere near enough will go a long way toward determining your response to Richard Barrioss Dangerous Rhythm: Why Movie Musicals Matter. The subtitle indicates which side Barrios comes down on. The fact of his having written the exhaustively researched and exuberantly argued A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film (1995) should settle any doubts.

title: Street Life
description: The flneur, that feature of the 19th-century urban landscape, stood apart from the city as a wide-eyed wanderer. But when he had a camera in his hands, he became the archetypal street photographer, a curious observer who captured his environment in what Henri Cartier-Bresson called its "decisive moments: spontaneous, serendipitous, intuitive, singular. In Unfamiliar Streets: The Photographs of Richard Avedon, Charles Moore, Martha Rosler, and Philip-Lorca diCorcia, the art historian Katherine A. Bussard explores the genre of street photography, beginning with this dominant definition and then expanding it. The photographers she investigates, whose work here spans the 1940s through 2001, manipulate the viewers imagination of the city, or change the way viewers act within it. According to Bussard, accurately representing experiences of city streets involves addressing issues of gender, commerce, race, collectivity, class, dispossession, sexuality and spectacle. In other words, street photography isnt only the magic of capturing a well-composed slice of life; its the more complex task of recapitulating or intensifying the economic, class and gender tensions of the city street within an image. The image should galvanize the viewer or, ideally, alter street life as its lived simply by the fact of the image having been made.

title: Minnesota Nice
description: Some writers define themselves by contrasting their talents or sensibility with those of another writer. Well, Im no Joyce Carol Oates, theyll tell you, false modesty oozing from their pores like musk. I publish a book every eight years. Or, You wouldnt confuse me with Thomas Merton, theyll say, referring to the Trappist monk and mystic. Kneeling bags my nylons. The best of these self-conscious comparisons may come from James Thurber, who was once asked to review Salvador Dals autobiography. Comparing his own golden-hued Columbus, Ohio, upbringing with young Dals chiaroscuro of ermine capes and necrophilia, Thurber wrote, The naked truth about me is to the naked truth about Salvador Dal as an old ukulele in the attic is to a piano in a tree, and I mean a piano with breasts.

title: Appetites
description: Ruth Reichl is known for many things, among them her best-selling memoirs, including Tender at the Bone and Comfort Me With Apples, as well as her years of reviewing restaurants for both The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times, and as the editor in chief of the seemingly immortal Gourmet magazine  until it folded. With the arrival of Twitter, Reichl added another genre to her rsum: haiku-like paeans to breakfast in any weather: Sunny in Charlotte. Returned to rain. Gray New York morning. Big bowl of ginger strewn congee. Chiles. Soy. Scallion. So consoled. The next day, it was still raining, but once again food came to the rescue: Gray drizzle. Umbrellas up. Sidewalks sloppy. Rye bread, still warm. Herring: pungent, rich. Sour cream. Onions. Solace in the city.

title: Five-Card Studs
description: Art is the deliberate transformed by the accidental. If youre a writer, you brew a pot of coffee, adjust the lights, go over your notes and get started, though you know that something  a phone call, a memory, a random image  is likely to barge in and change everything. Instead of art, of course, you could say science, making gumbo and even romance: You show up at Veronicas apartment with your hair slicked back and a bouquet in your hand, and who answers the door? Betty.

title: Get Down
description: When I was growing up in Chicago, there was no rowdier time in our house than Friday night, when my mother, my three siblings and I stayed up to watch Red Hot and Blues on Channel 26, Chicagos first UHF station. Part advertisement and part dance spectacle, it was our chance to celebrate the end of the week, listen and dance to our favorite R & B songs and howl at the cheesy commercials delivered by pitchmen selling used cars and ugly furniture: Youll do well to see Dells  Dells Furniture. (Even hearing the voice was enough to send us all into fits of laughter.) Just as attractive as the music was the lineup of shabbily dressed kids from the West Side who gathered in front of the camera to dance  a great counterpart to us shabbily dressed kids from the South Side. The show was the highlight of our week.

title: Hit Man
description: Bert Berns the producer is the Phil Spector youve never heard of. Bert Berns the songwriter is the Leiber and Stoller youve never heard of. Bert Berns the label exec is the Jerry Wexler youve never heard of.

title: Dress-Up
description: Five years ago Ruth Bader Ginsburg, associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, flung open her closet to Brian Lamb, the founder of C-SPAN.

title: Captured Obsessions
description: Over the last 50 years, Mary Ellen Mark has photographed twins, clowns, patients in a mental hospital, Ku Klux Klan members and Liza Minnelli. She likes to look at people who are used to being looked at, and she uses her camera like Wonder Womans golden lasso  as a truth-telling device that peels performance from personality. In one of her most famous photographs, Tiny (1983), a Seattle street kid poses in her Halloween costume: a little black dress, little black gloves and a hat with a netted veil. Its the daintiness of Tinys dress combined with her defiance that gives the photograph its charge. Tough Tiny looks afraid.

title: Disillusion
description: According to the oft-repeated statistic, roughly half of all marriages in this country end in divorce  which makes The Divorce Papers, Susan Riegers epistolary first novel about one couples messy split, certainly relatable. But how many people want to relive the emotions of a marriages demise, from the initial shock to the ensuing despair, fury and vengeance?

title: Today in Small Business: The Cost of Paper Checks
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Letters From London
description: This book seems to have been written specifically for me. Which is not quite the same as saying it was written for you. There is a chance, of course, that you too lived in London in the 1980s while studying for a degree in English literature, in which case you will get every cultural and political reference it contains. Its possible you are actually English yourself. If that is so, you (like me) will laugh aloud at the understated humor while enjoying the nostalgic mentions of TV shows and sporting events of years gone by.

title: Altar Ego
description: Jen Doll is Emily Posts worst nightmare.

title: BNP Paribas Shares Fall on Fine Fears
description: Updated, 12:32 p.m. |

title: Journey by Rail
description: In an era of railway mediocrity, epitomized by Amtrak, its easy to forget that train travel was once a romantic adventure. Riding the rails to Boston in 1924, George Gershwin listened to the roar of the steam engine and the turn of the wheels and found the inspiration for Rhapsody in Blue, his hymn to urbanizing, Jazz Age America. It was on the train, with its steely rhythms, its rattle-ty bang, that is so often so stimulating to a composer, he told a biographer, describing the moment of creation. I frequently hear music in the very heart of the noise. W. C. Handy and other African-American musicians heard a similar sound on the Illinois Central, the Midwestern line that spirited them away from the Deep South on the Great Migration that began during World War I. They married the whistle and drone of the locomotive to the plaintive chants of sharecroppers and invented the city blues. Steve Goodman, a little-known composer, was inspired by a journey on the same line to write a dirge that became one of the anthems of the Vietnam War era  The City of New Orleans.

title: Not Just Laughs
description: Christopher Buckley begins his new collection, But Enough About You, with an essay about the perils of being known as a humorist, the fear that people brand him as trivial and believe that what he and his literary forebears do is easy. Well, only five paragraphs in and already wallowing in self-pity, he writes. We just cant get no respect.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 13
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Inside the List
description: Hemingway on the Stoop: Near the beginning of Sons of Wichita, his biography of the politically influential Koch brothers  its No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list  Daniel Schulman describes the conservative beliefs of the family patriarch, the industrialist Fred Koch. Father was paranoid about Communism, lets put it that way, his son David Koch once told New York magazine, in a quote Schulman cites. Freds views filtered down to at least one of his four sons: Charles, the second-oldest and now the chief executive of Koch Industries, spent most of a blind date in the early 1960s railing against the evils of Communism, according to the biography. (I ended up leaving early and walking home, his date says.) Charles also let his politics spill over into literary criticism. Schulman, a senior editor at Mother Jones, reports that when a family friend showed up at the Koch house in the 1960s with a copy of The Sun Also Rises, Charles eyed the book apprehensively and finally asked the visitor to leave it outside.

title: Snooping Around
description: The word spying now brings to mind boundless digital nets trawling the ether for millions of emails at a time, but Miles Adler-Hart, the young protagonist of Mona Simpsons sixth novel, practices snooping the old-school way. He plants a walkie-talkie in his parents bedroom. He eavesdrops on therapy sessions through a heating vent. He listens to phone conversations by carefully picking up a landline in the next room.

title: How Sandy Koufaxs Motel Helped Lead to Baseballs Big-Money Era
description: In 1962, the star Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Sandy Koufax invested in a West Hollywood motor inn, which was renamed Sandy Koufaxs Tropicana Motel. Down Santa Monica Boulevard from the famed Troubadour club, these 74 luxurious air-conditioned rooms  rented at popular prices  came to lodge some of the biggest musical acts of the period: Alice Cooper, Bob Marley, the Mamas and the Papas, Led Zeppelin, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison and the Doors. I dont know which made me more excited, said one guest, to be in Sandys motel or to be in a room right beside Sly Stone, from Sly and the Family Stone.

title: Quantum Teleportation
description: Researchers teleported quantum information between two distant atoms for the first time in 2009.

title: Trouble in Paradise
description: THE VACATIONERSBy Emma Straub  Riverhead, $26.95.

title: V.A. Chief Resigns in Face of Furor on Delayed Care
description: WASHINGTON  Eric Shinseki resigned as secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs on Friday, leaving behind a sprawling bureaucracy embroiled in scandal and burdened with a decades-old legacy of overwhelmed facilities and management failures that his successor must now confront.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE CIRCLE,  by Dave Eggers. (Vintage, $15.95.) Orwells Ministry of Truth is transformed into a powerful tech company in Eggerss dystopian satire. In a not-too-distant future, human existence flows through the Circle, a Google-like, Facebook-like behemoth that aspires to record and quantify everything that happens to everybody, everywhere in the world. Into this digital wonderland steps Mae Holland, an ambitious new hire eager to comply with the Circles demands for transparency.

title: Editors Choice
description: STRESS TEST: Reflections on Financial Crises,  by Timothy F. Geithner. (Crown, $35.) The former Treasury secretarys memoir offers an inside look at the governments response to the financial crisis.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: walking, diet drinks and food labels. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Dissonance in Classical Music
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance - the perceived stability or instability of two or more sounds.

title: Dissonance: Schoenberg
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Arnold Schoenberg.

title: Dissonance: Stravinsky, Bach and Mozart
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the work of Stravinsky, Bach and Mozart. The full, uninterrupted video is available here.

title: Dissonance: Sondheim
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Stephen Sondheim.

title: Dissonance: Schumann
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Robert Schumann.

title: Dissonance: Jazz
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in jazz.

title: Dissonance: Copland
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Aaron Copland.

title: Dissonance: Gershwin
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of George Gershwin.

title: Everything You Need to Know About Thomas Piketty vs. The Financial Times
description: Last Friday afternoon, The Financial Times released an expansive report accusing Thomas Piketty of doing shoddy analysis of data on wealth inequality for his best-selling book, Capital in the Twenty-First Century. In the six days since, economists and writers around the world have produced many thousands of words on the controversy. Outsiders have weighed in on the newspapers case, the newspaper responded, and Mr. Piketty, on Thursday, provided his first detailed defense.

title: $5 Million to Endow Yale Poetry Chair
description: Yale University has received a $5 million gift from Frederick Iseman, the founder and chief executive of CI Capital Partners, a private equity firm, to be used partly to endow the schools first chair in poetry and partly to extend a program that gives Yale students free access to the Metropolitan Operas HD broadcasts as well its Met on Demand archives, the university announced.

title: Shinseki Outlines Actions for V.A.
description: Eric Shinseki, the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, said he is ousting the leadership of the departments Phoenix hospital after revelations about delays in care.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Shakespeare in America
description: This week, James Shapiro talks about Shakespeare in America; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Bob Mankoff discusses How About Never  Is Never Good for You?; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Win a Trip Winner Talks with Nicholas Kristof
description: The 2014 Win-A-Trip Winner Nicole Sganga sits down with columnist Nicholas Kristof for a candid conversation about global development and their journey to Myanmar! Follow their reporting trip on the blog and through Nicholass columns.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Shakespeare in America
description: This week, James Shapiro and Bob Mankoff.

title: Q. and A. on the Syrian Presidential Election
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria will hold a presidential election on Tuesday amid a three-year conflict that has killed more than 160,000 people and driven nine million from their homes. The disputed vote is virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a third seven-year term. Opponents of the Assad administration have dismissed the election as a sham, given the governments violent crackdown on a movement for political rights that began in 2011 and morphed into civil war.

title: A Cruise to Catch Autumn Leaves
description: Car trips are a popular way to see the picturesque fall foliage in New England and the eastern coast of Canada, but this year, Crystal Cruises has a new sailing in the region that will give travelers a different way to take in the seasons colors.

title: At Disney Concert Hall, Hadid Picks Up on Gehrys Tune
description: It was an artistic collaboration delayed by some 25 years: The London architect Zaha Hadid responded as much to Frank Gehrys Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles as she did to Cos Fan Tutte when she designed her undulating all-white set for the Los Angeles Philharmonics performance of Mozarts opera this week (it closes on Saturday). We were responding to the context, to Franks design, Ms. Hadid said in a telephone interview from London.

title: Middle-Class Lament: Rent
description: Michael and Melanie Bellanger Boyer, transplanted Parisians who live in a snug one-bedroom in the West 90s, are members of what social scientists sometimes call the forgotten middle.

title: The Art of Setting the Senses on Edge
description: An often-quoted phrase from Miltons Comus, a masque about the god of festivities, describes a roar that emerged from the woods and filld the Air with barbarous dissonance.

title: Suicide Bomber Is Identified as a Florida Man
description: WASHINGTON  An American who blew himself up in an attack in Syria on Sunday has been identified by law enforcement officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, a man in his early 20s who grew up in Florida and traveled to Syria late last year.

title: Sam Greenlee, Writer, Producer, Government Agent, Dies at 83
description: Sam Greenlee, a novelist and poet best known for a low-budget 1973 movie made from his novel The Spook Who Sat by the Door, which envisioned a black power revolution led by a militant black ex-C.I.A. agent  it was pulled from theaters after a brief box office success  died on May 19 in Chicago. He was 83.

title: Obama Accepts Shinsekis Resignation
description: President Obama announced he has accepted the resignation from Eric Shinseki, the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department, following evidence of mismanagement at the agencys medical facilities.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Next Week on Retro Report
description: Revisiting the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster. Visit www.nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: An Artists Priorities Are Shaken From the Abstract to the Concrete
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  PHILIPPE DODARD, often called the Picasso of Haiti, was searching for vibrations.

title: Book Review Podcast: Shakespeare in America
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Noah Millman reviews Shakespeare in America, a new anthology from the Library of America, edited by James Shapiro. Mr. Millman writes:

title: Grilled Cheese for Grownups
description: Every so often even I am too busy or tired  or both  to cook. But Im also too busy or tired to go out. This usually happens when Ive been cooking all day, as Ive been doing a lot lately because Im not only testing recipes for this column but also preparing food for book-tour cooking demonstrations.

title: When a Young Spouse Becomes the Caregiver
description: For Ivonne Thompson, 36, pulling her husband from his wheelchair to bathe him is a way to find time for their marriage. It is the only intimacy we have left, she says.

title: Image of the Day: May 30
Sky-High Demand for Luxury
description: Up, up and up. That is the answer to the question I have been posing lately: Where is the luxury condominium market headed?

title: Douglas Adams Biography to Include Unseen Hitchhikers Guide Material
description: There are very few things that Douglas Adams did not touch on in his Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy novels, a peculiar blend of science fiction and comedy that began life as a BBC radio series and later had life on television and film as well. Apart from disquisitions on the destruction of Earth, as well as its creation (with special attention to fjords), space travel, alien life forms, depressive robots, celestial bureaucracy, animals that beg you to slice off and eat bits of them, the crucial role of mice and the universes loudest rock band, the book asks and answers (well, kind of) the Big Question: What is the meaning of life, the universe and everything?

title: Gallery | Dzine Offers an Artistic History of Boxing, From the Greeks to Pay-Per-View
description: The artist Carlos Roln, better known as Dzine, has long been a boxing fan, if not a practitioner. My father took me for boxing lessons when I was 13, he says. I was more scared then excited. I developed a hernia. The injury didnt dampen his passion, which has led him to produce Boxed: A Visual History and the Art of Boxing, an image-driven compendium of the sport, from the Grecian Olympiads to bare-knuckle fighting to todays megabucks stadium battles.

title: NYT Now: Shinseki Resigns As V.A. Chief
description: President Obama announced Eric Shinseki, the Department of Veteran Affairs secretary, has resigned amid a scandal.

title: Why Couldnt My Kids Clean the Kitchen? They Didnt Have To.
description: I thought we would be there by now.

title: In Slightly Less Wealthy Circles, Too, Interest Rises in Private Equity
description: AS a young lawyer in New York, Robert Rich sometimes bought stocks based on tips he received while playing squash at the Yale Club. Most of them did not do well, so eventually he chose to put his money into mutual funds and focus on his work.

title: Phil Jackson Gives Knicks Carmelo Anthony a Plan C
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With the embers still smoldering from his failed pursuit of Steve Kerr, Phil Jackson has managed to remain in the hunt for another elusive target: Carmelo Anthony.

title: The Evolving World of Gay Travel
description: In the 1970s gay tours took men rafting in the Grand Canyon and to Rio de Janeiro for Carnival. Gay hotels began opening in Key West, Fla. And destinations like Provincetown, Mass., were creating some of the first marketing to gay and lesbian travelers.

title: For Gay Destinations, Thinking Outside the Obvious
description: Despite the fact that a sea gull once pooped on me while I was relaxing on a Fire Island beach, I do understand the allure of the place, and that of other idyllic destinations like Provincetown, Mass., and Key West, Fla., which have long been known as gathering spots for gay and lesbian vacationers. Many who identify anywhere along the L.G.B.T. spectrum simply want to go somewhere that is packed with kindred spirits, to relax without having to worry about fitting in with a straight crowd  or, in some places, about the potential perils involved when you dont fit in. But of course a lot of people who enjoy travel, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity, want to continuously add new cities to their places Ive been list, so I asked a few gay travel experts to suggest a lesser-known or up-and-coming L.G.B.T. hot spot that we may overlook when making travel plans. Here are some of their suggestions.

title: Finding Comfort and Safety as a Gay Traveler
description: Nearly every same-sex couple has experienced that awkward moment on vacation. It usually comes at hotel check-in, when you find yourself on the receiving end of a quizzical or disapproving look as you explain that yes, you did intend to book just one bed for you and your friend.

title: Maya Angelou Exhibition Opens at Schomburg Center
description: The New York Public Library is celebrating the life and work of the poet Maya Angelou, who died on Wednesday at age 86, in a free exhibition, Phenomenal Woman, at the librarys Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

title: Celebrating Gay Pride All Over the Map
description: Ten years ago, my gay friends and I found the perfect spot for watching New Yorks gay pride parade. It was near the entrance of a building near Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, with an awning to keep out the sun and a doorman who laughed along with our catcalls to bouncy go-go boys.

title: V.A.s Acting Chief: West Point Graduate and Ex-Leader of U.S.O.
description: WASHINGTON  The man who is temporarily replacing Eric Shinseki as secretary of veterans affairs is a West Point graduate, a onetime banker and a former chief executive of the United Service Organizations (known to most Americans as the U.S.O.) who joined the Department of Veterans Affairs just three months ago.

title: Books to Blankets: Travel Tips for Parents
description: Traveling on a plane with 1-year-old twins would be nerve-racking for any parent. But it was all the more so for Lucas Grindley, the editorial director of Here Media, before he and his husband took their daughters on their first flight. A crying baby is not just a crying baby for a gay parent like him, he said; he feared it would be seen as a commentary on his ability to be a parent.

title: In Rwanda, Looking to Art to Soothe
description: Theres no way youll find it yourself, the artist Strong Karakire told me on the phone, when I asked for directions to his studio in Nyamirambo, a lively neighborhood in the Rwandan capital of Kigali where dirt roads climb the steep hills past modest dwellings. Just wait at the petrol station, and Ill come get you.

title: The Rock Halls Class of 2014, Or: The Revenge of Kiss
description: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss this years inductees and the challenges of creating a rock canon.

title: Rethinking the Traditional Retirement Community
description: WHEN Rikki Selby began shopping for a retirement home, the 66-year-old sought a community where she could make friends with people her own age. But Ms. Selby had no interest in the kind of sprawling Sun Belt development that offers thousands of houses to older people. In those places, everybody is old, and you dont see young faces in the supermarket, said Ms. Selby, who recently retired as a financial planner.

title: What the Beats Deal Says About Apple: It Loves Tastemakers
description: Theres one thing executives at Apple would like you to know about their decision to buy Beats Music: Apple really loves humans. It loves us in the general sense  the company believes were better than computers at deciding what kinds of music we like  and it loves the specific humans who run Beats, especially the companys founders, the music impresarios Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine.

title: Artifacts and History, Steeped in Brine
description: The white paint is peeling and the cement steps are chipped at the old public school that houses the City Island Nautical Museum. Inside its shipshape. Four Barbaras and a Jane are among the can-do volunteers who maintain the collection of deftly crafted tenders and canoes, photos of sea captains and yachtsmen, models of minesweepers and tools for sail-making and boatbuilding.

title: Dandelion: A Tenacious Beauty
description: The common dandelion is a reproductive superstar. Though it is hard to remain objective about a plant so familiar as a pesky weed, the little yellow flowers dotting lawns, parks, neglected window boxes or just about any place left unmown for a week have a certain untamed beauty.

title: Drug Saves Fertility for Women With Cancer
description: CHICAGO  A commonly used drug can help young women with breast cancer retain the ability to have babies, apparently protecting their ovaries from the damage caused by chemotherapy, researchers reported here on Friday.

title: Journalist-Turned-Spokesman Resigns as Daily Voice of the White House
description: WASHINGTON  Jay Carney, the journalist-turned-press-aide who jousted daily with his former colleagues over issues from the Benghazi terrorist attack to the glitch-ridden health care website, stepped down as the White House press secretary on Friday.

title: Japan Offers Support to Nations in Disputes With China
description: TOKYO  Saying that his nation will play a larger role in regional security, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said on Friday that his government would support Vietnam and other nations that have territorial disputes with China by providing patrol ships, training and military surveillance equipment.

title: Rajat Gupta Loses Bid to Avoid Prison During Appeal
description: Rajat K. Gupta, a former director at the Goldman Sachs Group who was convicted on insider trading charges, has lost a last-minute attempt to stay out of prison.

title: Taking a Spin: Follow the Map to the Senate
description: The Democrats have many challenges this November, not the least of which are low voter turnout and President Obamas mediocre approval ratings. But their biggest challenge, by far, is the map.

title: Love in Its Own Sweet Time
description: Colin David Sutton is just about as connected as one can get. He is the vice president for client strategy at the social media agency SocialCode, and a marketing marvel who can sell just about anything on whatever technological device is nearest him.

title: Politically, V.A. Scandal Cuts Both Ways
description: WASHINGTON  Eric Shinsekis resignation as head of the Department of Veterans Affairs was perhaps more welcome in the offices of worried congressional Democrats than in the suites of top Republicans who had pressed the scandal against President Obama.

title: Where Fresh Is in the Name
description: People once complained that there were no good seafood restaurants in Fairfield County. Not only has that changed, but with the arrival three months ago of F.I.S.H. Restaurant & Bar in downtown Stamford (where the restaurant Boca used to be), theres also a really good place that specializes in sparklingly fresh fish and shellfish.

title: What Shinseki Leaves Behind
description: White House Correspondent Michael D. Shear on the challenges awaiting Eric Shinsekis successor at the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: Asparagus Soup With Ricotta Crostini
description: Melissa Clark makes a light asparagus soup topped with tender asparagus tips, accompanied by toasted bread coated with creamy ricotta for dipping.

title: Times Minute | What Shinseki Leaves
description: In the Video

title: Wimpy Kid Author to Open Bookstore in Hometown
description: Jeff Kinney, author of the best-selling childrens series Diary of a Wimpy Kid, said Friday morning that he is opening a bookstore in his home town of Plainville, Mass.

title: Rock Relics With a Signature Swagger
description: After a recent dinner at a restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Andrew Savage, the 28-year-old guitarist and vocalist of Parquet Courts, reached into his pocket to check his text messages. The device he pulled out, a beat-up old clamshell model, seemed a pointed rejection of modernity, even among nonconformist New Yorkers.

title: A Pair of Dreams to Compare and Savor
description: This month, the two most poetic and endlessly rewatchable Shakespeare ballets are to be performed on two sides of Lincoln Center: George Balanchines two-act A Midsummer Nights Dream (1962) from New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater (opening on Tuesday) and Frederick Ashtons one-act The Dream (1964) from American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House (starting June 30). You might suppose this is to commemorate the 450th anniversary of Shakespeares birth this year, but no. The same juxtaposition happened in 2010 and 2012. Its just the happiest symptom of Lincoln Centers Ballet Madness each spring, whereby Americas two leading companies play on different sides of the same plaza.

title: Tips for Those Who Set Their Own Salaries
description: TAYLOR JOHNSON works as a graphic designer, Mary-Kay Demetriou as a marketing consultant and Debra Kling as a color consultant. And they all work as negotiators.

title: A Spoonful of Spring Asparagus, Green as Can Be
description: In my frenzy to eat enough asparagus every spring, I inevitably take the speedy route to dinner: steaming, sauting, broiling, roasting. The aim is to get the stalks from raw to cooked as quickly as possible so I can gobble them up.

title: All Paths Lead to Illumination
description: A young woman hangs sheer white linens on a clothesline. A refulgent angel descends from the heavens while shepherds tend their flocks by night. And an early motion-picture camera captures the fairyland allure of a worlds fair, slowly panning its illuminated buildings.

title: Popcast: The Rock Halls New Class and the Revenge of Kiss
description: The 29th annual induction ceremony for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame happened at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn mid-April; Jon Pareles was there to report on it for The Times, and the filmed version of the evening will be broadcast on HBO this weekend. The new class includes Nirvana, Peter Gabriel, Cat Stevens (now Yusuf Islam), Kiss, the E Street Band, Linda Ronstadt and Hall and Oates.

title: On Our Walls
description: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: Dolan Spraying Champagne? It Could Happen With the Rangers
description: In the 17 years since Cablevision took over at Madison Square Garden, James L. Dolan has been an owner without a championship, with no photo of him giddily holding aloft a gleaming trophy.

title: Big Ticket | A Duplex Above the Park for $48 Million
description: A duplex penthouse perched near the pinnacle of the coveted park-side House portion of 15 Central Park West, the twin-towered limestone condominium where resale residences are appreciating in value much like vintage wine, sold for $48 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: After the Guests Have Left
description: Love, romance, infidelity and commitment are only some of the themes that propel 112 Weddings, an HBO documentary in which 10 couples are asked what they expected of marriage and how they thought their partnerships turned out.

title: Just Like Taco Trucks, Art Takes to the Road
description: On a recent Saturday, Elise Graham and her 23-year-old son, Aaron, pulled a 12-foot van into a parking spot on West 14th Street in Greenwich Village, swung open the back doors, lowered the aluminum stairs, and welcomed visitors inside their mobile Rodi Gallery.

title: Rio Violence Spikes Ahead of World Cup
description: In the months before the World Cup, violence in Rio has spiked despite pacification tactics that have drawn criticism from some who live in the favelas.

title: Rio Grapples With Violence Against Police Officers as World Cup Nears
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Alda Rafael Castilho dreamed of being a psychologist, and joined the police force to pay for her studies. Her dream ended at age 27 when gunmen stormed the outpost where she was on duty in Complexo do Alemo, a sprawling patchwork of slums. A bullet pierced her abdomen, and she bled to death.

title: In a Surprise Move, Valeant Again Raises Its Bid for a Rival, Allergan
description: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | As a rule, deal makers try not to bid against themselves. But Valeant Pharmaceuticals, exasperated in its pursuit of fellow drug maker Allergan, showed little hesitation in doing just that.

title: Fine Legal Point Poses Challenge to Appraisal Rights
description: The hedge fund Merion Capital might have hit a roadblock in its multimillion-dollar appraisal proceedings involving the $1.6 billion buyout of Ancestry.com. And its a roadblock that just might slow the trend toward exercising appraisal rights.

title: A Historic Ship Sets Sail From the Mystic Seaport
description: Connecticuts Mystic Seaport is showing off maritime history  and making it  this summer.

title: Kim Kardashians Wedding Dress, Cara Delevingnes Bunny Caper and Alexander Wangs Fro-Yo
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Six Short Blocks With a Lot to Say
description: What do Sid Vicious, Bella Abzug, Auntie Mame, John and Yoko, and the widow of the mysteriously disappeared Judge Crater have in common?

title: Comics
description: Jaime Hernandezs Love Bunglers, Jesse Jacobss Safari Honeymoon and more.

title: Visuals
description: New books that have something to do with portraiture or self-portraiture include a collection of drawings by Kurt Vonnegut.

title: Not Yet a Star, Taylor Townsend Flashes Star Power
description: PARIS  You may or may not subscribe to Andy Murrays theory that the American teenager Taylor Townsend is heading for finer tennis moments.

title: Clinton Takes Responsibility for Benghazi
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her soon-to-be-published memoir, takes responsibility for the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, while pushing back against accusations that she tried to hinder a Republican-led investigation into the deadly assault.

title: A Summit Without Russia Needs a Drink to Match
description: The G7 summit that will start next Wednesday in Brussels was supposed to be a G8 summit and was supposed to be held in Sochi, Russia. So this weeks Upshot With a Twist replaces the Moscow Mule with a more characteristically Belgian cocktail for the relocated and reduced meeting.

title: Keeping Windows 8.1 Up to Date
description: Q. Is it true that the big Windows 8.1 update that came out this spring is now required in order to get future security updates for my PC?

title: Classic Cars Head to Greenwich
description: The town of Greenwich, Conn., seems proud that its annual Town Party has drawn some top talent during the four years its been held in Roger Sherman Baldwin Park, which overlooks the harbor. Paul Simon and James Taylor have performed in the past; last Saturday, it was Carlos Santana.

title: Scenes From the Dismal Inertia on Immigration
description: This week, implacable forces kept rollingon, and others, frozen in place, refused to budge:

title: Administration Lays Out Ways Groups Can Support Program for Minority Men
description: The Obama administration announced recommendations on Friday on how public and private entities can participate in a White House initiative meant to support minority men and boys, including a move to focus on summer jobs and recruit adults who can serve as mentors.

title: The Gun Report: May 30, 2014
description: Recent shootings involving children have rocked two American cities.

title: Sterling to Reap 15,900 Percent Return on Sale of Clippers
description: Whether he likes it or not, Donald Sterling is poised to sell the Los Angeles Clippers to Steve Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive. And, for $2 billion, whats not to like about it? Sterling bought the Clippers for $12.5 million in June 1981, according to some reports, and hell get a tidy 15,900 percent return over 33 years, an annualized rate of 16.6 percent. In fact, hes probably done even better than that, because of the distributions of profits during the years of ownership.

title: Weekend Reading: Finding the Best Way to Spend $2 Billion
description: How should billionaires spend their money? While the short answer is any way they want, the debate over inequality often focuses on the financial habits of the 1 percent  whether it be conspicuous consumption or charity.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Driven | 2015 Volvo V60 T5 Drive-E
description: Volvo returns to its wagon roots with style. This time, theres no looking backward.

title: A Strip Club in Manhattan Proves That Vice Is Hard to Kill
description: After night falls in the theater district, a burly bouncer takes his post in front of an unmarked red door, revealing nothing about the secret attraction that lurks behind him.

title: Many Shades of Sorcery
description: Jen Rosenblits a Natural dance  induces a kind of morning-after haziness, its images revisiting you in the hours after youve seen it like scenes from a fitful dream. None of it quite makes sense: Why is Justin Cabrillos wearing that Wheres Waldo costume? What are Effie Bowen and Addys Gonzalez doing with all of those microphones? What is the meaning of this monologue about colors?

title: Big Mac, Thin Wallet
description: IN recent years we have seen plenty of studies of the impact of fast food on our bodies. But what about our psychological health?

title: Smooth Hip-Hop, Sneering Punk and Muscular Folk
description: Iamsu!

title: Pulled in Two Directions
description: Ukraine is conspicuously absent from the Eurasian Economic Union, the eastern counterpart of the European Union formed this week by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his counterparts from Belarus and Kazakhstan.

title: Keep Handguns Away From Teenagers
description: In response to the Isla Vista rampage, legislators in California are introducing a bill that would let the police and private individuals ask a court for a restraining order to deny guns to those who pose a threat to themselves or others.

title: Works of Dvorak, via Budapest
description: Some of the finest performances in New York in recent years  from creative concert stagings of Mozart operas to Beethoven symphonies  have arrived courtesy of the vibrantly theatrical Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and his powerful Budapest Festival Orchestra. On the heels of a recent Dvorak-filled concert with James Levine and the Met Orchestra, Mr. Fischer offers two more immersions in that Czech composer, both at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Going, Going, Gone to Sleep
description: Im glad that another baseball season is once again blooming  gathering meaning and texture now as spring deepens  for all of the usual reasons: the crack of the bat, the smack of ball into leather and the heartening prospect of the unpredictable ramble from the optimism of spring, through the grueling summer, to the iron-hard realities of autumn.

title: Music Makers Invade an Island
description: Three years ago, at the inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival, the Atlanta rapper Big Boi played a set peppered with tunes by his former group, Outkast. Hell be back this year as part of a sprawling and well-monetized Outkast reunion tour.

title: 50 Cent Makes TV His Turf
description: A former crack dealer turned rapper who survived a shooting, a stabbing and run-ins with the law, Curtis Jackson  a.k.a. 50 Cent  might very well have inspired the leading character in Power, the Starz series of which he is an executive producer.

title: Small Comfort to a Young Queen
description: In 16th-century Europe, smaller was considered better  more beautiful, more precious  when it came to hand-illustrated books. A high value indeed must have been attached to a 2 -by-2-inch prayer book created around 1517 for Claude de France, the first wife of the King Franois I. The book, made on commission from a young queen at her coronation by an artist now anonymous, is the centerpiece of Miracles in Miniature: The Art of the Master of Claude de France at the Morgan Library & Museum.

title: Subtle Inspiration
description: Al-Latif is one of the many names of Allah; it means the Subtle One. That inspired the title of a new work by the choreographer Ronald K. Brown that is receiving its world premiere in the first of two Brown programs that are running Tuesday through June 8 at the Joyce Theater.

title: The Longtime Lure of Shiny Objects
description: Jewel thieves come in many varieties. Smash-and-grab thugs. The type of dapper gents favored by makers of heist films. But Doris Payne may be in a class by herself. She is a real-life thief, not a Hollywood creation, though Hollywood is interested in making a drama based on her life. For now, though, theres the documentary The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne, playing through June 10 at Film Forum.

title: A Private Equity Perennial That May Flourish
description: Henry Kravis, a co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is cultivating private equity perennials. Buyout shops like his are selling companies to each other at a breakneck pace. Its easy to be skeptical about these so-called secondaries. But K.K.R.s $1.6 billion acquisition of the landscaping company Brickman Group may turn out to be an example of how such deals can flourish.

title: Sisters Strumming in the Darkness
description: Its just another modern-day discovery story: two Swedish sisters, harmonizing since childhood in perfect twangy English, introduced to the rest of the world via YouTube thanks to their covers of indie ballads and Johnny Cash classics. Klara and Johanna Soderberg were 15 and 17 when that happened, in 2008, and since then, they have toured the globe with their own spare guitar-driven songs, impressing the likes of Jack White (who produced a single for them) and Conor Oberst (who included them on his latest album). The sisters, now 21 and 23, record as First Aid Kit; their third album, Stay Gold, a major-label debut that adds the Omaha Symphony Orchestra to their lovelorn country-folk, will be released June 10 on Columbia Records, with a sold-out show on June 11 at Webster Hall.

title: New Refugee Camp in Jordan Tries to Create a Community for Syrians
description: AL AZRAQ REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan  His face was bright red from the desert sun, and his sons eyes, blank with exhaustion, gazed into the distance. Bahjat Sheikh, 58, and his family had crossed the Jordanian border to safety after an arduous two-and-a-half-day journey, mostly on foot, from the central Syrian city of Hama.

title: Pan-Roasted Duck Shows Off a Cherry-Sweet Side
description: Classic French duck recipes, the kind Julia Child swooned for, are now considered old-fashioned, bringing to mind starched white napery and middle-aged waiters in black vests carving tableside.

title: Print Matters | An Erudite, Fashion-Forward Magazine About Black Gay Culture
description: In 2009, Khary Septh, Kyle Banks and Andr Verdun Jones founded the Brooklyn creative agency Pink Rooster Studio. But as they made work for clients such as Swarovski and LOral, they also found themselves longing for a project with which they could express the full flower of talent and ideas among gay black men from all cultural walks of life  fashion, art, performance, letters and politics. We wanted to see what the image of ourselves would look like if we controlled it, says Septh.

title: A Preview of Volvos Heart-Healthy Future
description: Like a New York City mayor tilting at supersized sodas, several automakers have tried to forcibly wean Americans off their big, bad-for-you V8s. Six-cylinder engines are also being downsized in favor of 4s.

title: A Swede Thats Not Square to Be Hip
description: Say Volvo, and what image springs to mind? A station wagon, right? And not just any wagon, but one as square and imperishable as a Saltine, and as much a staple of the suburbs.

title: Reviving the Coming-of-Age Movie
description: LOS ANGELES  Confident yet vulnerable, adorable yet wearing an unfortunate trench coat, John Cusack hoisted a boombox over his head in Say Anything and, as Peter Gabriels In Your Eyes reverberated through the trees, delivered a scene that defined a genre: the great 1980s-era coming-of-age movie.

title: 2015 Volvo V60
description: Volvos well-rounded V60 wagon returns for 2015 with a downsized engine and class-leading economy.

title: Parents on the Rebound and Looking for Love
description: Its as if someone threw down a challenge to cable outlets of a certain ilk: Interpret the theme Suddenly Without a Spouse in a made-for-television movie. Lifetime, the Hallmark Movie Channel and Up all unveil films this weekend that seem as if they were responding. One is trashy and stupid. One is weepy and harmless. And one is uplifting and rather good for its type.

title: Reading Genesis, the Jazz Piano Edition
description: And Scott Joplin begat Jelly Roll Morton, who begat James P. Johnson, who begat Fats Waller, who begat Earl Hines, and on and on. That is a rough sketch of the jazz piano genealogy described by the pianist Jon Weber in his fascinating and essential show From Joplin to Jarrett: 115 Years of Piano Jazz, at the Metropolitan Room on Thursday evening.

title: Bill Cunningham | Pack Mentality
description: The black leather bikers jacket is hellbent to conquer fashion.

title: New York Public Library Temporarily Closes Reading Room
description: The New York Public Librarys majestic Rose Main Reading Room, which is nearly two city blocks long and has hosted scholars, students and authors for more than a century, has temporarily been closed after a piece of plaster fell from the ceiling this week.

title: A Bridge Deal From the Goldman Pairs
description: At the Eastern States Regional, which was held last week in New York City, the winners of the main pair event on the first day, May 21, were Alison Wilson and Chris Willenken. They finished just over two boards ahead of Tori Dauphinot and Judi Radin, with Paul Bethe and David Moss third. (All are of New York City).

title: Jay Carney Resigns as Press Secretary
description: President Obama announced the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, was leaving his post, in a surprise appearance in the press briefing room on Friday.

title: Bill Cunningham | Pack Mentality
description: The black leather bikers jacket is hellbent to conquer fashion. It has already achieved major status for daytime. And this spring, it has zoomed into the evening, topping long dresses, delicate prints and lace. One woman wore one over her long gown. Another woman, above, had a printed jacket that matched her dress.

title: A Pianist Stands Out as a Leader by Fitting in With the Group
description: The pianist Jacob Sacks is what you might call an inner-workings musician, drawn to the subtler, deeper mechanics of harmony and form. Over the last dozen years, this has made him a superb ensemble player in the expressionist wing of modern jazz, someone who raises the bar for group cohesion without drawing much attention to himself.

title: Evening Hours | Generations in Harmony
description: Parent and child, young and not-so-young.

title: Why You Hate Work
description: Editors note: We hope youre not totally miserable at the office tomorrow, but if you are, heres one article from the archives that may explain why.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Week in Pictures for May 30
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes Memorial Day celebrations across the city, wind turbines on a Queens rooftop, and sand dunes on Fire Island.

title: A Cop? No, He Just Played One in Life
description: LOS ANGELES  As if grasping at wisps of a long-forgotten high, Luke Greenfield was trying to remember the first time he did it. Impersonate a police officer, that is.

title: Help Isnt What It Used to Be
description: The minions have dwindled. The choreographer Bill T. Jones said: Mick Jagger tells a story about going to visit James Brown in his dressing room once. James Brown had a valet. He would keep the valet standing next to him, holding Browns trousers and waiting to dress him, while Brown held a meeting. It was a show of power.

title: A Rom-Com Path Less Traveled
description: The film Obvious Child has a curious tag attached to its own marketing materials: abortion comedy.

title: An Art Tour of Salzburg in Sound
description: New music is thankfully a preoccupation of the New York Philharmonic under Alan Gilbert, but glamour isnt always part of the equation. The orchestras new-music series, Contact!, has spent most of its time in no-frills, functional halls like the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium; the basement space SubCulture; and Symphony Space, as oppressively shoeboxy as the much-maligned Avery Fisher Hall.

title: After Fighting Insider Trading Charges for 10 Years, a Fund Manager Is Cleared
description: Updated, 7:49 p.m. | Standing outside a Manhattan federal court on Friday, Nelson Obus put on his victory tie.

title: The Desert in Demand
description: It was Dinah Shore Weekend in Palm Springs  or the Dinah, as its known  five days of Sapphic revelry that every April draws some 15,000 women from around the country to this sun-washed city 90 miles southeast of Los Angeles. On Saturday evening, however, the hottest ticket in town may not have been the L Word Pool Party, but a relatively low-key cocktail reception hosted by the Palm Springs Art Museum to benefit its new Architecture and Design Center.

title: Introducing | Brooke Candy, Pops Next Superstar
description: To many citizens of the Internet, the rise of Brooke Candy, 24, will sound familiar. A former stripper, Candys image proliferated through likes and retweets when a 2012 music video she appeared in  Grimess Genesis  went viral. A sword-wielding Barbarella for the Tumblr generation, Candy, clad in cyberpunk princess body armor and neon pink braids  then her trademark look  postured and snarled with primal confidence. The mysterious Candy then revealed her true self several months later, when she uploaded the video to Das Me, an abrasive yet empowering hip-hop churner that introduced her as a brash, talented M.C.

title: Movie Review: A Million Ways
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews A Million Ways to Die in the West.

title: Movie Review: Maleficent
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Maleficent.

title: Movie Review: Night Moves
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Night Moves.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, South Sudan, Ukraine and India.

title: Slides From Europe
description: Presentation (pdf) at ECB research conference in Sintra, Portugal.

title: Friday Night Music: Sun King Edition
description: Indie rock and the palace at Versailles, which is the site of my current meeting, dont seem to mix. I could do this:

title: Chilean Miners Recruited to Inspire World Cup Squad
description: Even for a collection of unusually talented soccer stars, the task facing Chiles national team at next months World Cup is daunting: playing the two finalists from the last tournament, Spain and the Netherlands.

title: Hilaria Baldwin Holds Her Center
description: Even for a yogi, maintaining peace can be hard when youre married to New Yorks most popular enfant terrible.

title: Jesus Christ Superstar Tour Is Abruptly Canceled
description: A high-wattage and eclectically cast new North American touring production of Jesus Christ Superstar has been abruptly canceled, just over a week before what would have been its first performance.

title: Hard Luck Lloyd
description: 1967: I Blew a Wheel

title: How to Be a Good Motorist
description: I. Motoring

title: In Print and Bound for the Road
description: If a picture is worth a thousand words, what about a book of pictures? Four of the seven books reviewed here are mostly photographs. Others include a history of the Cord 810 and 812, a biography of the racecar driver Lloyd Ruby and a quirky motorists handbook from 1923. The topics range widely, yet with luck, readers will find something of interest, for themselves or as a Fathers Day gift.

title: Picture This
description: A selection of images from our latest round of automotive book reviews.

title: For Jefferson Mays: After the Show, the Stairs Await
description: At 10 p.m. on Thursday, a couple of dozen people were waiting outside the Walter Kerr Theater in Midtown for Jefferson Mays, an old-fashioned theater type who is a nominee for a Tony Award as best actor in the musical A Gentlemans Guide to Love and Murder.

title: Malcolm Gladwell Surprised to Become an Amazon Bargaining Chip
description: In the dispute between Amazon and Hachette, neither side is blinking.

title: A Japanese Buzz in the Bronx
description: The Yankees have three prominent Japanese players, led by Masahiro Tanaka, who is creating a stir in his first year in the majors. As a result, a large Japanese media contingent is often present.

title: Quantum Teleportation
description: Scientists reported that they were able to teleport quantum information reliably across a distance of about 10 feet.

title: Higher Scores on Crash Avoidance
description: New test results suggest that automakers are quickly improving the safety systems intended to keep a distracted driver from rear-ending another vehicle or colliding with an object ahead. The tests of 24 models were released Thursday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: Mapping Apps Follow the Crowd
description: Think of it as the hive approach to car navigation systems: One driver, like a worker bee, finds the quickest way from Point A to Point B and then shares that route with all the other drivers. Its the basic idea behind all crowdsourcing, the sharing of free user-generated content to create information like restaurant ratings and contractor recommendations.

title: Unappreciated Love, the Russian Variety
description: Regret haunts the memories of men whove outgrown their brash younger selves, but oh, what pretty pictures torment makes. A glossy, mirrored wall as dark as anthracite looms over the action in the Vakhtangov State Academic Theaters arrestingly beautiful Eugene Onegin, at City Center, and a cloud of white mist floats above the stage.

title: Collected Wisdom From This Years Crop of Fashion-Industry Graduation Speakers
description: Its that time of year again, when the worlds most successful people travel around the country to give university commencement speeches. This year, a handful of fashion-industry heavy-hitters joined in the tradition.From the shoe designer Christian Louboutins address to the student body at F.I.T. to the lecture given by Steven Kolb of the C.F.D.A. at Kendall College of Art and Design, the speeches of several design luminaries suggested that slow and steady, more often than not, wins the race. Here, some of their collected words of wisdom.

title: In Way Over His Head
description: The Twilight Zone meets media critique meets psychological portraiture in James Scruggss Deepest Man, a thought-provoking experiment at the 3LD Art & Technology Center. Given that the show comes from 3-Legged Dog  a company known for integrating performance, video and effects  it is unsurprising that the piece, loaded with abstraction and supernatural traces, is a visual marvel.

title: A Prime View of Sunset
description: Particularly dramatic and romantic at sunset, the view from the Half Moon restaurants many vantage points is inspiring. As one of my dining companions observed, there is something about sunset on water that makes one wax Hallmarky. The promenade deck is so close to the Hudson River that when the wind is up, guests might be refreshed by the spray from a crashing wave.

title: Goodbye, Steinbeck; All Hail, Shelley
description: LONDON  When government shapes a nations literary education, politics inevitably plays a role. That has come clear in the case of the influential and controversial British minister of education, Michael Gove, who was accused of jingoism this week for new syllabus requirements that have led to the removal of classic American works like To Kill a Mockingbird and The Crucible.

title: Blackbeard as a Geek: Plundering in High-Tech
description: There are absolutists who still believe that everything on the Internet should be free and see themselves as partisans, not parasites. Their motto might as well be intellectual property is theft.

title: Beauty Is in the Eye of Your Fellow Swine
description: Before conducting the staged production of H K Grubers anarchic opera Gloria  A Pig Tale that opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night, the second event of the 11-day NY Phil Biennial, Alan Gilbert told the audience that he had thought a lot about what to say to prepare people for the wild piece they were about to hear. But, he explained, he had decided to say nothing, other than to warn audience members that this opera might not sound like anything else they had ever heard.

title: Two New Books on Porsche and Muscle Cars
description: In this weeks Automobiles section, readers will find reviews of a selection of books that delve into topics including design, history, motor sports and vintage motoring advice. Choosing the books to be reviewed is always a hand-wringing task here, a pleasant chore of sorting through publishers offerings to provide a balance of interests and formats.

title: After Losing Time Inc. Business, Distributor Is to Close
description: The second-largest magazine wholesaler in the country, Source Interlink Distribution, which employs about 6,000 workers, will soon cease operations.

title: Lit Class Field Trip, Movie Star Edition
description: O.K., so one smart aleck asked James Franco to take off his shirt during the question-and-answer session that followed Wednesdays matinee of Of Mice and Men. At that point, the audience at the Longacre Theater was full of teenagers, a lot of them girls, and they were in unusual proximity to a full-fledged movie star.

title: Under Cover: Paolo Pellegrin on Photographing Srebrenica, 20 Years After the Genocide
description: The June 1 cover story by Scott Anderson about efforts to uncover mass graves in Srebrenica, Bosnia, is accompanied by a series of haunting photographs by Paolo Pellegrin, who has been documenting the process for the past three years. Some of his pictures capture the scale of the genocide; others examine in extreme close-up the people affected by the tragedy  the man searching for remains, the Dutch soldier with PTSD who cant seem to leave Bosnia. Pellegrin recently shared with me what it was like photographing the annual Srebrenica memorial ceremony and burial of the dead.

title: Boehner on Shinsekis Resignation
description: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, addressed the resignation of the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, at a press conference Friday.

title: Depression-Era Tunes and Those Dancing Feet
description: One of the songs in 42nd Street, the popular 1980 musical based on a famous 1933 movie, asks, What do you go for, Go see a show for?

title: In the Temple Dancers Story, 3 Important Russian Debuts
description: Three Russian artists made important first appearances on Wednesday and Thursday with American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. The vehicle was Natalia Makarovas production of La Bayadre, which all three had already danced in their native land. Though none of them were new to New York, most people in the audience were watching them for the first time.

title: Junta Sets Years Goals for Its Rule in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Thailands military junta tightened its control on Friday with a far-reaching plan to appoint an interim government, write a new constitution and carry out large-scale public works projects. The junta also disclosed for the first time how long it intended to remain in charge  at least into the second half of 2015.

title: Prison Program Turns Inmates Into Intellectuals
description: Otisville Correctional Facility is a medium-security state prison, 79 miles northwest of Manhattan, on the site of a former tuberculosis sanitarium  with an equalizing element of portent, near the town of Mount Hope. Many of its prisoners are serving life sentences; they are men whom time, as one guard put it has mellowed out. Nearby, but unrelated, is the Otisville federal prison, named by Forbes Magazine as one of Americas cushiest incarcerators. Observers have likened it to a college, which is not an analogy you would easily draw at the state prison, where inmates rely largely on encyclopedias for the retrieval of information, in volumes that look as if they were last current when the nation was debating the merits of Dan Quayle.

title: Two Covers, One Choice
description: Pamela Paul is editor of the Book Review.

title: Diet Issues: What Is the Path to Weight Loss?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Reaches Deal on Hurricane Sandy Aid
description: New Jersey has agreed to spend more federal disaster money to provide housing to people displaced by Hurricane Sandy and to make sure that the hardest-hit parts of the state get a proportional share of the money, according to a settlement reached on Friday.

title: Get to Know the CFDA Nominees
description: Heres a tip sheet on the designers up for Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, which will be held on June 2.

title: John Waters Brushes Up for the CFDA Spotlight
